site_title: Japan considering re-opening door to some foreigners: media
summary: Japan is considering re-opening its borders to travelers from selected countries with low coronavirus infections, including Thailand, Vietnam, Australia, and New Zealand. The government plans to allow business travelers from these countries to enter if they test negative for Covid-19 in two separate tests. Travelers' movements would be restricted to areas including their place of stay, company offices, and factories, with public transportation banned. This move aims to ease restrictions put in place earlier this year to control the outbreak, which has resulted in around 17,000 confirmed cases and 900 deaths in Japan.

site_title: Duterte is paying Filipinos to move from city to countryside
summary: Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte is launching a program called "Back to the Province" to encourage city-dwellers to move to the countryside. The program offers cash and goods to induce people to leave Manila, which is experiencing overcrowding and strain on services due to the coronavirus pandemic. The goal is to reduce urban migration and alter long-established patterns of labor mobility.

images.alt_text: The coronavirus pandemic is giving Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte a reason to reduce overcrowding in Manila, which in recent decades has swelled into one of the most heavily populated areas on Earth.

site_title: China's solar giants forced to cut prices as virus curbs demand
summary: Chinese solar manufacturers, such as LONGi Green Energy Technology Co and Tongwei Co, are cutting prices due to the coronavirus disrupting global solar projects and reducing demand. Component prices, like wafers and cells, have fallen 20% since the start of the year, with prices likely to drop further as new mega-factories add supply. This could lead to consolidation among smaller players, but cheaper prices may also spur demand for a solar boom when the global economy recovers.

site_title: Tear gas fired as clashes erupt outside White House: AFP
summary: Clashes erupted outside the White House on Sunday, with police firing tear gas to disperse protestors during the sixth night of nationwide demonstrations. The crowds, chanting and holding protest signs, were met with flash bang devices and tear gas. The demonstrations were sparked by racism, with the sixth night of protests marking a continuation of the nationwide unrest. The incident occurred outside President Donald Trump's official residence, with AFP reporters witnessing the violence.

site_title: Broker's take: DBS upgrades ComfortDelGro to 'buy' on potential recovery
summary: DBS Group Research upgraded ComfortDelGro Corporation to "buy" with a raised target price of S$1.68, citing potential recovery from the transport giant's removal from the MSCI Singapore index. The stock retreated 6.5% in the past week. Analyst Andy Sim sees an opportunity to accumulate the stock on weakness.

site_title: Panama will fine ships up to US$10,000 if they tamper with transponders
summary: Panama's Maritime Authority will fine ships up to US$10,000 for tampering with transponders, which are tracking systems used to monitor vessels. The decision aims to comply with international sanctions and protect the country's 8,000-registered shipping fleet. The authority will investigate vessels with non-reporting transponders and impose sanctions, including fines or de-flagging, if found to be tampering with the systems. This move follows guidelines issued by the US State Department to combat sanctions evasion and smuggling.

site_title: KiotViet talks about e-commerce retail in Vietnam and how Covid-19 has shaken up the scene
summary: KiotViet, a Vietnamese business solutions startup, discusses the e-commerce retail landscape in Vietnam post-COVID-19. The company claims to have 100,000 stores under its belt, with a target of 200,000 by 2022. The pandemic has shaken up the e-commerce scene in Vietnam, with retailers adapting to new trends and consumer behaviors. Despite the challenges, KiotViet remains optimistic about its growth prospects, with a Series A funding round led by Jungle Ventures and Traveloka in 2019.

site_title: All Singapore pump prices down after SPC's two-week standoff
summary: Singapore's pump prices have decreased after a two-week standoff between SPC and other operators, with all pumps now offering lower prices. Esso and Shell reduced rates by around three Singapore cents last Friday, prompting Caltex and Sinopec to follow suit. SPC's resistance to previous price increases has led to the downward adjustments, with its diesel and 98-octane petrol now priced lower than the others.

site_title: Saudi Arabia to inject 50b riyals into banking system
summary: Saudi Arabia plans to inject 50 billion riyals (S$18.75 billion) into its banking system to stabilize the economy amid the coronavirus pandemic and oil price drop. The move aims to boost credit facilities and support private sector employment, with the goal of helping banks restructure loans without additional fees. The program is part of a broader effort to manage the fiscal deficit, which is expected to widen to nearly 13% of GDP this year.

site_title: From SARs to COVID-19: Reflections on ASEAN's collective response to public health crises
summary: ASEAN's collective response to the COVID-19 pandemic has been criticized for being slow. International organizations, such as the World Health Organization, were also expected to act faster. However, it's unclear what specific actions they are expected to take, as they can only offer advice and protocols. The lack of hard law obligations and humanitarian compacts limits their ability to provide tangible support. This highlights the challenges of relying on international organizations for public health crises.

site_title: South Korea's May factory activity contracts at fastest rate since 2009: PMI
summary: South Korea's manufacturing activity shrank at the fastest rate since 2009 in May, with the IHS Markit PMI falling to 41.3, the lowest since January 2009. The sector's output and new orders declined at rates not seen since the global financial crisis, with employment shrinking for a 13th straight month. The country's central bank cut interest rates to a record low and downgraded its 2020 economic projection to a 0.2% decline, amid a global recession and slow recovery.

site_title: Hot stock: Rex shares up 17.4% after deal completion for 2 Norwegian Sea drilling licences
summary: Rex International shares rose 17.4% on Monday after completing a farm-in deal for a 15% stake in two Norwegian Sea drilling licences. The company's subsidiary, Lime Petroleum AS, now holds a 15% interest in each licence. The deal follows a regulatory update, where Lime Petroleum AS acquired the stake from INEOS E&P Norge AS.

site_title: UK ex-foreign ministers call for G-7 Hong Kong monitor group
summary: Seven former British foreign ministers have urged Prime Minister Boris Johnson to push G-7 allies to establish an international monitoring group for Hong Kong, amid China's tightening control over the city. The call comes after Beijing plans to impose a national security law to combat "terrorism" and "separatism" following last year's pro-democracy protests. The proposed monitoring group would help address concerns over Beijing's increasing influence in Hong Kong.

site_title: E-scooter startup Beam bags US$26m in Sequoia-led Series A round
summary: Beam, an e-scooter sharing startup, has secured US$26 million in Series A funding led by Sequoia India and Hana Ventures. The funds will be used to expand its fleet in South Korea, Australia, Malaysia, New Zealand, and Taiwan, as well as accelerate the rollout of its new third-generation e-scooter, the Beam Saturn. The startup plans to introduce new features to keep its e-scooters safe for pedestrians when parked, minimizing vehicle losses. Beam's CEO expressed gratitude for investors' support, citing the company's innovative technology and focus on safety as key factors.

images.alt_text: E-scooter sharing startup Beam has clinched US$26 million in Series A funding led by Sequoia India and South Korea's Hana Ventures.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close higher on virus hopes
summary: Tokyo stocks closed higher on Monday as the Japanese capital lifted restrictions on retail stores and other facilities, boosting expectations for the economy to resume. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index advanced 0.84% to 22,062.39, while the Topix index rose 0.32%. The easing of restrictions, which includes department stores, theatres, and gyms, was seen as a positive sign for businesses. Blue-chip exporters such as Nintendo and SoftBank Group also gained, while Toyota declined. The move was seen as a hopeful sign for the Japanese economy.

site_title: Covid-fuelled cuts to luxury ad spending worsen magazines' plight
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has significantly impacted the advertising industry, particularly luxury brands, which have slashed their ad budgets by 30-80% for magazines and newspapers. With boutiques reopening, high-end brands are shifting their focus to digital marketing, potentially hastening a shift away from traditional print media. This decline in advertising revenue has worsened the financial struggles of magazines, which were already facing declining advertising spending. The pandemic's impact on luxury ad spending could accelerate the shift to digital marketing, further threatening the survival of print publications.

images.alt_text: The pandemic could hasten a shift to digital marketing by one of the last sectors to devote significant ad spending to newspapers and magazines.

site_title: Apple reopening flagship Tokyo stores as Japan eases restriction
summary: Apple is reopening its flagship Tokyo stores in Japan, marking its return to physical retail after the coronavirus outbreak forced restrictions. All 10 stores will be open by midweek, following the tentative reopening of two stores last week. Japan's easing of restrictions has led to the reopening of other businesses, including gyms and cinemas. Apple stores in Japan will require temperature checks, social distancing, and mask use, similar to local retailers. This is Apple's latest move in reopening stores globally, following reopenings in Australia, Germany, and the US.

site_title: Hong Kong Exchange plans suite of new exchange-traded products
summary: Hong Kong Exchange & Clearing (HKEX) is planning to introduce a suite of new exchange-traded products (ETPs), including leveraged and inverse products tracking mainland China A-share indices, fixed income ETFs, sectoral and thematic ETFs, and ESG-focused ETFs. The move aims to increase innovation and diversification in the US$38 billion market, following the tightening of trading spreads and enhancement of liquidity. HKEX head of exchange-traded products, Brian Roberts, sees the introduction of these products as a response to growing investor interest in fixed income ETFs and as a way to tap into the increasing demand for ESG investing.

site_title: Japan's May factory activity sinks as pandemic lockdowns hit demand: PMI
summary: Japan's factory activity declined at its fastest pace since 2009 in May, with a PMI of 38.4, down from 41.9 in March, according to a private sector survey. The decline is attributed to the demand blow from the coronavirus pandemic. Production volumes fell at a faster rate in May than in April, with economists warning of a prolonged economic slowdown.

site_title: Rex unit completes deal for 15% stake in 2 Norwegian Sea drilling licences
summary: Rex International's subsidiary Lime Petroleum AS has completed a farm-in deal for a 15% stake in two Norwegian Sea drilling licences, PL937 and PL937B, operated by INEOS E&P Norge AS. The deal, effective from January 1, 2020, marks Lime's second farm-in in the Norwegian Sea, following a 30% stake acquisition in 2019. The deal resulted in a 9.7% increase in Rex International's shares, trading at 17 Singapore cents.

site_title: Singapore shares rise at Monday's open, tracking US gains; STI up 0.4%
summary: Singapore stocks opened higher on Monday, tracking US gains, with the Straits Times Index (STI) rising 0.4% to 2,520.06. Gainers outnumbered losers 98 to 67, with 144.9 million securities changing hands. Sembcorp Industries led the gains with a 1.5% increase. The rally comes ahead of GDP data, which may influence market sentiment.

site_title: Oil prices slip as wary traders eye upcoming Opec+ meeting
summary: Oil prices dropped 1% on Monday as traders hedged bets ahead of an Opec+ meeting to discuss extending record production cuts. Brent crude fell to $37.50 a barrel and West Texas Intermediate crude futures fell to $35.17 a barrel. The price falls come after Opec crude production reached a 20-year low and demand is expected to recover as countries exit coronavirus lockdowns. Analysts expect a cautious pullback in prices, but a three-month extension could push prices to $40 a barrel.

site_title: Coronavirus turns a Spanish sea delicacy back into daily fare
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has led to a surge in demand for Spanish sea delicacies, particularly prawns, as restaurants closed and consumers turned to more affordable options. Wholesale prices for prawns plummeted from around €100/kg to €36/kg, making them accessible to a broader market. Fishermen are now selling their catch to fishmongers, who are supplying a wider range of customers, including those who cannot afford the luxury market. With Spain's restaurants set to reopen, the prawn market may return to its premium prices, but for now, the reduced prices have brought a welcome boost to the local fishing industry.

site_title: New fronts for mediation as preferred form of dispute resolution amid Covid-19
summary: Singapore's International Mediation Centre has introduced a new protocol, including online mediation sessions, amid the Covid-19 pandemic. The move aims to boost business confidence in the changed climate. The centre's expansion follows a successful mediation session in Seoul several years ago, where a mediator used a teapot to ease tension between an American and Korean party. The new protocol is seen as a response to the increasing need for alternative dispute resolution methods, with online sessions providing greater flexibility and accessibility.

site_title: Australian mall giant Vicinity to raise A$1.4b in virus cash dash
summary: Vicinity Centres, Australia's second-largest shopping mall operator, is raising A$1.4 billion in capital to respond to the uncertainty caused by the COVID-19 outbreak. The company cancelled its dividend and plans to ask corporate investors for A$1.20 billion and retail shareholders for A$200 million to ensure flexibility. This move comes after withdrawing profit guidance due to the virus's impact on the retail sector, which has infected millions worldwide and prompted governments to impose restrictions.

site_title: Australia's stalled migrant boom derails golden economic run
summary: Australia's economic growth, driven by immigration, has stalled due to the global coronavirus pandemic. The country's borders were closed early, leading to a halt in mass immigration, a key source of consumer demand, labor, and growth. This halt has resulted in Australia's first recession since the early 1990s. The country's economy, valued at A$2 trillion, is facing a significant economic downturn.

site_title: Delta, union working to avoid furloughs of 2,300 pilots
summary: Delta Air Lines and its pilots union are working to avoid furloughs of 2,300 pilots due to a reshuffling process to match staffing to summer 2021 flying. The airline has identified 7,000 pilots for reassignment, while 2,327 remain unassigned. Delta aims to shift pilots to different locations or aircraft types to minimize involuntary furloughs, according to the Air Line Pilots Association. The union and airline are working together to find alternative solutions to address the staffing imbalance caused by the COVID-19 pandemic.

images.alt_text: Delta Air Lines Inc and its pilots union said on Sunday they are working to avoid furloughs of roughly 2,300 pilots following a reshuffling process meant to match staffing to summer 2021 flying.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei index edges up at open
summary: Tokyo's Nikkei 225 index rose 0.10% to 21,900.54 at open on Monday, amid investor uncertainty following a mixed US close. The broader Topix index fell 0.05%. No specific reason was cited for the Tokyo market's movement.

site_title: UK government preparing stimulus package for July: FT
summary: The UK government is preparing a stimulus package in July to combat the recession caused by the coronavirus pandemic. Chancellor Rishi Sunak is working on proposals to invest in training programs, infrastructure, and technology firms, with a major speech planned for June to encourage people to return to work. Officials confirmed plans for a "fiscal event" in July, although Sunak refused to confirm an emergency budget. This move aims to lessen the depth of the recession and support the struggling economy.

images.alt_text: The UK government is preparing to unveil an economic stimulus package in July as it steps up attempts to lessen the depth of the recession caused by the coronavirus pandemic, the Financial Times (FT) reported, citing unidentified government officials.

site_title: Asia: Markets rally on virus hopes, Trump's Hong Kong action
summary: Asia markets rallied on Monday as investors breathed a sigh of relief after US President Donald Trump fell short of imposing strict measures against China. Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index jumped over 3% after Trump announced stripping several of the city's special privileges and bar some Chinese students from US universities. However, violent US protests and concerns over the potential spike in COVID-19 infections weighed on the mood. The gradual lifting of lockdowns and easing of virus restrictions also contributed to the rally.

site_title: Netease aims to raise US$2-3b in Hong Kong listing
summary: Netease Inc, a Chinese online gaming company, plans to raise between $2 billion and $3 billion in a Hong Kong secondary listing, one of the largest equity deals this year. The move comes amid rising tensions between the US and China, which have led Washington to question Chinese companies' ability to list in New York. The offering will run from Monday to the end of the week, with institutional and retail investors participating.

site_title: Keppel's Floatel associate to conduct independent review of business plan
summary: Keppel Corporation announced that its associate company Floatel International will conduct an independent review of its business plan, potentially updating assumptions used in vessel impairment assessments. The move follows Prosafe's US$810.5 million impairment, resulting from reassessed market outlook and assumptions. Floatel's assumptions differ significantly from Prosafe's, leading to a US$30.3 million impairment. The review may address potential discrepancies and ensure the accuracy of Floatel's financial assessments.

site_title: Chinese factories humming doesn't mean everyone is buying
summary: China's factories are experiencing a rebound in production after the coronavirus lockdown, but executives are concerned that demand at home and abroad remains weak. Orders are 40-50% lower than last year, and inventories have risen, leading to fears of deflationary pressures and worsening trade tensions. Manufacturers are shifting focus to the domestic market, but retail sales and consumer spending remain sluggish. Economists warn that sustained overproduction could lead to job losses and drag on China's growth, highlighting the need for a strong global demand to support the country's industrial sector.

site_title: Retailers already hit by coronavirus board up as US protests rage
summary: Retailers in the US, already affected by the coronavirus pandemic, shut stores amid violent protests and looting in cities like New York and Chicago following the death of George Floyd. Retailers such as Target, Nordstrom, and Apple closed or limited hours at over 200 stores, with some boarding up their locations for safety. The closures may have a significant impact on investor psychology and the markets, according to analysts, as US retail sales continue to decline due to the pandemic.

images.alt_text: Retail giant Target Corp said on Sunday it shuttered stores across the United States as retailers already reeling from closures because of the coronavirus pandemic shut outlets amid protests that included looting in many US cities.

site_title: Australia house prices fall as shutdowns hit property market
summary: Australian home prices fell 0.5% in May, the first decline since June 2019, as the impact of coronavirus shutdowns on the economy continues. Property values dropped in state and territory capitals, with Melbourne and Perth experiencing the largest declines. Experts warn that the easing of government stimulus packages will test the housing market, potentially leading to additional downward pressure on values if economic conditions don't improve by the end of the year.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares open with big gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks surged 2.52% at the start of trade Monday after US President Donald Trump stopped short of imposing sanctions on China over its plans for a security law in the city. The Hang Seng Index rose 578.44 points to 23,539.91, while China's Shanghai Composite Index climbed 0.69% and the Shenzhen Composite Index gained 0.74%. The rally was seen as a relief for investors, who had been bracing for potential sanctions.

site_title: Money FM podcast: Turning used cooking oil into biofuel
summary: The Breakfast Huddle podcast on Money FM 89.3 discussed turning used cooking oil into biofuel with Allan Lim, founder and CEO of Alpha Biofuels. Lim shared that his company is working on a commercial farm site in Singapore to produce biofuel from used cooking oil, ensuring food security and reducing waste. This innovative approach aims to utilize a common waste product, promoting sustainability and reducing reliance on fossil fuels.

site_title: German ministry proposes 5b euro car bonus scheme: sources
summary: Germany's Ministry of Economics proposes a 5 billion euro car buyer bonus scheme to boost car sales, part of an impending 80 billion euro stimulus package. The scheme would offer purchase premiums of up to 2,500 euros for electric and conventional cars, expiring at the end of the year. The plan faces criticism from policymakers and industry groups, who argue that it should prioritize climate change policies over supporting a single industry. The stimulus package, expected to be presented by the co-governing parties, aims to address the German auto sector's slump in sales amid the coronavirus pandemic.

site_title: S Korea's Celltrion aims to start in-human COVID-19 drug trial in July
summary: South Korea's Celltrion Inc. is set to start in-human COVID-19 clinical trials in late July, following promising animal testing results that showed a 100-fold reduction in viral load and improved recovery from symptoms. The treatment, which targets runny nose, cough, and body aches, has been shown to clear lung inflammation within six days. Celltrion aims to produce the therapeutic antibody treatment on a large scale if the trials are successful, and is considering conducting the trials in South Korea or abroad.

site_title: Heeton proposes to cut FY2019 final dividend to 0.3 S cent
summary: Property developer Heeton Holdings is proposing to cut its FY2019 final dividend to 0.3 Singapore cent per share from 0.45 cent due to financial uncertainty amid the Covid-19 pandemic, which has impacted its heavily invested travel and real estate industries. The reduced dividend will be tabled at its annual general meeting on June 19 via live webcast or audio-only teleconferencing.

site_title: Australia eases social distancing restrictions as economic recovery efforts intensify
summary: Australia has eased social distancing restrictions, allowing restaurants to host 50 seated patrons and public attractions to reopen, as the country aims to revive its ailing economy. The move follows a three-step plan to remove curbs by July, with new infections largely under control. This is the latest development in Australia's efforts to recover from the COVID-19 pandemic, which has recorded about 7,200 cases and 103 deaths.

site_title: Saudi FX reserves down sharply in April to back wealth fund investments
summary: Saudi Arabia's foreign reserves dropped to $443.75 billion in April, a decline of $25 billion from March, due to investments by the Public Investment Fund (PIF) abroad. The kingdom's economy is struggling with historic oil price lows and pandemic measures affecting its non-oil sector. To shore up its finances, the government transferred $40 billion from foreign reserves to PIF in April, marking a second consecutive month of sharp declines. The depletion of reserves coincides with austerity measures, including a VAT increase and suspension of a cost of living allowance.

site_title: Two Clearbridge Health units sued by unit's shareholder for 1.06 trillion rupiah
summary: Two Clearbridge Health units, Clearbridge Medical Asia and Tirta Medika Jaya (TMJ), are being sued by TMJ shareholder Tirta Medika Nusantara for 1.06 trillion rupiah (S$102 million) due to a notarial deed. The lawsuit was filed in the North Jakarta District Court on May 6, with a hearing scheduled for November 11. Clearbridge Health maintains that the notarial deed is in accordance with Indonesian law and has not received a formal letter of demand or summons. The lawsuit's basis and claim details remain unclear.

site_title: UK's Capco buys Hong Kong tycoon's stake in Shaftesbury for £436m
summary: British property manager Capital & Counties Properties has purchased Hong Kong tycoon Samuel Tak Lee's 26.3% stake in central London rival Shaftesbury for £436 million, a 13.9% discount from the closing share price. The deal is part of a larger trend of major British property deals halting due to the coronavirus pandemic.

site_title: Lufthansa bailout to trigger onslaught from low-cost rivals
summary: Deutsche Lufthansa AG secured a 9 billion-euro bailout, but must surrender airport slots to appease regulators. This move sparks heightened conflict with low-cost rivals, such as Ryanair and Wizz Air, who argue the market should dictate survival. The coronavirus crisis has intensified a long-standing rivalry between traditional carriers and discounters, with the German group and network carriers facing a battle to repel no-frills operators that have gained strength during the crisis.

site_title: Hot stock: First Reit units sink 11% after news of Lippo Karawaci rental restructuring
summary: First Reit's unit price dropped 11.3% or 10 cents to 78.5 cents after its former parent company Lippo Karawaci announced plans to restructure its leases due to the Covid-19 pandemic's impact on rental subsidies. The Singapore Exchange queried First Reit about the unusual price movements, and the company clarified that Lippo Karawaci has not approached it about the proposed restructuring. As a result, First Reit's units were down 17 cents or 19.2% to 71.5 cents.

site_title: Artist Christo, known for wrapping exteriors of landmarks, dies at 84
summary: Artist Christo, known for wrapping landmarks, has died at 84 due to natural causes. Born Christo Yavacheff, he escaped from Bulgaria in 1957 and later met his wife and art partner Jeanne-Claude in Paris. Together, they created iconic installations like "The Gates" in Central Park and wrapping the Reichstag in Berlin. Christo's latest project, "L'Arc de Triomphe, Wrapped," was set to be completed in 2021, following his death in 2020. Christo lived his life to the fullest, realizing his ambitious dreams, according to his office.

site_title: Hong Kong reports first local Covid-19 cases in 2 weeks
summary: Hong Kong reported its first local Covid-19 cases in over two weeks, with two confirmed cases and no travel history. The Centre for Health Protection is investigating and contact tracing is underway. The cases involve a 34-year-old woman and a 56-year-old man, both of whom work in a warehouse in Kwai Chung district where a co-worker tested positive a month ago. About 25 staff and three medical staff are being quarantined for 14 days. This marks a significant increase in cases, fuelling concerns over the spread of the virus in the region.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong has confirmed its first locally transmitted coronavirus cases in more than two weeks, fuelling concerns over its spread as restrictions on movement are relaxed.

site_title: Australia: Shares end 1% higher on firm recovery bets; miners rally
summary: Australian shares rose 1.1% to 5,819.20, driven by optimism over economic recovery and a surge in commodity prices. Mining stocks rallied amid a surge in iron ore and copper prices, while unease over US unrest boosted gold prices. The S&P/ASX 200 has soared 30% since its low in March. Markets await the Reserve Bank of Australia's policy meeting on Tuesday, expecting no major surprises.

site_title: Malaysia's Petronas says 'optimising production volume' on low LNG prices
summary: Malaysia's state-owned Petronas is optimising its production volume due to low liquefied natural gas (LNG) prices and reduced demand caused by the coronavirus outbreak. Monthly LNG export volumes from Malaysia are set to drop to their lowest since mid-2018, with Petronas cutting its shipments of spot cargoes. This move is aimed at adapting to the current market conditions and ensuring the company's financial sustainability.

site_title: Mukesh Ambani sets high bar for Jio
summary: Indian telecom operator Jio Platforms, led by billionaire Mukesh Ambani, has secured a $10 billion investment from a list of prominent investors, including Facebook, Microsoft, and Abu Dhabi's Mubadala. Jio has grown rapidly, signing up 388 million mobile subscribers and dominating the market with its low prices and wide range of digital services. The company's valuation of up to $68 billion is 23 times its Ebitda, making it one of the most valuable startups in the world. However, analysts question whether Jio's growth is sustainable and whether it can compete with established players like Airtel and China Mobile.

images.alt_text: There can be little doubt that Mukesh Ambani is ready to dial it up. The Indian tycoon's telecom operator, Jio Platforms, has been valued like a tech startup, at US$68 billion, by a growing list of A-list investors.

site_title: Stocks to watch: First Reit, Keppel, mm2 Asia, Ascott Residence Trust, ThaiBev
summary: Key developments in Singapore stocks include: First Reit to discuss lease restructuring with Indonesian giant Lippo Karawaci, Keppel Corp reviewing Floatel's business plan, mm2 Asia's net profit declines 81.5% due to Covid-19, Ascott Residence Trust not redeeming its perpetual issue, and ThaiBev dismissing reports of a buyer for its Vietnam businesses.

site_title: Samsung to add new memory chip line as COVID-19 boosts demand
summary: Samsung Electronics Co Ltd is constructing a new domestic production line for NAND flash memory chips, targeting mass production in the second half of 2021. The move is driven by increased demand for personal computers and servers due to the COVID-19 pandemic, with analysts estimating an investment of 7-8 trillion won. The added capacity will help meet demand for 5G smartphones and other devices, despite recent 5G network delays. This expansion is part of Samsung's efforts to boost chip production and meet growing demand in the global market.

site_title: South Korea's exports slump again as pandemic drags on
summary: South Korea's exports declined 24% in May, the second double-digit drop this year, due to the ongoing coronavirus pandemic. Chip exports rose 7.1%, but the overall decline is a sign of the pandemic's growing toll on global trade. The government is preparing its third supplementary budget and the central bank has cut interest rates to ease the economic contraction, forecasted to be the first since the Asian financial crisis. The outlook for South Korea's exports depends on China, its largest trade partner, and recovery in the global economy.

images.alt_text: South Korea's exports posted another double-digit decline in May in a sign of continuing pain from the coronavirus pandemic.

site_title: Europe: London, Paris stocks rally amid Frankfurt holiday
summary: European stocks surged Monday, with London's FTSE 100 rising 1.4% to 6,159.72 points and Paris's CAC 40 index gaining 1.5% to 4,766.95 points. The Frankfurt market remained closed due to a public holiday. Asian markets had driven the gains, with the rally continuing despite US-EU trade tensions and ongoing tariff threats.

site_title: IndoAgri directors who recommended lowball privatisation offer to seek re-election at AGM
summary: IndoAgri directors who recommended a lowball privatization offer to minority investors will seek re-election at the upcoming annual general meeting. The directors, who were advised by an independent financial advisor, have faced criticism for undervaluing the company. Shares have performed well since minority investors rebuffed the offer, and any new offer will need to comply with stricter SGX rules. The directors' re-election bids come as the parent group buys into the market, potentially changing the dynamics of the company's privatization efforts.

site_title: Sotheby's to stream live auctions in June
summary: Sotheby's is set to stream live auctions in June, with its first sale of contemporary art taking place on June 29. The auction will feature Francis Bacon's 1981 oil painting "Triptych Inspired by the Oresteia of Aeschylus," estimated to sell for at least $60 million. The event will be livestreamed in high-definition, allowing bidders to participate by phone or online, with Oliver Barker conducting the auction from London and specialists in New York, London, and Hong Kong taking bids.

site_title: China's May factory activity returns to growth but demand remains weak: Caixin PMI
summary: China's factory activity returned to growth in May, with the Caixin/Markit Manufacturing Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) rising to 50.7 from 49.4 in April. The improvement was driven by a sharp increase in output and steadying supply chains, but demand remained weak due to subdued export orders and cautious consumer spending amid global lockdowns. Factories continued to cut payrolls, but the pace eased, and the government announced additional fiscal measures to bolster the economy, aiming to create over nine million urban jobs this year.

images.alt_text: China's factory activity unexpectedly returned to growth in May as strict measures to contain the coronavirus outbreak were eased, but the improvement was marginal as export orders continued to shrink, a private business survey showed on Monday.

site_title: OCBC survey finds Singaporeans and PRs facing financial stress over Covid-19
summary: A recent OCBC survey of 1,000 Singaporeans and permanent residents found that nearly half have suffered a drop in income due to wage cuts or job loss, and nearly half are worried about losing their jobs despite government support. The survey also found that 55% of respondents have reduced their savings, with 16% intending to reduce their investments by more than 20%. However, some are taking steps to future-proof themselves, with 53% attending online courses and 61% working harder to keep their jobs.

site_title: OCBC to trim salary credit bonus interest on 360 account from July 1
summary: OCBC will reduce the salary credit bonus interest on its OCBC 360 savings account from July 1. For balances up to S$35,000, the interest rate will be revised to 0.6% (down from 1.2%), and for balances between S$35,000 and S$70,000, the interest rate will remain at 1.2%. The bank will also stop offering credit card spend bonus interest on the 360 account. The move is attributed to a weakened interest rate environment and challenging macro climate.

site_title: Investors face property dilemma created by Covid-19
summary: Investors are facing a dilemma in the property market due to the COVID-19 pandemic, which has led to changes in how people live and work, denting values and rental prospects of malls and skyscrapers. Despite this, some investors are doubling down on their bets, while others are opting for alternative assets like residential investment. Experts predict varying demand for different types of properties, with logistics real estate potentially seeing growth and residential investment being considered a safer bet.

site_title: Rand's quick recovery rally surprises traders
summary: The South African rand has made a rapid turnaround from its record low in April, surprising traders and analysts. Despite predictions of a decline of around 8% in the second quarter, the currency strengthened 5.6% in May, breaching key resistance levels. Analysts attributed the rally to a hawkish central bank and tentative return of risk appetite, while risks include rising tensions between the US and China and South Africa's struggling economy.

site_title: 65% of small Israeli start-ups could succumb to Covid-19: survey
summary: A survey by the Israeli Innovation Authority found that 65% of small Israeli start-ups expect to cease operations within six months due to the economic impact of the coronavirus crisis. The high-tech sector, which accounts for 10% of jobs, is facing bankruptcy, with over a third of companies putting staff on leave of absence. The survey's results show that the industry is not receiving sufficient assistance from the Israeli government, with an already approved emergency package deemed insufficient to prevent a potential collapse of the industry.

site_title: mm2 Asia FY20 net profit down 81.5% on Covid-19 impact
summary: Singapore-based film production group mm2 Asia reported an 81.5% decline in its net profit for the FY2020, reaching S$3.5 million, due to the Covid-19 pandemic's impact on the film industry. The company cited a challenging environment as the reason for the decline.

site_title: Singapore agrees to suspend HSR project till Dec 31
summary: Singapore has agreed to suspend the High-Speed Rail (HSR) project with Malaysia until December 31, 2020, allowing Malaysia time to clarify proposed changes. The 7-month extension follows a request from Malaysia's Senior Minister for International Trade and Industry Azmin Ali, who will lead the Malaysian team in discussions with the Singapore Government. The project, which would link Singapore and Kuala Lumpur, had been suspended for two years since September 2018. Both countries are optimistic about the project's prospects, with Singapore committed to a mutually beneficial project that will strengthen connectivity and people-to-people ties.

site_title: Philippines capital comes back to life although virus threat lingers
summary: Millions of people returned to work in the Philippine capital, Manila, as the country eased its strict 11-week coronavirus lockdown to revive its economy. Public transport was limited, and commuters faced long queues. The Philippines, with the third-highest number of cases and second-highest death toll in Southeast Asia, has allowed more businesses to reopen and people to leave home without permits. President Rodrigo Duterte aimed to balance COVID-19 protection with economic revival, but critics warn of the challenges in implementing relaxed rules.

site_title: Abu Dhabi locks down with one-week travel ban
summary: Abu Dhabi has announced a one-week travel ban, cordon off the UAE's capital, and restrict movement between regions within the emirate from June 2 to June 9. Residents can move freely within their regions between 6am and 10pm, while malls, restaurants, and hotel beaches reopen at 40% capacity. Outdoor activities such as horse riding and cycling are also allowed. The ban aims to rein in the spread of the novel coronavirus, which has recorded over 34,000 cases in the UAE, including 264 deaths.

site_title: Troops, police clamp down in US cities as unrest over racism flares
summary: Thousands of National Guard troops patrolled US cities on Sunday after five consecutive nights of protests over racism and police brutality. The unrest, sparked by the shocking videotaped death of an unarmed black man, George Floyd, at the hands of police in Minneapolis, has led to arson, looting, and clashes between protesters and police. President Trump blamed anarchists and far-left activists for the violence, while local leaders appealed for citizens to give constructive outlet to their rage without destroying their communities. Multiple arrests were reported, and 11 Washington police officers were injured in clashes with protesters.

summary:

site_title: Russia, after approving Japanese Covid-19 drug, to roll out 'game changer' next week
summary: Russia will start administering its first approved antiviral drug, Avifavir, to treat coronavirus patients from June 11, with enough to treat around 60,000 people per month. The drug, modified from a Japanese generic drug, was shown to be effective in treating the virus in most cases within four days in clinical trials involving 330 people. Russian health officials believe the drug is a "game changer" that will reduce strain on the healthcare system and speed a return to normal economic life, with the potential to be exported to countries in the Middle East and Latin America.

site_title: West Bank poor may double over pandemic: World Bank
summary: The World Bank warns that poverty in the occupied West Bank may double due to the economic fallout of the COVID-19 pandemic. With low infection rates, the Palestinian Authority's financial situation is expected to worsen, leading to a 14-30% increase in households living below the poverty line. The economy is forecast to shrink 7.6-11% this year, with a financial gap increasing from $800 million to $1.5 billion. The report recommends investing in mobile networks to boost the economy, which relies heavily on 2G and 3G data.

images.alt_text: Poverty in the occupied West Bank may double as Palestinians are slammed by the economic fallout of the coronavirus pandemic, the World Bank warned on Monday.

site_title: MSCI Singapore exclusions shave S$863m off market value
summary: Four Singaporean blue-chip stocks, including Singapore Press Holdings (SPH), Sembcorp Industries, ComfortDelGro, and SATS, lost a combined market capitalization of S$863 million after being excluded from the MSCI Singapore Index. The stocks experienced significant price declines due to the pandemic, with SPH and Sembcorp Industries hitting their lowest levels since 1992 and 2004, respectively. The changes took effect on May 29, following MSCI's semi-annual index review on May 12.

site_title: Temasek sold off NOL, so why save PIL?
summary: Temasek Holdings, a Singaporean investment firm, sold off Neptune Orient Lines (NOL) five years ago, but is now considering a deal with Pacific International Lines (PIL). The container shipping industry faces a bleak outlook, with slow vessels offering low returns. Temasek is likely considering PIL's call for help due to the poor performance of NOL, which may be unable to compete in the market. This decision may be driven by the need to salvage value from the struggling NOL, rather than a long-term investment strategy.

images.alt_text: Homegrown PIL employs some 9,000 people worldwide. It also has active business relationships with 700 to 800 vendors in the Republic, including about 100 homegrown Singapore entities.

site_title: Balancing now, next and beyond Covid-19
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has exacerbated existing risks for organizations, highlighting the need for boards to balance recovery with planning for the future. A stakeholder-centric approach can help distill insights and drive necessary actions. Boards must monitor emerging risks, assess financial scenarios, and ensure IT resiliency, cyber security, and data privacy. They should also prioritize workforce health and safety, communicate effectively with employees, and evaluate plans for managing redundancy and supply chain resiliency. By adopting a transformative mindset, boards can steer businesses forward and capitalize on opportunities to reboot and reshape their operations.

site_title: SG Digital Office to encourage digitalisation among seniors, hawkers
summary: The Singapore government will set up an SG Digital Office to promote digitalisation among seniors and hawkers. The office aims to recruit 1,000 digital ambassadors to help 18,000 stallholders adopt digital tools by June 2021. The digital ambassadors will provide training on SGQR codes for e-payment, aiming to reduce cash handling and encourage the use of digital tools. This initiative follows a bonus offer of S$300 per month for five months to encourage stallholders to use e-payments. The goal is to accelerate Singapore's digitalisation push and prepare the population for the post-Covid-19 environment.

site_title: Short-sales: Rules and safeguards
summary: Singapore's stock market has rules and safeguards in place to prevent unfair market practices. Investors must mark short-sell orders and aggregate all short positions, with some thresholds exempting them from reporting. The Monetary Authority of Singapore and the Singapore Exchange (SGX) impose penalties on naked short-sales, forced buying-in, and punitive cash settlements on short-sellers who fail to deliver securities within two business days. Borrowing securities prior to short-selling can mitigate the risk of penalties. The market also has circuit breakers to slow sharp price moves and review trades resulting in price dislocations.

site_title: Seoul: Shares jump as US-China worries ease
summary: South Korean shares rose 1.75% on Monday, closing at 2,065.08, after US President Donald Trump's threat against China over a national security law for Hong Kong was deemed weaker than expected. Despite sluggish trade and manufacturing activity, investors remained confident the US would not break its trade deal with China. Foreigners were net buyers of $90.05 million worth of shares, and exports tumbled for a third straight month.

images.alt_text: South Korean shares buoyed on Monday as the US President Donald Trump's threat against China over a national security law for Hong Kong was weaker than feared, even as the country's trade and manufacturing activity remained sluggish.

site_title: Brazil's Bolsonaro rallies supporters as US sends unproven drug
summary: Brazil's President Jair Bolsonaro rallied supporters outside the government palace in Brasilia, dismissing the COVID-19 pandemic and echoing his previous statements. The rally comes amid a health crisis and a court-ordered investigation into abuse of power, which could lead to his impeachment. The US has sent 2 million doses of the unproven antimalarial medicine hydroxychloroquine to help fight the pandemic, while Brazil faces nearly 500,000 confirmed cases and a death toll of nearly 28,000.

site_title: US lawmakers to unveil bill banning investment in firms tied to China's military
summary: US lawmakers plan to introduce a bill banning investments in foreign defense companies with ties to China's military. The legislation, led by Representatives Mike Gallagher, Jim Banks, and Doug LaMalfa, would require the Treasury Secretary to submit a report listing firms with substantial military ties, and American companies and citizens would be required to divest from those firms six months later. The move aims to curb US funding for China-based firms amid growing anti-China sentiment in the Capitol, following China's curbing of Hong Kong's independence.

site_title: Rio Tinto apologises for blowing up 46,000-year-old Aboriginal site
summary: Rio Tinto has apologized for destroying a 46,000-year-old Aboriginal cave in Western Australia, blowing up two ancient rock shelters in Juukan Gorge. The site, home to traditional owners the Puutu Kunti Kurrama and Pinikura people, contained significant cultural heritage artefacts, including 4,000-year-old human hair with genetic links. The mining giant has pledged to review its plans for other sites in the area and work with traditional owners to preserve heritage. An investigation is underway into the incident, with calls for reform of heritage protection laws.

site_title: Singapore looks to rely less on foreign workers after pandemic
summary: Singapore aims to reduce its reliance on foreign workers and accelerate automation in its post-pandemic economy. Second Minister for Finance Indranee Rajah emphasized the need to shift manual operations to automation and focus on higher-value-added activities for the local population. The city-state plans to redesign its infrastructure system, investing in clean energy, public health, and information technology, while promoting a "friendly regulatory environment". International financial sources remain available to support clean energy projects, and a training program with the World Bank Group and Singapore Management University will prepare senior government officials for project preparation.

site_title: Iranian fuel reaches Venezuelan stations as prices set to rise
summary: Iranian fuel shipments arrived at Venezuelan petrol stations on Saturday, ahead of President Nicolas Maduro's announcement of higher fuel prices. The new system combines subsidies and international prices, with monthly quotas and automated sales equipment. Despite the price increases, fuel will still be relatively cheap, costing around $1 to fill a tank. The move aims to end decades of almost-free petrol, but the US has warned against aiding the Iranian supply due to sanctions.

site_title: British watchdog enlists eight insurers for pandemic test case
summary: Britain's Financial Conduct Authority (FCA) has enlisted eight insurers, including Hiscox and QBE, to participate in a test case to determine whether their policies cover companies hit by the coronavirus pandemic. The FCA selected 17 examples from 16 insurers to seek clarity on insurance policy wording during the pandemic. The test case, set to take place in the second half of July, aims to provide guidance on business interruption insurance policies and will last five to 10 days. The FCA expects the test case to affect many other insurers and policies.

images.alt_text: Britain's Financial Conduct Authority (FCA) said eight insurers, including Hiscox and QBE, will take part in a test case to decide whether their policies should compensate companies hit by the coronavirus pandemic.

site_title: Clint Eastwood is 90, but doesn't want any fuss to 'make my day'
summary: Clint Eastwood turned 90 on Sunday, but the legendary actor and director has expressed no desire to retire. Eastwood has continued working in the entertainment industry despite controversy surrounding some of his films, and has hinted at future projects. He prefers to keep a low profile and has no plans to celebrate his birthday, instead opting for a quiet family gathering. Eastwood's career has spanned seven decades and over 50 films, with notable awards including Oscars for Unforgiven and Million Dollar Baby.

site_title: Broker's take: DBS says Sembcorp 'too cheap to ignore', upgrades to 'buy'
summary: DBS Group Research upgraded Sembcorp Industries (SCI) to "buy" with an unchanged target price of S$1.70, citing the company's "too cheap to ignore" valuation after its removal from the MSCI Index. The research team believes SCI's utilities business could be re-rated by 30-40 cents per share if spun off from Sembcorp Marine, and potential restructuring with Keppel Corp remains a wild card. The company's earnings are expected to remain in positive territory with mid-single-digit return on equity, offering 25% potential upside.

site_title: Amazon's Jeff Bezos invests in UK digital freight forwarder Beacon
summary: Amazon CEO Jeff Bezos has invested in UK digital freight forwarder Beacon, which raised over $15 million in Series A funding. The startup, founded by two former Uber executives, provides real-time data on cargo delivery and global shipping costs. With the investment, Beacon plans to expand its services, hire new staff, and enhance its technology. This investment comes as the COVID-19 pandemic accelerates digitalization in the logistics industry.

site_title: Debates rage in Britain as some children go back to school
summary: Britain partially reopens schools on Monday, despite warnings that the country is moving too quickly out of its coronavirus lockdown. The decision comes as the UK's death toll stands at 38,489, putting pressure on Prime Minister Boris Johnson. Johnson faced criticism for his chief adviser's decision to drive to a castle during lockdown, but the focus is now on the government's handling of the pandemic. The move has sparked debates in Britain about the pace of reopening and the risks of further lockdowns.

site_title: Google rejects call for huge Australian media payout
summary: Google has rejected demands to pay hundreds of millions of dollars per year in compensation to Australian news media under a government-imposed revenue sharing deal. The company's managing director for Australia, Mel Silva, dismissed estimates of Google earning A$6 billion per year from advertising in Australia, saying it earns barely A$10 million per year from news-linked advertising. The Australian competition regulator, ACCC, has estimated Google and Facebook together earn A$6 billion per year from advertising in Australia, with leading news publishers demanding 10% of that amount each year.

site_title: Stocks' rise may go on with Fed support despite 'madness'
summary: US stocks rose despite horrific economic data, with the "reopening trade" causing a blockbuster rally for industrial, retail, and travel companies. The Federal Reserve's support, led by Chairman Jerome Powell, is credited for the market's resilience. Investors are closely monitoring protests in Hong Kong and Covid-19 outbreaks in the Americas, but the market's focus is on the second half of the year, where bulls expect pent-up demand to drive economic activity. The stock market has written off the second quarter, but the bulls expect a surge in economic activity in the fall.

site_title: Japan Parliament to debate 2nd extra budget for pandemic relief next week
summary: Japan's government will submit a second extra budget to Parliament early next week to fund a US$1.10 trillion stimulus package to combat the economic impact of the coronavirus pandemic. The budget aims to protect businesses and jobs, with significant direct spending included. The move is expected to be approved by Parliament, boosting Japan's real GDP by 3.2 percentage points this year. The government's expanded fiscal deficit may draw market attention once the pandemic subsides, and analysts predict the possibility of a third extra budget later this year to address an expected slump in tax revenues.

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary: The Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights report for May 31, 2020, shows a mixed market for tankers and dry bulk vessels. The Capesize 5TC index rose +141 to settle at a low $3369, while the Pacific Round C10 dropped from $6563 to $4581. Bunker levels continued to decline, but high sulphur spreads widened. The Panamax market saw significant gains, with South America driving the market. The Ultramax/Supramax market saw some activity, with rates increasing in the high $9,000s. Handysize vessels saw strong support from east coast South America and the Pacific, leading to improved rates.

site_title: First Reit says Lippo Karawaci has not approached it about lease restructuring
summary: Indonesian real estate giant Lippo Karawaci plans to discuss lease restructuring with First Reit due to the Covid-19 pandemic's impact on its hospital subsidiary Siloam. The pandemic has rendered rental subsidies unsustainable, with revenues in some hospitals down 40-50% year-on-year. First Reit has not been approached by Lippo Karawaci regarding the matter, but will consider any proposal carefully and monitor the situation closely. The company's units fell 11.3% following the announcement, and further declined 17 cents or 19.2% after a trading halt was lifted.

site_title: New substantial shareholder for Sin Heng Heavy Machinery
summary: Sin Heng Heavy Machinery reported a new substantial shareholder, but no details were provided in the article. The Straits Times Index declined 1.6% over the specified sessions, bringing its 2020 total return to 20.7%. Eleven primary-listed stocks conducted share buybacks totaling S$6.0 million.

site_title: Macau's gaming revenues tumble 93.2% in May as coronavirus hit
summary: Macau's gaming revenue plummeted 93.2% in May, reaching 1.76 billion patacas (S$310 million), due to coronavirus restrictions. This represents a 96.8% decline from April. The drastic drop is attributed to the measures implemented to contain the spread of the virus.

images.alt_text: Gambling revenue in Macau slid 93.2 per cent in May year-on-year as authorities imposed restrictions in the world's biggest casino hub to contain the spread of the coronavirus.

site_title: Armed with disinfectant and admonishments, S Korean robot fights coronavirus spread
summary: In South Korea, a self-driving robot equipped with cameras, an LED screen, and disinfectant is being used to minimize human contact and reduce the spread of the coronavirus. The robot, developed by SK Telecom and Omron Electronics Korea, checks visitors' temperatures, dispenses hand sanitizer, and disinfects surfaces. It also uses artificial intelligence to detect gatherings and advise people to disperse. The robot's technology is being adopted by smaller businesses and retailers, including a café and a multiplex cinema chain, to promote social distancing and improve accuracy in temperature checks.

site_title: Indonesia capital gears up for post-holiday flow amid virus
summary: Indonesia's capital Jakarta prepares for a post-holiday influx of one million vehicles as people return from Eid al-Fitr holidays amid the coronavirus pandemic. Traffic is expected to peak from Saturday to Monday, with the government calling on citizens to delay their return to curb the spread of the virus. The government has increased monitoring and patrols at checkpoints, seaports, and airports to prevent a new wave of infections. With Indonesia's highest coronavirus death toll in South-east Asia, the measures aim to mitigate the spread of the pathogen.

site_title: US govt sells HK$10b worth of property in HK
summary: The US government has sold its property in Hong Kong's Shouson Hill neighborhood valued at HK$10 billion (S$1.82 billion). The sale comes amid ongoing protests and rising tensions between the US and China over national security legislation. The US government, which purchased the property in 1948, is part of its global reinvestment program, and the sale is part of efforts to enhance other US government-owned assets in Hong Kong, including the US Consulate General's office building.

site_title: It's still service with a smile, but from behind a mask
summary: Berlin's Michelin-starred restaurant Pauly Saal reopened after a two-month shutdown due to the pandemic, with staff wearing masks and modified dining practices. The restaurant had to perfect its new working practice in just 24 hours, with a completely new menu and limited seating due to social distancing measures. Despite initial challenges, the staff and diners adapted, with many customers enjoying their first post-lockdown meal at the restaurant. The reopening marked a barometer for fine dining's ability to survive during the pandemic, with over 30 diners seated by 8pm, exceeding some staff's expectations.

site_title: Infrastructure Asia, World Bank and SMU launch infrastructure capability programme
summary: Singapore's Minister in the Prime Minister's Office and Second Minister for Finance Indranee Rajah launched an infrastructure capability development programme for regional government officials, developed by Infrastructure Asia and the World Bank Group, with the Singapore Management University. The programme aims to train officials on creating a regulatory environment for private sector involvement and public-private partnerships in infrastructure, focusing on clean energy. The initiative seeks to support Asia's infrastructure development and promote sustainable infrastructure.

site_title: Natixis opens investment banking office in Saudi Arabia
summary: Natixis, a French investment bank, has opened a corporate and investment banking office in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia's capital, with former JPMorgan banker Reema al-Asmari as its CEO. The move follows Saudi Arabia's Vision 2030 program to privatize state assets and attract foreign capital. The office will offer tailored capital markets products and investment banking services, aiming to deepen relationships with existing clients and serve new ones, including family offices. This expansion is seen as a strategic move by Natixis to capitalize on opportunities in the region.

site_title: Youth use humour to cope with tough times
summary: Under-30s use humour to cope with various challenges, including climate change, debt, and mental health issues, as they struggle to afford therapy. A Twitter group chat member, Chuck Wentzell, jokes that the group posts for therapy as it's the most affordable option. This "gallows humour" helps young people stay sane amidst tough times.

site_title: US housing sales shoot up during lockdown
summary: US housing sales surged 30% in May, surpassing pre-pandemic forecasts for Lee Whitaker's Pacesetter Homes. The unexpected increase was attributed to Americans seeking to upgrade their homes during the lockdown. This trend suggests that the pandemic has boosted the housing market, with sales continuing to rise despite the ongoing economic challenges.

site_title: 506 new Covid-19 cases in Singapore, including 2 Singaporeans and PRs
summary: Singapore reported 506 new Covid-19 cases, including 2 Singaporeans and permanent residents, bringing the total to 34,366. Most cases involve foreign workers in dormitories. The Ministry of Health changed its discharge criteria, allowing patients to be discharged after 21 days of illness if they are clinically well, and will still need to stay at home for 7 days. This change comes after a record 1,337 patients were discharged on Friday, bringing the total recovered to 19,622.

site_title: Emirates Airline says must cut jobs over virus crisis
summary: Emirates Airline announced it will cut jobs due to the coronavirus crisis, with the airline stating it has no choice but to "say goodbye to a few of the wonderful people" who worked with it. The airline employs around 100,000 staff and has a fleet of 270 aircraft, with travel demand expected to take at least 18 months to return to normal. This move comes as the International Air Transport Association forecast a significant decline in air traffic in the Middle East and North Africa this year, with MENA airlines' revenues expected to be slashed by $24.5 billion.

site_title: MOH: Covid-19 testing done for all nursing home staff and residents
summary: The Ministry of Health (MOH) in Singapore has completed Covid-19 testing for all nursing home staff and residents, with only five staff members testing positive. The confirmed cases were announced on May 21 and May 8. The health ministry also reported 518 new Covid-19 cases, bringing the total number to 34,884, with 516 migrant workers residing in dormitories among the new cases. The number of community cases has decreased, with a daily average of four new cases over the past week, and 972 more patients were discharged, bringing the total number of recovered patients to 21,690.

images.alt_text: All nursing home staff members and residents have now been tested, said the health ministry.

site_title: New measures for foreign workers, dorm operators, employers from June 2
summary: Singapore has announced new measures for foreign workers, dorm operators, and employers to resume work after the "circuit breaker" period ends on June 1. Measures include implementing tight entry and exit controls, completing a checklist of measures, and providing proof of government agency approval. Migrant workers must monitor their health and report daily health status using mobile apps. Employers must agree to conditions, including providing upkeep and salary support to foreign workers unable to work, and paying prevailing salaries to full-time workers.

site_title: Tech giant Tencent making waves
summary: Tencent, a Chinese tech giant, faces challenges with its share price, which may struggle to break its 2018 high due to the US-China trade war and weakening advertising business. The company's share price has experienced a corrective 5-3-5 zig-zag momentum, indicating further downside before a potential trend reversal. Despite this, Tencent's gaming revenue remains strong, with a 37.3 billion yuan revenue in the first quarter of 2020. The company's WeChat app is expected to drive growth, but the bearish trend suggests a potential short-term decline.

site_title: Amazon calls delivery drivers back, closes hubs near protests in US
summary: Amazon is scaling back deliveries and adjusting routes in several US cities, including Chicago, Los Angeles, and Portland, due to protests sparked by the death of George Floyd. The company is prioritizing the safety of its teams and will only reopen delivery stations when it's safe. Delivery drivers were instructed to stop immediately and return home, with undelivered packages to be returned to the pick-up location. Amazon is in close contact with local officials and will monitor demonstrations in every zip code to plan delivery routes.

site_title: Gold's appeal rises as coronavirus hedge
summary: Gold prices are expected to rise to $2,000 per ounce in the next few months, driven by increased demand as a coronavirus hedge amid economic uncertainty. The surge in gold-backed exchange-traded funds (ETFs) in Q1, a 7-fold rise, has contributed to the rally, which is also fueled by central bank stimulus and inflationary expectations. Experts predict the gold fever will continue, with some forecasting a peak at $3,000/oz, while others expect a V-shaped recovery to limit prices to $2,000/oz.

site_title: Ho Bee bolsters recurring income shield
summary: Ho Bee Land has bolstered its recurring income shield by growing its rental income from S$14.4m in 2012 to S$209.4m in 2019, primarily from office assets in Singapore and London. The group has secured a site for Biopolis Phase 6, a biomedical sciences research facility, with a 38% winning margin in the concept-and-price tender. Ho Bee expects to achieve a net yield of 5-6% from the project, with a total development cost of S$400 million. The group's chairman and CEO, Chua Thian Poh, aims to hold the development as a long-term investment, following a similar strategy with its Metropolis office development.

site_title: Nasa resumes human spaceflight from US soil with historic SpaceX launch
summary: NASA has successfully resumed human spaceflight from US soil with a historic SpaceX launch, marking the first time American astronauts have flown on an American-made rocket from US soil in nine years. The SpaceX Falcon 9 rocket launched two NASA astronauts, Doug Hurley and Bob Behnken, into orbit aboard the Crew Dragon capsule, bound for the International Space Station. The mission, which took 19 hours, marks a major milestone for NASA and SpaceX, with the reusable rockets making spaceflight less costly and more frequent.

site_title: Biotech-heavy 'Nasdaq of Japan' is Asia's best-performing index
summary: Japan's Mothers Index, a biotech-heavy index, has reached its 1,000 point milestone for the first time since December 2018, with a 27% gain in the past month. The surge is attributed to the unexpected tailwind from the coronavirus pandemic, which has boosted shares in firms like AnGes Inc, Mercari Inc, and Sosei Group. The index is also expected to recover quickly due to its diverse composition of companies focused on new services, including biotechnology, online, and AI, making a "V-shaped recovery" highly likely, according to Libra Investments.

site_title: Thailand passes record stimulus package to combat virus impact
summary: Thailand's parliament approved a record $60 billion stimulus package to combat the economic impact of the coronavirus, with the majority of funds allocated to aid farmers and informal workers. The package is expected to boost the economy, which is forecast to contract by 6-7% in 2020. The government aims to stabilize markets and boost purchasing power, with $1.4 billion allocated for healthcare readiness. Critics expressed concerns over lack of transparency in allocation, while the government vowed to implement a step-by-step screening process.

site_title: Hong Kong tensions a risk to global economy, Japan official says
summary: Japanese Economy Minister Yasutoshi Nishimura expressed concern over Hong Kong's situation, stating that friction between the US and China could pose a risk to the global economy if the city loses its international financial hub status. Nishimura hopes China will undertake a structural overhaul to strengthen domestic demand, citing Japan's past efforts. The escalating tensions between the US and China over Hong Kong's trade status, coronavirus origins, and protectionism could have a major impact on the world, Nishimura warned.

site_title: EU trade commissioner Hogan mulling candidacy for WTO chief
summary: European trade commissioner Phil Hogan is considering running for the World Trade Organization (WTO) director-general position, set to become vacant at the end of August. Hogan, who has been a European commissioner since 2014, has expressed support for a reform agenda for the WTO. He is one of several European candidates, including Arancha Gonzalez Laya and Sigrid Kaag, who will be nominated by June 8. The WTO faces challenges such as intensifying US-China tensions and rising protectionism, and Hogan's candidacy could be influenced by the need for a leader from the developing world.

site_title: Masks for those who need them most
summary: A ground-up advocacy group, Masks For All SG, is distributing 500,000 masks to vulnerable groups in Singapore, including healthcare staff, the elderly, and migrant workers, as part of an educational outreach initiative. The group, which has partnered with government agencies and firms, aims to promote a culture of mask-wearing and provide direct support to high-risk groups. Masks For All SG is also partnering with China-based Zall Group, which has donated one million surgical masks to the Singapore Red Cross. The initiative is part of a larger effort to support Singapore's battle against the Covid-19 pandemic.

site_title: Zoom plans to roll out strong encryption for paying customers
summary: Zoom plans to implement strong encryption for paying customers, excluding free consumer accounts, in an effort to improve security. The move, subject to change, aims to prevent troublemakers from joining meetings, but may limit the company's ability to detect and address abuse. Experts weigh the benefits of enhanced security against concerns of over-regulation and the potential for malicious users to find alternative encrypted channels.

images.alt_text: Video conferencing provider Zoom plans to strengthen encryption of video calls hosted by paying clients and institutions such as schools, but not by users of its free consumer accounts, a company official said on Friday.

site_title: Investors pin hopes on ECB doing more to prop up European assets
summary: Investors are expecting the European Central Bank (ECB) to make significant moves to support European assets on Thursday. A 500 billion euro boost to the pandemic emergency bond buying fund is seen as the minimum required to reassure markets. Analysts also anticipate tweaks to the tiering system to help lenders cope with negative interest rates. If the ECB meets these expectations, Italian bonds are likely to rally, following their best May performance since 2003.

site_title: Singapore's Bayfront teams up with Japan's top law firm Nishimura
summary: Singaporean law firm Bayfront Law has partnered with Japan's top law firm Nishimura & Asahi to expand its reach across Asia and the US. The Nishimura & Asahi-Bayfront Law Alliance, established after Ministry of Law approval, will allow Bayfront to offer services in Japan, Thailand, China, and other countries through Nishimura & Asahi's global network. This marks the first formal tie-up between a Japanese and Singaporean law firm, with the alliance set to provide services in private and public law, including mergers, acquisitions, and civil litigation.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: MOM outlines new measures for foreign workers resuming work after June 1
summary: The Singapore Ministry of Manpower (MOM) has outlined new measures for foreign workers resuming work after June 1. Dormitory operators and employers must implement safety protocols, including staggered rest days, physical barriers, and health monitoring. Workers will initially be allowed to leave dorms only for work, with designated transport provided by employers. Measures will be phased in, with workers allowed to run errands and leave dorms for longer periods as restrictions ease. Non-compliance can result in fines or jail time, and workers will be required to report their health status and location on an MOM app.

site_title: Fed chief Jerome Powell fears second coronavirus wave, reiterates crisis-fighting pledge
summary: Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell expressed concerns about a potential second wave of COVID-19 infections, which could undermine public confidence and prolong the economic recovery. Powell stated that the Fed is prepared to continue supporting the economy but warned that a second outbreak could lead to a significantly longer recovery. The Fed has announced programs to cushion the economic impact, including lending programs for companies and local governments, and has ballooned its balance sheet to a record level of over $7 trillion.

site_title: 51-year-old Chinese national dies from Covid-19 complications; no new community cases
summary: A 51-year-old Chinese national died from Covid-19 complications in Singapore, marking the youngest patient to die from the virus in the country. The man, who had been treated for lymphoma, had been in the intensive care unit since April and died on May 31. This brings Singapore's death toll to 24. No new community cases were reported, with all new cases being from foreign workers in dormitories. The number of new community cases has decreased, and the number of recovered patients has increased to 22,457.

site_title: Trump postpones G-7 summit, seeks to add countries to invitation list
summary: US President Donald Trump postponed the Group of Seven (G-7) summit from June to September or later, citing the group's outdated format. Trump plans to expand the summit's membership to include Australia, Russia, South Korea, and India, stating the current group does not properly represent the world's current economic landscape.

site_title: SpaceX Crew Dragon docks with International Space Station
summary: SpaceX's Crew Dragon capsule successfully docked with the International Space Station, marking the first time a crewed US spacecraft has performed this feat in nearly a decade. The docking occurred at 10:16 am Eastern Time, followed by a hard capture and airtight seal. On board are astronauts Bob Behnkhen and Doug Hurley, veterans of the Space Shuttle programme. The crew will soon pressurize the vestibule and open the hatch, marking a significant milestone in space exploration.

images.alt_text: This Nasa photo obtained May 31, 2020 shows a SpaceX Falcon 9 rocket carrying the company's Crew Dragon spacecraft launched from Launch Complex 39A on Nasa's SpaceX Demo-2 mission to the International Space Station.

site_title: Employers must agree to 2 conditions to get foreign worker levy waivers, rebates: MOM
summary: Employers in Singapore must agree to two conditions to receive foreign worker levy waivers and rebates as the country reopens its economy. The conditions include allowing the Ministry of Manpower (MOM) to relocate cleared foreign workers from existing dormitories to cleared dormitories, and allowing MOM to second or transfer workers to companies with uncleared dormitories. Employers must also provide upkeep and salary support to foreign workers unable to work due to government support. Employers must make an online acknowledgement by June 10 to accept these conditions.

site_title: Covid-19 testing completed for all nursing home residents and staff
summary: Singapore's Health Ministry announced that all nursing home residents and staff have been tested for COVID-19, with only 5 out of 13,200 residents and 1 staff member testing positive. The confirmed cases were reported on May 21 and May 8. The country reported 518 new cases on May 31, bringing the total to 34,884. The new cases include a 73-year-old Singaporean woman and an 18-year-old permanent resident, both linked to community cases. The daily average of new community cases has decreased to four in the past week.

site_title: Singapore agrees to final extension of KL-S'pore High-Speed Rail project suspension till Dec 31
summary: Singapore has agreed to a seven-month extension of the High-Speed Rail (HSR) project suspension with Malaysia until December 31, 2020, to discuss proposed changes. The project, which would link the two countries' capitals, had been suspended for about two years since 2018. Transport Minister Khaw Boon Wan said the extension will allow both countries to assess Malaysia's proposed changes and discuss the implications. The project's completion date has been pushed to January 2031.

site_title: Merkel a 'no' for Trump's in-person G7 summit: report
summary: German Chancellor Angela Merkel will not attend an in-person G7 summit, citing concerns over the coronavirus pandemic. The summit, which was initially scheduled for video conference, has been revived by US President Donald Trump, who plans to host it "primarily at the White House" and potentially at Camp David. Merkel, a 65-year-old scientist, has declined due to her age and the ongoing pandemic, making her the first to give a firm "no" to the in-person gathering.

site_title: No ERP charges until at least June 28: LTA
summary: Singapore's Electronic Road Pricing (ERP) system will remain suspended until June 28, even as the country begins its economic reopening. The Land Transport Authority (LTA) will resume ERP rate reviews on June 2 and monitor traffic conditions. The first post-circuit-breaker review will be announced in late June, with new ERP rates potentially taking effect on June 29.

site_title: Singapore secured S$13b in investment commitments in Jan-Apr 2020; exceeds EDB projection
summary: Singapore secured S$13 billion in investment commitments from January to April 2020, exceeding the Singapore Economic Development Board's (EDB) full-year projection of S$8 billion to S$10 billion. The investments, mainly in electronics and infocomm media, are expected to generate a few thousand jobs.
