summary: Italy's Benetton family is open to reducing its stake in infrastructure group Atlantia, which is backed by Singapore's GIC, as a way to ease tensions with the Italian government. The dispute began after a 2018 bridge collapse that killed 43 people, and the government has threatened to strip Autostrade, a motorway unit, of its concession if the Benettons reduce their influence. Edizione chairman Gianni Mion stated that the family is open to diluting their stake if "credible partners come along with plans for development".

site_title: US braces for more protests over police killing of black man
summary: Protests over the police killing of a handcuffed black man, George Floyd, continue in Minneapolis and St. Paul, with hundreds marching and looting reported. The National Guard has been deployed to maintain security, and local officials have warned against violence. Floyd's family demands murder charges against the officers involved, while national leaders Jesse Jackson and Al Sharpton call for protests and justice. The US Department of Justice has made the investigation a top priority, and President Trump has expressed support for justice being served.

site_title: Medtech startup Endofotonics raises S$12m in Series B round
summary: Endofotonics, a cancer diagnostic company, has raised S$12 million in a Series B round led by Singapore Medical Group executives. The funding will be used to commercialize its early gastric cancer detection system in the Asia-Pacific and expand its cancer detection technology to other organs. Founded in 2013, Endofotonics' system uses Raman spectroscopy to detect early cancer during endoscopy. The company aims to drive growth in its technology, which has the potential to improve cancer diagnosis and treatment in the region.

site_title: Europe moves ahead with lockdown easing, but caution in Asia
summary: Europe is slowly easing lockdown measures as the COVID-19 pandemic continues to spread globally. Several countries, including France and Britain, have reopened bars, restaurants, and museums, while the English Premier League and Italy's Serie A plan to resume play in mid-June. However, fresh restrictions have been reimposed in parts of Asia, including South Korea and Sri Lanka, after new infections sparked fears of a second wave. The death toll has surpassed 357,000 worldwide, and over 40 million people have filed jobless claims in the US, with Brazil shedding five million jobs in the first quarter.

images.alt_text: Several European countries including France and Britain on Thursday moved to further lift crippling coronavirus lockdown measures, but fresh restrictions in parts of Asia signalled the crisis is far from over.

site_title: YouTube CEO responds to Trump order threatening web protections
summary: YouTube CEO Susan Wojcicki responded to US President Donald Trump's executive order threatening web protections, stating that the platform supports a wide variety of opinions and runs its service in a neutral way. Wojcicki said YouTube wants to understand the president's concerns and address them, while emphasizing the platform's efforts to ensure fair and consistent policies. The order aims to limit liability protections for social-media companies that engage in censoring or political conduct, following a dispute between Trump and Twitter.

images.alt_text: YouTube boss Susan Wojcicki responded to US President Donald Trump's executive order on Thursday, saying the online video giant supports a wide variety of opinions and runs its service in a neutral way.

site_title: Asia: Equities drop as Trump lines up China response
summary: US President Donald Trump plans to outline his response to China's plan to crack down on Hong Kong, sparking concerns of a renewed trade war. Asian equities fell, with Hong Kong down 0.3% and Shanghai 0.1% lower, amid hopes the world is slowly recovering from the coronavirus crisis. The US has already revoked Hong Kong's special status, potentially stripping it of key trading privileges. Traders are bracing for losses of around 7% for US markets, but some analysts see a potential bounce if stocks reach record highs.

site_title: TikTok owner ByteDance moves to shift power out of China: sources
summary: ByteDance, the owner of TikTok, is shifting its power out of China amid rising global tensions. The company has made several moves to transfer global decision-making and research capabilities to the US and other countries. This includes expanding TikTok's engineering and research operations in California, hiring a New York-based investor relations director, and recruiting engineers globally. The strategy aims to address concerns in the US over TikTok's handling of personal data and national security risks. ByteDance's efforts may help mitigate regulatory scrutiny, but experts warn that credibility remains an issue.

site_title: Hot stock: Broadway shares up 17.3% after proposal to sell hard-disk business
summary: Broadway Industrial Group shares rose 17.3% on Friday after the company proposed to sell its hard-disk drive business via the sale of its wholly-owned unit BIGL Asia. The counter was the most traded, with 39.3 million shares changing hands. The sale consideration will be in cash or equity, determined after the buyer's due diligence process. The shares jumped to a high of 11.5 Singapore cents, up from Thursday's closing price of 9.8 cents.

site_title: China can live with a less special Hong Kong
summary: China can live without Hong Kong's special status, as the city's economic significance has decreased since the global financial crisis. Hong Kong's trade share has dropped to under 10% in 2018, and foreign investment has decreased to around 1.5% of fixed-asset investment. The US proposal to strip Hong Kong of its unique autonomy is seen as unnecessary, as China can still benefit from the city's role as an Asian financial hub. China's economy has become more self-sufficient, reducing its reliance on Hong Kong.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong's unique brand of autonomy has been a gift for China. The city has been a channel for the world's most populous nation to get moderately richer without Beijing having to relinquish control over its economy and people.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Friday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Friday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 7.16 points, or 0.49%, to 1,450.34. The market saw a higher volume of 118.80 million lots worth RM59.71 million. Gainers outpaced losers 204 to 100.

site_title: Hong Kong govt warns removing US special status is 'double-edged sword'
summary: Hong Kong's government warned the US against withdrawing its special status, citing the potential harm to Hong Kong's interests and the US. The US is set to announce its response to China's national security legislation for Hong Kong, which democracy activists and Western countries fear could erode the city's freedoms. The legislation, which China says will tackle secession and foreign interference, has sparked protests in Hong Kong and prompted the US Department of State to consider stripping Hong Kong of its special treatment under US law.

site_title: Broker's take: DBS upgrades SPH Reit to 'hold', sees light at end of tunnel
summary: DBS Group Research upgraded SPH Reit to "hold" from "fully valued" and raised its target price to S$0.80 from S$0.70. Analyst Dale Lai cited the Reit's low valuation and potential rental waiver benefits under the proposed Bill as reasons for the upgrade. The Reit had cut its DPU by 79% in Q2, but Lai sees limited downside risks and believes the Reit's prudence in making provisions for tenant rental relief will provide a buffer to revenues.

images.alt_text: DBS Group Research on Friday upgraded SPH Reit to "hold" from "fully valued" and raised its target price to S$0.80 from S$0.70.

site_title: Management of bailout money poses political test for Trump
summary: US President Donald Trump's management of the Paycheck Protection Program (PPP) has emerged as a political liability, with businesses, banks, and Democrats criticizing the White House over its handling of the program. Despite being intended to help small businesses and workers, funds have flowed to rich hoteliers, the Los Angeles Lakers, and Planned Parenthood affiliates, sparking concerns of corporate cronyism. The Trump administration has defended the program, but left-leaning groups are seizing on its shortcomings, highlighting technical glitches and delays, and spending heavily to promote their message to voters ahead of the 2020 election.

site_title: US records 1,297 coronavirus deaths in 24 hours: Johns Hopkins
summary: The US recorded 1,297 coronavirus deaths in 24 hours, bringing the total to 101,573 since the pandemic began, according to Johns Hopkins University. The country also logged 1,720,613 cases, surpassing any other nation. This marks a significant increase in cases and deaths, highlighting the ongoing impact of the pandemic in the US.

site_title: Willas-Array falls deeper into the red due to 'intense' competition, stock clearance
summary: Willas-Array Electronics reported a net loss of HK$72.6 million (S$13.3 million) for its full year ended March 31, 2020, due to intense price competition and weak demand. Revenue fell 13.9% to HK$3.18 billion, and the gross profit margin decreased. The company's clearance of buffer stock and depreciation of the yuan further reduced its buying power. The loss per share deepened to 85.15 HK cents, and no dividend was recommended for fiscal 2020.

site_title: China's JD.com, NetEase said to win HKEX approval for secondary listings
summary: Hong Kong Exchanges & Clearing has approved secondary listing applications from JD.com and NetEase, two Chinese tech companies. NetEase plans to list on June 11, while JD.com aims to debut on June 18, with JD's sale potentially raising $2 billion. The approvals come amid uncertain market conditions in Hong Kong, which has faced political turmoil. The listings will allow the companies to raise capital and expand their presence in the global market, despite the city's status as an international finance center being questioned.

images.alt_text: JD.com and NetEase have won approvals to forge ahead with their Hong Kong share sales that could raise billions of dollars, according to people familiar with the matter, as political turmoil leaves the city's status as an international finance centre clouded in uncertainty.

site_title: Fury after Pennsylvania lawmakers concealed Covid-19 diagnosis
summary: Pennsylvania lawmakers faced calls for resignation after a Republican tested positive for Covid-19 and withheld the information from Democratic colleagues for a full week. Representative Andrew Lewis, who tested positive on May 20, did not disclose his diagnosis until after he had attended legislative sessions with Democrats. Democrats expressed outrage, saying the Republican leadership prioritized their own narrative over public health. The incident has sparked calls for the resignation of House Speaker Mike Turzai and other Republican leaders.

site_title: Singapore shares fall at Friday's open, tracking US losses; STI down 0.6%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.6% on Friday, tracking US losses, with the benchmark index closing at 2,499.58. The decline was led by telco Singtel, which dropped 1.6%, and media company Singapore Press Holdings, which fell 3.4%. The losses were partly attributed to US President Donald Trump's announcement of a press conference regarding China, sparking fears of a revived US-China trade war.

site_title: Vietnam May trade deficit at US$900m, consumer prices up 2.4% y-o-y
summary: Vietnam reported a trade deficit of US$900 million in May, driven by a 15.5% decline in exports to US$18.5 billion and a 15.9% decline in imports to US$19.4 billion. Consumer prices rose 2.4% year-over-year, while the country's trade surplus for the first five months of the year was US$1.88 billion.

site_title: Pandemic's hit to Japan's factory, retail sectors deeper than expected
summary: Japan's factory output plummeted 9.1% in April, the largest drop since 2013, due to the coronavirus pandemic's impact on supply chains and global demand. Retail sales also tumbled 13.7% in April, the fastest pace since 1998, as service-sector businesses closed and consumers stayed home. The nation's economy fell into recession for the first time in 4.5 years, with the jobless rate rising to 2.6% and non-regular workers experiencing the biggest year-on-year drop on record.

site_title: Trump signs order targeting social media giants' legal protections
summary: US President Donald Trump signed an executive order targeting social media giants, aiming to strip them of legal immunity for content posted by users. The move seeks to increase government regulation and make platforms like Twitter and Facebook liable for material they host. Trump claims the companies are no longer neutral forums but engaging in "political activism" and censoring users. The order faces strong opposition and is likely to be challenged in court.

site_title: CapitaLand to deploy disinfection technology in malls
summary: CapitaLand, a Singapore-based mall operator, plans to deploy disinfection technology in its malls to enhance cleaning and disinfection routines ahead of the country's phase one reopening in June. The company will deploy UV disinfection robots and air disinfection systems, including PhotoPlasma technology, at its malls. Additionally, it will apply anti-microbial disinfectant to high-contact areas and introduce floormats with disinfecting solution, increasing cleaning frequency to once every two to three hours.

site_title: Japan bankruptcies seen rising to seven-year high on virus
summary: Japan is expected to see a seven-year high in bankruptcy cases this year, with 10,000 or more companies filing for bankruptcy due to the coronavirus pandemic. Bankruptcy protection filings jumped to 758 in April, with 123 related to the pandemic. The global economic slowdown is causing companies worldwide to go out of business, threatening workers' livelihoods. Prime Minister Shinzo Abe has doubled Japan's stimulus measures to support the economy, which analysts forecast may shrink by over 20% this quarter.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Keppel, Yangzijiang, CapitaLand, Bukit Sembawang
summary: Keppel Corp unveiled a 10-year roadmap to redefine its businesses in energy and environment, urban development, connectivity, and asset management. The conglomerate also announced a US$300 million note issue due 2025 with a 2.459% coupon. Yangzijiang Shipbuilding secured a contract worth 392 million yuan (S$77.8 million) to build container feeders.

site_title: Volkswagen agrees to buy 50% of EV partner JAC's parent company
summary: Volkswagen has agreed to purchase 50% of Anhui Jianghuai Automobile Group Holding, the parent company of Chinese electric vehicle (EV) partner JAC Motors, in a deal reportedly worth billions of dollars. The investment, which is in final talks, marks Volkswagen's expansion into the Chinese EV market. The partnership aims to enhance JAC's capabilities and increase its global presence. The deal is seen as a strategic move to boost Volkswagen's EV offerings and gain a foothold in the growing Chinese EV industry.

site_title: Asset managers, wealth funds raise stake in BlackRock after PNC exit
summary: BlackRock attracted major institutional investors, including Wellington Management, Capital Group, and Norway's wealth fund, following PNC Financial Services Group's US$14 billion stake sale. Existing shareholders increased their holdings, while Abu Dhabi's Mubadala Investment, Kuwait Investment Authority, Qatar Investment Authority, and Saudi Arabia's Public Investment Fund also participated. The sale, the second-largest secondary offering of a US company, saw investors earning a 27% return in two weeks. BlackRock's shares closed at US$536.40 apiece, giving the company a market value of about US$82 billion.

site_title: Cancer patients twice as likely to die from Covid-19: study
summary: A large study published in The Lancet found that cancer patients are more than twice as likely to die from Covid-19 than those without cancer, with mortality rates increasing as cancer progression worsens. Patients with decreased daily functioning were at higher risk. The study of over 900 patients in the US, Canada, and Spain found no impact of chemotherapy or anti-cancer treatments on mortality outcomes. The findings suggest that fit cancer patients can continue with treatment, but those with progressing cancer or poor functionality should discuss risk and benefit with their oncology providers.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares sink at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks plummeted 1.52% at the open on May 29, 2020, amid fears of China-US tensions. The Hang Seng Index fell to 22,781.11, while China's benchmark Shanghai Composite Index dropped 0.37%. The decline was attributed to Donald Trump's statement that he would hold a news conference on the latest developments. The US-China tensions have been a major concern for investors, and the market reacted negatively to the news.

site_title: Sias calls on Hyflux to seek clarity on Utico's less favourable revised offer
summary: Sias, a Singaporean investor watchdog, has urged Hyflux to clarify key aspects of Utico's revised rescue deal for Hyflux's Perpetual securities and Preference shares (PnPs). The revised offer, which replaced an original S$400 million package with no cash component, has been deemed "less favourable" by Sias. The watchdog has called for Hyflux to seek clarity on the Utico entity whose shares will be issued and whether PnP holders can choose between upfront and deferred options.

site_title: Tesla performance opens door to Elon Musk payday
summary: Tesla has reached financial milestones, allowing CEO Elon Musk to receive the first portion of his multi-billion dollar compensation package. The company has surpassed $20 billion in revenue and $100 billion in market value, making Musk eligible to buy 1.69 million Tesla shares at $350.02 each. The shares are valued at nearly $775 million at current market prices. Musk must hold onto the shares for at least five years. The compensation package, worth $56 billion over a decade, has 12 tranches, with the first one having vested and become exercisable.

images.alt_text: Tesla has hit financial marks that let its colourful chief executive Elon Musk reap the first portion of a multi-billion dollar compensation package, the electric car maker said on Thursday.

site_title: Fourth Iranian fuel tanker enters Venezuela, US slams 'distraction'
summary: A fourth Iranian fuel tanker has entered Venezuelan waters, escorted by the Venezuelan navy, amid US criticism that the shipments are a distraction from Venezuela's democratic issues. The US sanctions both Iran's and Venezuela's oil industries. Iran is providing up to 1.53 million barrels of petrol to help ease Venezuela's acute shortage. The US has called for the restoration of Venezuelan democracy, while President Maduro has pledged to reform the fuel distribution system, introducing user fees for the first time. The US is weighing a response to the shipments.

site_title: Keppel prices US$300m 5-year notes at 2.459%
summary: Keppel Corp priced US$300 million 5-year notes at 2.459% per annum, with net proceeds used for general corporate purposes, including debt refinancing. The notes, part of a US$5 billion multi-currency programme, will be listed on the Singapore Exchange on June 5. Joint lead managers Daiwa Capital Markets Singapore and OCBC will facilitate the issue.

site_title: Some 50 world leaders call for post-pandemic cooperation
summary: Around 50 world leaders participated in a UN videoconference, calling for post-pandemic cooperation and resilience. They emphasized the need for innovation, solidarity, and support for vulnerable countries, particularly in Africa. The conference aimed to address sustainable development goals and debt relief for fragile nations. The US, China, and Russia did not participate, but the UN Secretary General expressed hope for future cooperation, stating that the three nations would participate in working groups. The leaders agreed to build back better and avoid future pandemics through global collaboration.

site_title: Google cautions EU on AI rule-making
summary: Google warned the EU that its proposed definition of artificial intelligence is too broad, potentially leading to over-regulation. The company urged Brussels to adopt a narrower definition to avoid stifling innovation. Google also expressed concerns about increasing liability for tech companies using AI applications, stating it would constrain innovation and disproportionately affect small and medium-sized enterprises. The EU's AI strategy is expected to be finalized by the end of the year, with Google and other tech giants closely monitoring the developments.

site_title: Trump says will hold Friday press conference on China
summary: US President Donald Trump announced he will hold a press conference on Friday regarding China amid escalating tensions. Trump stated, "we're not happy with China," but did not provide specific details on his plans. The announcement came as Wall Street closed lower, ending a three-day streak. This move follows recent US tariffs on Vietnam and China, and raises concerns about the impact on the global economy and trade.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower on US-China tension
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Friday, tracking falls on Wall Street due to rising US-China tensions. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index fell 0.56% or 123.03 points to 21,793.28, while the Topix index slipped 0.65% or 10.20 points to 1,567.14. The decline follows US President Trump's recent threats to extend tariffs, which has caused uncertainty in global markets.

site_title: Euro steady as doubts emerge over EU recovery fund
summary: The euro remained steady on Thursday as investors questioned the European Union's ability to deliver a 750-billion-euro recovery fund amid pandemic-hit economies. The EU Commission's plan, which includes 500 billion euros in grants, has been met with skepticism, leading to a slight increase in overnight implied volatility. French Finance Minister Bruno Le Maire expressed hope for a deal in the coming weeks, while analysts see a positive impact on the euro if the proposal is adopted.

site_title: Las Vegas casinos to reopen next week
summary: Las Vegas casinos, including the Bellagio, New York-New York, Caesars Palace, and the Flamingo, plan to reopen on June 4, with strict social distancing practices in effect. Nevada Governor Steve Sisolak made the decision after consulting with health experts, citing the gaming industry as the state's economic bedrock. However, casino workers are demanding enhanced measures to protect them, including regular testing and protective equipment.

site_title: Sport steps out of virus shadow
summary: Sport is slowly returning after the coronavirus pandemic, with the English Premier League and Italy's Serie A resuming play on June 17 and June 20, respectively. The German Bundesliga resumed on May 16, and Spanish La Liga is hoping to start again on June 11. Other sports, including tennis, golf, and cycling, are also set to resume with behind-closed-doors events. The NBA and MLB have announced plans to resume their seasons, while the NHL will abandon the rest of the regular season and proceed directly to a 24-team playoff.

site_title: Keeping afloat in turbulent waters
summary: Family-owned businesses are navigating the COVID-19 crisis by reviewing operations, wealth management strategies, and succession plans. The situation is likened to a ship's hull, which can withstand external pressure but will eventually sink if the force is too great. Many business owners face operational, wealth management, and familial harmony challenges simultaneously.

site_title: UN Security Council to discuss Hong Kong on Friday: diplomats
summary: The UN Security Council is set to meet informally on Friday to discuss China's planned imposition of a security law on Hong Kong, following a call by the US and Britain. This move comes after Beijing refused to allow a formal meeting called by Washington on the same subject on Wednesday. The meeting will allow any UN member to raise concerns without China's opposition, but the details of the discussion are not yet clear.

site_title: Oil rises as higher US refinery rates offsets surprise crude build
summary: Oil prices rose 2% on Thursday as US refining activity improved, offsetting a surprise build in crude and diesel inventories. US crude inventories rose 7.9 million barrels, but refiners boosted output, and petrol stockpiles fell. The market rebounded after a drawdown at the US Cushing storage hub. Oil prices have rebounded in recent weeks on improved demand expectations, but concerns over trade sanctions and Russia's commitment to output cuts keep the rally in check. Brent settled at $35.29 a barrel, and US West Texas Intermediate crude rose to $33.71.

site_title: US judge orders 15 banks to face big investors' currency rigging lawsuit
summary: A US judge has ruled that institutional investors, including BlackRock and Allianz, can pursue a lawsuit against 15 major banks for allegedly rigging currency benchmarks from 2003 to 2013. The lawsuit claims the banks conspired to manipulate prices in the $6.6 trillion-a-day foreign exchange market, causing losses to investors. The judge dismissed portions of some claims and dismissed some Allianz plaintiffs, but allowed the nearly 1,300 plaintiffs to continue their lawsuit. The banks, including Bank of America and Goldman Sachs, denied any wrongdoing and pointed to no transactions where the alleged manipulation caused losses.

images.alt_text: A US judge on Thursday said institutional investors, including BlackRock Inc and Allianz SE's Pacific Investment Management, can pursue much of their lawsuit accusing 15 major banks of rigging prices in the US$6.6 trillion-a-day foreign exchange market.

site_title: Qatar denies Gulf bloc exit rumours
summary: Qatar has denied rumors of its imminent departure from the Gulf Cooperation Council (GCC), stating that reports are "wholly incorrect and baseless." The gas-rich state expressed frustration over the GCC's fractured state, which has led to economic and political isolation of Qatar. The GCC was formed in 1981, but has been strained since Saudi Arabia, the UAE, and Bahrain imposed a blockade on Qatar in 2017. Qatar hopes the GCC will once again be a platform of cooperation and coordination, and is urging its allies to work towards resolving the ongoing crisis.

site_title: US indicts North Koreans, Chinese over US$2.5b network to dodge sanctions
summary: The US Justice Department indicted 28 North Koreans and 5 Chinese for operating a money laundering ring that processed over $2.5 billion to evade nuclear sanctions on Pyongyang. The network used over 250 front companies in multiple countries, including North Korea's blacklisted Foreign Trade Bank. The suspects included two former presidents and vice presidents of the bank. The indictment alleges they laundered money to buy goods and enrich themselves. The indictment marks a significant development in efforts to hold individuals accountable for evading US sanctions.

site_title: Europe: Stocks rise for fourth day on healthcare bounce
summary: European stocks rose for a fourth consecutive day, driven by optimism over businesses returning to work and stimulus for the battered euro zone economy. The Stoxx 600 index gained 1.6% to an 11-week high, with healthcare stocks rebounding from earlier losses. GlaxoSmithKline, the world's largest vaccine maker, surged 2.1% after outlining plans to produce 1 billion doses of vaccine efficacy boosters. The EU's 750-billion-euro stimulus plan and potential expansion of the European Central Bank's bond purchase program also boosted investor sentiment.

site_title: US: Stocks sag on China tensions as Europe rises on restarts
summary: US stocks declined in late afternoon trading on Thursday due to rising tensions between the US and China, with investors fearing a potential trade war revival. Despite weak economic data, including 2.12 million new unemployment filings and a 17.2% drop in US manufactured goods orders, stocks initially rose but pulled back after US President Donald Trump announced a press conference on China. In contrast, European bourses advanced as more countries lifted lockdown restrictions, including Italy's Serie A football league and France's nationwide reopening of bars, restaurants, and cafes.

images.alt_text: Wall Street stocks stumbled in late afternoon trading on Thursday on rising tensions between Washington and Beijing, after European bourses advanced as more of the continent took steps to end coronavirus shutdowns.

site_title: Notes on leadership in these Covid-19 times
summary: Singapore-based Prudential's new CEO, Dennis Tan, has emphasized the importance of empathy and communication in leadership during the Covid-19 pandemic. He has implemented various measures to engage with employees and customers, including virtual meetings, online learning platforms, and digital health tools. Tan believes that by being "over-communicating" and showing empathy, leaders can help their stakeholders navigate the challenges of the pandemic. He also aims to leverage technology to improve customer experiences and make healthcare more accessible and affordable.

images.alt_text: Dennis Tan runs up to 10 meetings daily because he believes in staying engaged. He has also promoted the use of technology for efficiency and engagement.

site_title: Singapore pension system scores mid-ranking in global study of 70 pension plans
summary: Singapore's pension system ranks 30th globally, with a score of 45.7 out of 100, according to the Allianz Global Pension Report 2020. The country excels in adequacy, ranking fifth globally, but lags behind in sustainability and demographic preparedness due to its high life expectancy and low statutory retirement age. Experts warn that further pension reforms are needed to address the looming pension crisis and preserve generational equality.

site_title: China approves HK security legislation, defying Trump's threat of possible sanctions
summary: China's National People's Congress approved a proposal for sweeping national security legislation in Hong Kong, defying US President Donald Trump's threat of possible sanctions. The legislation, which includes laws banning subversion, secession, terrorism, and foreign interference, was approved by a vote of 2,878-1. The move has alarmed Hong Kong's pro-democracy activists and opposition politicians, who fear it will undermine the city's independent judiciary and freedoms. The Trump administration has vowed to take action, including revoking Hong Kong's special trading status with the US, in response to the move.

site_title: When the CEO, already facing a crisis, gets the coronavirus
summary: Booking Holdings CEO Glenn Fogel contracted COVID-19 in late March, during a crisis for the online travel giant. His wife and daughter also became ill. Fogel continued to work while ill, and the company disclosed his condition in an SEC filing. Booking Holdings laid off 3,700 employees, wrote down the values of OpenTable and Kayak, and lost $699 million in the first quarter. The company is now figuring out how to navigate the altered travel market. Fogel's disclosure was seen as a way to maintain transparency and build the company's reputation.

site_title: Renault to cut 15,000 jobs in 2b euro cost cutting plan
summary: Renault plans to cut around 15,000 jobs worldwide, including 4,600 in France, as part of a 2 billion euro cost-cutting plan over three years. The company aims to achieve the job cuts without redundancies through voluntary departures, internal mobility measures, and retraining. The plan was announced to unions on Thursday evening, with the public announcement to follow on Friday.

site_title: India might soon battle a trifecta of calamities
summary: India is facing a potential trifecta of calamities in the form of cyclones, Covid-19, and locust invasions. The states of West Bengal and Odisha, already reeling from Cyclone Amphan and Covid-19, may also have to battle locusts. The locusts were born in the aftermath of Cyclone Mekunu in 2018, which flooded the southern Arabian desert and allowed them to breed freely. The Indian Meteorological Department has predicted the arrival of locusts, raising concerns about crop damage and food security.

site_title: France to reopen cafes, end domestic travel limit
summary: France announced the nationwide reopening of bars, restaurants, and cafes from June 2, with restrictions in place, and lifted domestic travel limits for the summer holidays. Prime Minister Edouard Philippe stated that "freedom will be the rule and restriction the exception" as the country enters the second phase of its gradual lifting of the coronavirus lockdown. The restrictions include outdoor seating, mask-wearing, and social distancing measures, with the goal of allowing people to live a life "almost normal" under the new rules.

images.alt_text: France on Thursday announced the long-awaited nationwide reopening of bars, restaurants and cafes from June 2, albeit with restrictions, and lifted limitations on domestic travel in time for the summer holidays.

site_title: CapitaLand bags loan linked to sustainable practices from UOB
summary: CapitaLand has secured a four-year, S$500 million sustainability-linked loan from United Overseas Bank (UOB), with loan proceeds tied to its environmental, social, and governance (ESG) performance. The loan is not linked to specific projects or properties, allowing the group to use the funds for general corporate purposes. This loan demonstrates CapitaLand's commitment to sustainable practices and ESG performance.

site_title: Secret to Smith & Wollensky's iconic steak isn't how you cook it
summary: A new cookbook, "Serving New York: For All the People Who Make NYC Dining Unforgettable," features recipes from top chefs and restaurants in New York City, with proceeds going to benefit the hospitality industry. The cookbook includes a recipe for Smith & Wollensky's iconic Cajun Rib Steak, which is a bestseller at the restaurant and Warren Buffett's go-to order. The recipe involves marinating a bone-in prime rib steak in a mixture of spices, oil, and herbs, then searing and grilling it to perfection. The cookbook has raised $50,000 for the Robin Hood Foundation's New York restaurant worker relief fund.

images.alt_text: The book's recipe for the Cajun Rib Steak is a bestseller at Smith & Wollensky; it is Warren Buffett's go-to order.

site_title: Money FM podcast: Migrant worker's rights during Covid-19
summary: Host Glenn van Zutphen discusses migrant worker rights with Braema Mathi, a social activist and researcher, on the Money FM podcast "Weekend Mornings". They focus on the living conditions and rights of foreign workers in Singapore's dormitories during the Covid-19 pandemic. Mathi highlights the need for better support and protection for migrant workers, including improved living conditions and access to healthcare. The conversation emphasizes the importance of addressing the systemic issues affecting migrant workers in Singapore.

site_title: EHT to use maiden distribution to pay for sponsor's liabilities
summary: Eagle Hospitality Trust (EHT) will redirect its maiden distribution to pay for critical expenses of its US-based hotel portfolio, following Urban Commons' failure to fulfill its obligations under the master lease agreements. The trust urgently needs to protect its asset value and fund portfolio preservation expenses, including significant liabilities incurred by Urban Commons. The decision is in the best interests of EHT and its unitholders, but the exact cost of these expenses remains unclear.

site_title: Billionaire Carl Icahn exits Hertz with 'significant' loss after bankruptcy filing
summary: Billionaire Carl Icahn, Hertz's largest shareholder, sold his nearly 39% stake in the company after filing for bankruptcy protection. He unloaded 55.34 million shares at 72 cents per share, resulting in a "significant loss." Despite this, Icahn expressed support for the board's decision and believes Hertz can be a "great company" in the future. His stake, valued at around $700 million at the end of 2019, is now worth less.

site_title: A positive mindset is key to seizing opportunities from reskilling programmes
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has accelerated employers' willingness to consider unconventional employment formats, including reskilling programs for mid-career individuals. The Singapore government's SGUnited Jobs and Skills Package aims to create over 100,000 opportunities, including 14,000 reskilling opportunities, with a S$2 billion investment. Employers will receive wage support for hiring reskilled workers. Industry experts believe that a positive mindset is key to seizing these opportunities, with factors such as a growth mindset, willingness to learn, and ability to connect with current employees being favored by companies.

site_title: What's Up This Week
summary:
Here's a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

Singaporean chocolatier Jolyn Yong combines traditional Chinese medicine ingredients with chocolate to create unique bars. Les Amis, a three-Michelin-starred restaurant, offers gourmet pantry ingredients for takeaway and delivery. Sofar Sounds hosts daily live music shows online, while Carly Rae Jepsen releases a surprise sequel to her album Dedicated. Recherché launches a hand sanitizing cream, and the Singapore Repertory Theatre goes virtual with a live broadcast of the play Boom. Meanwhile, Netflix's Tiger King documentary series explores the life of private zoo owner Joe Exotic, and the National Gallery Singapore hosts a music recital celebrating oceanic culture.

site_title: The Office Post Covid-19
summary: Singapore's workplaces are undergoing significant changes post-Covid-19, with a focus on social distancing, improved safety, and technology integration. Companies are adopting creative scheduling, rearranging workstations, and implementing touchless fittings to minimize risk. Designers predict three phases of office design transformation, with the first phase focusing on social distancing and hygiene. Technology is also being tapped to enhance office safety, including facial recognition software, biometric fingerprint systems, and automatic hand sanitizer stations. The survey suggests that companies may consider reducing their office footprint or setting up smaller offices in several locations to minimize risk. Ultimately, the office is expected to remain a vital space for fostering corporate culture and human interaction, with designers emphasizing the need for a balance between remote work and in-person collaboration.

site_title: Singapore rates unlikely to stay negative, but may remain low till 2021
summary: Singapore's one-month Swap Offer Rate (SOR) briefly fell below zero in May, raising concerns about the country's interest rate dynamics. However, analysts believe that negative rates are unlikely to persist, with SOR and Singapore Interbank Offered Rate (Sibor) expected to remain low until 2021. The main factor driving the decline in SOR is the drop in US dollar Libor expectations, rather than large swings in exchange rates. Analysts predict that the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) will remove excess liquidity from the system, preventing a persistently negative SOR.

site_title: Filings for benefits by jobless Americans still above 2 million
summary: The number of Americans filing for unemployment benefits remained above 2 million for the 10th consecutive week, totaling 2.123 million for the week ended May 23. This is amid the deepest drop in GDP output since the 2007-09 Great Recession. Economists warn that the prolonged high unemployment rate could lead to an extended period of economic hardship, with some predicting a slower recovery. The US economy's recession signals the end of the longest expansion and the start of a deep recession, with corporate profits slumping and manufacturing orders declining sharply.

site_title: It's time for banks to take digitalisation to new levels
summary: Singapore's banks have seen significant growth in digital transactions during the COVID-19 pandemic, with cashless transactions nearly doubling and online grocery shopping increasing by 44%. The volume of cash transactions has fallen, with consumers opting for digital banking and payments from home. This shift presents an opportunity for banks to accelerate their digital strategies and improve customer satisfaction, but also poses a risk to financial inclusion. To remain relevant, banks must invest in digital technologies, fintech solutions, and talent, and consider partnerships and acquisitions to stay competitive.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Yangzijiang Shipbuilding has secured a contract worth 392 million yuan to build four 1,000-TEU container feeders for Zhejiang Seaport Shipping Company. The feeders will have a maximum loading capacity of 15,000 tons, reducing fuel consumption. Meanwhile, Broadway Industrial Group is exploring the sale of its hard-disk-drive business through the sale of BIGL Asia to a potential buyer. In other news, oil prices rose over 2% as investors weigh market outlook, tariffs, and sanctions, while US stocks edged down from records amid tariff threats and a potential upgrade at London's Heathrow airport.

site_title: Using Design To Battle Covid-19
summary: Designers worldwide are collaborating with medical professionals to combat the COVID-19 pandemic through innovative products and solutions. Various firms have developed products such as sterilizing lamps, social distancing rods, face shields, and disinfectant gloves. Some companies have also released blueprints for DIY projects, like a self-sanitizing conveyor belt and a transparent mask that allows users to show their facial expressions. These designs aim to raise awareness about the importance of hygiene and public health during the pandemic.

site_title: Bersatu sacks Mahathir and four others
summary: Malaysia's Parti Pribumi Bersatu Malaysia (Bersatu) has sacked former Prime Minister Dr. Mahathir Mohamad and four others for sitting in the Opposition bench during a parliamentary sitting. The party cited its constitution, stating Dr. Mahathir's membership ceased immediately. The move comes amid speculation over the party's leadership and polls. Dr. Mahathir co-founded the party and led it to victory in the 2018 general election.

site_title: Reins of Stanley Ho empire are in daughter Pansy Ho's hands
summary: Stanley Ho, the billionaire who built Macau into the world's biggest gambling hub, has passed away at 98. His daughter Pansy Ho, 57, is now chairman of one of Macau's biggest conglomerates and co-chairman of casino operator MGM China Holdings, making her the heir to his $15 billion fortune. Pansy will need to unite the interests of the Ho family, rejuvenate the aging casino franchise, and lead the empire through the coronavirus pandemic, which has caused gambling revenue to plummet 90%. The challenge will be consolidating control over the family's complex network of business interests.

site_title: Parisian Chic
summary: Louis Vuitton's latest bag, the LV Pont 9 shoulder bag, is set to drop on May 29. Designed by Nicholas Ghesquière, the bag features a reinterpretation of the Louis Vuitton Circle logo and a Monogram flower-inspired magnetic closure. The bag is made from smooth, padded calfskin leather and is priced at S$5350. The design is inspired by the French capital and its iconic Pont Neuf bridge, which sits opposite Louis Vuitton's headquarters.

site_title: Where's The Beef?
summary: Plant-based meat alternatives, such as Impossible, Beyond, Omnimeat, and Quorn, have gained popularity in Singapore, particularly during the Covid-19 pandemic. These alternatives offer a sustainable and guilt-free option for consumers, with some containing pea protein, soy protein, and fungi-derived mycoprotein. While some critics argue that they are highly processed and lack nutrients, proponents claim they are a healthier alternative to traditional meat and can be part of a balanced diet. Experts emphasize the importance of reading labels and choosing products with fewer ingredients and no additives.

site_title: Most businesses could reopen before end-June if Covid-19 cases stay low
summary: Singapore is expected to reopen retail shops, consumer services, and sports facilities before the end of June if Covid-19 cases remain low. The country will start Phase One on June 2, with over three-quarters of the economy expected to resume operations. Dining in at F&B outlets and social gatherings will be allowed, but with group sizes capped at five people. The government will closely monitor the effects of increased activity and may proceed with Phase Two by mid-June if community infection rates remain low.

images.alt_text: If new Covid-19 cases continue to stay low, retail shops, consumer services, and venues such as sports facilities, stadiums, and swimming pools could reopen before the end of June, along with the lifting of a ban on dining in at food and beverage (F&B) outlets and social gatherings.

site_title: US outlook highly uncertain, businesses pessimistic: Fed
summary: The US economic outlook remains highly uncertain, with businesses nationwide expressing pessimism about a quick recovery from the COVID-19 pandemic. The Federal Reserve's beige book survey reported sharp declines in activity, employment, and car sales, with many firms citing challenges in retaining workers due to generous unemployment benefits. Despite rescue measures, including the Paycheck Protection Program, some companies are offering temporary wage increases to compete with unemployment insurance. The economic downturn is expected to continue, with potential financial challenges ahead once the economy restarts.

images.alt_text: The pandemic caused activity to decline in all 12 Fed districts, most of which reported steep declines in employment.

site_title: Cannes In Your Home
summary: The Cannes Film Festival, cancelled this year, has partnered with YouTube to showcase top international films in a 10-day virtual festival, We Are One: A Global Film Festival, from May 29 to June 7. Other prestigious festivals, such as Berlin, Venice, and Tribeca, are also participating, offering a diverse selection of stories to cinephiles worldwide. The festival benefits the World Health Organization and local relief partners, while independent arthouse cinemas are struggling to stay afloat, prompting audiences to support them by watching their films online.

site_title: China Club at Capital Tower closes for good after years of losses
summary: The China Club in Singapore, a members-only club, is permanently closing after suffering years of losses due to stiff competition and rising costs. The club, which has been in operation for 19 years, was initially set to close temporarily but will now cease operations on June 1. Despite efforts to remain financially viable, the club was unable to overcome losses and will file for voluntary liquidation, with all fees and deposits refunded to members.

site_title: A chance for public investors to align health and wealth
summary: A chance for public investors to align health and wealth, as the Covid-19 pandemic highlights the need for long-term investment in health infrastructure. The public sector funds 60% of global healthcare expenditure, with governments scrambling to procure medical supplies and maintain hospitals. Institutional investors can play a crucial role in strengthening health infrastructure, with asset manager Azimut launching an infrastructure fund to invest in medical facilities. This investment aims to attract sustainable infrastructure projects and align health and wealth for the future.

site_title: Noble ex-CEO wins appeal in Singapore court over shares
summary: Singapore's Court of Appeal ruled in favor of Noble Group Ltd's former CEO Ricardo Leiman, overturning an earlier decision that he was not entitled to millions of unpaid shares. The court allowed Leiman's appeal, stating he was deprived of entitlements, including share options, but not breach of non-competition obligations. Leiman was appealing a 2018 ruling that ordered him to pay two-thirds of Noble's costs. The court upheld the earlier decision on Leiman's bonus, but awarded damages.

site_title: Pre-Fall 2020
summary: Fashion trends for pre-fall 2020 include cozy quilts, mini dresses for casual errands, frills for everyday wear, and bright yellow as a happy color. Designers like Gucci, Valentino, and Stella McCartney referenced classic crafts and styles, while incorporating practical elements. For work-from-home occasions, consider off-the-shoulder dresses and tops with built-in tailoring.

site_title: Resumption of business activities from June 2
summary: Business activities in Singapore are set to resume on June 2, following the COVID-19 pandemic. Meanwhile, Japan's Sojitz is taking control of a specialist centre for Royal Healthcare in Tokyo or Osaka. Singaporean researchers are working on a startup to halve the price of sustainable marine fuel. Local businesses are also facing challenges, including a struggling tenant at Hao Mart's Taste Orchard, with some owners stating they are barely making enough to survive. In other news, OCBC aims to provide S$5 billion in loans to serial entrepreneurs by 2028.

site_title: Tough road ahead for Singtel, even with help from associates
summary: Singtel reported a 25.7% decline in Q4 net profit, with revenue falling 10.2% due to lower mobile service and equipment sales in Singapore and Australia. The decline was attributed to the impact of the Covid-19 pandemic, which affected associates in the region a month after Singapore and Australia. This may indicate a tough road ahead for Singtel and its associates, posing challenges for shareholders.

site_title: easyJet to cut 4,500 jobs to stay competitive after crisis
summary: easyJet plans to cut up to 4,500 jobs and shrink its fleet by 15% to 302 planes by the end of 2021 to adjust to the smaller travel market post-coronavirus crisis. The airline will also cut costs through deals with airports, maintenance suppliers, and in marketing. EasyJet's chief executive Johan Lundgren said the job cuts will ensure the airline emerges as a "more competitive business". Shares rose 6% following the announcement.

site_title: Normal churn - when not all businesses can (or should) be saved
summary: A Covid-19 crisis can lead to mass business closures, but not all closures are necessarily a cause for regret. Unproductive firms can free up resources, potentially making the economy leaner and more productive. The concept of "creative destruction" suggests that businesses that can innovate and transform will thrive. However, some firms may have been heading towards obsolescence before the pandemic, while others may struggle to adapt to the new reality. Governments and experts are studying how to determine which jobs and businesses may be lost forever, and how to support industries that require continued support.

site_title: Road To Recovery
summary: Beijing's Gallery Weekend, a major art event, was held in May with less than half the usual visitor numbers due to COVID-19 travel restrictions. The event, held at the 798 Art Zone, featured 22 galleries and institutions, including a Covid-19-themed exhibition at UCCA Center of Contemporary Art. Despite restrictions, the event offered solace and perspective to visitors, and the organizers plan to expand their online presence to reach international art lovers. The event marked one of the first major art events to open in China since the lockdown.

site_title: URA launches tender for Tanah Merah Kechil Link site
summary: The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) has launched a public tender for a 8,880 sq m land parcel at Tanah Merah Kechil Link, offering approximately 265 residential units and 2,000 sq m of commercial space. The site has a 99-year lease and a maximum building height of 49-55 metres. Developers are expected to bid cautiously due to economic recession and construction costs, with estimates suggesting top bids ranging from S$820 to S$870 per square foot per plot ratio (psf ppr). The tender will close on October 29.

site_title: Japan's bond traders count on BOJ to tide over supply deluge
summary: Japan's bond traders remain optimistic despite a 59.5-trillion yen increase in government debt issuance, citing expectations that the Bank of Japan (BOJ) will absorb the supply through increased bond purchases. The BOJ aims to keep benchmark yields around zero percent under its yield curve control policy. As a result, Japan's benchmark 10-year yield remained unchanged at minus 0.005 percent. Market analysts believe the BOJ's proactive stance will limit the impact of the increased supply on yields. The increased issuance has not significantly affected market reaction, with traders instead focusing on the BOJ's potential to mitigate supply concerns.

site_title: Amazon shareholders reject dissident moves to reshape company
summary: Amazon shareholders rejected 11 dissident proposals aimed at creating new social responsibility goals at the company's annual meeting. The proposals, put forth by critics, were turned down while four other measures on board membership, executive compensation, and company business were adopted. The outcome was announced by an Amazon spokesperson without further elaboration.

site_title: Bukit Sembawang lowers special dividend as Q4 loss deepens 23%
summary: Bukit Sembawang Estates reported a Q4 loss of S$14.2 million, 23% deeper than the previous year, due to higher operating costs. The company's full-year net profit dropped 25% to S$76.1 million, while revenue increased 3% to S$369.7 million. Bukit Sembawang has proposed a reduced special dividend of 7 cents per share and an unchanged final dividend of 4 cents per share.

site_title: Are our recycling efforts going round in circles?
summary: Singapore's recycling efforts face challenges amid the COVID-19 crisis, with increased packaging waste from takeaway and delivery services. Environmental advocates stress the need for individual action and sustainable practices. As the country recovers, there is a push for businesses to adopt environmentally friendly practices and prioritize sustainability over economic growth. The pandemic has refocused investor attention on sustainable recovery, with experts exploring the intersection of sustainability and resilience in the business world.

site_title: Crustacean cravings
summary: Three veteran seafood restaurants offer high-quality crustacean dishes. Blue Lotus stands out for its signature chilli crab, with a 1kg Sri Lankan crab available for S$81. Chin Huat Live Seafood offers a more affordable option, but with variable crab density. Jing Seafood's tomato-based gravy is a lighter alternative. These restaurants also offer a variety of other seafood options, including barramundi fish head and fried beancurd sticks. Prices range from S$42 to S$88 for a 900gm crab.

site_title: Keppel unveils 10-year roadmap, to focus on 4 units
summary: Keppel Corp, a Singapore conglomerate, has unveiled a 10-year roadmap, Vision 2030, focusing on four key segments: energy and environment, urban development, connectivity, and asset management. The plan aims to shift from project-based earnings to recurring income and achieve a 15% return on equity. Keppel will concentrate on renewable energy, environmental solutions, and sustainable urbanization, with its asset management arm, Keppel Capital, playing a key role in funding these initiatives. The roadmap is being launched amid Temasek Holdings' pre-conditional partial offer to gain control of the firm, which may lead to a comprehensive strategic review of Keppel's businesses.

images.alt_text: Keppel Corp CEO Loh Chin Hua says the Vision 2030 plan transcends Covid-19 and any short-term events for the group.

site_title: MAS to create 'fairness metrics' for AI and analytics adoption in financial services
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) is launching the "Veritas" initiative to promote responsible AI adoption in financial services. The first phase involves developing "fairness metrics" for credit-risk scoring and customer marketing, aiming to prevent AI-driven decisions from systematically disadvantaging individuals or groups. The metrics will be developed by a consortium of institutions, including United Overseas Bank, Element AI, and HSBC, and will be made available as open-source code to financial institutions by the end of the year.

site_title: Businesses should beat cyber crime through intelligence sharing
summary: Financial services are increasingly vulnerable to cybercrime as employees work remotely due to COVID-19, creating new opportunities for attackers. Global spending on security is projected to reach $151 billion by 2023, with financial institutions being targeted by phishing, ransomware, and other tactics. To combat these threats, intelligence sharing among financial services organizations is crucial, as seen through initiatives like the Financial Services Information Sharing and Analysis Centre (FS-ISAC). By sharing information and best practices, institutions can stay ahead of sophisticated cybercriminal networks and protect the overall trust in the financial system.

site_title: SGX price targets slashed on MSCI licence loss, increased competition
summary: Singapore Exchange (SGX) shares continue to decline after the bourse operator lost most of its MSCI equity index futures and options contracts. Analysts from various firms, including DBS, OCBC, RHB, and Jefferies, have cut their target prices and earnings forecasts for SGX due to the loss, with some downgrading the stock. The expiry of the MSCI licences is expected to hinder growth and increase competition in the derivatives space, with analysts warning of a "big hit" to one of SGX's growth engines.

site_title: China defends economic response to Covid-19
summary: China's Premier Li Keqiang defended the government's economic response to the Covid-19 pandemic, stating that the country has room for fiscal and monetary measures to support businesses and livelihoods. China's economy is expected to grow at 1% this year, and the government will focus on stabilizing the economy and generating jobs. The government has pledged 500 billion yuan in tax and fee cuts and will issue special bonds to support infrastructure projects, but analysts warn that private companies may struggle to access funding.

images.alt_text: Beijing's focus is now to stabilise the economy and generate jobs. The official unemployment figure is 6 per cent, but economists think it is closer to 20 per cent.

site_title: Singapore launches 4.4ha of industrial land supply for H2 2020
summary: The Singapore government has launched 4.4 hectares of industrial land across six sites for the second half of 2020 under the Industrial Government Land Sales (IGLS) programme. The confirmed sites include three in Tampines North Drive 3, Gambas Avenue in Sembawang, and Jalan Papan in Jurong, with tenures ranging from 10 to 20 years. Three reserve list sites are also available, with the option for interested parties to apply for tender if the minimum purchase price is acceptable to the government.

site_title: Former Noble CEO wins appeal in Singapore court over shares
summary: Singapore's top court ruled in favor of former Noble Group CEO Ricardo Leiman, overturning an earlier ruling on unpaid shares and allowing him to seek damages. The Court of Appeal allowed part of Leiman's appeal, ruling that Noble deprived him of share options and entitlements, but not the right to exercise them. Leiman was not found to have breached non-competition and confidentiality obligations. The decision upholds that he is not entitled to his 2012 bonus, but he is entitled to damages.

site_title: US manufactured goods sales plunge 17.2% in April
summary: US manufactured goods sales plummeted 17.2% in April, the largest decline since March, due to nationwide factory shutdowns amid the Covid-19 pandemic. Sales dropped to $170 billion from $246 billion pre-pandemic, with non-transportation sales falling 7.4%. This marks a continuation of the decline seen in March, where sales dropped 16.6%. The sharp decline highlights the significant impact of the pandemic on the US economy.

site_title: China Everbright bags deal to expand Shandong wastewater treatment plant
summary: China Everbright Water has secured a contract to expand the Dezhou Lingcheng Wastewater Treatment Project in Shandong province, China, with an investment of 130 million yuan. The project will have a daily treatment capacity of 30,000 cubic meters and meet the national Grade 1A standard for discharged water. The company expects to leverage economies of scale and synergies to provide better quality and higher efficiency water-treatment services, improving the local water environment and living environment.

site_title: Retail, F&B 'elated' over possibility of earlier reopening, but see uphill recovery
summary: Retail and food and beverage players in Singapore are relieved about the possibility of an earlier end to the lockdown, with Phase Two potentially happening before the end of June. However, they do not expect business to pick up immediately. The Multi-Ministry Taskforce on Covid-19 has set a reopening timeline, but it will depend on community spread of the virus. A 4-6 week wait for dine-in and retail reopening is still expected, despite the potential for an earlier Phase Two.

site_title: Coronavirus unleashing new wave of US layoffs
summary: The US economy continues to struggle with a new wave of job cuts, with over 2 million Americans filing for unemployment benefits last week. This marks the 10th consecutive week above 2 million claims, with state and local government layoffs contributing to the decline. Economists predict an extended period of high unemployment, and the Commerce Department reported a 5% annualized GDP contraction in the first quarter, the deepest drop since the 2007-09 Great Recession.

site_title: Rated project, infrastructure firms in Asia well-placed to manage refinancing: Moody's
summary: Moody's report finds Asian project and infrastructure companies well-positioned for refinancing through 2022, despite the COVID-19 pandemic. Investment-grade companies, many receiving government support, benefit from sectors less affected by the virus. China and South Korea hold the majority of Moody's outstanding bonds, with Indonesia, Malaysia, Singapore, and the Philippines contributing smaller percentages.

site_title: Phase two post-circuit breaker could happen before end of June
summary: Singapore's Multi-Ministry Taskforce on Covid-19 announced that Phase Two of the country's three-phased approach to reopening could happen before the end of June, if community infection rates remain low and stable. Phase One, starting Monday, will see over three-quarters of the economy resume operations, with most business activities allowed to reopen subject to safe-management measures. Masks will remain compulsory outdoors, and small-group social gatherings will be allowed, with some higher-risk activities, such as religious services and large-scale events, adopting a more cautious approach.

site_title: French court faults Goodyear over factory closure
summary: A French court has ruled that US tyre giant Goodyear unfairly dismissed over 800 employees at a factory in Amiens that closed in 2014. The court found that Goodyear fired the employees without a valid economic motive, awarding an "enormous victory" to the workers. No damages amount was disclosed. This decision is seen as a significant victory for workers in France, who have been affected by the erosion of the country's industrial heartland.

site_title: Cybersecurity firm Sygnia opens Asia-Pacific HQ in Singapore
summary: Sygnia, a cybersecurity firm, has opened its Asia-Pacific headquarters in Singapore. Led by Guy Segal, the regional operations will focus on building cyber resilience for clients in finance, retail, media, and pharmaceuticals. The move comes amid increased threats from threat actors targeting Asian-led organizations and operations. Sygnia was launched in 2015 and acquired by Temasek Holdings in 2018. The firm aims to strengthen its capability to support clients across the Asia-Pacific region with its expertise in consulting and incident response.

site_title: Gojek, Grab extend support for driver commission fees to late June
summary: Ride-hailing companies Gojek and Grab are extending discounts and rebates on commission fees for drivers through to late June, amid Singapore's circuit-breaker measures. Gojek is offering a 60-100% rebate until June 28, while Grab is halving its commission fees until June 21 and offering two days of free rental per week. The support measures aim to retain drivers but may also add to cash burn amid the economic downturn. Both firms have seen demand for ride-hailing shrink, with Grab warning it may not provide further financial support beyond June 1.

site_title: US pending home sales index falls to lowest in records to 2001
summary: The US pending home sales index plummeted 21.8% in April to a record low of 69, the lowest since 2001, due to coronavirus lockdowns. This decline was larger than the median forecast of a 17.3% drop. Despite efforts to contain the pandemic, near-record-low mortgage rates are showing signs of rekindling demand. Lawrence Yun, chief economist, expects buying activity to rise as states reopen and consumers become more comfortable with homebuying amid social distancing measures.

site_title: Owe money, pay later, with telco bill relief
summary: Singaporean telcos are providing relief to customers struggling to pay their bills due to the COVID-19 pandemic. Singtel, BT, StarHub, and M1 have introduced alternative payment plans, instalment payment options, and bill rebates to help customers manage their cash flow. Industry watchers approve of this strategy, citing its long-term benefits of retaining loyal customers and supporting severely-affected businesses and consumers. The telcos aim to ensure their customers continue to survive and remain in business, with a focus on anti-churn management and cost restructuring.

site_title: Sinopec to build 20b yuan LNG terminal in eastern China
summary: Sinopec has signed a contract to build a 20 billion yuan liquefied natural gas (LNG) terminal in eastern China's Zhoushan city, with an annual receiving capacity of 15 million tonnes. The project, expected to begin construction in 2021 and operations in 2024, will be the third LNG terminal in the city. The terminal will be jointly constructed and operated with a local government-backed company, with existing terminals in the area having capacities of 3 million and 12 million tonnes per year.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed higher on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 5.77 points to 1,457.50. The gains came despite a higher volume of 6.905 billion lots worth RM5.398 billion, with losers outnumbering gainers 593 to 395.

site_title: Sias urges Hyflux to seek clarity on Utico's 'bombshell' revised offer
summary: SIAS urges Hyflux to clarify key aspects of Utico's revised rescue deal, which offers PnPs shares comprising 5% of Utico and 12.5% of Hyflux with no cash component, valid until June 4. SIAS chief executive David Gerald calls for prompt clarification on the name of the Utico entity and whether PnPs can choose between upfront and deferred options. The revised offer stems from the lapsing of the long-stop date, and SIAS expresses disappointment at the reduced terms, urging Hyflux to provide timely and transparent updates to stakeholders.

site_title: US: S&P 500, Dow open higher as Boeing resumes 737 MAX production
summary: The S&P 500 and Dow Jones indexes opened higher on Thursday, driven by Boeing's resumption of 737 MAX production. The Dow Jones rose 0.58% to 25,697.36, while the S&P 500 opened 0.35% higher at 3,046.61. The Nasdaq Composite, however, dropped 0.21% to 9,392.99. Tensions between the US and China continued to impact investors, but the resumption of Boeing production provided a boost to the market.

site_title: Trump leapfrogs back ahead of Obama in stock market gains
summary: US President Donald Trump has regained the lead in stock market performance, surpassing his predecessor Barack Obama with a 42% gain since his election in 2016, compared to Obama's 31%. The S&P 500 has surged 36% from its March lows, with investors remaining cautious about the economic impact of the coronavirus pandemic. Trump's stock market performance trails Obama's, with the S&P 500 up 34% under Trump and 64% under Obama. Trump has repeatedly highlighted the market's gains on Twitter, citing them as evidence of his success in the White House.

site_title: Amazon to offer permanent roles to 70% of 175,000 new US hires
summary: Amazon plans to offer permanent jobs to about 70% of its 175,000 new US hires, affecting around 125,000 warehouse employees. The remaining 50,000 workers will remain on seasonal contracts. This decision follows Amazon's increased sales and a sufficient workforce to justify order fulfillment, despite easing government lockdowns and rival retailers reopening. Permanent roles come with benefits such as employer-offered health insurance and retirement plans, but some have raised concerns about employee health risks during the pandemic.

site_title: Yangzijiang inks new container feeder contract worth 392m yuan
summary: Yangzijiang Shipbuilding has signed a contract worth 392 million yuan (S$77.8 million) to build four 1,000-TEU container feeders for Zhejiang Seaport Shipping Company. The feeders, designed to consider China's Zhejiang province ports, have a maximum loading capacity of 15,000 tons and aim to reduce fuel consumption. The order is seen as a positive step for Yangzijiang, which is making "encouraging progress" amid market uncertainties from Covid-19.

site_title: STI slips 4.24 points to close at 2,515.24; Singtel, ComfortDelGro among worst performers
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) closed at 2,515.24, down 4.24 points or 0.17% on Thursday. Singtel and ComfortDelGro were among the worst performers, with Singtel's earnings dropping 25.7% and ComfortDelGro's stock price falling 1.96%. Despite a 1.48% gain in the S&P500 index overnight, regional sentiment remained cautious due to US-China tensions. The best-performing stocks were CapitaLand Mall Trust, CapitaLand Commercial Trust, and Jardine Strategic Holdings, which gained 2.5% each.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: China Club at Capital Tower in Singapore closes after years of losses due to stiff competition from new F&B establishments. GIC leads a US$250m funding round in US food science firm Apeel, joined by several US-based investors. CapitaLand secures an S$500m sustainability-linked loan, while Eagle Hospitality Trust plans to use its maiden distribution to pay sponsor's liabilities. The STI slips 4.24 points to close at 2,515.24, with Singtel and ComfortDelGro among worst performers.

site_title: Moderna extends lipids deal to boost Covid-19 vaccine candidate output
summary: Moderna has extended a deal with Swiss firm CordenPharma to secure large volumes of lipids for its experimental Covid-19 vaccine. The 10-year agreement aims to increase supply and meet expected global demand. Moderna plans to supply millions of doses per month in 2020 and tens of millions in 2021 if the vaccine proves successful. The move follows a recent successful test of its vaccine candidate, which produced protective antibodies in healthy volunteers. The deal is part of Moderna's efforts to build capacity and produce enough doses to meet global demand.

site_title: Keppel Corp unveils 10-year roadmap with focus on four key segments
summary: Keppel Corp unveils a 10-year roadmap focusing on four key segments: energy and environment, urban development, connectivity, and asset management. The diversified firm aims to pivot towards recurring income and meet a 15% return on equity target. Under Vision 2030, Keppel seeks to grow its units as an integrated business through mergers and acquisitions, and divestments of selected assets. The company's goal is to redefine its business model and achieve a market re-rating.

site_title: Bike travel boosted by Covid-19 adds US$5.6b to Shimano stock
summary: Shimano, a 99-year-old Japanese bicycle component manufacturer, is experiencing a surge in demand due to the COVID-19 pandemic, boosting its stock by US$5.6 billion. The company's CEO, Yozo Shimano, attributes the growth to people seeking alternative modes of transportation, citing a shift towards bicycles as a way to avoid congested public transportation. With global bicycle and components market size expected to grow 3.5% annually through 2027, Shimano is poised to capitalize on the trend, despite some analysts cautioning that the shares may have been over-hyped.

site_title: GIC leads US$250m funding round in US food science firm Apeel
summary: Apeel Sciences, a US food science firm, has raised US$250 million in a funding round led by Singapore's GIC, taking its valuation to over US$1 billion. The funding round also included US-based investors Viking Global Investors and others. The company aims to tackle food waste and extend the shelf life of produce. With the new funds, Apeel plans to save 20 million pieces of fruit from going to waste and reduce shrinkage for retailers. Celebrities Oprah Winfrey and Katy Perry also joined the round as minority investors.

site_title: Broadway Industrial enters non-binding proposal to sell hard-disk business
summary: Broadway Industrial Group has entered a non-binding proposal to sell its hard-disk-drive business, BIGL Asia, to a potential buyer. The consideration for the sale will be in cash or equity, with the buyer planning to retain key staff and complete the sale by December 30. The sale is subject to due diligence and unforeseen circumstances. If the sale does not proceed, the buyer will enter a non-compete and non-solicitation agreement with Broadway Industrial. The company's shares closed at S$0.098, up 1.03% on the news.

site_title: David Yeung, CEO & Co-founder of Green Monday
summary: Green Monday, a Hong Kong-based social venture, has seen significant growth in the plant-based food market, with its plant-based meat substitute OmniMeat available in 10 countries. The company's efforts to promote plant-based foods have contributed to a 34% increase in vegans and flexitarians in Hong Kong, from 23% in 2014 to 34% in 2020. CEO David Yeung attributes this growth to the company's strategy of not forcing people to become vegan, but rather creating a framework for change. He predicts that plant-based food will become the present for the sake of the world, with 10% of meats consumed being plant-based by 2030.

images.alt_text: David Yeung, CEO & Co-founder of Green Monday.

site_title: Relief for restaurants as France prepares new lockdown easing
summary: The French government is set to announce new lockdown easing measures, allowing restaurants in "green" zones to open as early as June 2, while those in "red" zones, including Paris, may wait until July. Cities will reopen parks and public gardens, with mask mandates still in place for red zone visitors. The government aims to revive the economy, with a focus on encouraging cycling and reducing car use, after a poll showed 84% of respondents fear a painful recession.

site_title: Malaysia's ruling party dumps Mahathir, dissenters
summary: Malaysia's ruling party, led by Prime Minister Muhyiddin Yassin, has terminated the membership of former Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad, 94, in an apparent attempt to consolidate power. Mahathir had criticized Muhyiddin's leadership and formed an opposition alliance, prompting the party to expel him. The move is seen as a bid to maintain Muhyiddin's position, which faces a possible challenge. Mahathir's expulsion comes after he rejected Muhyiddin's leadership and party presidency, and was subsequently deemed to have automatically ceased being a member.

images.alt_text: Malaysian Prime Minister Muhyiddin Yassin's ruling party on Thursday terminated the membership of his predecessor Mahathir Mohamad, a move widely seen as an attmept to consolidate power as he faces a possible challenge to his nascent premiership.

site_title: Struggling Nissan reports heavy losses, cuts production
summary: Nissan reported a record annual net loss of 671.20 billion yen (S$8.84 billion) due to weak demand and the impact of the coronavirus pandemic. The automaker is slashing global production by 20% and closing a plant in Barcelona that employs 3,000 people to return to profitability. The crisis-hit Japanese automaker also struggles with the fallout from the arrest of former boss Carlos Ghosn, currently an international fugitive. Nissan's situation is compounded by existing problems, including weak demand and tensions in its alliance with Renault and Mitsubishi Motors.

site_title: Malaysia's FGV optimistic on recovery from sharp quarterly loss
summary: Malaysia's palm giant FGV Holdings reported a sharp quarterly loss due to lower output and demand slump caused by the Covid-19 pandemic. However, the company is optimistic about its recovery in the second half of the year, citing the return of top buyers India and China. FGV aims to produce 4.5 million tonnes of crude palm oil this year, up from 4.4 million tonnes in 2019. The company expects yields to normalize in the next month, marking a promising turnaround for the struggling palm oil producer.

site_title: Post-Covid activity recovering in Vietnam, Thailand, Malaysia
summary: Economic activity is recovering in Vietnam, Thailand, and Malaysia as Covid-19 lockdowns are lifted. The three countries started easing measures in April and May, with Vietnam experiencing the fastest recovery in mobility metrics. Retail and recreation venues have rebounded to 15% below baseline in Vietnam, while 60% in Malaysia. Domestic tourism is picking up in China and South Korea, and some ASEAN countries may open to foreign visitors from selected territories. The economists believe this could lead to a U-shaped recovery rather than a V- or L-shaped one.

site_title: 1,018 Covid-19 patients discharged in Singapore; 2 new clusters in dormitories
summary: Singapore reported 1,018 Covid-19 patients discharged on May 28, bringing the total number of recovered patients to 18,285 (55% of 33,249 cases). Two new clusters emerged, one at a dormitory and another at a different dormitory, with 373 new cases, including 372 migrant workers and one community case. The average daily community cases has dropped, and 99% of new cases are linked to known clusters.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks hit by China-US stand-off
summary: Hong Kong stocks fell 0.72% on Thursday, as traders worried about the US decision to revoke Hong Kong's preferential status amid China's plans for a new security law.
