The Hang Seng Index dropped 168.60 points to 23,132.76, while the Shanghai Composite Index rose 0.33%. The decline was attributed to growing concerns about the impact on Hong Kong's future.

site_title: K-pop group BTS's agency files review for IPO
summary: Big Hit Entertainment, the agency behind K-pop group BTS, has filed for a preliminary review of a planned initial public offering (IPO). The underwriters include JPMorgan, NH Investment & Securities, and Korea Investment & Securities. As of 2019, founder Bang Si-hyuk held a 45.1% stake in the company, while gaming company Netmarble held 25.1%. Big Hit reported an operating profit of 98.7 billion won in 2019. The IPO could provide a new avenue for the group to expand its global reach and capitalize on its massive success.

site_title: Seoul: Shares edge lower on rising Sino-US tensions, grim economic outlook
summary: South Korean shares fell 0.13% on Thursday, closing at 2,028.54, amid rising US-China tensions and a grim economic outlook. The Bank of Korea cut interest rates to a record low, warning the Covid-19 pandemic would be worse for Asia's fourth-largest economy than the 2008 global financial crisis. US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo announced Hong Kong no longer qualifies for US special status, further dampening investor sentiment. Foreigners bought $34.47 million worth of shares on the main board.

site_title: S'pore nightlife industry group supports fair-tenancy lobby committee
summary: The Singapore Nightlife Business Association (SNBA) has supported the Fair Tenancy Framework Industry Committee's (FTFIC) 15 recommendations for fair tenancy legislation, aiming to address the imbalance of power between landlords and tenants. The recommendations include rental data transparency, education, and dispute resolution. SNBA president Joseph Ong described the proposals as "timely and reasonable" in a challenging period, with 93% of its members concerned about rents and 69.2% unsure of landlord support for further rental relief.

site_title: Europe: Equities extend gains at open
summary: European stock markets opened higher on Thursday, driven by optimism over a massive EU coronavirus recovery package and growing hopes for reopening economies. The FTSE 100 index rose 0.4% to 6,171.31 points, while the Paris CAC 40 index and Frankfurt's DAX added 0.5% each. The EU's $825-billion stimulus package, unveiled earlier in the week, aims to support the worst-affected countries with grants and loans, making it the largest EU stimulus package ever.

site_title: Japan 'seriously concerned' over Chinese security laws for Hong Kong
summary: Japan expressed serious concern over China's national security legislation for Hong Kong, which may endanger the city's autonomy and freedoms. The legislation, approved by China's Parliament, aims to tackle secession and subversion but has triggered large-scale protests. Japan has conveyed its views to Beijing and will carefully observe further developments in Hong Kong. The country values Hong Kong's special status under the "one country, two systems" framework and has attached great importance to upholding its free and open system.

site_title: NLB, SPH extend free access of digital newspapers beyond 'circuit breaker'
summary: The National Library Board (NLB) and Singapore Press Holdings (SPH) have extended the free access to SPH's digital newspapers beyond the "circuit-breaker" period, which ends on June 1. The eight digital newspapers, including The Straits Times and Lianhe Zaobao, are now available to library patrons for free, allowing them to access daily editions and past issues for a week. This extension aims to support the shift to digital newspapers and provide readers with continued access to news during the pandemic.

site_title: China Club at Capital Tower closes for good after years of losses
summary: The China Club Singapore, a members-only club, is closing permanently after years of losses due to stiff competition and rising costs. The club was initially set to close temporarily but will now cease operations on June 1. Founded 19 years ago, the club cited competition from new F&B establishments, escalating labor costs, and operating costs as major factors in its financial struggles. The club has refunded fees to members and will file for voluntary liquidation.

site_title: WeWork board factions head for clash over new directors
summary: WeWork's board is set to vote on appointing two new directors, Alex Dimitrief and Frederick Arnold, in a move that could clash with SoftBank Group, a major shareholder. The dispute centers on a scrapped US$3 billion deal between WeWork and SoftBank, with SoftBank citing unmet conditions as the reason. Two independent directors, Bruce Dunlevie and Lew Frankfort, have sued SoftBank, alleging the company reneged on its promises. The new directors will form a special committee to decide whether Dunlevie and Frankfort can represent WeWork in the lawsuit.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close higher on hopes for reopening economy
summary: Tokyo stocks rose 2.3% on Thursday, with the Nikkei 225 index closing at 21,916.31, driven by optimism over the gradual reopening of virus-hit economies worldwide. Investors also monitored US-China tensions over Hong Kong's status. The broader Topix index gained 1.8%.

site_title: China will strive for positive economic growth this year: Premier Li
summary: China's Premier Li Keqiang has vowed to strive for positive economic growth this year, aiming to recover from the COVID-19 pandemic's impact without setting a specific growth target. The government has pledged increased government spending and a fiscal deficit target of 3.6% of GDP, equivalent to a 4.1% stimulus. Li emphasized ensuring stability in employment, financial operations, and foreign trade, and will introduce new policies as needed to maintain the economy's stable operation. China does not require a massive stimulus but growth remains crucial.

images.alt_text: China will strive for positive economic growth to recover from the impact of the coronavirus pandemic this year, despite not setting a growth target, Premier Li Keqiang said on Thursday, promising more support if the economy faced further disruption.

site_title: JPMorgan reshuffles South Asia leadership
summary: JPMorgan has named Leo Puri chairman of its South and Southeast Asian operations, replacing Kalpana Morparia who announced her retirement. Puri will take on the role in Q1 2021, with Murli Maiya becoming the chief executive for the region. Madhav Kalyan will become senior country officer for India, overseeing Sri Lanka and Bangladesh offices, while remaining chief executive of JPMorgan Chase Bank in India. The executive changes aim to adapt to the new economic and work environment.

site_title: Global hiring stabilises even as pandemic keeps jobs market weak
summary: Global hiring has stabilized, with LinkedIn reporting a six-week increase in job changes among its members, despite the ongoing pandemic. France and Italy are showing the sharpest recoveries, while China and the US still experience declining hiring rates, with declines of 35% and flat year-on-year, respectively. The pandemic's impact on the labor market will take years to recover, according to LinkedIn's chief economist, Karin Kimbrough.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened higher on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index increasing 5.32 points, or 0.37%, to 1,457.05. The index saw 378.37 million lots traded, with gains beating losses 255 to 124.

site_title: JDE Peet brings forward hot coffee IPO due to strong demand
summary: JDE Peet, the world's No 2 coffee maker, is bringing forward its initial public offering (IPO) to Friday due to strong investor demand. The company aims to raise 2.30 billion euros, with shares starting trading on the Amsterdam stock exchange on May 29 instead of June 3. Books were oversubscribed within hours, valuing the company at up to 16 billion euros, with investors including George Soros' Quantum Partners. An exact price and number of shares will be announced on Friday.

site_title: More than S$50m to be paid out under enhanced Work-Life Grant (Covid-19)
summary: Singapore's Ministry of Manpower will disburse over S$50 million under the enhanced Work-Life Grant (Covid-19) to help companies implement flexible work arrangements. The grant, which opened on April 20, received over 2,700 applications in the past month, more than double the number of companies that benefited from the existing Work-Life Grant since 2018. The grant provides up to S$70,000 per worker for work-from-home arrangements or S$2,000 per worker for daily work-from-home. The scheme will remain open until June 1, with companies also eligible for Enterprise Singapore's Productivity Solutions Grant for further support.

site_title: China parliament adopts plan to impose security law on Hong Kong
summary: China's rubber-stamp parliament approved a plan to impose a national security law on Hong Kong, allowing mainland authorities to operate openly in the city and punish secession, subversion, and terrorism. The law, which critics say will destroy Hong Kong's autonomy, was endorsed by 2,800 delegates with only one opposing vote. The law's draft, released last week, has prompted condemnation from foreign governments, investors, and Hong Kong's pro-democracy movement, who say China is eradicating freedoms promised under the 1997 handover agreement.

site_title: China arrests yuan tumble with stronger-than-expected fixing
summary: China has arrested a record low for the offshore yuan, steadying at 7.1699 a dollar after a stronger-than-expected fixing. The People's Bank of China (PBOC) set its daily reference rate at 7.1277, amid escalating US-China tensions. State-run banks may have intervened to stabilize the currency, which had tumbled overnight. Chinese officials favour a stable yuan, and the fixing suggests a willingness to allow orderly depreciation, but a tougher US response could lead to further weakness.

site_title: Philippines task force backs easing one of world's toughest lockdowns
summary: The Philippines' coronavirus task force has recommended easing one of the world's toughest lockdowns in the capital Manila, which has been in place for nearly 11 weeks. The recommendation comes as daily infections are the highest since April 6, with over 11% of total cases reported in the past six days. Under the proposed relaxed rules, gatherings of up to 10 people will be allowed, and workplaces, shops, and some public transportation will reopen, while schools, restaurants, and stay-at-home orders for the elderly and children will remain in place.

site_title: Germany duels with EU over US$9.9b bailout for Lufthansa
summary: Germany is at odds with the European Union over a proposed $14.02 billion bailout for Lufthansa, with the EU demanding that the airline give up some of its takeoff-and-landing slots in Frankfurt and Munich. German Transport Minister Andreas Scheuer has criticized the EU's demands, citing Italy's plan to nationalize Alitalia as an example. The airline's supervisory board is holding off on accepting the bailout, citing concerns that jobs would be lost and the market would shift towards discount airlines. The delay has raised concerns about the arrival of much-needed funds and the stability of Europe's largest airline.

site_title: Australia: Shares end 1.3% firmer
summary: Australian shares rose 1.3% to a two-and-a-half-month high, with financial stocks leading the gains, after the Reserve Bank of Australia said the economic downturn due to the coronavirus crisis would likely be less severe than initially feared. The benchmark S&P/ASX 200 closed near its strongest level since March 11, with analysts attributing the surge to short-covering and hopes of a quicker-than-expected recovery. The country's success in curbing the pandemic's spread also contributed to the optimism, with the RBA Governor Philip Lowe suggesting employment in the June quarter may have fallen less than initially estimated.

site_title: Brokers' take: SGX price targets slashed on MSCI licence loss, increased competition
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) shares plummeted 7.1% after announcing it will stop MSCI equity index futures and options contracts, save for those under MSCI Singapore, when their licences expire in February next year. Analysts from DBS, OCBC, RHB, CGS-CIMB, and Jefferies slashed their target prices, with some downgrading the stock, citing lower earnings and greater competition in the derivatives space. The expiry of MSCI licences is expected to hinder growth and slow down SGX's growth considerably, with analysts questioning whether other suites within SGX's derivatives portfolio are also vulnerable.

site_title: Britain closes embassy in North Korea, evacuates diplomats
summary: Britain has temporarily closed its embassy in North Korea and evacuated all diplomats due to the country's strict entry controls, which made it impossible to sustain embassy operations. The move comes as North Korea maintains that it has not had a single case of the coronavirus. The British ambassador, Colin Crooks, has left the country and will seek to re-establish diplomatic relations as soon as possible. Hundreds of foreigners remain in the country, and analysts warn that the North's ramshackle health system may struggle to cope with a major outbreak.

site_title: GSK to produce 1b doses of coronavirus vaccine booster in 2021
summary: GlaxoSmithKline (GSK) plans to produce 1 billion doses of coronavirus vaccine boosters in 2021, expanding its production capacity for shots against COVID-19. The company is in talks with governments to secure funding for the program, which aims to increase production of future successful vaccines. GSK's adjuvant, which enhances immunity, can reduce vaccine protein required per dose, allowing for more vaccines to be made. This move is part of the global effort to develop a vaccine against the novel coronavirus, which has killed over 350,000 people, and is expected to take over a year to develop.

images.alt_text: GlaxoSmithKline (GSK) will expand production of vaccine efficacy boosters, or adjuvants, to produce one billion doses in 2021 for use in shots for Covid-19, the British drugmaker said on Thursday.

site_title: Can China's spenders lift the world?
summary: China's household balance sheets are being affected by the COVID-19 pandemic, with personal leverage from the 2010-2017 boom taking a toll. Despite this, Chinese consumers remain crucial to the global economy, accounting for about 10% of household consumption. Their spending habits, including luxury goods and travel, continue to drive growth. According to former Goldman Sachs chief economist Jim O'Neill, Chinese consumers are the "single most important thing in the world economy" and could be key to the next 40 years of growth, with no other country likely to replace them.

site_title: American Airlines says to cut management and support staff by 30%
summary: American Airlines plans to cut its management and support staff by 30% due to the coronavirus outbreak, affecting around 30,000 employees. The airline will offer voluntary options before implementing involuntary reductions. If take-up is low, frontline employees including flight attendants and pilots will be affected. American has already seen 40,000 employees opt for temporary leave or early retirement. The airline aims to avoid furloughs and has accelerated fleet retirement, expecting to fly 100 fewer aircraft in summer 2021.

site_title: MyRepublic broadband users face Internet issues in northern and western Singapore
summary: MyRepublic broadband customers in northern and western Singapore experienced internet issues on May 28, 2020, with connectivity restored at 10:15am after a three-hour outage. The issue affected 643 reports on Downdetector and was attributed to a potential network connectivity problem. This is the third network disruption in Singapore in two weeks, following issues with M1 fibre broadband and StarHub subscribers. The Communications and Information Minister said internet usage remains within operators' capacity, despite a spike in traffic during the "circuit-breaker" period.

site_title: MAS to create 'fairness metrics' for AI, analytics adoption in financial services
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) will develop "fairness metrics" for AI in credit risk scoring and customer marketing as part of its Veritas initiative. The metrics aim to ensure AI-driven decisions do not disadvantage certain individuals or groups. The first phase of Veritas involves United Overseas Bank and Element AI in credit risk scoring and HSBC, IAG Firemark Labs, and Gradient Institute in customer marketing. The metrics will be published in a white paper and open-source code will be released to enable financial institutions to adopt the fairness metrics by the end of 2020.

site_title: China's rich skirting Hong Kong to seek asset safety elsewhere
summary: Rich Chinese individuals are shifting their assets away from Hong Kong due to concerns over Beijing's proposed national security law, which may allow mainland authorities to track and seize their wealth. More than half of Hong Kong's private wealth is from mainland individuals, with Singapore, Switzerland, and London becoming popular alternatives. Some Chinese clients have already moved funds to Singapore, and wealth managers are tapping corporate recruiters to hire Mandarin-speaking advisers in other locations. The law's specifics remain unclear, but its impact on Hong Kong's status as a global financial center is a growing concern.

site_title: Some Hong Kong democrats want Trump to hammer city's economy
summary: Hong Kong's pro-democracy advocates are calling on US President Donald Trump to impose severe sanctions on China in response to Beijing's plan to impose national security legislation on the financial hub. The US believes Hong Kong is no longer autonomously governed under American law, prompting Secretary of State Mike Pompeo's declaration. Pro-democracy activists want Trump to freeze Chinese officials' bank accounts, revoke Hong Kong's special trading status, and impose targeted sanctions on sensitive technology exports. The move aims to pressure Beijing to moderate the national security laws and protect Hong Kong's autonomy.

images.alt_text: "Our only salvation is for President Donald Trump to impose sanctions," said Jimmy Lai, a Hong Kong media tycoon and prominent pro-democracy activist.

site_title: More than 350 Changi Airport workers move to temporary new jobs
summary: About 350 Changi Airport workers have been temporarily reassigned to alternative jobs in e-commerce and logistics due to the decline in air travel demand caused by the coronavirus pandemic. The workers, including guest relations officers and ground-handling staff, have been placed in roles at companies such as SingPost and FairPrice supermarket. The airport's Changi Airport Group (CAG) has shared over 1,000 job opportunities with these employees, with some using the downtime to attend SkillsFuture-certified courses to upgrade their skills.

images.alt_text: Some dnata staff who previously worked at Changi Airport have been temporarily deployed to the SingPost Airmail Transit Centre.

site_title: Elon Musk's SpaceX suit is like a tuxedo for the Starship Enterprise
summary: Elon Musk's SpaceX has designed sleek, white-and-black launch and re-entry suits for astronauts Robert Behnken and Douglas Hurley, evoking the style of James Bond and superhero attire. The suits, designed by Jose Fernandez, a costume designer, prioritize visual appeal over functionality, tapping into the romance and mythology of space travel. The suits' streamlined design and articulated musculature are reminiscent of 1960s fashion, while their darker panels and knee-high boots add a touch of modernity. The move reflects Musk's focus on design and branding, signaling a new era in commercialized spaceflight.

site_title: Hong Kong courts groan under weight of protest trials
summary: Hong Kong's courts are overwhelmed with protester trials, with nearly 9,000 arrested since June 2019 and 1,600 proceeding to trial. The judicial system is struggling under the strain, with lengthy jail terms possible for hundreds of mostly young demonstrators. Delays are attributed to the coronavirus outbreak and a shortage of resources, with some defendants facing trial after seven months on bail. The government and judiciary face criticism for handling the crisis, with some judges accused of bias and others warning that the courts cannot solve the underlying political issues.

site_title: Billionaire Icahn exits Hertz with 'significant' loss after bankruptcy filing
summary: Billionaire investor Carl Icahn sold his entire 55.34 million-share stake in Hertz Global Holdings Inc, resulting in a "significant loss" after the company filed for bankruptcy protection due to coronavirus-related travel shutdowns. Icahn held a nearly 39% stake and had representatives on the board, but still expressed support for the board's decision. He stated that he believes Hertz can be a "great company" in the future and plans to follow the company's reorganization, potentially supporting Hertz in the future.

site_title: Thailand may lose 2 million jobs due to coronavirus: planning agency
summary: Thailand may lose up to 2 million jobs this year due to the coronavirus outbreak, particularly in the tourist industry, with an expected jobless rate of 3-4%. The country's economy is predicted to shrink 5-6% this year. The National Economic and Social Development Council attributes the job losses to the outbreak's impact on economic activity, but notes that government relief measures and business reopenings will help increase jobs.

site_title: Australia Q2 employment fall may now be 15% vs earlier 20% estimate
summary: Australia's employment in the June quarter may have fallen by 15% from a year earlier, down from a previous 20% estimate, according to Reserve Bank of Australia Governor Philip Lowe. Lowe attributed the revised estimate to job increases in industries affected by the novel coronavirus. Despite this, Lowe reiterated that the economic outlook remains uncertain. This development comes as the central bank chief testifies before a parliamentary committee examining the Australian government's response to the pandemic.

site_title: Murdoch's News Corp closes or stops printing over 100 Australian titles
summary: Rupert Murdoch's News Corp will close or stop printing over 100 Australian regional and community titles due to the market dominance of digital giants, with dozens of smaller titles set to close and an unspecified number of jobs lost. The closures, effective June 29, leave 375 journalists covering local news, down from 1,200. The company blames the double impact of the coronavirus pandemic and lack of payments from technology platforms for the move, which continues the erosion of traditional media. News Corp's flagship titles will focus more on state-specific content.

site_title: Death of Stanley Ho gives empire reins to daughter
summary: Stanley Ho, the billionaire who built Macau into the world's biggest gambling hub, has passed away at 98. His daughter, Pansy Ho, 57, will now lead the US$15 billion Ho empire, which includes 20 casinos under SJM Holdings and the Chinese arm of MGM Resorts International. Pansy, a former socialite and already chairman of Shun Tak Holdings, is seen as the clear successor due to her close ties with her father and her experience managing casinos. However, the family's complex division of power and internal tensions may pose challenges for Pansy as she navigates the empire through the coronavirus pandemic.

images.alt_text: Stanley Ho fathered 16 recognised children with four women he considered wives.

site_title: ComfortDelGro to halve taxi rents for June
summary: ComfortDelGro Taxi will halve taxi rents for June, ranging from S$45 to S$86, as Singapore starts its phase one reopening plan. This move is expected to push the company into full-year losses for 2020, despite efforts to boost driver income through delivery jobs and alternative employment. The company has already onboarded 2,000 taxi drivers for delivery services and redeployed 400 cabbies. The decision comes as taxi demand is not expected to return to normal soon due to safe-management restrictions in place.

site_title: Offshore yuan wallows near record low as Sino-US tensions worsen
summary: China's offshore yuan rose to 7.1838 per dollar from a record low of 7.1966, despite escalating Sino-US tensions. The yuan's rebound was aided by firmer-than-expected central bank guidance, but investors remain wary of potential US sanctions and tariffs on China over its tightening grip on Hong Kong. The People's Bank of China set the yuan's midpoint rate at 7.1277 per dollar, weaker than market projections, and traders expect further yuan depreciation. Sino-US tensions remain a significant weight on the currency, with US options including sanctions and restrictions on Chinese companies.

site_title: Asia: Markets cheered by reopening moves, Hong Kong limits losses
summary: Asia markets rose on optimism over the easing of lockdowns, despite US-China tensions. Hong Kong limited losses despite the US decision to revoke its special status, which could impact its future as a global financial hub. The European Union proposed a $1.17 trillion stimulus package, while Disney plans to reopen its Florida theme parks. Investors are focusing on the reopening narrative, despite concerns about the uncertain global outlook and US-China relations.

site_title: Gum, mints and snack bar sales slump, as US consumers order online amid Covid-19 crisis
summary: US sales of mints and gum have declined 30% and 28% year-on-year, respectively, due to the COVID-19 pandemic and increased online grocery shopping. In contrast, toothpaste and mouthwash sales have increased 12% and 13%, respectively. Sales of impulse purchases, such as snack bars, have also dropped 19% due to reduced on-the-go consumption and economic uncertainty. Experts attribute the decline to changing consumer behavior and reduced spending on non-essential items during the pandemic.

site_title: US Democrats urge probe of allegations regarding TikTok and children's privacy
summary: US Democrats are urging the Federal Trade Commission (FTC) to probe TikTok for allegedly failing to remove videos made by children under 13, as agreed in a 2019 consent agreement. The 14 Democratic members of the House Energy and Commerce Committee wrote a letter expressing concerns that TikTok's actions could weaken protections for all Americans. They called the company's actions a "blatant disregard" for the consent decree. The FTC has not yet responded to the letter.

site_title: Arizona takes Google to court over location tracking
summary: Arizona filed a lawsuit against Google, accusing the company of deceptive location tracking despite users' opt-out options. The state claims Google exploits other methods to gather location data, violating Arizona's fraud law. The lawsuit seeks money from Google's activities in Arizona. Google maintains it has built-in privacy features and provided robust location data controls, and looks forward to "setting the record straight." The company can still target ads based on users' location, even if they decline to share data.

images.alt_text: The US state of Arizona filed a lawsuit on Wednesday accusing Google of committing fraud by being deceptive about gathering location data.

site_title: An 'avalanche of evictions' could be bearing down on America's renters
summary: The US is facing an impending wave of evictions as government relief payments and protections expire for millions of renters struggling financially due to the pandemic. With 90% of renters having made partial rent payments, many are at risk of eviction, particularly those with low incomes and limited savings. Experts predict a severe renter crisis, with some estimating that 3.7 million eviction cases were filed in 2016, a rate expected to increase with the expiration of current protections. A federal stimulus package is proposed, but its passage is uncertain, leaving many renters vulnerable to eviction.

site_title: CapitaLand gets S$500m sustainability-linked loan; Ascott to redesign serviced residences
summary: CapitaLand has secured a S$500 million four-year sustainability-linked loan from United Overseas Bank (UOB), the largest in Singapore's real estate sector. The loan is tied to the group's environmental, social, and governance (ESG) performance and will be used for general corporate purposes. If CapitaLand maintains or improves its rating on the Global Real Estate Sustainability Benchmark, it will receive interest savings. The property giant has raised over S$2.42 billion in sustainable financing instruments in less than two years. Meanwhile, Ascott will redesign its serviced residences to create a more productive workspace and deploy digital solutions to provide convenience and safety for guests.

site_title: SGX queries UG Healthcare after shares surge 40.9% on the week
summary: SGX queries UG Healthcare about unusual price movements in its shares, which surged 40.9% for the week. The company attributed the gains to its bourse filing on May 19 announcing optimum production efficiency with a 2.9 billion gloves per annum capacity. UG Healthcare replied it doesn't know of any unannounced information, but the stock rose 21.6% on Wednesday and 3.3% on Thursday, with 18.6 million shares changing hands.

site_title: SoftBank's Vision Fund is planning to cut 10% of staff
summary: SoftBank's Vision Fund is planning to cut 10% of its staff, affecting about 50 employees, due to reported losses of $18 billion from declining startup values. The fund's poor performance has led to a decline in investor confidence, prompting SoftBank founder Masayoshi Son to consider raising new capital. The cuts are expected to be across all levels of staff, with some analysts warning that the fund's best talent may exit, further weakening its performance.

site_title: China refuses UN Security Council meeting on Hong Kong
summary: The US requested an emergency UN Security Council meeting over China's proposed security law for Hong Kong, citing concerns over the law's impact on the city's autonomy and freedoms. However, China refused to allow the meeting to proceed, with its ambassador calling the US request "baseless." The Beijing legislature is set to move forward on the law, bypassing Hong Kong's own lawmaking body. The US has also announced it will no longer recognize Hong Kong's autonomy under US law, potentially leading to trade retaliation.

images.alt_text: Washington on Wednesday requested an emergency United Nations (UN) meeting over a controversial security law China has proposed for Hong Kong, but Beijing refused to allow it to proceed, according to US diplomats.

site_title: Google sees resurgence in state-backed hacking, phishing related to Covid-19
summary: Google reported a surge in state-backed hacking and phishing attempts related to the coronavirus outbreak, with 1,755 warnings sent to users in April. Hack-for-hire firms based in India created spoofed WHO accounts targeting business leaders, while hackers also targeted medical and healthcare professionals. Google removed over 1,000 YouTube channels believed to be part of a coordinated campaign. This resurgence in attacks highlights the ongoing digital threat to organizations and individuals involved in the global response to the pandemic.

site_title: US troops pull out from Afghanistan ahead of schedule
summary: The US military has withdrawn from Afghanistan ahead of schedule, with troop levels at approximately 8,500, as part of accelerated withdrawal due to COVID-19 precautions. The withdrawal is part of a deal signed with the Taliban in February, which aims to bring troop levels down to 8,600 by mid-July and withdraw all forces by May 2021. Despite the ceasefire, which ended on Tuesday, violence levels remained low, with air strikes killing 18 militants in southern Zabul province. The Afghan government continues to release Taliban prisoners as part of the deal, while the Taliban plans to free up to 100 Afghan security force members.

images.alt_text: The US military withdrawal from Afghanistan is considerably ahead of schedule, an official told AFP on Wednesday, as President Donald Trump reiterated calls for the Pentagon to bring troops home.

site_title: Sony is planning a PS5 conference for as early as next week
summary: Sony is planning a digital event, possibly as early as June 3, to showcase games for its next-generation PlayStation 5 (PS5) console. The event may be the first presentation of the console's details, despite the company not revealing every essential detail. Sony's CEO Kenichiro Yoshida has confirmed a strong lineup of PS5 games, and the company's shares were largely unchanged in early trading. This event follows Microsoft's regular updates on its Xbox Series X console, which is also set for release this fall.

images.alt_text: Sony is planning a digital event to showcase games for its next-generation PlayStation 5 (PS5) console that may take place as early as next week, according to people with direct knowledge of the matter.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares fall at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks fell 0.41% at the open on May 28, 2020, as investors worried about the city's status as a financial hub after the US revoked its special trading status. The Hang Seng Index dropped to 23,206.75, while China's Shanghai Composite Index edged up 0.05%. The US-EU trade tensions were also a concern, with stocks globally impacted.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on virus optimism
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Thursday, extending Wall Street's rally, as optimism over steps to reopen major economies worldwide grew. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index rose 0.98% or 210.63 points to 21,629.86, while the Topix index gained 0.76% or 11.84 points to 1,561.31. The positive trend followed Wall Street's gains, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reaching fresh records despite ongoing US-EU trade tensions.

site_title: URA launches tender for Tanah Merah Kechil Link site
summary: The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) has launched a tender for a 8,880 sq m land parcel at Tanah Merah Kechil Link, with a potential to yield 265 residential units and 2,000 sq m of commercial space. The site has a 99-year lease and a maximum GFA of 24,864 sq m. The tender, launched under the confirmed list of the first half 2020 government land sales programme, is expected to attract 5-10 bids, with a top bid ranging from S$840 to S$888 per square foot per plot ratio. The residential development is expected to be launched between late 2021 and the first half of 2022.

site_title: Migrant worker train deaths shock India amid lockdown fallout
summary: Nine Indian migrant workers died on special trains during the coronavirus pandemic, highlighting the plight of those struggling to return home under India's lockdown. The deaths, including a 2-year-old boy pulling at his mother's lifeless body, occurred due to illness, food, and water shortages, and poor facilities on the trains. Indian Railways denies reports of hunger-related deaths, stating that most deceased were old, sick people seeking medical treatment. The lockdown has left millions, including migrant workers, struggling to find food, shelter, and return to their homes.

site_title: Singapore shares dip at Thursday's open; STI down 0.2%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.2% to 2,515.39 at Thursday's open, with Singtel down 4.2% due to a 25.7% drop in net profit to S$574.4 million. Other stocks, such as Medtecs International and UG Healthcare Corporation, were also affected. Globally, Tokyo stocks rose 1%, while the US Dow Jones and S&P 500 advanced 2.2% and 1.5%, respectively. Eurozone stocks ended higher, supported by a EU recovery plan, but were weighed down by healthcare and technology stocks.

site_title: Australia economic downturn to be less severe than initially feared: RBA
summary: Australia's economic downturn is expected to be less severe than initially feared due to better-than-expected health outcomes from the Covid-19 pandemic. Reserve Bank of Australia Governor Philip Lowe attributed this to the mid-March stimulus package, which is helping build confidence in the economy. With Australia's low Covid-19 death toll and controlled new infections, Lowe suggests the country's recovery will depend on restoring confidence in health and finances. The economic downturn is likely to be less severe than initially thought, with Lowe stating that "much depends on how quickly confidence can be restored".

site_title: Eagle Hospitality Trust to use maiden distribution to pay for sponsor's liabilities
summary: Eagle Hospitality Trust, a US-based hotel trust, will redirect its maiden distribution to pay for critical expenses, including liabilities incurred by its sponsor and master lessee, Urban Commons, due to their failure to discharge obligations. The trust aims to protect and safeguard its asset value and fund portfolio preservation expenses, including taxes, utilities, and maintenance costs, to prevent waste, damage, and deterioration of its hotels. This decision is believed to be in the best interests of the trust and its unitholders.

site_title: South Korea central bank cuts rates to record low as pandemic hits economy
summary: South Korea's central bank, the Bank of Korea, cut its benchmark interest rate to a record low of 0.50% in its second easing this year. The 25 basis point cut aims to shore up the economy impacted by the coronavirus pandemic. This move follows an emergency 50 basis point cut in March and unlimited liquidity through June via repurchase agreements. Governor Lee Ju Yeol may announce revised growth and inflation forecasts, as well as additional policy measures, at a news conference later. The rate cut is in line with predictions made by 12 of 19 analysts surveyed.

site_title: US coronavirus death toll tops 100,000: Johns Hopkins
summary: The US coronavirus death toll has surpassed 100,000, according to Johns Hopkins University, marking a somber milestone and the highest total in the world. The country reported its first death nearly three months ago, with nearly 1.7 million infections tallied nationwide. Experts believe the actual number of deaths and infections is higher.

site_title: Amazon shareholders reject dissident moves to reshape company
summary: Amazon shareholders rejected 11 dissident proposals aimed at creating new social responsibility goals for the tech giant, including measures to address food waste, racism, and environmental justice. The proposals, backed by Amazon Employees for Climate Justice, were opposed by the board and failed to gain enough votes. The company defended its corporate responsibility efforts in a document to shareholders, stating that it already supports some initiatives and has taken actions to address concerns. The meeting came amid heightened tensions over Amazon's workplace policies amid the Covid-19 epidemic.

site_title: Pandemic puts up to 86 million children at risk of poverty: study
summary: A joint study by Save the Children and UNICEF warns that the Covid-19 pandemic could push up to 86 million children into poverty by the end of 2020, increasing the total number of affected children to 672 million, a 15% rise from last year. The majority of these children live in sub-Saharan Africa and South Asia. The organizations urge governments to rapidly expand social security systems and school feeding to mitigate the pandemic's effects, warning that poverty and hunger can have long-lasting impacts on vulnerable children.

site_title: Trump to sign executive order on social media on Thursday: White House
summary: US President Donald Trump plans to sign an executive order on social media companies on Thursday, amid a dispute with Twitter over tagging his unsubstantiated claims about mail-in voting. The move comes after a three-judge panel upheld the dismissal of a lawsuit against Google, Facebook, Twitter, and Apple, accusing them of suppressing conservative views. Trump has threatened to shut down websites he accuses of stifling conservative voices, with Facebook's CEO Mark Zuckerberg saying censoring a platform would not be the right reflex. The American Civil Liberties Union has stated that the First Amendment limits any action Trump could take.

images.alt_text: US President Donald Trump will sign an executive order on social media companies on Thursday, White House officials said after Mr Trump threatened to shut down websites he accused of stifling conservative voices.

site_title: SpaceX-Nasa crewed mission postponed due to bad weather
summary: SpaceX's crewed mission to the International Space Station has been postponed due to bad weather with 20 minutes to go until takeoff. Launch director Mike Taylor informed NASA astronauts Bob Behnken and Doug Hurley that the launch would not occur. The next launch window is scheduled for Saturday.

site_title: Pompeo says Hong Kong no longer warrants pre-1997 treatment
summary: US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo certified that Hong Kong no longer warrants special treatment under US law, potentially ending its status as a major financial hub. Pompeo cited China's plan to impose new national security legislation on Hong Kong, which has triggered street protests, as evidence of the territory's loss of autonomy. The certification now falls to President Donald Trump to decide on US economic privileges for Hong Kong, which could have significant implications for the territory's financial sector.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Singtel, CapitaLand, UOB, SGX, City Dev, Chip Eng Seng
summary: Singapore Telecommunications (Singtel) reported a 25.7% drop in net profit to S$574.4 million for its fourth quarter. CapitaLand secured a S$500 million sustainability-linked loan from UOB and plans to redesign serviced residences. UOB shares rose 0.01%. These developments may impact trading of these companies' securities.

site_title: France top European destination for new foreign investment: EY
summary: France has surpassed Britain and Germany as the top European destination for new foreign investment, according to a survey by EY. France received 1,197 foreign investment projects in 2020, a 17% increase from 2018. The country's efforts to make its economy more attractive, including easing labour laws and introducing tax cuts, appear to have paid off. However, the number of projects may be revised due to the impact of the coronavirus outbreak, with 2/3 of business leaders surveyed expecting to revise their plans.

site_title: Negative rates 'extraordinarily unlikely' in Australia: RBA
summary: The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) Governor Philip Lowe stated that negative interest rates are "extraordinarily unlikely" in Australia due to their potential costs to the financial system. This comes as the RBNZ has asked banks to prepare for negative rates by year-end, while the RBA has lowered its cash rate to 0.25% and launched an unlimited quantitative easing program to cushion the economy's COVID-19 impact.

site_title: Trump planning new arms sale to Saudi Arabia, says senator
summary: US President Donald Trump's administration plans to sell thousands of precision-guided bombs to Saudi Arabia, despite opposition from Senator Bob Menendez, who claims the sale is unjustified given the ongoing brutal war in Yemen. Menendez, the top Democrat on the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, recalled the previous contract that was blocked by Congress after the murder of Saudi journalist Jamal Khashoggi. He called on Congress to block the new sale, citing concerns over the lack of justification for the US to sell arms to Saudi Arabia.

images.alt_text: "The administration is currently trying to sell thousands more precision-guided bombs to the President's 'friend,' Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman," New Jersey Democrat Bob Menendez said in an op-ed published online by CNN.

site_title: Singtel Q4 profit falls 25.7% to S$574m
summary: Singtel's Q4 profit fell 25.7% to S$574m due to a net exceptional charge of S$302m, mainly related to a spectrum charge from Indian associate Bharti Airtel. Operating revenue declined 10.2% to S$3.90b, with lower mobile service and equipment sales revenues in Singapore and Australia. The company proposed a final ordinary dividend of 5.45 cents per share, down from 10.7 cents a year ago, to conserve financial headroom amid the Covid-19 pandemic.

site_title: Las Vegas casinos to reopen next week
summary: Several major Las Vegas casinos, including the Bellagio, New York-New York, Caesars Palace, and the Flamingo, will reopen on June 4 with strict social distancing practices in effect. Governor Steve Sisolak made the decision following consultations with health experts, citing Nevada's reliance on the gaming industry for its economic wellbeing. Casinos will operate at half-capacity and enforce guidelines such as limiting table gaming to three people and removing every other chair at slot machines. However, casino workers are demanding enhanced measures to protect them from the coronavirus.

images.alt_text: The Bellagio, New York-New York, Caesars Palace and the Flamingo are some of the resorts that will open their doors on June 4, with strict social distancing practices in effect.

site_title: Chip Eng Seng warns of H1 loss; four sales galleries closed
summary: Chip Eng Seng, a Singapore-based property and construction group, has warned of an overall loss for the first half of 2020 due to the impact of the coronavirus pandemic. The company closed four sales galleries and saw sales decline for some projects, but managed to meet deadlines for project completion. Construction activities were also affected, leading to delays and increased costs. The group's hospitality and education businesses also suffered due to travel restrictions and declining occupancy rates. Despite this, Chip Eng Seng's civil engineering arm secured new projects, and the company has taken steps to conserve cash flow.

site_title: US Congress ramps up China pressure over Uighur rights
summary: The US Congress has authorised sanctions against Chinese officials over the mass incarceration of Muslim Uighurs in China's Xinjiang region, ramping up pressure on Beijing. The Uighur Human Rights Act, passed by the House of Representatives, would freeze assets and ban entry to officials responsible for arbitrary detention, torture, and harassment. China has denied the mass incarceration, describing the camps as vocational training centers, and has denounced the US law as "slanderous." The legislation requires a classified report on Xinjiang and a study on alleged efforts to target US citizens and residents of Uighur heritage.

site_title: Europe: Euro zone shares supported by recovery plan, banks jump
summary: The Euro zone equities index rose 1.1% on Wednesday, supported by a 750-billion-euro recovery plan to prop up EU economies affected by the coronavirus crisis. The proposal would disburse two-thirds in grants and the rest in loans, primarily benefiting Italy and Spain. Despite this, healthcare and technology stocks fell, weighing on broader European markets.

site_title: Canadian court rules against Huawei executive fighting extradition
summary: A Canadian court ruled against Huawei executive Meng Wanzhou, allowing extradition proceedings to proceed despite her efforts to gain bail. The court found that bank fraud accusations against Meng would stand up in Canada, despite her claims of double criminality. Meng will continue to live under strict bail conditions while her case plays out, and hopes for a quick mending of Canada-China relations have been dashed. The ruling has sparked outrage from China, with the embassy accusing the US of trying to "bring down Huawei" and Canada of being an "accomplice."

site_title: Another cruise crew member in coronavirus limbo dies of apparent suicide
summary: A 32-year-old Filipino crew member on the Scarlet Lady cruise ship, owned by Virgin Voyages, died of apparent self-harm, the US Coast Guard confirmed. This is the latest in a series of apparent suicides among crew members trapped at sea due to the coronavirus pandemic. The ship, which was meant to make its maiden voyage in March, has been in limbo off the coast of Florida since its cancellation. At least six crew members have died of non-pandemic causes in May, with five being cases of suicide, raising concerns about the mental health and well-being of crew members.

site_title: US: Dow ends up 2.2%, extending rally on reopening optimism
summary: The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 2.2% to 25,548.27 on Wednesday, extending its rally on optimism over the US economy's reopening. The S&P 500 gained 1.5% and the Nasdaq Composite Index advanced 0.8%. Cyclical sectors such as banks and airlines led the market, with investors drawing hope from reopenings in Florida and Nevada. However, analysts expect Thursday's jobless claims report to show a significant increase in unemployment, and some warn that the market may have "gotten ahead of its fundamentals."

site_title: Lufthansa board rejects EU conditions on US$10b bailout
summary: Lufthansa's US$10 billion government bailout plan was rejected by the airline's supervisory board due to EU conditions that would require permanently giving up take-off and landing slots at Frankfurt and Munich airports. The board refused to accept the EU requirements, which would have weakened Lufthansa's airport hubs and ability to repay loans. Negotiations will continue, and the airline considers the bailout the only viable alternative to insolvency. The European Commission has no comment on the specific case, and rival airlines have expressed concerns about the potential impact on competition and European jobs.

site_title: National Jobs Council could drive a rethink of Singapore's skills and labour profile
summary: Singapore has unveiled the National Jobs Council to sharpen workforce planning in a post-coronavirus world. The council aims to create jobs and build deep skills, with a focus on digital skills and developing skills that are portable across sectors. Experts expect the council to identify emerging skills gaps and roll out training more quickly than companies. Digital skills, such as artificial intelligence and data analytics, are likely to be a priority, but some experts also call for an emphasis on skills across industries, including cleaning, farming, and construction.

site_title: US new-home sales post surprise gain in sign of stability
summary: US new-home sales unexpectedly rose 0.6% in April to a 623,000 annualized pace, surpassing economists' forecasts of a decline. The median sale price fell 8.6% from last year to $309,900. The slight gain suggests the housing market is stabilizing, despite soaring unemployment and tighter credit standards. Mortgage rates near historic lows may be supporting the market, but analysts are uncertain about the new normal, citing sales declines of 20% or 40% from 2019 levels.

site_title: HK police fire pepper pellets to disperse protests over security bill
summary: Hong Kong police fired pepper pellets to disperse protesters in the financial district, arresting over 300 people amid renewed anti-government demonstrations over proposed national security legislation. The US, Australia, Britain, and others have expressed concern about the bill, which could lead to Chinese intelligence agencies setting up bases in Hong Kong. Protests have flared repeatedly, with many calling it a threat to the city's freedoms.

site_title: Heartland merchants to be offered discounted tools to go digital
summary: Heartland merchants in Singapore will receive discounted digital tools and solutions to improve their online presence, as part of an initiative by Enterprise Singapore, IMDA, and HECS. Over 400 merchants in Ang Mo Kio, Bedok, and Clementi will have access to curated digital solutions, including loyalty programs and payment methods, at discounted rates. The program aims to support the digital transformation of small and medium-sized enterprises in the heartland precincts.

site_title: Will S$92b do it? Jobs may be best gauge of efficacy of support moves
summary: Singapore's S$92.9 billion Covid-19 support package may not be effective in its intended goal of mitigating the recession, according to analysts. Instead, its impact should be measured by its effect on unemployment rates and job losses. Analysts argue that GDP growth is not a reliable indicator, as Singapore's open economy makes it vulnerable to external factors. A lower-than-expected GDP contraction or high unemployment rates could be seen as a sign that the support fell short. Experts suggest focusing on people-related factors, such as income distribution, employment, and well-being, to assess the effectiveness of the support.

site_title: Malaysian launches landmark case against Islamic gay sex law
summary: A Malaysian man has launched the country's first legal challenge against Islamic laws banning gay sex, challenging accusations made in an Islamic court. The case, if successful, could help combat growing persecution of the LGBT community and halt the trend of local syariah authorities introducing harsh legislation targeting gay people. The man argues that local authorities have no power to criminalize gay sex, as it is already a crime under Malaysia's national penal code. A victory could have far-reaching implications, with campaigners aiming to bring cases against other states and potentially halting ongoing cases.

site_title: US outlook highly uncertain, businesses 'pessimistic': Federal Reserve
summary: The US economic outlook remains highly uncertain, with businesses expressing pessimism about a quick recovery from the COVID-19 pandemic. The Federal Reserve's beige book survey found sharp declines in activity, employment, and auto sales, with many firms citing challenges in bringing employees back to work due to health concerns and generous unemployment benefits. Job losses have approached 40 million, and retailers are struggling to pay rent, with delinquencies in mortgages, credit cards, and auto loans on the rise. The Fed's policy-setting committee will meet on June 9-10 to discuss the economy's future.

site_title: Boeing says production of embattled 737 MAX has resumed
summary: Boeing has resumed production of the 737 MAX at a low rate after a two-year grounding following two deadly crashes. The company restarted work at its Renton, Washington factory, implementing safety and quality initiatives. However, the aircraft still faces clearance from the US Federal Aviation Administration and other regulators. Boeing has also downsized its workforce by 10% due to the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic's impact on travel demand, affecting around 16,000 employees. The 737 MAX remains a number of steps away from commercial flight clearance.

site_title: NUS raises S$300m in its first green bond issuance
summary: The National University of Singapore (NUS) has successfully raised S$300 million through its first green bond issuance, with a 10-year fixed coupon rate of 1.565%. The bond proceeds will be used to finance green projects in five focus areas, including green buildings, renewable energy, and sustainable water management. NUS has also launched a new green finance framework, which is expected to encourage other educational institutions to diversify their funding sources with green financing, according to OCBC Bank's head of structured finance and sustainable finance.

site_title: Oil slides on US-China tensions, Opec+ uncertainty
summary: US oil prices tumbled on Wednesday after US President Donald Trump expressed concerns over China's proposed security law in Hong Kong, amid uncertainty over Russia's commitment to production cuts. Despite a telephone call between Russian President Vladimir Putin and Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman, some traders questioned Russia's reliability. OPEC+ announced a four-year reduction in oil demand, but market uncertainty persisted. Oil prices slid, with some traders weighing the impact of US tariffs and sanctions on the market outlook.

site_title: Euro up on proposed EU recovery package
summary: The euro is on a two-month high after the European Commission proposed a 1.85 trillion euro recovery package to combat the coronavirus economic crisis. Analysts believe the plan could push the euro higher if EU members approve it, reversing a decline since March. The proposal aims to support member states hit hardest by the pandemic.

site_title: KKR to invest US$1b to build data centres in Europe
summary: KKR invests $1 billion in new data center venture Global Technical Realty, partnering with industry veteran Franek Sodzawiczny to develop and build data centers for tech companies in Europe. This investment follows a surge in private equity firms chasing returns in the growing digital infrastructure market, with over 100 mergers and acquisitions involving data centers announced last year. KKR's commitment of capital from its third global infrastructure fund will enable Global Technical Realty to deploy over $2.5 billion for new data center construction.

site_title: A greater need for real estate agility
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has significantly transformed the way organizations work, leading to a greater need for real estate agility. Organizations that adopt flexible approaches to operations and real estate strategies are likely to be better equipped to navigate challenges ahead. With remote work becoming more prevalent, there will be a greater demand for flexible space, and companies will need to rethink their office space needs. The "new normal" will involve finding an optimal combination of traditional and flexible space, with a focus on enhancing cleanliness, employee well-being, and hub-and-spoke office models.

site_title: Malaysia to discharge Covid-19 patients after 2 weeks even if they still test positive
summary: Malaysia's Health Ministry will discharge Covid-19 patients after two weeks of hospital treatment, regardless of test results, as they are deemed not contagious. This change in protocol, announced by Health Director-General Dr. Noor Hisham Abdullah, aims to free up hospital beds for new patients. The previous protocol required patients to remain in the hospital until they tested negative on the 13th day. The move is part of Malaysia's efforts to manage the pandemic and alleviate hospital capacity.

site_title: Virtual wallet for Libra digital coins renamed 'Novi'
summary: Facebook's virtual wallet for Libra digital coins, renamed "Novi," was rebranded on May 27, 2020. The Novi digital wallet aims to give Facebook opportunities to build financial services, expand commerce, and let small businesses buy ads on the social network. The wallet will be available as a separate app for smartphones and integrated into Facebook-owned services Messenger and WhatsApp. The rebranding comes as the Libra Association shifts its plan to create stablecoins pegged to real-world currencies, aiming to alleviate concerns over disruption to the global monetary system.

site_title: ByteDance hit US$3b in net profit in 2019
summary: ByteDance, the parent company of TikTok, generated over $17 billion in revenue and $3 billion in net profit in 2019, surpassing the US$7.4 billion in 2018. The company's phenomenal growth in user traffic has drawn advertisers away from Tencent and Baidu, contributing to its impressive financial performance. With a valuation of between $150 billion and $180 billion, ByteDance is becoming a rival to global online behemoths like Facebook and Alphabet, despite concerns about privacy and censorship.

site_title: A socially distant Las Vegas? What are the odds?
summary: Las Vegas prepares to reopen its casinos and resorts after weeks of closure due to the coronavirus pandemic. The city's economy, which relies heavily on the leisure and hospitality industry, faces significant challenges. Many hotels and casinos on the Strip will remain closed, and big conventions, live shows, and sports events are uncertain to return. To ensure social distancing, casinos are removing slot machines, increasing minimum bets, and implementing new cleaning and safety measures. Despite these challenges, casino executives are optimistic that the city will bounce back, with some predicting it will come back "better than ever."

site_title: CDL unit M&C axes 8% of global team, furloughs about 30% of employees
summary: MILLENNIUM & Copthorne (M&C) Hotels has reduced its global headcount by 8% and furloughed 30% of staff due to the Covid-19 pandemic and governmental restrictions. The company, owned by City Developments Limited (CDL), has also implemented salary cuts for senior management and executives. About half of M&C's global hotel portfolio has been closed, but the group plans to end furlough arrangements when appropriate and return employees to their roles. CDL has taken steps to minimize operating expenses through business-optimization and cost-control initiatives.

site_title: Bank of England's Andrew Bailey: UK risks 'longer and harder recovery'
summary: Bank of England Governor Andrew Bailey warned that the UK's economic recovery from the coronavirus pandemic could be "longer and harder" than anticipated. He hinted at potential interest rate cuts and quantitative easing to boost growth, emphasizing the bank's readiness to support households and businesses. Bailey's statement came as the UK economy shrunk for the second month, dealing a fresh blow to opposition leader Keir Starmer.

images.alt_text: Bank of England Governor Andrew Bailey said on Wednesday Britain's economic recovery from the coronavirus pandemic could be "longer and harder" than anticipated and fresh bids to boost growth may be needed.

site_title: EU unveils proposed 750b euro post-pandemic recovery package
summary: The European Union unveiled a proposed 750 billion euro post-pandemic recovery package to aid countries devastated by the coronavirus pandemic. The package includes grants and loans for heavily indebted countries such as Italy and Spain, aiming to help them rebuild their economies. The proposal, seen as a "European breakthrough," is expected to kick off tough negotiations, particularly with northern EU states opposing grant aid to nations already under debt.

site_title: SGX RegCo queries EHT on restructuring process and progress of strategic review
summary: SGX RegCo has asked Eagle Hospitality Trust (EHT) to provide updates on its restructuring process and strategic review, including proposals made to the Special Committee and conflicts of interest. EHT must disclose the actions taken by its Special Committee to safeguard the interests of stapled security holders. The trust's Reit manager and trustee manager are also required to confirm that their priority was the interests of all unitholders, not their own. Trading in EHT stapled securities has been suspended since March 24.

site_title: Singapore's financial position weaker in coming years: Heng
summary: Deputy Prime Minister and Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat stated that Singapore's financial position will be "a lot weaker" in the coming years due to the S$100 billion set aside to combat Covid-19. He emphasized the need to manage this financial situation while prioritizing the safety of its people and reviving the economy.

site_title: China's offshore yuan on brink of record low
summary: China's offshore yuan hit a record low, sliding 0.45% against the US dollar, amid concerns authorities may use depreciation to counter US measures amid rising tensions. The currency has lost 1.2% in the past month, its largest drop among 32 major currencies tracked by Bloomberg. This move follows a surge in US tariffs and ongoing trade tensions between the two nations.

site_title: How Covid-19 is inspiring the hospitality sector to raise the bar
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic is prompting the hospitality sector to re-evaluate and improve its services, focusing on customer care, product quality, and team management. This shift is seen as an opportunity for the industry to return to its core values, inspired by the resilience of businesses during past crises, such as 9/11 and the SARS outbreak. As the world adapts to new norms, leaders are embracing change and innovation to ensure their businesses emerge from the uncertainty.

site_title: Singapore services receipts down 1.1% in Q1
summary: Singapore's services sector saw a 1.1% year-on-year decline in Q1 2020, reversing the 4.5% growth in the previous quarter. The decline was mainly attributed to the recreation and personal services industry, with a 24.1% fall in revenue due to the Covid-19 outbreak. However, industries like education, financial, and insurance services saw growth, while information and communications services rose due to e-commerce and telecommunications services. Economists expect a broader impact on receipts in the second quarter, with information and communications services likely to continue doing well.

site_title: Hyflux rescue deal hits snag as Utico changes cash offer to shares
summary: A rescue deal for Hyflux, a Singaporean water treatment company, has hit a snag as potential investor Utico demands that creditors accept shares instead of cash. Utico's CEO, Richard Menezes, wrote to Hyflux and stakeholders, citing a lack of support from creditor groups, and now wants senior creditors to accept 17% of Utico and 12.5% of Hyflux, and P&P holders to receive 5% of Utico and 12.5% of Hyflux. The deal, worth S$400 million, was previously set to involve cash payments, but Utico is now seeking to substitute stock for cash.

site_title: Singapore's Infrastructure Asia, Myanmar sign collaboration agreement
summary: Singapore's Infrastructure Asia (IA) has signed a collaboration agreement with Myanmar's Ministry of Planning, Finance and Industry to identify suitable investors for infrastructure projects in Myanmar. The agreement aims to implement projects in the Myanmar Project Bank, which aligns with the country's sustainable development plan. IA will share best practices and knowledge to structure and improve project bankability, connect investors, and appoint advisers. Minister Indranee Rajah emphasized the potential for growth in both countries, citing infrastructure investments as a way to rebuild and stimulate economies amid economic uncertainties.

site_title: S$285m support for startups: Will vetting be stringent enough?
summary: Singapore's government has announced an additional S$285 million to support startups, aiming to preserve the innovation ecosystem. The scheme matches private investments and aims to identify deserving startups. However, concerns arise about the effectiveness of the vetting process, given the lack of experience in assessing startups during downturns. Experts warn that the scheme must be stringent to avoid prolonging the lives of weak companies, which could defeat the purpose of correcting the startup ecosystem.

site_title: Employers urge caution amid calls to cut back foreign worker pool
summary: Employers in Singapore have urged caution amid calls to reduce the number of foreign workers, citing concerns that it would negatively impact the economy and jobs. Trade associations and commerce chambers emphasized the role of foreign workers in complementing the local workforce, given Singapore's limited labor force and aging population. They also pointed out that reducing foreign workers could lead to increased costs and blunt the nation's competitiveness.

images.alt_text: Foreign workers at the Thomson-East Coast Line. Employers say they have a crucial role to play as businesses emerge from the circuit breaker.

site_title: Japan approves new 117t-yen package to boost economy
summary: Japan's Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's cabinet approved a new US$1.1 trillion stimulus package to boost the economy amid the coronavirus pandemic. The 117 trillion yen package includes significant direct spending and is the record stimulus for Japan, following another 117 trillion yen package rolled out last month. The move aims to prevent the world's third-largest economy from further recession.

site_title: Pharmaceutical exports a rare bright spot for Singapore economy
summary: Singapore's pharmaceutical exports surged 86% this year, driven by global stockpiling of drug ingredients due to the coronavirus pandemic. In April, shipments increased 174% from the same month last year. This growth provides a rare bright spot for the country's economy, which is facing its deepest recession in 55 years. Singapore's unique position as a major pharmaceutical manufacturing hub, with over 50 facilities, has helped it capitalize on the demand for intensive care and emergency-use drugs. The boost in exports has lifted shipments for three consecutive months, defying forecasts.

site_title: Boris Johnson under severe pressure to sack his chief aide
summary: Prime Minister Boris Johnson is under intense pressure to fire his chief aide Dominic Cummings amid widespread public outrage over his decision to break lockdown rules by driving 400km to his parents' farm. Polls show 80% of voters believe Cummings broke the rules and 66% think he should resign. Conservative MPs have criticized Cummings, with nearly 40 calling for his removal. The government is facing calls to "level up" disadvantaged areas and focus on more pressing issues, with some ministers arguing Cummings' behavior has damaged public trust.

site_title: Air France-KLM seeks to cut staff in revamp
summary: Air France-KLM is restructuring and has started talks with unions to reduce staff, part of a plan to unveil in the coming months. The Dutch arm, KLM, has a voluntary departure plan for employees starting June 1. Air France is discussing a similar project with labor unions, encouraging employees to move to Paris from French regions. The airline also plans to cut domestic French capacity by 40% by the end of next year.

site_title: Singapore firms to pay 5% less dividends this year: IHS Markit
summary: Singapore companies are expected to deliver US$14.2 billion in dividends in 2020, down 5% from the previous year, due to the implementation of Singapore's circuit breaker, which is projected to shrink GDP by more than 4%. The banking, property-related, and telecommunication sectors will contribute around 70% of total dividends, with payments from major banks like DBS, OCBC, and UOB expected to decline moderately.

site_title: Trafigura targets big boost to renewables portfolio
summary: Trafigura Group plans to increase its renewable energy portfolio by 2 gigawatts by 2027, up from 350 megawatts, as the world shifts towards cleaner energy sources. The commodities trader aims to build a portfolio of at least 2 gigawatts over the next five to seven years. This move follows a trend of oil and gas traders investing in renewables to capitalize on the growing demand for sustainable power. Trafigura's investment in renewable energy is part of its strategy to adapt to declining oil demand growth.

site_title: Money FM podcast: How SMEs are coping during the circuit breaker
summary: A recent Money FM podcast discussed how Small and Medium-sized Enterprises (SMEs) in Singapore are coping during the circuit breaker. Experts shared concerns about the economic impact of the pandemic, with some SMEs struggling to stay afloat. Meanwhile, other news outlets reported on various business developments, including the potential opening of Royal Healthcare's specialist centre in Japan, a startup aiming to halve the price of sustainable marine fuel, and OCBC's target to provide S$5 billion in loans to serial entrepreneurs by 2028.

site_title: Reuben Brothers to develop houses, hotel near Madrid
summary: Billionaire brothers David and Simon Reuben have acquired a 250-hectare parcel of land in Madrid, Spain, to develop 650 homes and a hotel. The project, valued at $170 million, is located in an exclusive neighborhood one hour from Madrid. The Reuben Brothers, estimated to have a combined net worth of $11.7 billion, are confident the Canto Redondo development will be another success, while exploring further opportunities in the Spanish market.

site_title: India adds troops to northern border with China
summary: India has deployed additional troops along its northern border with China, amid an ongoing stand-off that began after troops clashed on May 5 in the Ladakh region. China has placed 5,000 soldiers and armoured vehicles along its side of the disputed border, prompting India to add a similar number of troops and artillery guns. Diplomatic talks between the two nations have failed to ease tension, with China committing to safeguarding peace and stability in the border areas. The situation remains volatile, with the two nations engaging in face-offs and staring downs, and a potential extended conflict appears likely.

site_title: Covid patients were at Bt Panjang FairPrice, market in Jurong West
summary: Singapore's Ministry of Health added two NTUC FairPrice supermarkets and a market in Jurong West to a list of public places visited by Covid-19 patients, following new cases. The list now includes four locations. 533 new cases were reported, with four community cases and 529 migrant worker cases. 832 cases were discharged, bringing the total recovered to 53% of 32,876 patients. Globally, over 5.67 million people have been infected, with 352,000 deaths.

site_title: Nissan, Renault unveil steps to reduce costs, revamp alliance
summary: Renault, Nissan, and Mitsubishi Motors unveiled steps to reduce costs and revamp their alliance, aiming for a 40% reduction in model investments. The companies will standardize platforms and focus on each other's strengths, with Nissan on autonomous driving, Renault on electric cars, and Mitsubishi on plug-in hybrids. The measures follow a fresh start for the partnership, which faces challenges from the global pandemic and electric vehicle shift. Renault plans a 2 billion-euro cost-cutting plan, while Nissan is expected to announce a 300 billion yen cost-cutting plan, including shutting production lines and phasing out the Datsun brand.

site_title: Chip Eng Seng files suit after Australian childcare business acquisition falls through
summary: Chip Eng Seng has filed a lawsuit after its proposed acquisition of a childcare business in Australia fell through. The company paid a deposit of A$350,000, which will be refunded if conditions aren't met by April 1. Guarantors Aditya Singh and Tashika Setia have jointly and severally guaranteed the vendor's obligations. The termination of the contract-of-sale marks a setback for Chip Eng Seng, which had planned to acquire Tarneit West Childcare in Victoria. The company will seek a refund of the deposit.

site_title: US strips Hong Kong of special status
summary: US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo declared Hong Kong no longer autonomous from China, stripping it of special status under US law. This move comes ahead of a key vote by Beijing on a new security law. Pompeo stated that Hong Kong's autonomy is not being upheld, contradicting the US's previous hopes that the territory would serve as a model for China. The US has certified that Hong Kong no longer warrants separate trading status.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: The Trendlines Group has invested in Saturas, an Israel-based precision irrigation-management system for agriculture. Saturas' decision-support system measures water stress in plant tissues, enabling farmers to plan irrigation exactly. Meanwhile, Chip Eng Seng terminated a childcare business acquisition contract in Victoria, Australia, and initiated legal proceedings for a refund. UNUSUAL Limited posted a 52% decline in net profit to S$6.3 million for the FY ended March 31, despite 9% revenue growth.

site_title: Taiwan pledges action plan for HK activists seeking sanctuary
summary: Taiwan's President Tsai Ing-wen has pledged a humanitarian "action plan" for Hong Kong activists seeking sanctuary on the self-ruled democratic island. The plan will provide complete planning for Hong Kong people's residency, accommodation, and care. The move comes amid rising fears that Beijing's national security law plans will quash pro-democracy protests in Hong Kong. Over 5,000 Hong Kongers have moved to Taiwan in the past year, and rights groups are urging the government to enact a refugee law to help protesters fleeing to the island.

site_title: Post-Covid secret weapon comes out of the shadows
summary: A colossal amount of unused private capital stands ready to be deployed into global projects, potentially neutralizing the economic effects of Covid-19. This unused capital, estimated to be in the multi-million-dollar range, was first identified in the 2006 OECD Global Pensions Report as a result of excessive liquidity in family offices, hedge, and private equity funds. Despite this warning since 2005, the trend remains unchanged, suggesting that private capital is still unable to generate meaningful returns. This unused capital could provide a "secret weapon" to mitigate the long-term impact of Covid-19 on the global economy.

site_title: A new way of doing things after the circuit breaker lifts
summary: Singapore begins its first phase of reopening on June 2 after the circuit breaker, with a focus on creating safer workspaces. Office designers suggest innovative solutions, such as hot desking, touchless fittings, and enhanced cleaning. Meanwhile, alternative meats like Impossible and OmniMeat gain popularity amid concerns over food safety and environmental sustainability. The magazine also features pre-fall fashion highlights, innovative pandemic products, and the post-lockdown opening of Gallery Weekend Beijing.

site_title: Long lost Philip Glass work recorded, finally
summary: Philip Glass's 1970 composition "Music in Eight Parts" has been rediscovered and recorded after being lost for decades. The manuscript resurfaced in 2017 and was later released on a recording by Orange Mountain Music. The piece, featuring rhythmic shifts and intricate contrapuntal voices, was initially performed only a handful of times before being shelved. Recent rehearsals and a recording have brought the work back into the repertoire, with plans for a live performance in Athens this autumn.

site_title: Sharing of rent liabilities will hit office, industrial Reits more
summary: A new Bill in Singapore will require landlords to provide rental waivers to small- and medium-sized enterprise (SME) tenants that have suffered significant revenue drops. Most retail Reits have already given out 0.4 to 3 months of rental rebates, while office and industrial Reits have taken a more targeted approach. The bill may disproportionately impact industrial and office Reits, which will need to offer greater rebates to tenants. Analysts recommend investors stick with liquid, large-cap Reits with strong sponsors and healthy balance sheets, and consider deeply discounted Reits.

site_title: HK, Huawei could 'deep freeze' UK-China ties
summary: The UK government is reviewing its decision to allow Huawei to supply 35% of UK 5G networks, amid growing concerns over China's human rights record and anti-competitive practices. The review, sparked by US sanctions and a draft Chinese security law on Hong Kong, could lead to a "deep freeze" in UK-China ties.
