By adopting a materiality assessment and integrating ESG into investment decisions, banks can unlock the value of sustainability and contribute to a more sustainable future.

site_title: 'No evidence of anti-competitive behaviour by petrol firms'
summary: Singapore's petrol companies have no evidence of anti-competitive behavior, despite tracking each other's moves, according to Senior Parliamentary Secretary for Trade and Industry Tan Wu Meng. A 2017 study found that prices do not always move in sync, and factors such as refining demand, storage, and operating costs affect retail petrol prices. While refineries may reduce production to clear excess supply, this can lead to upward pressure on prices. The government is prepared to work with consumers and companies to provide more cost breakdown information.

site_title: Companies need to be proactive in digital revolution
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has accelerated the need for businesses to undergo digital transformation, with companies that were prepared and adaptable showing fewer challenges. The Singapore government has announced a S$750 million package to support businesses, including a Digital Resilience Bonus and funding for developing offline-to-online business models. Upskilling and reskilling of the workforce are seen as key to innovation, with the National Jobs Council aiming to develop deeper skills and reimagine the workforce of the future.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: GSH Corporation proposed repurchasing up to S$20 million of its S$70 million notes due 2020 in cash at par, together with accrued interest. The move falls under its S$800 million multicurrency medium-term note programme. This is part of the company's efforts to manage its debt and financial obligations.

site_title: US, Europe to fall behind Asia if stagflation grips the West
summary: Asian economies are likely to outperform the US and Europe if stagflation grips the West, due to bailouts and inadequate investment in Western banks and equipment. Stagflation, a combination of stagnant growth and rising inflation, could lead to currency and financial instability. Economists debate whether disinflation and deflation will persist or inflation will accelerate. Some forecast inflation of around 5% in the US, while others warn of excessive debt limiting spending and leading to low inflation. Historically, stagflation occurred in the 1970s, with oil price shocks and limited recoveries, resulting in accelerating inflation and rising interest rates.

site_title: Drones might provide the solution to the next crisis
summary: Drones are being considered as a potential solution to future crises, such as pandemics, extreme weather, and terror threats, due to their ability to reduce human-to-human contact and operate in extreme conditions. With benefits including reduced risk of accidents, 24/7 operation, and low energy costs, drones could be used for transportation of humans, goods, and services. However, technological, safety, and regulatory issues must be addressed, as well as public acceptance and potential job displacement concerns.

site_title: Singapore's fiscal position strong amid further deficit, reserve draw
summary: Singapore's FY2020 budget deficit is expected to increase to S$74.3 billion, or 15.4% of GDP, due to the COVID-19 pandemic. Despite the large deficit, the country's fiscal position remains strong thanks to its massive reserves. The government is drawing on its reserves to support economic recovery and emergence. The overall deficit is the largest since Singapore's independence.

site_title: Warburg Pincus to own 48.7% of ARA
summary: US private equity firm Warburg Pincus is set to own nearly half of ARA Asset Management, following the exit of Chinese trust AVIC Trust. AVIC Trust will dispose of its 20.48% stake, while Warburg Pincus will raise its stake to 48.70% from 30.72%. Other pre-privatisation shareholders, including Straits Trading and JL Investment Group, will also increase their ownership to aggregate 51.30%. The changes are expected to complete by May 31, 2021.

site_title: With VCs turning cautious, government's extra S$285m to catalyse startup funding timely
summary: Singapore's government has allocated an additional S$285 million to match private investments in promising startups, aiming to support them through the COVID-19 crisis. This move comes as venture capital firms become more cautious and startups struggle to access loans due to credit-assessment criteria set by banks. The funds will be deployed by EDBI and SEEDS Capital to support startups in sectors the government aims to grow, such as telemedicine and online conferencing tools. The government's measures, including the SGUnited Traineeship scheme, aim to provide startups with the resources needed to recover from the crisis.

site_title: S$800m more put aside as aid for individuals
summary: The Singapore government has set aside an additional S$800 million for the Covid-19 Support Grant, providing aid to individuals who have lost jobs, are on no-pay leave, or face salary cuts. In three weeks, the government received about 48,000 applications. This move comes as the country navigates the ongoing pandemic.

site_title: Macau casino tycoon Stanley Ho dies at 98
summary: Macau casino tycoon Stanley Ho, 98, died peacefully, leaving behind a business empire valued at around $6 billion. He transformed Macau into the world's biggest casino centre, outpacing Las Vegas, and held a monopoly until 2002. His family, particularly daughter Pansy, is expected to play a significant role in the company's future, leading to potential ownership changes and a surge in shares of SJM Holdings, Shun Tak Holdings, and Melco International Development.

images.alt_text: Macau tycoon Stanley Ho with fourth wife Angela Leong On Kei and son Mario Ho.

site_title: Only a few hedge funds made money in March and April. Here's how
summary: Only 13% of hedge funds globally made money in both March and April, according to Bloomberg data. A few hedge funds managed to beat the market, including Nicolas Bryon's Atlantic Pacific Australian Equity Fund, which rose 23.6% during the period, and AVM Global Opportunity Fund, which delivered annualized returns of 9.9%. Funds that excelled were those with diversified portfolios, such as those with investments in China, and those that took a risk-averse approach, such as AVM Global Opportunity Fund's focus on government bonds and cash.

site_title: Steadying the ship for private banking clients
summary: Top private bankers advise clients to stay engaged, hunt for value, and focus on long-term growth trends amid the COVID-19 pandemic. They recommend diversifying portfolios with asset classes such as gold, short-end US Treasuries, and investment-grade corporate bonds. For bearish investors, principal-protected investment solutions can provide a feasible option. Clients are advised to gradually accumulate exposure to megatrend investment themes like 5G, health technology, and artificial intelligence during market weaknesses. Private banks are providing holistic advice to ensure clients' wealth can endure through difficult times, leveraging digital solutions and traditional tools to deliver timely advice and address clients' needs.

site_title: Scale, speed of China's vaccine developers puts pressure on US
summary: China is rapidly developing its own COVID-19 vaccines, with five vaccines being tested on humans, surpassing any other country. An early-stage study published in The Lancet showed an experimental vaccine from CanSino Biologics Inc. to be safe and generate an immune response. China aims to produce a successful vaccine globally and has pledged to make it accessible to developing countries. This development puts pressure on the US, which has launched Operation Warp Speed, and raises concerns about the potential use of vaccines for geopolitical purposes.

site_title: Don't let US-China economic rivalry turn into Cold War 2.0
summary: The US-China economic rivalry has sparked concerns of a potential new Cold War. However, a "Cold War 2.0" could be avoided if the US continues its live-and-let-live approach, focusing on economic and strategic interests rather than ideological differences. Unlike the former Soviet Union, China has not sought to export its authoritarian model globally, and the US has refrained from depicting its relationship with China as a contest between ideologies. Instead, US President Trump's goal has been to change the economic balance of power between the two powers, which could prevent the rivalry from escalating into a Cold War.

site_title: Singapore's headline inflation turns negative in April
summary: Singapore's headline inflation turned negative in April at -0.7%, easing from March's zero figure. Lower oil prices, a softening labour market, and deteriorating consumer demand are expected to keep domestic prices in check. Core inflation also fell to -0.3% for the third straight month, with private transport costs declining sharply due to a drop in petrol prices and suspended Electronic Road Pricing charges. Economists predict deflation for Singapore's consumer prices in the year ahead, with risks to the downside.

site_title: DBS, Maybank KE cut target price for ComfortDelGro
summary: Two analysts lowered their target prices for ComfortDelGro Corp's stock, citing lower rail ridership in Singapore, a weaker Australian dollar, and fewer routes in the UK. Maybank Kim Eng maintained a "buy" call with a reduced target price of S$1.98, while DBS Group Research cut its target price to S$1.50 due to higher-than-expected operating costs. Analysts expect a gradual recovery in the company's taxi business as restrictions ease, but note risks including loss of bus contracts and heightened competition from private hire companies.

site_title: Tharman to head new National Jobs Council
summary: Singapore is setting up a National Jobs Council with Senior Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam at its helm to oversee the SGUnited Jobs and Skills Package worth S$2 billion. The council's efforts will be integrated with the Future Economy Council's sectoral industry transformation maps. Tharman, who has expertise in finance and education, will oversee public- and private-sector hiring drives, traineeships, and full-time courses benefiting over 95,500 workers this year. The initiative aims to add positions and train workers amid the COVID-19 pandemic.

site_title: 3 lessons from investing in the era of Covid-19
summary: A recent "Zoom lunch" by The Smart Investor team discussed key takeaways from investing in the era of Covid-19. The team highlighted three essential lessons: investing in the era of Covid-19, dollar asset diversification, and the importance of productivity gains. They also touched on trends such as de-dollarisation, shifting safe havens, and the growth of ETFs in Asia and Europe. The discussion emphasized the need for investors to adapt to changing market conditions and focus on long-term wealth creation.

site_title: Tencent to invest 500b yuan in new infrastructure
summary: Tencent Holdings plans to invest 500 billion yuan (S$99 billion) in new technology infrastructure over the next five years, focusing on cloud computing, AI, 5G networks, blockchain, and cybersecurity. The move aims to expand the company's business services as consumer internet growth slows. Tencent Cloud currently holds 18% of China's cloud market, trailing Alibaba Group Holding Ltd. The investment is part of a broader call by Beijing to drive a tech-driven structural upgrade of the country's economy through investment in "new infrastructure".

site_title: Infographic: Fortitude Budget
summary: Singapore has announced the Fortitude Budget, a stimulus package to support the country's economy amid the COVID-19 pandemic. The budget includes measures to boost employment, support small businesses, and promote sustainable industries. Key initiatives include a new grant of up to S$100,000 for tariff-hit businesses and a focus on advancing sustainable aviation and advanced chip packaging. The government also aims to help workers future-proof their careers and provide training support for those in need. These measures aim to mitigate the economic impact of the pandemic and position Singapore for long-term growth.

site_title: HK leader says proposed national security law not a threat to freedoms
summary: Hong Kong leader Carrie Lam said the proposed national security law would not threaten the city's freedoms, despite concerns from business leaders and diplomats. The law aims to tackle secession, subversion, and terrorism, but critics say it would erode freedoms. Protests against the law and a national anthem bill have intensified, with online forums calling for a general strike and demonstrations. The US and Britain have expressed concerns over the law, which they say would undermine Hong Kong's autonomy.

site_title: Pandemic sparks prudence among Asia's family offices
summary: Asia's family offices have become increasingly prudent amid the pandemic, prioritizing liquidity and cautious investments. Unlike Western family offices, which are often in their third to fifth generations, Asian family offices are relatively young, with many still in their first or second generation. As a result, they are taking a more defensive approach, focusing on boosting liquidity and avoiding long-term commitments. The pandemic has also prompted Asian family offices to reevaluate their legacy and philanthropic efforts, with a growing focus on social capital and sustainability.

site_title: SMEs get over S$500 million funding boost to go digital - starting with F&B and retail
summary: The Singapore government has allocated over S$500 million to support digital transformation for small and mid-sized enterprises (SMEs), primarily targeting the food and beverage (F&B) and retail sectors. The measures include bonuses and incentives to encourage e-payment adoption, digital resilience bonuses, and support for adopting advanced digital solutions. Experts emphasize the need for proper change management to ensure SMEs can successfully adopt digitalization and stay on track, citing the importance of reskilling workers, ease of use, and overall cost.

site_title: Don't write off globalisation just yet
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic is exacerbating the already strained globalisation, with the US, China, and other countries experiencing increased tensions and disruptions. US President Donald Trump is pushing for a more national-security driven approach, reversing global supply chains and on-shoring industries. This shift could reverse the post-Cold War era of open markets and borders, threatening the liberal world order. However, countervailing developments, such as economic multilateralism and international institutions, suggest that globalisation may not unravel completely, and a more inclusive and sustainable globalisation could emerge. The US-China relationship remains a key driver of globalisation, with growing bilateral rivalry and potential for fruitful partnerships on issues like climate change.

site_title: Too long onboard but, perhaps, less time spent working
summary: The International Chamber of Shipping, International Trade Union Confederation, and International Transport Workers' Federation have urged the UN secretary-general to persuade 193 member states to act urgently to alleviate the humanitarian crisis faced by over 200,000 seafarers stuck at sea due to the COVID-19 pandemic. The seafarers are experiencing fatigue, exhaustion, and mental health issues due to stringent restrictions on shore leave and access to medical assistance. Industry leaders argue that governments must adhere to the UN Guiding Principles on Business and Human Rights, and that time is running out to implement crew changes by June 16, 2020.

site_title: Cathay Pacific's brand merger hits roadblock from China's aviation regulator: sources
summary: China's aviation regulator may block Cathay Pacific's merger of regional arm Cathay Dragon into its main brand due to infractions during last year's pro-democracy protests. The CAAC could deny Cathay access to 20 mainland routes flown only by Dragon, forcing the airline to cut costs and consolidate contracts. Cathay has received six demerit points, which could take a year to be cleared, and is considering cost-cutting measures such as moving veteran pilots to cheaper contracts. The airline is also exploring options like early retirement offers and layoffs.

site_title: Fortifying businesses in a Covid-19 economy
summary: Singapore's government has introduced the Fortitude Budget to help the country navigate its new normal amidst the COVID-19 pandemic. The budget includes measures to preserve and protect jobs, with a focus on digital transformation to support businesses' recovery and resilience. The government has set aside S$3.8 billion for the Job Support Scheme and S$250 million for digital transformation initiatives. The budget aims to address the challenges posed by COVID-19, including job displacement and digital transformation, and to ensure a sustainable future for businesses and workers.

images.alt_text: Even as Singapore moves towards a phased reopening of its economy and transitions out of the circuit breaker, there still remains much uncertainty about how businesses will be able to recover.

site_title: Giving in times of need - balancing immediate and longer-term philanthropy
summary: A global response to the coronavirus emergency has seen numerous examples of community and institutional efforts to support those in need. The World Health Organization and Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation have committed significant funds to develop a vaccine and strengthen health infrastructure. Meanwhile, organizations such as the Jack Ma Foundation are working on vaccine development in Asia. Effective philanthropic projects require a balance between immediate and longer-term support, emphasizing the importance of long-term thinking in rebuilding resilient communities and addressing health-related issues.

site_title: Supporting digital payments is the way to inclusive growth
summary: Digital payments are becoming a lifeline for consumers and businesses in South-east Asia, particularly during the COVID-19 pandemic. The shift towards digital payments is expected to continue, driven by governments and businesses adopting contactless and wallet-based solutions. To achieve widespread adoption, three key areas must be addressed: educating consumers about the benefits and mechanics of digital payments, supporting merchants and sectors lacking e-payment infrastructures, and driving public-private partnerships to make digital payments accessible to all. This can lead to inclusive growth and ensure nobody is left behind.

site_title: For banking to go digital, the first steps need to begin with empathy
summary: Banks are experiencing surges in online transactions as the COVID-19 pandemic limits physical interactions. However, a recent anecdote highlights the need for empathy in digital banking, as a customer was denied a better mortgage rate by their existing bank despite being offered a similar rate by a competitor. This experience underscores the importance of anticipating pain points and using technology to solve customer issues, rather than simply automating them. By prioritizing customer service and empathy, banks can improve their digital capabilities and stay ahead of the competition in the post-pandemic banking landscape.

site_title: Improving investor sentiment lifts euro
summary: The euro rose 0.6% against the US dollar on Tuesday, driven by growing optimism about a global economic recovery from the Covid-19 pandemic. A weaker US dollar and rising investor sentiment lifted euro values, with other riskier currencies such as the Australian and New Zealand dollars also gaining. However, Sino-US tensions kept the mood in check, and the euro's appreciation is expected to be short-lived due to ongoing disagreements within the EU about a corona-recovery fund.

site_title: Suspended home renovation jobs to be given priority ahead of new works
summary: Singapore's government will prioritize resuming suspended home renovation jobs in Phase 1 of the post-circuit breaker period, with existing projects allowed to proceed first. For new projects, contractors must demonstrate safety measures are in place to be considered for early resumption. The government has also made exemptions for minor works and offered subsidized rates for temporary accommodation to affected homebuyers. Despite this, some home renovation workers face a labor crunch, and stringent requirements may delay work even after resumption.

site_title: Mapletree donates over 2 million disposable medical masks
summary: Mapletree Investments Pte Ltd donated over 2 million disposable medical masks to more than 30 beneficiaries in seven countries, including Singapore, Malaysia, and India, to aid in the COVID-19 battle and alleviate mask shortages. The masks were distributed to frontline agencies, medical workers, and community caregivers for vulnerable groups. The donation, valued at a significant amount, conveys the company's commitment to corporate social responsibility and supporting local communities in need.

site_title: S$33b more to help firms, households, and to save, create jobs
summary: Deputy Prime Minister and Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat unveiled a S$33 billion Fortitude Budget to support firms, households, and create jobs. The budget aims to create 95,000 jobs and training places, with a focus on supporting small and medium enterprises, and providing targeted support for the needy and vulnerable. The total government support in the Covid-19 crisis has risen to S$92.9 billion, or almost a fifth of GDP. The budget includes wage support enhancements, rental waivers, and financing for startups, with the goal of helping Singapore recover from the pandemic and emerge stronger.

images.alt_text: With unprecedented levels of uncertainty in the Covid-19 crisis, the government will set aside an additional S$13 billion in the Contingencies Funds "so that we can respond to urgent and unforeseen needs swiftly", says Mr Heng.

site_title: China's mask boom takes raw materials away from nappy makers
summary: China's surge in mask production to combat the COVID-19 pandemic has led to a shortage of raw materials, affecting the production of hygiene products such as nappies, wet wipes, and sanitary towels. Manufacturers are halving production or increasing prices due to high costs, with some firms producing nappies at a loss. The industry is concerned about the future of supply lines, with suppliers making 10 times more profit by using raw materials for mask production. The shortage is expected to have a broader impact, potentially affecting global supplies.

site_title: DLF Holdings to call EGM to seek shareholders' nod to expand into blockchain
summary: DLF Holdings, a Catalist-listed company, is convening an extraordinary general meeting (EGM) to seek shareholders' approval for its plan to diversify into a new business area focused on blockchain agency and related businesses. The company aims to reduce its reliance on existing mechanical and electrical services and provide new revenue streams. The proposed diversification is expected to be complementary to its existing business, enabling access to new opportunities in blockchain-based payments and project management tools for the construction industry.

site_title: Oil gains on hopes market may balance in coming weeks
summary: Oil prices rose above $34 a barrel on expectations that the market may balance in June or July due to historic output cuts from global producers. Russia, a key Opec+ member, predicts the market will rebalance as it has already exceeded agreed supply cuts. The International Energy Agency sees oil consumption rebounding past pre-virus levels, leading to higher prices. Despite producers slashing global production by 14-15 million barrels a day, pockets of oversupply remain, with Nigeria lifting its selling price for supplies in June from record lows.

site_title: Ryanair to appeal Lufthansa rescue deal
summary: Ryanair plans to appeal against Germany's 9 billion-euro rescue deal for Lufthansa, citing "illegal state aid" that distorts competition. The deal gives Germany a 20% stake in Lufthansa, which Ryanair claims will harm competition in flights to and from Germany. The airline had previously taken a £600-million loan from the UK government. Ryanair's CEO, Michael O'Leary, claims Lufthansa is "addicted to state aid" and accuses the German government of ignoring EU rules.

site_title: 9 in 10 bids to defer mortgage payments get approval
summary: Banks in Singapore have approved over 90% of mortgage payment deferment applications by property buyers and SMEs to defer secured loan payments. This move aims to provide relief during the pandemic.

site_title: Pharma lifts Q1 but Q2 will be painful; full-year GDP to dip up to 7%
summary: Singapore's economy is expected to contract by 4-7% in full-year 2020, down from the previous forecast of 1-4%, due to a weaker external demand outlook and the impact of the two-month "circuit breaker" to curb the spread of the virus. The first quarter GDP declined 0.7%, beating expectations, but policymakers warn of a "very gradual" recovery in the second half, with potential negative year-on-year prints. The government has pledged S$92.9 billion in fiscal support, and economists expect the central bank to keep monetary policy unchanged, but with a risk of downward re-centring if the economy fails to recover.

site_title: The 'butterfly effect' and Covid-19: Implications for sustainable investing
summary: The Covid-19 pandemic has led to a global crisis with far-reaching implications for sustainable investing. The "butterfly effect" concept, suggesting small changes can have large consequences, is relevant as the pandemic's reverberations are felt through interconnected sustainability issues like rising temperatures, deforestation, and poor sanitation. As the crisis continues to unfold, it's crucial to integrate sustainability goals into recovery measures to ensure a more resilient future. This shift towards sustainable investing is likely to be a key factor in the world's recovery from the pandemic.

site_title: Hong Kong police issue warning amid calls for new demonstrations
summary: Hong Kong police have issued a warning against public order disruptions amid calls for new demonstrations on Wednesday, following the circulation of online calls for a general strike and protests against a national anthem law. The proposed law, part of a national security law, aims to curb freedoms in Hong Kong, a global financial center. Thousands clashed with police on Sunday, with almost 200 arrested, and the US has branded the security law a "death knell" for Hong Kong's autonomy. The city's Chief Executive Carrie Lam insists there is no threat to autonomy.

site_title: Jobs Support Scheme gets S$2.9 billion boost
summary: The Singapore government has announced enhancements to the Jobs Support Scheme (JSS), providing an additional S$2.9 billion in support for up to 10 months. The scheme now offers 25-75% wage support for eligible firms, with higher tiers applied to sectors hardest hit by the pandemic, such as aerospace and retail. The extension of JSS payouts by one month and increased support for foreign workers will help mitigate job losses, with economists predicting around 45,600 retrenchments this year. The government aims to retain jobs and retrain workers, while also creating new ones.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Monday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index fell 15.35 points to 1,436.76, closing lower on Monday. The market saw a volume of 6.686 billion lots worth RM4.191 billion, with losers outnumbering gainers 801 to 289.

site_title: US new-home sales post surprise gain in sign of stability
summary: US new-home sales unexpectedly rose 0.6% in April to a 623,000 annualized pace, defying economists' forecasts of a decline. This marks a stabilization in the housing market, which had dropped the most in almost seven years in March. The median sale price fell 8.6% from last year to $309,900, while mortgage rates near historic lows may be supporting the market. The slight gain in April has lifted homebuilder stocks, which have rebounded in recent weeks, but analysts caution that the new normal for the housing market remains uncertain.

site_title: Fashion shows should never be the same: Gucci
summary: Gucci's creative director Alessandro Michele announced a permanent reset of the fashion system caused by the COVID-19 pandemic. The brand will reduce its show schedule from five to two, effectively abandoning cruise shows and merging menswear and womenswear. Michele aims to "regain a new cadence" and "regain a new oxygen" to allow the fashion system to be reborn. Gucci's decision is part of a growing trend of brands rethinking their runway plans, with Saint Laurent, Dries Van Noten, and Giorgio Armani also making changes.

site_title: US: S&P 500 breaches 3,000 mark for first time since early March
summary: US stocks surged at the open, with the S&P 500 breaching 3,000 for the first time since March 5. The S&P 500 rose 2.2% to 3,020 points, while the Dow Jones Industrial Average and Nasdaq Composite also gained. The gains were driven by optimism over a potential coronavirus vaccine and business restarts, overshadowing Sino-US tensions.

site_title: Fortitude Budget: Construction sector to get more support for additional costs needed to resume
summary: Singapore's Deputy Prime Minister and Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat announced the Fortitude Budget, a fourth economic rescue package, to support the construction sector amid the Covid-19 pandemic. The government will co-share additional costs for businesses to meet safety requirements to resume projects. This move aims to continue planning and building significant infrastructure projects, including public infrastructure such as MRT lines and public housing.

site_title: China Sunsine Chemical to record lower revenue, profit for FY2020 on Covid-19 impact
summary: China Sunsine Chemical Holdings reported expected lower revenue and profit for FY2020 due to the Covid-19 pandemic's impact. The company, a specialty rubber chemicals producer, cited lower demand from customers, particularly overseas ones, as a major factor. Despite this, the group has maintained its original plans and expansion projects, aiming to strengthen its market leadership position upon completion. As of March 31, the company had a bank and cash balance of 1.35 billion yuan and no debt, and all employees have returned to work without any job cuts.

site_title: Temasek unit in rescue talks with PIL shipping line
summary: Temasek's investment firm Heliconia Capital Management is in talks with Singapore boxship operator Pacific International Lines (PIL) to provide a potential investment, aiming to help the company stay afloat. PIL, struggling to stay current on charter payments, has been divesting assets to shore up cash. Negotiations are preliminary, and the parties have not decided on the amount of cash to inject or the method of funding. PIL has sought support from lenders for a debt re-profiling plan, with 97.6% of lenders giving in-principle approval.

site_title: Economists divided on how far S$2b package can mitigate unemployment
summary: Singapore's government has announced a S$2 billion jobs and training package, known as the SGUnited Jobs and Skills Package, to mitigate the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on unemployment. The package aims to create over 100,000 job opportunities in the public and private sectors, as well as provide training and skills development programs. Economists are divided on the package's effectiveness, with some believing it could alleviate under-employment, while others predict a severe market outlook. Unemployment rates in Singapore rose to 3.3% in March, and economists forecast around 100,000 to 150,000 job losses this year.

site_title: Singapore faces worst recession since 1965, but in 'strong position' to overcome crisis: PM Lee
summary: Singapore is facing its worst recession since 1965, with an estimated 4-7% economic shrinkage this year. However, Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong believes the country is in a "strong position" to overcome the crisis due to fiscal prudence and discipline. The government has set aside almost S$100 billion in the "Fortitude Budget" to support businesses, create jobs, and provide training opportunities. Lee emphasized that no one will be left behind, and the government will prioritize saving and creating jobs to help Singapore emerge stronger after the pandemic.

site_title: NYSE trading floor partially reopens after coronavirus closure
summary: The New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) partially reopened on May 26, 2020, after a two-month closure due to the coronavirus. NYSE President Stacey Cunningham stated that the pause allowed the exchange to learn how to protect itself. The reopening marked the return of some traders, but it was not business as usual. The NYSE resumed trading at its iconic 11 Wall Street building, with Governor Andrew Cuomo in attendance, wearing a face mask.

site_title: Fiscal firepower notwithstanding, soft landing will still be a challenge
summary: The Singapore government has implemented stringent social distancing measures to combat COVID-19, resulting in a substantial economic cost, with GDP growth forecasted to be between -7% and -4% for 2020. Despite a fourth Covid-19 support budget worth S$33 billion, the government faces challenges in achieving a soft landing, with unemployment rates rising to 3.3% in March. The government is drawing on past reserves to fund its efforts, but the overall budget deficit is expected to increase to S$74.3 billion, or 15.4% of GDP.

site_title: Italian tenor Andrea Bocelli says he had coronavirus
summary: Italian tenor Andrea Bocelli revealed he contracted the novel coronavirus and was recovered. He had tested positive just over a month before singing alone in Milan's Duomo to raise spirits during the pandemic. Bocelli, who had been blind since age 12, described the experience as "a nightmare" and expressed gratitude that he was not a politician during the crisis. His plasma was donated to aid Covid-19 research and treatment development, and he now thanks God for his recovery.

site_title: Temasek unit leading consortium to rescue PIL
summary: Singapore's Pacific International Lines (PIL) is in exclusive talks with Temasek Holdings' unit Heliconia Capital Management for a potential investment. PIL, the world's 10th largest container shipping line, is struggling to stay current on charter payments and has been divesting assets to shore up cash. Negotiations are at a preliminary stage, and it's unclear how much cash will be injected into PIL or whether the funds will be raised through equity, debt, or convertible bonds. PIL has sought creditors' approval for a moratorium on enforcement actions, and discussions are ongoing with its finance lessors to re-profile certain lease agreements.

images.alt_text: PIL has commenced discussions with 15 of its financial lenders to seek their support for a "debt re-profiling plan". So far, lenders representing around 97.6 per cent of PIL's total bank debt have given their in-principle approval for a deferral of principal and interest payments until Dec 31, 2020, PIL says.

site_title: Fortitude Budget: Further draw of S$31b from reserves
summary: Singapore's President Halimah Yacob has given in-principle support for a further S$31 billion draw from past reserves to fund the fourth round of Covid-19 support measures, bringing the total to S$52 billion this year. The Fortitude Budget will commit S$33 billion to support the pandemic fight and position the country for recovery. The overall budget deficit for fiscal 2020 will increase to S$74.3 billion, or 15.4% of GDP, marking the largest deficit in Singapore's history since independence.

site_title: DLF Holdings to call EGM to seek shareholders' approval to expand into blockchain
summary: DLF Holdings, a CATALIST-listed company, is convening an extraordinary general meeting (EGM) to seek shareholders' approval to expand into blockchain agency and related businesses. The company aims to reduce its reliance on its existing mechanical and electrical services business and generate new revenue streams. DLF plans to change its name to "OIO Holdings Limited" to reflect its new focus on blockchain. The proposed diversification is expected to be complementary to its existing business and provide opportunities in blockchain-based payments and project management tools for the construction industry.

site_title: STI up 30.47 points on firm regional sentiment, expected gains on Wall St
summary: Singapore stocks rallied, with the Straits Times Index closing 30.47 points higher, or 1.22%, at 2,530.30. Firm regional sentiment and expectations of further gains on Wall Street contributed to the gains. Local banks DBS, OCBC, and UOB led the rally, while companies benefiting from the Covid-19 pandemic, such as Riverstone and UG Healthcare, also saw significant increases. The market was anticipating further fiscal stimulus from Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat.

site_title: Fortitude Budget: S$100 utilities credit for all households with at least one Singaporean
summary: Deputy Prime Minister and Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat announced a one-off S$100 Solidarity Utilities Credit for all households with at least one Singaporean to thank them for staying home during the Covid-19 pandemic. The credit will be credited in the July or August utilities bill and aims to offset expected increases in utility bills due to the "circuit-breaker" period. This comes on top of an earlier U-Save rebate announcement for eligible HDB households. Larger households with five or more members will save up to S$1,000 this year.

site_title: Fortitude Budget: S$118m top-up to support Singapore's charities and social service agencies
summary: The Singapore government is providing a S$100 million top-up for the Tote Board's Enhanced Fund-Raising Programme to support charities amid the Covid-19 pandemic. This top-up is on top of the existing S$70 million budget, bringing the total support to S$180 million. Charities can apply for dollar-for-dollar matching on eligible donations up to a cap of S$250,000 per charity. The Fortitude Budget, the fourth economic rescue package, aims to provide additional support for charities and social service agencies during this challenging time.

site_title: Li Ka-Shing Hong Kong group loses Israel deal amid US push
summary: Hong Kong conglomerate CK Hutchison Holdings, affiliated with billionaire Li Ka-shing, lost a bid to build and operate Israel's largest desalination plant to IDE Technologies, a local company. This decision comes amid US pressure on Israel to review potential security threats posed by China-based companies. The loss is the latest blow to Li Ka-shing's son and successor, CK Hutchison Chairman Victor Li, following a blocked bid to buy a gas pipeline operator in Australia two years ago.

site_title: STI up 30.47 points on firm regional sentiment; beneficiaries of Covid-19 pandemic bounce higher
summary: Singapore stocks rose 30.47 points, or 1.22%, to close at 2,530.30 on Tuesday, driven by firm regional sentiment and anticipation of further fiscal stimulus. The Straits Times Index gained, with three local banks leading the charge, and beneficiaries of the Covid-19 pandemic, such as glove makers, also saw significant gains. Singapore's GDP is forecast to contract between 4-7% this year, but the market remains optimistic, with the futures market pointing towards further gains on Wall Street.

site_title: Fortitude Budget: Extra S$13b to be set aside in Contingencies Funds
summary: Singapore's Deputy Prime Minister and Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat announced an additional S$13 billion to be set aside in the Contingencies Funds to prepare for the unpredictable Covid-19 crisis. This move aims to enable swift action in case of urgent and unforeseen expenditure needs. The funds will allow the government to respond quickly to public health or fiscal measures that may be required if the situation deteriorates. The extra funds will be included in a supply Bill to be voted on by Parliament, underlining the government's preparedness for any eventuality.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks close sharply higher
summary: Hong Kong shares surged 1.88% on Tuesday, outpacing China's Shanghai Composite Index, as investors focused on easing lockdown restrictions and hopes for a global economic recovery. The Hang Seng Index rose to 23,384.66, while the Shenzhen Composite Index fell 2.21%. The rally was driven by concerns over a proposed Chinese security law in Hong Kong, which was overshadowed by optimism about the global economy.

site_title: Xi seeks victory over Trump in race for a Covid-19 vaccine
summary: China is racing to develop a COVID-19 vaccine, mobilizing its state resources and companies, with President Xi Jinping promising to share any successful vaccine globally. The country has the most vaccine trials underway, with five vaccines being tested on humans. In contrast, the US has launched Operation Warp Speed to accelerate vaccine research and development, with President Trump's administration under pressure to produce a vaccine first. China's efforts have the potential to give Xi significant geopolitical clout if a vaccine is developed successfully.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat presented a S$33 billion supplementary budget to support firms, save jobs, and create opportunities in Singapore. The budget drew from past reserves and aims to mitigate the impact of the Covid-19 pandemic. The official recession forecast for 2020 has worsened to between -4% and -7%, while headline inflation turned negative in April due to a decline in private transport costs. Singapore's manufacturing output rose 13% in April, driven by a surge in biomedical manufacturing. The Straits Times Index closed up 1.22% on firm regional sentiment.

site_title: Fortitude Budget: Government tenants to get rental waivers of up to 2 months
summary: The Singapore government has extended rental relief for its tenants, including commercial tenants, hawkers, and industrial tenants, to help mitigate the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic. The relief includes four months of rental waivers for commercial tenants and five months for stallholders in hawker centres. Industrial tenants will receive two months of rental waivers. Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat emphasized that these measures will also benefit sub-tenants, such as small and medium-sized enterprises.

site_title: Fortitude Budget: 4,000 traineeships for unemployed mid-career individuals
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat announced the SGUnited Mid-Career Traineeships scheme in Parliament, providing 4,000 traineeships for unemployed mid-career individuals in Singapore. The program aims to help job seekers learn new skills and embark on new careers, addressing concerns about job prospects. The government will work with companies to offer these traineeships, supporting the job seekers.

site_title: Uber cuts 600 jobs in India as lockdown hits business
summary: Uber cuts approximately 600 jobs in India as part of its plan to reduce its global workforce by 23% amid the COVID-19 pandemic. The company has shifted focus to core businesses of ride-hailing and food delivery, citing the lockdown's impact on its operations. This move comes after rival Ola also cut around 1,400 jobs in India due to the pandemic's decline in revenue.

site_title: Sapphire Corp bags contracts worth 235.9m yuan
summary: Sapphire Corp's subsidiary Ranken Railway Construction Group secured two engineering, procurement and construction (EPC) contracts in Urumqi, China, valued at approximately 235.9 million yuan. The contracts include a 1.73 km transportation-infrastructure project at Urumqi Airport and an infrastructure upgrading project at Midong district. Additionally, Ranken leased its tunnel-boring machine for a Shenzhen Metro Line 14 project. The deals are expected to have a positive impact on Ranken's financial performance for the financial year ending December 31, with an order book of 1.5 billion yuan.

site_title: Data analytics startup Bonza bags funding from East Ventures
summary: Data analytics startup Bonza received seed funding from East Ventures, a Jakarta-based venture capital firm. The exact amount raised was not disclosed, but Bonza plans to use the funding to develop its technology and product, and expand its business operations. The startup aims to simplify data preparation for data analysts and C-suite and frontline workers.

site_title: 'How about next June?' Small meat processors backlogged as virus idles big plants
summary: Small-scale US meat processors are experiencing a surge in demand as major plants are closed or operating at reduced capacity due to the novel coronavirus. With 80% of US beef production controlled by four large companies, small-scale slaughterhouses are struggling to keep up with the demand, forcing some to ration sales and turn away farmers. The shortage has led to panic buying, with consumers seeking alternatives to traditional supply chains, and some farmers are now selling directly to consumers.

site_title: Fortitude Budget: Another S$800m set aside for Covid-19 Support Grant
summary: Singapore has set aside another S$800 million for the Covid-19 Support Grant, part of the Fortitude Budget. The grant provides up to S$800/month for job losses or involuntary leave and up to S$500/month for significant salary reductions. Since its launch, 46,000 applications have been received. The grant's precursor, the Temporary Relief Fund, provided S$500 each to 450,000 individuals. The Self-Employed Person Income Relief scheme will also disburse S$3,000 to over 100,000 self-employed persons.

site_title: Liquor makers push for bars to join revival in South Africa
summary: South Africa's liquor makers are urging the government to allow smaller bars to sell alcohol for home consumption when the nationwide ban is lifted on June 1. The industry, in dire straits after two months of inactivity, wants to prevent residents from traveling long distances and reduce illicit sales. CEO Richard Rushton of Distell Group Holdings Ltd. also proposes extending opening hours beyond a proposed Monday-to-Thursday window to reduce crowding. The government will decide final regulations following consultation with the industry, which has committed to distributing masks and health information.

site_title: Fortitude Budget: Up to S$5,000 payouts for F&B, retail businesses that go digital
summary: Singapore's government will allocate over S$500 million to support businesses in their digital transformation, Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat announced. The Digital Resilience Bonus will provide up to S$5,000 payouts to eligible food and beverage and retail businesses that adopt digital solutions, such as PayNow Corporate and e-invoicing. Additionally, businesses that incorporate advanced digital tools will receive an extra S$5,000. The government will also provide S$250 million to help businesses digitalize in partnership with platform solution providers and industry champions.

site_title: Fortitude Budget: S$1,200 allowance for job seekers going for training
summary: Singapore has introduced a new SGUnited Skills programme, offering a S$1,200 monthly allowance for job seekers to take industry-relevant training courses from July. The programme aims to help 30,000 job seekers upgrade their skills while looking for employment. Participants will receive career guidance, job placement support, and opportunities to apply their training through attachments or company projects. The training courses will be delivered by companies and Continuing Education Training Centres, with course fees substantially offset by participants' SkillsFuture Credit.

site_title: Fortitude Budget: S$285m to attract matching investments for startups
summary: Singapore is setting aside S$285 million to match private investments for startups, with the goal of sustaining innovation and entrepreneurship activities. The funding is part of the government's efforts to support promising startups, which have been struggling to raise capital and develop their businesses. This is in addition to the S$300 million set aside under the Unity Budget for deep-tech startups. The move aims to preserve Singapore's innovation ecosystem and prevent the loss of good jobs and companies.

site_title: Seoul: Shares hit 11-week high on economic recovery hopes
summary: South Korean shares rose to an 11-week high, closing at 2,029.78, driven by economic recovery hopes amid countries reopening their economies and stimulus efforts. Japan lifted a state of emergency, while China's central bank governor announced policy strengthening and lower interest rates. South Korea's central bank is expected to cut its policy rate to a record low. Foreigners bought $7.21 million worth of shares, but worries about the Sino-US rift remained.

site_title: Fortitude Budget: S$2b SGUnited Jobs and Skills Package to create 100,000 opportunities
summary: Singapore's Fortitude Budget allocates S$2 billion for the SGUnited Jobs and Skills Package, aiming to create close to 100,000 job opportunities in the public and private sectors. The package will also provide training and skills development opportunities. Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat announced the initiative as part of the government's fourth economic relief package to mitigate the impact of the Covid-19 pandemic.

site_title: Fortitude Budget: Hiring incentive now covers all ages, doubled for older workers
summary: The Singapore government has expanded the hiring incentive for local workers under the Fortitude Budget to cover all ages. Eligible employees under 40 will receive up to 20% of their monthly salary for six months, capped at S$6,000. This is part of the Unity Budget's SkillsFuture Mid-Career Support Package.

site_title: Lufthansa unit Eurowings to cut a third of head-office staff
summary: Eurowings, a low-cost airline owned by Lufthansa, plans to cut a third of its head-office staff, approximately 300 jobs, as part of efforts to return the German airline group to profitability after a major state bailout. The move comes after Lufthansa received a 9 billion euro bailout from Germany, which also grants Berlin a veto in the event of a hostile bid for the airline. The reduction aims to improve the airline's financial stability and competitiveness.

site_title: Fortitude Budget: Government sets aside further S$33b in Singapore's fight against Covid-19
summary: Singapore's government has set aside S$33 billion for the next phase of its fight against Covid-19, bringing the total support to S$92.9 billion. The Fortitude Budget focuses on jobs, providing additional support to workers and businesses affected by border closures and safe distancing measures. The government will also boost its clinical management of cases, swabbing, and testing capabilities. Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat emphasized the need for resilience and adaptability in the face of an unprecedented crisis, aiming to build a stronger and more inclusive society.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets jump at open
summary: European stock markets jumped at the start of trading on Tuesday, with London surging 1.9% and other major cities like Frankfurt, Paris, and Madrid also experiencing gains. The reopenings of virus-hit economies contributed to the surge.

site_title: Tencent to invest S$99b in 'new infrastructure'
summary: Chinese tech giant Tencent Holdings plans to invest 500 billion yuan (S$99 billion) in new infrastructure, including cloud computing, artificial intelligence, and cybersecurity, over the next five years. The investment aims to support the company's expansion into business services as consumer internet growth slows. Tencent's cloud services currently hold 18% of China's cloud market, trailing Alibaba Group Holding Ltd. The investment is seen as a response to Beijing's call for a tech-driven structural upgrade of the country's economy.

site_title: Frozen UK property funds face existential crisis
summary: British property funds face an existential crisis due to the coronavirus crisis, with 10 major funds frozen for months and others considering changes to structure to survive. The market's inability to accurately value real estate assets, combined with economic uncertainty, has led to a freeze on investor redemptions. Industry sources predict funds will remain frozen until at least September, with some potentially closing if they cannot meet redemption requests. Changes in structure, such as becoming investment trusts, may be necessary to avoid future suspensions.

site_title: Fortitude Budget: JSS extended for 1 month, aerospace firms to get 75% wage support
summary: Singapore's Fortitude Budget, announced by Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat, extends the Jobs Support Scheme (JSS) for one month until August 2020, providing additional wage support for all firms until then. The scheme now offers 75% wage support for aerospace firms, built environment sector, and retail outlets, and 50% for marine and offshore sectors. The enhancements aim to provide more relief as firms reopen after the "circuit breaker" period, with the total cost estimated at S$2.9 billion.

site_title: Fortitude Budget: New law to mandate landlords grant temporary rental waiver to SME tenants
summary: Singapore's government will introduce a new bill to mandate landlords grant temporary rental waivers to small- and medium-sized enterprise (SME) tenants affected by the Covid-19 pandemic. The four-month relief will be shared equally between the government and landlords, providing substantial support on rental costs for SMEs. The bill will also cover provisions on temporary relief from onerous contractual terms and allow tenants to repay arrears through installments. The move aims to safeguard Singapore's economic structure for the common good.

site_title: Couples who eat together may not stay together
summary: A study on couples who eat together reveals that it may not necessarily lead to a stronger relationship. Marianne Andrews, a 53-year-old stay-at-home parent, and her husband Jonathan Miller, a 55-year-old head of English, have been eating dinner together every night since the pandemic lockdown, but their daily meals have become increasingly strained due to his eating habits. Jonathan's loud crunching on nuts and his slow consumption of chocolate have become sources of frustration for Marianne. Experts say that food can be a source of anxiety and conflict in relationships, especially during quarantine, and may be exacerbated by misophonia, a condition where one person is highly sensitive to specific sounds.

site_title: Gucci says fashion shows should never be the same
summary: Gucci, a prominent Italian fashion brand, has announced a significant change in its fashion show schedule. Under the creative direction of Alessandro Michele, Gucci will reduce its annual show schedule from five to two, effectively eliminating mid-season "cruise shows." This move aims to revitalize the fashion industry, which has been severely impacted by the COVID-19 pandemic. Gucci joins other brands, including Saint Laurent and Dries Van Noten, in rethinking the traditional fashion show system, with some advocating for a permanent reduction in the number of seasons. The decision is seen as a potential game-changer in the fashion industry, with some speculating that it may force a broader reckoning with the feasibility of the ready-to-wear show season.

site_title: Fortitude Budget: SME tenants get cash grant to offset rents
summary: The Singapore government will provide a new cash grant to offset rental costs for small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs), with the aim of offsetting about two months' of rents for commercial properties and one month for industrial and office properties. The grant, costing S$2 billion, will be disbursed through property owners and passed on to SME tenants. The measure aims to support SMEs affected by the Covid-19 pandemic, with Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat stating that many businesses are struggling with rental costs, which are "especially tough" on SMEs.

site_title: Japan's Marvelous shares jump 17% as China's Tencent takes 20% stake
summary: Japan's Marvelous shares jumped 17% after Chinese gaming giant Tencent Holdings took a 20% stake in the company. Tencent will spend around 7 billion yen to acquire shares from Marvelous and its largest shareholders. Marvelous plans to use the funds to launch new games and expand overseas. This investment marks the latest influx of Chinese money into Japan's gaming industry, which faces competition from well-resourced overseas rivals.

site_title: Fortitude Budget: Foreign worker levy waiver and rebate extended to June and July
summary: Singapore's Deputy Prime Minister and Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat announced the extension of foreign worker levy waivers and rebates to June and July for businesses in the construction, marine, and offshore, and process sectors. This is part of the Fortitude Budget, the fourth economic rescue package to combat the Covid-19 pandemic.

site_title: 383 new Covid-19 cases in Singapore
summary: The Ministry of Health in Singapore reported 383 new COVID-19 cases on Tuesday, including two community cases and 381 migrant worker cases in dormitories. Two public places, a wet market and a FairPrice outlet, have been added to the list of places where people with COVID-19 have been spotted, with the aim of monitoring their health closely. With 706 new cases discharged, 16,435 patients have fully recovered from the disease, and 585 remain in hospital, including 15,291 in community facilities.

site_title: BP's Looney halves top management roles under energy transition plan
summary: BP is halving its senior management team, reducing the number of leadership roles from 250 to 120, as part of its energy transition plan. The company, under CEO Bernard Looney, is streamlining its structure to focus on low-carbon energy and solar power. Over 100 Tier 2 managers will form the leadership teams of 11 divisions, with many veteran executives set to leave. The changes aim to make BP more nimble and efficient, with a focus on cost savings and digitalization.

site_title: Australia, NZ shares hit 2-1/2-month high on bets of economic recovery
summary: Australia and New Zealand stocks surged to a 2-1/2-month high on hopes of a global economic recovery as countries exit the coronavirus-induced lockdown. The S&P/ASX 200 index rose 2.9% to 5,780 points, its highest level since March 11. In New Zealand, the S&P/NZX 50 index gained 1.3% to 10,914.74 points, also its highest since March 11, following a monthly trade surplus in April. The gains are seen as a positive sign for the region's economic outlook.

site_title: Covid-19 to accelerate shifts in global supply chains: Chan Chun Sing
summary: Singapore's Minister for Trade and Industry Chan Chun Sing stated that the Covid-19 pandemic will accelerate shifts in global supply chains, with a focus on relocating supply chains nearer to final demand markets for greater resilience. The outlook for outward-oriented sectors remains weak, but opportunities will arise for companies to fill unmet demand and participate in new supply chains. The government is helping companies and workers prepare by boosting connectivity, upholding Singapore's status as a financial and logistics hub, and introducing training and re-skilling programs.

site_title: Australian media face trial over Pell sex abuse case reporting
summary: Australian journalists and publishers face trial in November over their coverage of ex-Vatican treasurer George Pell's child sex abuse conviction in 2018. Prosecutors claim 19 journalists and 21 publications breached an Australia-wide gag order and suppression orders imposed by the trial judge. The trial will determine whether the media organizations aided and abetted contempt of court. The case stems from reports that some Australian media said an unnamed high-profile person had been convicted of a serious crime that could not be reported, while some overseas media named Pell and the charges, breaching suppression orders.

images.alt_text: Pell was found guilty in December 2018 of sexually assaulting two choirboys, but reporting on the case was gagged so as not to prejudice another trial on separate charges.

site_title: Chinese provincial official urges shut down of CNPC's Dalian refinery
summary: A Chinese vice governor, Chen Xiangqun, has urged the central government to shut down Dalian Petrochemical Corp's refinery in Liaoning province due to safety and pollution concerns. The 410,000 barrels-per-day refinery has had several severe accidents, including oil spills, explosions, and fires. Despite being relocated to Changxing island in 2017, the plant's status remains unchanged. Chen appealed for the refinery to be shut down and for the land to be sold to a new owner, and for the construction of a new refinery to be pushed forward using idle refining capacity.

site_title: Latin America's largest airline LATAM files for bankruptcy in US
summary: Latin America's largest airline, LATAM, filed for bankruptcy in the US on May 26, 2020, due to the drastic slump in business caused by the coronavirus pandemic. The airline's chief executive, Roberto Alvo, said the company was forced to make difficult decisions in response to the crisis. LATAM has scaled back operations by 95% and announced hundreds of job cuts. The airline's US Chapter 11 reorganization will allow it to reduce debt and address commercial challenges. This comes just two weeks after Colombia's Avianca filed for bankruptcy in the US.

site_title: Fortitude Budget: CPF contribution increase for seniors deferred to 2022
summary: Deputy Prime Minister and Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat announced that the planned rise in Central Provident Fund (CPF) contribution rates for senior workers in 2021 will be deferred to 2022. The original plan was to raise rates for workers aged 55-70 in stages, with the first stage to begin in 2021. However, to help businesses manage costs, the rate increase will now occur in 2022. The S$80 million CPF Transition Offset scheme will also be deferred until after the higher contribution rates kick in.

site_title: Brokers' take: DBS, Maybank KE cut target price for ComfortDelGro
summary: Analysts at Maybank Kim Eng and DBS Group Research have lowered their target prices for ComfortDelGro Corp's shares, citing slower-than-expected declines in operating costs and reduced earnings due to higher-than-expected costs in the public transport segment. Maybank maintained a "buy" call with a reduced target price of S$1.98, while DBS cut its target price to S$1.50 due to the impact of taxi rental waivers and reduced rail ridership. The analysts expect a gradual recovery in the taxi business as social distancing measures ease.

site_title: Eagle Hospitality Trust's sponsor directors confirm resignations on May 26
summary: Eagle Hospitality Trust's sponsor directors, Howard Wu and Taylor Woods, have confirmed their resignations as non-executive chairman and non-executive deputy chairman, effective May 26. The resignations follow an investigation into "prejudicial" interested-person transactions and are in line with plans to bring on a new strategic partner. Wu holds approximately 53.2 million stapled securities, while Woods holds 66.1 million. Trading in EHT stapled securities has been suspended since March 24.

site_title: Forget propping up the bar in the pub for a bit, UK's Gove says
summary: UK Cabinet Office Minister Michael Gove stated that opening up pubs, restaurants, and bars after the coronavirus lockdown will be difficult, and there will be no standing at the bar in pubs for a long time. Instead, outdoor hospitality, such as enjoying a drink in a pub's garden or eating outdoors in a cafe, may be possible. Gove expressed concerns that returning to pre-lockdown socializing, such as standing at bars or mingling in cafes, will be challenging.

site_title: Macau gambling king Stanley Ho dies aged 98
summary: Stanley Ho, Macau's former gambling king, died at 98. Ho built a business empire from scratch and transformed Macau into the world's biggest casino center. His company, SJM Holdings, was valued at around $6 billion. After holding a monopoly, Ho licensed five other operators in 2002. His daughter, Pansy, is now in line to take over the family business, sparking potential ownership changes and stock surges for companies in the family's empire.

site_title: Singapore headline inflation turns negative in April due to larger decline in private transport cost
summary: Singapore's headline inflation turned negative in April, falling to -0.7% year-over-year, due to a larger decline in private transport costs and steeper falls in the costs of services, retail, and other goods. Core inflation also fell for the third straight month to -0.3% year-over-year, as accommodation and private road transport costs were excluded. The decline was attributed to a sharp drop in car prices, petrol prices, and telecommunication equipment prices.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares rise to near 3-month high as Japan reopens economy
summary: Japan's benchmark Nikkei average rose 2.6% to 21,271.17, its highest close in nearly three months, as investors cheered Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's decision to lift the state of emergency and end coronavirus-induced restrictions nationwide. This move is crucial for the country's economic recovery, particularly for Tokyo, which accounts for one-third of Japan's GDP. Air and land transport companies led the rally, with shares of Japan Airlines and ANA Holdings surging 8.2% and 5.7%, respectively.

site_title: China's mask boom takes fabric away for nappy makers
summary: China's surge in mask production during the COVID-19 pandemic has led to a shortage of nonwoven fabric, essential for making nappies, wet wipes, and sanitary towels. Manufacturers are facing high costs, halved production, and price hikes due to the diversion of raw materials. The industry is concerned about the future of supply lines, with some firms producing nappies at a loss to maintain market stability. China's daily mask output has reached 450 million, but suppliers struggle to meet demand, citing a lack of raw materials and a shift in production to key anti-epidemic materials.

site_title: Masks too dangerous for children under 2, Japan medical group says
summary: A Japan medical group has urged parents not to put masks on children under 2 years old due to breathing difficulties and increased risk of choking. The group cited narrow air passages and heat stroke as concerns. The US Centers for Disease Control and CDC also recommend against cloth face coverings for children under 2. Japan's Prime Minister Shinzo Abe has lifted a state of emergency in Tokyo, but warned of potential re-imposition if the virus spreads.

site_title: Australia's New Century takes aim at Vale's New Caledonia assets
summary: Australia's New Century Resources Ltd is in talks to buy Vale's nickel and cobalt operations on New Caledonia, with the aim of decommissioning the troubled refinery and producing a mixed hydroxide product. The deal, valued at an undisclosed amount, would make New Century a major supplier of nickel and cobalt. Vale is expected to book a US$400 million impairment on the sale. The acquisition is seen as a positive move for Vale to leave a legacy, and New Century aims to maximize efficiency and production while lowering costs.

site_title: Tencent plans to sell billions of dollars in bonds globally
summary: Tencent Holdings plans to sell billions of dollars in US dollar bonds globally, testing market demand. The company aims to raise funds for general corporate purposes and has a maximum bond limit of $20 billion, with $12 billion already outstanding. Global co-ordinators Bank of America, HSBC, Morgan Stanley, and Goldman Sachs will assess investor demand before finalizing the deal's timing and size. The move is part of Tencent's efforts to diversify its funding sources and strengthen its financial position.

images.alt_text: Chinese social media and gaming giant Tencent Holdings is testing the market's appetite for a US dollar bond deal it plans to offer, according to a term sheet reviewed by Reuters.

site_title: Carousell rolls out 1,000 help packages to assist heartland merchants in digitalisation
summary: Carousell is offering 1,000 help packages to heartland retailers and service merchants in Singapore to aid digitalisation amid the Covid-19 pandemic. The Carousell for Business (CarouBiz) package, valued at S$720, includes a six-month subscription and S$480 in Carousell coins. Eligible SMEs can also apply for one-time funding support of 90% from Enterprise Singapore. The initiative aims to guide merchants in growing their customer base and realising new revenue streams, addressing the decline in customers due to the pandemic.

site_title: Singapore factory output up 13% in April, biomedical manufacturing doubles: EDB
summary: Singapore's manufacturing output increased by 13% in April, driven by a surge in biomedical manufacturing, which doubled from the previous month. Excluding biomedical manufacturing, output fell 3.5% due to COVID-19-related measures. The biomedicals cluster saw a 100.5% surge, while the electronics cluster rose 0.8%. Other sectors, including precision engineering and general manufacturing, also experienced contractions. The country's official growth forecast for 2020 was downgraded to -7% to -4% due to the pandemic's fallout.

site_title: Fortitude Budget could help to deal with expected rise in retrenchments: MOM official
summary: Singapore is preparing for a potential rise in unemployment and retrenchments due to the expected economic downturn, with the government expected to unveil a fiscal support package, known as the Fortitude Budget, later on Tuesday. The package aims to create jobs and training opportunities, with Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat saying it will help to make the labor market "relatively healthy". Unemployment rates in the US and China have surged due to the COVID-19 pandemic, and Singapore's overall unemployment rate has increased to 2.4% as of end-March.

site_title: Ex-Coutts banker on trial over US$700m transfer from 1MDB to Jho Low
summary: A Swiss compliance officer, identified as A, is on trial for allegedly failing to stop a $700 million transfer of funds from 1MDB to an account controlled by Jho Low, the alleged mastermind behind the 1MDB scandal. The transfer occurred in 2009 while A worked at Coutts, where Low had an account. The trial comes a decade after the scandal led to the fall of former Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak. Swiss prosecutors are citing A's approval of the transfer as evidence of his culpability.

site_title: Klook turns focus to domestic offerings, launches Klook Home amid Covid-19
summary: Klook launches Klook Home, a domestic experiences initiative, to combat the impact of Covid-19 on the travel industry. The platform offers almost 200 home-based experiences, including DIY kits, online workshops, and virtual tours, in 14 markets in Asia-Pacific and Europe. This is the first phase of Klook's global "multi-stage recovery approach" aimed at supporting the recovery of the travel industry.

site_title: No evidence of anti-competitive behaviour by petrol firms in S'pore: Tan Wu Meng
summary: Senior Parliamentary Secretary for Trade and Industry Tan Wu Meng stated that there is no evidence of anti-competitive behavior by petrol companies in Singapore. He explained that crude oil prices may not always lead to a drop in retail petrol prices due to factors such as refineries storing excess supplies or reducing production to sell more. Tan also noted that petrol companies' operating costs and taxes influence prices, and a 2017 study found that refined petrol costs account for less than a third of the listed retail petrol price.

site_title: Hong Kong airport to resume limited transit services
summary: Hong Kong's international airport will resume limited transit services starting June 1, allowing passengers to transit through the airport without entering the city, according to Chief Executive Carrie Lam. The move comes as the city gradually reopens while maintaining coronavirus restrictions, including mandatory testing for arriving passengers. The city has seen a significant decline in COVID-19 cases, with only 1,000 infections and four deaths reported out of 7.5 million residents.

site_title: Virus threatens Chinese traditions of chopsticks and family-style meals
summary: A growing concern in China is that the country's tradition of sharing food, particularly with chopsticks, could accelerate the spread of the coronavirus. The government is focusing on chopsticks as a potential vector for transmission. Sharing food is a cultural practice in China where parents serve their children, children serve their grandparents, and bosses serve employees as a gesture of respect and affection. This practice may be increasing the risk of coronavirus transmission, highlighting the need for new public health measures to mitigate the spread of the virus.

site_title: First test of Virgin Orbit rocket fails to accomplish goal
summary: Virgin Orbit's first test launch of its LauncherOne rocket failed to reach orbit after the rocket's first-stage engine developed trouble of unknown origin shortly after ignition. The test, which aimed to deploy a satellite, was conducted off the coast of California from a modified Boeing 747 plane, Cosmic Girl. The mission was deemed a success in releasing the rocket, but the company will analyze data to determine the cause of the anomaly. The failure marks a setback for Virgin Orbit's goal of offering a quick and flexible launch service for small satellites.

site_title: BOJ's Kuroda says ready to ease more including via new steps
summary: Bank of Japan Governor Haruhiko Kuroda stated the central bank is ready to ease monetary policy further, including expanding loan programs, cutting interest rates, and purchasing risky assets. He emphasized the need for market stability to ensure a solid recovery for Japan's economy once the pandemic is contained.

images.alt_text: Bank of Japan Governor Haruhiko Kuroda said on Tuesday the central bank was ready to ease monetary policy further such as by expanding its loan programmes, cutting interest rates and ramping up risky asset purchases.

site_title: US drilling industry says offshore ban would crush jobs, government revenues
summary: A US ban on new offshore drilling in the Gulf of Mexico, promised by presidential hopeful Joe Biden, would lead to hundreds of thousands of job losses and billions in lost government revenue over 20 years, according to a report by the National Ocean Industries Association. The report found that a ban would result in 179,000 jobs in 2040, down from 370,000 under current policies, and $2.7 billion in annual government revenue, down from $7 billion. The offshore industry would also face a 25% decline in jobs and revenues under the ban.

site_title: Seoul: Shares rally for 2nd day on economy reopening hopes
summary: South Korean shares rallied for a second day, gaining over 1% as global economies reopened and boosted risk appetite. The Kospi index rose 24.37 points, or 1.3%, to 2,019.59, while the Korean won strengthened and bond yields fell. Investors are confident in a smooth global reopening despite concerns over Sino-US tensions. Foreigners were net sellers of 54.6 billion won, but the won was still quoted 0.6% higher at 1,236.8 per US dollar.

site_title: Food delivery giant Meituan's sales beat estimates
summary: Meituan, China's largest meal delivery business, reported a smaller-than-expected 13% slide in revenue, beating estimates, and its shares soared. Sales fell 12.6% to 16.8 billion yuan in the first quarter, with net loss at 1.58 billion yuan. Despite severe lockdowns, businesses have begun to recover, with over 70% of restaurants regaining more than half their normal order volumes. The company's long-term prospects remain uncertain due to China's worsening economy and ongoing Covid-19 challenges.

site_title: Dubai to allow free movement, business activity from Wednesday
summary: Dubai will allow free movement and business activity to restart from Wednesday, with restrictions on movement and business operations lifted between 6.00 am and 11.00 pm. Retail and wholesale businesses, including cinemas and indoor gyms, will be allowed to reopen with sterilization and social distancing measures. The move reverses a nationwide curfew extension and comes after a reported increase in daily COVID-19 cases in the UAE. The country had suspended entry of non-Emirati residents and closed public venues to combat the virus.

site_title: California opens places of worship, in-store retail businesses: health officials
summary: California has reopened places of worship and in-store retail businesses with 25% occupancy capacity, following mounting pressure from churches and President Donald Trump. Businesses must submit a plan to county health departments, with measures including social distancing and face mask requirements. Church services are capped at 100 attendees, and attendees must maintain a six-foot distance from each other. The new rules come amid the global pandemic, which has killed nearly 100,000 people in the US, and amid a push to get America back to work.

site_title: Gold giant Australia is firing back up a record exploration boom
summary: Australia's gold mining sector is experiencing a record exploration boom, driven by surging gold prices and a lack of major discoveries in the past three years. Spending on gold exploration in Australia reached a new record in the final quarter of 2019, with a 20% increase in annual spending to over A$1 billion. This surge is expected to propel Australia to the top gold producer, surpassing China, next year. Companies with cash reserves are quickly resuming exploration drilling, anticipating a major gold boom.

site_title: Air New Zealand sees annual underlying loss due to coronavirus
summary: Air New Zealand reported an underlying loss in its financial year ending June 30 due to the coronavirus outbreak. The airline cut 30% of staff, or 4,000 employees, and grounded its 16 Boeing 777 planes until at least December. It expects a 50% capacity drop in the next six months, leading to a sharp fall in revenue. The airline has slashed costs and reduced its monthly cash outflow by NZ$50 million to NZ$60 million. It has short-term liquidity of NZ$640 million and has not drawn on a NZ$900 million government loan.

site_title: Japan's Isetan Mitsukoshi to reopen main stores on Saturday
summary: Japan's Isetan Mitsukoshi Holdings will reopen its main stores in the Tokyo area, including its Isetan flagship, on Saturday. The stores had been closed since April 8 due to the slump in foreign tourists and fears about the coronavirus. Isetan Mitsukoshi reported a net loss of 11 billion yen (S$145.1 million) for the year through March.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares open on Tuesday with big gains
