summary: Hong Kong stocks rose over 1% on Tuesday, driven by a global economic reopening, despite concerns over China's proposed security law. The Hang Seng Index gained 1.07% to 23,198.34, while China's Shanghai and Shenzhen Composite Indices also increased. Global economic reopenings overshadowed concerns about the security law, which has been a major topic of discussion.

site_title: UBS to start own venture capital fund in effort to digitise bank

The fund, which will hold stakes for at least five years, will focus on client engagement, investing, and operational improvements. This move comes as the bank shifts its focus towards digital services following the COVID-19 pandemic, and follows peers such as Credit Suisse Group, which invests in fintech through its entrepreneur capital arm.

site_title: Singapore recession forecast for 2020 worsens to between -4% and -7%
summary: Singapore's economy is expected to contract between 7% and 4% this year, a downgrade from earlier forecasts of a 1% to 4% contraction, due to the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic. The Ministry of Trade and Industry attributed the downgrade to weaker external demand and the impact of the "circuit breaker" period on domestic economic activity. Manufacturing showed a surprise expansion of 6.6% year-on-year, while the services sector lost 2.4% on the year before. The downgrade marks Singapore's worst recession since independence, with risks still dominating the second-half recovery path.

site_title: Singapore shares open higher ahead of fourth budget; STI up 0.9%
summary: Singapore shares rose 0.9% ahead of the announcement of the country's fourth Covid-19 support package, with the Straits Times Index gaining 21.69 points to 2,521.52. Despite a projected GDP contraction of 7-4% this year, which is a bigger drop than previous estimates, the market advanced. Gainers outnumbered losers 140 to 43, with local banks and real estate trusts leading the gains.

site_title: Asia: Equities build on gains as reopenings trump geopolitical tensions
summary: Asia's equities rose on Tuesday as lockdown reopenings outpaced geopolitical tensions, with Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index gaining 1.5% despite a proposed security law sparking fears for the city's financial future. Other countries, such as Singapore and China, also saw gains. Meanwhile, rising death and infection tolls in Brazil and Russia were largely overshadowed by declining figures in many other nations. The Asia market's gains contrast with US stocks, which edged down from records amid tariff threats and US-EU trade talks.

site_title: Asia: Equities advance, shrugging off tensions
summary: Asian stocks rose for a second day, driven by Japan's reopening and gains in Tokyo, Sydney, and Seoul. Treasuries were flat, while the US dollar remained unchanged. Hong Kong showed signs of stabilizing after weekend unrest, while Shanghai had modest gains. In contrast, European stocks declined due to bank and healthcare sector drag, with US-EU trade talks in focus. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq edged to fresh records despite tariff threats.

site_title: Mink infected two humans with coronavirus: Dutch gov't
summary: The Netherlands reports two confirmed cases of human infection with coronavirus, contracted from infected mink, on four farms where mink are bred for their fur. The risk of transmission outside the farms is considered negligible. The source of infection on three farms is believed to be a sick human, while the fourth case is under investigation. This is reportedly the first documented case of mink-to-human transmission of the virus in the Netherlands.

images.alt_text: Mink with the coronavirus have infected two people in the Netherlands in what are probably the first such cases of transmission during the epidemic, government and health authorities said on Monday.

site_title: US coronavirus death toll rises by 532 in past 24 hours: tracker
summary: The US coronavirus death toll has risen by 532 in the past 24 hours, according to the Johns Hopkins University tracker, bringing the total to 98,218 lives lost. US cases of infection now stand at 1,662,375, the highest in the world.

site_title: Cathay Pacific's brand merger hits roadblock from China's aviation regulator: sources
summary: China's aviation regulator may block Cathay Pacific's merger of regional arm Cathay Dragon into its main brand due to infractions during last year's pro-democracy protests. The airline aims to cut costs, streamline marketing, and consolidate pilot contracts around Cathay Pacific and low-cost arm HK Express. This move comes as rival Singapore Airlines is also merging regional and budget arms. The outcome could impact Cathay Pacific's restructuring efforts and affect the airline industry's cost-cutting strategies.

images.alt_text: China's aviation regulator may make it difficult for Hong Kong's Cathay Pacific Airways to merge regional arm Cathay Dragon into its main brand because of infractions during last year's pro-democracy protests, two sources said.

site_title: Rich Chinese snapping up luxury homes from Singapore to Sydney
summary: Wealthy Chinese buyers are resuming their luxury real estate purchases in Asia and beyond, driven by concerns over inflation and a weakening yuan. Since March, Chinese buyers have snapped up prime properties in Sydney, Shanghai, Seoul, and Singapore, with sales increasing 25% in Australia and 180% in South Korea. The surge in demand is bolstering prices in China and tempering declines in other markets, with top-end homes in Shenzhen and Shanghai experiencing a 1% price rise in April. This trend is also seen in the US, with Malaysian luxury properties attracting Chinese buyers.

site_title: Samsung Group heir questioned by prosecutors over a 2015 deal
summary: Samsung Group heir Jay Y Lee was summoned and questioned by prosecutors in South Korea over a 2015 merger of two affiliates, amid controversy surrounding the deal. The investigation is related to allegations of improper management and potential breach of securities laws. A Samsung Electronics spokesman declined to comment, while prosecutors were unavailable for comment. This is the latest development in a long-standing probe into Jay Y Lee's business dealings.

site_title: Japan keeps top creditor status as external assets hit record high
summary: Japan's net external assets reached a record high of 365 trillion yen (S$4.83 trillion) in 2019, solidifying its position as the top creditor nation for the 29th consecutive year. The country's net assets grew 6.7% from the previous year, with a significant increase in overseas investment and securities investments. Japan's net external assets surpassed those of Germany and China, with a surplus of 20.1 trillion yen in 2019, supporting the view that Japan earns more from its overseas investment than from its trade surplus.

site_title: GSH proposes to repurchase up to S$20m of notes due 2020
summary: GSH Corp has proposed to repurchase up to S$20 million of its S$70 million notes due 2020 in cash at par, starting on May 26 and ending on June 8. The move is part of the company's capital-management strategy to prudently manage interest costs. The repurchase will be facilitated by DBS Bank, with directors limiting their tender amount to 28.5% of their holdings. This proposal aims to manage interest costs and align with the company's capital-management strategy.

site_title: Brazil to begin exporting beef to Thailand: Ministry
summary: Brazil's Agriculture Ministry announced that Thailand has agreed to import Brazilian beef, with five meatpacking plants in various states approved for exports. This marks the second agricultural deal between the two countries in two weeks, following a deal for Brazilian dairy products. The imports are expected to boost Brazilian agricultural exports, which reached a record $10.2 billion in April, 25% above the same month last year.

site_title: Hong Kong landlord stocks trade like it's 2009 all over again
summary: Hong Kong's real estate stocks, particularly those of landlords, have plummeted by over 48% in the past 12 months due to protests and the coronavirus pandemic. Swire Pacific Ltd and Hongkong Land Holdings Ltd have fallen to their lowest levels since 2009, raising concerns about the future of the city as a global financial center. Beijing's plan to impose the national security law is also casting doubt on the rule of law, potentially weakening investor appetite for Hong Kong commercial properties this year.

site_title: China will maintain stimulus even as economy improves
summary: China's economy is improving, with production and people's lives returning to normal, according to People's Bank of China Governor Yi Gang. Despite global uncertainty, China will maintain its targeted easing approach, ensuring sufficient liquidity and lower borrowing costs. The PBOC plans to make its policy more precise and targeted in the future, with innovative tools. China's GDP growth is expected to slow, but the country's stimulus measures are seen as a "major strategic achievement." The decision aims to maintain economic momentum despite global turmoil.

site_title: WHO suspends trials of hydroxychloroquine as virus treatment
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) has suspended clinical trials of hydroxychloroquine as a potential treatment for coronavirus due to a study suggesting the drug may increase the risk of death among Covid-19 patients. The decision comes after a study published in The Lancet medical journal found that hydroxychloroquine and chloroquine could produce serious side effects and did not help patients hospitalized with Covid-19. The trials will continue with other treatments, but the WHO has taken a precautionary measure to review safety data.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher after lifting state of emergency
summary: Japan lifted a nationwide state of emergency, allowing the world's third-largest economy to gradually reopen. Tokyo stocks opened higher, with the Nikkei 225 index up 0.86% at 20,919.56. The broader Topix index edged up 0.67%. The move follows a period of lockdowns and restrictions to combat the coronavirus.

site_title: Parent of Singtel associate Bharti Airtel seeks US$1b from share placement
summary: Bharti Telecom, the parent of Indian mobile carrier Bharti Airtel, is seeking approximately $1 billion by selling a stake in the company through a share placement. The deal, facilitated by JPMorgan India, marks one of the largest follow-on offerings in India this year, following a 2020 sale that raised $3 billion. The move comes as investors anticipate the end of a years-long price war in the Indian telecom market.

site_title: Stocks to watch: ComfortDelGro, Koufu, DBS, Lian Beng, SLB, Geo Energy
summary: Singapore stocks to watch: ComfortDelGro's net profit fell 48.9% to S$36 million in Q1, hit by weak ridership amid COVID-19 lockdowns. Geo Energy's long-term issuer default rating was downgraded to C. iX Biopharma commenced telemedicine supply of its medicines in Australia.

site_title: France virus toll nears 28,500 as daily deaths slow
summary: France's total COVID-19 deaths neared 28,500, with 90 confirmed deaths on Monday, according to the health ministry. The daily death toll has shown signs of slowing, but officials caution that the epidemic is not over yet. President Emmanuel Macron has warned of the need for continued vigilance. The recent relaxation of the nationwide lockdown has not led to an increase in cases, but the counting process was delayed due to a long holiday weekend.

site_title: Trump fumes on Twitter as media slams pandemic golf outing
summary: US President Donald Trump criticized the media for negative coverage of his golf outing over Memorial Day weekend, despite the US death toll from the coronavirus pandemic nearing 100,000. Trump argued that playing golf is a necessary break for the president, citing his past defense of former President Barack Obama for doing the same during a crisis. Trump received support from former Obama adviser David Axelrod, who pointed out the hypocrisy in Trump's criticism.

site_title: Scientists fight online virus misinformation war
summary: Scientists and researchers are fighting misinformation about the coronavirus pandemic on social media. Experts warn that false claims can pose a serious threat to public health, and some have seen their Twitter followings increase as they share scientific research and aim to counter misinformation. Institutions and organizations, such as the World Health Organization and Facebook, are also working to combat misinformation. Researchers emphasize the need for a "culture of science" to educate the public about the complexities of scientific knowledge and the importance of credible sources.

site_title: World needs 'green recovery', health pros tell G-20 leaders
summary: G-20 leaders are urged to prioritize investment in public health, clean air, and a stable climate for a "healthy and green recovery" post-pandemic. A letter from 200 medical groups representing 40 million health professionals worldwide, backed by the World Health Organization, calls for trillions of dollars to be invested in pandemic preparedness, public health, and environmental stewardship. The letter highlights the health-wrecking impact of air pollution and climate change, and advocates for removing subsidies for oil, gas, and coal, and boosting renewable energy.

site_title: PM Johnson says Britain could reopen stores on June 15
summary: UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson announced that Britain could reopen all non-essential retail stores on June 15 if the coronavirus remains contained. This comes after the country's official death toll of 36,914, which is Europe's highest. The number of new deaths and infections has fallen sharply, and outdoor markets and schools for younger children are set to reopen on June 1. Johnson stated that progress against the disease will be the key factor in deciding the reopening of stores.

images.alt_text: Prime Minister Boris Johnson said on Monday that Britain could reopen all non-essential retail stores on June 15 if the coronavirus remains contained.

site_title: Singapore non-oil exports tipped to fall -4% to -1% in 2020
summary: Singapore's non-oil exports are projected to decline by 4.0% to -1.0% in 2020 due to the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic, according to Enterprise Singapore. site_title: Europe lifts virus shutters as Japan ends emergency
summary: Europe lifted virus shutters as countries eased coronavirus restrictions, with Spain and Germany reopening parks, gyms, and pools. site_title: First Iranian oil tanker docks in Venezuela

summary: Hong Kong leader Carrie Lam stated that proposed national security laws will not affect the city's rights and freedoms, amid widespread concerns. site_title: Franco-German proposal can be Europe's Hamiltonian moment
summary: European Union leaders are considering a Franco-German proposal for a 500 billion euro recovery fund, which could transform European politics. The plan involves financing the fund with bonds issued by the EU, increasing the European Commission's budget, and introducing pan-European taxes. Three key innovations could increase the flexibility of EU fiscal policy and transform European politics. The EU will need to levy new taxes, such as carbon emissions and financial transactions, and could issue perpetual bonds with no redemption date. A compromise may be reached, allowing the EU to agree on a powerful recovery plan that preserves the three essential elements of the proposal.

site_title: Covid-19: Some govt service centres to reopen on June 2
summary: Singapore government service centres will reopen on June 2 as the country enters Phase 1 of the post-circuit breaker period. The centres will resume services only by appointment, with information available on the agencies' websites. This move comes as Singapore aims to gradually resume normal operations after a two-month circuit breaker period.

site_title: Digital transformation the lifeline for SMEs in pandemic
summary: During the COVID-19 pandemic, many small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) in Singapore have turned to digital transformation as a lifeline to stay operational. Retail sales have plummeted, but e-commerce sales have surged, with FMCG sales increasing by 43% and online grocery orders tripling. The government has launched programs to support SMEs, including the "Singapore E-Commerce Programme", which covers 90% of the costs for retailers to start selling online. To succeed, retailers should consider partnering with e-commerce platforms that offer reliable delivery, data analytics, and training resources, such as Lazada, which has seen a ten-fold increase in weekly sales for local retailers like Mothercare.

site_title: Abe seeks to boost economy, plans second aid package
summary: Japan's Prime Minister Shinzo Abe announced the end of the nationwide state of emergency due to the COVID-19 pandemic, citing declining cases. A second aid package is set to be funded, totaling over $2.65 trillion, to support the economy. The package will include loans, rent subsidies, and income support for furloughed workers. Abe warned of a possible second wave of infections and plans to gradually ease restrictions, with professional baseball and concerts set to resume without spectators. Japan's economy is expected to contract by almost 22% this quarter, with concerns raised about the government's handling of the pandemic.

site_title: MOH lists public places visited by Covid-19 cases; 344 new cases in Singapore
summary: Singapore reported 344 new Covid-19 cases, with 338 migrant workers in dormitories, on May 25, 2020. The cases were linked to public places visited by confirmed cases, including NTUC FairPrice and Shokutsu Ten Japanese Food Street. Six community cases were also reported, with three linked to pre-school staff. The total count of cases in Singapore rose to 31,960, with 862 more cases discharged, leaving 16,199 active cases.

site_title: Preparing for the next big phase of remote working
summary: Remote working has become the norm in Singapore, with 90% of employees wanting to continue working from home in some capacity after the circuit breaker period. Companies must prepare for the next phase by addressing cybersecurity risks, maintaining temporal boundaries, and establishing clear processes for remote teams. This includes requiring remote cybersecurity readiness, encouraging employees to secure their home technologies, and setting standard deadlines for recurring tasks. Additionally, employers must rethink employee evaluations, considering digital repositories of collaboration and contributions, to ensure productivity and fairness.

site_title: Looking after the well-being of migrant workers in Singapore
summary: Migrant workers in Singapore's construction industry are receiving assistance amid the Covid-19 pandemic. Welfare groups, corporations, and government agencies are providing meals, hotlines, and amenities such as masks and hand sanitizers. Despite concerns over living conditions, experts say that the issue is complex and multifaceted, requiring a collective effort to address. Organizations like ItsRainingRaincoats and DBS are partnering to provide support, including over 700,000 meals, as the situation continues to evolve. The migrant workers, who make up a significant portion of the workforce, are calling for improved living conditions and better protections.

site_title: China steel body, producers call for domestic iron ore output boost
summary: China's steel association and major steelmakers have called for a boost in domestic iron ore production to ensure supplies. Chairman He Wenbo of the China Iron & Steel Industry Association recommended keeping domestic iron ore output above 20% of total demand. The association also urged investment in overseas iron ore exploration, particularly in Africa and Canada, to reduce reliance on imports. Additionally, proposals were made to increase the collection and utilization of steel scrap, a more environmentally friendly alternative to iron ore in steel making.

site_title: Chaos, cancellations as India air travel restarts
summary: India's air travel restart was marred by last-minute cancellations and chaos as states restricted flights hours before departure, leaving hundreds of passengers stranded. Airlines, including IndiGo and SpiceJet, had planned to resume operations with reduced capacity but new restrictions at major airports forced them to revise schedules. Industry executives and analysts say the handling of the restart has been "a farce," causing pain for airlines, airports, and passengers, and that a lack of clarity on quarantine rules will deter potential travelers.

site_title: Wyndham Hotels now operating at 50% occupancy, demand seen continuing
summary: Wyndham Hotels & Resorts Inc. is operating at 50% occupancy, a significant increase from the previous five weeks, according to CEO Geoff Ballotti. The company expects demand to continue. Ballotti praised the emergency support provided by Congress and the Federal Reserve, citing the Paycheck Protection Program as a "lifeline" for his franchisees. He also expressed a desire for more flexibility in the PPP system, allowing for longer repayment periods and more use of funds for operating costs beyond worker pay. Guests are also being asked to wear masks at Wyndham hotels.

site_title: Who will do the dirty, intensive jobs that Singaporeans shun?
summary: Singaporean employers are struggling to fill jobs deemed too dirty or intensive, despite offering higher pay and overseas work opportunities. Foreign workers are often recruited for roles such as warehouse packers, spa therapists, and F&B service staff, which locals shun. Companies like Mary Chia Group and Spa Esprit Group are adopting high-tech solutions and incentivizing local referrals to attract employees. However, it's unclear if these efforts will be enough to address the labor shortage, with some employers stating that foreign labor is essential to their operations.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: Fortitude Budget to help create new jobs and traineeships
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat announced the Fortitude Budget, Singapore's fourth Covid-19 support package, which will focus on creating new jobs, training opportunities, and assisting workers who want to upskill. The budget will also provide more assistance to social sector agencies. The government has tapped past reserves for the support package, totaling S$63.7 billion. Singapore aims to reopen its economy in phases, with the goal of moving to the next phase around the end of June.

site_title: China lowers yuan fix to weakest level since 2008 after currency drop
summary: China's central bank set its daily yuan reference rate at 7.1209 per dollar, the weakest level since 2008, amid increasing tensions with the US. The onshore yuan hit a seven-month low in trading on Friday. Analysts expect volatility in the yuan as the US reacts to Beijing's tightening grip on Hong Kong. The People's Bank of China will monitor the yuan's movement against the dollar, particularly if it reaches 7.2. The US-China relationship has worsened, with trade and human rights issues contributing to the tensions.

site_title: DBS approves over 3,500 loans worth more than S$1.1b for micro, small enterprises
summary: DBS has approved over 3,500 loans worth more than S$1.1 billion to micro and small enterprises in Singapore under Enterprise Singapore's financing schemes. The loans account for 80% of all government-assisted SME loans approved by the bank since March 2020. The majority of borrowers came from the services, building and construction, and retail sectors, with 2/3 borrowing less than S$200,000. DBS is working with key stakeholders to ensure working capital support reaches the most challenged micro and small businesses, with a focus on heartland enterprises.

site_title: Volkswagen loses landmark German case as diesel owners stand to receive damages
summary: A German federal court judge ruled that Volkswagen must pay compensation to motorists who purchased vehicles with manipulated diesel engines. The ruling, a major blow to the carmaker, allows owners to return their vehicles for partial reimbursement of the purchase price. This decision serves as a template for about 60,000 pending lawsuits and could cost Volkswagen more than 30 billion euros in damages and fines. The ruling comes after Volkswagen was forced to update its engine control software to ensure anti-pollution filters are activated.

site_title: Bank of Thailand's governor won't seek a second term
summary: Bank of Thailand Governor Veerathai Santiprabhob will not seek a second term due to family reasons. His term ends in September, and a new governor will take over, shaping policy for the Covid-19-induced economic crash. The economy is expected to shrink 6% this year, and the central bank has implemented measures to support the economy, including cutting interest rates and providing cheap funds for commercial banks to lend to small and medium-sized companies. A smooth transition is expected, and the change in governor is unlikely to affect policy direction.

images.alt_text: For family reasons, BOT governor Veerathai Santiprabhob will not apply for another five years as the head of the central bank. He will ensure a smooth transition when his term ends in September.

site_title: Time to look at Singapore-listed blue chip developers
summary: Singapore-listed blue chip developers CDL, UOL, and CapitaLand offer significant valuation upside for investors if they can ride out the current down cycle. The developers' shares are trading close to previous trough scenarios, with RNAV discounts ranging from 25% to 57% to their revalued net asset values. Analysts have set target prices for the companies, with CDL's target price ranging from S$8.03 to S$10.13 and UOL's at S$6.49. CapitaLand's shares have closed at S$2.87, with a target price of S$4.42. The companies' exposure to the residential and commercial markets, as well as their stable income profiles, make them attractive to investors.

images.alt_text: CDL's Piermont Grand. The developer is often said to be the most direct proxy for investing in the Singapore residential sector.
UOL's Velocity@Novena Square. While CDL has greater exposure to the residential space, UOL is more exposed to commercial properties.
Raffles City Chongqing. Most of CapitaLand's assets are in China. The key asset class driving its recurring income is retail, though the group also owns offices and serviced residences.

site_title: China official in Hong Kong says some protest acts 'terrorist in nature'
summary: China's foreign ministry office in Hong Kong stated that some actions during last year's pro-democracy protests were "terrorist in nature" and posed "imminent danger" to national security. Commissioner Xie Feng said the proposed national security legislation would tackle secession, subversion, and terrorism, and would only affect a small number of residents. The law's introduction has drawn condemnation from Western governments and sparked fears of limiting rights and freedoms.

site_title: Book sales soar as French lockdown eases
summary: Book sales in France have surged by over 230% since the country eased its lockdown, with readers stocking up at bookshops that reopened for takeaway or click-and-collect sales. Despite a 60% decline in overall sales compared to 2019, the French publishing industry remains badly hit, with revenues dropping 80%. Culture Minister Franck Riester is working on an aid package for the industry, which has more independent bookshops than most European countries.

site_title: Singapore's APL England loses cargo in heavy Australian seas
summary: A Singapore-flagged cargo ship, APL England, lost at least 40 containers in heavy seas off the coast of Sydney. The ship lost propulsion power about 73 kilometers south-east of Sydney while en route from Ningbo, China to Melbourne, Australia. 74 containers were damaged, with 9 protruding from the ship's sides. This incident is not the first time the vessel has lost cargo at sea, having lost 37 containers in 2016. Efforts to recover the lost containers were hindered by bad weather and poor visibility.

site_title: China says HK judiciary to stay independent under new law
summary: China has reassured Hong Kong that its judiciary will remain independent under a new national security law, but the lack of details has sparked concerns among the business community. The law, set to be passed by China's parliament, aims to ensure national security but has been criticized for undermining Hong Kong's autonomy. The Hong Kong Bar Association has called the legislation "worrying and problematic" and urged authorities to address constitutional and legal concerns. The measure is expected to pass before the end of China's annual session on May 28, prompting fresh protests in Hong Kong.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks close slightly higher
summary: Hong Kong stocks closed slightly higher on Monday, reversing a morning sell-off, after a weekend of protests against a proposed security law. The Hang Seng Index rose 0.10%, while the Shanghai Composite Index added 0.15%. The Shenzhen Composite Index declined 0.09%. The gains come amid ongoing tensions in the city, but investors remain cautious.

site_title: S Korean cafe hires robot barista to help with social distancing
summary: A South Korean cafe has introduced a robot barista to aid in social distancing measures during the COVID-19 pandemic. The robot, developed by Vision Semicon and a state-run science institute, can make 60 different types of coffee and communicate with customers. The cafe, which has a sparse seating arrangement, aims to supply at least 30 cafes with robots this year. The robot's introduction is part of South Korea's transition from intensive social distancing to "distancing in daily life" and may raise concerns about job market implications for human baristas.

site_title: Vividthree posts net loss of S$829,063 for FY2020
summary: Vividthree Holdings reported a net loss of S$829,063 for FY2020 due to a decline in content production revenue 61.2% year-on-year, primarily affected by the Covid-19 pandemic. Revenue fell 33.9% to S$6.14 million. The post-production segment saw a growth, but gross profit fell 68.3% year-on-year to S$2.05 million. Despite the loss, Vividthree remains optimistic about its future prospects, particularly for its flagship show "Train to Busan" and its digital platforms.

site_title: Tiger Woods prevails in star-studded tournament to raise US$20m for charity
summary: Tiger Woods won a star-studded golf tournament, raising US$20 million for charity. The 44-year-old Woods, who underwent surgery on his back, used the pandemic downtime to get in shape for a condensed fall golf season. Despite concerns about his surgically repaired back, Woods expressed confidence in his health and readiness to compete.

site_title: Food delivery giant Meituan Dianping posts Q1 loss as pandemic hits orders
summary: Chinese food delivery giant Meituan Dianping reported a Q1 loss of 1.58 billion yuan, a 10% increase from the same period last year, due to the pandemic's impact on orders. Revenue fell to 16.75 billion yuan, down 13% from the previous year. The company attributed the decline to nationwide business curbs and reduced consumer demand. Despite a slow reopening, Meituan warned its business will be affected for the rest of 2020 due to ongoing pandemic precautions and consumer confidence.

site_title: China says to take action if US undermines its interests in Hong Kong
summary: China has warned that it will take countermeasures if the US continues to undermine its interests in Hong Kong, following comments from White House National Security Adviser Robert O'Brien that the city's new national security legislation could lead to US sanctions. Chinese foreign ministry spokesperson Zhao Lijian stated that the US is trying to harm China's national security, prompting Beijing to lodge stern representations with Washington.

site_title: Gold prices slip on rising US dollar, equities
summary: Gold prices fell 0.3% to $1,729.05 per ounce, due to a strengthening US dollar and rising equities, despite limited losses from US-China trade tensions. Most markets were closed for public holidays, with US gold futures also down 0.4% to $1,729.40. The decline comes as investors weigh market outlook, tariffs, and sanctions, with gold seen as a safe-haven metal.

site_title: Cirque du Soleil founder wants to buy back show
summary: Cirque du Soleil founder Guy Laliberte announced plans to buy back the circus troupe, which has struggled due to the coronavirus pandemic. Laliberte, who sold his last remaining stake in 2020, claims to have a "good plan" to revive the circus. The troupe is heavily indebted, with an estimated $900 million debt, and has furloughed 95% of its staff. Laliberte wants to keep the headquarters in Montreal and maintain a Quebecois management team, and has expressed support from partners for the buyout.

site_title: Singapore may move to second phase of reopening at end-June: Lawrence Wong
summary: Singapore's Minister for National Development Lawrence Wong announced plans to move to the second phase of re-opening around end-June, with more activities to resume if all goes well. A phased approach will allow for better control of new cases, and proactive testing will continue. Wong expects a rise in coronavirus infections due to hidden cases in the general population, requiring cautious measures. The government will provide assistance to affected businesses, households, and workers, with Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat expected to announce details in a Budget speech on May 26.

site_title: Japan lifts Tokyo's state of emergency, eyes fresh stimulus
summary: Japan's Prime Minister Shinzo Abe announced the lifting of a state of emergency for Tokyo and four other prefectures, effective later in the day, amid a decline in new infections. The government has approved a total stimulus of 200 trillion yen from two economic packages to support the economy, which is on track for its deepest slump in postwar history. Despite the lifting of the emergency, the government will continue to monitor Tokyo and other areas for potential flare-ups, and a new economic stimulus package worth 100 trillion yen is being considered to support the economy.

site_title: DBS approves over 3,500 loans, worth over S$1.1b, for micro and small enterprises
summary: DBS bank has approved over 3,500 loans worth more than S$1.1 billion to micro and small enterprises in Singapore, accounting for eight in ten government-assisted SME loans. The loans were mainly approved to companies in the services, building and construction, and retail sectors. Many of these businesses have no prior relationship with DBS and may not be familiar with financing solutions. DBS is doubling down on its support for micro and small enterprises, working with stakeholders to reach the most challenged businesses.

site_title: Vietnam plans 15.84t dong tax cut for small businesses
summary: Vietnam plans to cut corporate income tax for small businesses by 15.84 trillion dong (S$968.9 million) this year, targeting companies with annual revenue of less than 50 billion dong and fewer than 100 employees. This move aims to help small firms overcome the impact of the coronavirus pandemic. The plan is pending government approval, which also includes a 37.5 trillion dong tax exemption for agricultural land use from 2021-2025.

site_title: Asahi to borrow 1.19t for purchase of AB InBev's Australia unit
summary: Asahi Group Holdings has agreed to borrow 1.19 trillion yen (S$15.69 billion) from Sumitomo Mitsui Banking Corp to finance its acquisition of Anheuser-Busch InBev's Australian subsidiary, Carlton & United Breweries. The deal, set to close on June 1, marks a significant expansion for Asahi in the Australian market. The loan is part of Asahi's efforts to strengthen its global presence.

site_title: Eurozone bond yields steady; focus remains on recovery fund
summary: Eurozone bond yields remained steady on Monday, overshadowing opposition to the European Union's planned 500 billion euro recovery fund from Austria, Sweden, Denmark, and the Netherlands. The four countries proposed a "loans for loans" approach, excluding mutualisation of debt and a temporary, two-year duration. The European Commission is set to release its recovery plan on Wednesday, with Eurogroup chief Mario Centeno calling it a step towards a fiscal union. Market focus remains on the plan, despite the "Frugal Four" countries' opposition.

site_title: LVMH boss Arnault's company to buy stake in Lagardere holding firm
summary: LVMH boss Bernard Arnault's company, Groupe Arnault, has agreed to buy a stake equivalent to around one-quarter of the share capital of Lagardere Capital & Management (LCM), the holding company of fellow French billionaire Arnaud Lagardere. This move comes after Lagardere fended off an activist fund's attempt to replace the supervisory board earlier this month. The deal is part of a larger expansion strategy for both companies, with Groupe Arnault's purchase providing LCM with additional capital and support.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares begin on negative note
summary: Hong Kong stocks began Monday with a 0.9% drop, extending a sharp decline at the end of last week. The Hang Seng Index fell to 22,725.70, while China's Shanghai Composite Index edged up 0.09%. The drop comes amid fresh street clashes over a proposed security law by China, further fueling concerns about the city's economic and social stability.

site_title: Property agent group appeals to Chan Chun Sing to allow physical viewings of vacant units
summary: A Singapore association of real estate agents has appealed to Minister Chan Chun Sing to allow physical viewings of vacant property units after the circuit breaker lifts on June 2, citing further loss of income for landlords, owners, and agents. A normal tenancy deal takes a month to complete, and the June to July period is a peak for potential tenants searching for homes before the international school semester starts in August. The suspension of physical viewings is expected to impact the property market during this critical period.

site_title: Fourth Covid-19 support package to focus heavily on jobs: Heng Swee Keat
summary: Deputy Prime Minister and Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat announced the fourth Covid-19 support package, dubbed the Fortitude Budget, which will focus heavily on jobs. The package will provide assistance to workers seeking employment, upskilling, and creating new jobs for those looking for work. It will also support social sector agencies and help vulnerable individuals. The government plans to draw on past reserves for the package, which will be the second time reserves are tapped for the Covid-19 response. Singapore aims to move to the next phase of re-opening by the end of June.

site_title: Seoul: Shares gain as lockdown curbs ease; Sino-US rift in focus
summary: South Korean shares rose 0.42% on Monday, driven by hopes of an economic recovery as lockdown curbs ease globally. However, concerns about mounting Sino-US tensions capped gains. The US Commerce Department added 33 Chinese companies to a blacklist for human rights violations, while China proposed national security laws for Hong Kong. Shares of Kakao Corp, a mobile messenger provider, surged 6% as demand for "contactless services" increased during the pandemic. Foreigners were net sellers of 69.1 billion won worth of shares, weakening the Korean won.

site_title: Football clubs forced to rethink recruitment strategy as virus impacts transfer market
summary: Football clubs are rethinking their recruitment strategies due to the COVID-19 pandemic's impact on the transfer market. Fees are expected to drop 30-50% and transfer activity by 70-75%, mainly due to matchday revenue losses. Clubs are forced to adapt, with some relying more on data and analytics, while others may emerge stronger. Scouts are no longer able to physically watch players, but the shutdown has given them time to reassess options. The financial uncertainty of the season's restart and potential relegation or promotion has added complexity to planning for the summer window.

site_title: China lowers yuan midpoint to weakest since 2008 global financial crisis
summary: China's central bank lowered its official yuan midpoint to 7.1209 yuan per dollar, the weakest since the 2008 global financial crisis, following Beijing's proposal of a new national security law for Hong Kong. The move reflects losses in the spot yuan on Friday. The People's Bank of China (PBOC) set the new midpoint 0.38% weaker than the previous fix.

site_title: Uniqlo to make masks using underwear fabric
summary: Uniqlo plans to sell face masks made from its Airism underwear fabric due to strong customer demand for protective gear amid the coronavirus pandemic. The masks, which feature a breathable and moisture-wicking fabric, will be sold at a later date. This decision comes after Uniqlo received many customer requests to produce face masks, despite the company initially being wary of making them. The move aims to address the shortage of face masks in Japan, where the epidemic has led to a shortage of protective gear.

site_title: Europe: Shares rise on recovery hopes, Bayer jumps
summary: European shares rose 0.9-1.2% in thin trading, driven by optimism over reopening and stimulus for the eurozone economy. Bayer jumped 6.3% after progress in a cancer claims settlement, while Lagardere surged 9.6% after a billionaire stake purchase. Despite US-China tensions, investors focused on European recovery signs, including a decrease in new coronavirus cases and Germany's rebounding business morale. The European Central Bank is poised to expand its stimulus scheme if economic data warrant it.

site_title: Renault must join French-German battery project: minister
summary: Renault must join a French-German battery project to receive a €5 billion government rescue loan, Finance Minister Bruno Le Maire said. The automaker will unveil a revamp of its operations and partnership with Nissan and Mitsubishi amid falling sales and profitability. Renault, which holds a 15% stake in the company, will need to make a commitment to become a shareholder in the electric battery alliance. This is one of the subjects being negotiated.

site_title: Taiwan considers revoking Hong Kong's special status on law fears
summary: Taiwan's President Tsai Ing-wen considers revoking Hong Kong's special status due to concerns over China's proposed national security law, which could limit Hong Kong's freedoms and judicial independence. If implemented, the law could lead to a change in Taiwan's rules allowing Hong Kong residents to visit and invest, potentially harming Hong Kong's economy and relations with Taiwan. Beijing views any move by Taiwan as a threat to its authority, sparking further tension.

images.alt_text: President Tsai Ing-wen said, a move that could anger Beijing and make it harder for Hong Kongers to visit and invest.

site_title: ShawKwei backs HK cosmetics packaging firm with eye on M&A
summary: Private equity firm ShawKwei has made an undisclosed investment in Hong Kong-based International Cosmetic Suppliers (ICS), a provider of cosmetic packaging. ICS, founded in 1991, will pursue strategic acquisitions in Asia, the US, and Europe to grow the business. ShawKwei's founder, Kyle Shaw, believes the industry is profitable if companies can meet market demands. The investment comes as private equity deal-making slows down amid the Covid-19 pandemic.

site_title: CEO buys ailing New Zealand media giant for one NZ dollar
summary: New Zealand media giant Stuff Limited was sold to its Australian owners' local CEO, Sinead Boucher, in a management buy-out deal for NZ$1.00. The sale reflects the difficulties in New Zealand's media sector due to the COVID-19 pandemic and its impact on revenues. Boucher aims to build on the trust of New Zealanders with local ownership, following a similar one-dollar bid from Stuff's main rival, NZME, being rejected earlier this month.

site_title: Fiji Airways to cut more than half its staff, seek aircraft payment deferrals
summary: Fiji Airways will cut 51% of its staff, affecting 758 employees, due to the pandemic-driven downturn. Remaining staff will see 20% salary cuts, and flying cuts will be extended to August. CEO Andre Viljoen aims to ensure the airline's survival, despite the global crisis. Fiji's tourism industry relies on the airline, and the country is seeking to be included in a proposed travel bubble with Australia and New Zealand.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on virus hopes
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Monday, with the Nikkei 225 index up 1.37% and the Topix index advancing 1.16%, following expectations that the state of emergency will be lifted for the whole nation, including Tokyo. This comes after the government lifted the emergency for the western Osaka region last week.

site_title: Social services to get supplementary Budget help
summary: Singapore's supplementary Budget, set to be announced on Tuesday, will include support for the social service sector amid the Covid-19 pandemic. Deputy Prime Minister and Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat said the sector will receive assistance to strengthen collaboration and capability building, as well as embrace digitalization. The fourth package of Covid-19 support will focus on workers and firms that cannot resume activities after the circuit breaker period ends on June 1, with potential further draws on reserves to fund the measures.

site_title: Increasing debt level feasible and necessary, says China official
summary: China's senior official Cong Liang says the country's plan to raise its debt level to stimulate demand and combat the economic effects of the coronavirus pandemic is feasible and necessary. The government plans to raise its fiscal deficit and sell anti-virus government bonds, with the goal of controlling debt-related risks. China's government debt ratio is relatively low globally at 38.5% of GDP, and the country aims to increase debt to support economic and social development. The government plans a fiscal deficit of over 3.6% of GDP and borrowings of around $600 billion.

site_title: Apple to start reopening stores in Japan this week
summary: Apple will reopen two retail stores in Japan, in Fukuoka and Nagoya Sakae, on May 27, following months of closure due to COVID-19. This marks the company's return to the country after previously reopening stores in other major markets. Apple's Japan stores will require temperature checks, social distancing, and mask-wearing for customers and staff, in line with local regulations. The move comes as Tokyo prepares to lift its state of emergency, which is expected to be lifted this week.

site_title: Most publicly-listed companies keep US small-business aid loans
summary: Most publicly-listed US companies that received emergency small-business loans from the government have kept the loans, totaling $435.8 million out of $1.35 billion. As of May 22, 68 companies had returned the funds, while 76 companies received loans but claimed they had enough resources to cover operating costs until at least June. The Paycheck Protection Program, created to help small businesses cope with the coronavirus outbreak, has faced criticism for allowing public companies to access capital.

site_title: Singapore dollar looks vulnerable even as economy opens up
summary: Singapore's currency remains under pressure despite an easing of lockdown measures, with the US dollar-Singapore dollar pair trading above its one-month low. The nation's economy is expected to contract 1.8% year-on-year in the first quarter, and the government projects a 1-4% GDP shrinkage in 2020. The Monetary Authority of Singapore has signaled its willingness to let the currency weaken to support the trade-reliant economy, which is also facing global headwinds and subdued growth forecasts.

site_title: Asia: Shares reverse early gains, eyes on US-China trade relations
summary: Asian stocks reversed early gains on Monday, weighed down by souring US-China relations and mounting fears about Hong Kong's stability. China's CSI300 index fell 0.2%, while Hong Kong's HSI index plummeted 1.4% to a two-month low. Analysts expect subdued trading due to US and British markets being shut for public holidays. Rising tensions between the US and China around Hong Kong, trade policy, and the 2020 economic dislocation threaten to end the post-March-trough rally, according to Perpetual analyst Matthew Sherwood.

site_title: India's ITC to acquire spices maker Sunrise Foods
summary: ITC, India's consumer goods giant, is set to acquire 100% of the equity share capital of Sunrise Foods Private Limited, a spices maker, in a deal not disclosed. The acquisition, announced on May 23, marks ITC's entry into the spice business under the trademark "Sunrise". This move aims to expand ITC's portfolio in the food and beverage segment. The deal is ITC's latest foray into the spice market, solidifying its position as a leading player in the Indian consumer goods industry.

site_title: Oil dips as US-China tensions add to nerves on global economy
summary: US-China tensions have added to global economic concerns, causing oil prices to dip 1.4% in Asia. Futures fell despite a 13% rise last week as producers curb output, exposing the industry's need for new drilling. The US market is closed for the Memorial Day holiday, and travel over the weekend is expected to be low due to Covid-19 worries. Big oil annual general meetings will provide insight into the impact of lockdowns on producers, while Russian President Vladimir Putin has set a deadline for a plan to support the country's oil industry.

site_title: US dollar edges higher as Hong Kong tensions fuel safe-haven demand
summary: The US dollar edged higher against other major currencies as investors sought safe-haven assets amid rising tensions between the US and China over Hong Kong's security law. A senior White House official warned that US sanctions could worsen relations with China. Sterling was also under pressure after members of Boris Johnson's party called for the resignation of an influential aide. The developments fueled concerns about global economic growth and led to increased demand for safe-haven currencies.

site_title: Car sales can be conducted safely, says Singapore trade association
summary: Singapore's Vehicle Traders Association has appealed to the government to resume car sales when the "circuit breaker" is lifted next month, citing the significant economic and job losses the industry has incurred since Covid-19 hit Singapore in January. The association claims that car viewings and test-drives can be managed safely with strict measures in place, and is also requesting clarity on the certificate of entitlement (COE) quota and the ability to cancel COE bids. The industry contributes S$6.3 billion to the economy annually, comparable to the airline industry.

site_title: 'Sunshine to Asia' power plan moves forward with cable contract
summary: Australia's "Sunshine to Asia" power plan moves forward with a 3,800-kilometre undersea cable connecting a giant solar farm in Australia to Singapore. The project, backed by Atlassian co-founder Mike Cannon-Brookes and Fortescue Metals' founder Andrew Forrest, aims to supply a fifth of Singapore's power needs. The project's total capital cost is estimated at A$20 billion, with commercial operations targeted for 2027. The Sun Cable project also plans to link to Indonesia, providing clean energy and reducing Australia's reliance on coal and gas export revenues.

site_title: Japan eyeing second extra budget worth over 100t yen: report
summary: Japan's government is considering a second extra budget worth over 100 trillion yen to combat the economic impact of the coronavirus pandemic. The budget includes 60 trillion yen for low-interest loan schemes and 27 trillion yen for other financial aid programs. The government is expected to approve the budget at a Cabinet meeting on Wednesday.

site_title: Magnitude 5.9 earthquake strikes New Zealand near capital city
summary: A magnitude 5.9 earthquake struck near Wellington, New Zealand's capital city, on May 24, 2020. The earthquake was 46km deep and 25km northwest of Levin, with no immediate reports of damage. New Zealand is located on the seismically active "Ring of Fire", making it prone to earthquakes. The earthquake occurred at a depth of 46km and was 25km northwest of Levin, according to Geonet.

site_title: Childcare centre worker among 548 new Covid-19 cases in Singapore
summary: A childcare centre worker in Singapore, confirmed to have Covid-19, was among 548 new cases reported on Sunday, bringing the total count to 31,616. The 33-year-old woman worked at Iman Childcare (Tampines) and was confirmed to have the virus after showing symptoms on Saturday.

site_title: Wyndham Hotels now operating near 50% occupancy, CEO says
summary: Wyndham Hotels & Resorts Inc CEO Geoff Ballotti reported that his midscale hotels are operating at about 50% occupancy after five consecutive weeks of increasing demand. Ballotti attributed the growth to guests following CDC, WHO, and state guidelines. He also expressed appreciation for emergency support from Congress and the Federal Reserve. Many franchisees have applied for the Paycheck Protection Program loan, and Ballotti suggested easing loan repayment terms to better support their operations. Guests are also being asked to wear masks upon check-in, and hotels have reported being cleaner than ever.

site_title: Qatar virus tracing app stirs rare privacy backlash
summary: Qatar's coronavirus contact tracing app, Ehteraz, has sparked a rare backlash due to its invasive permissions, including access to users' picture and video galleries and ability to make unprompted calls. Mandatory for citizens and residents, non-compliance can result in up to three years in jail. Critics argue the app's extensive permissions erode trust and are concerned about state surveillance. The government has offered reassurance and concessions, promising to address concerns and improve the app's efficiency, but many users are opting for "burner" phones to protect their privacy.

site_title: He says Trumps cost him US$2m, but hotelier now cheers federal assistance
summary: Hotelier Dinesh Chawla, who lost about $2 million in a failed partnership with the Trump Organization, has received federal assistance through the Paycheck Protection Program. Chawla obtained $250,000 in loans, with $50,000 going towards his former Scion hotel project. He credits the program with helping him keep employees on the payroll during the pandemic. Chawla's experience marks a rare instance of a Trump family business associate acknowledging federal funding, as many others have denied participation or declined to comment.

site_title: Hong Kong hit by fresh protest after China security proposal
summary: Thousands of Hong Kong protesters gathered against China's proposed security law, leading to clashes with police. The law, expected to ban treason, subversion, and sedition, has sparked fears of the erosion of Hong Kong's freedoms. At least 120 people were arrested as police fired tear gas and water cannon to disperse the crowd. The Chinese government insists the law must be imposed "without delay," sparking concerns from Western governments and campaigners.

site_title: Aston Martin to tap AMG head as new CEO in management shakeup
summary: Aston Martin is set to replace CEO Andy Palmer with Tobias Moers, head of Mercedes-AMG, amid a management shakeup. The move comes after a £536 million investment from billionaire Lawrence Stroll to rescue the debt-laden company. The company has struggled since Palmer took it public in 2018, with sales stalled and inventory piling up. Moers' appointment could signal a fresh approach to the company's turnaround plan, which includes the DBX SUV and plans for derivative models. Aston Martin has reported a £76.6 million operating loss in the three months ended in March.

site_title: Money Hacks: Passive vs active investing - debunking misconceptions (Ep 72)
summary: A podcast episode discusses the differences between passive and active investing, debunking misconceptions. Host Chris Lim talks to Gregory Van, CEO of Endowus, about the historically proven 17% chance of beating the market over 15 years. The episode explains the differences between active and passive investing, including cash, government debt, and equities. Digital investment advisers can help with lower costs and strategic asset allocation. The episode aims to provide actionable financial tips for investors in Singapore, with a focus on general information and caution to consult a financial adviser before making investment decisions.

site_title: Sales at self-storage firms in Singapore stall amid lockdown
summary: Sales at self-storage firms in Singapore have dropped sharply amid the lockdown, with some operators experiencing a 90% decline in actual sales and a 50% reduction in queries. However, long-term outlook for the industry remains promising, with flexibility and technology expected to play a key role in differentiating operators. The industry is expected to evolve to stay ahead of competition, with operators focusing on enhancing customer experience and leveraging data to improve services. As the circuit breaker measures lift on June 2, operators are preparing to resume operations with precautionary measures in place.

site_title: Director filing momentum returns
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) gained 1.3% over five trading sessions, bringing its decline in total return for the 2020 year to 20.8%. The iEdge S-Reit 20 Index rose 4.6% and eight primary-listed stocks conducted share buybacks, with Singapore Technologies Engineering (STE) leading the tally. Director and substantial shareholder transactions included 110 changes in director interests and substantial shareholdings, with notable acquisitions by Fullwealth Trading Ltd and substantial shareholders in Luxking Group Holdings and Hwa Hong Corporation.

site_title: OCBC taps on technology to continue volunteer outreach activities
summary: OCBC is leveraging technology to continue volunteer outreach activities amidst the COVID-19 pandemic, prioritizing the safety of its beneficiaries. The bank has organized interactive storytelling activities, virtual excursions, and cognitive exercises for children, youth, and seniors. With staff volunteers working remotely, OCBC aims to build relationships with its beneficiaries until face-to-face meetings can resume. The bank's virtual volunteering efforts are part of its ongoing commitment to charity partners, despite the challenges posed by social distancing measures.

images.alt_text: OCBC staff volunteers started an interactive story-telling activity for children.

site_title: Euro against US dollar on downward trend
summary: The euro against the US dollar (EURUSD) has been on a downward trend since 2018, with prices forming lower highs and lows. Recent price action suggests a possible continuation of the macro down trend, supported by indicators such as the 200-day exponential moving average, a rectangle pattern, and an overbought stochastics oscillator. Prices are currently trading within a narrow range, with a potential support level at 1.0795, and a possible next swing low at 1.0651.

site_title: China security law latest headache for HK developers
summary: Hong Kong's real estate stocks have plummeted as investors worry about Beijing's plan to impose a national security law, which could trigger violent protests and lead to a decline in property sales, shopping, and office rents. Wharf Real Estate Investment, Sino Land, and New World Development saw record losses, with the MSCI Hong Kong Index falling 5.4%. Concerns include increased vacancy rates for commercial properties, potential asset shifts out of the city, and the risk of the US and China becoming involved, which could spur outflows.

site_title: Professional services shore up staffing as insolvency cases loom amid virus outbreak
summary: Professional services firms in Singapore are bolstering their restructuring and insolvency (R&I) practices amid the COVID-19 outbreak, with several firms hiring more staff or reassigning existing team members to meet the increased demand. The surge in R&I cases is attributed to the pandemic's impact on various sectors, with firms seeking to navigate the challenges of debt restructuring. The move also comes as Singapore aims to establish itself as Asia's debt restructuring hub, with some firms collaborating with other departments or accounting firms to support the growing demand.

images.alt_text: As more businesses buckle under strain amid the virus outbreak, some firms in the professional services are boosting their restructuring and insolvency (R&I) practice with more aggressive hiring.

site_title: Fresh US-China tensions lift dollar
summary: The US dollar rose against a basket of currencies on Friday, driven by safe-haven demand due to heightened tensions between the US and China. China unveiled plans to impose a national security law in Hong Kong, which could lead to more unrest. The move further strained already deteriorating US-China ties, boosting the dollar.

site_title: Chinese companies listed on American exchanges feel the heat of US-China tension
summary: The US Senate has passed a bill that could disqualify Chinese companies from listing on American stock exchanges if they fail to comply with US auditing regulations. The bill, the Holding Foreign Companies Accountable Act, requires foreign issuers to submit documentation establishing they are not owned or controlled by a government entity and prohibits their securities from being traded on US exchanges if audits are not inspected for three consecutive years. This move is seen as a response to concerns over intellectual property theft and human rights abuses by Chinese companies, which have become a significant feature of the US market.

images.alt_text: This past week, the US Senate passed by unanimous consent a bill that could disqualify many Chinese companies from listing on American stock exchanges.

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary: The global dry bulk market has stalled out after a week of bounce momentum, with the Capesize 5TC index pricing at $4140, up from $1980 last week. Atlantic routes, particularly the fronthaul (C9) and Brazil to China (C3) routes, have shown resilience despite dreadful fundamentals. Bunker rates strengthened significantly, assisting the bounce, while Panamax rates remained low. Ultramax/Supramax activity improved, with a 63,000-dwt open Philippines fixing at $8,500 for 6-9 months trading. Handysize activity was limited, with east coast South America showing firming signs.

site_title: Hyphens Pharma revs up digital push amid Covid-19
summary: Hyphens Pharma International, a Singapore-based pharmaceutical and consumer healthcare company, is leveraging digital technology to stay connected with medical professionals and consumers amid the COVID-19 pandemic. The company has seen a 48.6% increase in net profit to S$2.12 million and a 16.4% rise in revenue to S$31.4 million in the first quarter. Hyphens is expanding its digital presence through its B2B and B2C portals, exploring telemedicine opportunities, and developing proprietary brands, with a long-term goal to become Asean's leading pharmaceuticals and consumer healthcare group.

site_title: Less is more as US art museums reopen
summary: The US art museum, Museum of Fine Arts in Houston, has reopened with timed tickets and limited entry, allowing each visitor to have a studio apartment's worth of space to themselves. The museum, which reopened on May 24, 2020, has implemented safety precautions such as thermal imaging devices, hand sanitiser, and masks. The move is seen as a success, with the museum's director, Gary Tinterow, stating that the controlled environment has given him confidence that the museum can reopen safely. Other Texas museums have also reopened, with some opting to wait due to financial concerns.

site_title: Opening up to big changes
summary: The Covid-19 crisis has accelerated a shift towards an omni-location work environment, where the office is no longer the primary location for work. This change is driven by the need for physical distancing and will lead to a fundamental shift in office culture, from an outcome-based to a trust-based culture. The office as a physical entity may become obsolete, and work will evolve to accommodate virtual work environments. Experts predict that the change will be irreversible, with a long-delayed transition to virtual work becoming the new norm.

site_title: China's efforts to resolve financial risks slowed by coronavirus
summary: China's efforts to address financial risks have been hindered by the coronavirus outbreak, with regulators extending their temporary custodianship of a bank and considering more tolerant measures to tackle new risks. The government has also dropped its annual growth target, with Premier Li Keqiang warning of mounting financial risks in the economy. Despite this, China's commercial banks saw a 5% year-on-year increase in profits in the first quarter, but the possibility of zero or negative profit growth in 2020 remains due to mounting bad loans and cash buffer depletion.

site_title: After Ghosn and coronavirus, Renault and Nissan weigh future
summary: Renault and Nissan, a Franco-Japanese industrial alliance, are reevaluating their strategy amid the economic fallout from the COVID-19 pandemic. The alliance, which once accounted for 10% of the global auto market, is set to cut production capacity and slash costs to cope with the crisis. Nissan, which holds a 43% stake in Renault, is expected to reveal heavy losses, while Renault is fighting for survival with a five billion euro loan package from the French government. The alliance's priorities are shifting towards core markets, with a focus on trimming production capacity and cutting fixed costs.

site_title: BT Budding Artists Fund beneficiaries lead Certis staff in virtual dance workshop
summary: Certis, an integrated security organization, partnered with The Business Times Budding Artists Fund (BT BAF) for a virtual dance workshop, as part of their Community Give Back series. The workshop, held on May 18, was led by BT BAF beneficiaries and aimed to create a video for a special TikTok hashtag challenge. The event aimed to promote kindness and arts education, and participants praised the experience, saying it was "gratifying" and "meaningful" to engage children and youth through dance.

site_title: Upcoming supplementary Budget to include support for social service sector
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat announced that the upcoming supplementary Budget will include support for the social service sector, following a meeting with sector partners to discuss challenges and potential solutions amid the Covid-19 pandemic. The budget will focus on workers and companies that cannot resume activities immediately after the end of the circuit breaker period on June 1. This could involve a further draw on reserves, previously used to fund Covid-19 support measures.

site_title: Investors return to walking on eggshells
summary: US stocks rose sharply last week as progress on economic reopening offset fears of a second trade war between the US and China. Investors are cautiously optimistic about a "smooth" reopening, despite concerns of a second wave of Covid-19 cases. Retail chains saw a surge in digital sales, while shares of airlines and cinema chains rebounded. However, the US labour market remains weak, with the unemployment rate expected to top 20%. The US-China trade tensions resurfaced, with potential for further selloffs if the situation escalates.

site_title: Asia investors scouting for property that benefits from social distancing
summary: Asian investors are scouting for properties in Europe that benefit from shifts in how people live and work post-coronavirus, driven by trends of remote working and e-commerce. TTB Partners, a Hong Kong-based investment advisory firm, has bought a minority stake in M7 Real Estate, which manages properties worth $7.76 billion across 14 European countries. The firm expects asset classes such as regional offices and retail warehousing to benefit from increased demand as working patterns and consumer habits evolve. Asian investors are seen as an important source of capital for European real estate investments.

site_title: Money FM podcast: Helping the F&B industry digitalise to manage costs
summary: A Money FM podcast discussed helping the F&B industry digitalize to manage costs, but the article does not mention the content of the podcast. However, a separate article from July 2, 2025, reported that Munchi Pancakes modernized traditional min jiang kueh as a 'national snack', while another article from July 8, 2025, covered Hao Mart's Taste Orchard, citing poor footfall and vacant units among tenants' concerns.

site_title: Australia calls on younger people to get virus tests as reopening accelerates
summary: Australia's New South Wales state reported three new COVID-19 cases, prompting a call for younger people to get tested as restrictions on pubs and restaurants are loosened. The state plans to allow up to 50 seated patrons from June 1, and health officials warn of a "second wave" of infections if people don't come forward for testing. The state has recorded nearly half of Australia's total cases and deaths, with 3,086 cases and 102 fatalities.

site_title: Italy's 'green corridors' bring in foreign farm workers
summary: Italy has begun importing foreign farm workers through its "green corridors" program, with the first group of over 100 Moroccan workers arriving on a special flight. The move aims to address a shortage of 250,000 to 270,000 day labourers due to the COVID-19 pandemic. The program, which includes workers from Mexico and other European countries, is expected to help Italy harvest its crops at the beginning of the summer season.

site_title: China's US$941b sovereign fund seeks more resilient assets
summary: China's US$941 billion sovereign fund, CIC, is seeking more resilient assets amid the coronavirus pandemic. The fund added to investments in credit markets, healthcare, and information technology stocks, and boosted holdings in Asia to minimize uncertainty. CIC aims to diversify its portfolio and boost alternative and direct investments to 50% of global assets by 2022, with a focus on growth areas and avoiding fragile sectors. The fund's overseas investments returned 17% last year, close to a record gain in 2017.

site_title: Thailand's healthtech field set to grow: analysts
summary: Thailand's health technology industry is expected to grow due to government efforts to digitallyize the healthcare sector. Key drivers include an ageing population, higher digital penetration, and supportive policies. The value of Thailand's medical device market is forecasted to reach US$1.45 billion this year, with a 4.9% compound annual growth rate since 2017. However, foreign investments are hindered by local product preferences, complex tax rules, and intellectual property rights issues. Analysts from GlobalData identify hospital systems, pharmaceuticals, and electronic health records as segments that could benefit from disruption.

site_title: Los Angeles dismisses Trump administration warning over 'unlawful' lockdown
summary: Los Angeles Mayor Eric Garcetti dismissed a Trump administration warning that the city's continued lockdown due to coronavirus could be illegal, stating that the city is guided by science and collaboration, not politics. The warning came after a county health official suggested restrictions could last another three months, prompting the Department of Justice to express concern over an "arbitrary and heavy-handed approach." Garcetti emphasized that people's lives are at stake and that the city will continue to safely reopen, despite the Trump administration's demands for further reopening.

site_title: Singapore contact trace app is opt-in 'as long as possible'
summary: Singapore's contact-tracing phone app, "Trace Together", will remain voluntary for "as long as possible", Foreign Minister Vivian Balakrishnan said. The app, used by about 20-25% of the city-state's population, is a hybrid system based on public support and maintaining privacy. Officials are considering alternative contact-tracing devices, such as a dongle, to boost participation. The government aims to balance centralized data collection with individual privacy, citing Singapore's low mortality rates and effective recovery from the pandemic.

site_title: Pandemic gives Dubai chance to put tech to the test
summary: Dubai is leveraging its technological and scientific capabilities to combat the COVID-19 pandemic, with a key part being the Covid-19 Command and Control Centre, which coordinates efforts among healthcare professionals. The centre uses digital infrastructure to track data and make quick decisions based on scientific evidence, preventing a greater spread of the virus and making lockdowns easier. The UAE has conducted over 1.6 million tests and declared over 28,700 infections, with Dubai's approach serving as a model for other countries.

site_title: US sees 1,260 coronavirus deaths in past 24 hours: Johns Hopkins
summary: The US recorded 1,260 coronavirus deaths in the past 24 hours, bringing the total to 95,921, according to Johns Hopkins University. The country has also seen over 1.6 million cases, the highest in the world. US President Donald Trump is pushing state and local governments to reopen the economy, including allowing churches to hold services despite Covid-19 restrictions. Trump has threatened to override governors' decisions, despite the lack of clear authority to do so.

site_title: Lian Beng seeks extension for disposal of assets competing with SLB unit
summary: Lian Beng Group has sought an extension for the disposal of competing assets, including two Australian properties and three unsold units in a Singapore condominium development, until April 19, 2022. The request comes due to unfavorable market conditions, including oversupply of units in Singapore and the COVID-19 pandemic. Lian Beng's mainboard-listed unit, SLB Development, has no objections to the extension, subject to certain conditions, and the audit committee has deemed it non-prejudicial to SLB's minority shareholders.

site_title: China official says increasing debt level feasible and necessary
summary: China's plans to increase debt levels to stimulate the economy amid the coronavirus pandemic are deemed feasible and necessary by a senior official. The government aims to raise its fiscal deficit and sell anti-virus bonds to combat economic effects. The debt ratio, currently 38.5% of GDP, is considered relatively low globally. The official stated that an appropriate debt level can aid economic and social development, which in turn can help control debt levels.

site_title: Ramadan rule-breakers: Indonesians try to beat Eid exodus ban
summary: Indonesians are bypassing the government's ban on domestic travel during Ramadan to reach their hometowns, using fake travel documents and smuggling methods to avoid COVID-19 restrictions. Authorities have arrested hundreds of drivers and seized fake papers, but thousands continue to attempt the journey, fearing a public health disaster and missing family celebrations. Indonesia has recorded a surge in COVID-19 cases, with the death toll at 1,326, and experts warn that the situation could worsen if people return infected.

site_title: 548 new Covid-19 cases in Singapore; 3 are citizens and PRs
summary: The Health Ministry of Singapore confirmed 548 new Covid-19 cases, bringing the total to 31,616. The majority were migrant workers in dormitories, with three new cases being Singaporeans and permanent residents. The average number of new community cases has risen to seven, partly due to increased surveillance and screening. Meanwhile, 927 patients were discharged, with 13,873 (45% of total) having fully recovered from the disease.

site_title: Credit Suisse CEO says will need fewer employees after crisis
summary: Credit Suisse CEO Thomas Gottstein said the bank will need fewer employees in the medium term due to the coronavirus crisis. Online banking is becoming more important, leading to a decrease in branch importance and staff working remotely 10-20% of the time. The bank aims to streamline processes and reduce office space. Gottstein also stated that Credit Suisse's investment banking unit needs to change, which has been loss-making for several quarters. Despite this, high-net-worth clients and Asian business are considered growth areas.

site_title: China exporters look inwards as virus hits overseas markets
summary: China exporters are shifting focus to domestic markets amid the ongoing coronavirus pandemic, which has hit overseas trading partners worldwide. Cancelled shipments, returned goods, and lack of new orders have left exporters in crisis. Chinese online marketplace Taobao saw a 160% spike in foreign trading companies opening stores on its domestic platform, while policymakers are welcoming the change as a chance to wean the country off cheap exports and government spending in favor of domestic consumption. Domestic sales from export businesses rose 17% in April, and the government is supporting trading enterprises to tap the home market instead.

site_title: Abe's support falls into 'danger zone' after prosecutor scandal
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's Cabinet support plummeted to 27% in a recent Mainichi poll, down 13 percentage points, amid public dissatisfaction over the handling of a top prosecutor scandal. The disapproval rating surged 19 percentage points to 64%, entering the "danger zone" of 30% or lower. The scandal involves the resignation of Hiromu Kurokawa, who bet on mahjong with reporters during the state of emergency. Abe's administration has seen little benefit from the low virus case and death rates, with public dissatisfaction fueled by the economic fallout of the outbreak.

site_title: Indonesia investigates data breach on 2.3 million voters
summary: Indonesia is investigating a data breach that leaked 2.3 million voters' personal information, including names, addresses, and identification numbers, which appeared to originate from the 2014 election voter list. The General Election Commission launched an investigation and denied the leak came from their servers. The data was previously shared with political parties, and the commission is trying to find the source of the leak.

site_title: BlackRock is about to find skeletons in Sweden's US$45b bond market
summary: BlackRock is advising Sweden's Riksbank on how to support its US$45 billion krona-denominated corporate bond market, which has suffered its worst rout since the financial crisis. The Riksbank has pledged to acquire parts of the market, but faces opposition from parliament over the legality of such purchases. The move is seen as crucial to prevent the market from becoming "completely dead" and to allow firms like MaxFastigheter i Sverige to raise money through bonds.
