site_title: SPH speeds up integration of student housing business, rebranding assets for UK varsity reopening
summary: SPH is accelerating integration of its student housing business and rebranding assets to prepare for UK university reopenings. The company is also hiring to boost on-ground operations and investing in quality management talent. Existing booking systems are being integrated under a proprietary platform, and certain assets are being rebranded to enhance brand identity and bolster returns. UOB Kay Hian raised its target price on SPH to S$1.52, citing potential value unlocking from non-core assets.

site_title: Taking Design Online
summary: Several design museums have created virtual tours and online programmes to engage with the public during the COVID-19 pandemic. The Vitra Design Museum, Design Museum London, and Bauhaus Archiv offer digital exhibitions, interviews, and workshops. The Victoria and Albert Museum features online exhibitions, including "Pandemic Objects" that explores everyday items that have taken on new meaning during the pandemic. These digital initiatives provide a unique opportunity for people to explore design museums from home and discover new inspiration for when tourism resumes.

site_title: Property agents soldier on with virtual marketing
summary: Singapore property agents continue with virtual marketing despite show flat galleries remaining closed until further notice. The decision follows the first phase of Singapore's economy reopening. Property sales have been delayed due to the closure, but developers and agents are adapting to the situation. The virtual marketing approach aims to maintain sales momentum in the prime property market, with a focus on projects above S$3,000 psf.

site_title: Flying an uncharted path
summary: The aviation sector is recovering from the COVID-19 pandemic, but the industry is facing unprecedented challenges. Airlines, airports, and aircraft makers are charting a new path as demand for travel resumes. Meanwhile, the post office is adapting to an online commerce world, and investors are navigating a dislocated stock market. Payouts to shareholders are being cut, and companies are re-evaluating their corporate purpose. As the world adjusts to a new reality, individuals are reassessing their belongings and priorities, and companies are exploring new ways to engage with their communities.

site_title: Commercial property transactions in US plunge 71% in April
summary: US commercial property transactions plummeted 71% in April to $11 billion, the lowest level in a decade, due to the coronavirus shutdown. Hotel deals fell 98% from last year, office and industrial deals dropped 60%. This collapse marks the smallest volume since April 2010.

site_title: Lobby group wants laws for a fair tenancy commission, data sharing
summary: A lobby group in Singapore, the Fair Tenancy Framework Industry Committee, has submitted 15 key recommendations to the Ministry of Law and Ministry of Trade and Industry, aiming to establish a Fair Tenancy Commission to regulate the industry. The committee proposes sharing information and costs between tenants and landlords, incentivizing value creation, and protecting tenants from unfair practices. However, the timeline for implementing these recommendations is uncertain, and mutual compromise is needed. The committee's recommendations come as 90% of the retail, F&B, and services businesses in Singapore are filing for relief, with 80% planning to do so in the coming days and weeks.

site_title: Almost half in Singapore expect family to care for them in retirement: survey
summary: A survey of over 1,000 Singaporeans found nearly half expect family to care for them in retirement, while nearly half believe they won't save enough to sustain their lifestyle. Over half (57%) experience retirement planning stress. Only 38% have life insurance, and 72% of those without are under 40. The survey highlights the need for financial planning, particularly for millennials, who may face financial burdens in retirement.

site_title: Maybank posts higher Q1 profit but cautions virus impact later
summary: Malaysia's largest lender, Maybank, reported a 2.05 billion ringgit (S$668 million) profit in the first quarter, beating forecasts and surpassing the previous year's profit of 1.81 billion ringgit. However, group president Abdul Farid Alias cautioned that the performance does not reflect expectations for the rest of the year due to the full impact of the Covid-19 pandemic not yet known. The bank managed to contain pressures on net interest margin, but expects it to remain compressed in a low interest rate environment.

site_title: Eagle H Trust needs an independent manager
summary: Eagle Hospitality Trust (EHT) needs a new, independent manager to restore confidence among unitholders. The current manager, Eagle Hospitality Reit Management, is controlled by UC's chairman and deputy chairman, who are also joint owners of the Reit. These individuals have been accused of transferring payment risks to EHT unitholders through non-disturbance agreements, which were not disclosed until recently. The Monetary Authority of Singapore is reviewing the situation, and some unitholders are calling for the Reit manager's license to be revoked. A new manager could provide better value for unitholders, and the Reit's sponsor, UC, is exploring a partnership with a new strategic partner.

site_title: Soy Goodness
summary: A new cocktail, "Soy", has been introduced at Laut restaurant in Singapore, made with fresh soybean milk, tamarind, chrysanthemum, and other ingredients. The drink has a subtle soy flavor and a sweet aftertaste. Laut's co-founder, Frank Shen, aims to deliver an evolving dining experience using local ingredients. The cocktail is available for S$88 and can be ordered through lautcollective.com.sg/delivery/soy. This unique beverage showcases soy's versatility beyond traditional products.

images.alt_text: Soy Cocktail.

site_title: What Elvis, Michael Jackson and Trump have in common
summary: US President Donald Trump has claimed to be taking hydroxychloroquine, despite doctors warning that it increases the risk of cardiac arrest. This aligns with Trump's pattern of science denialism and seeking out unproven medical treatments. As a famous and powerful individual, Trump's celebrity status can lead to doctors following his ego rather than science. This phenomenon, known as VIP Syndrome, has been observed in celebrities such as Elvis Presley and Michael Jackson, and can result in tragic consequences. Trump's actions raise concerns about the erosion of trust in mainstream medicine and the influence of radical individualism in health decisions.

site_title: Liling Ong, Restaurateur
summary: Restaurateur Liling Ong, founder of Cicheti group of Italian restaurants, says Covid-19 has opened the eyes of the public to the challenges faced by restaurateurs, including fixed capital costs and complicated landlord-tenant relationships. Despite the pandemic's impact, Ong's group is still on track to open its fourth and fifth concepts in Singapore this year and next, with a focus on authenticity and transparency. Ong attributes Cicheti's success to finding the right concept, hiring talented staff, and prioritizing people over profit. She hopes to see more Singaporeans elevating local cuisine to an international platform.

site_title: Asean-focused VCs face fund-raising challenges: report
summary: South-east Asia-focused venture capital firms raised US$1.33 billion in Q1 2020, more than triple from the same period a year ago, according to a report. However, the growth marks the end of a four-quarter streak of quarter-on-quarter growth, and the full impact of the Covid-19 outbreak may not be reflected in the numbers yet. With "dramatically changed" risk appetites, investors are seeking income-generating opportunities, and regional VCs may face an increase in capital call defaults.

site_title: Bidding wars are back in US housing market
summary: The US housing market is experiencing a surge in bidding wars due to a severe lack of inventory, despite economic uncertainty from the pandemic. Sales of existing homes are projected to drop 20% in April, while new house construction plummeted in April. This shortage has led to competition among buyers, with 40% of homebuyers facing multiple offers, and prices remaining stable. Experts predict home prices will hold up through the summer, but declines are coming as foreclosure moratoriums and forbearance programs end.

site_title: Promising new kids on the block
summary: Two new restaurants, LUMO and Nalati, have successfully adapted to the COVID-19 Circuit Breaker measures by offering takeaway and delivery services. LUMO, run by Chef Martin Wong, serves casual bistro-style fare with original touches, including a sweet milky sauce with deep-fried squid. Nalati, which opened during the Circuit Breaker, offers a robust zichar-ish menu with a family-style appeal. Both restaurants show promise, despite the challenges of the delivery process, and may help start a new dining trend.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Hyflux clarified a report stating Utico planned a $500 million sukuk issuance to pay down debt, and Utico took a 95% stake in Hyflux with a $400 million investment. The deal has not been completed. Del Monte Pacific sold a 12% stake in its subsidiary for $120 million, using the proceeds to pay down loans. CapitaLand Malaysia Mall Trust posted a 25.4% year-on-year fall in net property income due to a 14-day rental waiver for tenants affected by Covid-19.

site_title: Samsung starts construction on cutting-edge chip production line
summary: Samsung has begun construction on its sixth domestic chip production line in Pyeongtaek, South Korea, to produce logic chips for mobile phones and computers. The move aims to cut reliance on volatile memory chips and compete with Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. (TSMC), its bigger rival. The 5-nanometer fabrication facility is expected to start production in the second half of 2021, with the goal of driving robust growth for Samsung's foundry business. The investment is part of Samsung's effort to narrow the gap with TSMC in the contract chip-making market.

site_title: Money FM podcast: Logistics industry after Covid-19
summary: The Money FM podcast "Logistics industry after Covid-19" discusses the future of the global supply chain post-pandemic. Tan Chong Meng, group CEO of PSA International, shares insights on the key parameters to evaluate for change in the industry. He highlights the importance of digitalization, sustainability, and innovation to ensure the industry's resilience in the face of future challenges. The conversation aims to provide a comprehensive understanding of the logistics industry's evolution and its implications on the global economy.

site_title: Banks get a glimpse of post-Covid-19 future
summary: Banks have successfully adapted to the post-Covid-19 pandemic landscape, with online banking and digital payments on the rise. A survey by McKinsey & Co found that online banking use increased by 7-19% across six European countries, with over 20% of customers in Spain and Britain trying online banking for the first time. Digital payments also gained traction, with 63% of respondents in the UK reducing their cash usage. However, banks face significant challenges, including high expenses, declining revenue, and expected credit losses, making technology adoption critical to controlling costs.

site_title: Art of the Table
summary: Hermès has launched a new nature-inspired dining range, "Passifolia," designed by Nathalie Rolland-Huckel. The collection features a profusion of leaves and flowers on porcelain plates, teapots, and cups, with over 32 colors and 2,000 hours of labor involved in creating the designs. The range, inspired by a "Garden of Eden" theme, was conceived by Hermès' creative director, Benoit-Pierre Emery, who wanted to capture the essence of nature in a free and unencumbered way. The collection can be purchased individually or as part of a larger set, allowing customers to start with a small piece and build up their collection over time.

site_title: SBS Transit's Q1 profit after tax nearly halves, led by fall in public transport services
summary: SBS Transit's Q1 profit after tax dropped 46.1% to S$11.1 million, primarily due to a decline in public transport services and ridership. Revenue fell 3.3% year-over-year to S$339 million, with lower service fees and advertising contributing to the decline. The company has over S$250 million in available cash to manage the business, with non-essential capital expenditure deferred. Despite a 20% cut in director fees, the company's directors will review this decision at the end of June.

site_title: US jobless claims remain high as backlogs, layoffs linger
summary: US jobless claims remain high, totaling 2.438 million for the week ended May 16, as backlogs and disruptions from the novel coronavirus continue. The number is above economists' forecast of 2.4 million. The jobless claims report may offer early clues on how quickly businesses rehire workers as they re-open, and the success of the government's Paycheck Protection Program. The US economy lost a record 20.5 million jobs in April, on top of the 881,000 shed in March, amid the COVID-19 pandemic.

site_title: Disney World in Florida reopens, sans rides; masked customers can shop, dine
summary: Disney World in Florida reopened on May 21, 2020, with limited operations, including shopping and dining, but no rides due to the COVID-19 pandemic. Masked customers were allowed to visit the Disney Springs shopping strip, with social distancing measures and temperature checks in place. The reopening is part of Florida's phased reopening, with more restaurants and bars set to open next week. However, the state's amusement parks, including Disney World and Universal Studios, have no reopening date yet, and most beaches remain closed.

images.alt_text: Disney shares rose 5 per cent on the New York Stock Exchange following press reports - denied by the company - that it would announce on Thursday when the parks would reopen.

site_title: CapBridge gets fresh capital from Singapore, HK govt-backed entities
summary: CapBridge, a private capital platform backed by the Singapore Exchange, has secured equity investments from Singapore government-owned SGInnovate and Hong Kong government-linked Cyberport Macro Fund. The investments bring CapBridge's post-money valuation to over $40 million, closing its Series A financing round. The funds will be used to develop technology solutions, including blockchain-based share tracking and private equity investments, to optimize capital raising for growth companies in Singapore and the region.

site_title: Rolls-Royce 'working out' how job cuts will hit its 1,300 Singapore staff
summary: Rolls-Royce is restructuring globally, including in Singapore, due to a sharp drop in demand for civil aerospace engines and after-market services amid the coronavirus pandemic. The company plans to cut at least 9,000 workers worldwide, affecting 17% of its global workforce. In Singapore, Rolls-Royce has about 1,300 employees, excluding those in a joint venture. The company is working to adjust its workforce and operations to meet reduced customer demand, with a goal to save £800 million in cash.

site_title: Arts S.O.S.
summary: Singapore's arts scene continues to adapt to the COVID-19 pandemic, with many art establishments offering virtual experiences. Checkpoint Theatre, The Necessary Stage, W!ld Rice, T.H.E Dance Company, Chan+Hori, and Esplanade are providing online performances, radio plays, and exhibitions, allowing audiences to engage with art while supporting the arts community. Donations can be made through platforms like giving.sg, and many organizations are offering digital content and classes for free or at a low cost. These virtual offerings aim to preserve the arts and support the community during this challenging time.

site_title: Citi returning JSS funds; local banks pledge to keep, create jobs
summary: Citi Singapore will return its Jobs Support Scheme (JSS) funding to the government, estimated to be in the tens of millions, amid the COVID-19 outbreak. The bank's decision was a unanimous one from its management team, with CEO Amol Gupte citing the need to support those who have a "far greater need" for assistance. Meanwhile, local banks DBS, OCBC, and UOB have pledged to retain the JSS funding to create new jobs and boost training, with DBS committing to hiring over 2,000 people this year.

images.alt_text: Citi Singapore has moved to return to the government the co-funding offered to all companies as a form of wage support amid the Covid-19 outbreak.

site_title: Euro takes a breather after four-day rising streak
summary: The euro stabilized after a four-day rising streak, easing down 0.04% to US$1.0974, as concerns over the economic impact of the coronavirus pandemic and US-China tensions dominated markets. A proposed 500 billion euro recovery fund by France and Germany failed to lift the euro, which remains 4% away from 2020 highs. Economic data showed the eurozone economy remains depressed despite partial lockdown easing, with the Flash Composite Purchasing Managers' Index recovering to 30.5 from 13.6 in April.

site_title: US regulators willing to tweak Huawei chip curb rule
summary: US regulators are open to tweaking a new rule curbing global chip sales to blacklisted Huawei due to a potential loophole. The rule, unveiled by the Commerce Department, requires licenses for sales to Huawei of semiconductors made abroad with US technology. However, it only covers chips designed by Huawei, leaving a gap for shipments sent directly to its customers. Regulators are considering adjustments to the rule to address this loophole, with one potential solution being to tweak the language to capture chips sold "to the benefit of" Huawei.

site_title: Focusing on the Present
summary: Meditation and mindfulness can help individuals cope with the uncertainty and anxiety caused by the COVID-19 pandemic. Experts recommend focusing on the present moment, breaking down tasks, and practicing mindfulness or meditation to reduce stress. Various apps, such as Balance, Breethe, and Headspace, offer guided sessions to help beginners get started. Regular mindfulness practice can lead to increased self-awareness, calmness, and resilience in adversity, making it an effective tool for managing mental health during uncertain times.

site_title: Do the poorest Indians need self-reliance or a helping hand?
summary: India's $265 billion "Self-Reliance" financial stimulus package aims to boost economic growth, but critics argue it doesn't adequately address the urgent needs of the struggling masses. The package allocates 58% of its funds to businesses, farmers, and workers, but this may exacerbate debt for the poor. The government has allocated 3,500 crore rupees for migrant workers and 40,000 crore rupees for rural employment, but these funds will not be directly distributed to workers. The package's focus on long-term growth has raised concerns about the immediate impact on reviving economic growth, with some experts predicting a 45% annual decline in the economy.

site_title: US secures 300 million doses of potential Covid-19 vaccine
summary: The US has secured 300 million doses of the AstraZeneca Covid-19 vaccine by pledging $1.2 billion, with the goal of restarting its economy. This deal is part of Operation Warp Speed's efforts to develop a safe and effective vaccine by 2021. The vaccine, developed by the University of Oxford and licensed to AstraZeneca, is currently undergoing a Phase III clinical trial in the US. AstraZeneca has also secured agreements for at least 400 million doses and plans to begin deliveries in September.

images.alt_text: AstraZeneca says it has secured manufacturing capacity for one billion vaccine doses, with first deliveries due to begin in September.

site_title: Safety measures as crucial as attractive fares, perks for air travel to rebound
summary: Airlines may offer discounted fares to entice passengers back to air travel as the industry recovers from the COVID-19 pandemic. However, legacy carriers are more likely to ease booking restrictions to offer flexibility instead of deep discounts. Low-cost carriers may offer incredible fares while cross-selling ancillary products. Travel demand remains low, and airlines are expected to reintroduce capacity slowly, potentially pushing airfares up. The International Air Transport Association (IATA) advocates for comprehensive health and safety measures, including face masks and temperature screening, to restart travel.

site_title: Singapore creeping towards negative rates as 1-mth SOR drops below zero
summary: Singapore's overnight borrowing rate is less than two basis points above zero, down from 1.68% in January, as the one-month swap offer rate fell below zero for the first time in almost nine years. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) is managing the currency to cope with a virus-induced crunch, but the rates are not an intended policy tool. The one-month swap rate dropped to minus 0.01141% on Wednesday, the lowest since August 2011, amid forecasts of a 4% economy contraction this year due to the coronavirus outbreak.

site_title: Thomson Medical directors take 20% fee cut, managers forgo bonus
summary: Thomson Medical Group, a healthcare provider in Singapore and Malaysia, has announced a 20% cut in directors' fees, effective June 1, and senior managers will forgo bonuses and annual wage supplements. These measures aim to ensure the company's viability during the COVID-19 pandemic. The group also plans to adopt cost-cutting measures and fine-tune daily operations. Demand for obstetric services remains healthy in Singapore, but some services are closed or operating under restricted conditions in both countries due to the pandemic.

site_title: What's Up This Week
summary: A new book "Design in Asia: The New Wave" showcases 97 emerging design talents from 11 countries, featuring furniture, product, and interior design. Meanwhile, live music continues online, with streaming shows from artists like Chris Martin and David Gilmour. The Cabin Fever Festival brings wine and dine events online, and John Krasinski's YouTube channel "SomeGoodNews" offers lighthearted stories to combat the Covid-19 crisis. Netflix's "23 Hours to Kill" is a comedy special from Jerry Seinfeld, and Sofitel Singapore City Centre now offers a "work from hotel" day package for luxury room use.

site_title: Japan exports in April fall most since 2009 as pandemic hits demand
summary: Japan's exports in April fell 21.9% from the previous year, the largest decline since the 2009 global financial crisis, due to the coronavirus pandemic. Shipments to the US, China, and the European Union declined sharply, with car exports to the US plummeting 65.8%. Japan's economy fell into recession for the first time in 4.5 years in the first quarter, and factory activity accelerated in May with a sharp decline in output and orders. The country's services sector also remained in contraction, but employment conditions remained flat.

site_title: China plans national security laws for Hong Kong
summary: China plans to propose national security laws for Hong Kong in response to last year's pro-democracy protests, which plunged the city into turmoil. The proposed laws would ban secession, foreign interference, terrorism, and seditious activities, potentially eroding Hong Kong's freedoms and autonomy. The move is expected to trigger a revision of Hong Kong's special status in the US and spark more unrest. China's parliament is set to begin its annual session on Friday, amid heightened tensions between Beijing and Washington.

site_title: Miss flying? Here's an antidote
summary: Netflix releases a new sci-fi thriller series, "Into The Night," about a group of passengers stuck on a flight from Brussels to nowhere due to a catastrophic solar event that turns the sun into a giant menace, killing all living organisms. The pilot and a stewardess must navigate the tense situation, deciding whether to fly, give up, or find shelter to withstand the sun's rays. The 6-episode series is a fast-moving, well-crafted diversion from pandemic news, streaming on Netflix.

site_title: Settling the (tax) score after the fall
summary: A global economic slowdown due to the COVID-19 pandemic has led to a reevaluation of Base Erosion and Profit Shifting (BEPS) 2.0 measures. Multilateral organizations, such as the OECD, IMF, and UN, have suggested temporary reductions in tax-audit actions and simplified procedures to alleviate tax burdens. However, the timing of implementing these measures may not be ripe, as governments prioritize economic and health concerns. The Singaporean government's Covid-19 (Temporary Measures) Act, which imposes a moratorium on certain legal actions, may provide a parallel framework for consideration.

site_title: Covid-19 could trigger these 10 changes in the future of supply chains
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic is expected to trigger significant changes in supply chains, but rather than a "new normal," it will likely accelerate existing trends. Business requirements, technological advancements, and legislation will continue to evolve, making supply-chain management a constantly changing ecosystem. Companies that adapt to these changes will thrive, while those that fail to evolve will struggle. The shift towards automation, robotics, and digitalization will be particularly notable, with FedEx partnering with a startup to deploy robots for deliveries and Tesla expanding its robotaxi services.

site_title: In times of turbulence, the world needs physical commodity traders
summary: A recent crisis in the oil market highlighted concerns about the stability of commodities trading firms. However, experts argue that these firms play a vital role in managing risks and ensuring supply chains. Unlike financial institutions, commodity trading firms do not transform short-term liabilities into long-term assets, and their business model is focused on physical trade and ownership of commodities. In times of turbulence, these firms can alleviate bottlenecks and provide essential services to producers and consumers. Authorities should focus on the resilience and diversity of Singapore's physical trading hub rather than tightening regulation.

site_title: STI falls 0.3% as rising US-China tension worsens
summary: Singapore shares fell 0.26% as US-China tensions worsened, with the Straits Times Index closing 6.60 points lower. Despite regional declines, Taiwan and South Korea bucked the trend. Analysts expect geopolitical worries to continue to pressure global indices. Japan and South Korea released disheartening exports data amid the pandemic. The market saw 1.48 billion shares worth S$1.09 billion traded, with losers outpacing gainers.

site_title: Geo Energy offers steep discount to retire bonds
summary: Geo Energy Resources' subsidiary, Geo Coal International, is offering to repurchase $154 million in senior notes at less than half their par value. The tender offer, open until June 4, will pay holders $430 per $1,000 principal amount, plus accrued interest. The company aims to address its debt obligations and take advantage of the challenging market conditions. Proposed amendments to the bond indenture include removing a mandatory-offer-to-purchase covenant and increasing working capital permitted debt baskets. The changes require noteholders' consent and are intended to provide the company with "additional flexibility" in addressing its debt obligations.

site_title: In stock markets, economic reality is suspended
summary: Stock markets have risen significantly since their lows in March 2020, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index increasing by over 32% and 20% respectively. However, economists warn that the recession is likely to be deeper than expected, with the IMF forecasting a 3% contraction and a 5.8% rebound in 2021. The International Labour Organization expects 1.6 billion informal economy workers to suffer massive damage, leading to a significant loss of livelihoods and consumption. Despite central bank support, investors are cautioned to tread carefully, as fear of missing out and the expectation of a V-shape recovery may be "delusionary".

site_title: Restarting work - learning the new norm
summary: As the world slowly returns to work after 18 months of COVID-19 lockdown, leaders must adapt and prioritize employee safety. Social distancing measures will remain, and employees will need to be flexible and cooperative. Companies must focus on cash flow management, financial projections, and supply chain disruption. A survival team of reliable and committed employees will be crucial in navigating the new norm. Leaders must communicate openly and honestly with employees, and be prepared to make tough decisions. With the virus still present, employees must be vigilant and take necessary precautions to minimize risk, such as washing hands frequently and avoiding physical contact.

site_title: Wanted: New WTO head. Must thrive under global pressure
summary: The World Trade Organization (WTO) is seeking a new director-general to succeed Roberto Azevedo, who is set to leave in August, amid a backdrop of global challenges including the COVID-19 pandemic, US-China tensions, and rising protectionism. A strong, charismatic leader is seen as crucial to navigating these issues, with the WTO ideally seeking a successor by year's end. Potential candidates include African officials, with four possible contenders identified, but the process is expected to be challenging due to the novel coronavirus and the need for consensus among WTO members.

site_title: Sias asks Ying Li why it hasn't paid a dividend in 12 years
summary: Ying Li International Real Estate, a MAINBOARD-listed company, has not paid dividends to shareholders in 12 years. The company cited the COVID-19 crisis and need for capital to fund new growth plans as reasons for conserving cash. Ying Li is exploring a new asset-light operating model, which could minimize capital investments and provide recurring income. This model aligns with the Chinese government's economic growth strategy, but requires new resources and approvals from authorities. The company's counter closed down 1.21% on Thursday.

site_title: EasyJet among first carriers in Europe to plan restart
summary: EasyJet, Europe's largest discount carrier, will resume flights from 22 European airports on June 15, becoming one of the first airlines to restart services as the coronavirus lockdown eases. Passengers will be required to wear face masks and sit apart from others, with no food service on the first flights. EasyJet's move is earlier than most rivals, with Ryanair resuming operations on July 1. The airline aims to tap into the lucrative summer travel season, which is expected to see a pick-up in demand as travel restrictions are lifted.

images.alt_text: EasyJet shares traded 4.2 per cent higher at 573.6 pence as at 8:19 am in London, paring their decline this year to 59 per cent.

site_title: Running from the pandemic
summary: Mark O'Connell's book "Notes From An Apocalypse: A Personal Journey To The End Of The World And Back" explores the phenomenon of "preppers" who prepare for disasters and the end of the world. O'Connell traveled the world, meeting survivalists, ecologists, and others who believe the world will end, and found their preparations to be both amusing and comforting. However, O'Connell concludes that his journey made him less concerned about apocalypses, instead advocating for a communal approach to care for the future of the planet.

images.alt_text: Wanaka in New Zealand where billionaire Peter Thiel has a "prepper's paradise".
A survivalist shows off his bunker for hiding from doomsday.

site_title: Uber has spent US$19m on coronavirus financial assistance for drivers
summary: Uber has spent $19 million on financial assistance to nearly 48,900 drivers worldwide affected by the coronavirus crisis. The assistance, which began in mid-March, provided an average of $650 to North American drivers, with payouts varying by location. The company has also supplied masks and disinfectants to drivers and delivery workers, reaching almost half a million recipients. Uber has allocated an additional $50 million for safety supplies and has supported drivers in over 70 countries, despite some drivers facing challenges in receiving unemployment benefits.

site_title: SPH integrates student housing operations, rebrands certain assets
summary: SPH integrates student housing operations, rebrands certain assets in preparation for the UK university reopening. The company, Straits Capitol, aims to boost operational efficiencies, enhance student experience, and increase on-ground operational capabilities. Integration of booking systems and rebranding of "high-quality" assets will drive operational synergies and economies of scale. The company will also hire more staff and bring them under its employment to achieve consistent standards across its portfolio. Currently, 69% of the target revenue for AY 20/21 has been achieved through digital marketing initiatives.

site_title: Johnson will not face criminal action over links to US businesswoman
summary: British Prime Minister Boris Johnson will not face criminal action over allegations of misconduct related to his relationship with US tech entrepreneur Jennifer Arcuri, according to the police watchdog. An investigation found no evidence of wrongdoing, but suggested that Johnson's close relationship with Arcuri may have influenced decision-making on public funding and trade missions. Johnson's spokesman welcomed the decision, calling the complaint "politically motivated" and "untrue". The matter will continue to be investigated by the London Assembly.

site_title: US weekly jobless claims remain high as backlogs, layoffs linger
summary: US weekly jobless claims remain high, totaling 2.438 million for the week ended May 16, according to the Labor Department. This marks another month of staggering job losses, with economists predicting more disruptions as businesses reopen. The COVID-19 pandemic has resulted in the worst unemployment since the Great Depression, with claims having gradually declined since hitting a record 6.867 million in March. Backlogs and layoffs continue to linger, with gig workers and others seeking federal government benefits also contributing to high claims numbers.

site_title: 7 new Covid-19 cases from pre-school staff, nursing home
summary: Singapore reported 448 new Covid-19 cases, including 14 in the community and 434 work permit holders in dormitories. Seven cases were identified in a nursing home and pre-school staff. Four nursing home residents and three pre-school staff tested positive. All staff members have been tested and negative, and those in close contact have also tested negative. A 73-year-old male Singapore citizen died due to Covid-19 complications. The government is continuing to test nursing home residents and pre-school staff ahead of planned reopenings.

images.alt_text: There was an uptick in new Covid-19 cases among Singaporeans and permanent residents confirmed on Thursday, after seven cases were picked up during the Ministry of Health (MOH)'s active surveillance and screening of nursing home residents and pre-school staff.

site_title: With F&B places shut, demand for malt plunges
summary: Barley farmers in Europe face a decade-high stockpile due to a wet autumn, but the COVID-19 pandemic has further reduced demand for malt used in beer and whisky production. As a result, farmers may have to sell their crops at lower prices for animal feed. European barley stockpiles are expected to jump 14% to 6.6 million tons next season, while malting barley prices have hit their lowest since 2015. The situation is expected to last for 18 months to two years, affecting not only the barley market but also the whisky industry.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore developers will not be able to reopen show galleries to market their new projects by June 2, as previously planned, due to the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic. The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) made this decision to ensure a phased reopening of the economy.

site_title: Singapore shares close marginally lower
summary: Singapore shares closed marginally lower, down 6.60 points or 0.26%, to 2,555.34, amid escalating US-China tensions and downbeat data. Key gauges across the region fell, while Taiwan and South Korea bucked the trend. Overnight gains on Wall Street were tempered by geopolitical worries and trade figures. Analysts expect tensions to continue putting pressure on global indices.

site_title: The Power-Up sequence: Addressing the organisational costs of Covid-19 lockdown
summary: CEOs must implement a "power-up sequence" to bring employees back to work after the COVID-19 lockdown. Three critical actions include: preserving new behaviors and behaviors to fend off old ones; moving forward and avoiding a snapback to old ways of working; and addressing the organisational costs of lockdown liberation, including a lack of coordination, invisible contributors, and unsustainability. CEOs must align their teams around a new agenda, focusing on balance between solitude and teaming, external outcomes and internal norms, and local empowerment and central coordination. By adopting these actions, CEOs can ensure a successful transition back to work and position their organisations for a more turbulent world ahead.

site_title: 'Strong likelihood' US will need another aid package: Mnuchin
summary: US Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin stated there's a strong likelihood the US will need another aid package, following the $3 trillion already approved by Congress. Officials will review the next few weeks to determine how to spend more money and if additional aid is needed. Mnuchin also expects a "gigantic" rebound in economic growth in the fourth quarter of the year.

images.alt_text: The US most likely will need another injection of aid from the federal government, but officials will first take time to gauge the best next steps, US Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin said Thursday.

site_title: Dining Well in a Pandemic
summary: During the COVID-19 pandemic, a surge in demand for premium produce has been observed in Singapore, with consumers opting for gourmet groceries and high-end ingredients. Local suppliers have seen an increase in retail sales, with some experiencing a 200% rise, thanks to the rise of online shopping and e-commerce platforms. Luxury food suppliers, such as Angliss and S Foods, have benefited from the shift in consumer behavior, with many consumers seeking out premium products for home cooking. The growth of online platforms, such as Pasar United, has also enabled wet market stalls to reach a wider audience, resulting in increased sales and business for many suppliers.

site_title: Lloyds CEO says bank can weather bad loans spike in coronavirus crisis
summary: Lloyds Banking Group CEO Antonio Horta-Osorio stated the bank can absorb a spike in bad loans due to the coronavirus crisis, prioritizing customer support while incurring financial costs. Lloyds has provided £5 billion in state-backed finance and 1 million repayment holidays, despite setting aside £1.4 billion for likely bad loans. The bank faces potential shareholder dissent over executive pay arrangements, with ISS recommending a block on the pay policy due to concerns about guaranteed long-term bonuses.

site_title: The 'robots are taking our jobs' threat gets real
summary:
Here is a 100-word summary of the article:

The COVID-19 pandemic has accelerated the trend of automation in industries worldwide, with Chinese manufacturing experiencing a 90% workforce turnover after reopening. Analysts predict that the trend will continue globally, with 60% of production work being machine-replaceable. Companies are investing in automation to improve productivity and agility, despite concerns over job displacement. Governments are offering wage subsidies and incentivizing the transition to a robotic future, with Japan and China offering industrial subsidies to support automation. The shift towards automation may require companies to reskill and accommodate displaced workers, but could ultimately lead to increased productivity.

site_title: Hatten Land gets more time to repay US$20m loan by pledging more shares to lender
summary: CATALIST-listed property developer Hatten Land has been granted more time to repay a US$20 million loan to Haitong International Financial Products (Singapore). The company has pledged 360 million ordinary shares, increasing its stake with the lender to about 53%. Hatten Land will now repay the loan in four instalments: US$2 million on Jan 10 and US$6 million each on April 10, July 10, and Oct 10. The company is still in talks with the lender to further extend the payment period due to the impact of Covid-19 on its operations.

site_title: US: Wall St finishes down as US-China tensions heighten trade deal worries
summary: US stocks ended lower on Thursday, following a fresh wave of China-US tensions that raised doubts about the trade deal reached between the world's two largest economies. President Trump warned China would react strongly if national security laws were imposed on Hong Kong. The S&P 500 fell 0.78% and the Nasdaq dropped 0.97%, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average falling 0.41%. The market's recovery from its March low has been uneven, with almost half of S&P 500 stocks down 20% or more since February.

site_title: Straco Corp swings into S$3.4m net loss for Q1, now on cost-cutting drive
summary: Straco Corporation reported a net loss of S$3.4 million for the first quarter, down from a S$8.5 million profit previously, due to the COVID-19 pandemic forcing tourist attractions to close temporarily. Revenue fell 86.2% to S$3.4 million, with the Singapore Flyer attraction also in the red. To cut costs, the group has implemented wage cuts, pay freezes, and headcount freezes. Straco expects a material operating loss and negative operating cash flow for the first half of FY2020, with the financial results to be announced in August.

site_title: Covid-19 pandemic causes labour shortage for Malaysia's palm industry
summary: Malaysia's palm industry, the world's second-largest producer, is experiencing a labour shortage due to the COVID-19 pandemic. The industry relies on 70% foreign workers, mostly from Indonesia and South Asia, but recruitment has stalled due to stay-at-home orders. The Malaysian government reported a shortage of 500,000 workers in the plantation industry, including palm. The pandemic has disrupted the recruitment process, affecting the industry's operations and production.

site_title: US: Wall St dips as trade tensions add to virus woes
summary: US stock indexes fell at the open on May 21, 2020, as Sino-US tensions and mixed retail earnings weighed on the market. The Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped 0.05% to 24,564.27, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite fell 0.06% and 0.01% respectively. The economic slump caused by the coronavirus continues to pose concerns about the pace of recovery.

site_title: Indonesia's Covid-19 battle faces crucial test over Eid holiday
summary: Indonesia is facing a crucial test in its Covid-19 battle as thousands of people attempt to leave Jakarta for their hometowns during the Eid al-Fitr holiday, despite a ban on domestic travel. Authorities have set up checkpoints to prevent travel, but many are still attempting to leave, citing reasons such as work contracts. Experts warn that this could lead to new infections, and the country's Covid-19 taskforce has described the next few weeks as a "critical moment" to contain the outbreak.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 16.99 points to 1,452.11, closing higher on Thursday. The market saw a gain of 545 to 425 gainer-to-loser ratio.

site_title: Japan to seek extradition of men arrested in US over Ghosn escape
summary: Japan is working to secure the extradition of two men arrested in the US on charges related to former Nissan Motor boss Carlos Ghosn's escape in December. The men, a former US Army Special Forces soldier and another individual, were arrested on charges of financial misconduct. Chief Cabinet officer Yoshihide Suga acknowledged the arrests and stated that Japan is preparing for a "speedy extradition." The US authorities have been awaiting trial on the charges, and Japan's cooperation is seen as crucial to the process.

site_title: US to fly aid into Russia where coronavirus cases are climbing
summary: A US military transport aircraft is expected to deliver medical aid to Russia, including 50 ventilators, as the country struggles with a rising number of coronavirus cases (317,554) and deaths (3,000+). This aid aims to help Moscow cope with the pandemic. The US is the only country with more confirmed cases, and Russia's low death toll has sparked debate about its counting methods.

site_title: China plans national security laws for Hong Kong after last year's unrest: Xinhua
summary: China plans to propose national security laws for Hong Kong in response to last year's pro-democracy protests, which plunged the city into turmoil. The laws, which could ban secession, foreign interference, terrorism, and seditious activities, could be introduced as a motion to China's parliament and potentially trigger a revision of Hong Kong's special status in the US. The move has sparked concerns about erosion of freedoms and high degree of autonomy, with protesters denouncing what they see as Beijing's creeping meddling in the city.

site_title: Japan may end Tokyo state of emergency as early as next week: PM
summary: Japan's Prime Minister Shinzo Abe said the country may lift the state of emergency in Tokyo as early as next week if new coronavirus infections remain low. This comes after the relaxation of stay-at-home recommendations in much of the country. Japan's capital city and surrounding areas are showing promising signs that the rate of infections is coming under control, with 16,433 confirmed cases and 784 deaths. The lifting of the state of emergency in Tokyo and surrounding areas is vital for the country's economic recovery, which has tipped into recession due to the outbreak.

site_title: Hyflux clarifies report in Middle Eastern media on Utico
summary: Hyflux clarified a report by The National in Middle Eastern media stating that Utico was planning a US$500 million sukuk to pay down debt and had taken a 95% stake in Hyflux with a total investment of S$400 million. However, Hyflux denied the claims, stating that completion of the restructuring agreement with Utico has yet to occur and Utico has not made any investment in the company. The court has postponed scheme meetings to a later date due to the COVID-19 pandemic.

site_title: Italy PM accuses banks in blame game over cash for businesses
summary: Italy's Prime Minister Giuseppe Conte urged the banking sector to speed up the delivery of state-backed loans to businesses affected by the nationwide lockdown. Conte accused banks of making a "contribution, but can and must do more" to accelerate procedures. The European Commission forecasts a 9.5% economic contraction in Italy this year. Conte's remarks sparked protests from opposition politicians, who claimed the government's red tape was holding up the loans. Italy has eased lockdown measures, with shops and restaurants reopening with social distancing rules.

site_title: China supports 'improvement' of Hong Kong's political system
summary: China has expressed support for improving Hong Kong's political system, sparking concerns about tightening its grip on the territory. This comes amid ongoing protests and fears that Beijing is eroding Hong Kong's autonomy. The "one country, two systems" arrangement, which has allowed Hong Kong to maintain its economic system and autonomy since its return to Chinese rule in 1997, is being questioned. China's ruling Communist Party has vowed to push for long-term stability under this system, but the comments have fueled worries about Beijing's intentions.

site_title: AstraZeneca gets US$1b from US govt to make Oxford vaccine
summary: AstraZeneca received over $1 billion in US government funding to develop and manufacture the Oxford Covid-19 vaccine, accelerating its production to meet global demand. The funding, provided by the US Biomedical Advanced Research and Development Authority, supports a final-stage clinical trial and secures capacity to make one billion doses. AstraZeneca expects to have shots ready by September, with the US expecting 300 million doses available by October, and plans to prioritize vaccine supply to the UK. The funding is part of the Operation Warp Speed effort to secure vaccines for the US.

site_title: China to auction corn from state reserves in heated market
summary: China will auction 4 million tonnes of corn from state reserves starting May 28, amid tight supplies and rising prices. The move aims to "whittle down inventories" and cool down the heated market, where prices have jumped 15% in Harbin. Analysts expect more weekly sales until the end of October, when the new crop kicks in, and the government plans to release a portion of the reserves.

site_title: Fair Tenancy Framework industry panel offers 15 recommendations to level retail playing field
summary: The Fair Tenancy Framework Industry Committee (FTFIC) has submitted a 15-point report to the Ministry of Law and Ministry of Trade and Industry, aiming to create a level playing field for retail businesses. The recommendations include making rental data publicly available, prohibiting unfair tenancy practices, and establishing a Fair Tenancy Commission to oversee market-rental data and provide guidance. The move is seen as crucial for small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) struggling with the current retail landscape, with co-chairman Andrew Kwan warning that early lease terminations could lead to a severe uptick in unemployment.

site_title: Australia's Macquarie raises A$750m in subordinated bonds
summary: Macquarie Group's banking unit raised A$750 million in subordinated bonds at a 2.90% margin, a tighter margin than previously offered. The deal, managed by ANZ and other banks, was a floating 'BBB'-rated note. This comes after Macquarie's banking unit grew its home loan portfolio by 35% in the past year to A$52 billion, while other banks, such as ANZ, have seen their books shrink. The deal is part of Macquarie's efforts to raise A$1.70 billion in equity capital and A$26 billion of term funding in the 12 months to March 30.

site_title: SBS Transit's Q1 profit after tax nearly halves, led by fall in public transport services
summary: SBS Transit's Q1 profit after tax dropped 46.1% to S$11.1 million due to a 46% decline in public transport services, largely attributed to the COVID-19 lockdown period. Revenue fell 3.3% year-over-year to S$339 million. The group has over S$250 million in available cash and plans to defer non-essential capital expenditure to manage cash. The directors' fees were cut by 20% as a cost-cutting measure. The path to recovery is expected to be gradual, with social distancing expected to continue even after Singapore's lockdown period ends.

site_title: 73-year-old S'porean man dies of Covid-19; 448 new cases in Singapore
summary: A 73-year-old Singaporean man has died from Covid-19 complications, bringing the total number of fatalities to 23. The country reported 448 new cases, including 14 community cases and 434 work permit holders in dormitories. The majority of new cases are among Singaporeans and Permanent Residents. The government has taken measures to contain the spread, including testing residents and staff at a nursing home and pre-schools, and quarantining close contacts. The number of patients discharged from hospitals has exceeded new admissions for nine consecutive days.

images.alt_text: A 73-year-old male Singapore citizen died of Covid-19 complication on Thursday.

site_title: New Zealand PM Ardern's election prospects boosted by latest poll
summary: New Zealand Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern's popularity has surged ahead of the September elections, with a poll showing her Labour party's support at 59%, up 18 percentage points. Ardern's handling of the coronavirus pandemic has boosted her popularity, with her rating the highest in the poll's history. The National Party, led by Simon Bridges, has slumped to 29%, its lowest since 2003. Ardern's Labour party would likely govern alone if the current poll results are repeated in the elections.

site_title: Israeli anti-viral mask maker Sonovia eyes Nasdaq listing this year
summary: Sonovia, an Israeli company that produces washable and reusable anti-viral masks, is considering a Nasdaq listing by the end of this year. The masks, coated in zinc oxide nano-particles, show a nearly 99% effectiveness against viruses similar to Covid-19. The company aims to secure a valuation of $50 million and has received $18 million in investments, including $18.6 million in EU grants. A successful listing depends on scaling up production, and the masks are not certified for use in medical settings.

site_title: Shell evacuates foreign staff from Iraq's Basra Gas project: executives
summary: Shell temporarily evacuated around 60 foreign staff from Iraq's Basra Gas Company due to security concerns and a protest by laid-off workers at the headquarters. The staff were flown out of the country without disrupting production. The protest was staged near a Shell compound and prompted the evacuation. Production operations continued without interruption.

site_title: Asean business group calls for coordinated public-private response to Covid-19
summary: Asean business group Asean BAC urges the regional bloc to establish a high-level special commission to respond to the Covid-19 pandemic. The commission would facilitate coordination between the private and public sectors to address travel, essential goods, supply chains, medical services, and digital tools. Asean BAC also calls for deeper economic integration, removing non-tariff trade barriers, and investment restrictions to woo foreign direct investment after the pandemic. The joint statement was supported by various regional business councils, emphasizing the need for a coordinated response to mitigate the pandemic's worst impacts and ensure long-term prosperity.

site_title: Bill Gates gave US$519m to foundation last year
summary: Bill Gates and his wife Melinda donated $519 million in cash and stock to their foundation in 2019, boosting its endowment to $49.8 billion. This was the largest gift to the foundation last year, following a $2.7 billion donation from Warren Buffett in July. Despite significant donations, Gates' net worth remains unchanged at $108 billion, ranking him as the world's second-richest person.

site_title: easyJet to restart flights in June with compulsory masks
summary: British low-cost airline easyJet plans to restart a small number of flights on June 15, with mandatory masks for passengers and cabin crew, as well as enhanced cleaning measures. The airline will initially focus on domestic flights in Britain and France before adding other destinations. EasyJet joins competitors Ryanair, Air France-KLM, Lufthansa, and Wizz in implementing mask mandates. The airline aims to resume operations gradually, building demand as restrictions are lifted, and will initially offer no onboard food service.

site_title: Aviva first quarter sales rise, estimates £160m in Covid-19 claims
summary: British insurer Aviva reported a 28% rise in life new business sales to £12.30 billion in the first quarter, driven by bulk annuities. However, the company estimated £160 million in claims related to the COVID-19 pandemic. General insurance net written premiums rose 3% to £2.40 billion. Aviva's CEO warned that the pandemic would provide "additional challenges" in meeting 2022 targets, citing an uncertain economic outlook. The insurer has paid some claims in Britain and Canada where cover was in place.

site_title: Hong Kong, Shanghai: Stocks finish lower
summary: Hong Kong stocks closed lower on Thursday, retreating 0.5% or 119.92 points to 24,280.03, amid profit-taking and rising tensions between China and the US. The Shanghai Composite Index fell 0.6% and the Shenzhen Composite Index dropped 1%. This marked a reversal of three consecutive days of gains.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong stocks closed in negative territory on Thursday after rising for three days, hit by profit-taking and rising tensions between China and the US.

site_title: Australia: Shares end lower on China trade tensions, bank loan pain
summary: Australian shares ended 0.41% lower at 5,550.4, hurt by losses in miners and banks due to China's potential restrictions on iron ore and coal exports. The country's largest trading partner announced changes to its inspection process for iron ore imports, sparking concerns about a potential impact on exports. The bleak forecast about bank loan defaults also contributed to the decline.

site_title: Abu Dhabi wealth fund sees U-shaped global rebound next year
summary: Abu Dhabi's US$220 billion wealth fund predicts a U-shaped global economic rebound next year with 5% growth in 2021, according to CEO Musabbeh Al Kaabi. The fund gives a 70% probability to this outcome, with a 30% chance of a longer economic slump. The pandemic has forced a drop in oil prices, but demand for crude is expected to peak within 10 years due to the growing adoption of cleaner energy. Mubadala is shifting investments to natural gas, with no plans to completely kill the US shale industry despite low oil prices.

site_title: Thailand healthtech field set to grow: Report
summary: Thailand's health technology industry is expected to grow due to government efforts to digitalize the healthcare sector. A recent report by GlobalData identified hospital systems, pharmaceuticals, and electronic health records as key segments for disruption. The industry's growth is driven by an ageing population, higher digital penetration, and supportive government policies. Analysts predict the sector will continue to expand as the government incentivizes manufacturers of high-risk or high-technology medical devices.

site_title: Gold slides on hopes of recovery in economic growth
summary: Gold prices fell 0.7% to $1,737.35 per ounce, despite hopes for a swift recovery in economic growth following lockdown easing and potential vaccine development. Global equities surged overnight, but caution about the long-term impact of the coronavirus outbreak limited gains. Economists believe the recovery is still uncertain and that gold prices may not rise significantly. US Federal Reserve policymakers acknowledged the possibility of further support measures if the economic downturn persists, highlighting the ongoing challenges posed by the virus.

site_title: Seoul: Shares rise for fifth day in longest 2020 rally on recovery, stimulus hopes
summary: South Korean shares rose for a fifth consecutive session, their longest rally this year, driven by hopes of an economic recovery and stimulus measures from the US and China. The Kospi index closed 0.44% higher at 1,998.31, despite a 20.3% drop in exports for the first 20 days of May. Foreigners were net buyers of $62.54 million worth of shares. Minutes from the US Federal Reserve's April meeting reaffirmed a pledge to keep interest rates near zero until the economy recovers.

images.alt_text: South Korean shares ended higher for a fifth straight session on Thursday in their longest rally so far this year, as hopes of an economic recovery and fresh stimulus measures from the United States and China offset concerns over bleak domestic exports data.

site_title: SoftBank to sell US$3.1b worth of Japan telco unit stake
summary: SoftBank Group plans to sell 5% of its US$3.1 billion stake in Japan's SoftBank Corp as part of a US$41 billion asset sale program. The sale will leave SoftBank Group with a 62.1% stake and is aimed at raising cash for a record stock buyback. This comes as the conglomerate's tech investments falter, resulting in a record annual operating loss. The sale is part of SoftBank's efforts to shore up its balance sheet and restore investor confidence.

site_title: Show galleries to remain closed until further notice: URA
summary: The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) has advised that show galleries in Singapore will remain closed until further notice, starting from June 2, 2020, as part of the country's safe reopening in Phase 1. This decision is due to the high risk of COVID-19 transmission associated with economic, social, and entertainment activities. Developers and agents will have to continue using virtual methods to present and close property sales. The closure applies to show galleries set up by developers to market and sell properties.

site_title: US regulators open door to possible tightening of Huawei chip curb
summary: US regulators are open to revising a new rule curbing global chip sales to blacklisted Huawei Technologies, citing a loophole in the current rule. The rule, which expands US authority to require licenses for sales of semiconductors made abroad with US technology, does not cover shipments directly to Huawei customers. Regulators, including State Department assistant secretary Christopher Ashley Ford, say they will review the rule and make adjustments if necessary to close the loophole and effectively halt exports to the world's No 2 smartphone maker.

site_title: UK healthcare workers begin Covid-19 hydroxychloroquine trial
summary: British healthcare workers are set to begin a UK-led trial of hydroxychloroquine and chloroquine to prevent Covid-19. The 'COPCOV' study, involving over 40,000 frontline healthcare workers, aims to determine the effectiveness of the anti-malarial drugs in preventing the novel coronavirus. The trial, led by the University of Oxford, will open to British participants at hospital sites in Brighton and Oxford and is expected to yield results by the end of this year. The study follows recent claims by US President Donald Trump about taking hydroxychloroquine as a preventive measure.

site_title: Singapore sees negative rates creep in with flush liquidity
summary: Singapore's overnight borrowing rate fell below zero on Wednesday for the first time in almost nine years, following the Monetary Authority of Singapore's promise to provide sufficient liquidity. The one-month swap offer rate also dropped below zero, reaching a low of minus 0.01141% on Wednesday. This move is attributed to the city-state's efforts to cope with the virus-induced financial crunch, as it tracks US benchmarks. The rate drop is seen as a possible by-product of the MAS's operations, but not its intent. Singapore's economy is forecast to contract by up to 4% this year due to the coronavirus outbreak.

site_title: CapBridge gets backing from SGInnovate, Hong Kong govt-linked Cyberport
summary: CapBridge, a private capital platform backed by the Singapore Exchange, has secured equity investments from SGInnovate and Cyberport Macro Fund, a fund linked to the Hong Kong government. The investments close CapBridge's Series A round, valuing the company at over US$40 million. The funds will be used to develop technology solutions, including blockchain-based optimisation of share tracking and securities trading. The partnership aims to unlock value for private companies and investors in the region, with plans to scale up CapBridge's presence in Hong Kong.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares close lower on profit-taking
summary: Tokyo stocks closed lower on May 21, 2020, as profit-taking erased early gains from a potential state of emergency lift in western Japan. The Nikkei 225 index fell 0.21% to 20,552.31, and the Topix index lost 0.23% to 1,491.21.

site_title: JPMorgan plans to hire a dozen research analysts for China brokerage: sources
summary: JPMorgan plans to hire 12 research analysts for its China brokerage, marking its first major mainland hiring push. The move aims to double the number of China-listed firms covered by its research arm from 225 in five years. This expansion reflects the bank's efforts to take advantage of eased ownership rules and capitalize on the growing importance of China's financial markets, which JPMorgan CEO Jamie Dimon has described as a "critical market" for global clients.

site_title: Emirates faces dilemma over A380 superjumbos in shrunken travel market
summary: Dubai-based airline Emirates is facing a dilemma over its A380 superjumbo fleet due to reduced travel demand caused by the coronavirus pandemic. The airline is considering retiring a chunk of its 115 A380s, with options including cancelling outstanding orders, accelerating retirements, or using the planes for cargo or pilgrimage flights. However, finding a buyer for the planes is challenging due to the A380's unique design and limited second-hand market. Emirates may adopt a wait-and-see approach or explore alternative uses for the planes, which could potentially become a white elephant in the future.

site_title: Loyalty programmes getting better as airlines fight to keep customers
summary: Airlines are introducing new loyalty programs and offers to retain customers amid the COVID-19 pandemic, aiming to generate revenue. Airlines are increasing points earnings from shopping, expanding partnerships, and offering bonus miles for purchases and flights postponed. This is expected to make reward flights and upgrades more accessible to customers. Airlines can earn up to 2.5 US cents for every mile, generating significant revenue. Loyalty programs will play a crucial role in the industry's recovery, with airlines negotiating with the US Treasury to use loyalty programs as collateral for loans.

site_title: Abu Dhabi's Aldar Q1 profit down 39%, warns virus could delay project launches
summary: Abu Dhabi developer Aldar Properties reported a 39% fall in Q1 profit to 302 million dirhams, mainly due to a one-off write-down and a 309% fall in pre-construction sales. The company warned that the coronavirus pandemic could delay new project launches, but remains in a strong position due to its diversified business model and cash reserves. Aldar's revenue was flat at 1.76 billion dirhams. The developer is reassessing the timing and phasing of its planned launches amid market uncertainty.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets slide at open
summary: European stock markets declined at the start of trading on May 21, 2020, with London down 0.8%, Frankfurt and Milan each losing 1.2%, and Paris and Madrid dropping 1.3% and 1.4%, respectively. The decline was attributed to bank and healthcare sector drag, with US-EU tariffs in focus.

site_title: Japan's Abe wants to build ventilators that hospitals probably don't need
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe has pledged to build 2,000 new ventilators despite the government acknowledging that hospitals likely have enough, citing a need for national security and reducing dependence on overseas imports. Industry experts say Japan's small ventilator-makers will struggle to produce more than a few dozen a month, and qualified personnel are also in short supply. The plan has raised concerns about the potential vulnerability of supply lines and the risks of manufacturing ventilators without trained professionals.

site_title: Australia economic recovery riding on Covid-19 medical breakthrough: RBA
summary: Australia's economic recovery is uncertain, relying on a medical breakthrough to prevent and treat Covid-19, according to Reserve Bank of Australia Governor Philip Lowe. The country has reported over 7,000 infections and 100 deaths, with growth expected to remain slow. Lowe stated that restoring confidence on the health front is crucial for a strong economic recovery, and the RBA is prepared to scale up bond purchases to keep interest rates low. Without a medical breakthrough, the future remains "unusually uncertain."

site_title: HBO Max strikes more distribution deals in advance of launch
summary: AT&T's WarnerMedia has signed distribution deals with multiple pay-TV providers, including Cox Communications, Altice USA, and Verizon Communications, ahead of the launch of HBO Max. The streaming service will be available on various platforms, including gaming consoles, select TVs, and through its own mobile app. Deals have also been secured with Charter Communications, Apple, and Google. However, agreements with Comcast and Roku have yet to be reached, and WarnerMedia's CEO has stated that HBO Max may not be available on Amazon Fire TV devices.

site_title: Sea prices US$1b convertible notes at 2.375%
summary: Sea Ltd, the parent company of e-commerce platform Shopee and game developer Garena, is offering US$1 billion in convertible senior notes due in 2025 with a 2.375% coupon rate. The company also plans to exchange US$150 million in principal amount of existing notes for cash and ADSs. Proceeds will be used for business expansion, strategic investments, and acquisitions. Sea expects to close the new notes offering on or around May 22, 2020, and reported narrowed losses for the first quarter, with revenue more than doubling.

site_title: Japan to lift state of emergency for Osaka, nearby Kyoto, Hyogo
summary: Japan will lift its state of emergency for Osaka, Kyoto, and Hyogo, effective Thursday, as the number of new coronavirus infections drops to under 0.5 cases per 100,000 people. The decision comes amid hopes to boost the country's economy, which has tipped into recession due to the outbreak. The western prefectures will no longer be subject to restrictions, while Tokyo and four other prefectures will remain under the state of emergency. Japan has reported 16,433 confirmed cases and 784 deaths.

site_title: Australian states split over opening borders for domestic tourism
summary: Australian state leaders disagree over reopening internal borders, a crucial step in revitalizing the country's A$80 billion domestic tourism industry. The Australian Prime Minister wants to remove social distancing restrictions by July, but individual states, such as New South Wales, are hesitant due to differing views on safety. The country's tourism sector was severely impacted by the pandemic, with nearly 600,000 people losing their jobs, and unemployment rate rising to 9.6%. The debate highlights the challenges in implementing a uniform national plan to ease restrictions.

site_title: S-E Asia-focused VCs raised US$1.33b in Q1, more than triple from year ago: report
summary: Venture capital firms focused on South-east Asia raised US$1.33 billion in Q1 2020, more than triple the amount from the same period last year. This represents a sharp decline from Q4 2019, as the full impact of the Covid-19 pandemic has yet to be reflected in the numbers. With US$4.2 billion in capital, South-east Asia-based VC firms are now armed to invest in the region, but industry observers expect capital raising to weaken for the remainder of the year, particularly for early-stage funds.

site_title: Geo Energy seeks to buy back US$154m notes at steep discount and remove put option
summary: Geo Energy Resources' subsidiary, Geo Coal International, is offering to repurchase its US$154 million senior notes at a discounted price, less than half of par value. The move aims to provide flexibility to address debt obligations upon maturity in 2022. Proposed amendments to the bond indenture will allow the group to better manage debt once the bonds mature. The decision comes amid challenging market conditions, and the amendments are subject to noteholders' approval.

site_title: Coronavirus shut down the 'experience economy'. Can it come back?
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has severely impacted the "experience economy," which relies on live events, gatherings, and tourism. The industry's growth has been substantial, with the economy's reliance on live events increasing over the years. However, the pandemic's infectious nature has made it difficult for events to return, with many venues and businesses facing significant job losses and revenue decline. Experts predict that the industry will take time to recover, with some suggesting that it may never return to its previous levels. The pandemic's impact on the experience economy has profound implications for businesses and society as a whole.

site_title: Losses, infighting strain SoftBank's Masa-Misra partnership
summary: SoftBank's Vision Fund reported a $17.7 billion loss for its latest fiscal year, the largest in the company's 39-year history, amid concerns about the impact of the coronavirus pandemic on its holdings. The loss was triggered by a write-down of portfolio companies including WeWork and Uber Technologies. The Vision Fund's performance is being scrutinized due to the strained relationship between its CEO, Masayoshi Son, and co-founder, Rajeev Misra, who has been accused of efforts to tarnish internal rivals and is facing an internal review.

site_title: Mastercard to allow staff to work from home until virus fears subside
summary: Mastercard plans to allow employees to continue working from home until the COVID-19 pandemic subsides, with nearly 90% of its workforce already operating remotely. The company will reassess its real estate needs once the situation stabilizes, potentially leading to office occupancy rates of around 30%. Mastercard joins other tech and financial firms in adopting flexible work arrangements, with a "future of work" task force examining how to balance employee needs with office space.

site_title: Broker's take: UOB Kay Hian raises SPH target price, cites potential unlocking of value from assets
summary: UOB Kay Hian raised its target price on Singapore Press Holdings (SPH) to S$1.52 from S$1.50, citing potential value unlocking from its non-core assets, including property at Genting Lane. The brokerage maintains a "hold" rating. Analysts noted that SPH has divested a stake in AXA Tower and is reviewing non-core businesses, as part of its disciplined capital-allocation approach. As of Thursday, SPH shares traded at S$1.55, up 3.3% from the previous day.

site_title: In Washington, signs of lockdown fraying
summary: In Washington, D.C., signs of the lockdown's fraying are becoming apparent as compliance with stay-at-home orders remains patchy, particularly in neighborhoods hardest hit by the coronavirus pandemic. Despite strict rules, casual social gatherings are common, and some residents are taking to the streets to socialize, despite the risk of fines or jail time. The city's socioeconomic disparities have exacerbated the impact of the pandemic, with African-Americans disproportionately affected by the virus. Authorities may soon ease the lockdown, with Mayor Muriel Bowser considering a phased reopening plan.

site_title: McDonald's offers aid and warns some downsizing needed
summary: McDonald's is providing aid to US franchisees affected by the Covid-19 pandemic, with approximately $40 million in assistance earmarked. Franchisees may need to downsize or sell locations if aid is insufficient. Temporary assistance includes rent and service fee deferrals for operators in high-impact areas. Despite this, some franchisees have expressed frustration with the limited aid, and the company has warned that each restaurant must financially stand on its own.

images.alt_text: McDonald's is estimating that tens of millions of dollars will be needed to help US franchisees, but has also warned that some distressed franchisees may need to downsize or sell off locations.

site_title: Unlike China, India oil demand stays weak as economy falters
summary: India's oil demand remains weak due to the country's deepest recession ever, with fuel consumption collapsing by 70% during the nationwide lockdown. The economy is forecast to shrink by 45% in the second quarter, with oil demand expected to take until the end of 2020 to recover. In contrast, China's oil demand has largely recovered. India's fuel demand is currently at about 40% below last year's levels, with gasoline demand expected to return to pre-Covid levels in two to three months. The country's transport sector remains severely impacted, with diesel demand expected to take until August or September to reach 80-90% of its pre-Covid level.

site_title: Huawei's ambitions unbowed despite US pressure
summary: Huawei continues to expand its global workforce and business operations despite intensified US pressure, which aims to block supplies of vital semiconductors. The US Commerce Department has tightened efforts to deny Huawei access to global semiconductor supplies, but the company remains confident in its ability to find homegrown replacement chips. Huawei's global staff has grown from 180,000 to 194,000, and the company announced 19% growth in its global businesses in 2019. Huawei officials say the US pressure has not had a significant impact, and the company is preparing for a potential crisis by developing its own semiconductor supplies and training its workforce.

site_title: Asia: Markets swing as uncertainty tempers reopenings
summary: Asian markets experienced volatility on Thursday, with gains tempered by concerns over the long-term impact of the virus and worsening China-US relations. Despite optimism over easing lockdowns and potential economic recovery, investors are wary of the uncertainty and potential for another painful trade war between the US and China. The World Health Organization reported a surge in virus cases, while researchers made progress on a possible vaccine. Markets are cautiously optimistic, with some analysts expecting a vaccine to support economic recovery, but others warn of complacency and potential risks.

site_title: UK property could slump 12% on pandemic impact, warns Aviva
summary: UK property prices are expected to drop 12% due to the pandemic's impact, according to Aviva. Commercial real estate is forecast to decline by 15%. The coronavirus has led to businesses closing and unemployment rising, resulting in a sharp decline in rent collected by landlords. Aviva also expects to pay out £160 million in coronavirus-related claims. The insurer's real assets platform managed £45 billion. Insurance firms are expected to face at least $203 billion in losses this year due to the virus.

site_title: Commercial property transactions in US plunge 71% in April
summary: US commercial property transactions plummeted 71% in April, reaching the lowest level in a decade, due to the coronavirus pandemic. Hotel deals fell 98% to just eight transactions, while office and industrial deals decreased 60%. Despite this, prices for industrial, office, retail, and apartment properties remained 6.5% above year-ago levels. Non-bank lenders are expected to face the largest losses, as they provided a larger share of capital during the crisis. This collapse is seen as a potential floor for prices to help investors recover faster.

site_title: Strides Pharma to conduct trials in India for potential Covid-19 drug
summary: Indian pharmaceutical company Strides Pharma Science has received regulatory approval to conduct clinical trials of antiviral drug favipiravir, a potential Covid-19 treatment, in India.
