The trials follow a similar approval given by Glenmark Pharmaceuticals Ltd earlier this month. Favipiravir, manufactured by Fujifilm Holdings Corp, was previously approved for use as an anti-flu drug in 2014, but its efficacy in treating Covid-19 remains unclear. Strides' announcement comes after posting a fourth-quarter consolidated net loss, with its shares rising 1.8% following the news.

site_title: Samsung Electronics breaks ground for sixth domestic contract chip manufacturing line
summary: Samsung Electronics has broken ground for its sixth domestic contract chip manufacturing line in Pyeongtaek, South Korea. The new line will produce advanced 5 nanometre logic chips using extreme ultraviolet (EUV) technology, aiming to reduce reliance on the volatile memory chip sector. The facility is set to start production in the second half of next year, as Samsung competes with Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing (TSMC) for contract manufacturing orders from customers like Qualcomm Inc.

site_title: MVLLABS raises extended Series A round led by Shinhan Bank
summary: MVLLABS, the Singapore-based startup behind ride-hailing service TADA, has raised an undisclosed sum in its extended Series A round led by Shinhan Bank. The company has now raised just under US$10 million, with previous funding led by SV Investment in December last year. The new round will be used to expand existing markets and develop the mobility ecosystem built on its blockchain protocol, capitalizing on TADA's growth and delivering innovative products and services. This investment is expected to create synergies between Shinhan Bank and MVLLABS.

site_title: Perennial, Shun Tak donate 5 million surgical masks to Singapore's social service sector
summary: Perennial Real Estate Holdings and Shun Tak Holdings have donated 5 million surgical masks to Singapore's social service sector to aid in the fight against Covid-19. The masks, valued at 3 million and 2 million, were secured through the companies' combined network in China and will be distributed to welfare homes, disability homes, and children's homes. The donation is part of the companies' corporate social responsibility efforts.

images.alt_text: Perennial Real Estate Holdings and Hong Kong-based Shun Tak Holdings have donated five million surgical masks to the National Council of Social Service to aid in the fight against Covid-19

site_title: Thailand grants Gulf Energy licences to import up to 1.7m tonnes of LNG a year
summary: Thai Gulf Energy Development has received licenses to import up to 1.7 million tonnes of liquefied natural gas (LNG) annually, cutting energy costs. This move follows the state-owned Electricity Generating Authority of Thailand's grant of a similar license. The Energy Regulatory Commission approved Gulf Energy's request for an LNG shipper license. The company's new license allows it to position Thailand as a regional trading hub for LNG, as the country aims to free up its natural gas market.

site_title: Expedia signals May rebound as cancellations stabilise
summary: Expedia Group reported a quarterly loss of $1.30 billion, despite stabilizing cancellation rates and a 4% surge in shares. Demand is recovering, with the company seeing strength in its vacation rental business, Vrbo. Bookings for online travel agencies are expected to fall 60% in the third quarter, compared to an 80% decline in the prior quarter. Expedia secured $3.95 billion in funding, including $1.20 billion in preferred equity investments from Apollo Global Management and Silver Lake. The company expects a gradual recovery in the global travel industry as countries ease lockdowns.

images.alt_text: Online travel booking company Expedia Group on Wednesday pointed to demand recovering in May as cancellation rates stabilise, overshadowing a bigger-than-expected quarterly loss and sending its shares up nearly 4 per cent.

site_title: Team bonding during lockdown (Covid-19 Mental Health video series)
summary: A Singapore-based psychologist, Maria Micha, offers tips on team bonding during the COVID-19 pandemic. She emphasizes the importance of managers checking in with team members to show concern and acknowledge their basic need to be "seen." Micha suggests having team video-conferencing calls for fun activities and honest discussions, helping to create trust and connection in isolating times. By prioritizing team bonding, managers can foster a stronger and more resilient team, even in remote work arrangements. Micha's advice aims to support mental health and well-being during the pandemic.

site_title: HC Surgical: Vanda 1 asked for early redemption of S$5m bond on 'amicable grounds'
summary: HC Surgical Specialists confirmed that Vanda 1 Investments, managed by Heliconia Capital Management, requested the early redemption of a S$5 million convertible bond on "amicable grounds". No specific reason was provided. This decision came amid the ongoing Singapore Medical Council (SMC) investigation into surgeon Julian Ong and a court judgement in his case. HC Surgical's board was informed of the complaint, which will proceed to a disciplinary tribunal. The company has not disclosed any connection between the early redemption and the ongoing investigations.

site_title: Xiaomi profit beats estimates after smartphone sales jump in Europe, India
summary: Xiaomi reported a quarterly profit that beat analysts' estimates, driven by strong overseas smartphone shipments and growth in online services. Adjusted net income rose 11% to 2.3 billion yuan, with sales increasing 14% to 49.7 billion yuan. The company's strength in online device sales, particularly in Western Europe and India, helped drive growth. Despite potential challenges in the second quarter due to COVID-19 containment efforts and geopolitical tensions, Xiaomi's diversified revenue streams and growing online services are expected to support its performance.

site_title: China legislators take on wildlife trade, but traditional medicine likely to be exempt
summary: China's Parliament is set to discuss new laws banning the trade and consumption of wildlife, but traditional medicine is likely to be exempt. Following a temporary ban on the wildlife trade in late January and a February resolution promising a permanent ban, regions are taking action to implement the ruling. Local plans published this week suggest the fur trade and traditional medicine sectors will continue as usual, despite the proposed legislative changes. The national session of Parliament starts on Friday, with the outcome uncertain.

site_title: South Korea's May 1-20 exports tumble 20.3%, rate slower than April
summary: South Korea's exports for May 1-20 dropped 20.3% from the same period last year, slower than the 27.6% decline in April. Shipments to the US and EU fell 27.9% and 18.4%, respectively. However, exports to China, the nation's top trading partner, rose 1.7%. The decline is attributed to the ongoing coronavirus pandemic, but analysts predict trade data may have bottomed out as lockdowns ease. The country's trade deficit narrowed to $2.68 billion.

site_title: US coronavirus deaths rise by 1,561 in 24 hours: tracker
summary: The US reported 1,561 coronavirus deaths in the past 24 hours, bringing the total to 93,406, according to Johns Hopkins University. This brings the total confirmed cases to 1,550,959. The country remains hardest hit by the pandemic in terms of fatalities.

site_title: New Zealand opens bars as more curbs eased, four-day work week idea floated
summary: New Zealand has reopened bars and pubs after months of closure, as the government eases restrictions to revive the economy. The move comes as the country faces a tough task to reboot its $200 billion economy, with significant job losses expected. Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern has floated the idea of a four-day work week to boost the tourism industry, which was severely hit by the pandemic. The government has also announced a $50 billion package to support businesses and workers.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened higher on Thursday, rising 5.17 points or 0.36% to 1,440.29. Volume was 303.01 million lots worth RM160.76 million. Gainers outpaced losers 307 to 76.

site_title: Australia: Shares hit 2-month peak as investors eye economic recovery
summary: Australian shares rose to a 2-month peak, reaching 5,591.9, driven by an overnight tech-led rally on Wall Street and bets on a swift economic recovery. The gains came as the US Federal Reserve pledged to keep interest rates near zero until the US economy recovered. Australia and New Zealand also loosened lockdown restrictions, supporting gains in energy and tech sectors.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares start on front foot
summary: Hong Kong stocks began the day on a positive note, with the Hang Seng Index rising 0.53% to 24,528.91. The gains follow a week of optimism over global economic reopenings. China's Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also edged up, adding 0.24% and 0.37%, respectively. The positive start is attributed to the gradual reopening of economies worldwide, fueling investor confidence.

site_title: Fonterra cuts farmgate milk prices as virus hits demand
summary: Fonterra, the world's largest dairy exporter, has cut farmgate milk prices for the upcoming season due to the coronavirus pandemic's impact on global demand. The price reduction is attributed to the pandemic's "unprecedented" effect on markets and industries worldwide. Despite this, Fonterra's shares rose 1.7% following the announcement, outperforming the broader market. CEO Miles Hurrell described the pandemic as "like nothing we've experienced before," highlighting the uncertainty in the global dairy market.

images.alt_text: Fonterra said the coronavirus pandemic was "like nothing we've experienced before" as the world's largest dairy exporter cut the price it pays farmers for milk for the upcoming season with demand crumbling due to virus-led restrictions.

site_title: Thomson Medical directors take 20% fee cut, managers forgo bonus
summary: Thomson Medical Group's board of directors will take a 20% cut in directors' fees, effective June 1. Senior management will also forgo their annual wage increment, performance bonus, and annual wage supplement this year. These measures aim to ensure the group's viability and protect employees' jobs during the Covid-19 pandemic. The group operates in Singapore and Malaysia, where demand for obstetric services remains healthy but some clinics are closed or operating under restricted conditions. Thomson Medical's share price remains stable at 5.9 Singapore cents.

site_title: Singapore shares rise at Thursday's open, tracking US gains; STI up 0.5%
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.5% at Thursday's open, tracking US gains, with the Straits Times Index reaching 2,575.70. Gainers outnumbered losers 119 to 38, driven by sectors such as technology, finance, and real estate. Notable gainers included Singtel, Singapore Airlines, and Genting Singapore, while local banks DBS, OCBC, and UOB also rose. The rally follows positive US market performance and optimism over the reopening of the economy.

site_title: Keppel DC Reit acquires Netherlands data centre tenant
summary: Keppel DC Reit has acquired Borchveste Almere, its Netherlands data centre tenant, allowing the real estate investment trust to hold a direct relationship with the sub-tenant. The acquisition, at a price of one euro, does not significantly impact the Reit's financial performance for 2020. Keppel Data Centres Holding, a subsidiary of the Reit's sponsor, will cover expenses related to Borchveste Almere. The move aims to enhance the Reit's operational efficiency and provide better support to its clients.

site_title: Ford shuts two US assembly plants due to Covid-19 infections
summary: Ford Motor shut two US assembly plants due to COVID-19 infections. The Dearborn, Michigan, plant closed after a worker tested positive, while the Chicago plant was closed due to a parts shortage. Both plants are expected to resume production later on Wednesday. The closures come after Ford and other automakers imposed new safety measures to prevent a resurgence of infections. General Motors and Fiat Chrysler Automobiles NV reported no issues at their North American plants.

site_title: Australia backs technology in new carbon emissions plan
summary: Australia's conservative government has released a new plan to tackle climate change, focusing on technology and energy storage to reduce carbon emissions. The proposal targets the use of gas, hydrogen, batteries, and carbon capture, while avoiding a carbon price. The plan aims to electrify industrial processes, scale up hydrogen production, and drive down energy storage costs to back up wind and solar power. The government aims to turn the proposal into formal policy by September, marking a shift towards a low-carbon economy.

site_title: Asset managers lending to short-sellers can be ethical: study
summary: A study by the Pan Asia Securities Lending Association (PASLA) found that 89% of respondents believed securities lending could be compatible with environmental, social, and governance (ESG) principles if certain measures were put in place. The measures include proxy voting, collateral, and transparency. Industry experts, such as PASLA chairman Stuart Jones, are working on drawing up guidelines to address concerns that lending out securities can conflict with ESG investing. This practice, which earned asset managers over $10 billion in fees in 2019, could potentially align with ESG principles.

site_title: Vicom posts steady Q1 results in pre-circuit break period
summary: Vicom, a vehicle inspection group, posted a flat net profit of S$7.3 million for its first quarter ended March 31, 2020, due to stable inspection and testing services before the circuit breaker measures took effect in April and May 2020. Revenue remained steady at S$25.3 million.

site_title: US births hit 35-year low, part of larger 'baby bust'
summary: US births hit a 35-year low in 2019, with 3.75 million births, a 1% decline from the previous year. This marks the fifth year since 2014 that birth rates have declined, amid the coronavirus pandemic. Economists attribute the decline to economic uncertainty, particularly among millennials, who are delaying starting or expanding families due to job losses and shutdowns. The total fertility rate fell to 1.7, a record low.

site_title: Japan exports fall most since 2009 as pandemic hits demand
summary: Japan's exports fell 21.9% in April, the largest decline since the 2009 global financial crisis, as the coronavirus pandemic hit demand. Shipments to the US, China, and the EU plummeted 37.8%, 4.1%, and 28.0% respectively. Japan's economy slipped into recession for the first time in 4.5 years, with the pandemic causing a broader impact on businesses and consumers. Analysts warn of a bleaker picture for the current quarter as consumption crumbled following government requests to stay home and close businesses.

images.alt_text: Japan's exports in April fell the most since the 2009 global financial crisis as the world's third-largest economy braced for a deeper slide into recession, with the coronavirus pandemic taking a heavy toll on external demand.

site_title: In cash-rich Japan, a fifth of firms now see risk of insufficient capital
summary: A Reuters poll of 499 Japanese firms found that 14% are worried about insufficient capital due to the coronavirus crisis, with 21% considering tapping a government-financed financing scheme if market conditions remain severe. The crisis has pushed Japan's economy into recession, and some firms, including transport and retail companies, are most concerned about being short of capital. Firms have accumulated near-record cash reserves, totaling $2.47 trillion, but many expect losses or significant drops in profit if the crisis persists.

site_title: Some business models won't survive post-pandemic: Federal Reserve
summary: The US Federal Reserve warned that some businesses, particularly small ones, may not survive in the post-pandemic world due to the lasting financial effects of the coronavirus. Officials expressed concerns that a large number of small businesses may not endure the shock, and some business models may become economically unviable even after social distancing requirements are eased. Restaurants, theaters, and sporting venues are particularly vulnerable to the economic effects of the pandemic. The Fed also raised concerns about permanent layoffs and the possibility of secondary outbreaks of the virus.

site_title: Del Monte Pacific sells 12% stake in Philippine unit for US$120m
summary: Del Monte Pacific sold a 12% stake in its Philippine unit, Del Monte Philippines, Inc (DMPI), for $120 million, slightly smaller than the initially proposed $130 million. The sale's net cash proceeds will be used to pay down loans, resulting in a net gain of $114.5 million. The shares will be converted into redeemable convertible preferred shares, which can be redeemed after five years or upon an IPO or private sale.

site_title: US: Tech rally leads stocks higher
summary: US stocks rose on Wednesday, led by tech giants, with the Nasdaq Composite Index jumping 2.1% to a record high. The Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 also gained 1.5% and 1.7%, respectively. Optimism over the economy's reopening outweighed concerns about the impact of the coronavirus shutdowns. Tech stocks, including Amazon and Facebook, surged after new program announcements. Despite a mixed week, the rally reflects investor hopes for a quick economic rebound.

site_title: Why VCs need to stress-test their portfolio companies' sales abilities now
summary: Venture capital firms are urging their portfolio companies to stress-test their sales abilities amid the COVID-19 pandemic. A report found that 41% of startups globally have less than three months of cash reserves and 65% have less than six months. To survive, startups must focus on increasing sales efforts, rather than relying on investment lifelines. Billionaire Mark Cuban emphasizes that sales are crucial for startup success, and VCs should encourage founders to retrain staff and refocus on outbound sales. Effective sales can help identify product-market fit and adapt to changing market landscapes.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Manulife US Reit, Del Monte, Vicom, Keppel DC Reit, PropNex
summary: Several Singapore-listed companies saw new developments on Thursday, May 21, 2020. Manulife US Reit secured a $100 million five-year secured green loan from OCBC Bank to refinance a US office building. Del Monte Pacific sold a 12% stake in its Philippine subsidiary for $120 million. Vicom posted flat net profit for the first quarter, while Keppel DC Reit acquired a data-center tenant in the Netherlands. PropNex Realty sold 113 new homes in the first six weeks of Singapore's "circuit breaker" measures. Thomson Medical Group reduced directors' fees by 20% amid the Covid-19 pandemic, and Japan Foods expects lower net profit for FY2020.

site_title: Japan's May factory activity reels as pandemic hits output, orders: PMI
summary: Japan's factory activity declined sharply in May, with the manufacturing PMI dropping to 38.4, its lowest since 2009, due to output and orders slumping amidst the coronavirus pandemic. Employment conditions remained flat, but the services sector also contracted, with the services PMI at 25.3. The economy fell into recession for the first time in 4.5 years in the first quarter, with analysts forecasting a record decline in the current quarter.

images.alt_text: The decline in Japan's factory activity accelerated in May as output and orders slumped, highlighting increasing stress in the manufacturing sector from the coronavirus pandemic.

site_title: Oil rises on lower US stocks, firmer demand
summary: Oil prices rose on Wednesday as US crude inventories fell, reducing the supply glut. Brent crude increased 3.2% to $35.75 per barrel and US crude futures rose 4.8% to $33.49. Production declines and weaker refining margins have helped support prices. Despite gains, concerns over the economic fallout from the pandemic and weak demand limited increases. Analysts say rebalancing is needed for prices to rise further, with demand growth and OPEC's supply cuts contributing to the recovery.

site_title: US approves sale of 18 torpedoes to Taiwan
summary: The US State Department approved the sale of 18 heavyweight torpedoes to Taiwan for $180 million, citing US national, economic, and security interests. The sale, valued at $180 million, is seen as a move to modernize Taiwan's armed forces and maintain a credible defensive capability. This decision may further strain US-China relations, given the already tense relationship between the two nations.

site_title: Trump says G-7 summit could happen in person at Camp David
summary: President Donald Trump suggested hosting the G-7 summit in person at Camp David or Washington, D.C. in June, citing the country's recovery from the coronavirus pandemic. The move comes after the summit was initially planned for a remote meeting. Trump's spokeswoman Kayleigh McEnany described a face-to-face summit as a "show of strength and optimism." However, other G-7 leaders, including Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau and German Chancellor Angela Merkel, expressed caution, citing concerns over safety and travel restrictions due to the pandemic.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on Thursday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Thursday, following gains on Wall Street, as traders await a potential lifting of a state of emergency in western Japan. The Nikkei 225 index rose 0.53% or 109.39 points to 20,704.54, while the Topix index edged up 0.27% or 3.98 points to 1,498.67. The gains come amid a backdrop of US-EU trade talks and ongoing market volatility.

site_title: German government agrees Lufthansa rescue offer: report
summary: German ministers have agreed to a rescue deal for Lufthansa, offering a 20% stake in the airline and a 5% convertible bond. The state will invest €3 billion to support the airline, which is struggling due to the pandemic. In exchange, Lufthansa will give the state two seats on the supervisory board and allow Berlin to influence potential job cuts and environmental targets. The deal must be approved by the European Commission and shareholders, with a response period of two days.

site_title: Manager of Eagle Hospitality Trust may get new partner: sponsor
summary: Urban Commons, the sponsor of Eagle Hospitality Trust, plans to appoint a new strategic partner at the manager level to "stabilise, strengthen, and improve operations" of the Los Angeles-based real estate investment and development firm. The move comes after the resignations of Urban Commons founders Howard Wu and Taylor Woods, who will step down from EHT's current managers on May 26, 2020. The decision follows an ongoing strategic review that uncovered "prejudicial" transactions involving the two individuals, and trading in EHT stapled securities remains suspended.

site_title: Afghan Taleban leader says committed to deal with US
summary: The leader of the Taliban, Haibatullah Akhundzada, has reaffirmed the group's commitment to the landmark deal with the US, despite carrying out thousands of attacks in Afghanistan since its signing. The deal, signed in February, calls for the US to withdraw all troops by next year in exchange for security guarantees. Akhundzada urged the US not to waste the opportunity, while US envoy Zalmay Khalilzad reported similar commitments from the Taliban's chief negotiator. The deal aims to pave the way for direct peace talks between the Taliban and the Afghan government.

site_title: US airlines step up safety measures in preparation for recovery
summary: US airlines, including JetBlue and United, have introduced enhanced safety measures to boost confidence in air travel as domestic demand shows signs of improvement. With US states reopening and the Memorial Day holiday weekend approaching, airlines expect increased domestic travel. Despite recent data showing only a small fraction of flights were over 70% full, Airlines for America predicts planes may soon be full or nearly full, leading to a recovery in air travel.

site_title: HK land parcel sells for cheaper than expected
summary: The Hong Kong government sold a large residential plot in Kowloon for HK$4.95 billion (S$905.1 million), 10% less than analyst valuations. This sale comes as developers turn cautious amid a worsening economy. The plot, about four times the size of a football field, was sold to a unit of CK Asset Holdings. The sale price reflects the current market conditions, with developers opting for more conservative pricing.

site_title: Allegations against Surbana Jurong 'false and malicious': MOH, MND
summary: The Singapore government has denied allegations of profiteering and corruption against Surbana Jurong (SJ) in the development of the community care facility (CCF) at the Singapore Expo Convention and Exhibition Centre. MOH and MND stated that Temasek, which helped with the project, did not charge any management fees and only invoiced for expenses paid to third parties. SJ also provided its expertise at cost, without any profit or management fee. The government accepted that legitimate questions can be raised about spending but will respond firmly to any scurrilous allegations.

site_title: Europe: Shares follow Wall Street higher on recovery hopes
summary: European shares rose 1% on Wednesday, driven by hopes of a Wall Street recovery and technology stocks. The Stoxx 600 index gained 1.4% as tech stocks jumped 2.2% and chemicals rose 1.7%. AstraZeneca's 2.4% gain after US approval of a cancer treatment and Marks & Spencer's 10.8% jump after announcing a turnaround program also boosted the market. However, investors remain cautious, awaiting signs of economic recovery and a clear path forward for a potential coronavirus vaccine.

site_title: 'Super cyclone' Amphan batters Bangladesh, India
summary: A powerful "super cyclone" known as Amphan battered Bangladesh and eastern India, causing widespread destruction and at least nine deaths. The cyclone, which brought winds of up to 185 km/h and heavy rains, left three million people without power and inundated homes. Authorities had scrambled to evacuate over three million people, but the task was complicated by the need to prevent the spread of coronavirus. The cyclone is expected to weaken and recede to a tropical depression by midday Thursday, but not before leaving a trail of devastation across the region.

images.alt_text: The strongest cyclone in decades slammed into Bangladesh and eastern India on Wednesday, sending water surging inland and leaving a trail of destruction as the death toll rose to at least nine.

site_title: Coronavirus deaths top 325,000 worldwide: AFP tally
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) has reported that over 325,000 people worldwide have died from the novel coronavirus, with 75% of those deaths occurring in Europe and the United States. The virus has infected 4,943,050 people in 196 countries, with at least 1,827,200 considered recovered.

site_title: Federal Reserve debates longer-term crisis-fighting plan, minutes show
summary: US Federal Reserve policymakers are debating a longer-term crisis-fighting plan, with discussions focusing on providing more detailed guidance for short-term interest rates and capping long-term interest rates. The Fed has already implemented a multi-trillion-dollar effort to support the economy, including slashing interest rates to near zero and buying trillions of dollars of bonds. Policymakers are concerned about the potential for a prolonged economic downturn and are exploring new tools to navigate a rocky recovery, which is expected to be slower and more fraught than initially thought.

images.alt_text: Federal Reserve policymakers, still working to fully roll out a multi-trillion-dollar effort to shore up financial markets and an economy cratered by the coronavirus pandemic, last month dove into a new debate: how best to support the economy during a recovery they now agree could be slower and more fraught than initially thought.

site_title: France says no sign of virus rise after lockdown eased
summary: France's easing of its lockdown to combat the coronavirus has shown no signs of boosting the epidemic, according to Health Minister Oliver Veran. Despite daily deaths trending lower, Veran warned it takes at least 10-15 days to assess the impact. The total death toll has risen to 28,132, with 110 new deaths reported in hospitals and nursing homes. The number of people in intensive care has fallen to 1,794, down 100 from the previous day, as President Emmanuel Macron cautioned that the epidemic is not behind France.

site_title: ComfortDelGro trials plastic shield in 400 taxis to protect cabbies
summary: ComfortDelGro Corporation is installing plastic shields, called V-shield, in 400 of its taxis to minimize contact between drivers and passengers and reduce the spread of Covid-19. The shields, measuring 1m x 0.7m x 0.6m, cover the driver's cabin entirely with two "window" openings for payment. The trial aims to reduce the risk of physical harm to drivers, who are exposed to passengers throughout the day. If successful, more taxis will be fitted with the shields.

images.alt_text: The shield measures 1m x 0.7m x 0.6m and is made of an unbreakable material which can serve as added protection against violent physical harm. It also encases only the driver's cabin area and will not obstruct airflow in the rest of the cab.

site_title: Apple, Google launch contact tracing platform
summary: US tech giants Apple and Google have launched a contact tracing platform for coronavirus, offering health authorities worldwide a tool to track potential exposures. The platform, called Exposure Notifications, sends alerts to users who have been near someone who tests positive for Covid-19. Apple and Google are providing software updates for health authorities to use, but countries like France and Britain are developing their own systems. The companies have set conditions for use, including that the app must be voluntary, not gather geolocation data, and not be used for commercial purposes.

site_title: Economy, international relations on agenda as China's parliament convenes
summary: China's National People's Congress convenes on Friday, marking a critical moment for Beijing as it seeks to show the world it has overcome the Covid-19 pandemic and address mounting international criticism. The Communist Party will address China's worst economic crisis in five decades and announce strategic priorities for the year. Analysts will be watching for signs of how the world's second-largest economy will deal with rising hostility, including whether a fixed yearly growth target will be set. China's President Xi Jinping will also defend China's achievements in combatting the virus, amid criticism of its initial response and cover-up of the first cases.

site_title: Genuine incorporation or tax avoidance?
summary: A recent court case, GCL v Comptroller of Income Tax, clarified the Singapore tax law on tax avoidance, particularly for professionals incorporating companies. The case involved a dentist who incorporated a company to provide dental services and received a lower salary, which was deemed tax avoidance. The Income Tax Board of Review (ITBR) ruled that the use of a company to carry out a dental practice is not inherently a tax avoidance arrangement, but the remuneration received by the taxpayer was significantly low, constituting tax avoidance. The case established the "predication principle" and "arm's length transaction" tests to determine tax avoidance, providing clarity for professionals to structure their business operations without unacceptable tax avoidance.

site_title: Pandemic crushes Australia's dividends with banks leading fall
summary: Australia has made the deepest dividend cuts globally this year, with over A$9 billion deferred or cancelled due to the coronavirus pandemic. The country's normally high-yielding firms are conserving cash, causing foreign investors to lose confidence. The cuts will be felt locally, particularly among a population with one of the world's highest rates of share ownership, and may erode Australia's competitive advantage. Major banks, including Westpac, ANZ, and National Australia Bank, have cut or deferred dividends, with some predicting reduced dividends for at least three years.

site_title: Euro gains on EU common fund proposal
summary: The euro strengthened by 0.2% to US$1.0960, nearing a two-week high, following a Franco-German proposal for a 500 billion euro recovery fund to address the coronavirus pandemic. The proposal, if implemented, could move Europe closer to a fiscal union. However, the euro's gains were limited by concerns over the size of the fund compared to some European economies. The US dollar fell to a three-week low of 99.225.

site_title: Prudential, AFIN tie up to offer free insurance to staff of fintech firms
summary: Singapore's Prudential and AFIN have collaborated to offer free accidental death and injury insurance coverage to full-time employees of close to 150 fintech firms in Singapore, with coverage up to S$20,000 until April 2021. Employees who are retrenched will receive an increased coverage of up to S$50,000 for six months. Additionally, employees who are hospitalised for Covid-19 or dengue fever will receive a cash benefit. This package aims to provide "some peace of mind" to fintech employees during challenging times, according to Prudential's CEO Dennis Tan.

site_title: Facebook to help showcase online 'Shops'
summary: Facebook is launching free online "Shops" for businesses to showcase their products on the social network and Instagram. The tool allows merchants to customize their shop's look, display products, and direct customers to their websites for sales. The initiative aims to help small and medium-sized businesses survive the pandemic, with the goal of enabling them to thrive and adapt to new consumer behavior. The feature will roll out to 160 million businesses in the coming months, with plans to integrate it into Messenger and WhatsApp platforms.

site_title: Firms restarting face supply snags, higher costs, weak demand
summary: Singapore's businesses face increased costs due to Covid-19 disruptions, including supply chain and transport issues, as well as the need for safe-management practices. Firms are willing to incur higher costs to resume operations sooner, but production capacity and weakened demand remain major concerns. Cleaning and personal protective equipment (PPE) costs are expected to rise, with some SMEs reporting a four-fold increase in monthly expenses. The government's SMEs Go Digital scheme and Productivity Solutions Grant can help with costs, but firms seek clarity on guidelines and support for added expenses.

site_title: Extended dining-in ban a nail in coffin for many F&B outlets
summary: Singapore's food and beverage (F&B) sector is facing significant challenges due to the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic, with dining-in bans expected to continue for several weeks. A Chope survey found that over 2 in 5 restaurants will not last longer than two months, with 50% more restaurants closing in March and April compared to the same period last year. Takeaway and delivery revenue cannot offset losses, with 62% of restaurants experiencing a 50% revenue decline in April. More layoffs and job cuts are expected, with extended support on wages and rentals crucial for survival.

site_title: Twitter could end the office as we know it
summary: Twitter is allowing many employees to work from home permanently, following the company's CEO, Jack Dorsey's, decision. This move may signal a shift in the tech industry's design and culture of workplaces, potentially leading to the end of traditional offices. Despite the industry's long history of investing in office environments, technology advancements have made remote work more feasible. If other companies follow Twitter's lead, it could have significant effects on commercial real estate, cities, and the workforce, potentially leading to a more sustainable and equitable work environment.

site_title: Rolls-Royce plans to cut 9,000 jobs amid slump in air travel
summary: Rolls-Royce Holdings Plc plans to cut 9,000 jobs, or 17% of its workforce, amid a slump in air travel due to the coronavirus pandemic. The UK engineering giant is also considering closing sites and boosting savings goals to save £1.3 billion this year. The company's focus on larger aircraft is particularly exposed, with airlines scaling back years of plane orders. The move is seen as a response to a travel slump that's wiping out vital maintenance revenue.

site_title: Thailand cuts key rate for third time as economic crisis worsens
summary: The Bank of Thailand cut its benchmark interest rate for the third time this year to 0.5% amid the coronavirus pandemic, which has hit Thailand's economy, particularly exports and tourism. The economy is expected to contract by as much as 6% this year, the worst performance since the Asian financial crisis. The central bank's decision adds to the government's fiscal stimulus, estimated at 15% of GDP, and includes US$12 billion in emergency cash handouts to encourage consumer spending.

site_title: Maybank Kim Eng stays positive on S-Reits in 'conservation mode'
summary: Maybank Kim Eng maintains a positive outlook on Singapore Real Estate Investment Trusts (S-Reits), focusing on industrial Reits and US office S-Reits. Analyst Chua Su Tye expects occupancies and rents to be challenged by uncertain macroeconomics, but cash-flow visibility remains strong, particularly for industrial Reits. Maybank KE has issued "buy" calls on Ascendas Reit and US-focused office Reits, with target prices of S$3.35 and US$1.15, respectively. The brokerage expects sector valuations to stay elevated despite negative macro undercurrents and a lower interest rate regime.

site_title: Monkeys infected with Covid-19 develop immunity in studies, a positive sign for vaccines
summary: US researchers conducted two studies on monkeys infected with Covid-19, finding that survivors developed immunity from reinfection. In one study, nine monkeys were infected and then exposed to the virus again without getting sick. In the second study, 25 monkeys were vaccinated with six prototype vaccines, showing a substantial degree of protection against the virus. The findings suggest that vaccines under development may be effective in preventing reinfection, offering a positive sign for the success of Covid-19 vaccines.

site_title: Oxley unit finds buyer for Chevron House retail, banking units at S$315m
summary: Oxley Holdings announced an expression of interest (EOI) for the retail and banking units in Chevron House for S$315 million. The buyer was not identified, and it's unclear if the deal is linked to the proposed sale of the property to Golden Compass (BVI) for S$1.025 billion.

images.alt_text: Chevron House at 30 Raffles Place is a 32-storey commercial development with a net lettable floor area of 261,280 sq ft.

site_title: Exiting the pandemic not a case of survival of the fittest, but striking a positive balance
summary: Navigating out of the Covid-19 crisis requires balancing societal health with economic recovery. Governments have employed swift and inspiring short-term policy responses, including fiscal support packages and monetary easing. However, the prolonged duration of the pandemic poses structural issues for companies, including liquidity and solvency concerns. Policymakers must address the problem of moral hazard, where companies are seen to have a "heads I win, tails you lose" situation, and find a middle path of selective support to keep the critical parts of the economy functional. Governments are likely to need to increase intervention and consider equity financing over debt to ensure sustainable recovery.

site_title: Singapore market set for 2021 recovery; safety measures a new normal for firms that can reopen
summary: Singapore's market is expected to recover in 2021, driven by government fiscal support, ample liquidity, and investor willingness to look beyond the pandemic. A CGS-CIMB report forecasts the Straits Times Index to decline 22% in FY20 but grow 10% in FY21, outperforming previous economic downturns. Banks, led by DBS, OCBC, and Singtel, are expected to lead the recovery, with earnings growth of 4% in FY21. Companies have also implemented safety measures, such as digital platforms and remote working, which are expected to remain in place after the pandemic.

site_title: Johnson & Johnson to stop selling Baby Powder talc in US, Canada
summary: Johnson & Johnson announced it will stop selling its Baby Powder talc in the US and Canada due to declining demand and misinformation about the product's safety. The decision comes amid over 19,000 lawsuits claiming the product caused cancer due to asbestos contamination. The company claims its talc-based product is safe, citing decades of scientific studies. Johnson & Johnson will continue to sell cornstarch-based baby powder in North America and other markets worldwide.

site_title: No easy balance in exiting Circuit Breaker
summary: Singapore is set to exit the eight-week Circuit Breaker period and enter the Safe Opening phase, where dining-in is still prohibited, expected to last 6-8 weeks. This marks the first of three planned phases to reboot the economy. Some business activities will resume, but leisure activities like visiting kopitiams will remain limited.

site_title: Nurse at Ren Ci hospital among 570 new virus cases
summary: Singapore reported 570 new Covid-19 cases, with 562 being foreign workers living in dormitories. Two Singaporeans, a permanent resident, and eight community cases were also reported. A 30-year-old nurse at Ren Ci Community Hospital is among the new cases. The number of patients discharged exceeded new infections for the eighth consecutive day, indicating a possible stabilization of the Covid-19 situation. 11 patients remain in critical condition, and 36% of patients have fully recovered.

site_title: Australia opens up domestic life further as China dispute lingers
summary: Australia has announced plans to speed up the resumption of public life to boost its ailing economy amid a diplomatic dispute with China. New South Wales will allow recreational travel from next month, while other states are implementing a three-step federal government plan to unwind lockdown measures. The country's decision comes as China has attacked Australia's push for a global inquiry into the origins of the coronavirus pandemic, with concerns raised that it may be retaliation for Australia's lobbying efforts.

site_title: Air France retires Airbus A380 in coronavirus response
summary: Air France permanently withdraws its Airbus A380 superjumbos from service due to the coronavirus crisis, with a $549 million writedown to reflect early retirement. The airline plans to replace the planes with new generation aircraft, including Airbus A350 and Boeing 787, which deliveries are ongoing. The decision marks the end of Air France's Airbus A380 operations, originally set to remain in service until 2022.

images.alt_text: Air France will permanently withdraw its Airbus A380 superjumbos from service in response to the coronavirus crisis, the airline said on Wednesday.

site_title: Changi Airport to allow transit traffic from June 2
summary: Singapore will allow transit traffic through Changi Airport starting June 2, with airlines required to submit proposals for transfer lanes. Strict measures will be in place to keep transit passengers in designated areas, and airport staff will wear personal protective equipment. This move follows the gradual re-opening of air transport and aims to ease travel for foreign passengers. Existing precautions, such as safe distancing and temperature screening, will continue. The decision comes after Singapore shut its borders to short-term visitors in March 2020 to curb Covid-19 cases.

site_title: PropNex sells 113 new homes during 6 weeks of circuit breaker
summary: PropNex Realty sold 113 new homes in 6 weeks of the Singapore circuit breaker, accounting for 74.3% of top-selling projects. Buyers favored "rightly priced" properties, with median prices ranging from S$1,208 to S$2,241 psf. The company attributes the sales to its agents' training on virtual tours and online meetings. PropNex expects 200 units to be sold in May and predicts developers will offer "star buy" discounts to move sales after the circuit breaker ends.

site_title: Flush with cash, global property buyers wait for sellers to blink
summary: Global property buyers are waiting for sellers to lower prices amid the COVID-19 pandemic's economic impact. With $328 billion in dry powder, private equity firms like Blackstone and Brookfield are poised to hunt for bargains. Commercial real estate prices are expected to decline, with sellers offering 5% discounts and buyers hoping for 20% off pre-pandemic prices. The market is currently frozen, with transactions stalled due to social distancing rules and virtual travel restrictions, but experts predict a recovery in Asia, with Taiwan, South Korea, and Japan reopening for business.

images.alt_text: Real estate transactions in the Americas will fall an estimated 35 per cent this year, compared with a roughly 25 per cent decline in the Asia-Pacific region, analysts say.

site_title: Alibaba to invest 10b yuan in AI-IOT system
summary: Alibaba Group Holding plans to invest 10 billion yuan (S$1.99 billion) in an AI-IoT system centered around its Tmall Genie smart speaker. The investment will be used to enhance the smart speaker's content and develop proprietary technology. This move aims to expand Alibaba's presence in new technologies and business sectors beyond e-commerce. The company competes with Xiaomi and Baidu in the smart speaker market, having shipped 16.8 million smart speakers in 2019.

site_title: An audience comes out of lockdown for Schubert and Mahler
summary: In a bold attempt to revive live performances, the State Theater of Hesse in Wiesbaden, Germany, held a concert on May 18, 2020, with a sparse audience of fewer than 200 people, amidst the COVID-19 pandemic. The event, which featured works by Schubert and Mahler, was part of a general return to normal in Germany, where the growth of new cases has fallen below 1%. The theater implemented various anti-contagion measures, including social distancing and face coverings, and the performers accepted drastically lower fees. The event served as a model for other theaters, but also raised concerns about the safety of live performances during the pandemic.

site_title: Layoffs should be last resort, employers should pay retrenchment benefit: MOM
summary: The Ministry of Manpower (MOM) advises employers to treat retrenchment as a last resort, providing a fair retrenchment benefit to affected employees. Employers in sound financial position should pay retrenchment benefits according to existing contracts or norms, which include a payment rate of 2-12 weeks' salary per year of service. For employers facing financial difficulties, MOM suggests renegotiating a fair benefit package with unions or providing a lump sum retrenchment benefit. The ministry also emphasizes the importance of supporting retrenched employees in seeking new employment.

site_title: HSBC sees double-digit wealth asset growth in Asia by 2023
summary: HSBC expects to achieve double-digit asset growth in its Asia-Pacific wealth business by 2023, driven by its focus on high and ultra-high net worth clients. The combined wealth business, managing assets worth $1.3 trillion globally, aims to become the top wealth manager in the region. Despite the coronavirus pandemic disrupting trade and banking services, HSBC has seen increased usage of digital technologies by its wealth management clients, with significant growth in digital forex transactions and equity trading in Hong Kong. The bank plans to sharpen its focus on family offices and high-net-worth segments.

site_title: How executives use social media to build trust with investors
summary: A study from Singapore Management University found that executives' social media posts, particularly on Twitter, can inform investors about companies. Since 2013, the US Securities and Exchange Commission has allowed companies to post updates on social media, including by executives. The study found that younger, female, and more extroverted executives are more likely to have Twitter accounts. Executives' posts about financial information are more closely followed by investors, with a 0.3% stock price reaction for each tweet. The study concludes that what matters to investors is not the newness of the information, but the fact that executives are posting it, providing extra assurance about the company's information.

site_title: Panel urges help for 'vulnerable' workers as job losses loom
summary: A panel discussion at the Institute of Policy Studies in Singapore has highlighted the vulnerability of low-wage workers and freelancers in the gig economy due to the COVID-19 pandemic and globalization. Possible solutions include broader employer insurance, government-funded sick leave, and early drawdown of Central Provident Fund (CPF) savings. Experts also emphasized the need for companies to invest in training and retaining workers to minimize unemployment. However, implementing these solutions may be challenging due to legal constraints and the need to balance consumer costs with worker livelihoods.

site_title: Probe on WHO's virus response must not turn into a witch-hunt
summary: The World Health Assembly meeting ended with China signaling its support for a comprehensive, impartial probe into the origin and spread of the Sars-CoV-2 virus. China pledged $2 billion over two years to support the global Covid-19 response. However, US President Donald Trump threatened to pull US funding and revoke American membership from the World Health Organization if it does not improve. The US has the highest number of infections and deaths from Covid-19, and the probe must be allowed to run its course without turning into a witch hunt, as the focus should be on finding a vaccine to combat the threat of a second wave of infection.

site_title: Singapore shares fall as vaccine hopes fizzle
summary: Singapore shares fell 0.75% to close at 2,561.94, snapping a three-day win, amid doubts over Moderna's vaccine. Risk-on sentiments took a step back, with US-China tensions prevailing. In contrast, key gauges in Japan, Hong Kong, South Korea, and Taiwan posted gains. The Straits Times Index is down 20% year-to-date, with 20 counters falling and 8 rising in trading.

site_title: US homebuilding drops to 5-year low in April as pandemic continues damage
summary: US homebuilding dropped to a 5-year low in April, with housing starts tumbling 30.2% to 891,000 units, the lowest level since 2015. The decline, largely due to disruptions in building material supply chains and the ongoing pandemic, is expected to be the deepest economic contraction in the second quarter since the Great Depression. Despite a possible recovery, the housing market may remain subdued due to the 21.4 million job losses in March and April, and economists predict a 40% contraction in GDP in the second quarter.

site_title: All dressed down and nowhere to go: the new M&S shopping habits
summary: Marks & Spencer's annual results show a shift in shopping habits due to the coronavirus lockdown. Sales of sleep wear, active wear, and bras have surged, while suits and ties have declined. Online sales of baby wear and children's footwear also increased significantly. The retailer has noticed changes in browsing habits, with peak online browsing time shifting from 1900 to 1500-1700. These changes reflect the pandemic's impact on consumer priorities, with a focus on home comforts and family needs.

site_title: No more lip service. Time for a true digital transformation
summary: A recent crisis, caused by the COVID-19 pandemic and oil price collapse, has forced many Asian enterprises to embark on true digital transformation, a mindset shift as much as digitalization of data, assets, and processes. Despite hype, few had initiated this transformation before, but now they must, or risk becoming outdated and extinct. Eight key laws will determine success or failure in digital transformation, including de-layering decision-making, digitalizing assets, and empowering employees. CEOs must take decisive leadership to drive this transformation, as there is no longer time for alternatives in a post-pandemic world.

site_title: BofA warns of volatility-shock risk due to market fragility
summary: Bank of America warns that US markets are at risk of violent price swings due to increasing fragility. High-frequency traders' shutdowns and trend-chasing among investors have reduced liquidity, creating a massive log-jam when things go sour. The strategists predict a prolonged bear market similar in length to the recession, with potential opportunities for negative surprises. One potential solution is a Russell 2000 versus S&P 500 forward variance spread, which could perform well in either a recession or a major catch-up rally by small caps.

images.alt_text: Investors need to guard against violent price swings as markets become increasingly fragile, according to Bank of America Corp.

site_title: Spike in some Hong Kong flat sales raises fraud suspicions
summary: A surge in Hong Kong flat sales at HK$10 million (S$1.8 million) has raised suspicions of mortgage and tax evasion, following relaxed mortgage rules. In March and April, 61 and 70 transactions were recorded, compared to fewer than 40 previously. Realtors believe sellers may be helping buyers secure higher financing ratios by declaring lower transaction prices, which could distort market data and constitute both mortgage fraud and tax evasion. Bank officials have taken precautions to avoid approving applications below estimated values, and scrutiny on certain industries has increased since the recession.

images.alt_text: Regulators loosened rules in October, allowing buyers to borrow up to 80 per cent on properties worth HK$10 million or less versus HK$6 million previously.

site_title: CB rollback begins soon, but Singapore economy faces long road to recovery
summary: Singapore's economy is expected to face a long road to recovery, with a two-month quasi-lockdown set to end on June 2. Despite plans to reboot the economy, private economists believe the country is on track for its worst recession on record due to the ongoing novel coronavirus. A three-stage roadmap has been unveiled, but early projections show limited impact on analysts' predictions of a deep contraction.

images.alt_text: Singapore is still on track for its worst recession on record, private economists said on Wednesday, after plans were unveiled to exit a two-month quasi-lockdown on June 2.

site_title: Quarterly reporting has ended; but top SGX-listed firms provide voluntary 'updates'
summary: Singapore Exchange-listed companies no longer require quarterly reporting since February, but some firms have voluntarily provided 'updates' on their financials. The move is seen as a response to the Covid-19 pandemic. Companies that prioritize growth, placing their profit and loss statement first, are likely focused on growth, while those that do the opposite are more concerned with resilience. The lack of transparency raises questions about the reliability of these voluntary updates.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's F&B sector may face closures and layoffs, with 2 in 5 restaurants expected to shut down within two months. Prudential Singapore offers free insurance coverage to fintech employees against accidental death and injury. Employers must continue to pay retrenchment benefits, even if job cuts are inevitable. Oxley Beryl has entered an expression of interest to sell Chevron House's retail and banking units for S$315 million. The Straits Times Index fell 0.8% to 2,561.94, while US tariffs on Vietnam and the Asian garment industry may impact local businesses.

site_title: Japan Foods expects steady revenue but lower earnings for FY2020 due to Covid-19
summary: Japan Foods expects steady revenue for FY2020, comparable to the previous year, but lower earnings due to the COVID-19 pandemic. The company has maintained a skeletal operational model, with only 30 of its 59 restaurants open for takeaways and deliveries. Despite government support, the group's growth prospects for FY2021 are expected to be curtailed. Net profit after tax is expected to be lower than FY2019, with the company focusing on cost control and lean operations to mitigate the impact of the pandemic.

site_title: China slams US for 'dangerous' message to Taiwan's leader
summary: China has criticized the US for congratulating Taiwan's President Tsai Ing-wen on her inauguration, calling it "dangerous" and a breach of diplomatic commitments. The US recognition of Taiwan's sovereignty is a major point of contention between the two countries, with China viewing Taiwan as part of its territory and seeking to isolate it. Tsai's speech during her inauguration emphasized the need for peaceful coexistence and lower tensions, but also made clear that Taiwan will not accept Beijing's "one country, two systems" model.

site_title: All Singapore music for an all-S'pore cause
summary: Singaporean students from the School of the Arts (SOTA) are hosting an online concert to support frontliners and at-risk children during the COVID-19 pandemic. The event features local music by artists such as Dick Lee and Gentle Bones. The concert aims to promote Singaporean music and raise funds for those in need. The event highlights the talents of 14-year-old ukulele student Evan De Silva and a group of hip-hop dancers. The concert is a celebration of Singaporean music and a gesture of support for the community.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Hongkong Land Holdings' subsidiary issued $600 million senior unsecured notes with a 2.875% coupon, set to mature in 2030. Manulife US Reit secured a $100 million green loan from OCBC Bank to refinance its Atlanta office building Peachtree and fund environmental initiatives. The green loan is part of Manulife US Reit's new green finance framework.

site_title: Taiwan April export orders unexpectedly rise on 'explosive' telecommuting demand
summary: Taiwan's export orders unexpectedly rose 2.3% in April to $38.53 billion, driven by strong demand for telecommuting products such as laptops and tablets amid the coronavirus outbreak. This marks the second consecutive month of growth, defying economists' expectations of a decline. The Ministry of Economic Affairs warns of uncertainties in the global recovery and US-China trade tensions, expecting May export orders to decline by 1.9-2%. Taiwan's electronics industry, a key part of the global supply chain for tech giants, has been hit by slowing global demand for electronics.

site_title: UK says no new customs posts needed for post-Brexit Northern Ireland border
summary: The UK has proposed a plan to manage the Northern Ireland border post-Brexit, stating that no new customs posts are needed. Instead, existing checkpoints for agrifoods would be expanded, and some goods from mainland Britain would face limited additional checks. Businesses would have unfettered access to the rest of the UK, but tariffs would be levied on goods destined for Ireland or beyond. The aim is to prevent a hard border between Northern Ireland and the Irish Republic, maintaining the peace accord.

site_title: US borrowers in hardship jumped in April
summary: US borrowers seeking help on mortgages, credit cards, and auto loans increased by 12% in April, according to a TransUnion study. Serious delinquency rates for accounts 60 or more days past due remained unchanged, but forbearance programs and stimulus payments helped consumers stay liquid. The percentage of credit cards in hardship rose to 3.2%, while 5% of mortgages were considered in hardship. Large lenders like Bank of America and Citigroup have promised to protect customers from negative credit impacts, potentially understating hardship numbers. Further regulatory guidance is needed to assess the true financial health of consumers.

site_title: VW pulls 'racist' ad after outcry
summary: Volkswagen has pulled an Instagram ad featuring a giant white hand pushing a black person, amid widespread criticism that it was racist. The ad, promoting the new Golf car, showed the hand moving the person into a building with a sign reading "Petit Colon," a reference to colonialism. VW initially defended the ad, stating it opposed racism and xenophobia, but later removed it after viewers deemed it racist. The company's statement was met with skepticism, with many accusing the ad's creators of intentionally using racist imagery.

site_title: India domestic air travel to resume May 25 after virus shutdown
summary: India's domestic air travel will resume on May 25 after a two-month shutdown due to the coronavirus pandemic, with all airports and air carriers informed to be ready for operations. The announcement comes despite a reported surge in daily coronavirus infections, with 5,611 new cases recorded, and the total number of cases reaching 106,750. International travel remains uncertain.

site_title: US arrests 2 men wanted by Japan over former Nissan boss Carlos Ghosn's escape
summary: US authorities arrested two men, Michael Taylor and his son Peter Taylor, wanted by Japan over former Nissan boss Carlos Ghosn's escape. The men allegedly helped Ghosn flee to Lebanon in 2019 to avoid trial on charges of financial wrongdoing. Japan had issued arrest warrants for the Taylors and another man, George-Antoine Zayek, in connection with the escape. The Taylors are scheduled to appear before a federal judge via video conference. Ghosn denies the charges and fled to Lebanon, his childhood home, at the end of last year.

site_title: Singapore shares fall 0.8%
summary: Singapore shares fell 0.8% on Wednesday, snapping a three-day winning streak, amid doubts over Moderna's vaccine and US-China tensions. The Straits Times Index closed at 2,561.94, down 19.39 points. Risks from US-China tensions, circuit-breaker restrictions being lifted, and directionless US trading also weighed on the market. Despite some gains in regional indices, losses led gains with 20 counters down and eight counters up, with Jardine Matheson and OCBC among the biggest losers.

site_title: Venice Biennale postpones next two editions
summary: The Venice Biennale has postponed its next two international exhibitions due to the COVID-19 pandemic. The architecture biennale, titled "How Will We Live Together?", will now open in May 2021 instead of this month, and the contemporary art biennale will be pushed to April 2022 from May 2021. The delays were necessary due to the pandemic's impact on architecture studios and universities, and participants' concerns about health regulations and travel restrictions. The postponements will allow for more time to develop ambitious new projects and ensure the events can be held safely.

site_title: Manulife US Reit bags US$100m maiden green loan from OCBC Bank
summary: Manulife US Reit secured a US$100 million green loan from OCBC Bank, its maiden green loan. The five-year term loan will primarily refinance a 27-storey office building in Atlanta and can also be used for environmental initiatives in other properties. The loan is secured by share charges and intercompany loans. This new financing framework aligns with international green principles and complements the Reit's capital-management approach. The loan proceeds will minimize the environmental footprint of the properties and support sustainability efforts.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 11.15 points to 1,435.12 on Wednesday, with 561 gainers outpacing 356 losers. The market saw a significant volume of 6.715 billion lots worth RM3.628 billion.

site_title: Changi Airport to gradually allow transit traffic from June 2
summary: Singapore's Changi Airport will allow transit traffic starting June 2, with airlines submitting proposals for transfer lanes. Strict measures will be in place, including designated areas for transit passengers, safe distancing, temperature screening, and airport staff wearing personal protective equipment. Existing precautions, such as repatriation flights only being allowed for foreign passengers, will continue. The airport's gradual reopening aims to balance aviation safety, public health, and passenger well-being.

site_title: Dutch government's 2019 purchase of Air France-KLM shares 'irregular': audit office
summary: The Netherlands' Court of Audit ruled that the Dutch government's 2019 purchase of a 14% stake in Air France-KLM was "irregular" due to not informing Parliament in advance, as required by the country's constitution. Finance Minister Wopke Hoestra bought the shares for 774 million euros in February 2019, but the stake's value is now about a third of that. The court's findings do not obligate a reversal of the transaction, but it made recommendations for future purchases to inform Parliament.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end marginally higher
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose marginally, with the Hang Seng Index increasing 0.05% to 24,399.95, driven by optimism over easing global lockdowns and vaccine hopes. However, China's Shanghai and Shenzhen composite indices fell 0.51% and 0.97%, respectively. The gains were offset by concerns about the economic impact of the pandemic.

site_title: Cambodia lifts entry ban from six countries as coronavirus eases
summary: Cambodia has lifted the entry ban for visitors from six countries, including Iran, Italy, Germany, Spain, France, and the US, as the coronavirus situation eases. Foreign visitors must have a 72-hour old COVID-19 test certificate and proof of $50,000 health insurance. Upon arrival, they will be quarantined for 14 days and tested for the virus. Cambodia has reported 122 COVID-19 cases and no deaths, with the last patient recovering and leaving hospital.

site_title: Hong Kong no longer in top three IPO venues
summary: Hong Kong has fallen to fifth place in global initial public offerings (IPOs) for the first time in six years, with only $3.2 billion raised in 2020. This is behind Shanghai, New York, and Shenzhen, which have raised $14 billion, $11.6 billion, and $3.4 billion, respectively. Hong Kong was previously the top listing venue, with over $40 billion raised last year, but a slow start to 2020 has impacted its position.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong is not part of the top three listing venues globally for the first time in six years, as a slow start to 2020 has weighed on initial public offering activity.

site_title: WTO's goods trade index hits record low amid Covid-19 disruptions
summary: The World Trade Organization's goods trade index has hit a record low of 87.6, indicating a significant decline in global trade due to Covid-19 disruptions. This is the lowest level since its launch in 2016, with readings below 100 indicating trade below medium-term trends. The WTO estimates world merchandise trade could decline between 13% and 32% this year, consistent with the new reading. The indicator is a composite of various data points, designed to identify turning points and gauge momentum in global trade.

site_title: Germany to shield health companies from non-EU investors: ministry
summary: Germany has introduced a new regulation to shield health companies from non-EU investors, aiming to ensure the country's medical products and protective gear are not disrupted by foreign takeovers. The rule, which applies to companies developing or manufacturing key medical products, requires notification to authorities for investments exceeding 10% of ownership. The move aims to maintain Germany's self-sufficiency in healthcare and follows concerns over the COVID-19 pandemic's impact on medical supplies. The regulation is seen as an effort to safeguard Germany's healthcare system and production capacity.

site_title: Saudi pips Iraq as top oil supplier to India in April
summary: Saudi Arabia replaced Iraq as India's top oil supplier in April, after deep discounts on Saudi crudes lured refiners. India's oil imports rose 5% to 4.63 million barrels per day, with Saudi Aramco and UAE's ADNOC increasing output while cutting prices. The US also offered steep discounts, with Nigeria and Venezuela taking the 4th and 5th spots, respectively. The shift reduced the Middle East's share to 56.6% and increased the Mediterranean and African supplies, with the latter rising to 13.9%.

images.alt_text: Saudi Arabia replaced Iraq as the top oil supplier to India in April after a gap of three months as refiners in Asia's third largest economy were drawn by deep discounts on Saudi crudes, data obtained from sources showed.

site_title: Prudential offers Singapore fintechs S$20,000 cover against accidental death, injury to employees
summary: Prudential Singapore has partnered with the Asean Financial Innovation Network (AFIN) to offer complimentary insurance coverage to full-time employees of 150 Singaporean fintech firms, up to S$20,000 against accidental death and injury, and S$50,000 if retrenched. The coverage will last until April 7, 2021, and also includes a one-time S$500 cash benefit for quarantine orders and S$200 daily hospitalization allowance for Covid-19 hospitalization.

site_title: Coronavirus crushes Australia's dividends with banks leading the decline
summary: Australia has made the deepest dividend cuts globally this year, with over $6 billion deferred or cancelled by companies to conserve cash amid the coronavirus. The country's normally high-yielding firms have been hit hard, with Westpac, Australia and New Zealand Banking Group, and National Australia Bank announcing significant cuts. The dividend cuts may erode Australia's competitive advantage, particularly among a population with one of the world's highest rates of share ownership. Global equity strategists forecast a 26.6% decline in Australian annual dividends this year.

site_title: China's new outbreak shows signs the virus could be changing
summary: China reports a new cluster of coronavirus cases in the north-east region, with patients appearing to carry the virus for a longer period and taking longer to recover. According to Dr. Qiu Haibo, patients in the region take one to three weeks to develop symptoms, compared to one to two weeks in Wuhan, making it harder for authorities to catch cases before they spread. This change in the virus's behavior may indicate it is evolving, complicating efforts to control the outbreak.

site_title: Vicom posts steady Q1 results in period before circuit breaker
summary: Vicom posted a flat net profit of S$7.3 million for its first quarter ended March 31, with revenue remaining steady at S$25.3 million. The company's inspection and testing services businesses remained stable before the circuit-breaker measures took effect in April and May. Vicom has taken voluntary cuts in pay and fees to cope with the Covid-19 impact and has deferred non-essential capital expenditure to conserve cash. The company expects a gradual recovery from Covid-19, closely mirroring the economy's recovery.

site_title: US: Wall St opens higher on hopes of economic recovery
summary: US stocks opened higher on Wednesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average rising 1.03% to 24,455.94, the S&P 500 gaining 1.05% to 2,953.63, and the Nasdaq Composite rising 1.31% to 9,305.62. The gains were driven by upbeat quarterly earnings reports from retailers and hopes of a recovery from a coronavirus-fueled slump, with signs of more stimulus for ailing sectors.

images.alt_text: US stocks jumped more than 1 per cent at the open on Wednesday on upbeat quarterly earnings reports from retailers and hopes of a recovery from a coronavirus-fueled slump amid signs of more stimulus for ailing sectors.

site_title: ByteDance's value surpasses US$100b in private markets
summary: ByteDance's valuation has surpassed $100 billion in private share transactions, reflecting the company's strong performance despite the Covid-19 pandemic. The valuation represents a 33% increase from its last major funding round, with some transactions valuing the company as high as $140 billion. ByteDance's popular TikTok platform, which attracts 1.5 billion monthly active users, is driving investor interest. The company's recent appointment of Walt Disney's Kevin Mayer as chief operating officer of TikTok further underscores its growing influence in the tech industry.

site_title: Australia: Shares end higher on further easing of virus curbs
summary: Australian shares ended 0.24% higher on Wednesday, driven by plans to accelerate the resumption of public life and further opening of the economy. Despite China banning Australian barley imports and a slump in US stocks due to vaccine doubts, the S&P/ASX 200 index closed at 5,573. The country reported just 11 new Covid-19 cases, boosting optimism. New South Wales will allow travel for pleasure from next month, and international students may return to universities.

site_title: UK's Cambridge University to hold all lectures online next year
summary: Cambridge University in the UK announced it will hold all lectures online for the next academic year due to the ongoing coronavirus outbreak. The university's decision, made in May 2020, comes as the UK government continues to enforce strict lockdown measures. Although some in-person teaching groups may be possible, the university has decided to prioritize virtual teaching until summer 2021, citing ongoing social distancing requirements. This move follows similar decisions by other institutions, including California State University, and has sparked discussions about the future of university education.

site_title: Norwegian Air's lessors including China's BOC take main ownership
summary: Norwegian Air has completed a debt restructuring, securing a 2.7 billion crowns (S$382.9 million) credit guarantee from Norway's government. The airline's lessors, including China's BOC Aviation, have taken majority ownership, with Aercap holding 15.9% and BOC Aviation holding 12.67%. Norwegian Air will operate 7 aircraft initially before rebuilding its fleet to 110-120 planes in 2022. CEO Jacob Schram warned of tough times ahead, citing high uncertainty for the industry and limited revenues. The airline's shares were down 26% after hitting a new record low.

site_title: EU seeks to reset relationship with nature after Covid crisis
summary: The European Union has proposed new targets to make food production more sustainable, aiming to halt biodiversity loss and reduce greenhouse gas emissions. The EU aims to increase organic farming to 25% by 2030, reduce chemical pesticide use by 50% and fertiliser use by 20% by 2030. The measures, which are not yet legally binding, aim to align agriculture with the EU's goal of reducing net emissions to zero by 2050. The proposal also seeks to protect natural habitats and promote local, sustainable food production, despite concerns from farming groups about reduced yields and limited land use.

site_title: Seoul: Shares extend gains on policy expectations
summary: South Korean shares rose for the fourth consecutive session, closing 0.46% higher at 1,989.64, driven by expectations of government and central bank policy support to mitigate the economic impact of the Covid-19 pandemic. A special purpose vehicle will be set up to directly purchase commercial paper, calming the local debt market. Foreigners were net buyers of 78.1 billion won worth of shares, while analysts believe policy support may not lead to stronger momentum in stock prices.

site_title: Alibaba to invest 10b yuan in AI system for smart speakers
summary: Alibaba Group Holding plans to invest 10 billion yuan in its AI system for smart speakers, specifically the Tmall Genie, with the aim of developing proprietary technology and adding content. The company has shipped 16.8 million smart speakers in 2019, competing with Xiaomi and Baidu in the market. This investment is part of Alibaba's push into new technologies and business sectors beyond online shopping.

site_title: Thailand's central bank cuts policy rate by 25 bps to record low
summary: Thailand's central bank cut its key interest rate by 25 basis points to a record low of 0.50% for the third time this year, in response to the slowing business activity caused by the coronavirus pandemic. The move was in line with expectations and the fifth reduction in borrowing costs since August. The decision was made by the Bank of Thailand's monetary policy committee, voting 4-3. The cut aims to boost the economy and support business activity in the region.

site_title: 562 of 570 new coronavirus cases in Singapore are workers living in dormitories
summary: Singapore reported 562 new coronavirus cases, with 562 being foreign workers living in dormitories and 8 in the community. The total cases reached 29,364. 842 patients were discharged, exceeding new infections for the 8th consecutive day. The situation appears to be stabilizing, with the number of new daily cases falling for Singaporeans, PRs, and work permit holders outside dorms. 11 patients remain in critical condition, and 36% of Covid-19 patients have fully recovered.

site_title: Britain's Rolls-Royce to cut 9,000 jobs amid air travel slump
summary: Britain's Rolls-Royce plans to cut at least 9,000 jobs globally due to the reduced aviation market caused by the coronavirus pandemic. The job losses, primarily affecting its civil aerospace business and central support functions, will result in annual cost savings of £1.3 billion. The company will also cut costs across various areas. Consultations with unions will begin to address the restructuring.

site_title: UK inflation drops to lowest since 2016 as coronavirus hits
summary: The UK's inflation rate dropped to 0.8% in April, its lowest since 2016, due to the coronavirus pandemic's impact on global oil prices and clothing retailers cutting prices. The consumer price index (CPI) fell 0.2% in April alone, with the Bank of England predicting inflation could fall below 1% in the coming months. Core inflation remained steady at 1.5%, while retail price inflation dropped to 1.5%. The decline was attributed to falling petrol and diesel prices, as well as changes to the domestic energy price cap.

site_title: PropertyGuru grew sales 24% while gauging IPO window
summary: PropertyGuru, a South-east Asian online real estate leader, reported a 24% revenue growth in 2019 to S$88.4 million, exceeding its forecast of S$85.6 million. The company, which operates in five countries, rolled out new virtual viewing features to serve customers under lockdowns. Despite economic uncertainty due to the coronavirus pandemic, PropertyGuru is taking steps to emerge stronger. The company's operating free cash flow rose to S$14.2 million from S$11.9 million, and it's unclear when it might attempt to list again.

site_title: Norwegian Air gets 2.7b crowns in state-backed loan after debt restructuring
