summary: Norwegian Air secured a 2.7 billion Norwegian crowns (S$382.4 million) state-backed loan after completing debt restructuring, allowing it to survive in a slimmed-down version. The airline had run out of cash due to the coronavirus pandemic grounding its fleet. Bondholders, lessors, and shareholders agreed to a debt conversion and share sale, boosting the airline's equity ratio to 17% from 4.8% in 2019. The government provided the credit guarantee, which, combined with an earlier US$30 million payout, brings the total loan to US$301 million.

site_title: Beijing will 'never tolerate' Taiwan's separation from China: Xinhua
summary: Beijing has reaffirmed its stance that Taiwan will never be separated from China, with a spokesperson stating the mainland will "never tolerate" any separatist activities. China considers Taiwan part of its territory and has repeatedly advocated for reunification, using military force if necessary. The spokesperson also warned that Beijing will adhere to the principles of "peaceful reunification" and "One Country, Two Systems", while President Tsai Ing-wen's inauguration for a second term has further strained cross-strait ties.

images.alt_text: Beijing will "never tolerate" Taiwan's separation from China, a spokesperson at the mainland's top Taiwan body said Wednesday, after President Tsai Ing-wen was inaugurated for a second term.

site_title: Credit harder to come by as Philippine banks turn wary on loans
summary: The Philippines' banks are expected to become more selective with lending due to declining asset quality and increasing corporate debt levels. Despite efforts by the central bank to stimulate lending, banks will prioritize borrowers with a stronger credit profile. Loan growth is forecasted to be between 2-3% in 2020 and 10% in 2021, as the economy recovers from the COVID-19 pandemic. The Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas plans to count loans to small businesses towards reserve requirements to support the economy.

site_title: F&B sector in Singapore may see more closures, layoffs: survey
summary: A survey by Chope found that about 2 in 5 restaurants in Singapore may not last longer than two more months due to ongoing "circuit-breaker" measures and revenue losses. 50% more restaurants closed in March and April this year compared to the same period last year. 25% of restaurants plan to implement more retrenchments if dine-in suspensions are extended, and 11% have already retrenched full-time staff. Revenues from takeaways and deliveries are insufficient to offset losses, with 62% of restaurants facing a 50% decline in revenue in April.

site_title: Singapore running out of time to call election: Chan Chun Sing
summary: Singapore's government must hold its next general election in January, months ahead of the April deadline, due to the five-year parliament dissolution rule. With the city-state running out of time, Minister for Trade and Industry Chan Chun Sing emphasized the need for a strong mandate to address the challenges of the COVID-19 pandemic, which has infected over 29,000 people and poses a significant threat to the nation. The government's performance will be judged by Singaporeans, particularly in the long term, rather than just on episodic events.

site_title: China's Didi to start using AI to run virus monitoring in Latin America
summary: China's ride-hailing giant Didi Chuxing will use AI technologies to verify if drivers in its Latin American markets wear masks and disinfect cars, starting May 22. Drivers must take a selfie with a mask on and report body temperature and disinfection photos. Passengers must also wear masks, and both parties can cancel trips if they feel unsafe. Didi plans to roll out these technologies to most of its overseas markets, following similar measures introduced in China since January. This move aims to keep rides safe amid the coronavirus pandemic.

site_title: Kitchen Culture proposes acquisition of 40% stake in sanitiser maker
summary: Kitchen Culture Holdings has proposed a non-binding term sheet to acquire a 40% stake in Beijing Anxin Health Products Co, a Chinese manufacturer of medical supplies such as masks and sanitizers. Beijing Anxin owns the "AnXin" brand and intellectual properties. The acquisition is seen as synergistic with Kitchen Culture's KC Medical Supplies business.

site_title: Chloroquine is all the rage for Bolsonaro in Brazil's virus war
summary: Brazil's President Jair Bolsonaro is set to relax protocols for using chloroquine, an unproven anti-malarial drug, for mild COVID-19 cases despite warnings of side effects and no clinical trial success. The decision comes after two health ministers resigned due to objections to his strategy. Bolsonaro has ordered the military to increase chloroquine production, fueling public debate and concern over the president's approach to the pandemic. Experts warn of potential dangers, but the president remains committed to the use of chloroquine in Brazil's fight against COVID-19.

site_title: Dutch lender Rabobank sees big rise in 2020 loan provisions
summary: Dutch lender Rabobank expects a significant rise in 2020 loan provisions due to the coronavirus and market volatility, potentially adding 2 billion euros to its provisions. This would be among the largest booked by a European lender. The bank's 2019 profit of 2.20 billion euros could be exceeded by the additional provisions. Rabobank's loan portfolio is 418 billion euros, with 13% in sectors highly affected by the crisis, and it has a 10.90 billion euro exposure to the energy industry. The bank will report earnings for the first half of 2020 on August 13.

images.alt_text: Dutch lender Rabobank warned on Wednesday that provisions for souring loans could climb by an additional 2 billion euros (S$3.10 billion) this year and there would be a significant hit to profit as the coronavirus and market volatility drive defaults.

site_title: Doctor Anywhere to provide telehealth service to Great Eastern Shield clients
summary: Great Eastern Shield clients can now access discounted telehealth services through Doctor Anywhere, a telemedicine startup. Policyholders of the insurance company's Integrated Shield plan can receive a flat consultation fee of S$12 for general practitioner consultations through online video or at any of the 300 Doctor Anywhere panel clinics islandwide. This service, available 24/7, aims to provide convenient and accessible healthcare options amidst the COVID-19 pandemic. The partnership marks a significant expansion of the insurance company's shield insurance coverage and a growing trend towards telemedicine services in Singapore.

site_title: Spike in some Hong Kong flat sales raises fraud suspicions
summary: A surge in Hong Kong flat sales priced at HK$10 million (S$1.8 million) has raised suspicions of mortgage and tax fraud, following the relaxation of mortgage rules in October. The number of transactions at this price increased to 61 and 70 in March and April, respectively, from fewer than 40. Realtors and mortgage agents believe sellers may be helping buyers secure higher financing ratios by declaring lower transaction prices, potentially constituting mortgage fraud and tax evasion. Banks have increased scrutiny of applications and declined to approve loans if transaction values are 10-20% below estimated values.

site_title: Europe: Stocks ease at open
summary: European stock markets eased at the start of trading on Wednesday, with London down 0.2%, Paris 0.4%, Milan 0.1%, and Madrid 0.3%. Frankfurt remained flat. The decline was attributed to bank and healthcare sector drag, with US-EU tariffs also in focus.

images.alt_text: European stock markets eased at the start of trading on Wednesday, with London down 0.2 per cent.

site_title: Japan's MUFG to close up to 40% of domestic bank branches
summary: Japan's Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group (MUFG) plans to close up to 40% of its domestic bank branches by fiscal 2023 due to the coronavirus crisis. The company initially aimed to reduce branches by 35% but has widened the closure plan to cut costs. Despite being an essential industry, most bank branches have stayed open. MUFG aims to strengthen its online banking presence, expecting 6,000 job losses by fiscal 2023. The lender's move is part of its cost-cutting measures to adapt to the pandemic's impact on the global economy.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close higher on virus hopes in Japan
summary: Tokyo stocks closed higher for the fourth consecutive day, advancing 0.79% or 161.70 points to 20,595.15, driven by expectations of the Japanese government lifting a state of emergency for major cities on Thursday. The broader Topix index also rose 0.58% or 8.64 points to 1,494.69.

site_title: 'Circuit-breaker' has worked but Singapore must get used to new normal, says PM Lee
summary: Singapore's "circuit-breaker" measures, which limited gatherings and business operations, have been effective in slowing the spread of COVID-19. However, Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong says the country cannot revert to its previous state and must adapt to a new normal. Singapore will ease out of the measures in gradual phases, with some businesses reopening from June 2, while maintaining restrictions on dining in and retail stores. The government aims to keep community transmission low, citing examples of countries that experienced a resurgence in cases after lifting lockdowns.

site_title: Japan's JXTG plans 1.5t yen in capital expenditure over next 3 years
summary: JXTG Holdings, Japan's largest oil refiner, plans 1.5 trillion yen ($20 billion) in capital expenditure over the next three years, from April 2020 to March 2023, according to its new mid-term business plan. The plan assumes a continued decline in demand for petroleum products due to the Covid-19 pandemic. The investment will be used to adapt to changing market conditions and ensure the company's long-term sustainability.

site_title: Eagle Hospitality Trust's sponsor directors to resign
summary: Eagle Hospitality Trust's sponsor directors, Howard Wu and Taylor Woods, plan to step down from the trust managers' boards of directors, effective May 26, 2020, following the discovery of "prejudicial" transactions involving non-executive chairman Mr Wu and deputy chairman Mr Woods. The transactions involved Urban Commons master-lessor subsidiaries guaranteeing payment and performance of obligations, raising concerns over the interests of EHT and its minority stapled securityholders. Urban Commons has been in talks for a new strategic partner to stabilize operations, and trading in EHT stapled securities has been suspended since March 24, 2020.

site_title: Renewable energy should be at the heart of virus recovery plans: IEA
summary: The International Energy Agency (IEA) urges governments to prioritize renewable energy in their economic recovery plans from the COVID-19 pandemic. The agency forecasts a 10% decline in renewable capacity growth due to lockdown measures, supply chain disruptions, and financing challenges. Despite this, renewable energy is expected to remain resilient, with electricity sectors like solar, wind, and hydropower expected to continue growing. The IEA warns that a deep economic contraction could lead to a 8% reduction in global CO2 emissions, highlighting the need for governments to accelerate their efforts to meet climate targets.

site_title: HSBC sees double-digit wealth asset growth in Asia by 2023
summary: HSBC Holdings predicts double-digit wealth asset growth in Asia by 2023, driven by its combined wealth business in the region. The bank aims to sharpen its focus on high and ultra-high networth segments, with a target of becoming the top wealth manager in Asia Pacific. Following a merger of its global private banking and retail wealth businesses, HSBC expects to capitalize on the growing rich population in Asia, with nearly half of its global assets in the region.

site_title: Hang Seng Index makeover sets fresh benchmark for Hong Kong
summary: Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index has undergone a makeover, welcoming companies with secondary listings and dual-class shares, including Alibaba, Meituan Dianping, and Xiaomi. The changes aim to diversify the index, which has struggled to keep up with the times and has been dominated by financial institutions. The new additions are expected to reduce concentration risk and improve the index's representation of the tech economy. The changes are also seen as a step towards attracting more startups and improving the index's competitiveness with rival indices like MSCI China.

site_title: Employers must pay retrenchment benefit if job cuts are inevitable: MOM
summary: Singapore's Ministry of Manpower advises employers to provide retrenchment benefits to employees if job cuts are inevitable, especially those in sound financial positions. Employers should continue to pay according to existing contracts or prevailing norms, which recommend a payment rate of two weeks to one month salary per year of service. The advisory emphasizes empathy and responsible retrenchment practices.

site_title: Singapore sees downside risks despite recent jump in exports
summary: Singapore's economy shows a surprise improvement in exports, with non-oil domestic exports rising 9.7% in April, but Trade and Industry Minister Chan Chun Sing warns of "downside risks" despite the positive numbers. The city-state's economy contracted 2.2% in the first quarter, the worst performance since the global financial crisis. Authorities plan to reopen some businesses from June 2, with a focus on shared protocols with countries like China and Australia. A final GDP figure is set for May 26, and a fourth stimulus package may be announced on the same day.

site_title: Malaysia's Petronas to sell LNG to Chinese firm's tank facility
summary: Malaysia's state-owned energy firm Petronas has signed a deal to supply liquefied natural gas (LNG) to a Chinese firm's tank facility in Sarawak, using ISO tank containers. This approach allows for faster and more flexible delivery to remote locations in China. The deal, struck via video conference, is the first of its kind for Petronas and aims to attract buyers in a market where global demand is low due to the coronavirus pandemic. Details of the volumes and prices of the cargoes sold were not disclosed.

site_title: Visa extends work-from-home for majority of employees through 2020
summary: Visa extends work-from-home arrangement for most employees through 2020, following similar moves by other fintech companies, amid the COVID-19 pandemic's shift to remote work. CEO Alfred Kelly Jr plans to bring employees back to offices in stages, site-by-site. This move mirrors those of rival American Express and payments technology company Square, which have also allowed most employees to work from home.

site_title: Asia: Equities rally stalls on lingering economic uncertainty
summary: Asian markets were mixed on Wednesday as a rally stalled due to profit-taking and lingering economic uncertainty. Despite slowing infection and death rates, simmering China-US tensions and concerns about lockdown damage continue to trouble investors. The World Bank warned of a 60 million-person increase in extreme poverty and Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin predicted "permanent damage" to the US economy if lockdowns persist. Markets were also cautious ahead of a US$3-trillion aid bill and US-EU trade talks.

site_title: Malaysian air cargo carrier profits from soaring demand for medical gloves
summary: Malaysia's state-owned air cargo carrier, MAB Kargo, has reported "impressive" profits due to soaring demand for medical gloves and related safety gear during the coronavirus pandemic. The carrier has raised freight rates by up to 50% and added capacity on high-demand routes, with exports expected to jump 32% to 225 billion pieces this year. The cargo arm's profits have contributed up to 25% of group revenue, exceeding its typical 10-15% share.

images.alt_text: Global demand for safety gear has helped Malaysia's state-owned air cargo carrier MAB Kargo record "impressive" profits since February by exporting products from the world's biggest producer of medical gloves, its chief executive officer (CEO) said.

site_title: Broker's take: Maybank KE remains positive on S-Reits in 'conservation mode'
summary: Maybank KE maintains a positive stance on Singapore Reits, focusing on industrial Reits and US office S-Reits, which are in "conservation mode" due to uncertain macroeconomic conditions. Occupancies and rents are expected to be stable, with positive rental reversions, while retail Reits face yield expansion pressures and hospitality Reits have declining revenues. The brokerage prefers industrial Reits, such as Ascendas Reit, and retail Reits like CapitaLand Mall Trust, citing strong balance sheets and debt headroom.

site_title: France looks past Google, Apple for virus contact tracing
summary: France is developing a smartphone app to track people infected with the novel coronavirus, bypassing Apple and Google's contact tracing technology. The decentralized approach, which France prefers, allows users to control their own data and choose whether to notify authorities if exposed. In contrast, Apple and Google's decentralized system requires users to keep the app open at all times, which may lead to low usage rates. France aims to have its app operational by June 2, while several European countries are also expected to roll out their own contact tracing apps.

site_title: Broker's take: OCBC downgrades ThaiBev to 'hold' on weak sales, social distancing measures
summary: OCBC Investment Research downgraded Thai Beverage Public Co (ThaiBev) to "hold" and lowered its target price to 71 Singapore cents due to weaker sales and social distancing measures in Thailand. The company's second-quarter net profit declined 14.5% to 4.95 billion baht (S$220 million).

images.alt_text: OCBC Investment Research has downgraded Thai Beverage Public Co (ThaiBev) to "hold" and lowered its target price to 71 Singapore cents from 90 cents in light of its weaker sales and social distancing measures in Thailand.

site_title: Luckin scandal ripple effect prompts chairman-backed firm to seek cash: sources
summary: A company linked to Luckin Coffee, UCAR, is seeking fresh capital by selling its 1 billion yuan (S$199.4 million) limited partner interest in a Chinese private equity fund. The move comes as the chairman of both firms, Charles Zhengyao Lu, scrambles to avoid a cash crunch due to Luckin's fabricated transactions. UCAR has approached prospective investors for its 30.75% LP interest in the UCAR Industrial Fund, managed by Centurium Capital.

site_title: Schools reopen in South Korea as virus fears ease
summary: Hundreds of thousands of South Korean students returned to school on May 20, 2020, after a two-month delay due to the coronavirus outbreak. The reopening follows a successful "trace, test and treat" program that brought the outbreak under control. Around 440,000 final-year students are the first to return, with younger pupils shifting between online and offline classes. However, 66 schools in Incheon were closed after two pupils tested positive, highlighting the challenges of reopening schools while preventing transmission.

site_title: Taiwan president says wants talks with China, but not 'one country, two systems'
summary: Taiwan President Tsai Ing-wen has expressed a desire for dialogue with China, but rejected the "one country, two systems" proposal, which has been offered to Taiwan. Tsai stated that Taiwan is an independent state and does not want to be part of the People's Republic of China. She vowed to maintain peace and stability in the Taiwan Strait, engage in dialogue with China, and strengthen ties with the US, Japan, and other like-minded countries. China has increased military drills near Taiwan, but Tsai remains committed to finding a way to coexist with China.

site_title: Fujifilm shares fall after its Avigan drug showed no clear efficacy in some Covid-19 trials
summary: Fujifilm shares plummeted 3% after Japan's health ministry reported no clear evidence of efficacy for its COVID-19 treatment Avigan in some clinical trials. The drug, known as favipiravir, had been touted as a potential treatment after Chinese officials reported positive results, but concerns over its safety, including birth defects in animal studies, remain. The news raises doubts about whether Avigan can be approved by the end of this month, as sought by Japan's government.

site_title: Haunted by virus, China gears up for annual congress
summary: China's National People's Congress (NPC) begins Friday, with 3,000 delegates expected to gather in Beijing to rubber-stamp bills and budgets. The annual event comes amid the COVID-19 pandemic, which has killed thousands and paralyzed the world's second-largest economy. President Xi Jinping aims to project strength and control over the outbreak, despite international criticism. The congress is expected to focus on economic recovery, with Premier Li Keqiang's annual work report to announce growth targets and stimulus measures.

site_title: Malaysia's April CPI falls 2.9%, more than forecast
summary: Malaysia's consumer price index (CPI) fell 2.9% in April, its second consecutive month of deflation, exceeding forecasts of a 1.6% annual decline. This marks the first time prices have fallen since February last year, largely due to cheaper pump prices.

site_title: M1, SGInnovate team up to help startups use 5G in products and solutions
summary: M1 and Singapore Innovate (SGInnovate) have partnered to help startups leverage 5G technology for their products and solutions. The collaboration will connect startups with corporate partners and provide technical support, facilitating the development of innovative 5G applications. M1 will identify potential partners and provide a 5G testbed, while SGInnovate will match startups with suitable use cases. The partnership aims to unlock 5G's potential and drive economic growth in Singapore, with M1 and SGInnovate planning to create knowledge-sharing opportunities within the startup ecosystem.

site_title: China stands pat on benchmark rate, signals brief pause in easing efforts
summary: China's benchmark lending rate remained steady at 3.85% and 4.65% for one-year and five-year loans, respectively, signaling a brief pause in easing efforts. The decision was expected, with over 70% of analysts surveyed anticipating the move. The steady rate does not rule out future rate cuts or adjustments, with some analysts expecting more aggressive monetary and fiscal stimulus to aid economic recovery. China's GDP shrank 6.8% in the first quarter, the worst quarterly contraction on record, amid the pandemic.

site_title: South Korea sets up 10t won special purpose vehicle to stabilise bond market
summary: South Korea's government and Bank of Korea have set up a 10 trillion won special purpose vehicle to stabilize the local debt market, which has been affected by the coronavirus pandemic. The vehicle will directly purchase commercial paper, including subprime debt and high-credit-rated bonds, for six months. To fund the vehicle, the Bank of Korea will provide 8 trillion won in loans and the Korea Development Bank will issue 1 trillion won in debt. This move aims to calm the debt market and support the economy.

site_title: US Senate Democrats call for Trump administration to unveil details of TSMC plant deal
summary: US Senate Democrats urge the Trump administration to unveil details of a proposed $12 billion plant by Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co (TSMC) in the US, citing national security concerns and potential undisclosed subsidies. The Democrats, led by Chuck Schumer, asked for transparency and consideration of existing US-based companies, such as Micron and GlobalFoundries. The proposal, touted by Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross, aims to boost American manufacturing, but the Democrats question how it aligns with national security requirements and a broader strategy for a diverse US semiconductor supply chain.

site_title: Hong Kong land parcel goes for cheaper than expected to CK Asset
summary: Hong Kong's government sold a large residential plot for HK$4.95 billion, 10% less than analyst valuations, to CK Asset Holdings. The plot, about 4 times the size of a football field, was valued between HK$5.5 billion and HK$6.5 billion. The sale comes as developers turn cautious amid a worsening economy, with the city's unemployment rate rising to a decade-high in April. The sale includes a requirement to build and sell at least 1,000 apartments to Hong Kong permanent residents at a 20% discount to market rates.

site_title: Hongkong Land to issue US$600m 10-year notes due in 2030
summary: Hongkong Land Holdings' subsidiary, The Hongkong Land Company, has priced US$600 million of 10-year senior unsecured notes due in 2030 at a 2.875% coupon, payable semi-annually. The notes will be issued by The Hongkong Land Finance (Cayman Islands) Company Limited as part of its guaranteed medium-term note programme. The net proceeds will be used for general corporate purposes.

site_title: US records more than 1,500 coronavirus deaths in past 24 hours: tracker
summary: The US recorded 1,536 coronavirus deaths over the past 24 hours, bringing the total number of Covid-19 deaths to 91,845. The country also leads the global rankings in both highest death toll and infections, with over 1.5 million cases.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei index opens slightly higher on Wednesday
summary: Tokyo's Nikkei 225 index opened 0.27% higher on Wednesday, following a three-day rally. The broader Topix index slipped 0.02%. The gains came after US shares retreated due to warnings about lingering economic risks from the coronavirus. The Nikkei index rose to 20,488.10, while the Topix index fell to 1,485.75.

site_title: Garuda Indonesia to seek 3-year maturity extension for US$500m sukuk
summary: Garuda Indonesia is seeking a 3-year maturity extension for its US$500 million Islamic bonds, which are due on June 3, due to financial struggles caused by the coronavirus outbreak. The airline has submitted the proposal to Indonesia's Financial Services Authority and will seek holders' approval on June 10. This move aims to alleviate debt repayment pressure.

images.alt_text: Airline PT Garuda Indonesia is preparing to propose a 3-year maturity extension to its US$500 million Islamic bonds that are coming due on June 3, the company said in a statement late on Tuesday.

site_title: UK opens fund to help high-growth firms weather virus crisis
summary: The UK government has launched a £500 million fund, known as the Future Fund, to provide loans of up to £5 million to high-growth companies to help them weather the novel coronavirus crisis. Chancellor Rishi Sunak warned of a severe recession, with the goal of supporting 10 million jobs. The fund aims to support UK companies in high-growth industries, which are crucial to the country's economic recovery. The move is part of the government's unprecedented effort to help the UK economy survive the crisis.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares open higher on Wednesday
summary: Hong Kong shares rose 0.31% on Wednesday, extending gains from the previous two days, as countries ease lockdowns. The Hang Seng Index reached 24,462.90, while China's Shanghai Composite Index dipped 0.07%. The rise was tempered by concerns about economic damage from lockdowns.

site_title: A market relying on fax and phone shaken by work-at-home traders
summary: Companies in the liquefied natural gas (LNG) market, one of the few commodity markets relying heavily on face-to-face negotiations, are adapting to the work-from-home world due to the COVID-19 pandemic. Innovators are promoting online deals, citing the benefits of increased transparency and inclusivity. Industry expert David Thomas notes that email and mobile phones are sufficient for executing deals remotely. This shift could revolutionize the market, allowing for more efficient and cost-effective transactions.

site_title: Facebook to limit offices to 25% capacity, require masks at work
summary: Facebook plans to limit office occupancy to 25% capacity, requiring masks and temperature checks starting July 6. The company will also implement social distancing measures, limit gatherings in meeting rooms, and replace cafeteria buffets with grab-and-go meals. Office gyms will initially remain closed, and outside visitors will be barred. Employees who can work remotely will continue to do so through the end of 2020, while those in hardware, operations, or other roles will be required to return to the office.

site_title: Australia: Shares drop as ties with China come under pressure
summary: Australian shares fell 0.6% to a two-month low on May 20, 2020, due to escalating tensions with China. Beijing imposed heavy tariffs on Australian barley imports, expected to halt a trade worth billions of dollars. The move comes amid a global probe into the origin of the novel coronavirus. The S&P/ASX 200 index closed at 5,526.7.

site_title: Singapore shares edge up at Wednesday's open; STI up 0.1%
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.1% on Wednesday, driven by news of the country's gradual reopening of businesses and a new aid package from the government. The Straits Times Index (STI) increased to 2,583.09 points. Gainers outnumbered losers 65 to 62, with gains seen in Thai Beverage, Oxley Holdings, and DBS. Banking stocks also rose, while Singapore Airlines fell 2.2%. The global market was subdued, with Wall Street and European shares ending lower on Tuesday amid warnings of lingering economic risks from the novel coronavirus.

site_title: ComfortDelGro trials plastic shield in 400 taxis to protect cabbies
summary: ComfortDelGro Corporation is installing plastic shields, called V-shields, in 400 taxis to minimize contact between drivers and passengers and reduce Covid-19 spread. The shields cover the driver's cabin and provide added protection against violent physical harm. Installation began with 50 taxis per week, and if successful, more taxis will be fitted. ComfortDelGro CEO Ang Wei Neng said the shields will reduce the risk for cabbies, who take precautions by wearing masks and disinfecting cabs. The move comes after cabbies are exposed to passengers throughout the day and night.

site_title: Oxley Beryl enters into EOI to sell Chevron House's retail, banking units for S$315m
summary: Oxley Holdings announced that a potential buyer has entered into an expression of interest (EOI) to acquire the retail and banking units at Chevron House in Raffles Place for S$315 million. The buyer, who received a refundable deposit of S$3.15 million, may opt to ink a binding sale-and-purchase agreement by June 15, 2020, with completion expected by June 30, 2020. This sale is part of Oxley Holdings' proposed S$1.025 billion sale of the property to US real estate fund AEW through its investment vehicle Golden Compass.

site_title: Luckin Coffee receives Nasdaq delisting notice
summary: Luckin Coffee received a delisting notice from Nasdaq due to concerns over fabricated transactions and failure to disclose material information. The US exchange plans to tighten listing rules for Chinese companies, imposing a minimum fundraising size and float requirement. Luckin's shares have been suspended since early April, following the firing of its CEO and scrutiny from regulators in both the US and China. An appeal hearing is expected to be scheduled within 45 days.

site_title: Spotify new home for Joe Rogan's podcast, shares jump
summary: Spotify has announced that comedian Joe Rogan's podcast, "The Joe Rogan Experience", will become exclusive to the platform starting September 1, with shares jumping 8.4% in response. The deal is seen as part of Spotify's aim to transform itself into the Netflix of audio, with Rogan's podcast being downloaded millions of times each month and frequently featured on Apple's charts. The move is expected to further establish Spotify as a major player in the audio streaming market.

site_title: Three freehold shophouses in Lavender, Tiong Bahru up for sale
summary: Three freehold shophouses in Singapore's Lavender and Tiong Bahru neighborhoods have been put on the market, with guide prices of S$23.8 million and S$12.5 million. The shophouses, located on Cavan Road and Outram Road, offer opportunities for redevelopment or conversion to other uses, including hotels or student hostels. The sale is subject to various regulations, including the Urban Redevelopment Authority's (URA) Master Plan 2014 and buyer's stamp duty (ABSD).

images.alt_text: On 26 and 28 Cavan Road are two adjacent shophouses up for sale with a guide price of S$23.8 million.
The corner shophouse at 259 Outram Road has an indicative price of S$12.5 million.

site_title: Loaded with cash, global property buyers wait for sellers to crack
summary: Global property buyers are waiting for sellers to crack due to the pandemic, with many sitting on piles of cash. Commercial real estate prices are expected to drop, with sellers offering discounts of around 5% and buyers hoping for 20% off pre-pandemic prices. Private equity firms, such as Blackstone and Brookfield, are holding $328 billion in dry powder for real estate deployment and are expected to hunt for bargains. Transactions have stalled due to social distancing rules and virtual travel halts, with prices expected to fall in coming months.

site_title: Australian retail sales dive a record 17.9% in April: ABS preliminary estimate
summary: Australian retail sales plummeted a record 17.9% in April, the largest decline ever, due to widespread mobility restrictions caused by the coronavirus. This follows a 8.5% surge in March. The decline was most notable in clothing, travel, and dining out sectors, with sales being around half of April 2019 levels. The final estimate is due on June 4.

site_title: STI extends gains, up 42 points on Wall Street rally, vaccine hope
summary: The Straits Times Index in Singapore jumped 42.05 points, or 1.66%, to 2,581.33 on Tuesday, driven by vaccine hopes and Wall Street's overnight rally. Major Asian bourses also posted strong gains. Analysts attribute the optimism to easing restrictions and the potential Covid-19 vaccine, despite geopolitical tensions and caution over the trial's sample size. The market's momentum continues with Singapore's three banks, DBS, UOB, and OCBC, rising between 1.7 and 2.8%.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 5.12 points, or 0.36%, to 1,429.09 on Wednesday, driven by gains. The market saw 252.71 million lots traded worth RM97.19 million. Gainers outpaced losers 191-109.

site_title: Japan's March machinery orders fall as damage from pandemic spreads
summary: Japan's core machinery orders fell 0.4% in March, despite a 2.3% gain in February, indicating a widening economic impact from the coronavirus pandemic. The decline was offset by a large number of orders for big-ticket items. Economists predict a collapse in investment across the quarter, with the Bank of Japan to hold an emergency policy meeting to set up a reward scheme for financial institutions that boost lending to small firms. The country's economy slipped into a deepening recession, with the Reuters Tankan survey showing a decade-low business confidence in May.

site_title: UK Labour party cancels annual conference
summary: The UK Labour party has cancelled its annual conference scheduled for September due to the ongoing coronavirus pandemic. The decision, made by a spokeswoman, prioritizes the safety of members, staff, and visitors. The conference, which would have been the first under Keir Starmer's leadership, normally draws around 13,000 attendees. The British government's nationwide lockdown at the end of March has led to the postponement of the event.

site_title: Leading NGOs blast UN over virus pandemic inaction
summary: Leading non-governmental organizations (NGOs) have criticized the United Nations Security Council for its inaction during the COVID-19 pandemic, particularly in conflict zones. The council, hindered by a US-China confrontation, failed to agree on a resolution supporting ceasefires. The NGOs, backed by 200 organizations and 140 countries, argue that the Security Council's paralysis is "shameful" and "incomprehensible" to millions of people affected by the pandemic. The US and China are accused of prioritizing blame over cooperation, preventing the council from taking decisive action to reduce violence and ensure aid access.

site_title: Facebook to help struggling retailers create online stores
summary: Facebook is launching free tools to help struggling retailers create online storefronts on its platform and Instagram. The initiative aims to assist the retail sector affected by the pandemic. Merchants can easily set up shops, customize looks, and display products. The move is part of Facebook's efforts to support the retail sector during the coronavirus lockdowns worldwide.

site_title: US extends travel restrictions at Canada, Mexico land borders
summary: The US and Canada extended a 30-day ban on non-essential cross-border travel to June 22 to combat the coronavirus. The US also extended pandemic-related rules for migrants caught at the US border, which will be reviewed every 30 days. Non-essential travel has fallen by 60-70% since the restrictions were first imposed in mid-March. The decision aims to keep people safe and will be closely monitored by US health officials.

site_title: France revises down coronavirus death toll
summary: France has revised down its coronavirus death toll to 28,022, following revisions to nursing home data. The health ministry attributed the change to 342 fewer recorded deaths in nursing homes. Meanwhile, hospital deaths increased by 125 over the past 24 hours, and intensive care cases continued to fall, reaching 1,894. This marks a significant decrease from the peak of over 7,000 cases.

images.alt_text: France on Tuesday adjusted downwards its death toll for the coronavirus as a result of revisions to how fatalities are registered in nursing homes.

site_title: Oscars may be postponed due to coronavirus: report
summary: The Oscars may be postponed due to the ongoing coronavirus disruption in Hollywood. The Academy, currently scheduled for February 28, has already made significant rules changes amid the pandemic. With theatres closed, blockbusters delayed, and productions halted, a postponement is being considered. The exact decision has not been made, but the possibility of a delay is being explored.

site_title: UBS courts tycoons with view to double Russian wealth business
summary: UBS aims to double its assets under management for wealthy clients in Russia and Central and Eastern Europe, targeting high-net-worth individuals with $5-100 million in assets, over the next 4-5 years. The move comes as Western banks limited their activity in Russia after sanctions, but UBS sees opportunities with Russia's strong economic start to the year and President Putin's efforts to encourage businesses to return funds. UBS plans to expand its services through onshore and offshore teams in key locations, with a goal of becoming the most profitable franchise in eastern Europe.

site_title: Canada fines Facebook over misleading privacy claims
summary: Canada's competition watchdog fined Facebook C$9 million for making false or misleading claims about its privacy settings. An investigation found that Facebook gave Canadians the impression they could control who saw their personal information, but allowed data sharing with third-party developers. The fine is related to Facebook's practices from 2012 to 2018.

site_title: Lenovo posts 64% slump in quarterly profit, but beats expectations
summary: Lenovo reported a 64% drop in quarterly profit to US$43 million, beating analyst estimates of US$7.49 million. Revenue declined 9.7% to US$10.6 billion due to COVID-19 disruptions. Despite the slump, Lenovo attributed its strong performance to the "new normal" of working from home, which could benefit the company in the future. The company's results were seen as a positive surprise, highlighting its resilience in the face of the pandemic.

site_title: Australia to relax some domestic travel curbs
summary: Australia's New South Wales state will lift domestic travel restrictions, allowing residents to vacation within its borders starting June 1. The move comes as the state prepares to reopen tourist regions on its southern coast damaged by bushfires and the coronavirus pandemic. The state's premier, Gladys Berejiklian, emphasized the need for social distancing measures to maintain a "Covid-safe environment." The decision is part of Australia's staggered plan to unwind lockdown measures nationwide.

images.alt_text: Australians in the country's most populous state will be able to vacation within its borders next month, when art galleries and museums will also reopen, as officials seek to boost an economy hard hit by the coronavirus pandemic.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Singtel recognized a S$357 million share of Bharti Airtel's spectrum charge, valued at S$232 million post-tax. Prime US Reit appointed Harmeet Singh Bedi as its new deputy CEO and CFO. Suntec Reit launched S$200 million worth of new five-year notes with a 2.60% coupon.

site_title: China drops out of top three foreign investors in Germany
summary: China has dropped out of the top three foreign investors in Germany for the first time in over a decade, according to official German data. The US remains the largest investor, followed by Britain and Switzerland. China's drop is attributed to the Chinese government's focus on boosting domestic investments in infrastructure and research and development, regulating capital exports. The number of foreign companies moving to Germany decreased by 10% last year, but jobs planned to be created nearly doubled to 42,000, driven by foreign car and battery makers.

site_title: Empty middle seat on the plane? Depends on which country you are flying in
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has led to a patchwork of rules for air travel across countries, with varying regulations on middle seat occupancy, onboard service, and security measures. In some countries, such as Thailand and Malaysia, airlines are required to leave half the seats empty, while in the US and Europe, it's not mandatory. The lack of standardization poses challenges for the industry, with airlines and travelers adapting to different rules. Experts warn that the industry will take time to recover, with confidence and word-of-mouth experiences playing a crucial role in shaping the recovery.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Suntec Reit, SPH, Ho Bee Land, Oxley, UG Healthcare
summary: Suntec Reit launched and priced its $200 million 5-year notes at 2.6% per cent, while units rose 2.2% to $1.42. SPH announced its "resilient finances" and subsidiaries under judicial management, with no material impact on operations. Ho Bee Land reported its portfolio is "not as badly affected" by the virus. Oxley Holdings gained 2.3% after a buyer expressed interest in its Raffles Place development. UG Healthcare's production capacity increased, but shares fell 7.2% to 32 cents.

site_title: Syria central banks warns against currency 'manipulation'
summary: Syria's central bank warned against currency manipulation amid record lows against the dollar, citing a "large drop in the value of the Syrian pound" and blaming "manipulators" for exploiting the coronavirus lockdown and economic consequences. The bank will take action against institutions, companies, and individuals involved in currency manipulation and has tasked authorities to supervise money transfer and currency exchange offices. The official rate remains fixed at 700, but the black market rate has reached 1,650 to the dollar, causing economic hardship for most of Syria's population, who live in poverty.

site_title: US virus deaths projected to top 113,000 by mid-June: models
summary: The US is projected to surpass 113,000 coronavirus-related deaths by mid-June, according to a modeling average of nine institutions. As of Tuesday, the US has recorded over 1.5 million confirmed Covid-19 infections and 91,600 fatalities. The forecast is based on a 10% chance of seeing fewer than 107,000 deaths and more than 121,000. The US government has released guidelines for phased re-openings, but some states have been accused of reopening despite failing to meet the criteria, casting doubt on the nation's ability to curb the pandemic.

site_title: World Bank warns pandemic could push 60 million into extreme poverty
summary: The World Bank's president, David Malpass, warns that the coronavirus pandemic could push 60 million people into extreme poverty, erasing the gains made over the past three years. The bank anticipates a 5% contraction in the global economy and severe effects on the poorest countries. With nearly 5 million infected and 300,000 dead, the World Bank has already spent $5.5 billion on health systems and economies in poor countries. Malpass urges donor nations to step up bilateral aid to ensure a durable recovery and calls for restoring remittance payments and tourism as critical steps.

site_title: Volkswagen bosses avoid market manipulation trial with 9m euro settlement
summary: Volkswagen has settled a market manipulation trial for 9 million euros, avoiding a trial for its two top executives, Herbert Diess and Hans Dieter Poetsch, over allegations of failing to inform shareholders about the 2015 Dieselgate scandal. The executives agreed to pay 4.5 million euros each to settle the charges, with the company finding no indication of breach of duties. The settlement ends a potentially damaging case in the ongoing Dieselgate scandal, which has cost Volkswagen over 30 billion euros in fines and compensation.

site_title: Canada stores start reopening after Covid-19 lockdown
summary: Canada's 13 provinces and territories are easing lockdown restrictions, with stores with street access allowed to reopen along with hospital surgery rooms, dog parks, and golf courses. Ontario, the most populous province, is also allowing shopping malls, barbers, and farmers' markets to reopen. However, Quebec's largest city, Montreal, will not allow retailers to open until next week due to high COVID-19 cases. Shopkeepers are adjusting to new rules, including social distancing guidelines and limited customer capacity, and are concerned about the financial impact of the temporary closure.

site_title: China mulls targeting Australian wine and dairy on Covid-19 spat
summary: China is considering targeting Australian wine and dairy exports in response to Australia's calls for an investigation into the origin of COVID-19. Chinese officials have compiled a list of potential goods to be targeted, including wine, seafood, and dairy, which could be subject to stricter quality checks, tariffs, or customs delays. A final decision has not been made, but tensions between the two nations have grown, with China already slapping anti-dumping duties on Australian barley and suspending meat imports from four processing plants.

site_title: Johnson & Johnson to stop sales of talc-based baby powder in US, Canada
summary: Johnson & Johnson announced it will stop selling talc-based baby powder in the US and Canada due to declining demand and litigation advertising. The company has long denied claims the product contains cancer-causing asbestos, but will continue to sell the product in countries with higher consumer demand. Existing stocks will be sold until they run out, and the product will remain for sale in other countries. Johnson & Johnson remains "steadfastly confident" in the product's safety and will defend against lawsuits.

site_title: The dreary outlook for the 2020s has become drearier
summary: The global outlook for the 2020s has become increasingly bleak due to the COVID-19 pandemic. Economists predict a prolonged and painful recovery, with some expecting a W-shaped recession and others a more severe depression. The pandemic has exposed deep structural issues, including stagnant growth, high leverage, and declining productivity, which will take years to address. Central banks and governments face significant challenges in bridging the pandemic collapse, and protectionism and rising nationalism are likely to exacerbate the situation.

site_title: Surbana Jurong refutes allegations of profiteering in Singapore Expo job
summary: Surbana Jurong, a Temasek portfolio company, has denied allegations of profiteering in its involvement in converting the Singapore Expo venue into a community care facility during the COVID-19 pandemic. The company stated it responded to the government's call for support and provided expertise on a cost-recovery basis. It assembled a team of 50 experts and worked with partners to set up 10 halls with 8,000 beds in four weeks. Surbana Jurong said it will not hesitate to take legal action against those making scurrilous attacks against the company.

site_title: US energy capital spending to keep falling amid industry collapse: Dallas Federal Reserve
summary: US energy capital spending is expected to fall another 30% or more, according to the Dallas Federal Reserve, amid an industry collapse due to the coronavirus crisis. The decline in oil prices, triggered by a 30% drop in fuel demand, has hurt US investment spending and economic growth. US banks, however, are not overly exposed to the crisis, with most having exposure of less than 2%. The sharp reduction in capital expenditures by oil companies has significant implications for the overall economy.

site_title: Wall Street sees bull signal in bottoming earnings revisions
summary: Wall Street sees a potential bull signal as analyst estimates show a mild easing of downward revisions for S&P 500 profits, with more companies experiencing upward revisions than downward revisions in the past three weeks. This improvement suggests a potential bottom in the profit recession, which could lead to a slowdown in declines before growth turns positive early next year. The shift in analyst sentiment could also support views that investors see a trough in the profit recession, potentially supporting stock valuations despite the 40% profit contraction.

site_title: US: Stocks retreat after big Monday rally, Dow ends -1.6%
summary: US stocks retreated on Tuesday, ending the day 1.6% lower, after top economic officials warned of continued risks to the US economy. The Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped 1.6% to 24,206.86, while the S&P 500 fell 1.1% to 2,922.94. The market pullback came after a strong rally on Monday, amid concerns over how to safely revive the economy amid the ongoing Covid-19 pandemic. The White House and congressional Democrats differ on fiscal support, with the Fed's Jerome Powell hinting at potential additional measures.

images.alt_text: Wall Street stocks ended lower on Tuesday as top US economic officials warned the US economy faces continued risks, causing the market to give back some of the gains from the prior session.

site_title: Electric car sales to fall, but not as much as other vehicles
summary: Electric car sales are expected to drop 18% this year due to the coronavirus crisis, but not as much as combustion engine cars, which are forecast to decline 23%. The pandemic has disrupted sales and eroded consumer confidence, according to BloombergNEF. Despite this, electric vehicles are expected to reach 31% of the global car fleet by 2040 and account for 58% of new passenger car sales. The electrification of transport is expected to remove 17.6 million barrels of oil demand by 2040.

site_title: Will Cirque du Soleil rise again?
summary: Cirque du Soleil, the renowned Quebec circus, has been severely impacted by the COVID-19 pandemic, shutting down dozens of shows and temporarily laying off nearly 5,000 employees. The company's debt has reached nearly $1 billion, and its credit rating has been downgraded to near junk status. With no certainty on the timing of a vaccine or when cities will allow large public gatherings again, Cirque's future is uncertain. The company's chairman, Mitch Garber, and CEO, Daniel Lamarre, are considering all options, including bankruptcy protection, but remain optimistic about the company's ability to bounce back.

site_title: How Asia-Pacific taxmen are helping businesses stay afloat
summary: Asia-Pacific tax administrations have introduced supportive measures to help businesses and individuals affected by the Covid-19 pandemic. These measures include duty exemptions, tax concessions, and accelerated tax deductions for expenses related to the health crisis, economic fallout, and cashflow management. Tax authorities have also postponed tax return filings and collections, waived penalties and interest on late payments, and provided guidance on tax residency for stranded employees. These measures aim to ease the financial burden on businesses and individuals during a difficult time, with the understanding that they are temporary and will be phased out after the pandemic.

site_title: Dealing with global supply chain breaks
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has significantly impacted global supply chains, affecting raw material supply, labor availability, transportation, and retail channels. Businesses must adopt risk assessment and planning strategies to mitigate disruptions, including incorporating risk identification into business continuity plans. Experts emphasize the need for proactive measures to ensure the smooth flow of goods, particularly in key hubs like Singapore, which is crucial for the global supply chain. By doing so, businesses can minimize the impact of such disruptions and maintain a stable supply chain.

images.alt_text: Professor Shantanu Bhattacharya.

site_title: Euro rallies on Franco-German proposal for recovery fund
summary: The euro rallied on Tuesday, driven by a Franco-German proposal for a 500 billion euro recovery fund to support European Union regions and sectors hit by the COVID-19 pandemic. The euro rose to a two-week high of $1.0976 and last bought $1.0952, with the dollar losing its safe-haven appeal after vaccine trial results boosted riskier assets. The euro's cost of betting against it fell to the lowest since mid-March, but traders still requested a premium for put options, indicating bearish bets on the common currency.

site_title: US crude strengthens as certain stimulus measures to continue
summary: US crude strengthened 68 cents a barrel, or 2.1%, to $32.50, after Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin expressed support for extending stimulus measures to bolster the economy. Despite concerns about insufficient output cuts, oil prices have rallied following easing of restrictions worldwide. Benchmark Brent crude fell 16 cents to $34.65, as demand recovery is expected to be slow due to a global recession and potential spikes in illness in emerging markets.

site_title: Delayed reopening for retail, F&B: New help package on the way
summary: Singapore's multi-ministry taskforce announced the lifting of circuit-breaker measures in phases. Manufacturing and professional services will reopen on June 2, followed by retail, F&B dining-in, and small social activities. Working-from-home will continue. Preschools and schools will reopen with special arrangements, and visits to certain family members will be allowed with restrictions. A new help package for firms and individuals will be unveiled next week.

images.alt_text: Mantufacturing and professional-services workplaces are among those allowed to re-open under the first phase of the lifting of circuit-breaker measures on June 2, even as another package of support for firms and individuals will be unveiled next week.

site_title: LCH clears first Sing-dollar interest rate swaps referencing SORA
summary: Global clearing house LCH has cleared the first Sing-dollar interest rate swaps referencing the Singapore Overnight Rate Average (SORA), marking a significant milestone in Singapore's transition away from the Sing-dollar Swap Offer Rate (SOR). The swap was cleared between Standard Chartered and OCBC, with LCH's central clearing expected to deepen liquidity in SORA derivatives and catalyze the growth of the SORA market. This move aims to mitigate counterparty credit risks and operational savings for market participants, ultimately solidifying SORA's role as the replacement benchmark for SOR.

site_title: Workplace design majors join hands
summary: Singapore-based Space Matrix and US-based Interior Architects (IA) have formed a strategic partnership to provide workplace design services to their global client base. The partnership creates a "global studio" connecting over 1,400 staff across 37 locations, serving clients in over 500 cities in 60 countries. With combined revenue of US$125.49 million, the firms now rank second in the office design sector globally, after Gensler. The partnership aims to address the industry's need for a true global partner offering services, design thinking, and advice to clients worldwide.

site_title: Universal Resource seeks legal advice on irregularities in special audit report
summary: Universal Resource and Services is seeking legal advice following irregularities in a special audit report of its Chinese subsidiary, Sky Petroleum Technology Development (Tianjin). The report found material discrepancies in the company's bank statements, questionable corporate governance practices, and poor accounting practices. The company's board views the potential breaches of laws and/or listing manual rules as serious and is pursuing civil actions to recover losses. The Singapore Exchange Regulation (SGX RegCo) is also reviewing the findings.

site_title: UG Healthcare facilities operating at 'optimum production efficiency'
summary: UG Healthcare Corporation, a Singapore-based manufacturer of disposable gloves, reported its facilities are operating at "optimum production efficiency" with a capacity of 2.9 billion gloves per annum. The company faces increasing demand for gloves and healthcare products, with plans to add 300 million gloves in FY2021 and further expansion to be announced. UG Healthcare remains committed to building long-term business relationships with customers while prioritizing employee and community safety amid the COVID-19 pandemic.

site_title: Privacy: A casualty of the virus?
summary: Governments worldwide have implemented health monitoring policies during the Covid-19 pandemic, leveraging personal device data to contain the virus. While these measures aim to address the crisis, concerns over permanent surveillance infrastructure and impact on privacy have grown. Countries like China, Israel, and Singapore have implemented sophisticated monitoring systems, including facial recognition and smartphone data tracking. Critics argue that these policies set a dangerous precedent, while proponents see them as necessary measures to prevent future pandemics. The long-term implications of these policies on individual freedoms and society remain uncertain.

site_title: Shanghai Pudong Development Bank partners % Arabica to donate fresh brews
summary: Shanghai Pudong Development Bank (SPD) in Singapore partnered with coffee retailer % Arabica to donate 270 cups of fresh coffee to healthcare workers battling the Covid-19 pandemic. The medical professionals will receive a cup of coffee every Monday and Wednesday from May 18 to June 1. This is the bank's second donation drive in a month, following the delivery of 5,000 curry puffs to migrant workers on May 7. The initiative aims to appreciate and encourage healthcare workers during the pandemic.

site_title: Financial institutions allowed more on-site staff from June 2: MAS
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) announced that financial institutions will be allowed to reopen more customer-service locations on June 2, with more onsite staff to meet increased customer needs. FIs must implement strict safe-management measures, including staggered start times and flexible work hours, to ensure safe distancing. Customer-service locations for insurance, fund managers, and brokers will reopen, while FIs providing financial advice will be permitted to have in-person meetings with customers with MAS approval. The regulator will conduct onsite inspections to ensure compliance with safe-management requirements.

site_title: Ho Bee Land credits 'strategic' portfolio for cushion against Covid-19 impact
summary: Ho Bee Land, a Singapore-based developer, attributes its resilience to its "strategic and resilient portfolio" during the COVID-19 pandemic. The company reported it is "not as badly affected" as other firms, thanks to its diversified investments. Its annual general meeting responses, submitted to the Singapore Exchange, acknowledged the challenges but emphasized the firm's preparedness. This suggests Ho Bee Land's management has effectively navigated the pandemic's economic impact.

site_title: Julius Baer enjoys rare trading boom to lift profitability
summary: Switzerland's third-largest wealth manager, Julius Baer, reported a rare trading boom, lifting its profitability to the highest level in four years. The company's gross margin rose to 95 basis points, driven by an exceptional increase in trading volumes in the first four months. Wealthy clients sought to limit damage from the coronavirus, boosting assets under management to 392 billion Swiss francs. Despite this, the bank cautioned it cannot predict the impact of the coronavirus on its profit for the rest of the year, and shares jumped 9.6% in Zurich trading.

site_title: Money FM podcast: Covid-19 innovations in healthcare
summary: Singapore General Hospital's Dr Hairil Rizal Abdullah discusses COVID-19 innovations in healthcare equipment, including advancements in ventilation systems, telemedicine, and medical robots. These innovations have improved patient care and reduced the risk of transmission. The hospital has also implemented AI-powered systems to enhance diagnosis and treatment. The conversation highlights the significant impact of the pandemic on healthcare and the need for continued innovation to address emerging challenges.

site_title: Uber's closure of Asia-Pacific HQ in Singapore to impact 120 staff
summary: Uber will close its Asia-Pacific headquarters in Singapore, affecting 120 staff, as part of a global restructuring plan. The company will also lay off 3,000 more employees worldwide and cut investments unrelated to its core ride-hailing and delivery businesses. This move follows the company's previous layoffs in May, resulting in a global headcount reduction of about a quarter. Uber plans to provide severance packages, including 10 weeks' pay and health benefits, to affected employees.

images.alt_text: Uber launched its Asia-Pacific hub in Frasers Tower in April last year to support its operational markets in the region. It exited the Singapore market in mid 2018 following the acquisition of its South-east Asian operations by rival Grab.

site_title: Hong Kong's unemployment rate rises to highest since 2009
summary: Hong Kong's unemployment rate surged to 5.2% in the February-to-April period, the highest since 2009, amid the coronavirus pandemic and recession. The underemployment rate jumped to 3.1%, with joblessness in the consumption and tourism sectors reaching 9% and the food and beverage industry hitting 12%. The economy contracted 8.9% in the first quarter, and retailers are struggling, with one in four shops at risk of closure by December. The government has introduced virus-related aid, but economists warn of continued pressure on the labor market.

site_title: Powell says Fed has America's back with Congress arguing aid
summary: Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell stated the central bank is prepared to utilize all tools to support the US economy during the coronavirus pandemic. He acknowledged the need for more fiscal aid, saying the Fed is willing to go further if needed. The Fed has launched unprecedented support since mid-March, including slashing interest rates to near zero and unveiling emergency lending programs. Powell expects four remaining programs to be launched by the end of the month, amid ongoing debates between Republicans and Democrats over additional fiscal stimulus.

site_title: More than 15,000 Hong Kong shops may close without rent relief
summary: Hong Kong retailers face a bleak future with over 15,000 shops predicted to close by December unless landlords offer more rent relief. Chairman of the Hong Kong Retail Management Association, Annie Yau Tse, states that current rent reductions are insufficient. This could lead to a loss of one in four shops, ending Hong Kong's reputation as a shopping paradise.

site_title: AEM, UTAC to co-develop new test systems for image sensor chips
summary: AEM Holdings and UTAC Holdings have announced a collaboration to develop cost-effective test systems for CMOS image sensor products, expected to grow significantly in the security, automotive, and industrial fields. The partnership aims to provide scalable and adaptable solutions for semiconductor companies. AEM president Chandran Nair stated that the collaboration sets the foundation for increased cooperation and future growth for both companies. The move follows AEM's first-quarter net profit of S$36.1 million, driven by increased demand for semiconductor chips during the coronavirus-driven shift to telecommuting and virtual learning.

site_title: Logos, CSC Holdings to redevelop Jurong warehouse for S$108m
summary: Logos, an Australian logistics property specialist, is partnering with Singapore Mainboard-listed CSC Holdings Limited to redevelop a site at Tanjong Penjuru Crescent into a six-storey warehouse for S$108 million, part of Logos' Singapore Logistics Venture 2.

site_title: Hong Kong looks to speed up IPOs to boost liquidity, cut risk
summary: Hong Kong's stock exchange, HKEX, is considering speeding up the IPO process from 5 days to bring it in line with rival bourses. The move aims to boost liquidity and cut risk. HKEX will formally consult the market if there are no major objections. This proposal follows a review of the IPO settlement cycle.

site_title: Go big with economic push to fight Covid-19
summary: Economic policymakers must take bold and immediate action to mitigate the economic fallout from the Covid-19 outbreak. Governments worldwide should focus on extraordinary fiscal and monetary measures to provide critical short-term support to people and businesses. The US has gone big with its response, passing over $2 trillion in legislation, while Asian governments have been more restrained, with China announcing targeted fiscal support. Experts emphasize the need for global policy coordination and focus on addressing the immediate crisis, as well as investing in structural changes and sustainable solutions to prepare for the post-Covid-19 world.

site_title: More wage and rent support needed as most retailers stay closed, F&B firms still restricted
summary: Singapore's retail and food and beverage sectors will require more wage support as they remain closed and restricted, respectively. Most retailers will stay closed and dining-in will remain prohibited at F&B establishments until the Covid-19 situation stabilizes. The government will announce further support on May 26, including the extension of the 75% wage subsidy, which is crucial for businesses' survival. Industry associations also call for increased support, foreign worker levy rebates, and rental waivers to mitigate supply chain disruptions and demand declines.

images.alt_text: The Restaurant Association of Singapore said F&B players' survival will largely depend on whether the current 75% wage subsidy given to all firms is extended.

site_title: Thai PM vows to restructure Thai Airways
summary: Thai Prime Minister Prayut Chan-O-Cha has announced plans to restructure Thai Airways, citing the need to prevent the airline from going bankrupt and affecting over 20,000 lives. The airline, 51% owned by the government, has registered losses of almost $800 million over the past three years due to the global aviation crisis. Instead of bankruptcy, Thai Airways will submit a rehabilitation plan, allowing it to set out a debt restructuring plan, according to the government. The airline has not been provided with financial support by the government.

site_title: Europe: Banks, telecoms drag stocks lower after recent rally
summary: European stocks declined 0.6% on Tuesday, driven by falls in euro zone banks and telecoms stocks, despite optimism over a potential EU recovery fund. The Stoxx 600, which had risen 0.5% earlier, shed gains to close lower, following a strong session on Monday. Telecoms stocks, including Telecom Italia, fell 8.6%, while banks in Spain and Italy declined 2.5% and 2.1%, respectively. Optimism over the EU recovery fund and easing lockdowns had driven the Stoxx 600 to a 26% rebound from its lows earlier this year.

images.alt_text: European shares lost some ground on Tuesday after a rally in the previous session, as falls for euro zone banks and telecoms stocks countered optimism from a stimulus plan for the European Union.

site_title: Tribal loyalties versus medical concerns in US
summary: US politicians are increasingly at odds over healthcare policy during the coronavirus crisis, devolving into ugly political warfare. Tribal loyalties have replaced concerns for public health, with some Americans questioning the motivations of policymakers and experts. The divide has intensified, with Republicans accusing Democrats of prioritizing elections over public health and vice versa. The COVID-19 pandemic has exposed deep divisions in the US, with some embracing conspiracy theories and others criticizing the administration's handling of the crisis. The polarization has led to violent protests and accusations of elitism, with tribal loyalties seemingly overriding medical concerns.

site_title: Two As for the Covid-hit company: adapt quickly and announce more
summary: Singaporean companies are adapting to the COVID-19 pandemic by announcing more and moving quickly to assure customers and investors. This includes companies like Riverstone Holdings, which added a mask production line, and Sheng Siong Group, which diversified its sourcing and held a higher inventory level. In contrast, companies like Netlink NBN Trust suspended services due to limited workforce availability. A recent study found that companies with positive sentiment on labor, supply chain, and operating response to the crisis had higher institutional money flows and less negative returns.

site_title: Co-living operators upbeat as they look to demand from new segments
summary: Singapore's co-living operators remain optimistic despite the COVID-19 pandemic, with some reporting high occupancy rates and long-term leases. The industry is tapping into a growing demographic of young and mobile individuals seeking hassle-free affordable housing. Co-living leases start from three months, come fully furnished, and include utilities and cleaning. Occupancy rates are over 90% for some operators, with average leases of 10-12 months. The pandemic has even benefited the industry, with people seeking alternative accommodation options due to salary cuts or job losses.

site_title: Suntec Reit to issue S$200m 2.60% notes
summary: Suntec Reit has issued S$200 million worth of new 5-year notes with a 2.60% coupon, set to mature on May 27, 2025. The net proceeds will be used for acquisitions, asset enhancement, and general corporate purposes. The notes will be listed on the Singapore Exchange and are backed by Suntec Reit's trustee. The issue price is 100% of the principal amount, with units of Suntec Reit rising 2.2% to S$1.42 on the news.

site_title: Coronavirus reveals UK supply chain weaknesses
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the UK's supply chain weaknesses, with 82% of small- and medium-sized manufacturers saying the pandemic has affected their supply chains. The UK's impending Brexit, which triggers a massive shake-up of trading relationships in seven months, is exacerbating the issue. The government's struggles to fly in emergency supplies from abroad while UK factories were shuttered have raised concerns about the country's reliance on overseas supply chains. Some businesses are now calling for a "reshoring" of supply chains, bringing production back onto British soil, as a way to mitigate future disruptions.

site_title: EuroCham Singapore and partners to give free meals, mental-health checks to F&B staff
summary: International wine and spirits companies, including Bacardi and Moët-Hennessy Diageo, have launched the Together In Spirits campaign to support F&B staff in Singapore during the city's circuit breaker. The campaign provides free meals and mental health consultations to employees through partnerships with EuroCham Singapore and Montfort Care. The initiative aims to ease the financial and mental burden on F&B front-liners, with free meals available for two weeks and mental health consultations until the end of July.

site_title: Exxon revives sale of stake in giant Azeri oilfield
summary: ExxonMobil has relaunched the sale of its 6.8% stake in Azerbaijan's largest oilfield, the Azeri-Chirag-Gunashli (ACG) field, after initially putting the process on hold in 2018. The sale, run by Bank of America Merrill Lynch, is attracting interest from Asian oil and gas companies seeking to capitalize on the recent collapse in oil prices. Several Asian national oil companies, including CNOOC, ONGC, and Pertamina, have shown interest in the stake, which is likely to be valued significantly lower than Chevron's 9.57% stake sold in 2018.

images.alt_text: Exxon Mobil has relaunched the sale of its stake in Azerbaijan's largest oilfield, the company said on Tuesday, as banking and industry sources said the move was drawing interest from large Asian oil and gas companies seeking to capitalise on the recent collapse in oil prices.

site_title: US: Wall St opens lower after strong start to the week
summary: US stocks opened lower on Tuesday, following the S&P 500's best day in six weeks. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.08% to 24,577.48, while the S&P 500 dropped 0.18% to 2,948.59 and the Nasdaq Composite fell 0.08% to 9,227.46. Investors booked profits after the previous day's gains, which saw the S&P 500 reach its best level in six weeks.

site_title: SPH to weather Covid-19 crisis, will benefit from investment in data collection
summary: Singapore Press Holdings (SPH) reported resilient finances amid the Covid-19 crisis, with a disciplined approach to capital allocation and regular reviews of non-core businesses. Its media, student accommodation, and retail businesses are well-placed, and the company is investing in first-party data collection to deliver an enjoyable digital experience. With more browsers blocking third-party cookies, SPH stands to benefit from advertisers seeking publishers with first-party data. The company's subsidiaries, StreetSine Technology Group and StreetSine Singapore, have applied for judicial management but are expected to have no material impact on operations for FY2020.

site_title: Recent failures of commodities traders bear watching
summary: Singapore's commodities trading hub is facing scrutiny after recent failures, including the collapse of Hin Leong Trading, which has exposed over 20 banks to a $4 billion debt pile. The trader hid $800 million losses from financial statements and sold collateralized cargoes. Similar cases, such as Agritrade International and Hontop Energy, have also been reported. These incidents raise concerns about weak business practices in the industry and the need for regulatory oversight to protect the city state's reputation as a business hub.

site_title: Shaping the new normal for Asia grocery retail
summary: Asian grocery retailers are accelerating into the recovery phase from the COVID-19 pandemic, but with uncertainty and challenges. Executives must balance operational recovery with safety focus, leveraging trends such as e-commerce growth, private-label products, and digital marketing. To succeed, grocers must streamline product ranges, reduce promotions, and adapt their physical store networks. The sector is expected to experience consolidation, and executives must prepare for bold moves and potential investor activism.

site_title: Powell says Fed has America's back while Congress argues aid
summary: US Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell said the central bank is ready to use all necessary tools to support the US economy during the COVID-19 pandemic. He appeared before the Senate Banking Committee to discuss the first quarterly Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security (CARES) Act report. Lawmakers are debating additional fiscal aid, with Republicans and Democrats disagreeing on scale and timing. Powell stated that four of the nine emergency lending programmes launched by the Fed are expected to be launched by the end of the month, and the Fed is working to stabilize access to financing.

site_title: SPH to weather Covid-19 crisis, to benefit from investment in data collection
summary: SPH, the owner of The Business Times, reported resilient finances despite the Covid-19 crisis, with a strong balance sheet and over S$800 million in cash. Its media segment saw a 8% growth in digital subscriptions, while its PBSA business achieved 69% of its target revenue. The company is investing in first-party data collection to deliver a better digital experience and capitalize on advertisers seeking alternative data sources. With no loans due until June 2021, SPH's "disciplined approach" to capital allocation is expected to withstand the pandemic's impact.

site_title: UK announces plan for sweeping tariff cuts after Brexit
summary: The UK has announced a plan to cut import duties on many products, with £30 billion worth of tariffs to be removed on supply chain imports, starting January 1, 2021. The plan, which replaces the EU's common external tariff, will make 60% of trade tariff-free, up from 47%. The UK will maintain tariffs on cars and agricultural products, but cut duties on renewable energy items. The move is aimed at benefiting UK consumers and households, while protecting industries such as automotive and agriculture.

site_title: US housing starts fall sharply in April
summary: US homebuilding plummeted 30.2% to a 5-year low of 891,000 units in April, according to the Commerce Department. This marks the lowest level since early 2015. Economists had forecast a decline to 927,000 units. Housing starts dropped 29.7% year-over-year, with all four regions experiencing a decline. The sharp fall underscores fears of a deep economic contraction in the second quarter, rivaling the Great Depression.

images.alt_text: US homebuilding dropped to a five-year low in April, underlining fears that the novel coronavirus crisis would lead to the deepest economic contraction in the second quarter since the Great Depression.

site_title: Abattoirs could be coronavirus factories, experts warn
summary: Coronavirus clusters are multiplying in slaughterhouses worldwide, prompting health experts to call for better virus monitoring to prevent further infection. At least 5,000 meat and poultry workers in the US have contracted the virus, with four managers dying from COVID-19 due to inadequate social distancing measures.
