Other countries, including Germany, France, Australia, Spain, and Brazil, are also experiencing outbreaks. Experts attribute the spread to overcrowded conditions and strenuous physical work, but there is no evidence that meat can be infected with COVID-19.

site_title: Mnuchin expects large Q2 unemployment, negative economic data
summary: US Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin expects large Q2 unemployment and negative economic data, but notes that the economy is expected to improve as it reopens. He warned that prolonged lockdowns due to the Covid-19 pandemic risk causing "permanent damage." Mnuchin emphasized the need to balance worker and customer safety, stating that the US is beginning to open the economy in a way that minimizes risks.

site_title: Cyber attack on easyJet gets details of 9 million customers
summary: A cyber attack on British airline easyJet accessed the email and travel details of around 9 million customers, as well as the credit card details of over 2,000, in a late January incident. The airline has notified affected customers and advises them to be vigilant for online scams. EasyJet suspects a group of suspected Chinese hackers are behind the attack, which is believed to be part of a series aimed at bulk theft of travel records. The incident may lead to a hefty fine for the airline.

site_title: WHO states agree to independent probe of coronavirus response
summary: World Health Organization (WHO) member states agreed to an independent probe into the agency's coronavirus response amid US criticism. The probe aims to investigate the handling of the pandemic and the origins of the virus. Countries also adopted a resolution urging equitable access to COVID-19 treatments and vaccines, and a joint international response to the crisis. This move comes as the pandemic continues to impact global economies and public health.

site_title: India resumes purchases of Malaysian palm oil: traders
summary: India has resumed purchases of Malaysian palm oil after a four-month gap due to a diplomatic row, with buyers taking advantage of discounted prices and low domestic inventories. The renewed buying is driven by improving trade relations between the two countries and a record deal to buy 100,000 tonnes of Indian rice from Malaysia. Indian imports of palm oil fell by over 50% in the first four months of 2020, and the resumption of buying could further support Malaysian palm oil prices.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed higher on Tuesday, rising 13.81 points to 1,423.97. The index saw 9.415 billion lots traded worth RM4.612 billion, with losers outnumbering gainers 554 to 500.

site_title: DPM Heng to deliver ministerial statement on Covid-19 support measures on May 26
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat will deliver a ministerial statement on Covid-19 support measures in Parliament on May 26, outlining the fourth round of support measures since February. The statement will be published on the Singapore Budget website and covered live on television and radio. The announcement is aimed at helping businesses and individuals adapt and build resilience during the pandemic.

site_title: Hong Kong extends gathering ban to Tiananmen anniversary
summary: Hong Kong has extended its anti-virus gathering ban until June 4, likely preventing the annual Tiananmen anniversary vigil from taking place for the first time in 30 years. The ban, which restricts gatherings of more than eight people, was extended on a 14-day basis, with authorities citing public health concerns. The vigil, which commemorates the 1989 crackdown, has been held annually in Victoria Park since 1990, but its cancellation would be a significant blow to Hong Kong's pro-democracy movement.

site_title: European auto market hit by record sales plunge
summary: The European auto market suffered a record 76.3% drop in new car registrations in April, the first full month with COVID-19 restrictions. This represents the strongest monthly decline since records began. The decline is expected to continue, with the market likely to fall by more than a third this year. Italy and Spain were hit the hardest, with drops of 97.6% and 96.5%, respectively. Analysts predict a deep crisis, comparable to the 2008-2009 recession, with a potential market drop of 22% this year.

site_title: SPH subsidiaries seek judicial management
summary: Singapore Press Holdings (SPH) subsidiaries StreetSine Technology Group and StreetSine Singapore have applied for judicial management, citing a legal dispute with shareholders Samuel Cranage Baker and Jeremy Lee Chuen Yang. Despite being significant shareholders, the subsidiaries' combined net liabilities and losses are less than 1% of SPH's net assets and profits. The judicial management applications are expected to have a minimal impact on SPH's operations. A pre-trial conference is scheduled for June 4, with a hearing date yet to be determined.

site_title: Michelin refuses to put away knife as guides rally round restaurants
summary: The Michelin guide is refusing to put away its knives, continuing to rank and rate restaurants despite coronavirus lockdowns. New director Gwendal Poullennec claims great chefs have not lost their talent during the lockdowns, citing innovation and new recipe creation. Inspectors are eager to try out new dishes when restaurants reopen. The move has sparked debate among other top gastronomic guides, with some considering whether to continue ranking restaurants with closed locations.

site_title: Manufacturing, professional services among first sectors to re-open; new support package next week
summary: Singapore is set to re-open manufacturing, professional services, and some healthcare services on June 2, with "maximum work-from-home arrangements" in place. Preschools will re-open in stages, and schools will resume with special arrangements. Limited visits to family members will be allowed, but with restrictions. The government has announced a new support package for firms next week, while those unable to re-open will receive support. The goal is to resume normal operations and eventually transition to a "new normal" with more economic and social activities.

site_title: Universal Resource seeks legal advice on irregularities in special audit report
summary: Universal Resource and Services is seeking legal advice after a special audit report revealed material discrepancies in its Chinese subsidiary Sky Petroleum Technology Development (Tianjin)'s bank statements. The audit report also highlighted questionable corporate governance practices and poor accounting practices. The company's board has taken a serious view of the potential breaches of laws and/or listing manual rules, and has submitted the report to regulatory authorities. The company plans to pursue losses against wrongdoers, including commencing civil actions.

site_title: Singapore shares close 1.7% higher
summary: The Singapore bourse rose 1.66% on Tuesday, with the Straits Times Index jumping 42.05 points to 2,581.33. The gains were driven by vaccine hopes and Wall Street's overnight rally. Analysts noted that while geopolitical tensions and a small vaccine trial sample size may pose risks, the market's optimism is unfolding as more economies ease restrictions. Key performers included DBS, UOB, and OCBC, with Yoma Strategic and Perennial Real Estate Holdings also gaining.

site_title: GuocoLand obtains S$730m green loan for Tan Quee Lan project
summary: GuocoLand has secured a S$730 million green club loan from OCBC Bank, DBS Bank, and ICBC Singapore Branch for its luxury residential cum commercial development at Tan Quee Lan Street. The project aims to achieve Green Mark Gold Plus certification and will feature sustainable development, water and energy conservation, and immersive urban greenery. This is GuocoLand's first green loan and the largest for a development project, with proceeds financing the project's sustainable features.

site_title: Hong Kong's jobless rate highest in over a decade at 5.2%
summary: Hong Kong's unemployment rate surged to 5.2% in the February-April period, the highest in over a decade, due to the coronavirus crisis and a recession stemming from last year's anti-government protests. Total employment fell by 62,600 to 3.657 million, with the underemployment rate reaching 3.1%, its highest in 15 years. The economy suffered its worst contraction on record, with visitor arrivals near zero and retail stores expected to close by the end of the year. The labour market is expected to face "immense pressure" in the near term.

site_title: Ho Bee Land credits 'strategic' portfolio for cushion against Covid-19 impact
summary: Ho Bee Land, a MAINBOARD-LISTED developer, reported that its strategic and resilient portfolio helped cushion the impact of the Covid-19 crisis. The company's investment portfolio is concentrated in the office sector, which is more resilient than the hospitality and retail sectors. Despite rental rebates, Ho Bee Land's fully leased offices in Singapore and London, along with its recurrent income, will mitigate the crisis. The company is in a better position to seize investment and development opportunities during a crisis, with shares closing at S$2.13, up 0.95%.

site_title: Financial institutions allowed more onsite staff from June 2: MAS
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) announced that financial institutions (FIs) will be allowed to reopen more customer-service locations on June 2, with more onsite staff to meet increased customer needs. FIs must implement strict safe-management measures, including staggered start times and flexible work hours, to maintain safe distancing. Customer-service locations for insurance companies, fund managers, and brokers will reopen, as well as money changing services. FIs providing financial advice will be permitted to have in-person meetings with customers with MAS approval.

site_title: UG Healthcare facilities operating at 'optimum production efficiency'
summary: UG Healthcare Corporation, a manufacturer of disposable gloves, reported operating at "optimum production efficiency" with a capacity of 2.9 billion gloves per annum. The company plans to add 300 million gloves annually by 2021 and will announce further expansion plans. Despite the COVID-19 pandemic, UG Healthcare has seen increasing demand for gloves and healthcare products, leading to higher average selling prices. The company remains committed to building long-term relationships with customers and has implemented precautionary measures to prevent virus transmission in its facilities.

site_title: WeWork India lays off 20% of workforce as virus lockdowns weigh
summary: WeWork India laid off 100 employees, or 20% of its workforce, due to the prolonged nationwide lockdown caused by the coronavirus pandemic. This move follows other Indian startups, such as Zomato and Swiggy, that have also cut costs and revamped their operations. WeWork aims to be profitable by early 2021, with its CEO stating that the company has optimised its team strength based on its core business strategy. Softbank Group has invested over $13.5 billion in WeWork.

site_title: China mulls targeting Australian wine and dairy on coronavirus spat
summary: China is considering targeting Australian wine and dairy exports in retaliation for Canberra's calls for an investigation into the origin of COVID-19. Chinese officials have compiled a list of potential goods to target, including wine, seafood, oatmeal, and dairy, with measures such as stricter quality checks, tariffs, and customs delays. A final decision has not been made, but tensions between the two nations have grown, with China already slapping anti-dumping duties on Australian barley and suspending meat imports.

site_title: China offers farmers cash to give up wildlife trade
summary: China is offering cash incentives to farmers to stop breeding exotic animals, amid pressure to curb the illegal wildlife trade blamed for the coronavirus outbreak. The government has pledged to buy out breeders in two central provinces, Hunan and Jiangxi, with compensation schemes in place to persuade farmers to transition to alternative livelihoods. The schemes, announced for the first time, offer varying prices for different animals, including up to 600 yuan for a civet cat. Animal rights activists say the move is a step in the right direction, but caution that more needs to be done to phase out the practice.

site_title: Seoul: Shares post highest close since early March on vaccine hopes
summary: South Korean shares rose 2.25% to a 10-month high, closing at 1,980.61, after a potential coronavirus vaccine showed promising early-stage trial results. This lifted hopes for a quicker economic recovery. The move follows Wall Street's S&P 500 index reaching a 10-week high on Monday.

site_title: Thinking of buying a bike? Get ready for a very long wait
summary: The US is experiencing a severe bicycle shortage due to the coronavirus pandemic, with nationwide sales of bicycles and equipment nearly doubling compared to last year. Many stores have sold out of low-end consumer bikes, and global supply chains are struggling to meet the surge in demand. Bike sales are expected to continue, with some US cities planning to permanently transform their infrastructure to prioritize cycling. The pandemic may permanently shift the role of bicycles from a recreational activity to a safer alternative to public transit, with cycling expected to become more essential in the coming months.

site_title: Zoom suspends new free user registrations in China
summary: Zoom has suspended new free user registrations in mainland China, limiting them to enterprise customers only. Existing free users can still join meetings hosted by registered customers. This move comes as the company experiences significant growth in use globally, driven by coronavirus-fuelled lockdowns. The decision aims to restrict the spread of its platform in a country with strict internet regulations.

site_title: Ovo Energy plans to cut 2,600 workers as online replaces human jobs
summary: Ovo Energy plans to cut 2,600 staff due to a shift in customer behavior, with over 1 million online transactions recorded since the lockdown began. The company aims to integrate its acquisition of SSE Energy Services, which has accelerated the need for changes. The redundancy application program is voluntary, but Ovo CEO Stephen Fitzpatrick states that customers who engage with the company digitally rarely return to human interaction. Energy demand has not decreased despite the lockdown.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Uber to close its Asia-Pacific HQ in Singapore, lay off 3,000 people, and stop non-core investments. AEM and UTAC announced a partnership to develop test systems for CMOS image sensor products, which are expected to grow due to demand from various industries. GuocoLand secured a S$730m green loan for its Tan Quee Lan development project. LCH cleared the first SORA derivatives trade, while Surbana Jurong clarified its involvement in setting up a Singapore Expo care facility. The Straits Times Index rose 1.7% to 2,581.33.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares end with strong gains
summary: Hong Kong shares rose 1.89% on Tuesday, driven by easing lockdown restrictions and hopes for a coronavirus vaccine. The Hang Seng Index reached 24,388.13, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also saw gains. These gains were largely overshadowed by market concerns over US-EU trade tensions and tariff threats.

site_title: Australia: Shares end at over 2-month high on economic recovery hopes
summary: Australian shares reached a two-month high on May 19, 2020, closing 1.81% higher at 5,559.5, driven by gains in mining, energy, and financial stocks. Rising commodity prices and hopes of a demand recovery for commodities fueled the rally, with firmer Chinese iron ore futures contributing to miner gains. The optimism was also boosted by a robust Wall Street performance overnight, but analysts noted that underlying economic conditions in the US remain dire.

site_title: Companies fear protracted slump: World Economic Forum
summary: Companies are concerned about a prolonged global slump and surge in bankruptcies due to the coronavirus pandemic. A World Economic Forum report found that recessions on a scale not seen since the 1930s Great Depression require urgent action from governments to ensure a timely recovery. The survey of 347 company risk managers identified extended downturns, industry consolidation, and high youth unemployment as major concerns. The report also warned that debt from rescue packages could depress finances and hinder efforts to combat climate change.

site_title: UK announces new post-Brexit global tariff regime
summary: The UK has announced a new post-Brexit tariff regime, replacing the EU's external tariff, with a 10% tariff on cars but cutting levies on tens of billions of dollars of supply chain imports. The new UK Global Tariff aims to simplify trade policy and reduce costs, with 60% of trade entering the UK tariff-free. Tariffs will be eliminated on products supporting energy efficiency, and a temporary zero tariff will be introduced for COVID-19-related goods. The move marks a departure from the EU's complex tariff system and aims to secure free trade agreements with countries worldwide by 2022.

site_title: Yukos shareholders seize Russia vodka assets in the Netherlands
summary: Shareholders of defunct Russian oil giant Yukos have seized Netherlands-based assets of two vodka brands, Stolichnaya and Moskovskaya, controlled by the Russian state, in a move to obtain US$57 billion in damages from Moscow. A Dutch appeals court overturned a US$50 billion award to Yukos shareholders in 2020, and Russia's Justice Ministry has lodged an appeal to contest the decision. The seizure took place via a Dutch court on May 7, with the Russian state informed last week.

site_title: Thai govt approves bankruptcy plan for Thai Airways
summary: Thailand's Cabinet approved a plan to restructure Thai Airways International's finances through a bankruptcy court, replacing a government-funded rescue package. The airline has posted losses every year since 2012, except in 2016, with a reported loss of $377.3 million in 2019. The restructuring plan will be implemented through the Central Bankruptcy Court and Thai Airways will continue to operate, with operations including passenger and cargo transportation continuing in parallel. The airline's workers will also retain their jobs.

site_title: Singapore sorry for sending positive coronavirus test results in error
summary: Singapore has apologized to 357 Covid-19 patients who received an error text message saying they had tested positive again. The error was due to an IT system testing glitch. The patients had previously been confirmed negative and discharged. The health ministry acknowledged the mistake and alerted recipients within hours. Singapore has confirmed over 28,000 cases and 22 deaths, and is under lockdown until June 1.

site_title: Prime US Reit manager appoints Harmeet Singh Bedi as deputy CEO, CFO
summary: Prime US Reit has appointed Harmeet Singh Bedi as its new deputy CEO and CFO, effective within a few weeks. Bedi, with 29 years of investment and commercial banking experience, will oversee finance and investor relations functions. His appointment is seen as a valuable addition to the team, given his extensive experience in capital market and investment strategies. The Reit's manager has stated that the board and nominating and remuneration committee will monitor Bedi's double-hatting arrangement annually.

site_title: Julius Baer says 2020 profit unpredictable after trading boost
summary: Julius Baer, Switzerland's third-largest wealth manager, reported a boost in client trading, lifting profitability in the first four months of 2020. Gross margin rose to 95 basis points, driven by rising transaction fees. Despite a 2% growth in net new money, assets under management declined 8% to 392 billion Swiss francs due to negative market performance and the franc's strength. The bank cannot predict the impact of the coronavirus on profit for the rest of the year. CEO Philipp Rickenbacher plans to eliminate 300 jobs and boost profit while assets grow more slowly.

site_title: UK jobless claims jump by 856,000 to 2.1 million in April
summary: The UK unemployment claims rose by 856,500 to 2.097 million in April, the first full month of the coronavirus lockdown. This represents a significant jump, exceeding economists' median forecast of 676,500. The unemployment rate, however, fell to 3.9% in the January-March period, down from 4.0% in the preceding months. This data adds to concerns about the UK economy, which has shrunk for a second consecutive month.

site_title: French Connection says could run out of cash within months
summary: French Connection Group Plc, a British retailer, warned it could run out of cash within months due to the COVID-19 pandemic's impact on its business. The company abandoned plans to sell the business after a year-long review and is in talks with potential partners for new funding. French Connection aims to cut costs and reopen stores in an orderly manner from June, with online sales increasing by 44% over the last 6 weeks. The retailer has struggled to differentiate itself from competitors, but sees a small increase in activity in Europe as countries reopen.

site_title: 451 new Covid-19 cases in Singapore, taking total to 28,794
summary: Singapore reported 451 new Covid-19 cases, bringing the total to 28,794. The number of cases among Singaporeans and permanent residents has reached its lowest level since the circuit breaker measures began, with 10 patients in ICU. 10,356 patients have recovered, and 530 have been discharged. The remaining 450 new cases are foreign workers living in dormitories, with 26,541 migrant workers testing positive. The Covid-19 situation in Singapore appears to be stabilizing, with the number of new cases exceeding discharges for the first time in seven days.

site_title: US overtakes China as most attractive country for renewables investment: research
summary: The US has overtaken China as the most attractive country for renewables investment, according to an annual ranking by consultancy EY. The US was ranked first for the first time since 2016, driven by a short-term extension of a production tax credit for wind projects and plans to invest $57 billion in offshore wind by 2030. China remains in second place, with the global clean energy sector expected to bounce back quickly despite the coronavirus pandemic.

site_title: Farmworkers airlifted into Germany provide solutions and pose new risks
summary: Germany's government has airlifted migrant workers from Romania and Bulgaria to address a labor shortage in the agricultural sector, which was severely impacted by the coronavirus pandemic. Approximately 28,000 workers have been flown in, but the program has raised concerns about importing new infections and the exploitation of migrant workers. Farmers have also turned to volunteers and part-time workers, but the patchwork solution has created uncertainty for the future, particularly as travel rules may shift again in June.

images.alt_text: In a normal season, as many as 300,000 migrant workers from Eastern Europe make their way to Germany to harvest asparagus, pick strawberries and plant late-season crops.

site_title: China considers further relief as deadline nears on 1.5t yuan in bad debt
summary: China's banking regulator is considering extending loan relief for companies hit by the pandemic, potentially beyond a June 30 deadline, as banks face a surge in bad loans without such measures. The guidance would offer flexibility on principal and interest payments, helping lenders avoid weakening their ability to keep credit flowing. The move aims to prevent further damage to bank balance sheets, which are already under pressure due to the economic cost of the pandemic.

site_title: LCH clears first SORA derivatives trade
summary: LCH, a global clearing house, has cleared the first Singapore-dollar interest rate swap referencing the Singapore Overnight Rate Average (SORA), marking a milestone in Singapore's transition away from the Sing-dollar Swap Offer Rate (SOR). The clearing of SORA derivatives, including overnight indexed swaps and basis swaps, is expected to deepen liquidity in the market and catalyze its growth. This move aims to mitigate counterparty credit risks and facilitate the transition of legacy SOR derivatives to SORA, with several banks in Singapore already undertaking SORA-derivative transactions.

site_title: Abu Dhabi sells more US dollar bonds by reopening April issuance
summary: Abu Dhabi is offering more US dollar-denominated bonds to the market, seeking extra cash amid the economic downturn caused by the coronavirus pandemic and a slump in oil prices. The government has started marketing a "tap" of its existing dollar bonds, offering around 165 basis points over US Treasuries for a $2 billion bond due in 2025 and around 185 basis points for a $2 billion bond due in 2030. The proceeds will be used for "general budgetary purposes."

site_title: Africa's top coffee grower faces climate risk
summary: Ethiopia, Africa's largest coffee grower, faces significant climate-related volatility in its crop yields by 2030 due to rising temperatures and decreasing rainfall. A 25% drop in yields is predicted, according to McKinsey & Co. The consultancy warns that climate change will lead to higher price volatility, affecting not only coffee but also staple crops like wheat and corn. To mitigate this, Africa needs significant investments in irrigation, storage, and localized planning, estimated at $65 billion.

site_title: Australian dollar buoyed by reopening hopes, but resistance looms
summary: The Australian dollar rose 1.7% overnight, buoyed by hopes for a global economic reopening and optimism about a coronavirus vaccine. It now faces resistance at US$0.6570, but a break above could lead to further gains. The Reserve Bank of Australia's minutes showed an "unprecedented" economic contraction, but also indicated policy stimulus could aid recovery. The kiwi dollar also rose 1.7%, driven by improved risk appetite and commodity prices, including a surge in iron ore futures.

site_title: France reports fewer new coronavirus deaths, uptick in cases
summary: France reported a 0.5% decrease in new coronavirus deaths, with 131 fatalities, bringing the total death toll to 28,239. The number of new confirmed cases rose 0.3% to 492. Despite a slight uptick, France's health system appears to be improving, with the number of people in intensive care and hospitals declining for the fourth to fifth week. Authorities urged caution and respect for social distancing rules as the pandemic remains active.

site_title: Europe: Markets extend gains at open
summary: Europe's main stock markets rose further on Tuesday, mirroring Asian gains on hopes for a COVID-19 vaccine. The FTSE 100 index in London rose 0.7%, while the DAX 30 index in Frankfurt gained 1.0% and the Paris CAC 40 index rose 0.5%. The gains followed a US$542 billion agreement between France and Germany to combat the EU's economic fallout from the pandemic. Stocks were boosted by positive interim results from Moderna's COVID-19 vaccine candidate and a proposed EU recovery fund.

images.alt_text: Europe's main stock markets climbed further in opening deals on Tuesday, mirroring Asian gains on hopes for a vaccine to treat coronavirus.

site_title: Tesla's China car registrations plunge 64% m-o-m in April
summary: Tesla's China car registrations plummeted 64% month-over-month in April, reaching 4,633 units. This decline is attributed to lower sales, with the Shanghai-made Model 3 sedan seeing a 71% drop to 3,635 units. The decrease is in line with Tesla's sales pattern, with the first month of each quarter typically being the lowest.

site_title: Americans still don't trust self-driving cars: poll
summary: A recent poll by Partners for Automated Vehicle Education (Pave) found that nearly half of Americans (48%) would not get in a self-driving taxi, with 21% unsure and a fifth stating AVs would never be safe. Despite investment in self-driving cars, public opinion remains skeptical, with 60% of respondents wanting to know more about how the technology works to increase trust. Experts say educating the public is key to bridging the gap, with demonstrations and increased awareness helping to change opinions.

site_title: Uber to close Asia-Pacific HQ in Singapore as virus impact worsens
summary: Uber will close its Asia-Pacific headquarters in Singapore within the next 12 months due to the ongoing impact of the Covid-19 pandemic on its business. The move will result in approximately 120 job losses, with around 3,000 additional layoffs globally. Uber will also halt non-core investments and stop some business operations. The company aims to relocate its Asia-Pacific hub to another location in the region.

site_title: Singtel associate Bharti Airtel sees shares rise 10%; data demand, tariff hikes help
summary: Bharti Airtel's shares surged 10% to a record high due to strong data subscriber additions and rising average revenue per user, despite 25% increase in mobile tariffs. The company added 12.5 million 4G subscribers in the March quarter, boosting its market share. Airtel reported a quarterly net loss of 52.37 billion rupees, but total revenue rose 15% to 237.23 billion rupees. The company attributed the growth to strong data traffic growth and consumer acceptance of higher tariffs.

site_title: Sony to turn financial arm into wholly owned unit for 400b yen: Nikkei
summary: Sony will turn its financial arm, Sony Financial Holdings, into a wholly owned unit through a tender offer worth about 400 billion yen. The deal, valued at S$5.33 billion, will strengthen Sony's presence in fintech to compete with global tech giants. Sony plans to offer 2,600 yen per share for a premium of 30% over Monday's closing price, with shares of Sony Financial rising nearly 17% and Sony shares rising 4%. The deal is expected to be completed this summer.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei closes nearly 1.5% higher
summary: Tokyo's benchmark Nikkei index rose nearly 1.5% on Tuesday, extending gains on Wall Street due to optimism about easing lockdowns and promising coronavirus vaccine results. The Nikkei 225 index closed at 20,433.45, while the Topix index rose 1.8%. This follows rallies on Wall Street, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reaching fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: China urges its firms to list in London in renewed global push: sources
summary: China is urging domestic companies to list in London as part of its Stock Connect scheme, aiming to revive deals and strengthen overseas ties following the coronavirus crisis. Authorities have given the go-ahead for China Pacific Insurance and SDIC Power to move forward with their London-listing plans, while China Yangtze Power is preparing for a secondary listing. The move is seen as a bid to improve ties with the UK and help fund China's post-lockdown recovery, with potential listings expected in the second half of this year.

site_title: Surbana Jurong clarifies involvement in setting up Singapore Expo care facility
summary: Surbana Jurong clarified its involvement in converting the Singapore Expo venue into a community care facility (CCF) during the COVID-19 pandemic. The company responded to social media accusations of profiteering and corruption, stating it was working on a "cost-recovery basis" and was responding to a government call for support. Surbana Jurong assembled a team of 50 experts and worked with other companies to set up the facility in just four weeks, providing 8,000 beds. The company vowed to continue providing expertise to projects related to the COVID-19 crisis and may take legal action against those making "scurrilous attacks".

site_title: Hong Kong looks to speed up IPOs to boost liquidity, cut risk
summary: Hong Kong's stock exchange is considering speeding up the IPO process from five days to one day to boost liquidity and reduce risk. The move aims to make Hong Kong's listing market more competitive with rival bourses. This proposal was first floated by HKEX's CEO Charles Li last year, amid concerns that Nasdaq's tightening rules make it harder for Chinese companies to list there.

site_title: Coronavirus crushes Asia's garment industry
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has severely impacted Asia's garment industry, with hundreds of thousands of workers laid off and struggling to survive due to lack of welfare support and debt. In Myanmar, Bangladesh, and Cambodia, factories have shut down, leaving workers reliant on food handouts and facing debt. The industry, which accounts for 10% of Myanmar's exports, has lost almost $3 billion in exports since April. The European Union has created a wage fund for workers in Myanmar, but many factories are struggling to enforce social distancing and good hygiene practices, and orders have been slow to trickle back.

site_title: India coronavirus infections surge past 100,000, deaths top 3,000
summary: India has reported 101,139 coronavirus cases and 3,163 deaths, surpassing 100,000 cases. The number of new infections has continued to rise, averaging over 4,000 per day over the past week. India extended its lockdown to May 31, despite a slowdown in growth of new infections. The strict lockdown has shown little sign of slowing the spread of the virus.

site_title: Powell, Mnuchin to face Senate grilling on US coronavirus response
summary: US Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin and Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell are set to testify before the Senate Banking Committee on Tuesday, facing scrutiny over the government's response to the coronavirus pandemic. The hearing will focus on actions needed to support the economy and address missteps in rolling out aid programs, including the $3 trillion stimulus package. Powell warned of a potential 25% unemployment rate and 20% GDP contraction, while Mnuchin will face questions over processing glitches and policy changes affecting small and large businesses.

images.alt_text: The US government's handling of its massive economic response to the coronavirus pandemic will come under scrutiny on Tuesday as Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin and Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell testify before the Senate Banking Committee.

site_title: GuocoLand obtains S$730m green loan for Tan Quee Lan development
summary: GuocoLand has secured a S$730 million green club loan from OCBC Bank, DBS Bank, and ICBC Singapore Branch for its luxury residential and commercial development at Tan Quee Lan Street. The project, a joint venture between GuocoLand and two Hong Leong Holdings subsidiaries, is expected to meet the criteria for a Green Mark Gold Plus certification. The development will feature two residential towers with over 500 luxury apartments and a retail podium, with proceeds from the loan to be used for sustainable development and water and energy conservation efforts.

images.alt_text: The property developer has obtained a S$730 million green club loan from OCBC Bank, DBS Bank and ICBC Singapore Branch for the construction of a new luxury residential cum commercial development at Tan Quee Lan Street.

site_title: Delta will add flights to keep planes no more than 60% full as demand rises: sources
summary: Delta Air Lines plans to maintain planes at 60% capacity or less until at least July, adding more flights despite reduced demand, as part of its strategy to focus on premium experiences and capitalize on perceptions of safety. The move aims to halve its daily cash burn to $50 million by June. Industry-wide US airline load factors have been around 33%, down 90% from 2019 levels, and major US airlines require passengers to wear facial coverings while maintaining social distancing measures.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 10.30 points, or 0.73%, to 1,420.46 on Tuesday, driven by gains. Volume was 425.70 million lots worth RM113.25 million. The market saw 416 gainers compared to 56 losers.

site_title: Coffee company JDE Peet's seeks to raise 700m euros in IPO
summary: JDE Peet's, the owner of several coffee and tea brands, plans to raise 700 million euros in an initial public offering on the Euronext Amsterdam exchange. The company, which has operating profit of 1.26 billion euros, describes itself as the world's largest pure-play coffee and tea group by revenue. The IPO, which will be one of the largest this year, reflects a recent stock market rally and the resilience of its core business, and will be used to repay debt. Mondelez, which owns a 26% stake in JDE Peet's, is expected to sell shares.

site_title: Asia: Vaccine hope and easing of lockdowns fuel stocks rally
summary: Asian markets rallied on Tuesday as hopes for a coronavirus vaccine and easing of lockdowns fueled a surge. The number of infected people is approaching five million, but rates are slowing, allowing governments to reopen their economies. Major tourist attractions in Italy and Greece reopened, and top-tier football resumed in Germany. US biotech firm Moderna reported "positive interim" results on a vaccine candidate, boosting confidence. Regional stock markets, including Tokyo, Hong Kong, and Singapore, also rose, with airline stocks soaring.

site_title: Singapore shares advance at Tuesday's open after Wall Street surge; STI up 2%
summary: Singapore shares opened stronger on Tuesday, following Wall Street's surge, with the Straits Times Index rising 1.7% to 2,582.21. The benchmark index gained over 2% in the morning trade, with gains outnumbering losses 222 to 47. Key stocks including Genting Singapore, ComfortDelGro, and DBS Bank advanced, while OCBC Bank announced plans to rejig its branch network strategy amid the COVID-19 pandemic.

site_title: Singapore expats flouting virus rules spark alcohol clampdown
summary: Singapore authorities have ordered several restaurants in a popular expat neighborhood to stop selling takeaway alcohol after foreigners were seen flouting social distancing measures. Enforcement action will be taken against business operators and individuals, with a S$300 fine for the first offense. The move comes as the city-state battles a surge in COVID-19 cases, with thousands of foreign workers infected. Authorities are urging the public to report offenders through an app, and the government has extended its partial lockdown until June 1 to combat the outbreak.

site_title: AmEx says employees can work from home through 2020
summary: American Express CEO Steve Squeri announced that employees who can work from home should continue to do so for the rest of 2020, citing uncertainty over when offices will reopen. The company plans to return employees in phases, starting with 10% occupancy, and will implement social distancing measures, including temperature screening and limited meetings in conference rooms. This decision follows the company's shift to remote work during the COVID-19 pandemic, with over 60,000 employees equipped to work from home.

site_title: Trump threatens permanent freeze on WHO funding in 30 days
summary: US President Donald Trump threatened to permanently freeze World Health Organization (WHO) funding unless "substantive improvements" are made within 30 days. The US suspended funding in mid-April, citing the WHO's closeness to Beijing and handling of the coronavirus pandemic. Trump tweeted a letter to WHO Director-General Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus, stating that if improvements are not made, the US will reconsider its membership in the organization and make the temporary freeze permanent.

site_title: Mitsui considers stake sale in Indonesia's Paiton Energy
summary: Japanese trading house Mitsui & Co is considering selling its 45.5% stake in Indonesian power producer PT Paiton Energy, with a potential sale worth over $1 billion. The company is gauging interest from regional electricity producers and has not yet started a formal sale process. Mitsui aims to strengthen its financials by recycling its assets, but may still choose to keep its stake in Paiton Energy.

site_title: Home Depot, Lowe's primed for historic growth during lockdown
summary: Home Depot and Lowe's experienced significant growth during the lockdown, with foot traffic rising 10% and 21% respectively, according to data from SafeGraph. The home-improvement sector benefited from warmer temperatures, government designations as essential businesses, and a surge in DIY projects. Analysts predict same-store sales will increase 13% at Home Depot and 16% at Lowe's, with online revenue also seeing significant gains. This growth is unprecedented, with estimates surpassing those from 15 years ago, and could be short-lived as the economy reopens and consumers shift their spending.

site_title: Vietnam targets e-commerce turnover reaching US$35b by 2025
summary: Vietnam aims to reach a US$35 billion e-commerce turnover by 2025, with double-digit annual growth expected over the next five years. The country forecasts that over half of its 96 million population will shop online by 2025, with each shopper expected to spend an average of US$600 annually. Online shopping is expected to account for 10% of total retail sales by 2025, up from around US$12 billion in 2019.

site_title: Australia: Shares hit 2-month high as investors bet on vaccine hopes
summary: Australian shares hit a 2-month high as investors bet on vaccine hopes, with the S&P/ASX 200 index rising 1.9% to 5,565.9. Wall Street's overnight gains, fueled by Moderna's trial results, supported the rise. Energy stocks gained 5.7% and financials 3.3%, with Westpac and National Australia Bank leading the charge. Mining giants BHP and Rio Tinto also benefited from a surge in iron ore futures, while gold stocks dropped 3.5%.

site_title: AEM, UTAC to co-develop new test systems for CMOS image sensor products
summary: AEM Holdings and UTAC Holdings have announced a plan to co-develop next-generation test system solutions for CMOS image sensor products. CMOS image sensors are used in smartphones, cars, and CCTVs. The collaboration aims to provide cost-effective, application-specific test solutions that are scalable and adaptable for future product lines. The partnership is seen as a way for Singapore to remain a top semiconductor hub, enabling the country to harness the talents of both semiconductor manufacturers and local suppliers.

site_title: Financial gain trumps espionage as top motivator in cyber attacks: report
summary: A Verizon report found that 86% of data breaches in 81 countries were financially motivated, with 67% caused by credential theft, phishing, or compromised business emails. The number of confirmed breaches doubled from the previous year, driven by the shift to remote work during the coronavirus pandemic. Cyber attacks on businesses are expected to rise as more companies adopt web-based solutions. To mitigate risks, Verizon advises educating employees on phishing and other fraudulent tactics to access sensitive information.

site_title: Nasdaq to tighten listing rules, restricting Chinese IPOs: sources
summary: Nasdaq is set to introduce new restrictions on initial public offerings (IPOs), making it harder for Chinese companies to debut on its stock exchange. The changes, driven by concerns over accounting transparency and ties to powerful insiders, will require companies to raise at least $25 million in their IPO or achieve a quarter of their post-listing market capitalization. The move is part of a growing tension between the US and China, with the US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) struggling to inspect audits of US-listed Chinese companies.

site_title: Qantas set to ramp up domestic flights without social distancing
summary: Qantas plans to increase domestic flights by 40-50% in July if states relax border controls, without social distancing measures. The airline will introduce measures on board, such as providing masks and cleaning wipes, but will not leave middle seats empty. Qantas expects low and flexible fares to stimulate travel demand, with airfares potentially eight to nine times more than current prices. The airline aims to simplify catering, step up aircraft cleaning, and limit passenger movement to minimize risk. Qantas' frequent flyers are planning trips, and the airline is ramping up domestic capacity from 5% to normal levels.

site_title: Barley blow to Australian farmers after China slap
summary: China has imposed anti-dumping duties of 73.6% and an anti-subsidy duty of 6.9% on Australian barley, potentially wiping over half a billion dollars in value from the industry. The move has been condemned by the Australian government, with Trade Minister Simon Birmingham considering an appeal to the World Trade Organization. The decision is seen as a significant blow to the Australian agriculture industry, which relies heavily on China as its largest buyer. The duties could lead to a major loss to the economy and rural communities.

site_title: Sony, Microsoft strike deal on tiny AI chip with huge potential
summary: Sony and Microsoft have partnered to embed AI capabilities into Sony's imaging chip, a world-first for commercial customers. The new module features its own processor and memory, allowing for faster, simpler, and more secure AI analysis. The technology has potential uses in retail and logistics businesses, such as optimizing warehouse and factory automation, and making cars smarter about drivers and environments. The partnership aims to provide a self-contained AI system for commercial customers, differentiating it from existing methods.

site_title: Macron, Merkel agree 500b-euro virus recovery plan for Europe
summary: French President Emmanuel Macron and German Chancellor Angela Merkel proposed a 500-billion-euro fund to finance the European Union's recovery from the coronavirus crisis, with the goal of providing targeted support to the "worst-hit sectors and regions." The plan, which has been welcomed by the European Central Bank and European Commission, aims to boost the economy and demonstrate solidarity among EU member states. The agreement faces a potentially painful negotiation with all 27 member states and a vote in the European Parliament.

site_title: Hot stock: Perennial shares up 12.1% after disclosure on substantial shareholders mulling options
summary: Perennial Real Estate Holdings' shares rose 12.1% on Tuesday after disclosing substantial shareholders are reviewing options regarding their holdings. The company's shares surged to S$0.65 before retreating to 62.5 cents. Chairman Kuok Khoon Hong holds a 27.9% stake, with Wilmar International and Sim Chye Hock also having significant stakes. There's no assurance that a transaction will take place, but the review has sparked a surge in the company's shares.

site_title: Indian fuel sales boost signals worst of rout might be over
summary: India's fuel consumption has seen a surge in the first half of May, signaling the end of the worst of the virus-driven demand crash. Diesel sales increased by 75% and gasoline by 72% compared to the same period last month. Jet fuel demand rose the most, doubling over the two-week period. However, overall consumption remains down from last year, with jet fuel sales down 87% and diesel down 38%. The nation's fuel sales are expected to take time to recover, with restrictions still in place and a predicted recession.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Singtel, OCBC, Sembcorp, Starhill Global Reit, UOL, Perennial
summary: Singapore stocks saw developments on May 19, 2020, affecting trading of several companies. Singtel recognized its share of Bharti Airtel's spectrum charge at S$357 million. OCBC Bank expects to re jig its branch network strategy due to digital banking adoption. Sembcorp Industries expects lower energy business performance due to reduced demand and falling energy prices. Starhill Global Reit will disburse additional rental rebates to tenants. UOL announced salary reductions and disclosed retail tenants operating during the "circuit-breaker" period. Perennial Real Estate Holdings' substantial shareholders are reviewing options.

site_title: Royal Caribbean's lifeline had shrewd bond maneuver
summary: Royal Caribbean successfully sold $3.32 billion of debt linked to ships, exceeding its initial goal of raising $1.66 billion. The company used a unique structure, giving investors priority guarantees tied to ship ownership, to avoid restrictions imposed by its junk credit grade. This deal may encourage other "fallen angels" to seek funding, and analysts expect Royal Caribbean to regain its investment-grade ratings soon. The company plans to use the proceeds to repay a short-term loan and maintain liquidity.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares open on positive note
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened on a positive note, with the Hang Seng Index jumping 2.32% to 24,489.55, driven by a rally on Wall Street and hopes for a virus vaccine. China's Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also saw gains, adding 0.77% and 0.80% respectively. The positive start follows a global trend of lockdown easing and vaccine development, despite ongoing US-EU trade tensions.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong stocks started Tuesday with healthy gains following a rally on Wall Street, fuelled by hopes for a virus vaccine as well as further openings from lockdown around the world.

site_title: Biden says he would kill Keystone XL pipeline
summary: US presidential candidate Joe Biden has stated that if elected, he would rescind the permit for the Keystone XL pipeline, effectively ending its construction. This decision reverses President Donald Trump's 2017 actions that cleared the way for the $8 billion pipeline. The pipeline, which would carry crude oil from Canada to the US Midwest, has been delayed for over a decade due to opposition from landowners, environmental groups, and tribes. Biden's move would also undo Trump's central campaign promise.

site_title: More than 15,000 Hong Kong shops may close without rent relief
summary: Hong Kong's retailers face a grim forecast as over 15,000 shops may close without rent relief by December, with one in four potentially disappearing. The Hong Kong Retail Management Association estimates 62,400 retail stores in the city, but most landlords are only offering 10-20% rent reductions, far from the industry's demand of 50% or more. Sales have sunk 42% in March, with the city's economy contracting 8.9% in the first quarter, and many retailers are barely surviving, with some staff going on unpaid leave and requesting rent cuts.

site_title: Global economy could take 2 to 3 years to recover from Covid-19: IHS Markit
summary: The global economy is expected to take 2-3 years to recover from the Covid-19 pandemic, according to a research note from IHS Markit. The economy is currently in its worst downturn since the 1930s, with real global GDP projected to fall 5.5% this year. The recovery is expected to be "unusually slow" due to factors such as a fear of crowds in the travel and leisure industries and a significant number of bankruptcies. The fastest recovery is expected in early 2022, with many economies potentially experiencing a prolonged recovery.

site_title: Trump to tap new company to make Covid-19 drugs in US
summary: The Trump administration has signed a $354 million, four-year contract with Phlow, a US-based company, to manufacture generic medicines and pharmaceutical ingredients needed to treat Covid-19 in the US. The contract aims to bring essential medicines home and compete with foreign suppliers. Phlow, a "public benefit corporation," plans to create a strategic active pharmaceutical ingredient reserve and lead a team of private sector entities to support the US supply chain. The move is seen as a step to rebuild the US domestic ability to protect itself from health threats.

images.alt_text: The Trump administration will announce Tuesday that it has signed a US$354 million four-year contract with a new company in Richmond, Virginia, to manufacture generic medicines and pharmaceutical ingredients that are needed to treat Covid-19 but are now made overseas, mostly in India and China.

site_title: Rocket hits near US embassy in Baghdad: security sources
summary: A rocket hit near the US embassy in Baghdad, triggering security sirens but no casualties. The incident is the first in weeks and follows more than two dozen attacks on American interests in Iraq since October, blamed on Iran-backed factions. Tensions between the US and Iraq have been strained since a 2020 drone strike killed Iranian and Iraqi commanders. The US and Iraq are set to discuss a framework for US troop presence in Iraq, with the US having already drawn down its 7,500-strong force this year.

site_title: SoftBank's clouds come with some silver linings
summary: SoftBank Group, led by Masayoshi Son, reported a record annual loss of 1.36 trillion yen ($17.96 billion) due to pain at The We Company and unrealised losses in its Vision Fund. However, activist investor Elliott Management's push is yielding results, with funds being spent less frivolously, stock buybacks continuing, and asset sales on the horizon. The company is also refreshing its board, with the exit of Jack Ma and the addition of new outside directors, which may lead to further asset sales and accelerate the group's governance shift.

site_title: Mental health of Europe's teens on the decline: study
summary: A study by the World Health Organization covering 45 European countries found that the mental health of teenagers has declined since 2014. One in four adolescents report feeling nervous or irritable, with boys reporting better mental health than girls. Teens in low-income families are more likely to report multiple health problems. Investing in mental health services is recommended to bring health, social, and economic gains to current and future generations.

site_title: US oil output from major shale to drop in June to nearly 2-year low
summary: US crude production from major shale formations is expected to drop by a record 197,000 barrels per day in June to 7.822 million bpd, the lowest since August 2018. This follows a throttling back of production since March due to crashing prices and oversupply. The largest drop is expected in the Permian Basin, with production falling to about 4.29 million bpd. The decline is attributed to the novel coronavirus outbreak and the subsequent drop in demand.

site_title: Australia faces 'unprecedented' economic hit from coronavirus: RBA minutes
summary: Australia is facing a "significant" and "unprecedented" economic contraction due to the coronavirus pandemic, with the Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) predicting a 10% GDP fall in the first half and 6% for the year. The RBA left the cash rate at 0.25% and recommitted to buying government debt to keep bond yields near that level. This fiscal and monetary policy stimulus aims to cushion the economic blow, but the country is still expected to experience a substantial economic contraction.

site_title: Japan's Nomura to bolster private investment business, CEO says
summary: Nomura Holdings Inc, Japan's largest bank, plans to bolster its private investment business, including advising startups, after its first loss in five quarters. CEO Kentaro Okuda aims to more than double pretax income in the retail business over the next three years. This move comes as the company seeks to diversify and expand its services to counter the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic.

site_title: Bank of England not ruling out negative rates in future: Tenreyro
summary: Bank of England official Silvana Tenreyro expressed support for negative interest rates, stating the Monetary Policy Committee has not ruled out the tool. She cited European experiences as having a positive effect on real activity, but acknowledged specific considerations for Britain's large financial sector. The comments fueled expectations of negative interest rates in the UK, as the economy continues to struggle with the coronavirus slump.

site_title: Uber says slashing jobs and trimming investment
summary: Uber is cutting a quarter of its global workforce, approximately 3,000 jobs, and trimming investment to survive the financial impact of the coronavirus pandemic. The company will focus on its core ride-share and delivery businesses, and is closing or consolidating offices worldwide. Despite a significant loss of nearly $3 billion in revenue, Uber's Eats food delivery operation saw 53% revenue growth in the first quarter of the year. The company plans to provide laid-off workers with at least 10 weeks of pay and continue health benefits.

site_title: 1MDB trial resumes amid backlash to Najib's stepson's settlement
summary: The trial of Malaysia's former leader Najib Razak will resume on Tuesday amid controversy over his stepson's settlement. Najib faces 25 of 42 charges related to 1MDB, including receiving $681.5 million in bribes. The settlement with Riza Aziz, who was discharged from allegations of receiving $248.2 million, has sparked a dispute over whether ex-Attorney General Tommy Thomas approved the deal before resigning. Opposition leaders have criticized the decision, saying it gives the impression that Malaysia isn't serious about fighting corruption. Najib plans to clear his name through the court process.

site_title: McDonald's hit with sexual harassment complaint at OECD
summary: An international group of labor unions has filed a complaint against McDonald's at the OECD, alleging "systemic sexual harassment" at the fast food chain's restaurants worldwide. The complaint cites witness testimony of attempted rape, indecent exposure, and unwanted bodily contact, with victims often being ignored, mocked, or punished when reporting incidents. McDonald's has stated it will review the complaint, emphasizing its commitment to promoting positive change and creating a safe workplace. The Dutch government will examine the complaint, with up to three months to decide on a mediation process.

images.alt_text: An international group of labor unions said Monday it has filed a complaint against McDonald's for "systemic sexual harassment" at the fast food chain's restaurants around the world.

site_title: Vietnam's Bamboo Airways plans US$2b GE order amid pandemic
summary: Vietnam's Bamboo Airways plans to order 60 General Electric engines for its Boeing 787 Dreamliners in a deal valued at US$2 billion, despite the devastating impact of the coronavirus pandemic on global aviation. The airline aims to almost double its domestic routes to 60 this year and expand its international destinations to 25, with plans to list in Vietnam in the fourth quarter. Bamboo Airways' chairman, Trinh Van Quyet, believes the Vietnamese market is resilient and will recover quickly, with domestic tourism expected to increase as international travel is curtailed.

site_title: China new wind, solar capacity plummets in Q1
summary: China's wind and solar power installations plummeted in Q1, with 2.36GW of new wind power and 3.95GW of new solar power connected to the grid, down from 4.78GW and 5.2GW in the same period last year. Total wind capacity stood at 213GW and total solar capacity at 208GW, accounting for 10.8% and 10.8% of China's total power capacity, respectively. The slowdown is attributed to the coronavirus pandemic, which disrupted construction and caused electricity consumption to decline.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on virus hopes
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on May 19, 2020, as investors remained optimistic about the easing of coronavirus lockdowns and promising vaccine results. The Nikkei 225 index rose 1.65% to 20,465.14, while the Topix index increased 1.44% to 1,480.28. This follows a rally on Wall Street, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edging to fresh records despite ongoing US-EU trade tensions.

site_title: Facebook chief wants EU not China to lead on tech rules
summary: Facebook's Mark Zuckerberg urged the European Union to set global tech regulations, warning that countries following China's model could lead to human rights abuses. Zuckerberg emphasized the EU's GDPR data protection legislation as a standard, and suggested Western democratic countries should lead the way. EU Commissioner Thierry Breton said Facebook must uphold values, while acknowledging the company sometimes falls short. The EU is set to introduce a Digital Service Act, which Silicon Valley firms are preparing to lobby against, fearing it could lead to stricter regulations and changes to their business models.

site_title: SoftBank's first Vision Fund may be its last after US$17.7b loss
summary: SoftBank's first Vision Fund, initially valued at $100 billion, has lost $17.7 billion, marking the worst loss in the company's 39-year history. The fund's return on investment is negative 6%, down from 62% the previous year, due to business missteps and the coronavirus pandemic. Masayoshi Son has conceded that he may not be able to draw outside investors for another Vision Fund, instead opting to continue investing with SoftBank's own money, expecting 15 startups to fail and 15 to thrive.

site_title: Nassim bungalow put on market with asking price of over S$41m
summary: Singapore's luxury market has a new listing, as LMG Realty puts its nearly completed freehold bungalow on Nassim Road up for sale for over S$41 million. The property features six ensuite bedrooms, a 14.5-metre lap pool, and a car porch in the basement. With a land area of 13,293 sq ft, the asking price works out to S$3,084 per square foot. Savills Singapore is the exclusive marketing agent, and the temporary occupation permit is expected to be obtained in the second half of this year.

images.alt_text: The temporary occupation permit (TOP) for the new bungalow, designed by RT+Q Architects, is expected to be obtained in the second half of this year.

"Houses on Nassim Road are rarely available for sale. This property provides an opportunity for, say, a new Singapore citizen, to move into a well-designed brand new house almost immediately." - Galven Tan, Savills Singapore's deputy managing director of capital markets

site_title: Singtel to recognise its share of Airtel's provision at S$357m
summary: Singtel will recognize its share of a one-time spectrum charge at S$357m, or S$232m post-tax, following its Indian associate Bharti Airtel's provision. This comes from reassessed regulatory costs related to the spectrum charge, amounting to 56.4 billion rupees (S$1.1 billion). The charge will be classified as an exceptional item in Singtel's Q4 and FY 2020 financial results, announced on May 28.

site_title: Baidu sees robust quarter as China's economy reopens
summary: Baidu, China's search engine giant, reported robust second-quarter revenue above expectations as businesses reopened in the world's second-largest economy. The company forecast revenue between 25.0 billion yuan and 27.3 billion yuan, beating analysts' estimates. Daily active users surged 28% in March to 222 million, and revenue from its online marketing services business declined 19% to 14.24 billion yuan. Despite a wider net loss, Baidu's shares jumped 8% in extended trading. The company's performance suggests China's economy is recovering faster than expected, with the digital ad market reviving.

site_title: Top European CEOs see multi-year recovery: survey
summary: European CEOs predict a multi-year recovery from the coronavirus recession, with a majority believing it will take 1-2 years to return to pre-lockdown levels. A survey of 56 top CEOs showed divided expectations, with some expecting improvements and others worsening prospects over the next six months. The CEOs, including BASF's Martin Brudermüller and L'Oreal's Jean-Paul Agon, expressed concerns about the economic contraction, with millions of jobs lost and businesses closed.

images.alt_text: Some of Europe's top CEOs believe that the recovery from the coronavirus recession will be painfully slow, a survey showed on Monday.

site_title: US tops 90,000 coronavirus deaths, 1.5 million cases
summary: The US has surpassed 90,000 coronavirus deaths and 1.5 million confirmed cases, according to a Johns Hopkins University tally. New York state accounts for nearly a third of US deaths, with nearly 28,300 linked to Covid-19. Globally, the pandemic has killed over 316,000 people. The US has the world's highest number of deaths and infections, but some countries have recorded more fatal cases per capita.

images.alt_text: The United States on Monday surpassed 90,000 deaths from the novel coronavirus and 1.5 million confirmed cases, according to a running tally from Johns Hopkins University.

site_title: US auto plants get back to work after Covid-19 halts
summary: The US auto industry has begun to resume production after a two-month shutdown due to the COVID-19 pandemic. Detroit's "Big Three" automakers, including General Motors, Ford, and Fiat Chrysler Automobiles, have implemented social distancing protocols, mask-wearing, and temperature checks to minimize the risk of outbreaks. The resumption is seen as a boost to the economy, particularly in the midwestern United States, and is expected to lead to a gradual return to pre-pandemic production levels, with some analysts warning of potential productivity losses due to the new measures.

site_title: Players dig into building game Minecraft amid pandemic
summary: Minecraft, a popular building and exploration game, continues to thrive amid the COVID-19 pandemic, with 126 million monthly players and over 200 million copies sold. Microsoft-owned Mojang Studios, which acquired the game in 2014, reported a surge in online play and views on YouTube. The company's gaming division has seen significant growth, bolstered by the acquisition. The gaming industry is expected to continue growing, with a report predicting it will boost its share of the entertainment sector to 36% by 2023.

site_title: British MPs vote for new post-Brexit immigration system
summary: British MPs have voted in favor of legislation ending free movement of EU workers after Brexit, with the transition period set to expire on December 31. The bill does not provide details on new immigration controls, but Prime Minister Boris Johnson has outlined plans for a points-based system prioritizing high-skilled jobs.

site_title: Disney's streaming chief to become TikTok CEO
summary: Disney's streaming chief, Kevin Mayer, will become CEO of TikTok on June 1, replacing the current CEO. Mayer led the successful launch of Disney+ and previously was passed over for Disney's top job. His appointment aims to address concerns over TikTok's handling of personal data and its Chinese ownership. ByteDance, TikTok's parent company, has made efforts to separate TikTok from its Chinese businesses and hired high-profile executives to alleviate concerns.

images.alt_text: Walt Disney Co's top streaming executive, Kevin Mayer, will leave the entertainment and theme parks giant to become the chief executive officer (CEO) of TikTok, the popular video app owned by China's ByteDance Technology Co, the companies said on Monday.

site_title: Mapletree gives helping hand to those on no-pay leave
summary: Mapletree, a Singaporean property group, has raised over S$85,000 for its Mapletree Community Sharing Fund (MCSF) to support tenants and service providers affected by the Covid-19 pandemic. The fund was contributed by over 100 Mapletree staff, with the group's CEO Hiew Yoon Khong expressing hope that it can alleviate financial challenges faced by the community. The fund will provide cash grants to over 180 individuals who have been on no-pay leave due to temporary business closures.

site_title: US: Stocks surge on Covid-19 vaccine progress, Dow ends +3.9%
summary: US stocks surged on Monday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average gaining 3.9% to 24,597.37, following positive news on a coronavirus vaccine. Moderna reported "positive interim" results in its phase 1 test, boosting shares and lifting shares of airlines, hotels, and other beaten-down sectors. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index also rose, with Moderna's shares jumping 20%. The rally was also supported by state reopenings and Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell's comments on the economic downturn.

site_title: Presymptomatic virus patients can contaminate environments: study
summary: A study published in the Emerging Infectious Diseases journal found that coronavirus was detected on several surfaces in hotel rooms of two presymptomatic Chinese students who later tested positive for Covid-19. Researchers collected 22 samples, eight of which tested positive for Covid-19, highlighting the importance of proper handling procedures when changing or laundering used linens. The study demonstrates that presymptomatic patients have high viral load shedding and can easily contaminate environments, with the virus surviving on surfaces for up to seven days.

site_title: Sembcorp expects lower performance for energy segment
summary: Sembcorp Industries expects its energy segment to perform "markedly lower" in 2020 due to reduced power demand and falling prices. The company attributes this to the impact of the coronavirus pandemic and lockdowns, which led to a 10-25% decline in power demand in Singapore, India, and Britain in April compared to the same period last year. The company expects a S$30 million currency translation loss and a lower net realisable value of its gasoil reserves, contributing to further losses in its energy business.

site_title: Europe: Shares surge as recovery hopes boost cyclicals
summary: European shares surged 4.1% on Monday, their largest one-day gain since March 24, driven by cyclical sectors and optimism over a potential Covid-19 vaccine. Miners led the gains, while automakers, oil, and gas companies rose between 6.5% and 7.9%. The Stoxx 600 index is now up 27% from its March lows, as governments and central banks unleash unprecedented stimulus. A European Recovery Fund worth €500 billion is being discussed, with France and Germany calling for its creation to help the region recover from the crisis.

site_title: US drugmaker reports promising early results from Covid-19 vaccine test
summary: US biotech firm Moderna reported promising early results from its Covid-19 vaccine test, mRNA-1273, which produced an immune response in 8 volunteers similar to that seen in people convalescing from the virus. The vaccine appeared to be "generally safe and well-tolerated" with minimal side effects. The results have sparked optimism, with US President Donald Trump expressing his support and the Dow Jones Industrial Average gaining around 775 points. Moderna plans to begin Phase 3 trials in July, with the goal of producing up to 1 billion doses per year.

images.alt_text: US biotech firm Moderna reported promising early results on Monday from the first clinical tests of an experimental vaccine against the novel coronavirus performed on a small number of volunteers.

site_title: No criminal probe of Obama or Biden: US attorney general
summary: US Attorney General Bill Barr stated he will not investigate former President Barack Obama or former Vice President Joe Biden over the 2016 Russia election meddling case, citing it as a "grave injustice" to President Donald Trump. Barr aimed to stop "political investigations" using the US justice system, including those of Obama and Biden, who is Trump's rival in the upcoming presidential election.

site_title: Money FM podcast: Staging for the return of the workforce
summary: Host Michelle Martin discusses a survey with Aon's Alexander Krasavin on how companies globally are balancing business decisions and employee welfare as workers return to the office. The survey of over 1900 companies found that many are adopting flexible work arrangements, prioritizing employee well-being, and investing in HR systems to support their workforce. Companies are recognizing the importance of balancing business needs with employee welfare to attract and retain talent in a post-pandemic work environment.

site_title: Exiting the pandemic will require more, not less, integration
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has accelerated a retreat from globalization, with governments turning inward in response to the crisis. However, to exit the pandemic, a more integrated and cooperative approach is needed, with global markets remaining open and accessible to facilitate economic recovery and risk management. Financial markets can play a crucial role in allocating capital efficiently and delivering price formation and transparency. A more interconnected and interdependent world may emerge from the pandemic, with increased global cooperation and mutual trust required to secure a sustainable future.

site_title: Oil jumps to 2-month high on easing lockdowns, positive vaccine results
summary: Oil prices rose to a 2-month high on May 18, 2020, due to positive early results on a potential coronavirus vaccine, optimism about economic activity resuming, and producers adhering to planned output reductions. Brent futures jumped 7.1% to $34.81 per barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude rose 8.1% to $31.82. This was the highest settlement since March 11.

site_title: China defends handling of pandemic, backs review of global response under WHO
summary: China's President Xi Jinping defended the country's handling of the COVID-19 pandemic, calling it a "global public health emergency" and stating that China acted with "openness and transparency and responsibility." Xi also pledged $2 billion over two years to help with the global response. The World Health Assembly is expected to discuss a resolution calling for an independent review of the WHO's performance, backed by 116 countries. China has opposed calls for an international investigation into the pandemic but appears more amenable to the resolution, which includes a call for examining the zoonotic origins of the coronavirus.

site_title: Cafes, churches reopen in Italy, Greece; Spain targets mid-summer revival
summary: Italy, Greece, and Spain cautiously reopen their borders and businesses, marking a gradual easing of coronavirus lockdowns. Italians can now visit cafes and churches, while Greeks welcomed tourists back to the Acropolis. Spain aims to reopen its borders to tourists by late June, with Transport Minister Jose Luis Abalos assuring a phased reopening. Other countries, such as Denmark and parts of England, have also begun to relax lockdown restrictions, with varying degrees of success.

site_title: Trump calls world health body 'puppet of China'
summary: US President Donald Trump criticized the World Health Organization, calling it a "puppet of China." He stated the US pays around $450 million annually, citing the WHO's "bad advice" during the pandemic. Trump mentioned China pays only $40 million annually, suggesting the US could reduce its contribution to $40. The WHO is holding its first assembly since the pandemic, coinciding with Trump's comments.

images.alt_text: President Donald Trump attacked the United Nations health body as a Chinese "puppet" on Monday and confirmed he is considering slashing or canceling US support.

site_title: Trump reveals he is taking hydroxychloroquine
summary: President Donald Trump revealed on Monday that he has been taking hydroxychloroquine, an anti-malaria drug not recommended by his government experts for fighting the novel coronavirus. Trump said he takes the drug daily, citing its potential benefits, despite the US government regulators' warnings of its safety. He claimed to be taking the drug "for about a week and a half" and has tested negative for the virus, showing no symptoms. Trump's use of the disputed remedy has sparked concerns, especially given his frequent downplaying of the coronavirus threat.

site_title: Trump needs to harness soft power resources more
summary: US President Donald Trump's threat to "cut off the whole relationship" with China has fueled concerns of a new cold war, but the relationship is more intertwined than the US-Soviet Union due to people-to-people interaction, trade, and economic ties. China is cultivating an increasing range of allies through hard and soft power, with a favourable view of the US in 21 out of 33 nations surveyed, but Beijing is punching back hard, particularly in the Asia-Pacific region. The US needs to harness soft power resources more effectively to maintain its influence and avoid being left on the sidelines.

site_title: SoftBank Group reports record losses on virus, WeWork woes
summary: SoftBank Group reported record losses of 961.6 billion yen ($8.9 billion) due to the coronavirus pandemic and its struggling investment in WeWork. The company's Vision Fund portfolio also recorded operating losses of 1.9 trillion yen. SoftBank's CEO, Masayoshi Son, has faced criticism for his investments in overvalued and unprofitable start-ups, with WeWork being a major headache. The company is working with WeWork's portfolio firms to prepare for further business deterioration.

site_title: Ant Financial to invest US$73.5m in Yoma Strategic's mobile payments joint venture in Myanmar
summary: Ant Financial, Alibaba Group's affiliate, is investing $73.5 million in Yoma Strategic's mobile payments joint venture, Wave Money, in Myanmar. The investment aims to promote financial inclusion in the country by targeting the unbanked and underbanked communities. Wave Money will leverage Ant Group's experience in building mobile payment platforms to boost its digital competence and service offerings. The partnership follows Ant Financial's expansion into the Philippines, Vietnam, and Singapore, and is part of its efforts to bolster its presence in South-east Asia.

site_title: SGX RegCo reviewing Universal Resource auditors' findings on irregularities
summary: The Singapore Exchange Regulation (SGX RegCo) is reviewing findings by Moore Stephens on irregularities in Universal Resource and Services' Chinese subsidiary, Sky Petroleum Technology Development (Tianjin). The audit highlighted material discrepancies in bank statements and questionable corporate governance practices. The company's internal controls were lacking, allowing multiple false disclosures to the investing public. SGX RegCo may take disciplinary action and refer the matter to relevant authorities if necessary, citing non-compliance with listing rules and potential contravention of the law.

site_title: One in 2 SMEs see falling sales for next 12 months: poll
summary: Singapore SMEs expect a year-on-year decline in sales for the next 12 months, with 47% of surveyed businesses anticipating a drop. The transport and storage sector is the most pessimistic, followed by hospitality and F&B. About 74% of manufacturing SMEs may not have sufficient funds in the next 6-12 months, while 73% of transport and storage SMEs face a cash crunch. Businesses cite late payments, cancelled orders, and cash flow as major challenges, but government support measures have helped ease pressure, with 93% of SMEs focusing on retaining employees and improving cash flow.

site_title: India's 'jack of all fruits' goes global as meat alternative darling
