summary: India's jackfruit, a fruit once considered a backyard nuisance, has gained global popularity as a meat substitute, particularly among vegans and vegetarians in the West. The fruit's popularity has grown manifold due to its pork-like texture when unripe, and it is now being used as an alternative to pulled pork and pizza toppings. India, the world's biggest producer of jackfruit, is capitalizing on its growing popularity, with demand reaching 100 metric tonnes every day during peak season, yielding a turnover of $19.8 million a year.

site_title: Japan suffers first recession since 2015; expects worse to come
summary: Japan's economy has entered its first recession since 2015, with the country's GDP shrinking by 0.9% in the first quarter due to the COVID-19 pandemic. The recession follows a 1.9% decline in the fourth quarter of 2019, attributed to a tax hike and typhoons. Economists predict further decline, with some forecasting a 10.2% drop in the second quarter, the worst since the 2008 financial crisis. The government has implemented stimulus measures, including a 100,000 yen cash handout, to mitigate the effects of the crisis.

site_title: Agility, resilience needed for a post-Covid world
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has left the global economy in a state of uncertainty, with sectors such as aviation, tourism, and manufacturing struggling with falling demand and disruption. To survive and thrive post-pandemic, business leaders must adopt an entrepreneurial mindset, embracing agility and innovation. Governments and companies must work together to devise novel solutions and improvise existing ones. Key strategies include re-imaging strategic responses, re-planning workforce and business models, and leveraging government support for accelerated growth. With the emergence of new risks and opportunities, businesses must be prepared to adapt and seize opportunities during adversity.

site_title: Changing hands
summary: Oil prices rose over 2% as investors weighed market outlook, tariffs, and sanctions. The US stock market edged down from records amid tariff threats, while European stocks declined due to bank and healthcare sector concerns. NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was 9.8 times oversubscribed. Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall and operating loss in the second half. Meanwhile, London's Heathrow airport planned to increase fees for a £10 billion upgrade, and Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a 285 trillion rupiah graft case.

site_title: UOL managers and above taking pay cut of up to 18% to manage costs
summary: UOL, a Singaporean property developer, announced a 18% pay cut for managers and above to manage costs, effective April 1, 2020. The company has also implemented measures to reduce costs, including deferment of non-essential capital expenditure and tapping government assistance. Despite a 12.4% decline in shopper footfall, retail space occupancy remains at 95.2%. Hotel occupancy in Singapore and Australia has also declined, with revenue per available room dropping significantly. UOL continues to sell residential units, with 85 home units sold in the first quarter.

site_title: London office construction hit a record just as virus arrived: Deloitte survey
summary: London's office construction reached a record high in the six months through March, with about 5 million square feet of new office buildings underway, according to a Deloitte survey. The surge in construction started after the UK's general election in December, which alleviated uncertainty and boosted project starts. The construction wave coincided with the arrival of the coronavirus, which had a significant impact on the construction industry.

site_title: Tech talent in demand more than ever during pandemic
summary: The demand for tech professionals is stronger than ever during the pandemic, as companies accelerate their digitalization efforts amid the slowdown. Industry watchers say that tech roles linked to e-commerce, data, and emerging technologies like AI and blockchain are in high demand. Companies like Telco Singtel and Containers Printers are looking to hire more than 2,000 people to meet their short-term and long-term needs. Recruiters note that talented candidates are becoming more reluctant to take risks and move to new roles, and companies must focus on hiring those with the capacity to learn and adapt to new technologies.

site_title: Singapore retail, F&B firms team up to spur China business
summary: Singaporean retail and F&B companies are teaming up to boost business in China, led by industry bodies. A promotional campaign on Chinese e-commerce platform Meituan Dianping reached 5.5 million visits, while another campaign on WeChat garnered 92,000 views. The efforts aim to help F&B businesses drive traffic amid a slow recovery from the coronavirus pandemic. By banding together, Singapore companies can benefit from collective branding and enhance their digital marketing capabilities.

site_title: Big debate in China over whether to QE or not to QE
summary: China is considering quantitative easing (QE) to stimulate its economy, but economists are divided on the issue. Analysts estimate a potential fiscal stimulus of 5-6 trillion yuan, or 5-6% of GDP. Head of the Chinese Academy of Fiscal Sciences, Liu Shangxi, has proposed the central bank buy special bonds directly, while Ma Jun and Zhang Ming have raised concerns about fueling inflation and asset bubbles. The People's Bank of China (PBOC) is likely to play a key role in the fiscal stimulus, possibly by funding bond purchases by big banks.

site_title: Australia construction to drop more than 10% a year to June 2022
summary: Australia's commercial construction activity is expected to drop by 15.7% in the fiscal year to June 2021 and 11.5% in the 12 months ending mid-2022 due to the impact of Covid-19, according to Master Builders Australia. The industry body attributes the decline to the collapse of private sector demand and urges governments to provide stimulus in sectors such as education, health, and defence to aid in the recovery. The Reserve Bank of Australia forecasts a 10% economic shrinkage in the first half of the year, with a record 594,000 jobs lost in April.

site_title: Firms in Indonesia opt for debt over equity fundraising
summary: Indonesian firms have shifted their fundraising strategy from equity to debt, with 98% of capital raised from January to April coming in the form of debt. The country saw a significant increase in bond issues, reaching $15.3 billion, compared to $7.2 billion in the same period last year. IPOs were valued at an average of $10 million, down from $36 million in the previous year. This trend is attributed to liquidity tightness among local banks and the economic fallout from the Covid-19 pandemic.

site_title: Coronavirus: 2 new Singaporean cases, 4 new clusters
summary: Singapore reported 305 new confirmed COVID-19 cases, the lowest in over a month, with 58% of cases linked to foreign workers in dormitories. Four new clusters were announced, and 495 patients were discharged, bringing the total number of recovered cases to 35% of the 28,343 cases in Singapore. The daily average of new cases outside dormitories has decreased, and contact tracing is ongoing. Globally, over 4.7 million people have been infected, with 315,000 deaths reported.

site_title: StanChart pushes fresh tech strategy to target Indonesia's mass market
summary: Standard Chartered plans to expand its digital banking services in Indonesia, targeting the mass market with a "banking as a service" solution called nexus. The bank aims to acquire at least 5 million customers through partnerships with digital platforms, with plans to roll out the service next year. This strategy will allow StanChart to offer loans, credit cards, and savings accounts to customers under the partner's brand, gaining access to millions of new customers. The bank expects to grow its share of operating income in Indonesia from 6% to around 20% in the next five years.

site_title: Sea Ltd's Q1 loss narrows to US$280.8m as revenue doubles
summary: Sea Ltd, a Singapore-based company, reported a net loss of US$280.8 million for the first quarter to March, narrowing from US$689.6 million a year ago. Revenue more than doubled to US$714.9 million, driven by growth in its gaming and e-commerce arm. The company's losses are still significant, but the narrowing gap indicates improving financial performance.

site_title: A game changer for Indonesia's education sector
summary: Indonesia's education sector is poised for a paradigm shift due to the COVID-19 pandemic, with technology playing a key role in delivering higher-quality education. The government has recognized this need and appointed a digital tycoon as the new minister of education. To address the country's challenges, including a lack of technical skills and outdated curriculum, the education sector must be revamped. A collaborative approach between the government and the private sector is necessary to bring in new ideas and technologies, such as gamification, virtual reality, and emerging technologies. The government must also prioritize teacher training and development to support the adoption of online learning.

site_title: Banding together for a good cause
summary: Charity organizations and individuals in Singapore are banding together to help families affected by the COVID-19 pandemic. Glyph, a social enterprise, has started distributing food to families in need, while Operation Hope Foundation is preparing reusable face masks for Nepal. Meanwhile, a group of individuals, including Cheryl Chen, has launched the Solidarity Gift for SG Livelihoods Fund to raise money for vulnerable families. The fund has raised S$250,000 so far, aiming to reach S$600,000 by June 30, with all funds going to Community Chest to support those in need.

site_title: Jump in pharma exports lifts Singapore NODX in April
summary: Singapore's non-oil domestic exports (NODX) expanded for the third straight month in April, driven by a surge in pharmaceuticals, with a 9.7% year-on-year increase. The growth defied economists' expectations of a 5% decline. Pharmaceutical exports jumped 174.3% due to high demand for medical supplies amid the pandemic. However, electronic exports declined 0.6% in April, and economists remain mixed on the outlook, with some predicting a recession and others seeing a glimmer of hope.

site_title: Thai government to table Thai Airways rescue plan at bankruptcy court
summary: The Thai government plans to submit a rehabilitation plan for Thai Airways International to a bankruptcy court, replacing a previous rescue plan. The plan, which is similar to filing Chapter 11 in the US, aims to show clarity on how the airline will recover and propose a capable person to lead the process. The plan will be submitted to the Cabinet on Tuesday, and the Ministry of Finance will initiate the proceedings. Thai Airways shares have slumped 12% on the news, and the workers' union has agreed with the steps, citing the need for an unbiased court process.

site_title: Fragile UK unity must be maintained at time of crisis
summary: UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson's new "roadmap" for easing the lockdown has exacerbated domestic political divisions, particularly with Scotland, Wales, and Northern Ireland rejecting key elements of the plan. The crisis has exposed fault lines in the UK's devolved political settlement, with Labour's Manchester mayor Andy Burnham criticizing Johnson's approach. Johnson must now address growing regional variations in infection rates and allow for greater flexibility in policy-making to prevent further division and preserve unity.

site_title: China home prices up again in April, adding momentum to recovery
summary: China's new home prices rose 0.5% month-over-month in April, following a 0.1% increase in March, as the government eases virus-busting restrictions. Average prices are up 5.1% year-over-year, driven by pent-up demand and easier access to mortgages. Most cities reported monthly price increases, with some areas, such as Nanjing and Tangshan, outperforming. However, analysts caution that a broader recovery in home prices is unlikely due to mortgage and purchase restrictions.

site_title: Malaysia's king upholds PM Muhyiddin's appointment as opposition mounts challenge
summary: Malaysia's King Sultan Abdullah Sultan Ahmad Shah upheld Prime Minister Muhyiddin Yassin's appointment, stating that he had majority support from the Dewan Rakyat. The king warned lawmakers against resorting to hostility and slander, urging them to work together to develop the nation. The opposition had challenged Muhyiddin's appointment, citing a lack of clear majority support. Despite this, the king's endorsement is unlikely to sway a potential vote in parliament on Muhyiddin's leadership.

site_title: Subaru braces itself for Covid-19 impact after full-year profit rises
summary: Subaru posted a 15.7% rise in annual operating profit to 210.3 billion yen, exceeding consensus estimates, but warned of a hit from the novel coronavirus outbreak. The carmaker expects limited output in the coming months due to anaemic demand, supply chain disruptions, and social distancing measures. Subaru has secured a 200 billion yen credit line and slashed its year-end dividend by 61% due to uncertainties related to the virus. Global vehicle sales are expected to slump, with some analysts predicting a 30% decline this year, and Subaru anticipates a global production hit of around 150,000 units.

site_title: UK's Intu says it's on course to default in June
summary: UK mall operator Intu Properties Plc warns it will likely breach debt commitments by June due to falling rental payments. The company, which owns Trafford Centre and Lakeside in Essex, will seek standstill agreements with creditors until December 2021 to ride out the coronavirus crisis. Intu has £4.69 billion in net debt and £2 billion in losses from 2019, citing uncertainty over securing new funding or selling properties to address covenant issues.

site_title: OCBC set to rejig branch network strategy as pandemic drives digital banking
summary: Singapore's second-largest bank, OCBC, plans to restructure its branch network strategy due to the COVID-19 pandemic's impact on traditional banking services. The bank expects higher net operating profits in the long term through reduced manpower costs and lower physical branches. OCBC saw a surge in digital banking services during Q1, with 2.4 times more SME accounts opened digitally and 49% of SME loans applied digitally. The bank's peers, DBS and UOB, also reported significant increases in digital banking adoption. OCBC's CEO, Samuel Tsien, outlined six mega trends that will impact the bank's future growth, including digitalization and cybersecurity risks.

site_title: ComfortDelGro rated a buy on 'increasingly defensive' earnings: Maybank KE
summary: Maybank KE has reinitiated coverage on ComfortDelGro Corp with a "buy" call and a target price of S$1.99, citing an "increasingly defensive" revenue base due to stable bus-contracting models and government support. The analyst believes longer-term public policy and ESG imperatives will favor public transport over private vehicle ownership, driving growth. ComfortDelGro's overseas acquisitions are expected to overtake domestic revenue by 2023, improving earnings visibility. Maybank KE also expects the railway business to grow in the long term, with operating leverage improving and potential adoption of a bus-contracting model.

site_title: Hotels vs Airbnb: Has Covid-19 disrupted the disrupter?
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has disrupted the hotel industry, which was previously disrupted by Airbnb. Hotels, which once struggled to compete with Airbnb, have seen a resurgence in bookings and revenue. Airbnb, on the other hand, has laid off a quarter of its workforce due to financial strain. The shift in the market may be a result of travelers opting for more traditional hotel stays over the flexibility and affordability of Airbnb. The pandemic has also accelerated the growth of new hotel brands and the development of new hotel amenities, such as restaurants and bars.

site_title: Clifford Capital, SMBC provide US$140m in loans for Summit Power's power plant project
summary: Singapore-based Clifford Capital and Sumitomo Mitsui Banking Corporation (SMBC) have provided US$140 million in loans to Summit Power International's subsidiary for a 300-megawatt oil-fired power plant project in Bangladesh. The project, awarded in 2017, will supply power to the Bangladesh Power Development Board under a 15-year agreement. The financing, completed during the Covid-19 lockdown, demonstrates a competitive bespoke financing package. The power plant is the first independent project in Bangladesh to be financed solely by international commercial institutions.

site_title: Soon Lian says ex-chairman and CEO disagreed with executive directors
summary: Soon Lian's ex-chairman and CEO Tony Tan Yee Chin resigned following disagreements with executive directors Tan Yee Ho and Tan Yee Leong over strategic direction. The new leadership will focus on stability before growth, scrutinizing debt collection and reviewing purchasing strategies. The company prioritizes a healthy cash flow position and stable growth with a "moderate level of risk", with opportunities in the marine, semiconductor, and precision engineering industries.

site_title: Amid lingering uncertainty, Genting Singapore is a long-term bet
summary: Genting Singapore's stock price has seen a significant recovery from its 11-year low of S$0.51 in mid-March, currently trading at around S$0.74. Despite the company's bleak first quarter results, analysts remain optimistic, with 10 out of 21 polled by Bloomberg recommending a "buy" or "hold" call. Genting's strong balance sheet and dividend payments of around 5% yield are seen as positives, while its cash hoard of S$3.7 billion and long-term bets on Japan are also viewed as supporting its prospects.

site_title: Singapore refineries starting to cut output amid pandemic pains
summary: Singapore refineries are cutting output amid the COVID-19 pandemic, with production down 25% from pre-pandemic levels. The decline is attributed to weaker demand in Asia and poor refining margins. Refineries have brought forward maintenance shutdowns and reduced operating rates. Despite this, demand is showing some improvement, and analysts expect a balancing process to begin, with shut-ins of supply and managed shutdowns starting in April and May. Global refining activity is expected to fall by 13.4 million barrels per day in Q2, with average throughput down by 6.2 million barrels per day.

site_title: STI rises 0.6% on positive data, easing of lockdown measures
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 15.73 points, or 0.62%, to 2,539.28 on Monday, driven by positive domestic data and easing of lockdown measures. Non-oil domestic exports unexpectedly rose for a third straight month, suggesting manufacturing may escape a recession. Gold traded at its highest in seven years, while crude oil surged to over US$30 a barrel. Market sentiments remain optimistic despite potential risks, including new waves of infection and US-China tensions.

site_title: GSK's long-acting injection beats Truvada in HIV prevention trial
summary: GlaxoSmithKline's long-acting injection of cabotegravir was found to be 69% more effective in preventing HIV infection than Gilead's daily Truvada pill in a trial involving men who have sex with men. The injection was administered every other month and showed superior results, but cheaper generic versions of Truvada are expected to be launched in the US in September. GSK plans to discuss possible approval of cabotegravir for prevention with regulators, potentially giving its ViiV unit a foothold in the market.

site_title: Pompeo says Taiwan exclusion 'further damages' WHO credibility
summary: US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo condemned the World Health Organization's (WHO) exclusion of Taiwan from its annual meeting, calling it a "further damage" to the organization's credibility. Pompeo accused WHO Director-General Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus of bowing to pressure from China, despite having the power to include Taiwan. The move is seen as a blow to Taiwan's efforts to combat the pandemic, with only seven deaths and 400 infections reported, and contrasts with China's handling of the outbreak.

site_title: Logos and CSC to redevelop ramp-up warehouse in Jurong
summary: Logos, a logistics company backed by ARA Asset Management, is partnering with CSC Holdings to redevelop a 46,000 sq m ramp-up logistics facility in Jurong, Singapore. The $108 million project will include office space, a cafeteria, and a built-to-suit workshop for CSC. The redevelopment aims to maximize land potential and increase the built-up area significantly. Construction is expected to commence after the COVID-19 lockdown and completion is expected by end of Q4 2021.

site_title: Steinway's youth piano contest goes virtual
summary: Steinway's youth piano contest has gone virtual due to social distancing measures and lockdown restrictions. Performers livestream their playing from home, while judges watch from their homes. The competition, which includes a new Amateur Class, has seen almost double the number of participants compared to past editions. Viewers can vote for their favorite participants and donate to charity. A representative from Singapore will compete in regional rounds to represent the nation in the International Steinway Festival in Hamburg, Germany, in September 2020.

site_title: Opec+ cuts oil exports sharply in May
summary: Opec+ has sharply cut oil exports by 9.7 million barrels per day from May 1, in line with a production cut agreement, according to Kpler. This decline marks a "stunning reversal" from April, when producers pumped at will. The cut is aimed at offsetting a slump in prices and demand caused by the coronavirus outbreak. Opec+ seaborne oil exports have declined to 27 million barrels per day, indicating a strong start in complying with the agreement.

site_title: No spike in April 2020 numbers for business cessations
summary: A correction was made to the Business Times article "Over 8,500 business entities close shop in April; highest in recent years" after a reader pointed out an error. The actual number of business entities that ceased registration in April 2020 was 3,771, not 8,663 as initially reported. This number is comparable to March 2020 (3,793) and April 2019 (4,124). The correction highlights the importance of verifying data accuracy in business reports.

site_title: eToro offers Asia-Pac clients free trading in US stocks
summary: eToro, an investment platform, has begun offering commission-free trading in US stocks to its Asia-Pacific clients, including those in Singapore, in an effort to encourage young investors to start investing. This move aims to remove the cost barrier for traders. Additionally, eToro has introduced "copy trading," allowing users to observe and imitate other traders' activities.

site_title: Price jump due to substantial shareholders mulling options for their stakes: Perennial
summary: Perennial Real Estate Holdings saw its share price jump 14.9% to S$0.58 due to substantial shareholders reviewing their stakes. The company stated that a decision on these options has yet to be made and no assurance of a transaction can be given. This price increase may indicate the substantial shareholders are considering selling their stakes, potentially affecting the company's future.

site_title: Germany looking to lift travel warning, foreign minister says
summary: Germany is set to make progress in lifting its global travel warning, Foreign Minister Heiko Maas said, after talks with EU partners. The warning, in place until June 14, will be replaced with guidelines for international travel based on regional infection rates. Controls will remain on Germany's borders with certain countries and for air arrivals from others. Maas aims to ensure a "vacation feels like a vacation" while preventing infection hotspots. Talks with EU partners will focus on establishing criteria for safe travel.

site_title: ARA-backed crowdfunding platform sees debut property investment tranche snapped up in 11 minutes
summary: A crowdfunding platform Minterest backed by ARA Asset Management launched its debut property investment product, which was snapped up by 21 investors in 11 minutes, generating S$500,000 in sales. The product, offering a 6% gross return, was co-invested with Straits Real Estate and managed by SRE on behalf of investors. The strong demand demonstrates pent-up demand for attractive real estate investments in a low interest rate environment, with ARA planning to launch more tranches soon.

site_title: Let Libor survive the virus to die another day
summary: The London Interbank Offered Rate (Libor) is scheduled to be phased out by the end of 2021 due to its flaws and vulnerabilities, but market regulators are considering extending its deadline. Despite flawed replacements like Sonia, SOFR, and ESTR, Libor remains in use, with over $2.1 trillion of derivatives tied to it, compared to just $17.2 billion for SOFR in the US. Regulators are delaying deadlines, citing the need to maintain credit flow to the real economy, and some argue it's a distraction to change benchmarks now.

site_title: First Reit 'optimistic' about resolving road subsidence issue near Surabaya hospital
summary: First Reit expressed optimism about resolving a road subsidence issue near Siloam Hospitals Surabaya in Surabaya, Indonesia. The issue hindered development works after the company sold land to PT Lippo Karawaci Tbk in 2015. The company has commissioned experts to conduct feasibility studies and is planning to terminate the deal if the works remain uncompleted by June 28, 2020.

site_title: Digitalisation drives growth, agility for logistics firms
summary: Singaporean logistics firms are embracing digitalization to boost efficiency, cost savings, and agility in the face of crises like the Covid-19 pandemic. Companies like Masindo Logistic and Lim Siang Huat (LSH) have implemented digitalized operations systems, e-stores, and inventory management systems, resulting in improved productivity and revenue recovery. Digitalization has also enabled the companies to stay nimble and adapt to changing market conditions. Experts emphasize the importance of digitalization for small and mid-sized enterprises (SMEs) in Singapore's logistics sector, with support from Enterprise Singapore and the Centre of Innovation for Supply Chain Management (COI-SCM).

site_title: 'He liked my backside': Brigitte Bardot's cheeky tribute to dead co-star
summary: French film legend Brigitte Bardot paid tribute to late co-star Michel Piccoli, saying he had "talent, humour, and he liked my backside." The two starred in Jean-Luc Godard's 1963 film Contempt, which became notorious for a nude scene. Bardot's comments, made after Piccoli's death from a stroke at 94, were seen as cheeky and raised eyebrows given her past comments on the #MeToo movement. Bardot and Piccoli had a mutual esteem and worked together in Contempt, considered a classic of French cinema.

site_title: China will deepen economic reforms as growth slows
summary: China is set to deepen economic reforms as growth slows, with plans to open up more sectors to private firms, reduce government interference, and prioritize fiscal, monetary, and employment policies. The country aims to boost its socialist market economy through new regulations and control mechanisms. China's economy shrank 6.8% in the first quarter of 2020, and leaders have promised sweeping reforms since 2013, but implementation has been slow. The government will also draw up new national plans, liberalize domestic gas pricing, and push forward property tax legislation.

site_title: US: Wall St jumps at the open on coronavirus vaccine hopes
summary: US stocks surged at the open on May 18, 2020, as a potential Covid-19 vaccine trial sparked optimism, with the Dow Jones rising 1.58% and the S&P 500 gaining 2.40%. The Nasdaq Composite also opened higher. Investors were also awaiting more stimulus to rescue the economy from the virus-driven slump.

site_title: US homebuilder confidence rises in May
summary: US homebuilder confidence rose 7 points to 37 in May, suggesting the economic downturn may be nearing its end as the country reopens. This follows record job losses and a collapse in manufacturing output and retail sales in April. Mortgage applications have also risen, but homebuilder confidence remains low due to high unemployment and supply-side challenges. The National Association of Home Builders/Wells Fargo Housing Market Index measures indicate a rebound in housing activity, with sales expectations and prospective buyers index also showing signs of improvement.

site_title: IMF chief warns full global economic recovery unlikely in 2021
summary: IMF Managing Director Kristalina Georgieva warned that the global economy will take much longer to recover from the COVID-19 shock than initially expected, with only a partial recovery expected next year. The Fund is likely to revise downward its forecast for a 3% contraction in GDP in 2020, citing worse-than-expected data. Georgieva emphasized the danger of protectionism, urging countries to maintain open communication and trade flows. She also warned against retreating into protectionism, highlighting the benefits of international trade and collaboration in overcoming the crisis.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares end on positive note
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.58% on Monday, driven by advances across Asia as countries ease lockdown measures. The Hang Seng Index climbed to 23,934.77, while the Shanghai Composite Index added 0.24%. However, the Shenzhen Composite Index eased 0.43%. The gains come as the global economy recovers from the COVID-19 pandemic.

site_title: SGX RegCo reviews Universal Resource's special-auditor report for rule breaches
summary: The Singapore Exchange Regulation (SGX RegCo) is reviewing a special auditor's report on Universal Resource and Services, which found material discrepancies in Sky Petroleum Technology Development's bank statements. The auditors highlighted questionable corporate governance and accounting practices.

site_title: Vietnam tipped to be most resilient regional economy amid virus crisis
summary: Vietnam is expected to emerge as the most resilient regional economy amid the coronavirus crisis, with a 1% expansion in 2020. This growth is attributed to low wages and an export basket comparable to China. However, the economy may face downside risks, including trade tensions with the US, potential trade tariffs, and a resurgence of the virus in the healthcare system. Despite these challenges, Vietnam and Indonesia may still see modest growth this year.

site_title: Hong Kong's Hang Seng benchmark paves way to include Alibaba
summary: The Hang Seng Index, a 50-year-old benchmark in Hong Kong, made rule changes to allow the inclusion of Chinese internet giants Alibaba, Xiaomi, and Meituan Dianping. This move aims to better reflect the opportunity set available in the market, according to China equities portfolio manager Michael Lai. The changes are expected to shake up the index's composition, which is currently dominated by financial services institutions and conglomerates.

site_title: Sembcorp expects lower performance for energy segment
summary: Sembcorp Industries expects its energy segment to perform "markedly lower" this year due to reduced power demand and falling energy prices, impacted by the COVID-19 pandemic. The company expects a S$30 million accumulated currency translation loss and a S$45 million reduction in book value for its gasoil reserves. Its marine division is also expected to incur losses, with business volumes weakening over the rest of the year. Despite the challenges, Sembcorp expects to maintain positive operating cash flow in 2020 due to long-term contracts and a diversified portfolio.

site_title: Dollar struggles as rising oil prices lift commodity currencies
summary: Oil prices surged, boosting commodity currencies like the Norwegian kroner and Canadian dollar against the US dollar. The rising oil prices lifted optimism about a reopening of economies, stifled by the novel coronavirus pandemic, and raised hope for a recovery in demand. The US dollar index fell 0.12% to $100.25, while other major currencies, such as the Australian dollar and euro, also rose. Investors are now looking to Purchasing Managers' Index surveys for further insight into the outlook, and policymakers are bracing for Japan's worst post-war slump.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's non-oil domestic exports (NODX) grew for the third straight month in April, surpassing expectations. OCBC is re-evaluating its branch strategy due to the shift towards digital banking. Yoma Strategic's mobile payments JV with Ant Financial has secured $73.5 million in funding. Healthtech startup Holmusk raised $21.5 million in a Series A round, planning to expand in the US and Asia. eToro introduced commission-free trading in US stocks to the Asia-Pacific region. The STI rose 0.6% to 2,539.28, while global markets were influenced by US tariff announcements and economic concerns.

site_title: Starhill Reit to disburse S$4.4m more in rent rebates
summary: Starhill Global Reit is disbursing an additional S$4.4 million in rent rebates to eligible tenants in Singapore, bringing the total to S$18.1 million. This includes property tax rebates from the Singapore government, as the circuit breaker measures are extended to June 1, 2020. The move aims to share the burden faced by tenants during the difficult period, and the company will continue to work with tenants and authorities to navigate the situation.

site_title: Singapore stocks close 0.6% higher
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 15.73 points or 0.62% to close at 2,539.28 on Monday, driven by encouraging domestic data and easing lockdown measures. Non-oil domestic exports unexpectedly rose for the third straight month in April, suggesting manufacturing may escape a recession. Global market anxiety has decreased to a third of its peak level, but analysts warn of potential risks, including new waves of infection and US-China tensions.

site_title: GrabFood trials programme for hawkers with lower commissions
summary: GrabFood has launched a pilot project, "Hawker Centre 2.0", to help hawkers with lower commission fees and a new ordering format. The initiative, starting May 11, is being implemented at AMK 724 Food Centre and aims to replicate the physical hawker centre experience with a mix-and-match feature. GrabFood will offer lower commissions, currently 25-30%, to participating hawkers. The goal is to provide stop-gap relief and gain insights into hawkers' challenges as they digitalise their businesses.

site_title: OCBC to rejig branch strategy after Covid-19 crisis
summary: OCBC Bank plans to restructure its branch network strategy due to the Covid-19 pandemic's impact on digital banking adoption. The bank saw a surge in digital transactions, such as online trading, loan applications, and PayNow transactions, with 22 branches temporarily shut. OCBC expects higher net operating profit in the long term due to reduced manpower costs and fewer physical branches. Despite no immediate overhead cost savings, the bank's digitalization efforts will continue to improve its cost-income ratio.

site_title: Global insurance market is well capitalised in the face of Covid-19
summary: Global insurers are well-capitalized to absorb the impact of the Covid-19 pandemic, according to a stress test by ratings agency AM Best. Most insurers performed well in the test, with adequate buffers against potential shocks to their balance sheets. However, life, health, and mortgage insurers were more sensitive to the pandemic's impact. Insurers are expected to see significant earnings hits in 2020, but their risk-adjusted capitalization remains strong. The pandemic's impact on businesses and markets worldwide has led to a surge in claims, with costs potentially reaching tens of billions of dollars or more.

site_title: Alarm as another German abattoir hit by coronavirus outbreak
summary: Germany has uncovered another coronavirus outbreak at a slaughterhouse, with 92 employees at the Westfleisch plant in Lower Saxony testing positive. The plant has been closed until further notice, joining a string of German slaughterhouses that have suffered similar outbreaks. This is the latest in a series of concerns about working conditions in the country's meat packing plants, with many cases among abattoir workers from eastern Europe. The government is set to discuss the issue on Monday, with calls for stricter oversight of working conditions and "far-reaching reforms" to improve health and safety for employees.

site_title: Europe: Shares gain on oil boost as economies reopen
summary: European shares rose 1.8% on Monday, rebounding from their worst week in two months, as investors awaited a gradual economic recovery with many countries easing lockdowns. Energy majors Total, BP, and Royal Dutch Shell surged 4% on rising oil prices, while German conglomerate Thyssenkrupp jumped 7% after talks to consolidate its loss-making steel business. Other countries, such as Italy, New York, and Spain, also lifted restrictions, providing a boost to markets.

site_title: WeWork's valuation has dropped to US$2.9b: SoftBank
summary: WeWork's valuation has dropped to US$2.9 billion due to the coronavirus pandemic and ongoing business struggles, a significant decrease from its peak of US$47 billion. SoftBank, its largest shareholder, reported earnings and disclosed the new valuation, following a bailout agreement in September. WeWork's co-founder Adam Neumann is locked in a legal battle with SoftBank over a scrapped US$3 billion deal, with Neumann claiming SoftBank relied on faulty pretexts to renege on the agreement.

site_title: UOL managers and above take pay cut to manage costs
summary: UOL, a property developer, announced a 18% salary reduction for managers and above, effective April 1, 2020, to manage costs. The company also implemented measures to reduce non-essential capital expenditure and operating costs, and tapped into government grants. Retail space occupancy remained steady at 95.2% despite a 12.4% decline in shopper footfall during the circuit-breaker period.

site_title: Australia: Shares end higher as rising commodity prices boost miners, energy stocks
summary: Australian shares rose 1.03% to 5,460.5 points, driven by gains in mining and energy stocks. Iron ore prices hit a record peak, boosting mining stocks, while copper prices climbed as economies reopened. Energy stocks saw their best day in almost two weeks, with oil prices rising 3.51% and 4.38% for Brent and US West Texas Intermediate crude, respectively.

site_title: eToro extends commission-free trading in US stocks to the Asia-Pacific
summary: eToro has extended its commission-free US stocks offering to Asia-Pacific clients, making it the first platform to do so globally. The zero-commission offering applies to Nasdaq and NYSE-listed stocks. This move aims to increase accessibility to US stocks for clients in Singapore, where most brokerages charge fees for trading US stocks and ETFs. eToro believes this expansion enhances its competitive edge in the market.

site_title: Saudi Arabia: Stocks extend gains, Aramco touches IPO price as oil prices jump
summary: Saudi Arabian shares rose 1.2% on Monday, driven by a jump in oil prices and positive corporate earnings from the banking sector. Saudi Aramco, the state-owned oil giant, advanced 1.5% and touched its initial public offering price of 32 riyals per share, while Al Rajhi Bank and Samba Financial Group also reported strong gains. Oil prices climbed 3.3% to $33.56 a barrel, supported by output cuts and signs of demand recovery amid easing coronavirus curbs.

site_title: English Premier League could show more matches on free-to-air, minister says
summary: English Premier League matches may be shown on free-to-air TV platforms, including the 3pm BST slot on Saturdays, to prevent fans from attending matches behind closed doors. Minister Oliver Dowden stated this could resume mid-June at the earliest, with the intention of increasing the number of free-to-air matches to prevent fans from leaving their homes to watch.

site_title: China supports inquiry 'after pandemic brought under control': Xi
summary: China's President Xi Jinping supports a "comprehensive evaluation" of the global response to the COVID-19 pandemic, following its control. Xi stated that China had a "open, transparent and responsible attitude" in sharing virus information. The World Health Assembly, held online, will discuss a resolution calling for an impartial evaluation of the international response to the crisis.

site_title: Seoul: Shares rise on hopes of economic recovery as lockdowns ease
summary: South Korean shares rose 0.51% on Monday, driven by hopes of global economic recovery as lockdowns ease. The Kospi index closed at 1,937.11, following South Korea's easing of social distancing rules. Despite this, shares of SK Hynix fell 1% after the US moved to curb shipments to Huawei. Analysts expect a narrow range for stock prices this week, with worries about coronavirus second waves offset by expectations of Chinese stimulus plans.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Monday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 6.72 points to 1,410.16 on Monday, driven by gains. The index saw 11.134 billion lots traded worth RM4.383 billion, with 663 gainers outnumbering 331 losers.

site_title: Healthtech startup Holmusk raises US$21.5m in Series A round
summary: Singapore-based healthtech startup Holmusk raised US$21.5 million in a Series A funding round led by Health Catalyst Capital and Optum Ventures. The new capital will be used to expand operations in the US and Asia, and to build a real-world evidence platform for behavioral health and chronic diseases. Holmusk plans to hire 30-40 additional staff to focus on data science, technology, and business development. The funding round is seen as a sign of the growing demand for digital solutions and data science in healthcare.

site_title: Aldi UK partners Deliveroo for grocery home delivery
summary: Aldi UK partners with Deliveroo for a trial grocery home delivery service, starting with a store in Nottingham. The service will allow customers to order over 150 products, including fresh produce and non-food items, for delivery via Deliveroo's network in 30 minutes. If successful, the service could expand to further Aldi stores by the end of 2020. This move follows Aldi's previous online sales expansion to help vulnerable customers during the coronavirus crisis, and is part of Britain's big four supermarkets' efforts to ramp up online delivery businesses.

site_title: Australians urged to avoid rush hour virus crush in return to work
summary: Australian officials have urged citizens to avoid rush hour crowds as the country's most populous state, New South Wales, begins its first full week of loosened lockdown measures. Premier Gladys Berejiklian plans to open pop-up parking lots and extra bicycle lanes in Sydney to maintain social distancing between commuters. The move comes as Australia's states and territories begin to allow more public activity under a three-step government plan, which officials credit with keeping the country's exposure to the pandemic relatively low.

site_title: Taiwan says did not receive WHO meeting invite, issue off the table for now
summary: Taiwan's Foreign Minister Joseph Wu stated that the country did not receive an invitation to this week's World Health Organization meeting due to Chinese pressure, despite efforts to participate. Taiwan had been lobbying for a seat on the assembly, citing its successful experience in fighting the coronavirus pandemic. China objects to Taiwan's participation unless it accepts being part of China, a stance Taiwan refuses. The issue has been put off until later this year, allowing the assembly to focus on the pandemic.

site_title: China's defence budget likely to grow despite economic cost of coronavirus
summary: China's defence budget is expected to increase despite the economic challenges posed by the coronavirus pandemic. The country's military spending, due to be announced this week, is likely to rise again, with some experts predicting a higher rate of growth than in 2019. This move is seen as a response to increased military pressure from the US and a desire to demonstrate China's military capabilities to the West. China's defence budget accounts for a relatively low percentage of its GDP, but the country's military is expected to continue expanding its capabilities.

site_title: Hotels firm Accor gets 560m euro credit line, sees signs of recovery
summary: Accor, a French hotel company, secured a 560 million euro credit facility, backed by several major banks, to support its recovery from the COVID-19 pandemic. With 42% of its hotels in operation, Accor reported initial signs of business improvement, including revenue growth in China. The company has reopened 250 hotels since April and has over 4 billion euros in liquidity. Accor's recovery efforts come after it warned of likely losses for April and May.

images.alt_text: French hotel company Accor - one of many in the tourism sector to have been hit hard by the impact of the coronavirus - said on Monday it had secured a new 560 million euros (S$864 million) banking credit facility.

site_title: 58-year-old woman who went to work at Bishan MRT station among 2 S'porean cases; 4 new clusters
summary: A 58-year-old Singaporean woman tested positive for COVID-19 after going to work at Bishan MRT station, alongside a 50-year-old man who tested positive in Tai Seng. This marks the lowest daily case count since April 12, with 305 new cases reported, mostly among foreign workers in dormitories. The Ministry of Health also announced four new clusters.

site_title: Sustainable Energy Future for Asean? Cities Decide
summary: ASEAN cities are crucial to the region's sustainable energy future, but are vulnerable to climate change and high population density. With 53% of the population living in cities, ASEAN cities are the biggest consumers of global primary energy and carbon dioxide emitters. To address this, cities are taking localized solutions, such as implementing waste-to-energy projects, launching bike-sharing systems, and developing comprehensive e-waste collection systems. International networks like the C40 Cities and ASEAN Smart Cities Network are also promoting sustainable urban development and energy transitions. Effective governance and regional cooperation are essential to achieving a sustainable energy future for ASEAN cities.

site_title: Thai Airways steps closer to restructuring in bankruptcy court
summary: Thai Airways International is closer to restructuring through a bankruptcy court after a key government panel backed the plan. The airline has outstanding debt of approximately 92 billion baht, with 78% owed to bond investors. Thai Airways has posted annual losses since 2013, and its shares have tumbled over 90% from a peak in 1999. A bankruptcy restructuring plan is due for consideration by the Cabinet on Tuesday, amid global efforts to prop up airlines affected by the coronavirus pandemic.

images.alt_text: Flag carrier Thai Airways International is a step closer to restructuring via a bankruptcy court after a key government panel backed the plan, which is due for consideration by the Cabinet on Tuesday.

site_title: Firms in Indonesia opting for debt over equity fundraising
summary: Indonesian companies are opting for debt over equity fundraising amid the COVID-19 pandemic, with over 98% of capital raised in the first four months of 2020 coming from debt. Indonesian bond issues reached $15.3 billion, more than double the previous year's amount. IPOs were valued at an average of $10 million, less than half of the previous year's average of $36 million. The country is on track to see its lowest amount of equity capital raised since the 2009 global financial crisis.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close higher despite weak growth data
summary: Tokyo stocks closed higher on Monday, defying weak growth data, as investors focused on improving coronavirus conditions. The Nikkei 225 index rose 0.48% to 20,133.73, while the Topix index gained 0.38% to 1,459.29. The data confirmed Japan's first recession since 2015, but investors prioritized hopes for a recovery amid the pandemic.

images.alt_text: Tokyo stocks closed higher Monday as investors shrugged off data confirming the Japanese economy had slipped into its first recession since 2015, focusing instead on hopes the coronavirus situation will improve.

site_title: US tells China not to intefere with its journalists in Hong Kong
summary: The US has warned China against interfering with American journalists working in Hong Kong, amid escalating tensions over press freedom and trade issues. US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo stated that journalists are part of a free press, not propaganda cadres, and any interference would impact the US assessment of Hong Kong's autonomy. China has previously expelled American journalists in response to US actions, and the issue has raised concerns about a new precedent and potential impact on international companies in Hong Kong.

site_title: Ryanair reports full-year profit up 13 per cent, cuts traffic for coming year
summary: Ryanair reported a 13% increase in full-year profit to 1 billion euros, but cut its annual passenger traffic target to 80 million due to the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic. The airline expects a loss of 200 million euros in the next quarter and lacks visibility on customer behavior, making a forecast for the full year impossible. This decision follows a 45% decline in shares over the past three months, amid increased competition from rivals and a global travel downturn.

images.alt_text: Ryanair on Monday reported a profit after tax of 1 billion euros (S$1.54 billion) for the year to March 31, but said it was unable to provide a forecast for the current year due to Covid-19 and cut its annual passenger traffic target by a further 20 per cent.

site_title: Emirates considers cutting 30,000 jobs, retire A380s faster
summary: Emirates Group is considering cutting 30,000 jobs, approximately 30% of its workforce, to reduce costs amid the coronavirus pandemic's impact on the airline industry. The airline also plans to accelerate the retirement of its A380 fleet, which could potentially end the program. Emirates raised $1.2 billion in new financing and is seeking aid from Dubai to cope with the travel downturn expected to last for years. The airline's president has warned that demand for airline travel will be "tempered" for at least the next couple of years.

site_title: SoftBank posts record 1.4t yen operating loss as tech bets slide
summary: SoftBank Group reported a record 1.4 trillion yen (S$18.55 billion) operating loss in the April-March financial year due to a 1.9 trillion yen loss at its US$100 billion Vision Fund. The fund's portfolio is underwater, with significant losses on WeWork and Uber investments. SoftBank's CEO Masayoshi Son's strategy is under strain as valuations tumble, and the company is forced to sell or monetize assets to finance a buyback to prop up its share price, including a potential sale of Alibaba Group.

site_title: Singapore F1 can't be held behind closed doors, say organisers
summary: Singapore F1 organisers say it's "not feasible" to hold the race behind closed doors due to the street circuit's layout, requiring temporary infrastructure that typically takes three months to set up. The Singapore Grand Prix, scheduled for September, is a night street race that drew 268,000 spectators last year. Organisers will continue to assess possibilities, prioritising fan safety and wellbeing amidst the COVID-19 pandemic. The event's feasibility remains uncertain, adding to the challenges of the coronavirus-affected Formula One season.

images.alt_text: Singapore F1 organisers Monday said it was "not feasible" to hold the race behind closed doors, threatening further problems for the coronavirus-ravaged season.

site_title: US auto industry to begin reopening plants in recovery from pandemic
summary: The US auto industry is slowly reopening its vehicle assembly plants after a two-month shutdown due to the coronavirus pandemic. General Motors, Ford Motor Co, and Fiat Chrysler Automobiles NV are resuming production with safety measures in place, including temperature monitors and personal protective equipment. The reopening is critical to ending the cash drain caused by the shutdown and is expected to impact the financial health of suppliers, which may struggle to stay afloat due to delayed payments. The industry aims to restart production of profitable vehicles such as the Chevrolet Suburban and Ford F-150 pickup truck.

site_title: Indonesia doubles volume of rice released to market to blunt price spike
summary: Indonesia's food procurement agency Bulog has doubled its rice release to the market, aiming to stabilize prices amid a coronavirus outbreak. As of May 17, Bulog distributed 596,305 tonnes of rice, more than double the 225,685 tonnes distributed in the same period last year. This move comes as other agencies have snapped up supplies, causing prices to remain high despite Indonesia's current rice harvest season.

site_title: SoftBank in talks to sell down T-Mobile US stake to Deutsche Telekom: WSJ
summary: SoftBank Group is in talks to sell a significant portion of its 24% stake in T-Mobile US to Deutsche Telekom, with the German carrier's stake potentially rising above 50%. The deal would help SoftBank raise $41 billion for its struggling tech investments and fund a record share buyback. Lock-up provisions from the 2019 merger would need to be altered to allow the transaction, which is expected to be completed in the coming months.

site_title: Subaru braces for coronavirus impact after full-year profit rises
summary: Subaru reported a 15.7% rise in annual operating profit to 210.3 billion yen (S$2.80 billion) for the year ended March, exceeding analyst estimates. However, the company warned that the coronavirus outbreak would impact car sales, with limited output expected in the coming months due to anaemic demand, supply chain disruptions, and social distancing measures. Subaru cut its year-end dividend by 61% and declined to give an earnings forecast for the current business year, citing uncertainties related to the virus.

site_title: Clifford Capital, SMBC provide US$140m in loans for Summit Power's Bangladesh power plant project
summary: Clifford Capital and Sumitomo Mitsui Banking Corporation (SMBC) have provided US$140 million in loans to Summit Power International's subsidiary for a 300-megawatt oil-fired power plant in Bangladesh's Gazipur district. The financing consists of a fixed-rate term loan from Clifford Capital and a floating-rate term loan from SMBC. The project, the first independent power project in Bangladesh to be financed solely by international commercial financing institutions, was awarded in 2017 and achieved commercial operations in 2018. The loans will be used for the development, construction, and operation of the power plant.

site_title: Gojek partners Deliveroo, Advo, Ebb & Flow to provide delivery jobs for drivers
summary: Gojek has partnered with Deliveroo, Advo, and Ebb & Flow to provide delivery jobs for its drivers amid the Covid-19 pandemic. Gojek drivers will deliver food from restaurants to customers in Central Singapore, while also participating in a meal delivery initiative to vulnerable single-parent households. This partnership aims to create additional earning opportunities for drivers and support those in need during the pandemic. Gojek has previously introduced measures to support its drivers, including grocery vouchers and ride vouchers for healthcare workers.

site_title: Anthem bill sparks new clashes in Hong Kong legislature
summary: Clashes broke out in Hong Kong's legislature on Monday as pro-democracy lawmakers tried to block a law banning insulting China's national anthem. Pro-government politicians installed a new chair, citing external legal opinion, but pro-democracy lawmakers claim the move is illegal. The chaos is part of an entrenched political crisis in Hong Kong, where calls for greater democracy have grown amid fears of Beijing's erosion of freedoms. Protests last year, sparked by a controversial extradition bill, have left the city's legislature without a leader and set the stage for further unrest.

site_title: ARA-backed Minterest sells out first real estate investment product in 11 minutes
summary: Minterest, a crowdfunding platform, launched its first real estate investment product backed by ARA Asset Management. The short-term, fixed-income product was snapped up in 11 minutes by investors seeking a 6% annual return. The product is secured by a Melbourne high-rise development project. ARA's stake in Minterest helped the platform develop more real estate investment options, with plans for future institutional-quality investments. The "overwhelming response" to the product is encouraging, with Minterest planning to expand into more investment opportunities.

site_title: New Jersey's boat charters are back as virus conditions improve
summary: New Jersey's boat charters resumed on May 17, 2020, with social distancing measures in place, as the state's coronavirus pandemic conditions improved. The state reported 1,272 new Covid-19 cases, bringing the total to 146,334, with 10,356 deaths. Hospitalized patients decreased by 58% to 3,411, with the lowest number of intubated patients since early April. Governor Phil Murphy announced the relaxation of restrictions, following a vow to bring the state's economy back with "deliberate incremental steps."

site_title: India's 'superfood' jackfruit goes global
summary: India, the world's largest producer of jackfruit, is capitalizing on its growing popularity as a "superfood" meat alternative globally. The fruit, with a pork-like texture when unripe, is gaining popularity in the West for its versatility and nutritional benefits. Indian farmers are seeing a surge in demand, with mature green jackfruit and seeds selling for $19.8 million annually. The pandemic has accelerated interest in vegan alternatives, and jackfruit is becoming a sought-after substitute for meat, with chefs and entrepreneurs hailing its potential as a nutritious and drought-resistant staple crop.

site_title: SK Hynix shares fall on demand worries after US curbs on Huawei chip supply
summary: SK Hynix shares fell 3.3% after the US Commerce Department imposed curbs on semiconductor supplies to Huawei, citing US chipmaking technology. The move stoked fears of reduced demand for mobile phones and components, particularly for SK Hynix and cross-town rival Samsung Electronics, which use US technology in their chipmaking. Analysts expect Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co Ltd (TSMC) to be impacted, while Samsung may benefit from Huawei's struggle in its smartphone business.

site_title: Malaysia's king upholds PM's appointment as opposition mounts challenge
summary: Malaysia's King Sultan Abdullah Sultan Ahmad Shah upheld Prime Minister Muhyiddin Yassin's appointment, stating it was proper and constitutional. The appointment, made on March 1, was challenged by the opposition who claimed it lacked majority support from parliament. The king's endorsement does not influence a vote in parliament, but he cited the Federal Constitution as supporting Muhyiddin's qualifications. The king's decision comes as parliament postponed a vote on an opposition challenge to Muhyiddin's leadership, with the next session scheduled for July 13 to August 27.

site_title: India should abandon budget gap aim this year, Modi adviser says
summary: India's government should abandon its budget deficit target for the year ending March due to the ongoing coronavirus outbreak, according to an adviser to Prime Minister Narendra Modi. The government had planned a 3.5% deficit, but with consumer demand collapsing and a recession looming, a dynamic approach to the deficit is needed. Goldman Sachs predicts a 5% economic contraction, while Nomura Holdings estimates a 7% deficit and a 5.2% output shrinkage. The adviser cited the unprecedented crisis and lack of fiscal flexibility as reasons for abandoning the target.

images.alt_text: India should refrain from setting a budget deficit target for the year ending March because the coronavirus outbreak is forcing the government to undertake unscheduled spending, an adviser to Prime Minister Narendra Modi said.

site_title: Uber may be able to raise Grubhub offer to 1.925 Uber shares: Dow Jones
summary: Uber may be able to increase its offer for Grubhub to 1.925 Uber shares per Grubhub share, up from 1.9 previously, according to people familiar with the matter. Grubhub CEO Matt Maloney had previously indicated the offer was too low. Uber and Grubhub chiefs continued deal talks over the weekend, but an agreement is still unlikely in the next few days. Delivery Hero and Just Eat Takeaway.com have considered possible bids but appear unlikely to make a move as Uber appears to be the front-runner.

site_title: New rules designed to keep US tech on top, says Huawei executive
summary: Huawei executive Richard Yu claims new US restrictions on the Chinese tech giant are actually designed to protect American tech dominance, not address cybersecurity concerns. Yu stated that the "key is the threat to the technology hegemony of the US" posed by Huawei. He also shared a link to a Chinese article questioning why the US wants to harm Huawei. The move is seen as a response to the US government's efforts to limit Huawei's global presence.

site_title: China sees post-lockdown rise in air pollution: study
summary: China's air pollution levels have risen after dropping during the COVID-19 lockdown, with average levels of nitrogen dioxide, sulfur dioxide, and fine particulate matter increasing compared to the same period in 2019. The rebound is attributed to industrial activity as the country reopens its economy. Concerns have been raised about the impact on public health, with campaigners urging governments to take tougher measures to clean up industries. The study suggests that the recovery from the pandemic may be reversing air quality gains, with emissions likely to continue unless stricter regulations are implemented.

images.alt_text: China's levels of some air pollutants have risen back to above last year's levels after dropping when the government imposed strict lockdown measures to contain the coronavirus pandemic, according to a study published on Monday.

site_title: China in communications with Australia over trade disputes: commerce minister
summary: China's commerce minister Zhong Shan confirmed the country is in communication with Australia over trade disputes, including the suspension of four beef exporters and a proposed 80% tariff on Australian barley shipments. The tensions stem from Australia's call for an independent inquiry into the COVID-19 pandemic's origins. China's decision to suspend the beef exports and impose tariffs on barley shipments have escalated tensions between the two nations.

site_title: England's anglers cast coronavirus worries aside, return to action
summary: England's anglers have flocked to lakes and reservoirs to cast their lines, ignoring coronavirus concerns, after the country eased lockdown restrictions. Days after the easing, anglers like Patrick Quelch and Mike Ward queued up to access lakes, with many arriving early to secure one of the 50 available tickets. Fisheries have implemented safety measures, allowing anglers to return to a much-needed escape from the pandemic, with many describing it as a form of mindfulness. Over 800 fish were caught in a single day, with anglers taking home six to eat, but the day is about more than just catching fish.

site_title: Broker's take: Maybank KE issues 'buy' on ComfortDelGro, sees 'increasingly defensive' earnings
summary: Maybank KE has reinitiated coverage on ComfortDelGro Corp with a "buy" call and a target price of S$1.99, citing an "increasingly defensive" revenue base and structural growth. Analysts believe longer-term public policy and ESG imperatives will favor public transport over private vehicle ownership. ComfortDelGro's shares were trading at S$1.51, up 3.4% at the midday break on Monday. The analyst sees significant exposure to a long-term structural theme, driven by Singapore's commitment to zero-car growth.

site_title: Asia: Equities climb as countries slowly reopen
summary: Asian equities rose as countries gradually reopened, despite a warning from the Federal Reserve that a full recovery is unlikely until next year. Infections and death rates fell in some worst-hit countries, allowing businesses to reopen and top-tier football to resume. Traders looked past the warning, focusing on the potential impact of a vaccine. Meanwhile, US stocks edged down from records amid tariff threats, and Europe's mining and healthcare sectors supported shares.

site_title: Pandemic exposing UK inequalities in age, education and work
summary: The UK pandemic is exposing and reinforcing existing inequalities in age, education, and work. A survey found children from wealthier families spend 30% more time on educational activities, while adults fear job losses and reduced wages. One in five workers worry about losing employment, and 77% believe the crisis will be worse than the 2008 recession. The government's furlough program is helping, but concerns remain about job losses once it's tapered. Experts call for a recovery plan and increased pay in sectors hit hard by the virus, particularly in education and social care.

site_title: China's trade faces 'unprecedented' challenges amid pandemic: commerce minister
summary: China's commerce minister, Zhong Shan, stated that global demand has significantly slumped due to the coronavirus pandemic, posing unprecedented challenges to the country's trade. Despite a slight increase in exports in April, China faces difficulties with imports, tight funding, and supply chain risks. The government plans to boost domestic demand and consumption to mitigate the impact of the pandemic.

site_title: Chinese miner CNMC's stake sale fails to win support from unit's shareholders
summary: A unit of state-owned China Nonferrous Metal Mining Group Co (CNMC) failed to win support from shareholders for a proposal to acquire shares in an affiliate with African copper and cobalt assets. The proposal, valued at 7.36 billion yuan, required a two-thirds majority but received less than 55% support from small- and medium-sized shareholders. The outcome may limit CNMC's control over the affiliate, which has mines in Zambia and the Democratic Republic of Congo. The proposal was opposed by Wanxiang Resources and China Mining International Investment Co, citing concerns over the company's recent net loss.

site_title: More Chinese dine out and schools reopen as normal life resumes
summary: Chinese citizens are gradually returning to normal life, with more people dining out and schools reopening. In downtown Beijing, restaurants are seeing increased occupancy, with some areas reaching 70% capacity. The reopening of schools, which has already seen over 100 million students return, is expected to boost demand for meat, cooking oil, and other products. This trend is also driving increased imports of soybeans, with companies anticipating record shipments from Brazil, potentially reaching 10 million tons this month. The recovery in hog breeding is seen as a key driver of demand for these products.

site_title: Warsaw's open-air Chopin concerts move online due to coronavirus
summary: Warsaw's annual Chopin open-air concerts, a traditional summer cultural event, have moved online due to coronavirus restrictions. For the first time in over six decades, the concerts featured pre-recorded music played from loudspeakers in the Royal Lazienki Park, with the option for fans to watch on YouTube. The decision was made to curb public gatherings, and organizers hope to resume in-person concerts before September, when the ban on public gatherings may be lifted.

site_title: Philippines' Cebu Air defers plane capex, seeks govt support amid virus crisis
summary: Cebu Air, the Philippines' largest budget carrier, has deferred its planned aircraft capital expenditure due to the coronavirus pandemic's impact on travel demand. The airline, which finalized the purchase of 30 Airbus aircraft last year, is reviewing its long-term fleet plan and discussing flexibility with suppliers. Cebu Air is also seeking government support in the form of emergency credit lines and fee waivers. The airline's decision follows similar moves by other carriers, such as Singapore Airlines, which reported its first-ever annual loss.

site_title: Dealing with job loss (Covid-19 Mental Health video series)
summary: Singapore-based psychologist Maria Micha advises individuals who have lost their jobs due to Covid-19 to stay mentally positive and focus on their strengths and skills. She emphasizes that losing a job does not mean losing those skills and encourages individuals to reinvent themselves by synthesizing existing skills with market information to find a unique role. Negative thoughts are seen as mere thoughts, not reality, and should not be allowed to defeat individuals. By staying mentally positive and proactive, individuals can innovate and find new opportunities in a rapidly changing job landscape.

site_title: Australia, New Zealand: Shares climb as more countries emerge from lockdown
summary: Australian stocks rose 0.9% on Monday, driven by optimism over countries emerging from lockdown and fueling an economic recovery. The S&P/ASX 200 index reached 5,452.9 points, with gold stocks surging 6.5% due to renewed US-China trade tensions. New Zealand's benchmark index also rose 0.4% as countries gradually lift restrictions. However, uncertainty arose over Australia's trade relations with China, with the country calling for an international enquiry into the pandemic's origins.

site_title: Broker's take: DBS downgrades ST Engg to 'hold' on limited upside potential
summary: DBS Group Research downgraded Singapore Technologies Engineering (ST Engineering) to 'hold' due to limited upside potential. The analysts lowered the target price to S$3.40 from S$4.60, citing the negative impact of global lockdowns on new order wins and existing order deliveries.

site_title: BGH, Bain, Indigo Partners, Cyrus Capital make Virgin Australia shortlist: source
summary: Virgin Australia Holdings' administrators have shortlisted four potential buyers: BGH Capital, Bain Capital, Indigo Partners, and Cyrus Capital Partners. The airline, which entered voluntary administration last month owing nearly A$7 billion, is expected to receive eight non-binding indicative offers before a submission deadline on Friday. The shortlisted parties will receive detailed financial and operational information before making final bids, with a deal aiming to be agreed by the end of June.

site_title: India's lockdown mints more than a million new stock traders
summary: During India's strict lockdown, the number of new stock traders has surged, with over 1.2 million new accounts opened in March and April. This is largely driven by retail investors seeking a buying opportunity in the stock market, which has seen its S&P BSE Sensex index 26% below its January peak. Online discount brokers such as Zerodha and Upstox have seen significant growth in account openings and trading volume, with many new investors, mostly under 30 years old, taking advantage of the low valuations.

site_title: US records 820 new coronavirus deaths in 24 hours: tracker
summary: The US reported 820 new coronavirus fatalities in the previous 24 hours, bringing the total death count near 90,000, according to a Johns Hopkins University tracker. The country also has 1,486,376 cases of novel coronavirus, the highest in the world. This marks the lowest daily death toll since May 10, but the count has ranged as high as 1,894 in subsequent days.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares begin Monday's session lower
summary: Hong Kong stocks began Monday's session lower, with the Hang Seng Index slipping 0.26% to 23,736.67. This follows fresh US data highlighting the global economy's impact from the virus. In contrast, China's Shanghai Composite Index rose 0.14% and the Shenzhen Composite Index edged up 0.09%.

site_title: Japan slips into recession, worst yet to come as pandemic wreaks havoc
summary: Japan's economy has slipped into recession for the first time in 4.5 years, with its GDP contracting 3.4% in the first quarter, according to preliminary data. The coronavirus crisis has severely impacted businesses and consumers, with private consumption and exports falling. The median forecast is for an annualised 22% contraction in the current quarter, the largest on record. The government has announced a record $1 trillion stimulus package, and the Bank of Japan has expanded stimulus measures to combat the economic blow.

site_title: Tech-heavy markets to emerge winners amid pandemic: DBS
summary: Tech-heavy markets are expected to outperform amid the COVID-19 pandemic, according to a report by DBS's chief investment office. Companies are undergoing accelerated digital transformations, driving the technology sector's dominance. The report notes sectoral composition is a key factor in stock market performance, with tech-related companies in the S&P 500 accounting for 37.4% of the index. The technology sector's 16.5% CAGR growth rate between 2002 and 2019 surpasses the broader market's 7.3% growth rate. The report concludes that the relationship between the stock market and macro data is "extremely weak" due to valuation, liquidity, and positioning.

site_title: Thai Q1 GDP falls 1.8% y-o-y, sharpest contraction in 8 years
summary: Thailand's economy contracted 1.8% in the first quarter of 2020, the sharpest decline in 8 years, due to the COVID-19 pandemic's impact on tourism and domestic activity. The state planning agency revised its GDP forecast to a 5.0-6.0% contraction for 2020, the worst since the 1998 Asian financial crisis. Economists expect the central bank to cut interest rates further to support the economy, which relies heavily on global trade and tourism.

site_title: Iran complains to UN, summons envoy over US threat on Venezuela shipment
summary: Iran has complained to the UN and summoned the Swiss ambassador, who represents US interests in Iran, over possible US measures against an Iranian fuel shipment to crisis-stricken Venezuela. The US was considering options in response to the shipment, which could disrupt Iran's oil sales. Iranian officials warned against any US threat, calling it "hegemonic gunboat diplomacy" that threatens freedom of international commerce and navigation. Iran reserves its right to take necessary measures to secure its legitimate rights and interests.

site_title: Ambani's Jio gets US$873m investment from General Atlantic
summary: Mukesh Ambani's Jio Platforms has secured a $873 million investment from US-based private equity firm General Atlantic, valuing the digital services business at $97.01 billion. This deal adds to Jio's recent funding rounds, taking the total investment to nearly $9 billion. The investment supports Jio's e-commerce drive and Ambani's plan to pay down debt, while also putting the company in direct competition with Amazon and Walmart in India's vast consumer markets.

site_title: Freeport cuts workforce at Grasberg mine as coronavirus cases in area rise
summary: Freeport-McMoRan Inc's Indonesian unit has cut its workforce at the Grasberg mine due to a rise in coronavirus infections in the area, including 150 cases and three deaths. The mine will operate with a "skeletal team" to ensure social distancing and prevent further spread of the virus. The move affects about 25,000 workers, with some contractors and workers in high-risk categories being removed or returning to their employers. Operations at the mine remain unaffected, and the company has taken measures to minimize the risk to workers.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Monday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened higher on Monday, rising 6.83 points or 0.49% to 1,410.27. The market saw 446.4 million lots traded worth RM79.3 million, with 311 gainers and 59 losers.

site_title: Apple reopening 25 more US stores, will soon top 100 worldwide
summary: Apple will reopen over 25 US stores, bringing the total to nearly a fifth of its worldwide retail outlets. The company initially closed all non-Greater China stores in March due to the coronavirus. This move follows the reopening of its first five US stores last week. Apple has 510 stores globally and 271 in the US.

site_title: Singapore shares rise on upbeat exports data; STI up 0.2% at open
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 0.2% at open, driven by a 9.7% increase in non-oil domestic exports in April, exceeding analyst expectations. Non-electronics exports surged 12.8%, with significant gains in pharmaceuticals and food preparations. Gainers outnumbered losers 103 to 44, with Thai Beverage Public Co rising 0.8% and Singtel gaining 0.4%. The index was boosted by local banks, with DBS, OCBC, and UOB rising 0.1-0.4%.

site_title: Ardern eyes virus-free haven as NZ charts rapid rebuild
summary: New Zealand aims to emerge as a virus-free haven, leveraging its successful early response to the pandemic to rebuild its economy. The government has announced a 20% fiscal stimulus package, predicting it will jump-start growth and lower the jobless rate to pre-virus levels within two years. This approach is seen as a positive departure from many other countries, with economists expressing cautious optimism about New Zealand's prospects for a "regular horrible recession." The country's lockdown strategy is being touted as a model for other nations.

site_title: Support for Japan's Abe hits 2-year low on virus and prosecutor bill
summary: Japan's Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's support rate has fallen to 33% in a survey, its lowest level in two years, due to criticism of his virus management and a bill that critics say gives him greater power to pick senior prosecutors. The government is considering dropping the bill after a massive public backlash. Despite the backlash, Abe is unlikely to face an immediate threat as opposition parties have low support rates. Japan's economy has also been hit by the pandemic, with a record 21.5% contraction expected this quarter.

site_title: Shares of Philippines' ABS-CBN slump as trading resumes after 8-day halt
summary: ABS-CBN, the Philippines' largest media company, saw its shares plummet 14% after the stock exchange resumed trading following an 8-day halt. The halt was due to the company's expired franchise, which was temporarily reinstated until the end of October.
