The suspension was a result of the government ordering the network to stop broadcasting. The stock exchange's decision allowed the shares to trade again, leading to a significant drop in value.

site_title: For cruise crew members stuck at sea, mental strain is huge
summary: Thousands of cruise ship crew members remain stranded at sea due to the coronavirus crisis, experiencing immense mental strain. At least three crew members have taken their own lives, and some fear a major mental health crisis is brewing. Crew members describe their situation as "Groundhog Day" with no end in sight, while others see the isolation as a positive opportunity for self-reflection and growth. The process of repatriation is slow and complicated, with many crew members facing uncertainty about their future and feeling trapped.

site_title: Fed's Powell says 'medical metrics' most important data for US economy now: CBS
summary: US Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell says medical metrics around the coronavirus pandemic are the most important data for the US economy, emphasizing the need for three to six more months of government financial help to prevent another outbreak. He urged Americans to follow social distancing rules and called for more fiscal spending to aid the recovery. Powell warned of a long road to recovery, with unemployment potentially hitting 25% and some industries under pressure until a vaccine is available, but expressed confidence in a steady recovery through the second half of the year.

images.alt_text: The most important data for the US economy right now are the "medical metrics" around the coronavirus pandemic, Federal Reserve (Fed) chairman Jerome Powell said Sunday night in broadcast remarks where he outlined the likely need for three to six more months of government financial help for firms and families.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher despite weak growth data
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Monday, despite weak growth data confirming Japan's first recession since 2015. The Nikkei 225 index rose 0.45% to 20,128.04, while the Topix index increased 0.39% to 1,459.45. Investors appeared to shrug off the economic data, instead focusing on gains on Wall Street and US-EU trade talks.

site_title: JPMorgan Asset says it's too soon for negative US rates
summary: JPMorgan Asset Management's head of global rates, Seamus Mac Gorain, has expressed skepticism about the possibility of negative US rates in the near future. The Fed has pushed back against the idea, focusing on balance sheet tools instead. Futures markets, however, are pricing in the possibility of negative rates for the second quarter of 2021, contradicting the Fed's stance. Mac Gorain believes it may take three to four years for the economy to show signs of weakness before the Fed considers negative rates.

site_title: London office construction hit a record just as virus arrived
summary: London's office construction reached a record high of 5 million square feet in the six months leading up to March, driven by the UK's general election in December. However, with the UK's recession and the coronavirus, developer confidence has plummeted, leaving commercial tenants struggling to pay rent and questioning future space needs.

images.alt_text: London's office construction rebounded to a record high earlier this year. And then the coronavirus arrived.

site_title: Italy shops to reopen Monday, but for many It's already too late
summary: Italy's retail businesses reopen on Monday, but many merchants say they're facing significant economic damage from the coronavirus lockdown. Many stores, including some in Rome, will remain closed due to lack of funds. Giulio Anticoli, a family-owned shoe and clothing store owner, fears his creditors will be "all over" him once he raises his portcullis, highlighting the dire financial situation. The country's 2.7 million merchants are struggling to recover from the economic downturn caused by the lockdown.

images.alt_text: Italy's shoppers may be digging out their wallets as retail businesses reopen on Monday, but many of the country's 2.7 million merchants say there's little to celebrate.

site_title: Visitors to UK shops drop 85% during virus lockdown: survey
summary: A survey by the British Retail Consortium found that footfall in UK shops dropped 84.7% year-on-year in April, with the majority of physical stores closed due to the coronavirus lockdown. This resulted in a 19.1% drop in total sales, the largest since the BRC began its monthly index in 1995. Many retail firms are shutting stores to cut costs and focus on online operations, as the UK economy shrunk by a record 6% in March.

site_title: Alibaba's Jack Ma resigns from SoftBank board
summary: SoftBank Group Corp announced that Alibaba co-founder Jack Ma will resign from its board, effective at the annual general meeting on June 25. Ma, who retired as Alibaba's executive chairman in September, will focus on philanthropy. SoftBank will propose three new board appointments, including CFO Yoshimoto Goto, CEO Lip-Bu Tan, and professor Yuko Kawamoto. The departures come as SoftBank CEO Masayoshi Son seeks to restructure the board.

site_title: New Zealand's resident population tops 5 million
summary: New Zealand's resident population has reached 5 million, surpassing the previous record of 4 million in 2003. This milestone was achieved in just over six years, with a 1.8% annual growth rate since 2013, driven by net migration. The population growth is attributed to increased net migration due to citizens returning home after living abroad and fewer moving overseas. The COVID-19 pandemic has also contributed to the recent surge in residents.

site_title: China home prices rise again in April, adding momentum to recovery
summary: China's new home prices rose 0.5% in April, the fastest pace since October, driven by easing virus restrictions and increased liquidity. Home prices increased 5.1% annually, following a 5.3% increase in March. The market's recovery is underpinned by pent-up demand, easier access to mortgages, and lower interest rates. While the government has not relaxed property policies, local authorities have introduced measures to help developers, including a "hukou" reform to boost urban consumption. The property market is expected to continue recovering, with some areas outperforming, but analysts caution that broader recovery is unlikely due to mortgage and purchase restrictions.

site_title: Amazon contractors hit hard by pandemic
summary: Amazon contractors, who are third-party delivery firms working on behalf of the company, are struggling financially and without adequate benefits during the COVID-19 pandemic. Adrienne Williams, a 42-year-old California single mother, joined protests calling for better pay and benefits, citing the lack of health care benefits despite promises from her "delivery service provider." Amazon has announced temporary measures, including a $2-an-hour pay boost, but Williams says it's insufficient for her to live in an expensive region like San Francisco.

site_title: Yoma Strategic's mobile payments JV ties up with Alipay operator Ant Financial
summary: Yoma Strategic's mobile payments joint venture, Wave Money, has tied up with Alipay operator Ant Financial, investing US$73.5 million in the company. The partnership aims to promote financial inclusion in Myanmar, focusing on unbanked and underbanked communities. With this investment, Ant Group will become a substantial minority stakeholder, enhancing Wave Money's digital competence and capabilities. Yoma Strategic's CEO, Melvyn Pun, expects the partnership to boost Wave Money's capabilities in a cashless society, driven by the Covid-19 pandemic and e-commerce growth.

site_title: Money FM podcast: South-east Asia's C-suites preparing themselves for post-Covid-19
summary: South-east Asian C-suites are preparing for a prolonged post-Covid-19 economic impact, according to the EY Global Capital Confidence Barometer. Experts anticipate the pandemic will have a deeper effect on the economy, prompting C-suites to reassess their crisis management strategies. Vikram Chakravarty, ASEAN transaction advisory services leader at EY, advises C-suites to adopt more proactive and agile approaches to mitigate potential risks, including diversifying revenue streams and enhancing risk management systems. The shift towards more proactive crisis management is seen as crucial for long-term success in the post-pandemic era.

site_title: UK government boosts vaccine funding as daily virus deaths fall
summary: The UK government has increased funding for COVID-19 vaccine development to £250 million, with a focus on accelerating trials and mass production. The new funding aims to produce 30 million doses by September, with the UK set to be first in line for access. The government also announced a £93 million boost to build a specialist vaccine manufacturing centre, which will be completed a year ahead of schedule. Despite the progress, Prime Minister Boris Johnson acknowledged public frustration with the ongoing restrictions.

site_title: 2.5% of workers at NSL's Dubai unit test positive for Covid-19
summary: NSL's Dubai unit reported 2.5% of workers testing positive for Covid-19, despite precautions, as of April 30. Several customers' sites were temporarily closed due to the spread of the virus among contractors. The company did not disclose the number of workers who tested positive. This follows a period of increased cases in the region.

site_title: Bank of England examining negative rates: chief economist
summary: The Bank of England is examining unconventional monetary policy measures, including negative interest rates, amid the economic slump caused by the coronavirus pandemic. Chief Economist Andrew Haldane stated that the central bank is reviewing policies to include riskier securities and may consider borrowing costs going below zero. However, Haldane emphasized that these measures are not imminent and that the BOE is also exploring other options, including expanding its asset-purchase plan. The European Central Bank has already cut rates below zero, sparking debate about the effectiveness of negative rates.

site_title: France coronavirus death toll rises to 28,108: ministry
summary: France reported 483 new coronavirus deaths on May 17, 2020, bringing the total to 28,108. This is the highest number since April 23, but a health ministry spokeswoman attributed the increase to "additional data." The number of confirmed cases rose to 142,481, and hospital and intensive care unit admissions declined. These indicators have been trending downward for four to five weeks, indicating the French health system's ability to cope with the epidemic is improving.

site_title: Michael Jordan memorabilia soars in value amid Last Dance nostalgia
summary: Michael Jordan memorabilia has seen a surge in value amid the global success of the documentary "The Last Dance" and the COVID-19 lockdown. Sales of collectibles, including sneakers, jerseys, and trading cards, have increased by hundreds of thousands of dollars. The game-worn Air Jordan 1 sneakers sold for $240,000 at Sotheby's, while a 1986 Fleer collector's card sold for $96,000. The documentary's success has fueled interest in Jordan, making him the most sought-after collectible personality, with sales of Bulls-branded items up 400% in May.

site_title: Nigeria seizes British plane for flouting virus flight ban
summary: Nigeria has seized a British plane, Flair Aviation, for violating a travel ban imposed to curb the spread of COVID-19. The airline was authorized for humanitarian flights but operated commercial flights, sparking outrage from Nigeria's aviation minister. The plane has been impounded, and the crew is being interrogated, with maximum penalties expected. Nigeria has shut its airports and airspace since March to contain the virus, which has infected 5,621 people and claimed 176 lives.

site_title: UK-flagged tanker repulses pirate attack in Gulf of Aden
summary: A UK-flagged chemical tanker, Stolt Apal, was attacked by armed pirates in the Gulf of Aden on May 17, 2020. The pirates approached the ship in two speedboats but were repulsed after the armed guard team fired warning shots and returned fire, disabling one skiff. The ship sustained minor damage but no injuries or cargo damage. A coalition warship responded and the vessel resumed its voyage. This incident is the ninth reported pirate attack in the Gulf of Aden this year, highlighting ongoing security concerns in the region.

site_title: Pharma shipments lift Singapore exports for third straight month
summary: Singapore's exports unexpectedly rose 9.7% year-on-year in April, driven by a surge in pharmaceuticals, marking the third straight month of expansion. This contradicts economists' predictions of a 5% decline. However, uncertainties surrounding the Covid-19 pandemic and US-China trade tensions continue to impact Singapore's trade prospects.

site_title: CDC 'let the country down' on coronavirus testing: White House
summary: The White House criticized the CDC for its handling of coronavirus testing, stating it "let the country down" due to a faulty test and bureaucratic delays. The CDC had been under scrutiny since producing a faulty test, and critics argue it could have accepted WHO-provided kits instead. The FDA also criticized the CDC for not following its own protocols. The US has the world's largest coronavirus outbreak, with over 88,000 deaths and 1.5 million confirmed cases, and has been slow to roll out testing, with only 12 million Americans tested out of 330 million people.

site_title: Eagle Hospitality Trust posts US$8.9m Q1 loss
summary: Eagle Hospitality Trust (EHT) has posted a US$8.9 million loss for the first quarter to March, primarily due to an impairment loss on trade receivables from uncertain master lessees. Revenue and net property income fell 24.4% and 31.7% below projections, respectively, mainly due to the global pandemic. The trust's net asset value per stapled security decreased to US$0.83, and trading in its securities has been suspended since March 24. The Reit manager has withdrawn profit and distribution forecasts for the financial year ending December 2020.

site_title: Oil prices climb more than US$1 ahead of WTI June contract expiry
summary: Oil prices surged by more than US$1 a barrel on Monday, reaching their highest in over a month, driven by output cuts and signs of fuel demand recovery. Brent crude rose 4.1% to US$33.84 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude jumped 4.8% to US$30.83 a barrel. The June WTI contract's expiry is seen as a factor, with production cuts and Opec+ agreeing to maintain existing oil cuts beyond June. US Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell expressed optimism about economic recovery, further supporting oil prices.

images.alt_text: Oil prices jumped by more than US$1 a barrel on Monday to their highest in more than a month, supported by ongoing output cuts and signs of gradual recovery in fuel demand as more countries ease curbs imposed to stop the coronavirus pandemic spreading.

site_title: Stocks to watch: UOB, Sembcorp, OUE, Singapore Airlines, NetLink
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

Singapore stocks saw mixed developments on Monday, with UOB's online investment product sales surging 406% in Q1, while OUE's net profit jumped to $87.1 million. Sembcorp Industries redeemed a $200 million perpetual security, and Singapore Airlines' shares fell amid bearish analyst views. NetLink NBN Trust's fibre service delivery was affected by the coronavirus outbreak. Other companies, such as Japfa, Del Monte Pacific, and Yoma Strategic, saw gains. Meanwhile, Chip Eng Seng's planned joint investment in China fell through, and NSL reported a COVID-19 outbreak at one of its subsidiaries.

site_title: WHO committee to discuss Taiwan exclusion
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) is set to discuss Taiwan's participation as an observer at the World Health Assembly, despite being excluded. Nearly 15 countries have requested the issue be added to the agenda, but the WHO claims only member states can decide. The proposal will be considered by the General Committee, which will likely make a decision during the physical meeting at the end of the year. A vote could be difficult due to the virtual format of the assembly, but not impossible.

site_title: India extends nationwide lockdown through May as virus cases rise
summary: India extended its nationwide lockdown until the end of May as the country reported its biggest single-day jump in COVID-19 cases, with 4,987 new infections. The lockdown, which has affected 1.3 billion people, aims to contain the spread of the virus while easing economic pain. Some sectors, such as restaurants and sports complexes, will be permitted to operate with restrictions, while others, including schools and cinemas, remain closed.

site_title: Game-worn Air Jordan sneakers sell for record-breaking US$560,000
summary: A pair of game-worn Air Jordan sneakers worn by Michael Jordan in 1985 sold for a record-breaking US$560,000 at Sotheby's auction house, surpassing the previous record held by "Moon Shoes" sold for US$437,000 in 2019. The white, black, and red shoes, autographed by Jordan, were part of the "Chicago" color scheme of the Air Jordan 1 model, considered the most iconic sneakers of all time. The sale highlights the growing market value of items associated with the retired basketball superstar, particularly since the release of "The Last Dance" documentary.

site_title: HSBC, Citi speed up digital push to ward off Asian upstarts
summary: Banks in Asia's financial hubs, such as HSBC and Citigroup, are accelerating their digital push to counter the threat from virtual upstarts due to the coronavirus outbreak. With branches shut and customers increasingly using digital services, these banks are rolling out new video services and mobile features to cement customer loyalty and reduce costs. The surge in digital activity is expected to have a long-term impact on their balance sheets, with potential gains for the bottom line absorbing some of the shock from loan losses.

site_title: World monetary policy stance may not be as easy as it appears
summary: Central banks' monetary policy stance may be tighter than expected as the surge in government debt issuance outpaces their asset buying programs. Analysts predict higher yields and steeper curves in the medium term due to a growing proportion of bonds ending up in private hands. The Federal Reserve's buying has not matched the US government's record stimulus, and only New Zealand is set to see a decline in publicly held debt. This could lead to increased calls for negative interest rates or yield curve control policies to manage government deficits and borrowing costs.

site_title: Thyssenkrupp in talks with peers over steel business: source
summary: Thyssenkrupp, Germany's largest steelmaker, is in talks with international peers to consolidate its loss-making steel business. The talks follow a 372 million euro loss by Thyssenkrupp Steel Europe in the first half of the fiscal year. Thyssenkrupp is discussing a potential sale or shutdown of assets with Tata Steel, SSAB, and Baoshan Iron & Steel, with both parties interested in acquiring a majority stake in the German firm's steel unit. The strategy revamp is expected to be unveiled on Monday.

site_title: Covid-19 market turmoil: Is the worst over?
summary: A recent market rebound has raised concerns among "market timers" that the worst is yet to come, with some considering selling their US stocks due to worsening corporate profitability. Financial advisers often caution against market timing, and the author questions their own motives and potential regret. The article highlights various market and economic news, including rising oil prices, declining stocks, and tariff threats, which may impact investor decisions.

images.alt_text: With economic activity and international trade slowing quickly, companies were suffering reduced cash flow and needed to borrow more US dollars. The tighter US dollar liquidity that ensued weighed on the markets.

site_title: UOB has 406% rise in Q1 purchase of investment products
summary: United Overseas Bank (UOB) reported a 406% increase in online purchases of its investment products in Q1 compared to the same period last year. Investors sought defensive and diversified assets amid market uncertainty. UOB's advisory team provided six video updates and written reports to clients, attracting high viewership, and its digital investment platform, Portfolio Advisory Tools (PAT), helped one in four non-active wealth clients become active. The bank also reassessed investment portfolios with its risk-first approach, leveraging technology to engage customers.

site_title: India plans to suspend new bankruptcy filings for a year
summary: India plans to suspend new bankruptcy filings for a year to mitigate the economic impact of the coronavirus outbreak. Finance Minister Nirmala Sitharaman announced the plan, raising the minimum threshold for initiating insolvency proceedings to 10 million rupees. This move aims to largely insulate small businesses from bankruptcy. The decision is part of efforts to revive economic activity.

site_title: SoftBank concentration risk comes to the fore in Asia tech ecosystem
summary: SoftBank's Vision Fund is expected to announce a massive 1.8 trillion yen (S$24.2 billion) loss in its US$100 billion portfolio for the year ended March, marking the group's first loss in 15 years. This comes amid soured bets on WeWork and valuation writedowns on startups impacted by Covid-19. The loss may pressure SoftBank's Asian portfolio companies, including ByteDance and Oyo, which rely on the Japanese conglomerate for funding. Companies with diverse shareholder bases may be more resilient, while those heavily reliant on SoftBank may face headwinds, potentially forcing them to exit or diversify their investor pool.

site_title: Japfa fishes for growth in aquaculture
summary: Japfa, a Singapore-based food company, aims to double its aquaculture segment, the smallest of its five business pillars, in the next three to four years. The segment, which generates 7% of its revenue, has been growing steadily, with aqua-feed sales volume increasing 22% and 15% in FY18 and FY19, respectively. CEO Tan Yong Nang believes the trend of farmed fish production will outpace wild fishing and that research into commercial fish farming will help reduce operating costs. Japfa plans to focus on upstream operations and expand into new markets, with a "five-by-five mosaic" expansion blueprint.

site_title: Transformation coming soon to lagging Hang Seng Index
summary: The Hang Seng Index, a 50-year-old benchmark, is expected to undergo significant changes, potentially transforming it from a gauge dominated by banks and insurers to one better reflecting China's technological dynamism. Companies with unequal voting rights, such as Alibaba Group Holding, may be included for the first time, which could lead to a shift in the index's weighting. The changes could spur a surge in local share sales by US-listed firms, benefiting Hong Kong's stock market.

site_title: Air France's grounded pilots sent to simulator
summary: Air France is sending grounded pilots through flight simulator training as the airline prepares to resume flights to suspended destinations. The carrier plans to increase capacity to about 10% of normal levels by mid-June, up from 3-5% currently. This move aims to gradually restore flights as COVID-19 lockdown measures are lifted.

site_title: Saudi sovereign wealth fund seeks margin loan
summary: Saudi Arabia's Public Investment Fund (PIF) is seeking a $10 billion margin loan by pledging stakes in SoftBank Group Corp's technology investment vehicle, the Vision Fund. The move aims to shore up liquidity as PIF embarks on an investment spree since the start of the Covid-19 pandemic. PIF has built stakes in major companies, including Facebook, Boeing, and Citigroup, and expects to see opportunities in the crisis-affected sectors. The loan follows a similar plan by Qatar's sovereign wealth fund to raise funds against its European equity investments.

site_title: US stock market volatile but stays at elevated levels
summary: US stocks fell last week amid warnings from infectious diseases expert Anthony Fauci about premature reopenings and potential second waves of COVID-19. Dr. Fauci's comments, coupled with unexpected salvos in the US-China trade war, contributed to the market volatility. The US stock market remains at elevated levels, with concerns about a potential selloff later this week if China responds to US efforts to restrict Huawei's access to chip technology or if COVID-19 cases surge in reopened states.

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary: The Baltic Exchange's Capesize 5TC index plummeted 50% in value, closing at $2394, due to a combination of factors including interrupted cargo supplies, cheap bunkers, and demand destruction amid the Covid-19 pandemic. A small rebound at the end of the week offered slim hopes for a faster market recovery. The iron ore stockpile situation in China has led to a sharp drop in inventories, which may require additional tonnage.

site_title: China central bank should avoid buying special treasury bonds: adviser
summary: China's central bank should avoid buying special treasury bonds to prevent fueling inflation risks and asset bubbles, and to avoid depreciation of the yuan currency, according to policy adviser Ma Jun. The move is seen as a risk to China's credit rating and could encourage excessive government borrowings. Ma Jun suggested that the central bank could instead cut banks' reserve requirement ratios or provide liquidity to support economic growth. China's leaders have pledged to monetize its fiscal deficit through quantitative easing to support the virus-ravaged economy.

site_title: ESG investments show resilience in crisis
summary: ESG investments have shown resilience during the Covid-19 market crisis, with sustainable funds attracting US$45.6 billion in the first quarter of 2020, compared to an outflow of US$384.7 billion in the overall funds universe. Despite the decline in assets, Morningstar notes that ESG funds tend to be more "sticky" and have higher long-term performance. Recent outperformance of ESG-rated stocks and funds has also been observed, with some indices returning higher than their benchmark counterparts. Experts attribute this to ESG-integrated funds' focus on robust and resilient companies, rather than just excluding high-risk stocks.

site_title: FMR LLC increases deemed interests in First Resources
summary: FMR LLC increased its deemed interest in First Resources to 6.10% after purchasing 1,997,300 shares for S$2,436,706. Fidelity Management & Research Company LLC also increased its deemed interest in First Resources to 5.30% following the purchase. Meanwhile, UOB-Kay Hian Holdings chairman Wee Ee Chao increased his stake in the company to 29.97%. Other notable transactions include Hong Lai Huat Group's deputy chairman Ong Bee Huat acquiring 513,300 shares for S$66,709 and Roxy-Pacific Holdings independent director Winston Tan Tien Hin acquiring 100,000 shares for S$32,500.

site_title: Alibaba on track to recovery
summary: Alibaba is on track to recovery, driven by the growth of e-commerce and cloud computing following the COVID-19 pandemic. The company's market share in China's cloud business is leading the market, and its cash flow from operating activities has been steadily growing. Despite a lower earning-per-share forecast for Q1, Alibaba's share price has recovered, forming an uptrend support line. Technical analysis suggests a bullish trend, but traders are advised to remain cautious due to potential profit taking at key resistance levels and the ongoing US-Sino trade war.

site_title: The future of frequent flying
summary: Business travel is expected to resume gradually, but at a reduced level, post-pandemic. CEOs and industry experts emphasize the importance of face-to-face interactions and the need for careful risk assessment. Digital transformation will accelerate in the aviation industry, with contactless interactions and technology-driven solutions becoming the norm. Companies will be cautious in reintroducing business travel, prioritizing employee safety and leveraging virtual ways of working. The recovery of business travel is expected to be slow, with most companies focusing on cutting costs and a vaccine being widely available.

site_title: Vietnam 'most outstanding' in handling of Covid-19: Control Risks report
summary: Vietnam has been praised by a Control Risks report as the most outstanding Asian economy in handling the Covid-19 pandemic, thanks to its toned-down authoritarianism and targeted resourcing. The report's author cited Vietnam's low-cost, low-impact campaign of deep quarantine and mobile testing, coupled with social distancing measures, as a key factor in its success. In contrast, Indonesia and the Philippines have been criticized for their lack of preparedness, while China remains the poster child for effective infection suppression.

site_title: India's gas demand gradually picking up as virus restrictions ease
summary: India's natural gas consumption is slowly recovering as the country eases its lockdown, allowing some economic activity to resume in areas with low Covid-19 cases. The government's decision to lift restrictions has led to a gradual increase in gas demand, with industry sources indicating a slow recovery. Despite ongoing virus restrictions, the government is taking steps to boost economic activity, including allowing the resumption of industrial activity.

site_title: Australia says China ignores calls to ease trade tension
summary: Australia has urged China to respond to its calls to discuss easing trade tensions between the two countries. China has suspended beef imports from four Australian meat processors and is considering imposing tariffs on barley imports. Australian Trade Minister Simon Birmingham has requested talks with his Chinese counterpart, but China has accused Australia of playing "petty tricks". The tension comes as Australia has called for an international inquiry into the origins of the novel coronavirus. China has refused, leading to a stalemate in trade negotiations.

site_title: Growth in China's industrial production lifts prices of metals
summary: China's industrial production rose 3.9% in April, exceeding analysts' predictions, indicating a slight recovery from a 1.1% decline in March. This growth is expected to lift metals prices, particularly copper, which has been a leader in setting the tone for other base metals. Analysts attribute the revival to the government's potential boost in spending on infrastructure and construction, driving demand for metals like copper and aluminium. However, a potential deficit in global copper output due to falling demand in the West and increasing demand in other regions may lead to higher prices.

site_title: Next Jobs Support Scheme payout to be disbursed from May 28
summary: The next instalment of the Jobs Support Scheme (JSS) in Singapore, providing S$4 billion in wage support for over 140,000 employers, will be disbursed from May 28. Employers will receive 75% support for the first S$4,600 of wages paid to local employees, based on last November wages. Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat urged companies to retain their workers using the JSS wage subsidies, as the total committed under the scheme now exceeds S$20 billion.

site_title: Indonesian govt plans US$8.6b Covid-19 bailout for state firms
summary: The Indonesian government plans a $8.6 billion bailout for 12 state-owned firms to mitigate the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic. The financial support will be provided through cash compensation and working capital investments, with key recipients including national carrier Garuda Indonesia, power utility Perusahaan Listrik Negara, and steelmaker Krakatau Steel. The government has proposed a total of $12.28 billion in financial support, which still requires President Joko Widodo's approval.

images.alt_text: Garuda Indonesia, which is trying to restructure US$500 million worth of Islamic bonds that mature next month, would receive 8.5 trillion rupiah in working capital investments.

site_title: 2020 list of UK's richest shows first fall in wealth in a decade
summary: The UK's richest individuals saw a combined annual wealth drop for the first time in a decade, with a loss of £54 billion, largely due to the coronavirus pandemic. Despite this, inventor James Dyson topped the list with an estimated £16.2 billion, thanks to strong business performance. The Hinduja brothers and Jim Ratcliffe also experienced significant falls in their fortunes, with some losing as much as £6 billion. The total wealth of Britain's super-rich decreased to £743 billion, and the number of billionaires dropped by four to 147.

site_title: Isetan Singapore issues H1 loss warning
summary: Isetan Singapore has warned of a loss for the first half of 2020 due to the novel coronavirus pandemic and disruptions to its retail business. The company's stores remain closed until June 1, and its renovation project at Isetan Scotts has been delayed, leading to a decrease in revenue. Despite measures to lower operating expenses, the retailer expects challenges in the second half of the year, with potential rental revenue impacts and uncertainty over the pandemic's end.

site_title: URA orders Robertson Quay restaurants to stop selling takeaway alcohol
summary: The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) in Singapore has ordered restaurants along Robertson Quay to stop selling takeaway alcohol due to social distancing breaches. The move comes after photos of people gathering and flouting safe distancing measures went viral on Facebook. URA has issued a written direction to the restaurants, stating that selling takeaway alcohol contributed to more individuals gathering. The directive is part of Singapore's efforts to prevent gatherings and enforce safe distancing measures during the circuit-breaker period.

site_title: Hollywood hype machine plots virus-proof red carpets
summary: Hollywood is developing virus-proof red carpet premieres as California coronavirus restrictions ease. Event planners are incorporating plexiglass barriers, screened-off "pods" for interviews, and drop-off zones for socially-distanced fan interactions. Temperature checks and limited fan attendance are also being considered. While lavish parties may be delayed, publicists are exploring virtual press junkets and pop-up immersive experiences to maintain awareness. The focus is shifting to building excitement for upcoming movies, with Warner Bros' Tenet set to be the first major Hollywood blockbuster back in theaters on July 17.

site_title: Remote working set to stay post-pandemic
summary: Remote working due to the coronavirus pandemic may lead to companies slashing office space to save money, despite potential negative impacts on productivity. Experts question the future of skyscrapers as symbols of modern capitalism. As lockdowns ease, businesses may permanently allow staff to work from home, challenging traditional office space usage. This shift could result in cost savings but may not necessarily improve employee productivity.

site_title: Business outlook falls below 2008 crisis level to record low: poll
summary: Singapore businesses report record-low optimism, with a net balance of 84% expecting worsening business over the next six months. Sales, profits, and orders have fallen at a faster pace, with scores dropping by 40, 35, and 41 points respectively. The economy is expected to contract by 4.3-5% in the second quarter, with some economists predicting a 15-20% shrinkage in gross domestic product. The pandemic-driven recession is seen as worse than the 2008 global financial crisis, with larger firms and foreign firms being more despondent about their prospects.

images.alt_text: Singapore companies saw their worst levels of business since the Asian financial crisis in the first three months of the year, as the deadly novel coronavirus pandemic forced the economy into hibernation.

site_title: Straco's Underwater World Xiamen to reopen on May 17 at 30% capacity
summary: Straco Corp's Underwater World Xiamen will reopen on May 17 at 30% capacity, following the resumption of operations for Shanghai Ocean Aquarium on May 15 and Lixing Cable Car on March 20. The attraction joins others in China to reopen, with measures in place to control visitor numbers and prevent the spread of the novel coronavirus. Temperature screening, contact tracing, and safe distancing will be implemented, in addition to the visitor capacity limit.

site_title: ThaiBev expects Covid-19 to accelerate off-premise sales
summary: Thai Beverage Public Co (ThaiBev) expects Covid-19 to accelerate off-premise sales, as consumers shift to online or supermarket purchases during lockdowns. On-trade sales are unlikely to rebound quickly due to ongoing restrictions on social gatherings. Despite this, ThaiBev's spirits segment remains resilient, posting a 9.5% increase in net profit in its second quarter. The company plans to cut advertising and focus on off-trade marketing, while analysts maintain a "buy" call and revised target price for ThaiBev.

site_title: Europe should temporarily ban Chinese takeovers: Germany's Weber
summary: European Union leader Manfred Weber suggests a 12-month ban on Chinese takeovers of undervalued or crisis-hit European companies. He aims to protect the EU from "Chinese shopping tours" amid the coronavirus crisis. Weber views China as a strategic competitor and an authoritarian power, but emphasizes the need for vigilance. The German government has already tightened rules to shield domestic firms from non-EU takeovers. Chinese and EU leaders are set to meet in September, but the meeting's fate is uncertain due to the pandemic.

site_title: Temporary layoff schemes no cure-all in slow Covid-19 recovery
summary: Temporary unemployment schemes across Europe may not effectively save jobs in the leisure and travel sectors, which are expected to take a long time to recover from the Covid-19 pandemic. The schemes, championed by Germany, provide 80% pay for workers for a limited period but may not be sustainable, with the UK bill for covering 7.5 million workers expected to reach £8 billion per month. Experts warn that the schemes are only a temporary solution and that industries like tourism and retail may experience permanent shifts.

images.alt_text: A closed travel agency store in UK. Temporary layoff schemes work well for sectors of the economy that can bounce back well. However, the tourism or entertainment sectors does not look set for a V-shaped recovery.

site_title: NSL sees loss for half year on oil price collapse, Covid-19 containment measures
summary: NSL, a Singaporean mainboard-listed company, expects a loss for the half-year to June due to the collapse of oil prices and COVID-19 containment measures. Its subsidiaries, Eastern Pretech and NSL Chemicals, initially operated at reduced capacity but had to stop work from April 27 to June 1. The company attributed the financial losses to the circuit breaker measures, which limited their operations.

site_title: HSBC, Citi speed up digital push to ward off Asian upstarts
summary: HSBC and Citigroup are accelerating their digital push to counter the threat from Asian virtual upstarts amid the COVID-19 pandemic. With branches shut and customers increasingly using digital services, the banks are rolling out new video services and mobile features to cement customer loyalty and reduce costs. This shift is expected to have a longer-term impact on their balance sheets, potentially absorbing some of the shock from loan losses. The banks' digital adoption in Asia is on the rise, with HSBC's digital transactions in Hong Kong reaching 94% and Citigroup's digital wealth management transactions increasing by 37%.

site_title: Covid-19: 1 new cluster found; 24-year-old man who works at CDPL Tuas Dormitory among 4 Singaporean cases confirmed
summary: Singapore's Ministry of Health confirmed 682 new COVID-19 cases, bringing the total to 28,038. Four new cases, including a 24-year-old Singaporean man, were reported, with the man working at CDPL Tuas dormitory linked to 452 cases. One new cluster was identified at 9 Sungei Kadut Avenue, with 13 earlier confirmed cases. 998 cases were discharged, and 1,210 patients remain in hospital, with 22 deaths reported due to COVID-19 complications.

site_title: Dollar notches small weekly gain after weak US data, threat of 2nd Covid-19 wave
summary: The US dollar rose 0.66% for the week, driven by concerns over a potential second wave of COVID-19 infections and weak US economic data. Retail sales declined for a second consecutive month, and the economy is on track for its biggest contraction since the Great Depression. Despite this, the S&P 500 index and Dow Jones Industrial Average ended the day slightly up. The dollar index was flat against the Japanese yen, as investors sought safe-haven assets amidst market uncertainty.

site_title: Japan Covid-19 doctors lack fresh masks, hazard pay: union survey
summary: Japanese hospital doctors on the front line of the Covid-19 pandemic face challenging conditions, with many reusing masks and receiving no hazard pay. A survey of 170 doctors found that three-quarters were ordered to work on the coronavirus front line and four-fifths received no hazard allowance. The survey also revealed that 31% of doctors reused N95 respirator masks indefinitely, with some using the same mask until the ear bands break. The government's failure to provide adequate financial assistance and protective gear has been criticized, with nearly 70% of doctors saying the government is not handling the situation properly.

site_title: Next Jobs Support Scheme payout to be disbursed from May 28
summary: Singapore's Jobs Support Scheme (JSS) will disburse its next instalment of S$4 billion to over 140,000 employers on May 28, providing 75% support for the first S$4,600 of wages paid to local employees. The payment is based on last November wages and will be adjusted for actual wages paid in May 2020. Employers are encouraged to use the JSS wage subsidies to retain local employees, and can sign up for PayNow Corporate for faster payouts. The JSS has committed over S$20 billion since its inception.

site_title: Is Covid-19 the great leveller?
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has exposed weaknesses in the global economy, particularly in Singapore, where technology has accelerated the rich-poor divide. Lower-skilled workers are being replaced by automation, leading to job losses and displacement. To address this, the government must take a courageous step of saying "no" to saving companies with no place in the new economy. Corporates must also adopt innovation and technology to cut out back-breaking work and create highly regarded roles. Society must also recognize the importance of jobs that were previously undervalued, such as healthcare work and service industry jobs.

site_title: China urges food companies to boost supplies on fears of further Covid-19 disruption
summary: China has urged food companies to boost supplies amid concerns of a possible second wave of coronavirus cases and disruptions to global supply lines. The country's Ministry of Commerce has asked trading firms and food processors to increase inventories of grains and oilseeds, particularly soybeans and corn, due to potential disruptions in Brazil and other major suppliers. China has also stepped up purchases of US soybeans and corn, and is under pressure to buy more US farm products under a trade deal signed in January.

site_title: Del Monte Pacific subsidiary raises US$1.3 billion
summary: Del Monte Pacific's subsidiary has raised $1.3 billion through a mix of equity and loans, primarily for refinancing existing loan facilities. The company invested $378 million in equity, mostly in its US unit Del Monte Foods, and issued $500 million in senior secured notes and a $450 million asset-based loan facility. The funds will be used to refinance existing loan facilities of approximately $1.1 billion. This move aims to strengthen Del Monte Foods' financial position as a producer, distributor, and marketer of premium quality, branded, plant-based food products in the US.

site_title: Disney says it will reopen shopping area at Florida resort on Wednesday
summary: Walt Disney World Resort in Florida will partially reopen its Disney Springs entertainment and shopping complex on May 20, with third-party operating participants and some Disney-owned stores opening. The company has reached an agreement with unions on COVID-19 safety measures, allowing for the phased reopening. Disney Springs will implement safety measures such as cashless payment, face coverings, and increased cleaning. The reopening comes after the company lost an estimated $1 billion in revenue from closed theme parks and 120,000 unpaid furloughs.

site_title: China starts new LNG terminal project in Shandong
summary: China has broken ground on a new liquefied natural gas terminal project in Shandong Province, marking the company PipeChina's first energy infrastructure project since its establishment in December last year. The project, jointly built with Nanshan Group, is designed to receive 20 million tonnes of LNG per year, with 20 gas-storage tanks. Phase one of the project, expected to launch in 2023, will have a capacity of 5 million tonnes.

site_title: China injects US$2.25b into local chip firm
summary: China has invested US$2.25 billion in Semiconductor Manufacturing International (SMI) to support advanced chip production, amid US restrictions on Chinese technology. The investment increases SMI's registered capital to US$6.50 billion, reducing its stake in the Shanghai facility from 50.1% to 38.5%. The move aims to reduce China's reliance on US technology, following US sanctions on Huawei and other Chinese companies. SMI plans to boost production capacity to 35,000 wafers per month, with a potential Shanghai share sale raising over US$3 billion.

site_title: Amazon says 'appropriate' executive to be available, as US panel calls on Bezos to testify
summary: Amazon has agreed to make an "appropriate" executive available to the US House of Representatives Judiciary Committee to testify about allegations of using third-party sellers' data to create competing products. The committee had called for CEO Jeff Bezos to testify, citing a Wall Street Journal report that alleged Amazon's business practices were misleading and possibly criminal. Amazon has previously denied any wrongdoing, stating that such practices would violate its policies. The company will investigate any allegations and provide answers to the committee's questions.

site_title: Fiat seeks 6.3b euro state-backed loan for Italy operations
summary: Fiat Chrysler Automobiles (FCA) is in talks to secure a 6.3 billion euro state-backed loan from Italy's Intesa Sanpaolo SpA to support its finances amid the coronavirus pandemic. The three-year credit facility would benefit about 10,000 enterprises in Italy's automotive supply chain. The company has already burned through $5.5 billion in the first quarter and scrapped 1.1 billion-euro dividends due to the pandemic. This would be Europe's largest government-guaranteed financing for a carmaker related to the pandemic, following a 5 billion-euro deal struck by Renault last month.

site_title: US banking regulators temporarily expand easier bank leverage requirements
summary: US banking regulators temporarily eased a leverage requirement for depository institutions, allowing banks to ignore certain safer assets and continue lending. The new rule excludes Treasury securities held at the US Federal Reserve from calculating the supplemental leverage ratio, a measure directing larger banks to hold more capital against their assets. This move builds on relief provided in April during the coronavirus outbreak and aims to support banks' lending activities. The rule applies to depository institutions and is a temporary measure.

site_title: Fiat Chrysler in talks over 6.3b euro state-guaranteed loan in Italy: sources
summary: Fiat Chrysler is in talks with Intesa Sanpaolo for a 6.3 billion euro state-guaranteed loan to help the automaker recover from the coronavirus crisis. The loan, part of Italy's emergency liquidity measures, would be issued by a pool of banks and reviewed by Italy's export credit agency SACE. Fiat Chrysler, which has restarted operations in Italy, is seeking 80% guarantees, taking advantage of a clause favoring essential industries. The loan must be approved by Intesa Sanpaolo's board before being reviewed by the Treasury.

images.alt_text: Fiat Chrysler is in talks with Intesa Sanpaolo over a 6.3 billion euro (S$9.73 billion) loan backed by Italian government to help the automaker weather the coronavirus crisis, two sources close to the matter said on Friday.

site_title: Eagle Hospitality Trust posts US$8.9m Q1 loss
summary: Eagle Hospitality Trust (EHT) posted a Q1 loss of US$8.9 million due to an impairment loss on trade receivables and lower-than-expected revenue of US$16.6 million. Net property income was also below projections, resulting in a 31.7% shortfall. The trust's financial performance was impacted by the global pandemic, with 14 hotels shuttered and uncertainty on master lessees' ability to make rental payments. The trust's net asset value per stapled security fell to US$0.83, and trading in EHT securities has been suspended since March 2020.

site_title: Tesla tells employees it has county approval to reopen California plant
summary: Tesla has received approval from Alameda County's interim health officer to resume operations at its Fremont factory in California, following a court battle with the county. The approval comes after Elon Musk threatened to move the company's headquarters to Nevada or Texas if the county blocked the reopening. Tesla's Fremont plant employs approximately 11,000 workers. The company had sued the county earlier this month, claiming it didn't meet criteria to reopen. Musk's threat was seen as the "final straw" prompting the county's approval.

site_title: Iran's Opec governor dies after brain haemorrhage
summary: Iran's Opec governor Hossein Kazempour Ardebili has died of a brain haemorrhage two weeks after falling into a coma. Ardebili, a key figure in Iran's oil industry, served as the country's deputy foreign minister and deputy oil minister in the 1980s. He was also Opec governor and ambassador to Japan in the early 1990s. The cause of his death was not specified.

site_title: Air Canada to cut workforce by up to 60% due to coronavirus
summary: Air Canada to cut workforce by up to 60% due to coronavirus. The airline plans to reduce its workforce amid the pandemic and re-size operations to expected traffic levels. Employees may be asked to reduce hours, go on leave for up to two years, or resign with travel privileges. The move is part of the airline's efforts to save cash and mitigate losses caused by the health crisis.

site_title: 18 discharged from D'Resort facility after being cleared of coronavirus: MOH
summary: 18 patients discharged from D'Resort facility in Singapore after being deemed non-infectious despite still testing positive for coronavirus. The patients, who had stayed at the facility between 38 and 51 days, were clinically well but shed dead viral components. They will quarantine themselves at home for 7 days as a precaution. The Ministry of Health (MOH) will review cases individually and consider discharging patients based on their risk of infecting others, adopting a cautious approach to manage the situation.

site_title: 465 new Covid-19 cases in Singapore; 4 are Singaporeans and PRs
summary: Singapore reported 465 new Covid-19 cases, with 4 being Singaporeans and permanent residents. The majority of cases are work permit holders in foreign worker dormitories, bringing the total count to 27,356.

site_title: Startups should launch now, says Sun Microsystems co-founder
summary: Scott McNealy, co-founder of Sun Microsystems, is investing in a new venture capital fund, Conversion Capital, to back startups during the current economic downturn. He believes the high unemployment since the Great Depression makes it an optimal time to start a company, citing lower salaries and rent as cost-saving measures. McNealy expects startups in financial services, healthcare, and government to thrive, and is optimistic about the industry's potential. Conversion Capital is raising a $50 million early-stage fund to support innovative companies.

site_title: Myanmar's US$800m tower sale shortlists CVC, Guodong
summary: Private equity firm CVC Capital Partners and Chinese wireless infrastructure company Guodong Group are among shortlisted bidders for Myanmar's Irrawaddy Green Towers, a US$800m telecommunications tower company. Malaysia's edotco Group also made the cut. The companies have until the next few weeks to submit binding bids, but discussions are ongoing and no certainty remains about the deal's progression. Irrawaddy Green Towers serves major operators in Myanmar, including Telenor and Ooredoo.

site_title: China, South Korea consult Japan on easing business travel curbs: media
summary: China and South Korea have consulted Japan on easing border controls on business travelers to revive business activities. The proposed plan would allow for fast-track entry of business people who test negative for the new coronavirus before and after travel. However, Japan is cautious due to fears of another spike in infections and lack of test kits. This comes as Japan's Prime Minister Shinzo Abe has lifted state of emergency in 39 prefectures, easing restrictions on 54% of the population.

site_title: China tells US to stop 'unreasonable suppression' of Huawei
summary: China has urged the US to stop "unreasonable suppression" of Huawei and Chinese enterprises after the US announced new export controls restricting the tech giant's access to semiconductor technology. The restrictions, targeting Huawei's acquisition of US software and technology, are seen as a new escalation in the US-China battle for global technological dominance. China's Ministry of Foreign Affairs warned that the US actions "destroy global manufacturing, supply and value chains" and will be met with retaliation, including imposing restrictions on major US firms.

site_title: Juul adds former Canadian health minister to e-cig giant's board
summary: Former Canadian Health Minister Rona Ambrose has joined Juul Labs' board of directors, aiming to reset the e-cigarette company's relationship with global regulators. Ambrose's public health and regulatory experience will help Juul reposition itself. She emphasizes the need for businesses and regulators to work together to combat underage use. The appointment is part of Juul's efforts to change its image from a disruptive tech startup to a responsible smoking alternative.

site_title: KKR picks rival TPG's Trehan to head India private equity business
summary: KKR has appointed Gaurav Trehan, a former partner at TPG, as head of its private equity business in India. Trehan left TPG this month after joining in 2004. The move comes as private equity firms strengthen their management teams to capitalize on potential buyout opportunities in India amid the pandemic. KKR's India business has invested in companies such as Bharti Infratel and Max Financial Services, and is predicting the pandemic will be an inflection point for its business, with opportunities for expansion.

site_title: Cambodia says all Covid-19 patients recovered, no new cases for a month
summary: Cambodia reports its last Covid-19 patient has recovered, marking the end of the country's outbreak. The last patient, a 36-year-old woman from Banteay Meanchey province, was released from the hospital after a month without new cases. Health Minister Mam Bunheng urged continued vigilance, emphasizing the need for border checks and quarantines for travelers. With 122 reported cases and no deaths, Cambodia has effectively eradicated the virus. No easing of restrictions has been announced, and the country will continue to monitor the situation closely.

site_title: China central bank to strengthen monetary policy support for economy, governor says
summary: China's central bank governor, Yi Gang, announced plans to strengthen monetary policy support for the economy amid the coronavirus pandemic. The People's Bank of China will focus on policy flexibility while maintaining financial stability, using tools such as re-lending and targeted lending support. This move comes as China's economy faces new challenges from the pandemic's global spread. The central bank has already rolled out easing measures since February, including reserve requirement cuts and lending rate reductions, to support the economy and stabilize employment. The goal is to stabilize employment and stabilize the economy.

site_title: India's coronavirus infections surpass China, but contagion slowing
summary: India surpasses China in coronavirus cases, reaching 85,940, though the contagion is slowing due to a strict lockdown. The death rate in India is 2,752, compared to China's 4,600, and cases are doubling every 11 days, down from 3.5 days. The government is expected to extend the lockdown, which would otherwise expire on Sunday, with fewer restrictions. India's low death rate may be due to the majority of infected individuals having mild symptoms or being asymptomatic, and the lockdown preventing a major catastrophe.

site_title: UK researchers test dogs' ability to sniff out Covid-19
summary: UK researchers are testing dogs' ability to sniff out Covid-19, with £500,000 pounds invested in the project. Six dogs will be trained to distinguish Covid-19 odors from those of uninfected individuals. The goal is to develop a fast, non-invasive method for detecting the disease, which could allow one dog to check up to 250 people an hour. This is part of a wider testing strategy, and similar research is being conducted in the US and France.

site_title: Applovin values video game maker Machine Zone at around US$500m
summary: AppLovin acquired Machine Zone, a video game maker, for approximately US$500 million, a fraction of its 2016 valuation of US$5 billion. The deal marks a significant decline in the company's value, reflecting the impact of the pandemic on startups. Machine Zone, known for its mobile game Game of War, has raised around US$725 million in private funding since its founding in 2008. The acquisition is the latest example of startups seeking tie-ups with private companies amid a downturn in the industry.

site_title: Euro zone banks sell subordinated bonds after three month hiatus
summary: Euro zone banks have reopened the issuance market for subordinated bonds, the riskiest debt banks can issue, after a three-month hiatus due to the coronavirus pandemic. Deutsche Bank kicked off the issuance with a 1.25 billion euro raise, followed by Bank of Ireland with a 675 million euro raise. The move comes after severe sell-offs in the asset class, with borrowing costs rising and banks waiting to release first quarter earnings. The 80 billion euro market had been shut since February 20.

site_title: Fed warns of significant hit to asset prices if crisis grows
summary: The US Federal Reserve warned of significant declines in asset prices if the coronavirus pandemic deepens, citing commercial real estate as a particularly vulnerable industry. The report highlighted risks to the US banking system and broader economy, citing disruptions in the hospitality and retail industries. The Fed has intervened with liquidity and eased regulations to cushion the economy, but warned of potential solvency stresses among highly leveraged businesses.

images.alt_text: The US Federal Reserve issued a stark warning on Friday that stock and other asset prices could suffer significant declines should the coronavirus pandemic deepen, with the commercial real estate market being among the hardest-hit industries.

site_title: Equinor-led group approves major Norwegian CO2 storage project
summary: A group of European energy companies, led by Norway's Equinor, has approved a major Norwegian CO2 storage project. The Northern Lights carbon capture and storage (CCS) project, in partnership with Royal Dutch Shell and Total, aims to store 1.5 million tonnes of CO2 per year beneath the North Sea. The project, valued at $962.3 million, is expected to help combat climate change and reduce carbon emissions by 2050. Final approval is pending from Norwegian authorities, and the project is seen as a significant step towards meeting the 2015 Paris climate agreement.

site_title: Democrats launch probe of Trump's firing of US State Dept watchdog
summary: Democrats in the US Congress have launched an investigation into President Donald Trump's firing of the State Department's internal watchdog, Inspector General Steve Linick. The move comes amid accusations that Trump is escalating his fight against oversight of his administration. The top Democrats on the House and Senate Foreign Relations Committees questioned the timing and motivation of the removal, calling it an "unprecedented" action. The investigation aims to determine the reasons behind the removal and its potential implications on government accountability.

images.alt_text: Democrats in Congress on Saturday launched an investigation into President Donald Trump's move to oust the State Department's internal watchdog, accusing the president of escalating his fight against any oversight of his administration.

site_title: UK's lowest earners bear the brunt of Covid-19 job hit: survey
summary: Britain's lowest-earning workers have been disproportionately affected by the coronavirus crisis, with 25% temporarily laid off and 5% losing their jobs, according to a survey by the Resolution Foundation think-tank. In contrast, the top fifth of earners have been less affected, with only 6% furloughed and 3% losing their jobs. The survey highlights the need for increased support for low-income workers, particularly as the government phases out its job retention scheme.

site_title: US gave no assurance to Taiwan's TSMC for licence to sell to Huawei: official
summary: The US has not provided assurance to Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co (TSMC) that it will be granted a license to sell US technology to Huawei, a senior US official said. TSMC's $12 billion investment plan in Arizona is at risk due to the proposed rule change, which could restrict TSMC's sales to Huawei, a blacklisted company. The US undersecretary for economic growth, Keith Krach, stated that TSMC's business with Huawei is around 10-12% and that the company will be restricted unless granted a license.

site_title: US funds rush to tech companies and battered energy stocks in Q1
summary: In the first quarter, prominent US fund managers rushed to technology stocks and battered energy sectors, amid the coronavirus-fueled selloff. They cut exposure in restaurants, retail, and airlines, while increasing positions in tech giants like Microsoft, Amazon, and Alphabet. Some hedge funds, such as Viking Global Investors and Cinctive Capital Management, took contrarian bets on energy companies, which saw sharp increases in shares. The filings provide a glimpse into the historic stock market selloff and the start of an economic crisis being likened to the Great Depression.

site_title: US House passes US$3 trillion coronavirus aid bill opposed by Trump
summary: The US House of Representatives approved a $3 trillion coronavirus aid bill, despite opposition from President Donald Trump, who has vowed to veto it. The bill, called the Heroes Act, includes $500 billion in aid to state governments, direct payments to individuals and families, and hazard pay for healthcare workers. The vote came after a heated debate, with Democrats accusing Republicans of not doing enough to help those affected by the pandemic. The bill now heads to the Senate, where Republican leaders have vowed to block it.

site_title: Fake MAS e-mails scammed nine individuals of over S$50,000 in total
summary: Nine individuals were scammed out of over S$50,000 after receiving fake e-mails impersonating the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS), with the scammers claiming to need "validation fees" for loan applications. The scammers also used bogus websites impersonating licensed moneylenders to trick victims into transferring funds. The Singapore Police Force (SPF) is investigating seven individuals for their suspected involvement in the loan scam, warning the public to be wary of e-mails and websites that solicit personal information or ask for payments before loan disbursement.

site_title: Listening during a pandemic
summary: During the COVID-19 pandemic, relationships have been put to the test, with some people experiencing increased disconnection and alienation. However, listening to others can help strengthen ties and show care, even in difficult times. By finding common interests or "third things" to discuss, such as music or art, people can begin to build intimacy and understanding. Effective listening requires patience, sensitivity, and a thoughtful response, rather than just being quiet or trying to solve the other person's problems. Experts emphasize the importance of being present and acknowledging emotions, rather than offering words or solutions, to truly connect with others.

images.alt_text: With the world effectively on pause, now is a unique opportunity to listen to those close to you, or to those you wish were closer to you.

site_title: Fearing Covid-19, biggest US university system makes fall semester virtual
summary: The California State University system, serving 482,000 students, has announced that nearly all classes will be virtual for the fall semester due to concerns over the spread of Covid-19. The decision, made in response to uncertainty about a potential second wave of infections, affects 23 university campuses. Exceptions may include the maritime academy, which holds classes on a training ship. The system aims to minimize risks and ensure student safety.

site_title: General Motors chief calls jobs cuts in self-driving unit 'prudent'
summary: General Motors (GM) chief Mary Barra has described the company's plan to cut 160 jobs, or 8% of its staff, in its self-driving unit Cruise Automation as "prudent". The layoffs, which do not affect technical staff focused on developing self-driving vehicles, come amid the company's first-quarter earnings plunge and sales decline due to the COVID-19 pandemic. Barra noted that the move will help the company navigate challenging market conditions.

site_title: Trump administration to restore partial funding to World Health Organization
summary: US President Donald Trump's administration will restore partial funding to the World Health Organization (WHO), agreeing to pay up to what China pays in assessed contributions. This move reverses a suspension of US contributions in April, citing accusations of promoting China's disinformation about the coronavirus outbreak. The new funding level will be about one-tenth of the US's previous annual contribution of $400 million.

site_title: Musk's SpaceX is denied job funding sought from California panel
summary: California's Employee Training Panel rejected SpaceX's $655,500 funding request, citing concerns over wages, job retention, and turnover. The decision comes after Elon Musk defied a San Francisco Bay area health order, threatening to move Tesla's headquarters out of the state. Labour leaders opposed the funding, stating that Musk prioritizes enriching himself over being a good corporate partner. The rejection is an early indication of blowback following Tesla's lawsuit against a California county over reopening its auto plant.

site_title: Latam Airlines says cutting 1,400 jobs in South America
summary: Latam Airlines announced plans to lay off 1,400 employees in South America due to the coronavirus pandemic's drastic impact on business. The airline cited the need to protect its sustainability in the medium term. Despite efforts to preserve jobs, the drastic slump in business made reducing the size of the company inevitable, according to executive director Roberto Alvo. This move is part of the airline's efforts to adapt to the new market conditions and ensure its long-term survival.

site_title: WHO probes possible coronavirus link to rare disease in children
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) is investigating a possible link between COVID-19 and a rare inflammatory illness in children, dubbed Multisystem Inflammatory Syndrome in Children (MIS-C). Reports of the syndrome have been made in several countries, including France, the US, and the UK, where children have died and over 100 cases are being investigated. While the WHO has developed a preliminary case definition for MIS-C, the link to COVID-19 has yet to be clearly established, and the cause may be related to the immune response to the virus rather than the virus itself.

site_title: US department store chain JC Penney files for bankruptcy protection
summary: JC Penney Co, a US department store chain, filed for bankruptcy protection on May 16, 2020, citing prolonged store closures due to the Covid-19 pandemic. The company reached a US$900 million debtor-in-possession financing deal with existing lenders to aid operations. JC Penney plans to permanently close some stores and explore a possible sale, with an additional US$500 million in cash on hand. The retailer filed for bankruptcy in federal court in Corpus Christi, Texas.

site_title: Italy to allow travel to and from abroad from June 3
summary: Italy's government approved a decree allowing free travel to and from abroad from June 3, marking a major step towards unwinding its strict coronavirus lockdown. The decision comes after over 31,600 Italians have died of Covid-19, with the government aiming to prevent a second wave of infections. Travel restrictions within individual regions will remain in place until June 2, but all movement will be allowed from June 3. The government hopes to salvage the summer vacation season and allow shops, restaurants, and parks to reopen under strict social distancing and hygiene rules.

site_title: Carmaker Kia closes Algeria assembly line over supply disruptions
summary: Kia Motors, a South Korean carmaker, will shut down its assembly line in Algeria from May 17 due to supply chain disruptions caused by the government's ban on importing spare parts. The ban affects around 1,200 employees and marks a significant blow to Algeria's nascent automobile industry, which relied on the "semi knocked-down" or SKD kits system. The move follows a similar halt in production by Volkswagen in 2019, amid corruption scandals. Kia's decision highlights the challenges facing the industry in Algeria.

images.alt_text: South Korean carmaker Kia Motors will shut down its assembly line in Algeria from Sunday due to supply chain disruptions after authorities imposed a ban on the import of spare parts.

site_title: United Airlines only needs 3,000 of 25,000 flight attendants in June: sources
summary: United Airlines has informed staff that it only needs 3,000 of its 25,000 flight attendants for June, warning of job losses if demand doesn't recover by the fall. The airline is receiving $5 billion in government payroll aid under the CARES Act, which prohibits job or pay cuts before October. United is paying staff until September 30. This move is part of the industry's efforts to match crews and fleets to an uncertain recovery from the economic crisis sparked by the COVID-19 pandemic.

site_title: Dinner with dummies: US eatery fills empty seats with mannequins
summary: A Michelin-starred US restaurant, The Inn at Little Washington, is filling empty seats with costumed mannequins to enforce social distancing during its reopening in May. The mannequins, dressed in 1940s attire, are strategically placed at tables that must remain empty. Chef Patrick O'Connell, the restaurant's owner, says the solution was "obvious" to reduce occupancy by half and provide a fun, photo-worthy experience for guests. The Inn, with its sprawling grounds and high-end tasting menu, aims to bring people together while maintaining social distancing measures.

site_title: Young adults take refuge in parents' empty nests
summary: Young adults, struggling financially due to the pandemic, are returning home to live with their parents. Many have lost their jobs, experienced canceled contracts, or seen their income decline. This trend is adding fiscal strain to parents, who must now support their adult children, often with limited savings. Career momentum is also at risk, particularly for those just starting out in industries affected by the pandemic. Experts warn of lasting consequences, including a downward career spiral, and highlight the need for younger workers to build rainy-day funds.

site_title: E-commerce startup banks on robotics, AI to win consumers
summary: A US e-commerce startup, Home Delivery Service (HDS), plans to launch a fully automated warehouse model with robotics and AI to deliver groceries and merchandise, aiming to cut out supermarkets as intermediaries. Led by Louis Borders, the company plans to launch in 2021, starting with San Francisco, and aims to sell "tens of millions" of products. HDS aims to reduce staff to one-third of its peers, partnering with Toyota and Ingram Micro on robotics systems, and will use autonomous delivery systems as they become available.

site_title: Amazon planning to reopen its French warehouses from May 19
summary: Amazon plans to reopen its six French warehouses on May 19, following an agreement with unions and work councils to address coronavirus protection concerns. The warehouses were closed since April 16 due to court rulings restricting deliveries during the pandemic. The company aims to gradually reopen the sites, which employ about 10,000 people, after a dispute over Covid-19 protection measures. Amazon has faced multimillion-dollar fines if it unintentionally shipped items not included on the restricted list. The reopening is seen as a positive step for the US e-commerce giant's operations in France.

site_title: US Justice Dept subpoenas Wall Street banks for small business loans info: sources
summary: The US Justice Department has sent grand jury subpoenas to major Wall Street banks seeking records related to small business loans under the Paycheck Protection Program (PPP), amid concerns of potential abuse of the $660 billion emergency loan programme. The subpoenas do not necessarily indicate wrongdoing on the part of the banks but aim to gather evidence of potential fraud. The Justice Department has already brought charges against borrowers who lied about their businesses and employee numbers. Banks are worried about being swept up in a federal crackdown on PPP fraud, particularly if a Democratic administration takes office.

site_title: Oil prices jump as demand shows signs of picking up
summary: US crude oil prices jumped 7% to their highest since March, reaching $29.43 a barrel, amid signs of improving fuel demand as countries eased travel restrictions. Brent crude rose 5.2% to $32.50 a barrel. Market tightness, driven by OPEC supply cuts, and improving demand, particularly in China, contributed to the price increase. Analysts expect global crude inventories to fall by 5.5 million barrels per day in the second half and oil demand to fall by 8.6 million barrels per day this year.

site_title: Facebook buys GIF website Giphy to integrate with Instagram
summary: Facebook has acquired Giphy, a popular GIF website, for around $400 million, integrating it with its Instagram app. The acquisition comes amid antitrust scrutiny, with the American Economic Liberties Project urging regulators to investigate. Giphy's GIF library will be integrated into Instagram and other Facebook-owned apps, allowing users to upload and share GIFs. The deal is seen as a move to centralize control over online communications, with the Federal Trade Commission not immediately commenting on the acquisition.

site_title: US state attorneys general likely to bring antitrust lawsuits against Google: source
summary: US state attorneys general, led by Texas, are likely to file an antitrust lawsuit against Google this year, amid ongoing federal and state investigations into the company's market dominance. The Justice Department is also moving towards a case, with shares of Alphabet Inc's parent company falling 1.5% in after-hours trading. Texas Attorney General Ken Paxton aims to wrap up the investigation by fall and has not ruled out breaking up the company if necessary. Google has declined to comment on speculation about potential litigation.

site_title: China calls on US to pay its debts to the United Nations
summary: China has called on the US to pay its outstanding debts to the United Nations, totaling over $2 billion, including $1.165 billion in peacekeeping operations and $1.63 billion in regular budget payments. The US is the largest debtor, despite paying 22% of the UN's annual running costs and 25% of its peacekeeping operations. The US mission to the UN dismissed the call, citing recent payments and a fiscal year that can make the debt appear larger at certain times.

images.alt_text: China on Friday issued a statement calling on all UN member states to "actively fulfill their financial obligations to the United Nations", stressing that Washington owes the organisation more than US$2 billion.

site_title: Trump says US working with other countries on coronavirus vaccine
summary: President Donald Trump announced at a White House event that the US government is working with other countries to develop a coronavirus vaccine, with the goal of having it ready by the end of the year. The administration will invest in the top vaccine candidates, with 14 promising options currently under consideration. Trump expressed his hope that a vaccine would be distributed once it's available, and his administration is preparing for its distribution.

site_title: Berkshire sells majority of Goldman stake, trims JPMorgan
summary: Berkshire Hathaway, led by Warren Buffett, sold off nearly 33% of its Goldman Sachs stake, reducing its value to around $330 million. The company also trimmed its JPMorgan Chase investment by 3% and exited a bet on Travelers Cos. Berkshire cut its Amazon stake by 0.7% and boosted its stake in PNC Financial Services Group. The moves come as Berkshire continues to reassess its investments amid the global pandemic's impact on financial markets.

site_title: Gold, silver race higher on fears of second virus wave
summary: Gold prices surged to their highest since 2012, reaching $1,756.30 an ounce, amid concerns over a potential second wave of the coronavirus pandemic. The US factory production plummeted in April, and retail sales plummeted, fueling fears of a bleak economic picture. The US Federal Reserve chairman warned of a heavy toll on the economy, while gloomy American unemployment data and rising cases in Texas further intensified fears. As a result, investors are piling into gold, driving interest rates lower. Silver also rose to its highest in over two months.
