site_title: Carlyle says Covid-19 pandemic warrants killing AmEx stock deal
summary: The Covid-19 pandemic has led to the cancellation of a $1.5 billion deal between Carlyle Group and Singapore sovereign-wealth fund GIC to buy 20% of American Express Global Business Travel (AmEx GBT). Carlyle and GIC sought to scrap the deal due to the pandemic's devastating impact on the travel industry, citing a "material adverse effect" clause in the agreement. A Delaware Chancery Court judge denied Certares' request for a speedy trial, stating it would be impractical to try to protect the June 30 financing deadline.

site_title: Japan lifts state of emergency in most areas
summary: Japan lifted a state of emergency in 39 of its 47 prefectures, but it remains in place in Tokyo and Osaka, where Prime Minister Shinzo Abe aims to control the spread of the virus and cushion the economic blow. The emergency was declared a month ago, urging citizens to reduce person-to-person contact by 80% to slow the spread of the virus. Economists predict a gradual normalization, with the government keeping a wary eye on the possibility of a second wave of infections.

site_title: US House Democrat wants the country's airlines to cap seating because of coronavirus
summary: US House Democrat Representative Peter DeFazio urged major airlines to maintain at least one seat-width of spacing between passengers and cap seating at 67% of capacity to address the coronavirus pandemic. This move comes as US travel demand has fallen by over 94%, allowing airlines to space out passengers on most flights. The proposal aims to reduce the risk of coronavirus transmission and ensure a safer flying experience.

site_title: Dollar nears 3-week highs on comments from Fed chief
summary: The US dollar strengthened to a three-week high after Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell dismissed speculation about negative interest rates, lifting investor confidence. European stock markets fell, and US stock futures indicated a negative start to the day. Powell warned of a recession worse than any since World War II, while also urging more fiscal stimulus. The dollar edged 0.2% higher to 100.37, while the Australian dollar and pound tumbled below key levels.

site_title: Li Ka-Shing's twin business empires rocked by global pandemic
summary: Li Ka-shing's business empires, CK Hutchison Holdings and CK Asset Holdings, have been significantly impacted by the global pandemic. CK Hutchison expects a 50% plunge in retail profit in the first half, with retail being "acceptable" in the second half. CK Asset expects a material reduction in net income due to the pandemic. The companies are grappling with volatility in financial and currency markets, and Hong Kong's tourism industry has been severely affected. Shares in the companies have declined, with CK Hutchison down 25% and CK Asset down 16% year-to-date.

site_title: US: Wall Street closes with strong gains as recovery hopes offset pandemic fears
summary: US stocks surged on Thursday, closing with strong gains as investors weighed recovery hopes against pandemic fears and trade tensions. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 1.62%, the S&P 500 gained 1.15%, and the Nasdaq Composite added 0.91%. The Wisconsin Supreme Court struck down lockdown orders, while a whistleblower warned of a potential "darkest winter" if the US response to the pandemic fails to improve. Despite this, investors remain optimistic about a vaccine and economic recovery, with all major US stock indexes ending the session higher.

site_title: Stiffer penalties mooted for Singapore's data-protection law
summary: Singapore's proposed amendments to its Personal Data Protection Act could impose stricter penalties for data breaches, up to 10% of annual gross turnover or S$1 million, whichever is higher. The proposed changes, part of the Personal Data Protection (Amendment) Bill, also include mandating organisations to notify the data protection commission of breaches involving 500 or more individuals and introducing a Data Portability Obligation, allowing individuals to request a copy of their personal data to be transmitted to another organisation. The changes aim to increase public trust in organisations' data management.

site_title: Money FM podcast: NextLifeBook
summary: Host Glenn van Zutphen of Money FM 89.3's Weekend Mornings podcast spoke to Chua Teck Hiong, co-founder and director of NextLifeBook, about his new digital platform to capture memories and celebrate family milestones. The conversation centered on NextLifeBook's mission and features, but no specific details or events were discussed in the provided article.

site_title: NYSE to partially reopen trading floor on May 26: WSJ
summary: The New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) will partially reopen its trading floor on May 26, allowing floor brokers to return in smaller numbers while wearing protective masks. The move comes over two months after the exchange closed its floor to control the spread of coronavirus. Brokers and visitors will also undergo screening and temperature checks before entering the building. This marks the exchange's first steps towards resuming in-person trading, following a temporary closure in March.

images.alt_text: The New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) trading floor will partially reopen on May 26, over two months after it closed down to control the spread of the coronavirus, NYSE president Stacey Cunningham said in an opinion piece in the Wall Street Journal.

site_title: Airbus to start talks with unions on permanent staff cuts
summary: Airbus is preparing to start talks with unions on permanent staff cuts, hitting its commercial aircraft division harder than its helicopters and defense division. The company needs to reduce production amid a collapse in demand, with discussions set to begin next week. Airbus has already slashed production goals by over a third and may eliminate around 10,000 jobs, with the number of positions to be eliminated still undecided. The move comes as the aerospace industry shifts from crisis management to drastic resizing of operations, following the COVID-19 pandemic's impact on air travel.

site_title: Silverlake Axis posts 51% fall in Q3 net profit to RM25.6m
summary: Silverlake Axis reported a 51% decline in Q3 net profit to RM25.6 million, mainly due to lower other income and higher expenses. Revenue slipped 2% to RM151.7 million, while income tax expense rose 36% to RM11.3 million. Earnings per share fell to 0.97 sen from 1.99 sen in the previous year. The company attributed the decline to lower project-related revenue segments and cyclical sales of software and hardware products.

site_title: Temasek joins Facebook-backed Libra project
summary: Temasek, a Singapore state-owned investment company, has joined the Facebook-backed Libra project, a global digital payments network. The move comes as the project faces severe criticism from financial authorities. Libra aims to lower transaction costs and provide access to financial services for those outside the banking system. The association, led by Dante Disparte, is seeking approval for digital coins in individual currencies, with stablecoins pegged to real-world currencies. This plan aims to minimize disruption to the global monetary system.

images.alt_text: Singapore state-owned investment company Temasek has joined the Facebook-backed Libra project seeking to create a worldwide digital payments network, the Swiss-based Libra Association said Thursday.

site_title: Going digital is no longer just a short-term concern for SMEs
summary: Singapore's "circuit breaker" period has prompted small and medium-size enterprises (SMEs) to venture into e-commerce and delivery services to stay afloat. However, some businesses risk damaging their reputation due to late or poor deliveries, and lack of communication. To mitigate this, the government has introduced support packages, including an E-Commerce Booster Package that covers 90% of the cost of retailers getting onto e-commerce platforms. SMEs are advised to manage their digital capabilities, logistics, and marketing to avoid reputational damage and ensure a successful digital transition.

site_title: Sharp oil price pullback unlikely as demand improves: Goldman
summary: Goldman Sachs believes a sharp oil price pullback is unlikely due to improving demand and lower output, citing a gradual lifting of coronavirus lockdowns and a faster-than-expected decline in oil production. The bank raised its May global demand estimate, but still expects a 16 million barrel-per-day decline from pre-Covid levels. Oil prices are expected to remain range-bound with limited upside, with Goldman maintaining summer price forecasts of $30 per barrel for Brent and $28 per barrel for WTI.

site_title: Background Detail
summary: Several companies, including Binary Style, HiHello, The Great Room, Studio Ghibli, Gardens by the Bay, Star Wars, Sistic, and Paintinks by Melt, are offering free virtual backgrounds for use in online meetings. These backgrounds, which feature local elements, iconic films, and outdoor gardens, aim to add cheerfulness and color to virtual calls. The virtual backgrounds can be used for work, social gatherings, or personal use, and some even include QR codes for sharing digital business cards.

site_title: DBS to hire over 2,000 this year despite pandemic
summary: DBS Bank has committed to hiring over 2,000 people in Singapore this year, despite the ongoing Covid-19 pandemic. The bank will create over 1,000 new roles for fresh graduates and seasoned professionals, with a focus on growth technology areas such as UX/UI, data science, and artificial intelligence. DBS has also reassured staff that there will be no layoffs, and has announced plans to hire over 700 young talent in specialized programs and traineeships.

site_title: SPH partners Google on joint business plan for 2020
summary: Singapore Press Holdings (SPH) partnered with Google to launch a joint business plan for 2020, focusing on three main pillars: growing digital advertising revenue, driving subscription audiences in new platforms, and developing digital video content. The collaboration aims to boost programmatic advertising, reduce churn and friction, and enhance talent and innovation. The partnership reflects SPH's commitment to adapting to the post-COVID-19 business landscape and leveraging Google's technology and innovation capabilities to strengthen the digital advertising and news publishing ecosystem.

site_title: HK land auction fails in rare property market setback
summary: Hong Kong's government rejected all four bids for a 19,788 square meter plot at the former Kai Tak airport, failing to meet the reserve price. This marks the seventh failed government auction in the past eight years, amid the city's worsening economic crisis. The plot, roughly the size of New York's Central Park, offers prime real estate in a densely populated city, but its inability to be used for residential projects may have deterred developers. The government attributed the failed bids to various factors, including market conditions and site attractiveness.

site_title: SPH, IMDA call for short-form video content proposals
summary: SPH and IMDA have launched a call for proposals for short-form video content, aiming to support the local creative community affected by the Covid-19 disruptions. Companies can submit proposals for videos at least 10 minutes long and not exceeding PG-13 classification. The funding will support production of engaging and entertaining content for SPH's audience through its multi-channel platforms. The call for proposals starts on May 15 and closes on June 5, with funding criteria and submission forms available on cfp.sph.com.sg.

site_title: ThaiBev Q2 net profit falls 14.5% in 'challenging' environment
summary: ThaiBev Q2 net profit fell 14.5% to 4.95 billion baht (S$220 million) due to the Covid-19 outbreak's severe impact on Thailand's economy. The company attributed the decline to a "challenging business environment".

site_title: The polarising power of orange wine
summary: Orange wine, a type of red wine made from white grapes, is produced by macerating the juice with the grape skins, resulting in a darker color and tannins. This process, similar to conventional red wine production, sets orange wine apart from traditional white wines, which have minimal skin contact and are fermented quickly. The unique production method contributes to orange wine's distinct flavor and texture, making it a polarizing choice among wine enthusiasts.

site_title: What's Up This Week
summary:

Opposition Party, a Singaporean punk rock band, has launched a YouTube channel.

site_title: Oil prices rise on dip in US crude stockpiles and IEA data
summary: Oil prices rose by 6.7% to $31.13 a barrel after the International Energy Agency (IEA) forecast lower global stockpiles in the second half of 2020. The increase comes amid some countries relaxing coronavirus restrictions, while investors weigh market outlook, tariffs, and sanctions. The rise in oil prices follows a dip in US crude stockpiles and the IEA's data on lower global stockpiles.

site_title: Tesla CEO lists more California homes after vow to sell possessions
summary: Tesla CEO Elon Musk has listed several California properties, including a group of four Los Angeles homes for $62.5 million and a mansion in Hillsborough for $35 million, after announcing plans to sell "almost all physical possessions". Musk, 48, stated that possessions weigh him down and has also threatened to move Tesla's headquarters to another US state if local officials don't allow his car manufacturing plant to reopen. His decision comes as he seeks to address criticism of billionaires, including his own net worth of $39.3 billion.

site_title: Satellite operator Intelsat files for Chapter 11 bankruptcy
summary: Satellite operator Intelsat filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection, listing assets and liabilities between $10 billion and $50 billion. The company received $1 billion in debtor-in-possession financing amid the COVID-19 pandemic's financial disruptions. Intelsat's Chapter 11 filing comes after it suspended its 2020 outlook and delayed filing its first-quarter results. The company needs to spend over $1 billion on clearing activities to meet the FCC's accelerated clearing deadlines and receive $4.87 billion in relocation payments. Intelsat General, a subsidiary, is not part of the bankruptcy proceedings.

site_title: Golden Agri sinks into the red with US$95m net loss in Q1
summary: Golden Agri-Resources reported a net loss of US$95 million in Q1, reversing from a profit of US$18 million the previous year, mainly due to foreign exchange translation losses. Revenue rose 2% to US$1.66 billion, driven by higher average selling prices for crude palm oil. Despite lower sales volume and higher costs, the company's plantations and palm oil mills segment accounted for most of the group's consolidated Ebitda, with the downstream business negatively impacted by supply chain disruptions.

site_title: A consequential pick
summary: US President Joe Biden may choose his vice-president as the 47th US president if he is removed from office or dies. Historically, the selection of a vice-president has had little impact on the general election. However, Biden's age, 77, has become a major issue in the campaign. Despite initial plans to select an African-American woman, Biden is now considering women from different backgrounds, including centrist Senator Amy Klobuchar, progressive Senator Elizabeth Warren, and Michigan Governor Gretchen Whitmer. The choice of a running mate will not only add pizzazz to the ticket but also provide a clear advantage for the vice-president to become the next US president if Biden is incapacitated.

site_title: Retail, F&B players in Singapore to push for fair tenancy legislation
summary: Industry stakeholders in Singapore's retail and F&B sectors are pushing for the adoption of landlord-tenant legislation, citing unfair clauses such as personal guarantee clauses and artificially inflated rent prices. The Fair Tenancy Framework Industry Committee represents over 10,000 companies and has been advocating for greater transparency in rental information. The issue has been exacerbated by the COVID-19 pandemic, leading to calls for government action to protect tenants. The government is expected to unveil its recommendations on May 21.

site_title: Singapore stocks continue to slide; SIA takes a beating
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 49.70 points, or 1.93%, to 2,522.31, amid uncertain economic outlooks and strong risk aversion. The US Federal Reserve warned of significant downside economic risks, echoing the World Health Organisation's bleak warnings amid the global health crisis. The decline follows a similar trend in Asia markets and US futures.

site_title: UK plan to revive housing is set to unlock £82b of deals
summary: The UK government's plan to revive the housing market, announced by Housing Secretary Robert Jenrick, aims to unlock £82 billion of deals stalled by the coronavirus lockdown. The easing of restrictions allows realtors to show homes and homebuilders to resume construction, with approximately 373,000 stalled sales expected to move forward. However, house prices are expected to be lower initially, and may not recover for about a year, according to the Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors.

site_title: RHB sees value among small-cap stocks amid Covid-19 crisis
summary: RHB Securities suggests investors focus on smaller-cap companies in Singapore that can withstand pandemic challenges. According to Jarick Seet, head of Singapore small and mid-caps at RHB Securities, these companies may emerge from the crisis relatively unscathed or outperform peers. The research team sees value in these companies, which could benefit from the crisis.

site_title: Millions more file for US jobless benefits
summary: The US labor market continues to be severely impacted by the COVID-19 pandemic, with millions of Americans filing for unemployment benefits. Initial claims for state unemployment benefits totaled 2.981 million for the week ended May 9, marking the sixth straight weekly drop but still higher than economists' expectations. The report cements a third straight month of massive job losses in May, with the economy losing 20.5 million jobs in April. Economists attribute the continued elevation in claims to processing of application backlogs and the processing of job losses during the pandemic.

site_title: Number of bankruptcy applications at the lowest since October 2016
summary: Singapore has seen a significant drop in personal bankruptcy applications, with 160 cases filed in April, a 65% decrease from March. This is the lowest number since October 2016, largely due to temporary laws increasing debt thresholds and courts delaying insolvency cases amid tightened lockdown measures.

images.alt_text: IRB Law's Mohamed Baiross says the numbers are unlikely to pick up as long as the temporary provisions are in place.

site_title: KL drops 1MDB case against Wolf of Wall Street producer
summary: Malaysian prosecutors have dropped a $248-million money laundering case against Riza Aziz, co-founder of Red Granite Productions and stepson of former Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak, citing a deal for an undisclosed amount of funds to be paid to the government. The charges were withdrawn without acquittal after a deal was reached, with prosecutors stating steps would be taken to ensure a full acquittal upon completion of the deal.

site_title: Outlook for Luxury: Conservative Buying
summary: Luxury retailers in Singapore are cautiously optimistic about the outlook despite pent-up demand. A day after Hermes reopened its flagship store in Guangzhou, it recorded S$3.8 million in sales, but this is not representative of the entire market. Instead, "revenge shopping" only appeals to those with extra cash, and most consumers will adopt a wait-and-see attitude. To adapt, retailers must prioritize safety, social commerce, and customer-centric solutions, and be prepared to evolve their sales methods to retain customers.

site_title: Tired of confinement, Spaniards now keener on homes in suburbs than city centres
summary: Spain's coronavirus outbreak may shift homebuyers away from city centers, with Aedas Homes observing a 25% increase in inquiries for suburban homes. Since March, people are seeking lifestyle changes due to the health emergency. This trend may indicate a shift in demand, with city center homes potentially losing appeal. The prediction comes as the country continues to navigate the pandemic's economic impact on the housing market.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Sasseur Reit, a Chinese outlet mall owner, reported a 19.4% drop in distribution per unit to 1.334 Singapore cents for its first quarter. Rental income fell 10.1% to S$27.6 million, impacted less by the Covid-19 pandemic due to its entrusted management agreements model. Huan Hsin, an electronics contract manufacturer, issued an exit offer letter to shareholders at S$0.016 per share. Frencken Group, a manufacturer, posted a 10.5% year-on-year increase in net profit to S$9.5 million, despite a 4.8% decline in revenue due to the pandemic.

site_title: New high of 1,164 Covid-19 patients discharged; 752 new cases identified
summary: Singapore reported a daily high of 1,164 Covid-19 patients discharged, with 752 new cases identified, bringing the total count to 26,098. The number of people fully recovered from the disease has risen to 5,964. Globally, the outbreak has infected over 4.4 million people, with 298,000 deaths, and the US remains the worst-hit country with over 1.4 million cases and 85,000 deaths.

site_title: Enterprise is tough but rewarding
summary: A letter to the editor expresses the author's experience as an independent contractor, highlighting the challenges and rewards of entrepreneurship. Despite initial struggles to convince clients, the author gained valuable experience and relevant skills. The author attributes success to access to mentors and a supportive ecosystem, which increases the chances of success for entrepreneurs. Successful entrepreneurs contribute to innovation, job creation, and building resilient societies, making entrepreneurship a tough but rewarding path.

site_title: Homegrown superhero universe packs a punch for Indonesian moviemakers
summary: Indonesian moviemakers have created a homegrown superhero universe, Bumilangit, with a Marvel-style cinematic universe, featuring the first movie "Gundala", directed by Joko Anwar. The film is set to play in cinemas across North America, tapping into growing global demand for diverse characters. This marks a significant step for Indonesian film industry, showcasing its potential to compete with global franchises.

site_title: PropNex's Q1 net profit more than triples on higher property transactions
summary: PropNex, a Singaporean real estate agency, reported a 3.4-fold increase in Q1 net profit to S$8.2 million, driven by higher property transactions and a recovery in the private home market. Revenue rose 82.7% to S$135.6 million. The company attributes the growth to a private residential market recovery and expects 30 projects with over 10,000 units to be launched in subsequent quarters. However, PropNex warns of a potential contraction in the private residential segment for 2020, with most impact expected in the second half of the year.

site_title: Capacity crunch ruled out as cause of M1 outage; users to get fee rebates
summary: M1, a Singaporean network operator, has attributed its fibre service outages to network upgrading, contrary to initial speculation of a capacity crunch. The disruptions, which affected thousands of users, have sparked an investigation by the Infocomm Media Development Authority. M1 users can apply for a one-week rebate on their June home broadband bills. The company is cooperating with the probe and prioritizes service reliability, taking extra measures to prevent future incidents.

site_title: Virus pushes Food&HotelAsia trade show to May 2022
summary: The Food&HotelAsia trade show has been postponed to May 2022 due to the ongoing Covid-19 pandemic, two years after its initial planned date in 2020. The event, which was set to take place at the Singapore Expo, will now run from May 10-13, 2022, with the venue remaining unchanged. The organiser, Informa Markets, has decided to use the extra time to develop a new and improved show to make up for the delay.

site_title: Outlook On Luxury: Can Virtual Sales Hold Up The Market?
summary: The art world has rapidly shifted to digital sales platforms due to the cancellation of art fairs and exhibitions. Artists are leveraging social media to showcase their work, engage with followers, and sell luxury goods. Auction houses have seen significant online business, with Phillips reporting a 127% increase in new account creations in April 2020. Online art sales have also seen a rise, with the March online art sale in New York achieving a 52% increase from the previous year and setting new auction records for artists such as Noah Davis, Yoan Capote, and Leonardo Drew.

site_title: Gourmet dining the DIY way
summary: Chefs' meal kits are helping diners replicate professional-level cuisine at home with DIY meal kits. While the process may not be as simple as the instructions suggest, those who successfully execute the recipes can experience the satisfaction of an a la minute experience. Meal kits offer a convenient way for diners to create gourmet meals without needing extensive cooking skills, but the outcome depends on individual cooking abilities.

site_title: UK home prices predicted to fall as property sector slowly reopens
summary: UK home prices are predicted to fall as the property sector slowly reopens after the Covid-19 pandemic. Three-quarters of chartered surveyors expect prices to drop in the coming weeks, with some predicting a 4% decline. Rents are also expected to fall across the UK in the next three months, but stabilize in a year. Property sales prices are predicted to rise by around 2% per annum over the next five years. The market is expected to recover to pre-Covid-19 levels in about a year, with some predicting a 5% price fall in prime London and 7% in the UK.

site_title: Australia media group wants tech giants to pay US$400m a year
summary: Australia's leading media group, Nine Entertainment, is calling for tech giants Google and Facebook to pay around US$400 million annually as part of a mandatory code of conduct ordered by the government. The proposed payment is estimated to be 10% of the tech companies' advertising revenue in Australia, which is around A$6 billion per year. The move aims to ensure more advertising revenue flows to publishers and address the crisis faced by Australia's struggling news industry. The government has ordered the tech giants to share advertising revenues and cover data sharing and news content ranking.

site_title: Jessica Minh Anh, Model & Fashion Show Producer
summary: Vietnamese-born model and fashion show producer Jessica Minh Anh built a successful career by staging fashion shows at iconic locations like the Eiffel Tower and Grand Canyon Skywalk. Despite limited job prospects after graduating in the 2008 financial crisis, she started her own company from scratch and has since become a global brand. Anh's secret to success lies in effectively pitching her ideas, combining a bullet-proof plan with a talented team and global PR strategies. She also believes in promoting meaningful causes alongside fashion, and her shows have become a platform for designers to showcase their work and for her to raise awareness on renewable energy and sustainability.

site_title: Have property cooling measures lost their punch?
summary: Singapore's property market has had 10 rounds of cooling measures since 1996, but their efficacy is questioned. Experts suggest that these measures may have lost their punch due to prolonged periods of low interest rates and a lack of significant price drops. The prolonged COVID-19 pandemic has disrupted the economy, and governments have resorted to unconventional tools to mitigate the effects. As a result, property cooling measures may need to be re-evaluated to address the changing market landscape.

site_title: GM to resume building vehicles in Mexico
summary: General Motors plans to resume building vehicles in Mexico as early as next week, following government approval for factory restarts. The automaker will restart its three Mexican vehicle-assembly plants, including a full-sized truck factory in Silao, to restock low inventories of its lucrative pickup trucks. This move is crucial for GM and other Detroit-based automakers, as Mexico provides critical parts and manufacturing facilities for trucks that generate significant profits. The restart comes after the COVID-19 pandemic forced GM to shut down North American production in March.

site_title: Olam's Q1 net profit up 6.1% at S$179m on net exceptional gains
summary: Olam International reported a 6.1% increase in net profit to S$179.1 million for the first quarter, driven by S$43.2 million in net exceptional gains from the divestment of its Far East Agri stake. Excluding exceptional items, earnings fell 24.9% to S$135.9 million, while revenue rose 4.6% to S$7.68 billion.

site_title: World leaders 'unlikely' to meet at UN assembly as planned in September: Guterres
summary: World leaders are unlikely to meet in person at the UN General Assembly in September due to the ongoing Covid-19 pandemic, according to UN Secretary-General Antonio Guterres. The meeting, scheduled for September 15, may instead be held by videoconference, with some ambassadors predicting a "hybrid" event with a reduced physical presence. The UN headquarters has been largely empty since mid-March, with employees and diplomats working from home, and the meeting has never been cancelled since the UN's founding in 1945, but has been delayed twice before.

site_title: Powell rules out negative interest rates
summary: Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell ruled out negative interest rates, citing the committee's unchanged view on the tool. Powell stated that policymakers may need to do more to prevent bankruptcies and unemployment, warning that liquidity problems can turn into solvency issues. The Fed has taken drastic measures to combat the coronavirus pandemic, including cutting interest rates to nearly zero and implementing emergency lending programs. Despite speculation about negative rates, Powell emphasized that the Fed has a good toolkit and will not consider it at this time, with US President Donald Trump disagreeing with the decision.

site_title: M1 blames upgrade drive for service disruption; offers one-week rebate to users
summary: Singapore's M1 network operator blamed a "network bolstering initiative" for its broadband service outage, which affected thousands of users. The outage occurred on Tuesday and Wednesday, and the company ruled out a capacity crunch and cyber attack as causes. M1 will offer a one-week rebate to affected users and is cooperating with the Infocomm Media Development Authority's probe. The incident comes after a rival telco, StarHub, experienced similar issues in April.

site_title: ThaiBev Q2 net profit falls 14% to 4.95b baht in a 'challenging' environment
summary: ThaiBev recorded a 14% decline in Q2 net profit to 4.95 billion baht due to the challenging business environment caused by the Covid-19 outbreak. The company attributed the decline to measures implemented by the Thai government, including closures of entertainment venues and restaurants, and temporary prohibition on alcoholic beverage sales. ThaiBev expects these measures to affect sales figures in the next quarter.

site_title: Singapore commercial property investment volume dives 78% in Q1
summary: Singapore's commercial property investment volume plummeted 78% in Q1 to $432 million, the lowest in a decade, according to Real Capital Analytics. This decline is largely due to a high base from 2019, when the market saw record investment volumes. Despite this, experts expect Q2 to see a slight increase in transactional activity, with some predicting a surge in big-ticket transactions. However, market observers remain cautious, citing a "buyer-seller stalemate" and uncertainty over asset values due to the Covid-19 pandemic.

site_title: Why open offices will survive in post-Covid-19 era
summary: Open offices may survive the post-Covid-19 era, despite concerns about germ transmission and reduced productivity. Essential organizations that remained open during lockdowns implemented measures such as staggering shifts, remote work, and one-way travel. However, redesigning open offices is expensive and may not be feasible. Instead, companies are focusing on behavior change, including increased cleaning, touchless technology, and flexible work arrangements. Many firms will likely encourage remote work and staggered office visits, and some may adopt new layouts that prioritize social distancing and hygiene.

site_title: Preparing for a roller-coaster
summary: Economists disagree on whether inflation rates will rise or fall in the coming years, contradicting a decade of stable rates. Some predict a surge in inflation due to global supply chains being reversed, increased money supply, and a V-shaped economic recovery, while others expect deflation due to a prolonged pandemic, excess supply, and weak demand. The uncertainty stems from the COVID-19 pandemic's impact on consumer demand, global supply chains, and central bank policies. The outcome will likely be a rollercoaster of inflation rates, affecting labor markets, wage inflation, and consumer spending.

site_title: Looks like remote working is here to stay
summary: Remote working is likely to become a permanent fixture in many workplaces post-COVID-19, with many employees eager to continue working from home. A recent survey in Singapore found that 8 in 10 employees wish to continue working from home at least half the time or more after the enhanced distancing measures are lifted. Organizations that adopt a hybrid distributed model, combining remote and on-site work, can increase resilience, reduce costs, and boost employee morale. By adopting Agile methodologies and reengineering processes, leaders can build a "one-team" culture and create a more flexible and efficient work environment.

images.alt_text: Companies that use the crisis to take purposeful steps towards remote working will find themselves better prepared to pull through Covid-19.

site_title: SIA posts S$732m Q4 loss as bad hedges worsen virus woes
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) posted a net loss of S$732.4 million in Q4, reversing from a net profit of S$202.6 million in the same period last year. The loss was largely due to S$198 million in fuel hedging losses as fuel prices plummeted towards the end of the quarter. SIA is also exploring alternative funding sources, including secured financing and sale-and-leaseback transactions, amid worsening virus-related woes.

images.alt_text: SIA sees no visibility on the timing or trajectory of an aviation recovery at this point as there are few signs of an abatement in the Covid-19 pandemic.

site_title: Outlook on Luxury: Setting a new path for gems
summary: Jewellers believe a luxury market rebound is imminent, despite a predicted 20-35% contraction for the full year. China's post-lockdown shopping sprees have given players reason to be optimistic. Bvlgari's CEO, Jean-Christophe Babin, notes that the company reopened all stores in China after the crisis and saw excellent results, exceeding previous year's sales. However, business in other countries has been halted until their peaks pass, highlighting the need for a 'reset' button. A potential global rebound is on the horizon, with China leading the way.

site_title: Banking amid a pandemic
summary: Singaporean banks DBS, OCBC, and UOB have undergone leadership changes amid the pandemic. Tan Teck Long, a former DBS veteran, will succeed Helen Wong as OCBC's CEO. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and the People's Bank of China (PBOC) plan to deepen cooperation in green and transition finance. China's GDP growth is expected to slow, increasing pressure on policymakers. Citigroup has set a target of 1,150 for the MSCI's global equity index by mid-2026. Chinese banks are struggling due to Beijing's consumer lending push.

site_title: The Hot Mess Of Hollywood
summary: Ryan Murphy's new Netflix series Hollywood reimagines 1940s Hollywood as a progressive town, addressing the racist, sexist, and homophobic wrongs of its past. The show aims to right the wrongs of actress Anna May Wong, who was forced to play stereotypical roles and was denied Oscar recognition for her complex performances. In reality, Wong won an Oscar for her portrayal of a complex woman, differing from the "yellow face" stereotypes. The series seeks to bring change to the US and the world, mirroring Wong's own words about playing a woman with heart and soul.

site_title: German court dispute goes to EU's heart
summary: A German constitutional court's ruling challenging the European Central Bank's (ECB) role in quantitative easing has significant implications for the European Union's (EU) legal structures and the heart of the European project. The ECB is not seriously threatened, but the central bank may need to review its actions. The ruling also challenges the EU Court of Justice's authority, potentially leading to a reevaluation of the EU's intergovernmental vs. supranational nature. The outcome could force compromises and diminish the EU's authority over member states, raising questions about the EU's future.

site_title: Outlook on luxury: Fashion gets real
summary: Luxury industry players report spending sprees despite COVID-19 pandemic, with top auction houses and brands seeing increases in sales. However, global consultancy Bain & Company predicts a 20-35% contraction in the global luxury market for 2020, citing a decline of 25% in the first quarter. Despite this, brands are shifting focus to online platforms, customer service, and community engagement, with many donating to healthcare and research efforts. Analysts predict a transformed industry with consumers driving demand for substance over hype, and brands must adapt to remain relevant.

site_title: Outlook For Luxury: Delivering A New Dining Experience
summary:
Restaurateurs and chefs weigh in on the post-Covid-19 F&B landscape, with a focus on adapting to social distancing norms. Key findings include:

* Many restaurants are diversifying revenue streams through delivery and takeaway services, with some achieving up to 50% of original revenue.
* A new model combining dine-in and delivery operations is being explored, with a focus on quality in-home experiences.
* Restaurants are investing in air filtration systems and other safety measures to ensure a safe dining environment.
* Long-term planning is crucial, with some restaurants considering restructuring and rebranding to adapt to the new normal.
* Delivery platforms are expected to remain a significant revenue driver, but may not be sustainable in the long term.
* Fine dining restaurants are struggling to adapt to the new reality, with some considering a shift to mid-tier concepts or virtual branches.

site_title: Best World Q1 net profit up 29% to S$13.3m, led by Taiwan, China sales
summary: Best World International, a Singapore-listed skincare company, reported a 28.6% year-on-year increase in Q1 net profit to S$13.3m, driven by 39.7% revenue growth to S$74.6m, mainly due to strong sales in Taiwan and China. Revenue from Taiwan rose 29.8% and from China, 53.2%. However, the company expects volatility in its performance due to ongoing COVID-19 concerns, delayed shipments, and construction delays in Singapore.

site_title: Redefining safety and security in a digital-only world
summary: Governments worldwide are redefining safety and security in a post-pandemic digital-only world. The COVID-19 outbreak has accelerated the shift, with billions working from home, online learning, and digital connections. To address this, governments must focus on ensuring security in collaboration platforms and protecting citizens' data. This requires transparency about data storage and use, empowering consumers to make informed decisions, and holding companies accountable for data misuse. A balance must be struck between holding corporations responsible and providing citizens with data protection and societal benefits.

site_title: US: Wall St opens lower on economic concerns, trade war fears
summary: US stocks opened lower on Thursday, with the Dow Jones falling 198.91 points, or 0.86%, to 23,049.06. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also declined, as investors grappled with economic concerns due to the coronavirus outbreak and the threat of a renewed Sino-US trade war. The decline came despite the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reaching fresh records earlier in the week.

images.alt_text: US stocks opened lower on Thursday as investors grappled with the possibility of prolonged economic weakness due to the coronavirus outbreak, while the threat of a renewed Sino-US trade war also added pressure.

site_title: Centurion posts higher Q1 revenue but expects Covid-19 to push up operating costs
summary: CENTURION Corp posted higher Q1 revenue, driven by 15% year-over-year growth in its purpose-built workers' accommodation business to S$22.8 million and 13% growth in student accommodation to S$12.4 million. However, the company expects disruptions from Covid-19 to push up operating costs.

site_title: Data privacy startup Dathena raises US$12m in Series A round led by Jungle Ventures
summary: Dathena, a Singapore-based data privacy startup, has raised US$12 million in a Series A round led by Jungle Ventures. The funding will be used to expand its sales, marketing, and customer success teams in the US, as well as build up its research and development efforts. Dathena uses AI-powered solutions to help identify, classify, and protect sensitive information and ensure regulatory compliance. With the new funding, the company plans to expand its co-sell partnership with Microsoft into the US and further grow its global presence.

site_title: Europe: Shares hit 3-week low on doubts over speedy recovery
summary: European shares hit a 3-week low due to investor concerns over a prolonged economic downturn caused by the coronavirus pandemic. The Stoxx 600 index fell 2.2% to its lowest level since April 22, driven by worries about a second wave of infections from early easing of lockdowns. This marks a reversal of the index's sharp recovery from mid-March lows, which was aided by massive stimulus actions.

site_title: Rajah & Tann, CMS, Cooley invest over US$10m in global open platform for lawyers
summary: Three international law firms, CMS, Cooley, and Rajah & Tann, have invested over $10 million in Lupl, a global open platform for lawyers. The platform aims to synchronize all aspects of legal matters into a single secure space, enabling efficient collaboration and workflow. With over 10,000 lawyers from major law firms and corporations beta-testing it, Lupl is set to become financially independent in the long term. The platform will be available in all markets and will integrate with various technology providers via open APIs.

site_title: Renault to discontinue iconic models as carmaker cuts costs
summary: Renault plans to discontinue iconic models like the Espace minivans, Scenic, and Talisman as part of its cost-cutting efforts to trim down its vehicle range. The company aims to cut costs by 2 billion euros over the next three years, coinciding with its Japanese partner Nissan's strategic update. Renault will focus on crossovers and SUVs, with the Espace and other models considered "practically a given" to be scrapped. This move follows Renault's first net loss in 10 years and the impact of the coronavirus crisis on the car industry.

site_title: Oil outlook improves 'somewhat' on easing virus lockdowns, output cuts: IEA
summary: The International Energy Agency (IEA) reports that the oil market has steadied somewhat since the "Black April" due to easing virus lockdowns and steep production cuts. Global oil demand is now expected to fall by 8.6 million barrels per day, a modest improvement from the previous estimate of a 9.3 million barrel drop. However, major uncertainties remain, including the possibility of a virus resurgence and whether output cuts can be sustained. If the Opec+ agreement is fully respected, global oil supply is set to fall by 12 million barrels per day, a nine-year low.

site_title: Millions more Americans file for jobless benefits as coronavirus layoffs widen
summary: The US labor market continues to be battered by the global novel coronavirus crisis, with millions more Americans filing for unemployment benefits. Initial claims for state unemployment benefits totaled 2.981 million for the week ended May 9, down from 3.176 million in the prior week. Economists expect a third straight month of massive job losses in May, with the economy losing 20.5 million jobs in April. The continued elevation in claims is attributed to processing of application backlogs and the ongoing pandemic.

site_title: US import prices post largest drop in over five years
summary: US import prices fell 2.6% in April, the largest decline in over five years, as the coronavirus crisis depressed demand for petroleum products. This drop in import prices follows a revised 2.4% decline in March and a 6.8% decline over the past 12 months. Economists had predicted a 3.1% decline. The decline in import prices, combined with a drop in the consumer price index and producer prices, raises concerns of deflation, which could worsen the economic downturn. Lockdowns and reduced global demand have contributed to the decline in prices.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close mostly flat on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's stock market closed mostly flat on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 0.12 to 1,397.25. The index saw a volume of 6.979 billion lots worth RM4.031 billion, with losers outnumbering gainers 614 to 344.

site_title: Qatar makes face masks mandatory on threat of jail, fines
summary: Qatar has made face masks mandatory for everyone stepping outside their homes, with violators facing jail time and fines up to $55,000. The move comes as the country reported a single-day record of 1,733 novel coronavirus cases. The cabinet mandated the wearing of face masks "upon leaving the house for any reason" except when driving alone. This measure aims to curb the spread of the virus amid a surge in reported cases.

site_title: Tesla, California appear to end standoff over restarting factory
summary: California authorities have agreed to allow Tesla's US auto assembly plant in Fremont, California to reopen, ending a politically charged standoff. Authorities met with Tesla representatives, reviewed the company's safety plans, and made recommendations. The reopening is contingent on Tesla's Prevention and Control Plan and stable public health indicators. Tesla can begin augmenting its Minimum Business Operations this week, with a possible reopening as soon as next week.

site_title: Global refining activity slump extends into May as glut builds
summary: Global refining activity has continued to decline in May, with the International Energy Agency reporting a 66.2 million barrels-per-day crude refining throughput, unchanged from April. The decline is attributed to rising crude prices and falling diesel profits, with refiners facing a double whammy of reduced demand and increased storage costs. A gradual recovery in refining activity may start in June, but the easing of lockdown restrictions is expected to boost demand for oil products, putting pressure on refiners to maintain output.

site_title: Thousands of pigs rot in compost as US faces meat shortage
summary: The US is facing a meat shortage due to Covid-19 outbreaks at slaughterhouses, leading to the largest pig culling effort in the country's history. Thousands of pigs are rotting on compost heaps as grocers run out of meat, with an estimated 7 million animals to be destroyed this quarter alone. Farmers are struggling financially and emotionally, with some resorting to euthanizing animals due to the lack of a market for their products. The industry is calling for a shift towards more humane and sustainable practices to address the vulnerabilities in the nation's food system.

site_title: Outlook for Luxury: Holiday With A Purpose
summary: Post-COVID-19, there's cautious optimism that travel will return before the end of 2020, driven by a desire for nature, wellness, and social distancing. A Skyscanner survey of over 6,000 people in the Asia-Pacific region found that over half believe it will be safe to travel internationally later in the year. Travel experts, including Skyscanner's senior director Paul Whiteway, are optimistic that travel will thrive in a post-coronavirus world, citing the desire to reconnect with family and friends overseas and explore the world.

images.alt_text: Belmond Cap Juluca offers seclusion and privacy in its villas.
At one with nature on a game drive in Sabi Sand.
Travellers will want more unique experiences such as a sleeping under the stars at andBeyond's Phinda Private Game Reserve.

site_title: Japfa net profit grows five times to US$35.5m in Q1
summary: Japfa, a staple foods producer and supplier, reported a net profit of US$35.5 million for Q1, five times that of the previous year, driven by 4.2% year-on-year revenue growth across Indonesia, Vietnam, Myanmar, India, and China. Higher feed margins in Indonesia, swine-fattening prices in Vietnam, and raw milk prices in China contributed to the gains. However, the company postponed capital expenditure in South-east Asia due to the Covid-19 outbreak and may face reduced demand due to the pandemic's impact on purchasing power.

site_title: Jumbo posts 72% decline in half-year profit to S$2.1m amid virus outbreak
summary: Jumbo, a Singapore-based restaurant operator, recorded a 71.5% year-on-year decline in half-year net profit to S$2.1 million due to the novel coronavirus outbreak. Revenue fell 13.1% to S$66.7 million, and gross profit margin compressed to 62.6%. To adapt to the pandemic, Jumbo implemented cost-cutting measures, including non-bonus accruals and reduced labor costs. The company expects its bottom line to be significantly lower than the same period last year.

site_title: WTO Chief quits suddenly, adding to global turmoil
summary: WTO Director-General Roberto Azevêdo resigned unexpectedly, effective August 31, amidst global trade turmoil. His departure adds uncertainty to international trade relations during the coronavirus pandemic and escalating trade conflicts. Azevêdo's views clashed with US President Donald Trump's preference for bilateral power politics, and he cited the selection process for his successor as a distraction from desired outcomes. The WTO's operations have been crippled by US refusal to approve nominees for a crucial appeals panel, and Azevêdo's resignation may further complicate trade disputes and negotiations.

site_title: SIA posts S$732.4m in Q4 net loss as bad hedges worsen virus woes
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) posted a net loss of S$732.4 million in Q4 2020 due to fuel-hedging losses and a sharp decline in passenger traffic due to the Covid-19 pandemic. Revenue fell 21.9% to S$3.18 billion, leading to an operating loss of S$803 million. The carrier warned of further fuel-hedging losses ahead and expects fuel prices to remain weak in the near term. SIA's parent airline, SIA, and its subsidiaries, SilkAir and Scoot, also reported significant losses.

site_title: Delta to retire Boeing 777 from its fleet
summary: Delta Air Lines plans to retire its Boeing 777 aircraft by the end of 2020, accounting for a $1.4 billion to $1.7 billion write-off. The airline expects demand for domestic flights to recover more quickly than international flights due to the coronavirus crisis. This move comes as Delta accelerates plans to retire the McDonnell Douglas MD-90, removing the jets in June. The airline's decision is likely to deepen its second-quarter loss.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's property investment volume plummeted 78% in Q1 2020, with just 13 deals completed, a 32% decline from the previous year. DBS plans to hire over 2,000 staff in Singapore this year, including apprentices and specialized roles. Hyflux secured waivers and extensions for its annual reports amid a proposed reorganization. In corporate news, Singapore stocks dropped 1.78% with SIA taking a beating, and the STI settled at 2,526.21. Internationally, Vietnam reacted to the US tariff announcement, while Malaysia and China face economic challenges.

images.alt_text: Singapore experienced a steep decline in real estate investment volume in the first quarter this year, with transactions tumbling 78 per cent year on year (y-o-y) to US$432 million.

site_title: Health groups ask India to rescind Gilead's patents for Covid-19 drug remdesivir
summary: Two health advocacy groups in India have urged the government to revoke Gilead Sciences' patents for the Covid-19 drug remdesivir, citing concerns that the patents will limit access to the affordable treatment in poorer nations. Gilead has signed non-exclusive licensing pacts with Indian generic drugmakers, allowing them to produce remdesivir for 127 countries, but critics argue that this may not lead to cheaper versions being made available in less profitable markets. The Indian government has yet to respond to the appeal.

site_title: PropNex's Q1 net profit more than triples on higher property transactions
summary: PropNex, a real estate agency, reported a 3.3-fold increase in Q1 net profit to S$8.2 million, driven by higher property transactions and a recovery in the private home market. Revenue rose 82.7% to S$135.6 million, largely due to carried-forward transactions and a private residential market recovery. However, the company warned that the private residential segment may contract in 2020, with most impact expected in the second half of the year.

site_title: Singapore stocks drop, SIA takes a beating
summary: Singapore stocks declined 1.93% on Thursday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) settling at 2,522.31. The drop was attributed to risk aversion amid the global health crisis, with the US Federal Reserve chairman Jerome Powell warning of uncertain economic outlook. The STI fell 49.70 points, with Industrials and Consumer sectors being the worst hit. Singapore Airlines (SIA) took a significant beating, with analysts downgrading the stock and forecasting substantial losses for FY2021.

site_title: Pandemic to cost global insurers US$203b: Lloyd's
summary: The global insurance industry is expected to incur a total loss of approximately US$203 billion due to the COVID-19 pandemic, according to a Lloyd's of London forecast. The estimated 2020 underwriting losses are around US$107 billion, while investment portfolio losses are estimated at US$96 billion, driven by plunging global economic activity and social distancing measures. This puts the cost on par with major claims years, such as the September 11, 2001 terror attacks.

site_title: Tesla to cut prices in China again as competition heats up
summary: Tesla is cutting prices of its long-range Model 3 in China by about 20,000 yuan (S$3,998) to stay competitive in the world's largest electric-vehicle market. The move comes as car demand in China gradually recovers from a slump worsened by the coronavirus outbreak. The reduced price, around 6% lower, aims to qualify for state subsidies, but the longer-range variant will still not qualify due to the discounted price exceeding the maximum threshold. Tesla's Shanghai plant has resumed production after "normal maintenance work".

images.alt_text: Tesla is cutting prices of cars sold in China for a second time this month as competition starts to heat up again in the world's largest electric-vehicle market.

site_title: Grab prepares for 'long winter' as virus hits revenue
summary: Grab, a South-east Asian ride-hailing firm backed by Softbank, is preparing for a potentially "long winter" due to the coronavirus outbreak, co-founder Tan Hooi Ling said. Revenue has dropped, with an uptick in food and parcel deliveries, but the core ride-hailing business has declined. Overall revenue is lower than pre-Covid levels, and the company is preparing for the worst-case scenario.

site_title: Frencken Group's Q1 net profit up 10.5% to S$9.5m on forex gain
summary: Frencken Group reported a 10.5% year-over-year increase in net profit to S$9.5 million in Q1, driven by gains from the US dollar's appreciation against the Singapore dollar. Revenue fell 4.8% to S$151.4 million, mainly due to lower sales from the automotive and industrial automation segments. The company expects revenue to be affected by the novel coronavirus' impact on end-user demand and government measures to curb the spread of the virus. Factories in Singapore, Malaysia, and China have resumed operations, while the India factory remains closed temporarily.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei closes down more than 1.7%
summary: Tokyo's benchmark Nikkei index dropped 1.7% on Thursday, closing at 19,914.78, amid profit-taking and cautious trading ahead of Japan's partial lifting of a state of emergency due to the coronavirus outbreak. The broader Topix index fell 1.91%.

site_title: German venture capital firm Redstone raising US$217m fund
summary: Redstone Digital, a Berlin-based venture capital firm, is raising a 200 million-euro fund (S$307.4 million) to invest in startups focused on the fourth industrial revolution. Led by SBI Holdings, the Future Industry Ventures Fund aims to invest up to 10 million euros per company in later growth phases, targeting an internal rate of return of at least 20%. The fund's investments will focus on combining robotics, machine learning, and other technologies to create smart factories. The first investments are expected to be made in the second quarter of 2020.

site_title: China unicorn creation falls to 6-year low as investors play it safe
summary: China's unicorn creation rate has dropped to a six-year low due to investors playing it safe amid the economic impact of the coronavirus outbreak. Only four Chinese startups have reached unicorn status as of May 13, with early-stage venture funding declining 35% and the number of startups founded falling 70% compared to the same period last year. Investors are prioritizing helping portfolio companies survive the pandemic over new investments, with many businesses suffering falling sales and tighter cash flow.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end with more losses
summary: Hong Kong stocks declined 1.45% on Thursday, following a global downturn, as the head of the Federal Reserve warned about the economic impact of coronavirus shutdowns. The Hang Seng Index fell to 23,829.74, while the Shanghai Composite Index dropped 0.96% to 2,870.34. The decline was attributed to concerns over the economic impact of the pandemic and US-EU trade tensions.

site_title: Taiwan says WHO has 'forgotten' neutrality by barring island
summary: Taiwan's Vice-President Chen Chien-jen accused the World Health Organization (WHO) of "forgotten" its neutrality by excluding the island due to China's influence. Taiwan claims the WHO has misreported its infections and not provided coronavirus information. The WHO disputes this, saying Taiwan has received all necessary help but only China can represent it in the organization. Chen criticized the WHO's prioritization of politics over health, saying Taiwan's 23 million people have become "orphans" in the global health system.

site_title: Japan lifts virus emergency for most regions
summary: Japan's Prime Minister Shinzo Abe lifted a state of emergency for 39 out of 47 prefectures due to the coronavirus, but kept it in place for top cities Tokyo and Osaka. New infections have sharply declined, enabling the government to end the measure before it was due to expire on May 31. However, Abe warned residents to remain vigilant and urged citizens to refrain from going out and visiting other regions to prevent a possible fresh outbreak.

images.alt_text: With new cases still emerging daily in Tokyo, Osaka and the northern island of Hokkaido, Prime Minister Shinzo Abe told reporters in a televised news conference that the state of emergency would be kept in place for those regions.

site_title: DBS to hire more than 2,000 in Singapore this year amid pandemic
summary: DBS, Southeast Asia's largest lender, plans to hire over 2,000 people in Singapore this year, despite the economic downturn caused by the Covid-19 pandemic. The bank will create over 1,000 new permanent roles, including apprenticeships for fresh graduates and specialized roles for seasoned professionals, particularly in growth technology areas. DBS will also offer internships and specialized talent development programs to help staff upskill and transition to technology careers. The bank aims to avoid layoffs and ensure its 12,000-strong workforce in Singapore remains on full pay.

site_title: UK surveyors expect price falls when housing market reopens
summary: UK property surveyors predict a decline in house prices as the market slowly reopens after the Covid-19 lockdown. Eighty percent of surveyors reported buyers and sellers pulling out of transactions in April, and 40% expect a price drop of more than 4%. The Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors (RICS) expects prices to recover their pre-lockdown levels in 11 months. Nearly two-thirds of surveyors believe a temporary suspension of stamp duty tax will help the market recover.

site_title: Proposed changes to Singapore's data protection law seek stiffer penalties for info leaks
summary: Singapore is considering stricter penalties for data breaches under proposed amendments to the Personal Data Protection Act. Fines could reach up to 10% of annual gross turnover or S$1 million, similar to the EU's General Data Protection Regulation. The amendments also include requirements for organisations to notify authorities and affected individuals of data breaches and introduce a Data Portability Obligation, allowing individuals to request a copy of their personal data. The public consultation on the draft bill ends on May 28.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets slide further at open
summary: Europe's main equity markets slid further at the start of trade on Thursday, with London's FTSE 100 index down 1.44% to 5,819.21 points, and Frankfurt's DAX 30 index losing 1.4% to 10,397.46 points. The Paris CAC 40 dropped 1.5% to 4,279.26. Fears of a potential second wave of coronavirus infections and US-EU trade tensions contributed to the losses.

site_title: Airbus to start talks with unions on permanent job cuts
summary: Airbus is set to initiate talks with labor unions on permanent job cuts amid a collapse in demand due to the coronavirus pandemic. The company has already reduced production goals by over a third and is considering cutting back on temporary and subcontracted workers, with the number of positions to be eliminated yet to be decided. Airbus executives will discuss an initial plan on a call next week, with the process expected to take months to finalize.

site_title: Seoul: Shares fall as Powell comments drive recession fears
summary: South Korean shares fell 0.80% on Thursday, following Wall Street losses, amid recession fears sparked by US Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell's comments. Powell warned of an extended economic weakness and called for more fiscal spending, but dismissed negative interest rates. The Seoul stock market's main KOSPI closed at 1,924.96, 15.46 points lower. This decline follows Powell's comments, which also affected Wall Street's three major indexes on Wednesday.

site_title: Japan says Gilead's Covid-19 treatment remdesivir now in use in hospitals
summary: Japan has begun treating severely ill COVID-19 patients with Gilead Sciences' remdesivir drug, which was approved for emergency use on May 7. The US-based company has pledged to donate 1.5 million doses, with a portion already given to the Japanese government. Remdesivir has shown promise in reducing hospital stays by 31% compared to a placebo treatment, although it did not significantly improve survival. Japan has distributed the drug to hospitals since May 11, targeting patients in intensive care or on ventilators, as the country seeks to curb the coronavirus outbreak.

site_title: Hotel, restaurant and cafe suppliers' trade show postponed to 2022
summary: The FHA-HoReCa trade show for hotel, restaurant, and cafe suppliers has been postponed by two years to 2022 due to the Covid-19 pandemic. Originally scheduled for March 2020, the event was postponed to July 2020 and then to May 2022, with the venue remaining unchanged.

site_title: Indonesian moviemakers bet on homegrown superhero universe
summary: Indonesian filmmakers are launching a homegrown superhero universe, inspired by local comics, to compete with global franchises like Marvel. The first film, "Gundala," directed by Joko Anwar, has gained critical acclaim and will soon be released in North America. The series, produced by Screenplay Bumilangit, features interconnected characters and settings, drawing from Indonesian mythology and tackling local issues. The success of international superhero films like "Black Panther" and "Captain Marvel" has sparked demand for diverse stories, and Indonesian filmmakers aim to capitalize on this trend.

site_title: BMW CEO sees 'very slow' US recovery after sales rebound in China
summary: BMW CEO Oliver Zipse expressed caution about the US recovery from the coronavirus pandemic, stating it will be "very slow" compared to China, where sales rebounded 14% in April. Despite China's strong rebound, BMW lowered its profit expectations for the second quarter due to weaker-than-expected demand. The company is gradually ramping up production in various countries, including the US, as it navigates the pandemic's impact on global economies. Zipse emphasized that economies in Europe, such as Spain, Italy, and the UK, will also experience slow car demand recovery.

images.alt_text: BMW on Thursday said China sales of luxury passenger cars rebounded in April but the German premium car and motorbike manufacturer cautioned that other markets including the United States will be "very slow" to recover from the coronavirus pandemic.

site_title: Vietnam determined to save British pilot, avoid its first Covid-19 death
summary: Vietnam is determined to save the life of its critically ill British pilot, "Patient 91", who has been on life support for over 30 days with just 10% of his lung capacity left. The country has spent over 5 billion dong (S$302,550) on aggressive testing and a mass quarantine program, and has successfully identified 18 infected individuals connected to the cluster. A lung transplant is the only way to save the patient's life, and 10 people have volunteered as donors, but regulations currently prohibit most living donations.

site_title: Australia: Shares drop as record job losses batter sentiment
summary: Australian shares plummeted to a one-week low as the country reported its largest-ever job losses in April, with 594,300 jobs lost and a 6.2% unemployment rate. The S&P/ASX 200 index fell 1.72% to 5,328.7, erasing gains from 2019 and marking the country's first recession in three decades. The economic toll of coronavirus-induced lockdowns continues to weigh on the market, with Prime Minister Scott Morrison warning of more bad news ahead.

images.alt_text: Australian shares closed at their lowest in more than a week on Thursday after data showed that jobs in the country fell the most on record in April, underscoring the economic toll of coronavirus-induced lockdowns.

site_title: UK's BT Group adds US fiber supplier to limit its reliance on Huawei gear
summary: BT Group, the UK's largest landline network, has signed a long-term contract with US firm Adtran to limit its reliance on Huawei gear and ramp up its fiber-optic system. The move aims to comply with national security rules and follows Britain's 35% cap on Huawei's technology in its networks. The deal will help BT meet its goal of connecting 20 million premises by the mid to late-2020s and may cost it 500 million pounds. The partnership also bolsters Openreach's plan to overhaul its systems, with Adtran expected to make up 10% of its sales.

site_title: Satellite operator Intelsat files for Chapter 11 bankruptcy
summary: Intelsat, a satellite operator, filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection due to financial pain caused by the Covid-19 pandemic. The company listed assets and liabilities between $10 billion and $50 billion and received $1 billion in debtor-in-possession financing. Intelsat needs to spend over $1 billion on clearing activities to meet FCC deadlines and be eligible for $4.87 billion in relocation payments. The company's US commercial arm, Intelsat General, is not part of the bankruptcy proceedings.

site_title: Zoom will seek public feedback on plan for stronger encryption
summary: Zoom plans to offer end-to-end encryption to users, the highest standard of digital communications security, after seeking public feedback on its encryption design. The company will implement stepped-up procedures starting May 30, with GCM-level encryption and the ability for hosts to prevent participants from accessing a single meeting through multiple devices. This comes after the company faced criticism for security lapses, including data sent to Facebook and calls routed through China, and follows the acquisition of secure-messaging provider Keybase.

site_title: Bankruptcy applications dip as legal reprieve takes effect
summary: Personal bankruptcy applications in Singapore have dropped to the lowest since October 2016, with 160 individuals applying in April, a 65% decline from March. The temporary provisions, which raised debt thresholds for personal bankruptcy and corporate insolvency, have taken effect. The number of actual bankruptcy orders and discharged individuals also fell. Lawyer Mohamed Baiross expects the numbers to remain low as long as the temporary provisions are in effect.

site_title: Hot stock: Singapore Airlines slumps to record low ahead of results release
summary: Singapore Airlines' share price plummeted 6.5% to a 30-year low of S$3.74, with 16.6 million shares changing hands. This is the flag carrier's worst performance since 1990. The drop comes ahead of the airline's results release, sparking concerns about its financial health.

site_title: SPH partners Google on joint business plan for 2020
summary: Singapore Press Holdings (SPH) has partnered with Google on a joint business plan for 2020, focusing on three pillars: growing digital advertising revenue, driving subscription audiences in new platforms, and developing digital video content. The collaboration aims to boost programmatic direct advertising and reduce churn with innovative news experiences. SPH will also benefit from enhanced technology and product innovation capabilities, strengthening the sustainability of the digital advertising and news publishing ecosystem.

site_title: Oil rises on signs of easing supply glut
summary: Oil prices rose 1.2% to $25.60 a barrel and 0.5% to $29.33 a barrel as production cuts, triggered by the pandemic, began to ease a supply glut. The US Energy Information Administration reported a 745,000 barrel drop in inventories, while Opec stated the market rebalancing process was underway. However, gains were limited by Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell's warning of a slow economic recovery, which also pushed stock prices lower. Analysts remain optimistic about oil prices continuing to recover as economies restart activity and Opec shows commitment to supply discipline.

site_title: RedDoorz offers online counselling to staff, hotel partners
summary: RedDoorz, a Singapore-based budget hotel operator, is offering free online counselling sessions to its employees, hotel partners, and their staff through its "Hope Hotline" programme. The initiative aims to support mental wellbeing amid the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic. RedDoorz has partnered with counsellors and psychologists to provide video counselling sessions in Indonesia and individual psychologists in the Philippines. The company also plans to host a complimentary webinar on managing daily stress and maintaining emotional wellbeing for professionals in the travel and hospitality industry.

site_title: Singapore posts 78% fall in property investment volume in Q1: report
summary: Singapore's real estate investment volume plummeted 78% in Q1 2020, reaching US$432 million, according to Real Capital Analytics' Asia-Pacific Capital Trends report. This decline was largely due to a record year in 2019 and a significant drop in the number of deals, with only 13 transactions recorded. Despite the slowdown, Singapore remains a global destination for real estate investment, and experts expect deal volumes to recover once yields cross a certain threshold. The Asia-Pacific region as a whole saw a 50% decline in real estate investment volumes to US$21.3 billion in Q1 2020.

site_title: Sasseur Reit Q1 DPU falls 19.4% to 1.334 S cents
summary: Sasseur Real Estate Investment Trust (Sasseur Reit) reported a 19.4% drop in distribution per unit (DPU) to 1.334 Singapore cents for its first quarter ended March 31, 2020. Rental income under entrusted management agreements fell 10.1% to S$27.6 million, mainly due to the weakening of the yuan against the Singapore dollar. Excluding straight-line adjustment, EMA rental income dropped 18.2% to S$25.3 million.

site_title: Hyflux gets waivers, extensions for AGMs and results pending reorganisation
summary: Hyflux, a debt-laden water treatment firm, has received waivers and extensions from the Singapore Exchange and Accounting and Corporate Regulatory Authority to convene its annual general meetings (AGMs) and file annual returns. The company has been granted three-month extensions for each AGM, pushing back the FY18 meeting by 17 months and the FY19 meeting by five months. Hyflux also received four-month extensions to announce its unaudited full-year financial statements for FY18 and FY19, with some quarterly financial statements waived due to the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic.

site_title: UK plans to cut tariffs on US agricultural imports: FT
summary: The UK is planning to cut tariffs on US agricultural imports as part of a free trade agreement, with trade minister Liz Truss leading the "big concession package" to US negotiators. However, Environment Secretary George Eustice has raised concerns that this could undercut UK farmers. The move aims to advance progress on the UK-US free trade deal, but internal opposition from Eustice poses a challenge to the plan.

site_title: Japan seeks to end state of emergency for most regions; Tokyo to stay on alert
summary: Japan is expected to lift a state of emergency for 39 of its 47 prefectures, but Tokyo will remain under restrictions. The move aims to balance economic damage from prolonged shutdowns and the need to contain the virus. The government will reassess the situation in mid-June and may lift the emergency for Tokyo and Osaka before then, which could lead to a faster economic recovery. Japan has reported 16,100 confirmed COVID-19 cases and 696 deaths, with the capital city conducting just 50,000 tests so far.

site_title: New high of 1,164 Covid-19 patients discharged, 1 new cluster
summary: Singapore reported a new high of 1,164 Covid-19 patients discharged, with 752 new cases identified, bringing the total count to 26,098. This marks the third time this week that discharged cases exceeded new patients. The country has seen a decrease in new daily cases outside dormitories and unlinked cases among Singaporeans and permanent residents. Globally, over 4.4 million people have been infected, with 298,000 deaths, and the US remains the worst-hit country with over 1.4 million cases and 85,000 deaths.

site_title: FBI seizes senator's phone in insider trading case, report says
summary: The US Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) seized Senator Richard Burr's phone as part of an investigation into stock sales. The senator, chairman of the Senate Intelligence Committee, sold holdings after receiving closed-door briefings about the coronavirus threat. The seizure came after the FBI issued a warrant to Apple for information on the senator's iCloud account. The move is linked to insider trading allegations, with the Los Angeles Times reporting that Burr and three other senators sold stocks after receiving sensitive briefings. The investigation is ongoing.

site_title: Hong Kong land auction fails in rare property market setback
summary: Hong Kong's land auction for a 19,788 square metre site at its former Kai Tak airport failed to sell after all four bids failed to meet the reserve price. This is the seventh failed government auction in the past eight years, and the second since anti-government protests began in June. The site, roughly the size of New York's Central Park, offers prime real estate in a densely populated city, but the failure marks a reversal from last year when developers were willing to pay top-dollar for the land. The setback highlights Hong Kong's worsening economic crisis.

site_title: Japan's big banks boost lending as pandemic intensifies corporate funding strains
summary: Japan's major banks boosted lending in April at the fastest pace since the 2009 global financial crisis, with outstanding loans rising 3% from the previous year to 553.486 trillion yen. This surge reflects companies' need for funds amid the pandemic-driven funding gap, and analysts expect further increases. The Bank of Japan's cheap loan programme saw a surge in participants, with the number more than doubling to 74. BOJ Governor Haruhiko Kuroda emphasized the need to stabilize markets and smooth corporate financing, with the central bank prepared to take additional steps.

site_title: France to force Web giants to delete some content within the hour
summary: France has passed a law requiring social media companies to remove paedophile and terrorism-related content within an hour or face a fine of up to 4% of their global revenue. The law also sets up a digital prosecutor and government unit to monitor hate speech. Critics argue the law is unrealistic and targets internet giants' business models instead of the content itself. The law aims to reduce online hate speech, with Justice Minister Nicole Belloubet stating it will encourage companies to take responsibility for their content.

site_title: Advocacy group says TikTok violated FTC consent decree and children's privacy rules
summary: A group of privacy advocacy organizations is filing a complaint with the FTC, alleging that TikTok violated a consent decree and a law protecting children's privacy online. The complaint claims TikTok failed to remove all videos made by children under 13, despite agreeing to do so under a 2019 consent agreement with the FTC. The FTC previously fined TikTok $5.7 million for failing to get parental consent to collect children's personal information. The complaint seeks further action against the company for violating children's online privacy rules.
