images.alt_text: A group of privacy advocacy organisations is filing a complaint with the Federal Trade Commission (FTC) on Thursday alleging that the popular app TikTok violated a consent decree and a law protecting children's privacy online.

site_title: US envoy threatens to trigger return of UN sanctions on Iran
summary: The US has threatened to trigger a return of all UN sanctions on Iran if the UN Security Council does not extend an arms embargo on Tehran, set to expire in October under the 2015 Iran nuclear deal. US special envoy Brian Hook confirmed the plan, drafting a Security Council resolution and planning to press for support. However, Russia has signaled opposition to extending the arms embargo, and the US retains the right to renew sanctions if diplomacy fails.

site_title: Germany's new coronavirus cases climb most in 5 days
summary: Germany reported 927 new coronavirus cases, the highest in 5 days, bringing the total to 174,098. Fatalities rose to 7,861, the highest daily death toll since May 7. The reproduction factor of the virus dropped to 0.81, and Health Minister Jens Spahn considers introducing a virus immunity card, despite opposition. Germany's borders with European neighbors will reopen by June 15, as long as the disease remains under control.

images.alt_text: Germany recorded the highest number of new coronavirus cases in five days as the government gradually lifts restrictions on daily life. Still, the infection rate dropped further below a key threshold.

site_title: Australia media group wants tech giants to pay US$400m a year
summary: Australia's second-largest media company, Nine Entertainment, is calling for tech giants Google and Facebook to pay US$400 million a year under a mandatory code of conduct ordered by the government. The payment would be 10% of the tech companies' estimated A$6 billion annual advertising revenue in Australia. Chairman Peter Costello argues that the tech companies are using news content without paying for it, taking advertising revenue that could support journalism. The government's regulations, set to be unveiled in July, will also cover data sharing and news content ranking, with binding dispute resolution mechanisms and penalties.

site_title: China seen draining funds from bank system in surprise move
summary: China's central bank, the People's Bank of China (PBOC), drained 200 billion yuan (S$39.90 billion) from its one-year lending facility, leaving lenders to find additional funds for fiscal stimulus and economic support. This move follows a 30th consecutive day of no short-term liquidity injection, and analysts expect a potential operation on Friday to further cement the MLF rate as China's future policy rate. The move is part of China's efforts to stabilize the economy, which is struggling due to the coronavirus outbreak, with key government meetings scheduled to approve more debt sales and stimulus policies.

site_title: Buzzfeed closes news operations in Britain, Australia
summary: BuzzFeed is shutting down its news operations in Britain and Australia due to the COVID-19 pandemic's impact on advertising revenues. The company will furlough 14 staff members in the two countries and no longer cover local news, but will retain some employees focused on global news topics. This move follows cost-cutting measures, including in the US, where "workshare programs" are being explored to avoid furloughs. The company aims to scale back global ambitions to cut costs and focus on news that resonates in the US.

site_title: Cisco's Q3 gets boost from demand for work-from-home apps
summary: Cisco Systems reported a beat on quarterly revenue and profit estimates, driven by demand for remote-work tools and networking equipment amid the Covid-19 lockdowns. The company's third-quarter revenue fell 8% to $12 billion, narrowly beating analysts' average estimate. Cisco executives said they expect a wider revenue forecast for the full year, but also noted that some customer projects have been put on hold due to the economic challenges faced by certain industries. The company's shares rose nearly 3% after the bell.

images.alt_text: Cisco Systems beat quarterly revenue and profit estimates on Wednesday as Covid-19 lockdowns globally boosted demand for its remote-work tools and networking equipment, sending the Dow component's shares up nearly 3 per cent after the bell.

site_title: Temperature checks, masks the new normal for air travel, says Dubai airport CEO
summary: Dubai International Airport, one of the world's busiest, is implementing temperature checks and face masks for air travelers to mitigate COVID-19 spread. CEO Paul Griffiths notes that physical distancing measures could make flying more expensive due to reduced ticket sales. Until a vaccine or reliable virus detection method is available, measures to reduce contagion risk will be enforced. Global travel recovery depends on countries lifting lockdowns and regaining public confidence in air travel safety, with controlled borders driving demand in the near term.

site_title: Lendlease appoints Gan Chong Min as MD of Asia investment management business
summary: Lendlease appoints Gan Chong Min as managing director of its Asia investment management business, based in Singapore. Gan replaces Kelvin Chow, who now leads Lendlease Global Commercial Reit. Gan brings experience managing high-value real estate funds and large-scale integrated assets, having previously held roles at CapitaLand and the Shanghai-based managing director of fund management. He reports directly to Ng Hsueh Ling, Lendlease's Singapore managing director and Asia chief investment officer.

site_title: China's hot convertibles market on alert for first default
summary: China's convertible bond market is on alert for its first default after Shenzhen Huifeng Bio Agriculture suspended trading in its bond due to concerns over its ability to pay investors. The company warned it may default if a large proportion of its notes fail to convert into equity upon maturity in 2022. The market has become increasingly speculative, with smaller companies raising funds through high demand, pushing up prices in the secondary market. Analysts warn of increased credit risks and the threat of early redemption, with 14 companies reaching their redemption thresholds this year.

site_title: UN warns of global mental health crisis due to Covid-19 pandemic
summary: The United Nations warns of a global mental health crisis due to the COVID-19 pandemic, citing isolation, fear, and economic turmoil as major contributing factors. Experts predict an upsurge in mental illnesses, with vulnerable populations including children, healthcare workers, and those facing domestic violence and economic hardship. The World Health Organization recommends prioritizing mental health, increasing access to psychological services, and providing emergency mental health support via remote therapies. Governments are urged to address the issue urgently to mitigate long-term social and economic costs.

site_title: How managers can address staff's mental health in Covid-19 crisis (Covid-19 Mental Health video series)
summary: Singapore-based psychologist Maria Micha advises managers to watch for signs of low-level anxiety and depression in staff, such as changes in work behavior and presentation. She suggests regular check-ins via video conferencing calls, engaging counselors for webinars, and sending care packages to homes to show care. Small gestures can create trust and confidence in the organization, highlighting the importance of addressing staff mental health during the Covid-19 crisis.

site_title: Software startup FoodRazor raises US$900,000 in seed funds
summary: FoodRazor, a US-based software startup, has secured US$900,000 in seed funding from Cocoon Capital and Found. Ventures, alongside angel investors. The company provides an online platform that digitizes data entry for food and beverage operators, generating cost savings of up to 20%. FoodRazor will use the funding to expand into new markets and industries, such as accounting and logistics. The startup waives three months of subscription fees for customers affected by the Covid-19 downturn, serving 300 restaurants across 8 countries.

site_title: Singapore stocks slip after US retreat; STI opens 1.1% lower
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index fell 1.1% to 2,543.19, following a negative lead from US stocks. The benchmark index retreated 28.82 points, with losers outnumbering gainers 118 to 25. Financial stocks DBS, OCBC Bank, and UOB declined, while integrated resort operator Genting Singapore posted a 55% fall in adjusted earnings. The decline was partly due to concerns over a potential second wave of the novel coronavirus and downbeat comments by the US Federal Reserve head.

site_title: Japan to create scheme to inject capital into pandemic-hit firms
summary: Japan plans to create a scheme to inject capital into large and mid-size companies struggling due to the coronavirus pandemic. State-affiliated lenders will offer subordinated loans or accept preferred shares to help companies strengthen their financial standing. The move aims to prevent bankruptcies and job losses, with the government funding the scheme partly by a second supplementary budget. The plan is part of a broader economic response to cushion the economic blow from the pandemic, which has forced Japan's economy to the cusp of a deep recession.

site_title: 115 lawyers called to the Singapore Bar via Zoom
summary: The Supreme Court of Singapore admitted 115 lawyers to the bar via Zoom in an unprecedented move, marking the first time a bar examination was conducted remotely. The examination was held over six sessions, presided over by two justices. This move aims to increase accessibility and flexibility in the legal profession, particularly during the COVID-19 pandemic.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks drop at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks plummeted 0.59% or 142.23 points to 24,038.07 at the open on Thursday, following a warning by the Federal Reserve head about a long-term downturn caused by the coronavirus crisis. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also declined, with the latter falling 0.41% or 7.48 points to 1,815.38. The downturn comes amid rising US-EU trade tensions and concerns over global economic recovery.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong stocks opened with losses Thursday morning after the head of the Federal Reserve warned about a long-term downturn caused by the coronavirus crisis.

site_title: Philippines moves to allow ABS-CBN broadcast with shorter permit
summary: The Philippines' House of Representatives has approved a temporary franchise for ABS-CBN, allowing the broadcaster to air until October 31, 2020, while lawmakers debate renewing its 25-year permit. The move comes after the network was ordered shut by the telecommunications commission due to its expired franchise. ABS-CBN welcomed the provisional permit and will participate in the renewal process, citing losses of 35 million pesos daily from being off the air. The bill still needs Senate and President Rodrigo Duterte's approval before it can become law.

site_title: New Zealand unveils record spending to deal with pandemic shock
summary: New Zealand has unveiled a record NZ$50 billion fund to combat the economic shock caused by the coronavirus pandemic. The massive spending includes billions on infrastructure, healthcare, and an extension of a wage subsidy scheme. However, the fund significantly widens the fiscal deficit and increases the country's debt levels to 53.6% of GDP by 2023 and 2024. Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern's government is seeking to consolidate support ahead of the September poll, despite warning that thousands may lose jobs and businesses shut down.

images.alt_text: New Zealand unveiled a record NZ$50 billion (S$42.65 billion) fund in its budget on Thursday to restore an economy hit by the coronavirus pandemic, but warned it may not be enough to stop thousands from losing jobs and businesses shutting.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares rise at Thursday's open
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 10.55 points or 0.8% to 1,407.68 at Thursday's open. Trading volume was 296.9 million lots worth RM139.1 million, with 175 gainers outpacing 169 losers.

site_title: Yoma Strategic sinks into the red with US$15.9m H2 2020 net loss
summary: Yoma Strategic Holdings reported a net loss of US$15.9 million for the six months ended March 31, 2020, compared to a net profit of US$20.6 million a year ago. The loss was primarily due to increased interest expenses and administrative costs, offset by lower joint venture losses and a share of profit from associated companies. Revenue rose 4% to US$52.2 million, and the company's full-year net loss was US$73.4 million. Despite the challenges, CEO Melvyn Pun expects the company to weather the current business environment and emerge stronger.

site_title: China needs more active fiscal policy as pressure on economy increasing: People's Daily
summary: China's economy is facing increasing pressure due to the coronavirus outbreak, with fiscal revenue growth declining in the first quarter of 2020. Finance Minister Liu Kun stated that a more active fiscal policy is necessary to mitigate the downward pressure on the economy. Analysts expect the government to announce a substantial stimulus package at the upcoming National People's Congress, which may include corporate relief measures, higher fiscal deficit targets, and debt sales to fund infrastructure projects. China's economy contracted 6.8% in the first quarter, with economists predicting a 1.3% growth rate in the current quarter.

site_title: BNP's Cardif in talks to buy Indonesian life insurer stake
summary: BNP Paribas' insurance arm Cardif is in talks to buy a significant minority stake in PT Asuransi BRI Life, Indonesia's life insurer, with a bid of about US$500 million. The deal would involve a bancassurance partnership between the insurer and Bank Rakyat Indonesia, the country's oldest lender. This would be at least the third attempt by Bank Rakyat to sell a stake in the insurer, after previous attempts in 2015 and 2018. The deal could be finalized within the next few weeks, pending agreement among the parties.

images.alt_text: BNP Paribas' insurance arm is in talks to buy a significant minority stake in PT Bank Rakyat Indonesia's life insurer, according to people familiar with the matter.

site_title: Amazon.com asks for federal law against price gouging during national emergencies
summary: Amazon.com is urging Congress to pass a federal law against price gouging during national emergencies, citing instances of excessive price increases on high-demand products during the COVID-19 pandemic. The company claims to have removed over 500,000 items and suspended 4,000 selling accounts in response to criticism. Amazon argues that disparate state laws on price gouging create challenges for retailers and consumers. The proposed law would define gouging, be enforced by the Federal Trade Commission and states, and come into effect during national emergencies.

images.alt_text: Online retailer Amazon.com, criticised for not acting quickly enough to curb sellers who charged hundreds of dollars for high-demand hand sanitiser during the early phase of the new coronavirus pandemic, urged Congress on Wednesday to pass a law against price gouging during times of national emergency.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower with eyes on Japan virus policy
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower, tracking US falls, as investors await Japan's partial lifting of a state of emergency due to the coronavirus. The Nikkei 225 index dropped 0.70% and the Topix index fell 0.68%. Sony's annual net profit tumbled 36.5% due to the pandemic, while Takeda Pharmaceutical rallied after exceeding market expectations with an operating profit forecast. The Dow ended down 2.2% on Wall Street, with automakers like Honda and Toyota also losing value.

site_title: Pan Pacific Hotels Group provides 20,000 meals for needy families
summary: Pan Pacific Hotels Group has provided over 20,000 meals to low-income families with children through its "From Our Hearts" initiative, in partnership with local organizations. The meals were prepared at a temporary halal-certified facility and distributed until June 1, 2020, as part of the company's efforts to meet community needs during the Ramadan season. This is an expansion of PPHG's initial efforts to provide meals for beneficiaries from local schools and autism centers.

site_title: US: Stocks slump on Fed comments, fears of second coronavirus wave
summary: US stocks fell on Wednesday, with the Dow shedding 2.2% as Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell expressed concerns over the economic outlook and warned of potential additional measures to support the US economy. The decline was also driven by fears of a second coronavirus wave, with data showing fresh outbreaks in South Korea, China, and Germany. European stocks also slumped, with the FTSE 100 index falling 1.5% as the British economy contracted by 2.0% in the first quarter.

site_title: Oil falls 2% despite surprise US crude stock drawdown
summary: Oil prices fell 2% on Wednesday despite a surprise decline in US crude inventories, as the US Federal Reserve chairman warned the economy would take months to recover from the coronavirus pandemic. Global benchmark Brent crude settled at $29.19 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude futures settled at $25.29 a barrel. The US Energy Information Administration reported a 745,000-barrel drop in US crude stockpiles last week, but the market was weighed down by fears of a second wave of coronavirus infections and the Fed's skepticism of negative interest rates.

site_title: Tencent game sales surge most in years in China's lockdown
summary: Tencent Holdings' revenue surged 26% to 108.1 billion yuan in the March quarter, driven by a 31% increase in online gaming sales during China's COVID-19 lockdowns. The company's gaming division benefited from increased spending from homebound players, but warned that gains may decline as China returns to normality and global macro uncertainty affects online advertising spending. Shares rose 4% in Hong Kong, their largest gain in over a month.

site_title: Australian employment plunges, jobless rate at 5-year high on pandemic shutdowns
summary: Australia's employment plummeted by 594,300 in April, the largest decline on record, with the unemployment rate soaring to 6.2%, its highest since 2015. The main reason for the unexpected decline in unemployment was a significant drop in the number of people actively seeking work. The participation rate fell to 63.5%, its lowest since 2004. Economists predict the unemployment rate will continue to rise, with the Reserve Bank of Australia forecasting a 10% unemployment rate by June and a 10% decline in GDP for the first half of the year.

site_title: Europe: Travel and auto stocks lead shares lower amid virus fears
summary: European stocks fell 1.9% on Wednesday, hitting a one-week low, as fears of a coronavirus resurgence and weak economic data dented hopes of a swift recovery. Travel and auto stocks plummeted 5% and 3.7%, respectively, while banking shares slid 3.7%. A batch of weak earnings reports and US Federal Reserve chair Jerome Powell's warning of an "extended period" of weak growth also contributed to the decline.

site_title: More than 280,000 tonnes of petrol stored on Singapore, Malaysian waters
summary: Over 280,000 tonnes (2.4 million barrels) of petrol are stored on ships anchored off Malaysia and Singapore, with three more ships added to the total. This brings the total volume of petrol stored in the region to over 280,000 tonnes, as oil demand slumps due to COVID-19 restrictions. The petrol is stored by Swiss trading company Trafigura and Norwegian refiner Equinor, with the majority coming from India and South Korea.

site_title: Shareholders' loan in AXA Tower deal with Alibaba amounts to S$364.7m: Perennial
summary: Perennial Real Estate disclosed that a shareholders' loan of S$364.7 million, part of which will be transferred to Alibaba Singapore, is associated with its deal to acquire a 50% stake in AXA Tower. The consideration for the half stake will be based on the net asset value of AXA Tower and an agreed property value of S$1.68 billion. Perennial will use the net proceeds from selling its stake to pare borrowings and inject cash into a new consortium, NewCo, which will own the remaining half of the shares and the other half of the shareholders' loan.

site_title: Las Vegas Sands gives up on US$10b Japan project
summary: LAS Vegas Sands, the world's largest casino company, is ending its pursuit of a Japanese casino licence after failing to secure a concession that would last beyond 10 years, a major hurdle. The company had been trying to expand in Japan since 2005 but was deterred by the country's restrictive casino legislation. This marks the end of Sheldon Adelson's multidecade quest for a major prize in the global gambling business.

site_title: Digital currency can impact monetary policy
summary: China's People's Bank of China (PBOC) has begun a pilot test of its digital yuan, the first major economy to introduce a central bank digital currency (CBDC). The move is part of China's ambition to become the digital currency leader, with President Xi Jinping urging greater urgency in the development of blockchain. While China's CBDC is designed to complement fiat currencies, private cryptocurrencies like Libra could pose challenges to monetary policy and potentially replace sovereign currencies, particularly in countries with high inflation.

site_title: Stocks to watch: DBS, SIA, Genting, Olam, Golden Agri, Perennial, SPH
summary: DBS shares jumped 0.4% on a four-fold increase in POSB account openings for migrant workers, with a target to bank all 750,000 migrant workers by end-of-year. SIA shares fell 6.8% after describing the Covid-19 pandemic as the aviation industry's greatest challenge. Genting shares dropped 0.7% after its earnings more than halved for the first quarter. Olam International's shares rose 0.7% after a 6.1% profit rise, while Golden Agri-Resources sank into the red with a net loss of US$95 million. Perennial Real Estate's shares rose 1% after a S$364.7 million outstanding loan was disclosed.

site_title: Condo, HDB rental volumes plunge more than 36%
summary: Singapore's condo and HDB rental volumes plummeted 36.5% and 36.7% respectively in April, with demand sharply dropping due to the "circuit breaker" measures implemented in April. Market observers attribute the decline to reduced foreign expats entering Singapore and travel restrictions affecting the rental market. Rental prices for private condos and apartments dipped 0.9% year-over-year, while HDB rents fell 0.2%. Experts predict the rental market may continue to face challenges in the coming months, with a potential 2-4% year-on-year decline in private residential and HDB rental indices in 2020.

site_title: Olam Q1 PATMI up 6.1% to S$179.1m on net exceptional gains
summary: Olam International reported a 6.1% increase in profit after tax and minority interests (PATMI) to S$179.1 million for Q1 2020, driven by S$43.2 million in net exceptional gains from divesting its Far East Agri stake. Revenue rose 4.6% to S$7.68 billion. The company maintained its liquidity position with S$20.5 billion of available liquidity. Despite the COVID-19 pandemic, Olam's food staples business remained resilient, with demand for non-food categories like cotton and almonds impacted by lockdowns.

site_title: Money FM podcast: Building a better cybersecurity posture
summary: The Money FM podcast "Building a better cybersecurity posture" discussed the importance of robust cybersecurity measures in today's digital landscape. Experts emphasized the need for companies to prioritize cybersecurity and implement effective systems to protect against cyber threats. The conversation also touched on the role of leadership in driving cybersecurity awareness and investment. Key takeaways include the need for a proactive approach to cybersecurity and the importance of leadership in setting the tone for a secure digital environment.

site_title: Sembmarine's Q1 revenue hit by Covid-19, oil price collapse
summary: Sembcorp Marine's Q1 revenue declined due to the Covid-19 pandemic and oil price collapse. The company deferred non-essential capital expenditures to preserve cash flow and manage liquidity. Revenue recognition was also lower due to industry-wide cuts to capital expenditures and delays in executing existing orders. The company generated positive cash flow from operations but remained in a net current liabilities position. Sembmarine expects further weakening of business volumes and continued losses for the rest of the year.

images.alt_text: Sembmarine's Singapore yards continue to operate, having been granted exemptions from the authorities, although a limit was imposed on the number of workers allowed on the premises.

site_title: Frasers Property's Q2 profit falls 38.1%; bosses take pay cuts
summary: Frasers Property's Q2 profit fell 38.1% due to various factors. The company's group CEO, Panote Sirivadhanabhakdi, and senior management members took pay cuts, with Sirivadhanabhakdi's base salary reduced by 25%. Other senior management accepted base salary cuts of up to 10%. This move aims to conserve financial resources, as the company navigates challenging market conditions.

site_title: Will 'revenge spending' save the luxury market?
summary: The luxury market is expected to suffer a significant decline due to the Covid-19 pandemic, with global consultants predicting a 35-60% collapse by the end of 2020. However, "revenge spending" among Chinese consumers and online shopping in Singapore may help mitigate the damage. Fashion houses are finding success online, while jewellers and hoteliers are cautiously adapting to the new normal. Experts also discuss the potential for a rebound and the need for the industry to re-tool and prioritize community presence and social distancing measures.

site_title: Will Covid-19 crowd out the agenda for climate change and other pressing issues?
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has revealed misplaced priorities and gaps in addressing pressing issues such as climate change. Despite the significant economic support measures, policymakers face a long-lasting downshift in demand, leading to a need for new engines of growth. To mitigate this, investments in renewable energy, green infrastructure, and education can be directed towards climate change and societal outcomes. The crisis also highlights the need for well-targeted social safety nets, public health provisions, and national stockpiles to address extreme events. The pandemic serves as an opportunity to galvanize support for climate action and sustainable development.

site_title: April home sales dive 62%; May unlikely to see improvement
summary: Singapore's new private home sales plummeted 62% in April, with 277 transactions, excluding executive condominiums. The drop is attributed to the extended circuit breaker and shuttered sales galleries. The decline is expected to continue in May, with virtual showflats failing to generate sales. This marks a challenging time for the local property market, which was already impacted by the COVID-19 pandemic.

site_title: Airline sector suggests new norms amid Covid-19 threat
summary: The International Air Transport Association (Iata) and Airports Council International (ACI) recommend a layered approach to safety measures amid the Covid-19 pandemic, including contact tracing, temperature screening, social distancing, extra cleaning, and mask wearing. Airlines and airports worldwide are implementing these measures, with some requiring masks and emptying middle seats. Reliable Covid-19 testing is supported, but virus and antibody tests are not viable at airports. The groups emphasize the importance of balancing risk mitigation with travel demand, aiming to restore confidence in air travel safety.

site_title: Indonesia prepares to launch new stimulus plan
summary: Indonesia is set to launch a new stimulus plan to boost its economy, which has been severely impacted by the COVID-19 pandemic. The government has announced a five-stage gradual reopening of business activities starting June 1, aiming to revive the economy by the end of July or early August. The plan aims to mitigate large-scale unemployment and bankruptcies, but economists warn of a potential long-term economic impairment. Indonesia's economy is expected to contract for the first time in over 20 years, with GDP growth predicted at 2% this year.

site_title: US economy may face extended period of weak growth: Fed chief
summary: US Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell warned that the country may face an "extended period" of weak growth and stagnant incomes due to the ongoing coronavirus pandemic. He called for more fiscal spending and pledged to use the Fed's power as needed to mitigate the economic impact. Powell noted that the recovery may take time, and the longer health risks persist, the more likely businesses will fail and households will struggle. He urged Congress to consider additional economic relief measures to avoid long-term economic damage.

site_title: Boards should lead in the focus on sustainability
summary: In the wake of the Covid-19 pandemic, boards must shift their focus towards sustainability, going beyond traditional corporate governance and financial oversight. This requires directors to challenge management and stakeholders to adapt to the new normal and prioritize the corporation's survival and sustainability in a post-pandemic world. Boards must examine key areas, including talent protection, job creation, employee well-being, and social and environmental considerations, to ensure the corporation's long-term viability and protect shareholder interests. By doing so, boards can build a meaningful legacy for future generations.

site_title: Malaysia's Q1 GDP unexpectedly expands, but tough Q2 looms
summary: Malaysia's economy grew 0.7% in Q1, beating expectations, but is expected to contract in Q2 due to the coronavirus pandemic's impact on exports and domestic demand. Private consumption drove growth, but the pandemic is expected to affect the labor market. Unemployment rose to 3.5% in Q1, while exports fell 4.7% in March. The central bank has taken measures to support the economy, including rate cuts and loosened liquidity rules. Full-year growth forecast remains uncertain due to pandemic uncertainties.

site_title: The fight to fuel Australia's post-virus economy
summary: Australia's clean energy industry is pushing for a renewable-powered economic recovery from the Covid-19 pandemic, with a proposed A$50 billion investment in solar and wind projects. However, the government-backed fossil fuel industry is opposing the plan, citing the potential of natural gas expansion projects. The government may struggle to cut ties to the resources sector and commit to de-carbonisation, despite global support for climate-friendly measures. Australia stands out as a global laggard on climate change, and the country's clean energy industry is urging leaders to adopt a greener path to recovery.

site_title: Open source software for public good
summary: Singapore's open-source contact tracing app, TraceTogether, has been made available to the international community, supporting global efforts to combat the COVID-19 pandemic. The app's open-sourced codebase has contributed to Australia's development of its own contact tracing app, COVIDSafe, demonstrating the potential of open-source software (OSS) to foster cross-border collaborations and accelerate digital innovations. OSS offers numerous benefits, including cost and time savings, improved transparency, and increased innovation, but requires careful consideration of its quality, documentation, and licensing terms.

site_title: US court dismisses a cause of action in EIG lawsuit against Keppel O&M
summary: A US court has dismissed one of two causes of action brought by EIG Management Co's funds against Keppel Offshore & Marine (Keppel O&M) in a racketeering lawsuit. The court dismissed the cause of action under the Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act (RICO), allowing EIG to proceed with the remaining cause of action alleging Keppel O&M aided and abetted fraud committed by Petrobras and Sete Brasil Participacoes. Keppel O&M had previously settled a related US$422 million bribery scheme with US prosecutors.

site_title: Golden Agri sinks into the red with US$95m net loss in Q1
summary: Golden Agri-Resources reported a net loss of US$95 million for its first quarter ended March 31, 2020, compared to a net profit of US$18 million in the previous year. Revenue rose 2% to US$1.66 billion, driven by higher average selling prices, but was partially offset by lower sales volume due to logistics issues during the Covid-19 pandemic.

site_title: BT new digital subscriptions double in April from March amid Covid-19
summary: Digital subscriptions at Singapore Press Holdings (SPH) doubled in April from March, with The Straits Times seeing a 40% increase, Lianhe Zaobao a 138% increase, and Berita Harian's doubling. Visitors to SPH news sites and apps nearly doubled, while page views nearly tripled in April 2020 compared to the previous year. Print subscribers also increased, with 65% reading newspapers more frequently, and 40% spending over an hour perusing printed papers. SPH's efforts to provide free Covid-19 articles and a new subscription package have contributed to the surge in engagement.

site_title: Norway's wealth fund blacklists giants over coal
summary: Norway's $1 trillion wealth fund has blacklisted several major coal companies, including Glencore, Anglo American, RWE, Sasol, and AGL Energy, due to their coal production and use. The move, made under Norway's parliament's 2019 decision, aims to align with climate considerations for long-term investors. The fund has also excluded four Canadian oil firms for excessive greenhouse gas emissions and will reverse exclusions if companies address issues raised. The move is seen as a significant step towards reducing coal investments and aligning with climate goals.

site_title: US dollar eases from 3-week high ahead of Fed speech
summary: The US dollar steadied below a three-week high ahead of Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell's speech, as investors await a potential discussion on negative interest rates. Despite US President Donald Trump's call for negative rates, Fed officials have expressed skepticism, with Commerzbank strategist Antje Praefcke saying they are unlikely to be considered. The euro edged down against the US dollar, while the US dollar index remained flat at 100.02, hovering below its recent high. Powell is set to speak on a webcast on Thursday.

site_title: Reopen US economy to reduce unemployment levels
summary: The April US employment numbers show a catastrophic impact of the lockdown on the labor market, with non-farm payrolls declining by 20.5 million and unemployment reaching 14.7%, the highest in over a decade. The services sector, particularly leisure and hospitality, was severely affected, while manufacturing and construction also suffered. The labor market faces a formidable challenge to rebuild jobs and livelihoods, with 22 million jobs lost and 6.4 million people exiting the labor force. A rapid reopening of the economy is crucial to reduce unemployment, but time is of the essence as prolonged unemployment will lead to long-term human and economic costs.

site_title: Covid-19 - lessons for the social services sector
summary: Singapore's social services sector is facing challenges in responding to the Covid-19 pandemic due to the lack of experience and limited funding. The government has set aside S$350 million in Budget 2020 to support the sector, but leaders are worried about the potential loss of funding and long-term sustainability. With over 480 non-profit organizations in Singapore, the sector is under pressure to ensure continuity of services for beneficiaries, particularly those with dementia, in case of a funding crisis or sponsorship pullback. The sector's long-term viability remains uncertain.

site_title: POSB aims to bank all migrant workers by end-2020
summary: DBS's POSB has seen a significant surge in account openings for migrant workers in Singapore, with 41,000 new accounts opened in April, more than four times the usual number. The bank aims to bank all 750,000 migrant workers by the end of 2020, with over two-thirds already having accounts. POSB's mobile app, POSB Jolly, has seen 520,000 downloads and has enabled migrant workers to access digital banking services despite the Covid-19 pandemic. The bank has distributed guides on digital banking to dormitories and is pushing for financial inclusion among marginalized groups.

site_title: WTI June futures in spotlight after US crude's crash
summary: US crude West Texas Intermediate (WTI) futures are in focus as the June contract nears its settlement on May 19, following a historic crash in April. Despite concerns over storage capacity, experts believe there's no need to expect a renewed crash, with open interest levels and changes in the US Oil Fund's strategy reducing selling pressure. Analysts predict a more subdued price movement, with WTI trading in a $10 range, as lockdowns ease and oil majors cut output.

site_title: Controversy over SIA DLC shorts stems from risks caused by SocGen's untimely disclosure
summary: Singapore Airlines' 5x Short Daily Leveraged Certificates (DLCs) were suspended on May 6 after their value fell to zero due to a surge in SIA shares. SocGen, the issuer, made a goodwill payment to traders who lost their entire holdings, citing the complexity of SIA's rights issue and the importance of prompt notifications. However, traders argue that SocGen shifted the goalposts after the match had begun, breaching rules requiring adjustments to be announced earlier. The Singapore Exchange has commenced investigations into the circumstances leading to SocGen's adjustment announcement.

site_title: Wall Street mines Apple, Google mobility data to spot revival
summary: Investors and strategists are using Apple and Google's mobility data to track economic recovery and estimate consumer spending across regions. As countries relax lockdowns, these data sources provide early clues on which economies will recover faster. Asset managers and analysts, such as Legal & General Investment Management, are adjusting their asset allocation based on the data, which shows the US economy holding up better than other regions. However, activity remains weak in major economies, with regional differences apparent. The data is being used to reassess the likelihood of different economic scenarios and inform investment decisions.

site_title: Outage outrage as M1, NetLink fibre issues add to lockdown pain
summary: Thousands of home broadband users in Singapore are without internet access due to outages by M1 and NetLink fibre providers, exacerbating the challenges of the "circuit breaker" lockdown. M1's outage lasted over a day and a half, while NetLink is struggling to fulfil orders due to restrictions on its foreign workforce. The Infocomm Media Development Authority (IMDA) has opened a probe into the M1 outage and warned of strong enforcement action if lapses occur. The disruptions highlight the risks for locally listed telcos, which have been outperforming the benchmark Straits Times Index.

site_title: Japan's Softbank sees consolidation in Latam food delivery
summary: SoftBank Group Corp, a shareholder in Latin America's largest food delivery companies, expects consolidation in most markets due to having more than two players in the food delivery area. According to Paulo Passoni, a senior executive, global consolidation is inevitable. This comes after reports of Uber Technologie's talks to buy Grubhub, and SoftBank's stakes in Rappi and Didi Eats. The COVID-19 pandemic has increased demand for digital services, with digital wallets and online banks booming, making consolidation a more likely outcome.

images.alt_text: Japan's SoftBank Group Corp, a shareholder in some of Latin America's largest food delivery companies, expects consolidation in most markets, a senior executive said on Wednesday.

site_title: Malaysian PM delays confidence vote scheduled for May 18
summary: Malaysian Prime Minister Muhyiddin Yassin has delayed a scheduled confidence vote on May 18, citing the ongoing battle against the coronavirus as a priority. The vote, initially set for May 18, was approved by Parliament last week after 94-year-old Mahathir Mohamad, who resigned as prime minister in February, brought a motion of no confidence. The decision comes as Malaysia continues to grapple with the pandemic's impact on the country.

site_title: India unveils major credit line for small businesses, lenders
summary: India's government has unveiled a $60 billion loan guarantee package to support small businesses, shadow banks, and power companies affected by the novel coronavirus pandemic. The 20 trillion rupee fiscal and monetary package includes 700 billion rupees in debt and equity funds and 900 billion rupees for power distribution companies. Finance Minister Nirmala Sitharaman aims to help 4.5 million businesses by October with collateral-free loans, but opposition leaders say the measures fall short of expectations, particularly for migrant workers who have lost jobs.

site_title: WHO stresses need to find source of coronavirus
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) emphasizes the need to identify the source of the coronavirus to understand how it has rapidly invaded the human species. Director Sylvie Briand stresses that tracing the origin of the virus, which likely originated from bats, can help prevent future pandemics and improve treatments. Despite collecting thousands of samples, the analysis is ongoing, and the WHO has called on China to invite international investigators to assess the virus's origin.

site_title: Two new infections end Hong Kong's 24-day virus clean sheet
summary: Hong Kong has ended its 24-day run of no new local coronavirus cases after two people tested positive, including a 66-year-old woman and her 5-year-old granddaughter. The cases were described as local transmissions, with the woman having no travel history. The city's ability to control the outbreak has been attributed to intensive testing and contract tracing, but the new cases raise concerns about a potential new outbreak. Hong Kong had been easing social distancing measures, including the re-opening of bars, gyms, and cinemas, after a three-week closure.

site_title: S$16b in government Covid-19 support disbursed between March and May so far
summary: The Singapore government has disbursed S$16 billion in Covid-19 support between March and May, with S$7 billion under the Jobs Support Scheme, S$4 billion under the scheme in May, and S$2.5 billion in property and corporate tax rebates. Individuals and households have received S$2 billion, including a Solidarity Payment of S$600. The Covid-19 Support Grant provides up to S$800 per month for those affected by the pandemic. The Health Ministry reported 675 new Covid-19 cases, bringing the country's total to 25,346.

images.alt_text: Ms Indranee says the S$16b worth of aid is on top of existing schemes such as the Ministry of Education's Financial Assistance Scheme and ComCare, which have also been enhanced during this period.

site_title: Fed's Powell says economy may face 'extended period' of weak growth
summary: Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell warned that the US economy may face an "extended period" of weak growth and stagnant incomes due to the coronavirus pandemic. Powell, a deficit hawk, acknowledged the risks and pledged to use more Fed power as needed. He also called for increased fiscal spending to support the economy. The US response to the pandemic has been swift and forceful, according to Powell, but the economy still faces significant challenges.

site_title: Singapore stocks slide; MSCI Singapore drops ComfortDelGro, Sats, SCI, SPH
summary: Singapore stocks declined 15.80 points, or 0.61%, to 2,572.01, amid market anticipation of US Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell's comments on the US economy. The Straits Times Index (STI) was influenced by the removal of four stocks from the MSCI Singapore Index, including ComfortDelGro, Sats, SCI, and Singapore Press Holdings. Investors are cautious, with head of international market strategy at Goldman Sachs warning of uneven recovery prospects and a lower growth, lower interest rate, and lower inflation environment.

site_title: Protesters mock Hong Kong leader on her birthday
summary: Hundreds of protesters gathered in shopping malls across Hong Kong on May 13, 2020, to mock Chief Executive Carrie Lam's 63rd birthday, flouting social distancing rules. Police responded with pepper spray, and at least one arrest was made. The protests, sparked by Lam's unpopular leadership, come as the city has relatively successfully contained the coronavirus. Demonstrators demand an independent inquiry into police handling of protests and universal suffrage, and are incensed by renewed calls for national security legislation from Beijing.

site_title: New S$6m grant scheme to aid Singapore fintechs amid Covid-19
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS), Singapore FinTech Association (SFA), and AMTD Group have launched a S$6 million grant scheme to support Singaporean fintech firms affected by the Covid-19 crisis. The grant, comprising a Business Sustenance Grant (BSG) and a Business Growth Grant (BGG), will help firms maintain operations and continue to innovate. Eligible firms can receive up to S$20,000 for day-to-day expenses and up to S$80,000 for proof of concept projects, with applications opening on May 18, 2020.

site_title: US: Stocks fall as Fed chief warns of lasting economic hit
summary: US stocks fell early Wednesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average down 0.9% to 23,550.84, and the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Indexes down 0.7% and 0.4%, respectively. Federal Reserve chief Jerome Powell warned that more fiscal support may be needed to prevent lasting economic damage from the coronavirus crisis, contributing to the market decline.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: A complaint against surgeon Julian Ong, 70% owner of HC Surgical Specialists, will be referred to a disciplinary tribunal by the Singapore Medical Council. Dr Ong lost a defamation lawsuit against complainant Serene Tiong in April. If found guilty, HC Surgical Specialists may reassess resources and reallocate them to other specialists. Meanwhile, ASL Marine Holdings expects a 40% reduction in Q4 FY2020 revenue due to the COVID-19 pandemic, and Tuan Sing Holdings priced its S$65 million bonds at 7.75%. Executive director Xu Zhan of SIIC Environment Holdings resigned for personal reasons, and Yang Jianwei will take over.

site_title: ABN Amro warns of surging provisions after Q1 loss of 395m euros
summary: ABN Amro warned that provisions for souring loans could reach 2.5 billion euros (S$3.84 billion) this year due to the novel coronavirus crisis and oil price crash, resulting in a higher-than-expected first-quarter loss of 395 million euros. The Dutch bank's exposure to the global oil-and-gas industry triggered losses in the first quarter.

site_title: US producer prices post biggest drop since 2009
summary: US producer prices fell 1.3% in April, the largest decline since 2009, leading to the largest annual decline in nearly 4-1/2 years. The drop was attributed to the novel coronavirus depressing demand, and could potentially lead to deflation. The core PPI also declined 0.2% in March, marking the third straight month of decline, and the largest 12-month drop since November 2015.

site_title: Genting Singapore posts 55% fall in Q1 earnings; remains gloomy for rest of year
summary: Genting Singapore reported a 55% year-on-year decline in Q1 earnings, citing the global COVID-19 pandemic's impact on tourism. Adjusted Ebitda fell to S$146.9 million, with gaming revenue declining 38% and non-gaming revenue down 34%. The company remains pessimistic for the rest of the year, foreseeing a long-drawn recovery. Genting has suspended operations at Resorts World Sentosa and plans to develop an integrated resort in Japan. The company has a strong balance sheet, but expects social distancing measures and border restrictions to hinder recovery.

site_title: Mapletree launches coronavirus virtual shows
summary: Mapletree launched a digital series, "Mapletree Arts in the City on Air," to support local artists, salute frontliners, and entertain Singaporeans during the COVID-19 circuit breaker. The series features 12- to 15-minute clips on YouTube, with new videos uploaded every Thursday and Saturday. The initiative aims to bring cheer to those at home and frontline workers, while providing an avenue for artists to hone their craft. Mapletree invites artists to pitch ideas for the series until May 22, 2020.

site_title: Britain plunges into recession as economy shrinks 6% in March
summary: The UK economy contracted by almost 6% in March, its largest decline since the financial crisis, as the nation went into lockdown to control the coronavirus. The recession is expected to worsen, with the Bank of England forecasting a 25% contraction this quarter. The government has extended aid programs and stimulus measures to support the economy, which has failed to grow for three of the previous four quarters due to Brexit uncertainty. A strong rebound is expected in 2021, but many analysts regard such a scenario as overly optimistic, with some predicting a return to pre-virus levels of activity in 2022.

site_title: Homebuyers get 6 months to review new purchase
summary: The Singapore Ministry of Law has extended temporary relief measures to buyers facing hardship due to the Covid-19 pandemic. Under the Covid-19 (Temporary Measures) Act, buyers with options to purchase (OTPs), sale and purchase (S&P) agreements, or agreements for lease (AFLs) with housing developers now have six months to review their purchases. This relief protects buyers from legal action and allows them to negotiate with developers or re-examine their ability to make payments. The relief applies to contracts entered into before March 25, 2020, with performance due on or after February 1, 2020.

site_title: EU consumer group warns against 'game-changer' Google-Fitbit deal
summary: The European Union's consumer group Beuc has warned that Google's planned $2.1 billion acquisition of Fitbit may harm consumers and hinder innovation, citing concerns over the potential misuse of health data. Beuc argues that the deal could give Google access to a vast amount of health data, allowing it to undermine competition and undermine consumer choice in digital markets. Google has stated that it will be transparent about data collection and user choices, but regulators and privacy advocates remain concerned about the potential risks.

images.alt_text: Alphabet Inc-owned Google's planned US$2.1 billion buy of fitness trackers company Fitbit may harm consumers and hinder innovation, European consumer group Beuc said on Wednesday, calling it a game-changer deal in the health and digital markets.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end lower
summary: Hong Kong stocks ended lower on Wednesday as investors worried about a potential second wave of virus infections amid easing lockdown measures. The Hang Seng Index fell 0.27% to 24,180.30, while the Shanghai Composite Index rose 0.22%. The Shenzhen Composite Index also gained 0.67%.

site_title: EU won't tell airlines to leave middle seat empty as travel resumes
summary: The European Union's executive has announced that airlines will not be required to leave middle seats empty to maintain social distancing, but passengers will be required to wear masks on board and in airports as travel resumes. The EU will propose vouchers for cancelled flights or holidays that remain valid for at least a year, with protection against bankruptcies. Airlines will be advised to limit contamination risks through measures such as hospital-grade air filtering and personal protective equipment.

site_title: Airline industry likely to remain highly competitive even after Covid-19: SIA
summary: Singapore Airlines' CEO Goh Choon Phong says the airline industry will likely remain highly competitive post-Covid-19, despite the pandemic being the greatest challenge faced by the industry. The company is raising up to S$15 billion through rights and convertible bonds to cope with the crisis and has detailed long-term strategies and recovery plans in place. SIA will continue cost-cutting measures and exploring additional funding sources, including secured financing and aircraft sales. The company expects to be in a strong position to "capture opportunities" once air travel returns.

site_title: US accuses China-linked hackers of stealing coronavirus research
summary: US officials have accused China-linked hackers of stealing coronavirus research, warning scientists and public health officials to be on the lookout for cyber theft. The Federal Bureau of Investigation and the Department of Homeland Security are investigating digital break-ins at US organizations working on Covid-19 research. China denies longstanding allegations of cyberespionage, while Iran-linked hackers have also targeted US research in the past. The US is prioritizing coronavirus-related research and data as a key intelligence priority.

site_title: Muhyiddin delays confidence vote, says virus battle takes priority
summary: Malaysian Prime Minister Muhyiddin Yassin has delayed a confidence vote, citing the ongoing battle against the coronavirus pandemic as a priority. Initially scheduled for May 18, the vote, which was triggered by a motion by former Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad, will now be held on a later date, with parliament resuming on July 13. The ruling coalition, led by Muhyiddin, is expected to maintain its majority among 222 elected members of parliament.

site_title: Singapore stocks slip, 4 names dropped by MSCI
summary: Singapore stocks declined 0.61% to 2,572.01, with 2.2 billion securities traded. The Straits Times Index is watching for US Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell's comments on the US economy. Meanwhile, Mapletree Logistics Trust will be added to the MSCI Singapore Index on May 29, while four stocks - ComfortDelGro Corporation, Sats, Sembcorp Industries, and Singapore Press Holdings - will be deleted. Analysts warn that the recovery may be uneven, citing negative growth forecasts and a lower growth, lower interest rate, and lower inflation environment.

site_title: Genting Singapore's Q1 earnings halved; remains pessimistic for rest of year
summary: Genting Singapore's Q1 earnings declined 55% year-over-year to S$146.9 million due to the global coronavirus pandemic's impact on tourism. The company remains pessimistic for the rest of the year, foreseeing a long-drawn recovery. Revenue fell 38% in gaming and 34% in non-gaming segments. Genting implemented cost-cutting measures, including pay cuts for managerial team members, to mitigate the impact. The company has a strong balance sheet and plans to develop an integrated resort in Japan, despite its uncertain outlook.

site_title: More than 280,000 tonnes of gasoline stored on Singapore, Malaysia waters
summary: More than 280,000 tonnes of gasoline, equivalent to 2.4 million barrels, are stored on ships anchored off Malaysia and Singapore, Asia's top oil trading centre. Three ships, owned by Trafigura and Equinor, are carrying gasoline from India, South Korea, and Norway, respectively. The storage is due to reduced oil demand worldwide, with governments restricting people movements to combat the coronavirus. The total volume of gasoline stored is expected to fill 92 Olympic-size pools, with the region's fuel supply continuing to exceed demand.

images.alt_text: At least three more ships loaded with gasoline are now anchored off Malaysia and Singapore, Asia's top oil trading centre, taking the total volume of petrol sitting in the region to more than 280,000 tonnes (2.4 million barrels)

site_title: Opec slashes oil demand forecast but sees cuts helping restore balance
summary: Opec slashed its global oil demand forecast for 2020, expecting a 9.07 million barrel per day (bpd) contraction, or 9.1%, due to the coronavirus outbreak. This is a decrease from the previous forecast of 6.85 million bpd. Record supply cuts by Opec and other producers are helping to rebalance the market, with oil prices having collapsed to a 21-year low of $15.98 a barrel in April. The report suggests that the market is on the path to recovery.

site_title: Indonesia reports biggest daily rise in coronavirus infections
summary: Indonesia reported its biggest daily rise in coronavirus infections with 689 new cases, bringing the total to 15,438. The country also reported 21 new deaths, with 3,287 recoveries. Over 33,000 patients are suspected to be carrying acute respiratory illnesses without a clinical explanation. The country has tested over 123,570 people.

site_title: Deliveroo to top up first 10,000 customer tips to support restaurants
summary: Deliveroo is supporting local restaurants during the Covid-19 period by topping up the first 10,000 customer tips, up to S$30,000, from May 15 to June 1. Customers can now add a tip to their bill, which will be passed directly to the restaurant without commission. Deliveroo will also provide a new payment service, allowing restaurants to receive their delivery revenue within a week, free of charge. This move aims to help restaurants with cash flow and cover costs such as staff wages.

site_title: Seoul: Shares gain ahead of US Fed chair speech
summary: South Korean shares rose 0.95% to 1,940.42, snapping a two-day losing streak, ahead of US Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell's speech. The gains were tempered by concerns over a second wave of the coronavirus outbreak, with 26 new cases reported in South Korea and new clusters in China and Germany. Foreigners sold US$259.90 million worth of shares on the main board.

site_title: Two new infections end Hong Kong's 24-day virus clean sheet
summary: Hong Kong ended its 24-day run of no new local coronavirus cases after two people tested positive, a 66-year-old woman and her 5-year-old granddaughter. The cases were classified as local transmission, with the woman having no travel history. This marks a shift in the city's approach to social distancing regulations, which had been eased after a three-week closure. The new cases raise concerns about the risk of a new outbreak, despite Hong Kong's successful track record in containing the virus, with only around 1,000 cases and four deaths.

site_title: POSB sees migrant worker account openings surge amid virus outbreak
summary: DBS's POSB has seen a significant surge in migrant worker account openings, with a four-fold increase in April, following the COVID-19 pandemic. The bank processed 41,000 accounts, with a target to bank all 750,000 migrant workers by the end of this year. POSB has enabled end-to-end digital account openings and launched a mobile app, POSB Jolly, to facilitate digital banking services, including remittances and SMS-banking, with over 520,000 downloads. The bank aims to promote financial inclusion and provide basic banking services to marginalized groups.

site_title: Australia: Shares end the day higher
summary: Australian shares ended the day higher, reversing an earlier 2% decline, after Commonwealth Bank of Australia reported decent results and sold a 55% stake in its Colonial First State business for A$1.7 billion. The bank booked provisions of A$1.5 billion to cover pandemic-related loan losses. The S&P/ASX 200 index rose 0.35% to 5,421.9, boosted by hopes of a gradual reopening of the local economy and effective management of new virus clusters.

site_title: Australia church fined for selling bleach as virus cure
summary: A church in Australia, MMS Australia, a chapter of the Genesis II Church of Health and Healing, has been fined Aus$151,200 for unlawfully advertising a purported "miracle" coronavirus cure containing bleach. The Therapeutic Goods Administration said the "Miracle Mineral Solution" poses serious health risks, including nausea, vomiting, and severe dehydration. The church claims its website does not promote the cure, but the regulator has received 12 fines for promoting the product, which is banned in the US.

site_title: Sony annual net profit down 36.5%
summary: Sony reported a 36.5% decline in annual net profit to 582.2 billion yen ($5.4 billion) due to lower revenue from games and electronics products. Operating profit fell 5.5% to 845 billion yen as sales sank 4.7% to 8.3 trillion yen. The company cited uncertainties over the coronavirus pandemic and factory shutdowns as contributing factors. Sony did not release a forecast for the current year, citing business uncertainty. The decline in sales is attributed to the PlayStation 4's seventh year and the impact of the coronavirus outbreak on electronics production and retail sales.

site_title: South Korea sticks with virus lockdown rollback despite nightclub outbreak
summary: South Korea has decided not to reinstate strict social distancing rules despite a recent outbreak of COVID-19 linked to nightclubs in Seoul's Itaewon district. The outbreak, which has linked 119 cases to the night spots, has raised concerns of a second wave. However, Vice-Health Minister Kim Gang Lip stated that the government will continue to monitor the situation as long as the daily number of new cases remains below 50 and 95% of infections can be traced. The country's experience highlights the need for long-term efforts to prevent new outbreaks.

site_title: Gaming firm Razer to roll out mask vending machines in Singapore
summary: Gaming firm Razer plans to deploy 20 mask vending machines in Singapore by June 1, providing free surgical masks to citizens and residents aged 16 and over. The company, in partnership with Sunningdale Tech, aims to double its mask production capacity to 10 million a month. This move comes as Singapore lifts lockdown measures and makes mask-wearing compulsory in public. Razer will allocate the masks through its mobile wallet app, Razer Pay. The company aims to support Singapore's self-sufficiency in face masks.

site_title: First Abu Dhabi Bank has US$73.2m exposure to fallen agri-trader Phoenix
summary: First Abu Dhabi Bank (FAB) has a US$73.2 million exposure to Phoenix Commodities, a fallen agri-trader, according to a document prepared by liquidators. This is the largest disclosed exposure by a UAE lender to the group, which has amassed US$400 million in potential trading losses. FAB's exposure includes US$7.7 million in a syndicated loan and US$55.3 million in bilateral and syndicated loans to related entities. Shares in FAB fell 4.5% following the disclosure.

site_title: ABN Amro warns of ballooning provisions after US$1.2b Q1 hit
summary: ABN Amro, a Dutch bank, warned of a potential 2.5 billion euros in loan loss provisions for 2020 due to the novel coronavirus crisis and oil price crash. The bank reported a 395 million euros loss in Q1, partly due to 1.1 billion euros in loan loss provisions for two clients. ABN shares closed lower, down 59% in 2020, after CEO Robert Swaak ramped up a review of the investment bank to be completed by August.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore has distributed S$16 billion in Covid-19 support to firms and individuals from March to May, with measures nearing the halfway mark. Meanwhile, Vietnam reacted to the US's surprise announcement of tariffs on its garment industry, while Malaysia is set to seize RM3 billion of Daim Zainuddin's assets. China's GDP growth is expected to slow, raising pressure on policymakers. In other news, Citigroup predicts a mid-2026 target of 1,150 for the MSCI global equity index, and Thailand's Thaksin Shinawatra is confident his daughter will be cleared in an ethics case as PM.

site_title: Singapore homeware retailer Iuiga gets S$10m Series A funding, to focus on Indonesia
summary: Singapore homeware retailer Iuiga secured S$10 million in Series A funding from Konimex Group, focusing on Indonesia. The funding will be used to grow operations in the country, doubling staff strength in six months and expanding physical stores to meet growing omnichannel demand. Iuiga aims to tap into Indonesia's "strategically burgeoning" markets, leveraging Big Data and AI for e-commerce personalization. The company has seen a surge in online retail traffic, with daily traffic four times that of brick-and-mortar stores, and has grown 12 times in gross market value since its founding in 2017.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close lower with eyes on earnings
summary: Tokyo stocks closed lower on May 13, 2020, due to investor focus on corporate earnings impacted by the coronavirus pandemic. The Nikkei 225 index fell 0.49% to 20,267.05, while the Topix index slipped 0.14% to 1,474.69.

site_title: WeWork is exploring a plan to sublease its Manhattan headquarters
summary: WeWork is exploring plans to sublease its Manhattan headquarters, considering options to rent out specific floors or the entire building. The company, which laid off staff last month, aims to minimize its lease liabilities and has been promoting working from home due to the Covid-19 pandemic. WeWork has been evaluating its real estate usage, with its New York employees occupying space at 620 Avenue of the Americas. The company has not made a decision, but subleasing is seen as a way to adapt to changing market demands.

site_title: Europe: Stocks sink more than 1% at open
summary: European stocks declined by more than 1% at the start of trading on May 13, 2020, due to fears of a second coronavirus wave and a shrinking UK economy. The FTSE 100 index dropped 1.01% to 5,934.47 points, while the DAX 30 and CAC 40 indices lost 1.5% and 1.4% respectively. The UK economy contracted by 2.0% in the first quarter, according to official data.

images.alt_text: London's benchmark FTSE 100 index shed 1.01 per cent to 5,934.47 points.

site_title: New S$6m grant scheme to support Singapore fintechs
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore, the Singapore FinTech Association, and AMTD Group have launched a new S$6 million grant scheme to support Singaporean fintech firms amid the COVID-19 pandemic. The grant consists of a S$1.5 million Business Sustenance Grant and a S$4.5 million Business Growth Grant, providing short-term and long-term funding for fintech firms to sustain operations and innovate. Applications for the grant will open on May 18, 2020, and will be available until Dec 31, 2021.

site_title: UK economy shrinks by record 5.8% in March on coronavirus impact
summary: The UK economy contracted by a record 5.8% in March from February due to the coronavirus crisis, with gross domestic product (GDP) shrinking 2.0% from the last three months of 2019. This is the largest quarter-on-quarter fall since 2008. Economists expect a bigger fall in April due to the entire month being under lockdown. The Bank of England warned of a possible 14% annual slump in GDP, while economists predict a 15% rise in 2021.

site_title: Bitcoin rises after eagerly awaited 'halving'
summary: Bitcoin rose 1.6% to US$8,897 after the "halving" took place, making it 25% higher this year. The adjustment limits the amount of virtual currency on the market, making it more difficult to generate new Bitcoins, which analysts say will support prices. The move comes as investors view Bitcoin as a hedge against inflation, and follows a broader shift from stocks into other assets.

site_title: Philippine economy to shrink 2% to 3.4% in 2020
summary: The Philippine economy is expected to shrink 2-3.4% in 2020 due to measures to contain the COVID-19 pandemic, affecting domestic demand and investments. However, the government anticipates a rebound in 2021, with a 7.1-8.1% growth rate, supported by an economic recovery program.

site_title: IHH Healthcare rolls out telemedicine in Singapore and other key markets
summary: IHH Healthcare has rolled out telemedicine services across its key markets, including Singapore, Malaysia, Turkey, India, and Hong Kong. Patients can book virtual consultations and receive doorstep drug delivery through the MyHealth Connect app. The expansion is part of the group's strategy to meet evolving patient needs, particularly amid the COVID-19 pandemic. IHH's shares rose 3% to S$1.73 after the announcement.

site_title: UK researchers try to crack genetic riddle of Covid-19
summary: UK researchers are sequencing the genetic codes of thousands of Covid-19 patients to understand why the virus kills some people but leaves others with mild symptoms. The study, involving up to 20,000 people in hospital intensive care and 15,000 with mild symptoms, aims to identify specific genes that may contribute to individual risk. Researchers believe that genetic clues could help understand the virus's deadly impact and potentially lead to new therapies. The study's findings will be shared globally, and some answers may be available in a few weeks from a study of almost 2,000 people already underway.

site_title: S Korea shoppers line up before dawn ahead of expected Chanel price hike
summary: More than 100 South Korean shoppers waited in line outside a Chanel store in Seoul, eager to buy products before expected price hikes. The shoppers, many of whom are planning to gift luxury bags for upcoming weddings, arrived as early as 5am and were issued numbered tickets online. The price increases, announced by Chanel's French headquarters, are expected to kick in later this week. The move comes as South Korea has seen a recent surge in COVID-19 cases linked to nightclubs, raising concerns of a second wave.

site_title: World's largest wealth fund blacklists four Canadian firms for emissions
summary: Norway's $1 trillion sovereign fund has excluded four Canadian oil and gas companies - Canadian Natural Resources, Cenovus Energy, Suncor Energy, and Imperial Oil - from its portfolio due to excessive greenhouse gas emissions. This marks the fund's first use of this criterion for exclusion. The decision follows a recommendation from its ethics watchdog, which also led to the exclusion of three other companies for environmental damage. The fund sells shares before exclusions are announced to avoid market movements.

site_title: Aston Martin posts deep loss as coronavirus outbreak hits sales
summary: Aston Martin reported a £119 million pre-tax loss in the first quarter due to a 31% year-on-year decline in core retail sales, primarily caused by the coronavirus outbreak and dealer destocking. CEO Andy Palmer attributed the impact to the global economic shutdown. The company's sales slump was attributed to the pandemic's effects on the automotive industry.

site_title: Temporary relief measures to also cover purchases of new homes: MinLaw
summary: Singapore's Ministry of Law has extended temporary relief measures to cover purchases of new homes under the Covid-19 (Temporary Measures) Act. The relief, which began on April 20, 2020, will last for six months and covers options to purchase, sale and purchase agreements, and agreements for lease for residential property. The measures include protection from legal action and prohibition on unilateral increases of charges. Buyers and developers can seek relief by serving a Notification for Relief, and the government encourages buyers to seek extensions from developers first.

site_title: Nissan plans US$2.8b in cuts as part of restructuring plan
summary: Nissan plans to cut $2.8 billion in annual fixed costs as part of its restructuring plan, citing a drop in sales that could impact its recovery from years of poor profitability. The Japanese automaker aims to slash costs in areas such as marketing and research, and considers phasing out its lower-cost Datsun brand and closing an additional vehicle production line. Nissan's restructuring plan, to be announced on May 28, follows a strategy of aggressive selling that has pummeled its bottom line, and comes after the ousting of ousted leader Carlos Ghosn.

site_title: E-sports: T1 officially adds Singaporeans Meracle, Poloson to Dota 2 roster
summary: T1, a professional Dota 2 team, has officially added Singaporeans Meracle and Poloson to their roster. Meracle and Poloson, both 24, were added as permanent members after serving as temporary stand-ins for the past two months. They played alongside Lee "Forev" Sang-don, Tri "Jhocam" Kuncoro, and Muhammad "inYourdreaM" Rizky. The team helped T1 tie for seventh in recent tournaments, including the Thailand Celestial Cup S2 and the BTS Pro Series: Southeast Asia.

site_title: Complaint against HC Surgical's Julian Ong moved to SMC disciplinary tribunal
summary: A complaint made against Singaporean surgeon Julian Ong by Serene Tiong alleging he colluded with another specialist to have sex with vulnerable female patients will proceed to a disciplinary tribunal. The Singapore Medical Council (SMC) had previously dismissed Dr. Ong's defamation lawsuit against Ms. Tiong, finding her claims justified. If the SMC takes adverse action, HC Surgical Specialists will reassess and reallocate resources to its other specialists.

site_title: Tourism giant TUI to slash 8,000 jobs over virus crisis
summary: TUI, the world's largest tourism group, plans to slash 8,000 jobs globally to cut costs by 30% due to the coronavirus pandemic's impact on the tourism industry. The move affects one in 10 jobs and is part of the company's efforts to stay afloat despite a net loss of €763.6 million (S$1.17 billion) in the second quarter. TUI had sought a government loan to keep it afloat and has been supported by a €1.8 billion state-guaranteed loan.

site_title: The effects of COVID-19 on global supply chains: short term pain but potential long term benefits
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has significantly disrupted global supply chains, causing inventory backlogs, delays, and economic hardship. However, this disruption may also present opportunities for businesses and logistics companies to adapt and improve their operations. SMEs can pivot by leveraging digital technologies and partnering with local suppliers to reduce costs and increase efficiency. The last-mile delivery sector, where goods are dispatched to consumers, is particularly vulnerable to disruption and can be optimized through the use of on-demand logistics providers. As the pandemic recedes, businesses that adapt and invest in digital technologies and agile logistics may emerge stronger and more resilient.

site_title: Thailand reports no new coronavirus cases for first time since March 9
summary: Thailand reported no new coronavirus cases for the first time since March 9, bringing its total to 3,017 cases and 56 deaths. The Thai government continues to urge public adherence to mask-wearing, hygiene, and social distancing measures, particularly in high-risk areas such as Bangkok and southern Thailand. Meanwhile, 2,844 patients have recovered from infections.

site_title: Uber said to be in talks to acquire Grubhub to create food delivery giant
summary: Uber is in talks to acquire Grubhub, a food delivery giant, in an effort to create one dominant player in the industry amid the COVID-19 pandemic. Uber has proposed a potential all-stock takeover bid, valuing Grubhub's stock at over $60 a share, which would peg a deal at around $6.1 billion. The talks are ongoing and could fall apart. The acquisition would help reduce competition in the food delivery market and allow Uber to limit damage to its ride-hailing business.

site_title: S Korea's LG Chem sends delegation to India to probe deadly gas leak
summary: LG Chem has sent a delegation to India to investigate a deadly gas leak at its chemical plant in Visakhapatnam, killing 11 people and forcing 800 into hospital for treatment. The 8-member delegation, led by LG Chem's petrochemicals business head, will brief support measures for affected residents and meet with Indian government officials. The accident occurred at a plant operated by LG Polymers, a unit of LG Chem, in the southern state of Andhra Pradesh.

site_title: China car sales begin recovery after virus plunge
summary: China's auto industry has begun a recovery after a two-year slump due to the coronavirus pandemic, with sales rising 4.4% year-on-year in April. The lifting of lockdowns and restrictions has led to a surge in demand for commercial vehicles, with sales increasing over 30%. Passenger car sales, however, still plummeted 80% from a year ago in February. The government's support for electric vehicles and lifting of vehicle restrictions are seen as key factors in the recovery. Industry experts predict a "double-digit" downturn this year, but wealthy customers and electric vehicle sales are expected to drive growth.

site_title: Condo, HDB rental volumes plunge more than 36% in April from March
summary: Demand for condo and HDB rentals in Singapore plummeted 36.5% and 36.7% respectively in April from March, with the circuit breaker measures limiting property viewings. Rental prices for private condos and apartments fell 0.9% and 1.8% year-over-year, while HDB rental prices rose 1.3% but were still 14.1% down from their peak. Experts predict a 2-4% year-on-year decline in the rental index for 2020 due to the pandemic's impact on employment and the leasing market.

site_title: Broker's take: Maybank KE upgrades Wilmar to 'buy', lowers TP on palm oil uncertainty
summary: Maybank Kim Eng upgraded Wilmar International to 'buy' but lowered its target price to S$4.12 due to palm oil uncertainty. Analysts expect volume momentum to pick up in China, driven by the country's reopening, and the potential listing of Wilmar's China business. However, palm oil may face pressure due to weaker bio-diesel demand and import restrictions. Maybank Kim Eng lowered its 2020-2021 estimates for Wilmar's palm oil segment by 9-20% and net profit after tax by 2-12%.

site_title: Chile asks IMF for a US$23.8b line of credit
summary: Chile has requested a US$23.8 billion line of credit from the International Monetary Fund (IMF) over two years, citing strong economic fundamentals and institutional policy frameworks. The request comes as the country navigates the COVID-19 pandemic and recent protests. IMF managing director Kristalina Georgieva is expected to recommend approval, considering the credit line as precautionary to safeguard against external shocks. The IMF warns that the economic downturn could lead to new protests if policy actions are perceived as insufficient or unfair.

site_title: Citi, HSBC among others opening Asia offices show way for rest of world
summary: Thousands of bankers have returned to their offices across Asia's major financial hubs, adopting new safety measures such as face masks, desk shields, and temperature checks. In China, banks have boosted office staffing, with Bank of Communications Co ordering most staff back in March. In Hong Kong, Citigroup, HSBC, and Morgan Stanley are implementing social distancing measures, including limiting meetings and separating staff.
