The changes signal a potential return to normalcy in London and New York, where firms are waiting for infection rates to fall further.

site_title: Kuwait tells oil buyers to load less crude on ships in June: sources
summary: Kuwait Petroleum Corp (KPC) has told oil buyers to load less crude oil in June, setting an operational tolerance of minus 5% for all crude cargoes. This measure is part of Kuwait's commitment to reduce production as part of the Opec+ agreement, which aims to cut output by 9.7 million barrels per day in May and June. The move follows Kuwait's announcement of 80,000 barrels per day in production cuts in June, and will be applied to all cargoes nominated for loading in June.

site_title: Australia saw overseas visitors fall 99% in April amid coronavirus lockdown
summary: Australia saw a 99% decline in overseas visitors in April due to coronavirus lockdowns, with 21,600 arrivals recorded, mostly returning Australian citizens. Arrivals from New Zealand and China plummeted by 161,950 and 132,040 respectively, to 1,180 and 320. Departures from Australia also dropped 96.5% to 63,500, mostly foreigners returning home. The massive decline in tourism is a significant blow to the industry, highlighting the devastating impact of the pandemic on Australia's economy.

site_title: UK finance ministry sees budget deficit hitting £337b : Telegraph
summary: Britain's finance ministry warns of a potential £337 billion budget deficit due to the coronavirus, citing an internal government document. Under a worst-case scenario, borrowing could surge to £517 billion. To stabilize borrowing, officials propose £25-£30 billion in tax rises or spending cuts, or £90 billion in extreme cases. A "prolonged recovery and some permanent damage" to the economy is considered a more realistic scenario, with the budget deficit projected to fall to £83 billion by 2021-22 and £32 billion by 2024-25.

site_title: BT sees new digital subscriptions double in April from March amid Covid-19 pandemic
summary: BT reports a 100% increase in new digital subscriptions in April compared to March, amid the Covid-19 pandemic and "circuit-breaker" measures. The Straits Times saw a 40% increase, while Lianhe Zaobao and Berita Harian also saw significant growth, with increases of 138% and 100%, respectively.

site_title: Jardine Matheson faces pain in Indonesia after expansion
summary: Jardine Matheson Holdings, a Hong Kong-based British trading house, is facing challenges in Indonesia due to the COVID-19 pandemic, which has impacted its automotive distribution unit and PT Astra International, the second-largest profit contributor. Indonesia's car industry association has halved its 2020 vehicle sales forecast, and the country's economic growth is expected to cool to its slowest in almost two decades. The pandemic has also weakened the Indonesian rupiah, further exacerbating the challenges for Jardine.

site_title: Startup Sesto Robotics unveils disinfecting robot to fight Covid-19
summary: Singapore-based startup Sesto Robotics has launched SESTO HealthGUARD, an autonomous mobile disinfecting robot designed to combat Covid-19. The robot can disinfect 100 square meters in 45 minutes and provides an industry-leading utilisation rate of up to six hours on a single charge. Equipped with UV-C germicidal lamps, the robot eliminates 99.9% of bacteria, germs, and viruses. The startup has received interest from retail malls, bus operators, hotels, and healthcare facilities, and is in talks for trials and purchases.

site_title: Australia, New Zealand: Shares tumble on fears of virus resurgence as economies reopen
summary: Australian shares fell 1.27% on Wednesday, with the S&P/ASX 200 index reaching its lowest since May 5, amid fears of a second coronavirus wave and a delayed vaccine. Energy stocks led the decline, with Santos and Oil Search dropping 3.4% and 3% respectively. Healthcare stocks also fell, with CSL Ltd and Healius plummeting 2.5% and 4.5% respectively. Investors are cautious ahead of wage growth data and New Zealand's cash rate decision, with safe-haven assets such as gold rising.

site_title: Frasers Property's management take pay cuts; Q2 net profit falls 38.1%
summary: Frasers Property's management, including the CEO, has taken pay cuts of up to 10% effective May 1, as the company aims to conserve financial resources. The group's Q2 net profit fell 38.1% to S$74.5 million, due to increased administrative expenses and interest costs. Revenue rose 2.2% to S$954.7 million, driven by settlement of development projects in China and the consolidation of Golden Land Property Development. The company has suspended interim dividends and prioritizes capital and liquidity management to weather the Covid-19 crisis.

site_title: Malaysia's Q1 economic growth slows to 0.7%, better than forecast
summary: Malaysia's economy experienced a slower growth rate of 0.7% in Q1, beating the forecasted 1.5% decline due to the coronavirus pandemic's impact on exports and domestic demand. The economy was still below the 3.6% growth rate in the fourth quarter. The Bank Negara Malaysia attributed the slowdown to lockdowns and economic activity crimping demand across major and regional economies.

site_title: Grocery delivery startup Instacart weighs new financing: report
summary: US online grocery delivery company Instacart is in talks to raise $500-700 million from existing and new investors, potentially doubling its valuation to $12-14 billion. The company has around $800 million in cash and has been on a hiring spree amid surging demand for grocery delivery services due to the pandemic. Instacart has declined to comment on the rumors, stating it remains focused on serving customers and shoppers. The deal would put the company's valuation significantly higher than its $7.87 billion valuation in 2018.

site_title: Keppel: Court dismisses racketeering cause of action in EIG lawsuit
summary: Keppel Offshore & Marine (Keppel O&M) has successfully dismissed a racketeering cause of action brought by EIG Management Co's funds in a US court, leaving only one cause of action to proceed. The court dismissed the Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act (RICO) claim, while allowing EIG to proceed with a claim of aiding and abetting fraud related to a Brazilian bribery scheme. Keppel O&M maintains that the aiding and abetting claim is "without merit" and will continue to defend it vigorously.

site_title: S$16b in Covid-19 support given out so far: Indranee
summary: Singapore has disbursed S$16 billion in government assistance to individuals and firms since March to help weather the Covid-19 crisis, according to Second Minister for Finance Indranee Rajah. The support includes wage offsets, tax rebates, and cash grants, with S$2 billion allocated to individuals and households. The government has managed to disburse this amount in less than three months due to prudent financial management and strong reserves, which have been built up over the years.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened higher on Wednesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 0.99 points, or 0.07%, to 1,380.92. Volume was 223.82 million lots worth RM90.38 million. Losers outperformed gainers 174 to 135. The gains followed a global trend, with stocks in Europe and the US also rising despite concerns over US-EU trade tensions and ongoing tariff threats.

site_title: Developing online business strategy with millennials through partnership with university
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has accelerated online shopping among Singaporean consumers, with 37% of consumers increasing online shopping activities. Businesses that lack an online presence are struggling, and engaging millennials, who are expected to comprise 75% of the global workforce by 2025, is crucial. Millennials value experiences, discoveries, and excitement online, requiring businesses to create digital experiences that extend beyond customer service, incorporating social media and technology to deliver seamless offline-to-online interactions. Establishing a 'millennial-friendly' digital experience is a major challenge for many businesses due to a lack of understanding of millennials' shopping behaviors.

site_title: Facebook to pay US$52m settlement for trauma to content reviewers
summary: Facebook has agreed to a $52 million settlement to compensate over 10,000 content moderators who suffered mental trauma from reviewing graphic and violent images. The settlement includes at least $1,000 per person, with additional compensation for those diagnosed with specific mental health conditions. The agreement also includes mental health support and counseling for content moderators in the US. The settlement stems from a class-action lawsuit filed in 2018, which highlighted the stress and difficult conditions of moderators hired by Facebook contractors.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Singtel, StarHub, Keppel, SIA, Frasers Property, SembMarine, EC World Reit
summary: Keppel Corporation's wholly-owned subsidiary successfully dismissed a US lawsuit, while telco M1 continued to receive complaints about its broadband services. Singapore Airlines extended a payment to investors as a goodwill gesture, and Frasers Property posted a 38.1% drop in net profit. SembCorp Marine deferred non-essential capital expenditures to preserve cash flow. Meanwhile, Singtel and StarHub are expected to see industry price repair due to the need for 5G capacity on a wholesale basis.

site_title: Singapore shares fall at Wednesday's open tracking Wall St retreat; STI down 0.5%
summary: Singapore shares fell 0.5% on Wednesday, tracking a Wall Street retreat, as investors worry about a second wave of virus infections. The Straits Times Index dropped 12.35 points to 2,575.46, with decliners outnumbering advancers 100 to 38. Banking stocks, including DBS, UOB, and OCBC Bank, declined, while Mapletree Logistics Trust and Singapore Airlines fell due to sector-specific concerns. A US government scientist's warning against premature reopening of the economy also contributed to the market downturn.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares open Wednesday's session with losses
summary: Hong Kong stocks began Wednesday's session with losses, following a sell-off on Wall Street. The Hang Seng Index fell 0.55% to 24,111.67, amid growing concerns over the easing of lockdown measures sparking new virus infections. The Shanghai and Shenzhen Composite Indices also declined 0.30%. The losses were attributed to global market worries, with US-EU trade tensions and the ongoing pandemic being major concerns.

site_title: SembMarine revenue recognition hit by Covid-19, oil price collapse
summary: Sembcorp Marine's revenue recognition has been impacted by the COVID-19 pandemic and oil price collapse. The company will defer non-essential capital expenditures to preserve cash flow and has seen lower revenue recognition due to industry-wide cuts to capital expenditures and delays in executing existing orders. The pandemic has also severely constrained yard activities, with the company reducing its operating yard workforce to 850 from 20,000 previously. SembMarine expects overall business volumes to further weaken for the rest of the year, with losses expected to continue.

site_title: Pollution in China's smog-prone Hebei falls by a quarter in April
summary: Air pollution in China's Hebei province, known for its smog, decreased by 26.7% in April to 33 micrograms per cubic meter, meeting China's interim air quality standard. The decline is attributed to crackdowns on dust and straw burning, as well as stricter policies on diesel use and fireworks. Hebei's PM2.5 concentrations have fallen 15.7% for the first four months, still exceeding the World Health Organization's recommendation. The province aims to control ground ozone pollution over the summer, primarily from vehicle exhaust fumes and sunlight.

site_title: US adds 1,894 coronavirus deaths in 24 hours: tracker
summary: The US recorded 1,894 coronavirus deaths in 24 hours, bringing the total to 82,246, according to the Johns Hopkins University tracker. This sharp rise follows a decline in daily tolls on Sunday and Monday. The country has also confirmed 1,367,927 cases, making it the hardest hit by the pandemic in terms of fatalities.

site_title: Asia: Equities slip as second wave fears come into focus
summary: Asian markets declined on Wednesday, following losses on Wall Street, amid concerns over easing lockdown measures and the risk of a second wave of COVID-19 infections. US President Trump's top adviser warned that premature easing could lead to another wave, while brewing tensions between the US and China added to market volatility. The US proposed giving the president powers to impose sanctions on China if it doesn't provide a "full accounting" for the coronavirus outbreak. The decline in Asian markets follows recent gains driven by slowing infection and death rates.

images.alt_text: Asian markets fell again on Wednesday after Donald Trump's top virus adviser warned that easing lockdown measures too early could spark another dangerous wave of infections and batter the economic recovery.

site_title: India PM announces relief package to boost virus-hit economy
summary: India's Prime Minister Narendra Modi announced a 10% GDP stimulus package worth $377.3 billion to boost the economy, which has been severely impacted by the coronavirus pandemic and lockdown. The 20-trillion-rupee (US) relief plan aims to support laborers and small businesses, with Finance Minister Nirmala Sitharaman to unveil further details in the coming days. The package is seen as a much-needed boost for the Indian economy, which was already struggling with a liquidity crisis, bad loans, and rising unemployment.

site_title: CXA gets fresh funding from existing investors HSBC and Humanica
summary: CXA Group, a health and wellness startup, has secured fresh funding from existing investors HSBC and Humanica. The latest capital injection will be used to further customize CXA's platform, which can be white-labelled and used by banks in Asia. The platform offers personalized health, wealth, and wellness services to employees through a mobile app, and HSBC will invest in CXA through its indirect subsidiary HSBC Life (International) Limited. The partnership with Humanica will integrate its Human Capital Management platform with CXA's platform in Thailand, serving 3,000 local enterprise customers and their 700,000 employees.

site_title: South Korea's April jobs fall at sharpest pace since 1999
summary: South Korea's unemployment rate remained unchanged at 3.8% in April, but the number of employed people dropped 476,000 to 26.6 million, the largest decline since February 1999. The decline was largely due to measures to contain the coronavirus, such as business closures and reduced social activity. The nation's labor market continues to be affected by the pandemic, with the fastest pace of employment decline in over two decades.

site_title: Indian trains start rolling again despite virus surge
summary: India's railway network has resumed operations with limited services, despite a surge in coronavirus cases. The country, which imposed a strict lockdown in March, has eased restrictions, with two trains leaving New Delhi with 2,300 people on board. However, new cases continue to rise, with over 3,600 infections recorded on Monday. The government has announced a stimulus package worth $266 billion to boost the struggling economy and has vowed to reveal further announcements about changes to the lockdown in coming days.

site_title: Carlyle, GIC sued over AmEx stock buy
summary: Carlyle Group and Singapore sovereign wealth fund GIC are being sued by a unit of Certares Management over a failed deal to buy a 20% stake in American Express Global Business Travel (AmEx GBT). The lawsuit claims Carlyle's losses from the coronavirus led to buyer's remorse, prompting it to scrap the $5 billion deal. Certares alleges Carlyle used fake excuses to renege on the purchase, while Carlyle counters that the economic impact of the pandemic constitutes a "material adverse effect" under the stock-purchase agreement.

images.alt_text: Carlyle Group and Singapore sovereign wealth fund GIC are allegedly using fake excuses to renege on buying a 20 per cent stake in American Express Global Business Travel (AmEx GBT), according an unsealed lawsuit.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower with eyes on earnings reports
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on May 13, 2020, following Wall Street's declines, as investors focused on corporate earnings affected by the coronavirus pandemic. The Nikkei 225 index fell 1.11% and the Topix index dropped 0.89%. The declines were attributed to the ongoing impact of the pandemic on corporate earnings.

images.alt_text: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Wednesday, tracking falls on Wall Street as investors focused on corporate earnings that have been decimated by the coronavirus pandemic.

site_title: UK says it plans to start virtual trade talks with Japan shortly
summary: The UK plans to start virtual trade talks with Japan shortly, with the goal of securing a free trade agreement that could save British exporters millions of pounds a year in tariffs. The talks aim to increase trade, boost investment, and create jobs, with the UK seeking to diversify its supply chains and increase resilience. Key industries such as textiles, clothing, and professional services are expected to benefit from the deal, which could increase trade flows between the two countries by 15.2 billion pounds. The agreement will be based on the existing EU-Japan free trade deal.

site_title: US airlines tell crews not to force passengers to wear masks
summary: US airlines American Airlines, Delta Air Lines, and United Airlines have told their flight attendants not to force passengers to wear masks, but to encourage compliance. The airlines will deny boarding to unmasked passengers at the gate, but enforcement becomes less strict once on board. Exemptions are available for young children, medical conditions, and eating/drink periods. The Federal Aviation Administration has declined to implement a nationwide mask mandate, leaving airlines to set their own policies amid the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic.

site_title: EU will push to unlock borders as coronavirus ravages travel and tourism
summary: The European Union executive plans to recommend lifting border restrictions and restarting travel to revive the tourism industry, which has been severely impacted by the coronavirus pandemic. Nearly all travel in Europe has been halted, contributing to a devastating blow to the sector, which accounts for almost one-tenth of the EU's economic output. The move aims to gradually lift restrictions and allow travel to resume in order to revive the industry.

site_title: US: Stocks retreat as top scientist urges caution on reopening
summary: US stocks retreated on Tuesday, ending a six-day gain for the Nasdaq, as top scientist Anthony Fauci urged caution on reopening the economy. Analysts cited Fauci's testimony, profit taking, and escalating US-China tensions as factors. The pullback also reflects concerns over high equity valuations and "buyer exhaustion."

site_title: US Democrats unveil US$3t virus relief package
summary: US Democrats unveiled a $3 trillion coronavirus response package, the largest yet, to fund pandemic efforts and provide emergency payments to millions of households. The Heroes Act includes second-round payments of up to $6,000 per household, funding for health workers, and boosting small businesses. However, Senate Republicans oppose the bill, calling it a "bloated liberal wish list." The measure also directs nearly $1 trillion to state and local governments and reserves $200 billion for a "Heroes fund" to provide hazard pay for essential workers.

site_title: US Senate threatens sanctions on China over Covid-19 accounting
summary: US Republican senators proposed the "Covid-19 Accountability Act," which would allow President Trump to impose sanctions on China if Beijing doesn't provide a full accounting for the coronavirus outbreak. The legislation requires China to close high-risk wet markets and release arrested activists. If China fails to comply, Trump can impose sanctions, including asset freezes and travel bans. The bill's sponsors, including Senators Jim Inhofe and Lindsey Graham, claim China's refusal to cooperate with an investigation on the virus's origin. The 60-day certification deadline is set to determine China's compliance.

site_title: Boeing reports more 737 MAX cancelations as CEO offers grim outlook
summary: Boeing reported 108 737 MAX orders canceled in April, with 101 contracts downgraded, lowering its backlog to below 5,000 planes for the first time since 2013. The company's CEO, David Calhoun, warned of a major airline potentially going out of business due to the industry downturn caused by the coronavirus pandemic. Calhoun expects airlines to trim headcount and traffic levels to remain below pre-outbreak levels until at least the end of the year, with a long-term recovery expected in 3-5 years.

site_title: Some movement on much-needed ship crew changes
summary: Crew repatriation efforts in the cruise industry are showing signs of progress, with over 8,000 crew members successfully repatriated from around the world, according to Singapore-based Sharp Crew Management. The International Maritime Organization (IMO) has endorsed protocols to facilitate safe crew changes, and industry associations are urging governments to implement the measures. A 30-day implementation period is set to begin on May 15, with the International Transport Workers & Federation (ITF) calling on governments to facilitate crew changes during this time.

site_title: Once taboo, investors begin to imagine negative US rates
summary: US investors are increasingly considering the possibility of negative interest rates, with rate options implying a 23% chance of the key federal funds rate going below zero by the end of 2020. The Federal Reserve has ruled out negative rates, but the economic impact of the pandemic has led to a shift in market expectations. Investors worry about the potential consequences, including bank profit squeezes, sub-zero bond yields, and money market turmoil. While some experts see negative rates as a possible solution, others express skepticism, citing concerns about the potential disruption to the US economy and financial sector.

site_title: Tuan Sing to issue S$65m 7.75% 2-year notes
summary: Property developer Tuan Sing Holdings priced S$65 million, 7.75% 2-year non-call notes at par for May 19, 2020, and they will mature on May 19, 2022. The net proceeds will be used to finance property development, debt refinancing, and general corporate purposes.

site_title: Starbucks rival Luckin Coffee fires CEO in fraud scandal
summary: Luckin Coffee, a Chinese coffee chain rivaling Starbucks, has fired its CEO Jenny Zhiya Qian and COO Liu Jian amid a massive fraud scandal. The company's shares plummeted by over 70% after it revealed that Liu may have fabricated 2.2 billion yuan ($440 million) in sales in 2019. The board of directors terminated both executives, and trading in Luckin shares remains suspended. The company has named Jinyi Guo as acting CEO and vowed to cooperate with the internal investigation and focus on growing its business.

images.alt_text: The chief executive of Luckin Coffee, a chain rivalling Starbucks in China, and another top executive have been sacked in the wake of a massive fraud scandal that has rocked the company.

site_title: Oil rises as Opec looks to deepen, extend supply cuts
summary: Oil prices rose by 6.8% and 1.2% on Tuesday, with US West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude futures settling at $25.78 a barrel and Brent crude futures at $29.98 a barrel. Opec and its allies, including Saudi Arabia, the UAE, and Kuwait, agreed to maintain a record 9.7 million barrel per day (bpd) output cut through June, exceeding initial expectations. This move is expected to support oil prices amid the ongoing coronavirus pandemic, which has led to a 30% drop in fuel demand worldwide.

site_title: Australia's CBA profit slides 23.5%, keeps A$1.5b for Covid-19 credit losses
summary: Commonwealth Bank of Australia (CBA) posted a 23.5% drop in third-quarter cash profit due to expected loan losses from the Covid-19 pandemic. The bank set aside A$1.5 billion to cover credit losses and reported troublesome and impaired assets at A$8.1 billion. CBA's total credit provision rose to A$6.4 billion. The bank also sold a 55% stake in its pension arm Colonial First State to KKR & Co for A$1.7 billion. This is part of a larger trend of record-low interest rates, rising unemployment, and a likely recession in Australia.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Thakral Corporation will not declare a dividend by June 2020 due to the ongoing coronavirus pandemic. Healthway Medical Corporation cut its directors' fees by 10% amid the crisis. ST Engineering appointed May Ng Bee Bee as an independent non-executive director. EC World Reit reported a 22.9% decline in distribution per unit due to rental rebates provided to tenants. Alpha Energy Holdings is diversifying into education services amid a roadblock with its Mustang oilfield project.

site_title: Europe: Shares end higher as defensives find favour
summary: European shares ended modestly higher on Tuesday, driven by gains in telecoms, healthcare, and utilities sectors. Britain's FTSE 100 rose 0.9% with help from a weaker pound, while the Stoxx 600 index gained 0.3%. Telecom stocks, including Vodafone's 8.7% surge after retaining its dividend, led the gains. Despite a rebound in April, European shares have lost momentum in May as investors weigh risks from lockdowns being lifted.

images.alt_text: European shares finished modestly higher on Tuesday, as telecom stocks surged after Britain's Vodafone maintained its dividend, while defensive stocks were broadly in favour as investors weighed risks from many countries starting to lift lockdowns.

site_title: Facebook trains AI on 'hateful memes'
summary: Facebook has unveiled an initiative to combat "hateful memes" by training its AI on a database of 10,000 maliciously motivated images and text combinations. The social network is releasing the database to researchers, offering a $100,000 prize pool to develop improved algorithms to detect hate-driven visual messages. This move follows a ramped-up effort against hate speech, with Facebook using a combination of AI and crowd-sourcing to identify and remove hateful content. The goal is to improve the detection of hate-driven visual messages on the platform.

images.alt_text: Facebook unveiled an initiative Tuesday to take on "hateful memes" by using artificial intelligence, backed by crowd sourcing, to identify maliciously motivated posts.

site_title: Indonesia's Kopi Kenangan raises US$109m in Sequoia-led round
summary: Indonesian coffee retail chain Kopi Kenangan raised US$109 million in a Series B funding round led by Sequoia Capital, with new investors B Capital, Horizons Ventures, and others also participating. The funding will support the company's expansion plans.

site_title: Singapore April condo resale volume tumbles 57.3%: SRX Property
summary: Singapore's condo resale volume plummeted 57.3% in April to 309 units, a 62.2% year-on-year decline. The outside central region accounted for 58.1% of the volume. Despite low resale numbers, prices remained resilient, with a 0.2% drop from March 2020 and a 0.7% decline from last year. The highest transacted price was S$27.7 million for an apartment at Ardmore Park, while the lowest median TOX was recorded in District 10 at negative S$50,000.

site_title: Tentative restart for trains in India as virus cases surge
summary: India's railway network is gradually restarting after a coronavirus lockdown, with parts of the network resuming services on May 12. Despite easing restrictions, new cases continue to rise, with over 3,600 new infections recorded on Monday. The government did not set a program for when more services will resume. Experts say India is underprepared for a major outbreak due to insufficient testing and crowded cities. The lockdown is set to end on May 17, with Prime Minister Narendra Modi discussing further relaxations with state chief ministers.

site_title: Broadway to stay closed until at least September
summary: New York's Broadway theatres will remain closed until at least early September, according to the Broadway League's announcement. The decision comes as the US epicentre of the coronavirus pandemic continues to impact the state, with over 150 daily Covid-19 deaths. The closure, which began in mid-March, affects 31 running productions and eight in rehearsals with spring opening dates. Refunds and ticket exchanges are now available for performances through September 6, with no set date for performances to resume. The Broadway League prioritizes health and well-being before allowing shows to return.

site_title: Xiohoo takes learning online for seniors
summary: Xiohoo, a social enterprise in Singapore, has adapted its learning program for seniors to go online due to the COVID-19 circuit breaker. The program, launched in 2018, aims to make seniors IT-savvy through training on smartphone usage, online shopping, and digital skills. Over 1,000 seniors have attended the program, with the online version allowing for more seniors to participate. The initiative has also helped alleviate boredom and isolation among seniors, with many expressing appreciation for the content provided.

site_title: China halts beef imports from 4 Australian firms as Covid-19 spat sours trade
summary: China has suspended beef imports from four Australian firms due to labelling and health certificate issues, amid a souring trade dispute over the COVID-19 pandemic. The suspension affects 20% of Australia's beef exports to China, valued at A$3 billion. China rejects an independent inquiry into the pandemic's origins, citing Australian criticism as contributing to the dispute. The move has weighed on the Australian dollar, with China being Australia's largest trading partner.

site_title: Musk says Tesla will defy orders and reopen car plant
summary: Tesla CEO Elon Musk stated the company will defy California orders and reopen its Fremont car plant, despite a county ban. The move comes after Tesla told production workers they could return to work, contradicting Governor Gavin Newsom's statement that the plant would reopen as early as next week. Musk tweeted that he would personally return to work and that anyone arrested would only be him. The company had sued the county over the weekend after being told it didn't meet reopening criteria. Musk had previously threatened to move Tesla's headquarters to Nevada or Texas.

site_title: Hong Leong Asia to acquire remaining shares in Tasek
summary: Hong Leong Asia is making an offer to acquire the remaining shares in Malaysian cement maker Tasek for approximately RM83.9 million (S$27.4 million), following a previous attempt to take the company private last year. The offer is for RM5.80 per ordinary share and RM6.51 per preference share, representing 11.84% and 35.09% of the issued shares, respectively. This move comes after Tasek posted a net profit of RM4.74 million for its first quarter, ending nine consecutive quarters of losses.

site_title: Nine multi-storey carpark rooftops in Singapore to be converted to urban farms
summary: Singapore plans to convert nine multi-storey carpark rooftops into urban farms, as part of its 30 by 30 goal to produce 30% of the country's nutritional needs locally by 2030. The rooftops, including five single sites and two cluster sites, will be up for tender for a three-year term. The move aims to increase local food production and reduce the country's dependence on food imports, currently at 90%. The initiative is part of the Singapore Food Agency's efforts to strengthen the country's supply chain resilience and food security.

site_title: Details out next week on first sectors to re-open after circuit breaker
summary: Singapore's post-circuit breaker re-opening plan is set to begin next week, with essential services likely to be among the first to reopen. The progress will depend on the number of new Covid-19 cases after the first step, and measures may be reintroduced if the outbreak worsens. Health Minister Gan Kim Yong said the taskforce is studying the possibility of allowing visits to family members living separately, and travel restrictions will continue to be reviewed. The government is also testing all 300,000 migrant workers and plans to progressively clear them to safely return to work.

site_title: CDL sells more homes but achieves lower sales value in Q1
summary: CDL sold 185 homes worth S$278.1 million in Q1, a 46% decline in sales value compared to the same period last year. The lower sales value was due to more affordable units sold, primarily in mass to mid-market projects. CDL's global hospitality portfolio was also impacted by the pandemic, with 30% of its hotels globally temporarily closed and occupancy rates declining 28.8% in Singapore. The company maintained a breakeven position in April through corporate and public-sector bookings.

site_title: Vettel to leave Ferrari at end of 2020 F1 season
summary: Sebastian Vettel will leave Ferrari at the end of the 2020 F1 season, following a joint decision with the team. The four-time Formula One world champion, who joined Ferrari in 2015, cited a lack of common desire to stay together beyond the end of the season. Vettel, 32, had reportedly rejected a one-year contract extension with a salary reduction, and the team's priority now shifts to young driver Charles Leclerc, who has a contract until 2024.

site_title: Navigating the new normal need not be a Gordian knot for telcos
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has accelerated the need for reliable connectivity and bandwidth in Singapore, with telcos facing unprecedented demands. Internet data traffic has surged by 60% as employees work from home, and telcos must upgrade their networks to meet these demands. Leveraging big data and analytics is crucial for efficient traffic monitoring, site upgrades, and investment decisions. Telcos must also prioritize network performance, anomaly detection, and swift investment decisions to maintain healthy operations and customer service levels. By embracing accelerated analytics, telcos can optimize capacity planning, create efficient networks, and gain the public's trust.

site_title: Money FM podcast: Banyan Tree rooted in sustainability
summary: Claire Chiang, co-founder of Banyan Tree Hotels & Resorts, discussed the company's sustainability journey on Money FM's Workday Afternoon podcast. Emphasizing the importance of environmental responsibility, Chiang highlighted Banyan Tree's commitment to sustainable practices, such as reducing carbon emissions and implementing eco-friendly policies. The company's focus on sustainability is deeply ingrained, and Chiang believes it is essential for their business model and future success.

site_title: No-deal Brexit could be second shock for Europe in 2020
summary: A new Brexit crisis is brewing between the UK and EU, with talks set to start Monday and potentially collapse in May or June. EU Trade Commissioner Phil Hogan warns of a "critical" stock-take in June, amid little progress on key issues such as a "level playing field" and fisheries policy. The UK government, led by Prime Minister Boris Johnson, appears inflexible in its approach, ruling out an extension to the transition period beyond December. A no-deal Brexit remains a possibility, which could lead to a new crisis and require both sides to return to negotiations in 2021.

site_title: BOJ will do 'whatever it can' to combat pandemic fallout: Kuroda
summary: Japan's central bank, the Bank of Japan, will take "whatever it can" to mitigate the pandemic's economic fallout, Governor Haruhiko Kuroda said. The BOJ will focus on easing corporate funding strains, not stimulating demand, and has various tools to ramp up stimulus if needed. Kuroda ruled out buying municipal bonds, citing no need for the time being. Japan's economy is on the cusp of a deep recession, with a double-digit contraction projected for the current quarter, and the outlook remains highly uncertain.

site_title: Reopen the economy by exploiting the virus's weak spot
summary: A proposed strategy to reopen the economy by exploiting the Covid-19 virus's latent period involves alternating two-week work cycles with 10 days of lockdown. This would minimize the spread of the virus by allowing people to work while still being infectious to others. Implementing this strategy, where households work alternating weeks, could help resume economic activity without causing a resurgence of infections, potentially leading to a more stable future for schools and businesses.

site_title: Aims Apac Reit cuts Q4 DPU by 27.3% to conserve cash amid pandemic
summary: AIMS Apac Reit reported a 27.3% decline in distribution per unit (DPU) to 2 Singapore cents for Q4, due to lower rental income and recoveries for its 15 Tai Seng Drive property. Gross revenue fell 5.7% to S$28.2 million, while net property income (NPI) grew 0.9% to S$20.5 million. The Reit retained S$2.9 million of Australian distributable income to conserve cash amid the Covid-19 pandemic.

site_title: Park Hotels closes in on US$500m junk bond sale
summary: Park Hotels & Resorts is nearing a US$500 million junk bond sale, according to a source. The Virginia-based real estate investment trust, which has seen its stock plummet 65% in the year, is seeking credit ratings ahead of the potential bond offering. The company has suspended operations at 38 hotels due to the pandemic and reduced capacity at its remaining hotels. Park Hotels has fully drawn on its revolving credit facility and has US$1.2 billion in current liquidity. The company is well-positioned to navigate the virus disruption, according to CEO Thomas Baltimore.

site_title: Largest US mall operator to reopen half of retail properties this month
summary: US mall operator Simon Property Group plans to reopen half of its over 200 retail properties in the US within the next week, despite major retail tenants struggling to stay afloat due to the COVID-19 pandemic. The company reported a 20% decline in quarterly profit and scrapped its annual forecast. Key tenants such as Gap and Neiman Marcus have filed for bankruptcy, while J C Penney is preparing to close a quarter of its stores. Simon Property's CEO David Simon expressed confidence in reopening malls safely, despite health experts warning of a potential new wave of COVID-19 infections.

site_title: What Covid-19 hasn't changed
summary: Investors are navigating unprecedented changes due to the COVID-19 pandemic, including low interest rates and increased government debt. However, the author suggests focusing on the things that are not changing, such as the fundamental relationship between businesses and stock prices. He proposes building a successful investment strategy around stable attributes, including understanding stocks, investing for the long run, and looking for businesses with six key traits: growth, profitability, management quality, financial health, competitive advantage, and industry trends. The author believes that despite the pandemic's impact on individual industries, the long-term relationship between stock prices and business performances remains unchanged.

site_title: The great unwinding
summary: Covid-19 is expected to reverse the effects of globalization, with global supply chains shifting towards regionalized networks. The pandemic has already incentivized companies to relocate production away from China, and this trend is likely to continue. To adapt, multinationals will need to optimize transport and storage, focus on scenario planning, and digitalize their business models. Companies will also need to think strategically about pricing models and bring risk management to the core of their operations. The shift towards regionalized supply chains and digitalization will require significant investments in data management and supply chain resilience, but will ultimately help companies build resilience in the face of uncertainty.

site_title: 'Vibrant' 5G retail scene for Singapore looks a long way off
summary: Singapore's 5G retail market is expected to be limited due to mandatory wholesaling arrangements, which may deter new entrants. Only Singtel and a StarHub-M1 joint venture have been awarded 5G licenses, with some operators facing financial difficulties. The Infocomm Media Development Authority (IMDA) aims to promote retail competition through wholesaling, but the cost of leasing 5G capacity may be too high for some players, including mobile virtual network operators (MVNOs) and TPG Telecom. Analysts predict industry price repair, but the market's vibrancy remains uncertain.

site_title: US$ dips after 'potentially positive' Covid-19 data
summary: The US dollar dipped on Tuesday after the World Health Organization reported some treatments appearing to limit the severity or length of Covid-19. This positive news led investors to seek riskier assets, while the Federal Reserve's comments on negative interest rates boosted the US dollar's yield. New coronavirus cases were found in China, South Korea, and Germany, raising concerns about a potential second wave. Despite this, the euro and Japanese yen rose against the US dollar, while the Australian dollar fell to a five-day low due to a trade dispute with China.

site_title: US core consumer prices suffer record fall in April
summary: US core consumer prices dropped 0.4% in April, the largest decline since 1957, amid the coronavirus pandemic. This is the first time the core CPI has fallen since 1957. The overall CPI declined 0.8% in April, and annual inflation slowed to 0.3%, the smallest increase since 2015. The decline is attributed to a collapse in travel and apparel spending. The cost of food at home surged 2.6% in April, while energy prices slumped 10.1%. The report adds to economic indicators showing an historic impact from the Covid-19 pandemic.

site_title: Q1 market reset sparks jump in retail interest in SGX stocks
summary: A market reset in Q1 has sparked a surge in retail interest in Singapore stocks, with stockbroking firms witnessing a 30% increase in account openings and reactivations from January to March. First-time investors are taking advantage of bargains, while long-dormant investors are recalibrating their portfolios. This trend is attributed to the post-pandemic economic recovery and investors' renewed interest in the market.

site_title: Cromwell Reit sees logistics rents up 22% in Q1
summary: Cromwell European Reit reported a 12.1% average rent reversion rate in Q1, driven by e-commerce and global supply constraints. The Reit's net property income rose 17.2% to 31 million euros, while gross revenue increased 21.4%. Rent reversions for logistics space averaged 22.1%, outperforming office space. The Reit's average occupancy rate rose to 94.7%, and it expects to maintain a competitive edge in acquisitions. The manager has reduced its exposure to small- and medium-sized enterprise tenants and will hold off on non-essential capital expenditure.

site_title: Qatar Airways giving away 100,000 free tickets to healthcare workers
summary: Qatar Airways is giving away 100,000 free economy class return tickets to frontline healthcare workers worldwide as a thank you for their work during the Covid-19 pandemic. The giveaway started on May 12 and will close on May 18, with daily allocations dependent on population size. Eligible healthcare professionals can book up to two tickets and enjoy unlimited destination or date changes without fees. The tickets are valid until Dec 10, 2020, and fare and surcharges will be waived, with airport taxes applying.

site_title: Australia, NZ dollars down on concerns over virus, China trade
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars declined on Tuesday due to concerns over a potential second wave of coronavirus infections and trade friction with China. The Aussie dollar fell 0.6% to US$0.6445, while the kiwi dollar dropped 1.1% to US$0.6065. China's suspension of Australian beef exports and pressure on trade disputes contributed to the market's decline. The Reserve Bank of Australia is expected to issue a large bond, which may test the market's resilience.

site_title: Twitter launches labels, warnings on misleading Covid-19 info
summary: Twitter is introducing labels and warnings on tweets with disputed or misleading information about COVID-19, as part of its new approach to combating misinformation. The labels will provide links to more information and may include warnings if the tweet conflicts with public health guidance. This move follows similar efforts by social media sites Facebook and YouTube to combat misinformation about the pandemic. Twitter's approach will also be extended to other topics, with the goal of reflecting debates rather than stating outcomes.

site_title: Have we already seen the peak in global oil consumption?
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has accelerated the transition from fossil fuels to cleaner renewable energy, with global oil consumption expected to decline by 17mbd in April and 5.2mbd in 2020. The industry's biggest ever drop in demand has led to unprecedented shocks, with oil prices in the US futures market going negative for the first time. The EIA projects a V-shaped rebound in 2021, while the IEA sees demand returning to pre-2019 levels by the end of the year. However, structural pressures such as decarbonization, deflation, and air pollution may continue to drive the energy transition, making it uncertain whether oil demand will recover.

site_title: UMS announces interim dividend as Q1 net profit rises 53% to S$10.7m
summary: UMS Holdings, a Singapore-based company, reported a 53% rise in Q1 net profit to S$10.7 million, driven by better performance in its semiconductor component business. The company announced an interim dividend of 1 cent per share, more than double the previous year's 0.5 cent. This marks the company's first dividend increase in two years.

site_title: Luxury stores test the water in a Paris devoid of tourists
summary: Luxury stores in Paris, once bustling with tourists, are slowly reopening with new hygiene protocols. Brands like Louis Vuitton and Hermes are making face masks compulsory and implementing extensive cleaning measures, including quarantining handbags and steaming clothes. Despite these efforts, sales remain sluggish due to travel restrictions and the absence of international tourists. The industry is expected to slump by up to 50% this year, with luxury brands focusing on easing into new routines and adapting to the new normal.

site_title: BlackRock stake sale frees PNC to hunt for another acquisition
summary: PNC Financial Services Group Inc plans to sell its $17 billion stake in BlackRock Inc through a public offering, freeing up funds to grow amid the coronavirus pandemic. This move follows a 25-year relationship between the bank and BlackRock, which began when PNC bought the business from Blackstone Group Inc. The sale will bolster the bank's position and allow it to seize opportunities if rivals stumble. The move is expected to benefit PNC's financial health during the pandemic.

site_title: Beijing school students trial temperature-tracking bracelets
summary: Beijing has launched a trial of temperature-tracking bracelets for middle school students, the latest high-tech measure to track the population's possible exposure to COVID-19. The bracelets provide real-time temperature data that can be monitored by schools and parents via an app. If a student's temperature rises above 37.2 degrees, the bracelet will prompt teachers to alert the police. This trial follows the deployment of thermal cameras and app-based infection risk ratings in public areas and most places across China.

site_title: Singapore stocks falter ahead of MSCI reweighting
summary: Singapore stocks fell 0.9% on Tuesday, retreating from earlier gains, amid concerns of a second Covid-19 wave and US-China trade tensions. The Straits Times Index closed at 2,587.81, down 23.50 points. The market remains cautious ahead of the MSCI reweighting later in the day, which will impact some stocks. Singapore Airlines dropped 2.7% to close at S$4.29, while DBS led the top value stocks with a 3% decline.

site_title: Singapore watching tightness of USD amid higher demand
summary: Singapore's central bank, the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS), has set up a US$60 billion swap facility with the US Federal Reserve to secure ample access to the greenback amid global dollar tightness. The facility, launched in March, has seen "quite strong interest" from banks looking to draw on the USD, with USD funding costs falling to around 0.3% across various short-term tenors. The MAS has also seen a significant increase in USD-denominated cross-border lending to emerging Asia markets, with total lending jumping to US$2.1 trillion in 2019.

site_title: Changi to suspend T4 as passenger numbers fall off the cliff in April
summary: Changi Airport will temporarily suspend Terminal 4 operations from May 16 due to a significant decline in passenger numbers, with 25,200 passengers passing through in April, a 99.5% drop from the same month in 2019. This move aims to consolidate terminal operations and adapt to the post-pandemic travel landscape.

site_title: Fate of emerging market currencies may just lie with US voters
summary: US public attitudes towards China may influence emerging-market currencies. A Pew Research Center poll found 66% of Americans hold unfavorable views on China, increasing the likelihood of fresh tariffs on Chinese goods. This could prompt the People's Bank of China to weaken the yuan, triggering currency volatility. Emerging markets, such as the Turkish lira and Brazilian real, are already trading at or near all-time lows. A senior fellow at Brookings Institution estimates a 50% chance of additional tariffs before the presidential election, potentially leading to a significant sell-off in the yuan.

site_title: EPL braced for TV losses as player protests mount
summary: The English Premier League is bracing for potential losses due to the coronavirus pandemic, with broadcasters seeking a huge refund if the season is completed behind closed doors. The estimated refund could be up to £340 million if the season is played out, and £760 million if it is not completed. The league's CEO, Richard Masters, warned of a £1 billion loss, including the absence of gate receipts. Player protests, including comments from Raheem Sterling and Danny Rose, have raised concerns about the safety of returning to contact sport amidst the ongoing pandemic.

site_title: Ryanair to mandate masks and ban queueing for toilets
summary: Ryanair to restart flights on July 1 with reduced schedules, mandating masks and prohibiting queueing for toilets to minimize coronavirus spread. Temperature checks will also be implemented. Toilets will be made available on request, not queueing. This move aims to reduce transmission risks and follow UK government guidelines.

site_title: Hin Leong's Ocean Tankers granted interim JM
summary: Singapore's largest tanker operator, Ocean Tankers Pte Ltd, has been granted interim judicial management by the High Court following the troubled performance of its sister company, Hin Leong Trading. The court appointed Ernst & Young's Angela Ee and Purandar Rao as interim judicial managers, exposing Ocean Tankers to potential claims estimated at US$2.07 billion. The move comes amid concerns over Ocean Tankers' exposure to potential claims related to bills of lading issued in relation to Hin Leong Trading's trades.

site_title: P2P lending platform Validus raises US$20m in Series B+ round
summary: Singapore-based P2P lending platform Validus Capital raised US$20 million in its Series B+ funding round led by Kuok Group's Orion Fund and Vertex Growth Fund. Existing investors also participated in the round. The fresh funds will support technology investments and expansion into Thailand, where Validus estimates a US$30-35 billion market opportunity for unmet SME credit demand. The company has disbursed over S$453 million in loans and has a non-performing loan ratio of 2.69%.

site_title: SocGen extends one-off payment after protest by investors of SIA shorts
summary: SocGen has extended a one-off payment of 30 Singapore cents per certificate to investors of its 5x Short Singapore Airlines (SIA) daily leverage certificates (DLCs) following a protest over delayed disclosure and unfair pricing. The payment, made to registered holders as of May 11, is a "goodwill gesture" and does not compensate for losses. SocGen emphasized prompt notifications and said the payment reflects recognition of the importance of timely disclosures. The Singapore Exchange has commenced investigations into the matter.

site_title: Social distancing key in fight against Covid-19
summary: The UK government has partially relaxed lockdown measures amid a high number of Covid-19 cases, with 223,000 infected and 32,000 deaths. Critics call for a public inquiry into the government's handling of the pandemic, citing inadequate testing and care home outbreaks. The government has issued guidelines for businesses, transport, and education, with social distancing measures in place, and Chancellor Rishi Sunak extends aid for furloughed workers. Relaxation of lockdown rules is conditional on the R-rate below 1, currently at 0.5-0.9, and may be delayed or suspended if the rate rises.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks close sharply lower
summary: Hong Kong shares plummeted 1.45% on Tuesday, closing at 24,245.68, following recent gains and concerns over rising coronavirus cases in Asia. The Hang Seng Index fell, while the Shanghai Composite Index eased slightly. The Shenzhen Composite Index on China's second exchange gained 0.33%. The decline follows recent market gains and comes as traders weigh rising infections in Asia.

site_title: China's factory deflation deepens as pandemic takes a toll on demand
summary: China's factory prices fell 3.1% in April, the sharpest rate in four years, due to weakening industrial demand caused by the coronavirus pandemic. The producer price index (PPI) decline was driven by a slump in global crude oil and commodities prices. Despite a rise in consumer prices, China's core inflation remained benign at 1.1% in April. The data suggests China's economy is struggling to recover from its first economic contraction on record, with demand-side pressures expected to persist for some time.

images.alt_text: Chinese manufacturers have been hit by a plunge in overseas orders and face rising inventories and falling profits, while many have let workers go to cut costs.

site_title: Allianz profit slumps on virus impact
summary: Allianz, a German insurer, reported a 29% decline in quarterly profits to €1.4 billion, primarily due to claims from Australian wildfires and COVID-19-related losses. The group abandoned 2020 targets due to global economic uncertainties caused by the pandemic. Despite this, the life and health insurance arm saw a 6% increase in revenues, while the asset management division reported a jump in operating profits. The company's CEO, Oliver Baete, expressed confidence in the group's resilience and ability to overcome the challenges posed by the crisis.

site_title: Toyota expects profit to drop 80% as virus saps car sales
summary: Toyota expects its profit to drop 80% to its lowest in nine years due to the impact of the novel coronavirus on global car sales. The company forecasts a 500 billion yen (S$6.6 billion) operating profit for the year through March 2021, down from 2.44 trillion yen in the previous year. Global sales are expected to reach 8.9 million vehicles, a nine-year low, before recovering to 2019 levels next year. Toyota plans to slash production in North America by nearly a third through October and invest over one trillion yen in capital expenditure and R&D.

images.alt_text: Toyota's outlook came as global rivals including Honda Motor Co Ltd and General Motors have refrained from issuing forecasts, citing uncertainty about the coronavirus impact.

site_title: Indonesian coffee chain raises US$109m; Eduardo Saverin to join board
summary: Kopi Kenangan, an Indonesian coffee retail chain, has raised US$109 million in Series B funding led by Sequoia Capital and joined by new investors including Eduardo Saverin. The funding will be used to expand operations in Indonesia, launch new products, and invest in technology. Kopi Kenangan plans to grow to 500 stores by the end of the year and expand to Thailand, the Philippines, and Malaysia post-pandemic. Saverin will join the board to build a global brand celebrating Indonesian flavors.

site_title: Offline app updates villagers on Covid-19
summary: Offline app, developed by impact enterprise reach52, provides Covid-19 information and medical care to rural communities in Cambodia and the Philippines, using an offline-first digital platform. The chatbot, launched in 10 days, advises users to consult a doctor if symptoms are present. With 52% of the world lacking access to healthcare, reach52 aims to connect masses to essential health services. The response to the chatbot has been "excellent," with over 6,500 users in a week, and plans to roll out the platform in more than 10 countries.

site_title: Trump and Republicans narrowly top Biden in April fundraising
summary: US President Donald Trump's re-election campaign and the Republican National Committee raised $61.7 million in April, narrowly beating the combined total of $60.5 million from Joe Biden's campaign and the Democratic National Committee. This marks a record for the Trump campaign, bringing their total cash on hand to $255 million. Despite the coronavirus pandemic, Biden's fundraising figure follows a record total in March and reflects his campaign's efforts to catch up with Trump's war chest, which has been amassing funds since 2017.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Changi Airport will close T4 terminal on May 16 as part of cost-cutting measures. The move aims to save on utilities and cleaning costs. Meanwhile, Vietnam reacted to US President Trump's tariff announcement, seeking a lower rate. The Asian garment industry is bracing for higher US tariffs. In other news, Malaysia is set to seize RM3 billion of assets from Daim Zainuddin, China's GDP growth is expected to slow, and Citigroup predicts a mid-2026 target of 1,150 for the global equity index.

site_title: Singapore stocks falter ahead of MSCI reweighting
summary: Singapore stocks fell 0.9% on Tuesday, retreating from earlier gains, amid concerns over a potential second wave of Covid-19 infections and US-China trade tensions. The Straits Times Index closed at 2,587.81, down 23.50 points, after bouncing off its low in March. The market remains cautious ahead of the MSCI reweighting, which will impact global indices, and investors are also concerned about the sustainability of any rally given poor corporate outlook and weak economic data.

site_title: Hong Leong Asia to acquire remaining shares in Tasek
summary: Hong Leong Asia is acquiring the remaining shares in Tasek, a Malaysian cement maker, worth approximately RM83.9 million (S$27.4 million). The move follows an 88.16% stake held by Hong Leong Asia through two subsidiaries. The offer price is RM5.80 for every ordinary and preference share. This acquisition aims to take Tasek private, following a similar move last year. The book value of Tasek's group is approximately RM512.9 million.

site_title: US: Stocks open higher, extending rally
summary: US stocks opened higher on Tuesday, extending their rally, with the Nasdaq Composite Index up 0.1% to 9,203.55, the Dow Jones Industrial Average up 0.4% to 24,324.92, and the S&P 500 advancing 0.2% to 2,935.02. Investors continue to bet on a solid economy recovery from the coronavirus downturn.

site_title: Bryan Adams faces backlash over 'racist' Covid-19 post
summary: Canadian rocker Bryan Adams faced backlash and accusations of anti-Chinese racism after posting on Twitter and Instagram that his London shows were canceled due to the pandemic, blaming "bat eating, wet market animal selling, virus making greedy bastards." He also told the Chinese to "go vegan." His comments sparked widespread criticism, with many accusing him of racism and xenophobia. Adams later removed his posts, but the damage was already done, highlighting the sensitivity of online language during the pandemic.

site_title: Europe, Asia risk coronavirus relapse if lockdowns eased too soon, says IMF
summary: IMF senior economists warn that Asia and Europe risk a coronavirus relapse if lockdowns are eased too soon, putting gains in halting the spread of Covid-19 at stake. Over 250,000 people in South and East Asia have been infected, with 9,700 deaths, while Europe has 1.8 million confirmed cases and 160,000 deaths. The IMF advises caution, citing concerns over testing, contact tracing, and case isolation in Europe, which may lag behind Asian countries.

site_title: The early bird catches the public health worm
summary: The Covid-19 pandemic has highlighted the need for a more proactive approach to diagnostics, shifting from reactive measures to monitoring pathogens in the population to improve vaccine and treatment development, and outbreak preparedness. Diagnostics should map circulating pathogens, enabling timely production of vaccines and drugs. However, the development of respiratory virus-related diagnostics and drugs are in a deadlock, due to a lack of demand and funding. To address this, routine testing should be prioritized, leveraging new technologies such as drones and autonomous mobile labs, and implementing cost-effective business models, governance structures, and funding mechanisms to ensure equitable distribution of resources.

site_title: Job cuts may offer short-term relief but lead to longer-term pain, employers warned
summary: Singapore employers are advised to hold on to their workers as the Covid-19 pandemic recovery timeline is uncertain, with some experts predicting a 12- to 18-month vaccine timeline and others seeing the crisis lingering for 36 months. Layoffs may provide short-term relief but can lead to longer-term pain, including reduced productivity and increased unemployment. Experts warn that companies must be cautious not to prioritize shareholder interests over worker welfare, and that redeploying staff to other roles or working from home can help mitigate the impact of job cuts.

images.alt_text: Singapore's banks have found ways to redeploy their staff to other roles or to work from home. For example, OCBC Bank has redeployed 30% of its total branch sales and service staff.

site_title: EC World Reit sees lower Q1 DPU due to rental rebates given to tenants
summary: EC World Reit reported a 22.9% drop in distribution per unit (DPU) to 1.158 Singapore cents for Q1, largely due to rental rebates provided to tenants amid the coronavirus crisis. The manager retained 5% of the available distribution amount for prudence. Gross revenue and net property income were relatively stable, with growth from the Fuzhou E-Commerce acquisition partially mitigating the impact of rebates. The Reit's operations have mostly restarted and are back to normal.

site_title: Fauci warns Senate of needless death if US reopens too fast
summary: Anthony Fauci, the US top infectious disease official, warned a Senate panel that reopening the economy too soon could lead to new coronavirus outbreaks. Fauci expressed concern about communities "prematurely opening up without having the capability to respond effectively and efficiently." This contradicts President Trump's efforts to reopen the country and ease restrictions, which have crushed the economy. Fauci's caution highlights the ongoing debate over when to safely reopen businesses and ease restrictions amidst the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic.

site_title: China shouldn't be front and centre of American presidential race
summary: US President Donald Trump and his administration are using the COVID-19 pandemic to launch a diplomatic campaign against China, blaming them for the outbreak and its spread. Despite rising tensions, few politicians support a cold war with China, which could be economically costly and potentially ignite a hot war. Trump's strategy is part of a Republican strategy to turn China into a dominant issue in the 2020 presidential election campaign. This approach is seen as irresponsible and unlikely to help Trump win re-election, instead inviting a new cold war that could harm US national interests.

site_title: SocGen extends one-off payment after investors of SIA shorts protest; SGX opens probe
summary: Societe Generale (SocGen) is extending a one-off payment of 30 Singapore cents per certificate to investors of the 5x Short Singapore Airlines (SIA) daily leverage certificates (DLCs) following protests over lack of timely disclosure and unfair pricing. The Singapore Exchange has launched an investigation into the matter. Registered holders of the certificates as of May 11 will receive the payment, with mechanics and notification to follow.

site_title: China says Phase 1 trade deal beneficial to US, China and the world
summary: China's foreign ministry stated that the Phase 1 trade deal between China and the US is beneficial to both countries and the world. Spokesperson Zhao Lijian emphasized the importance of implementing the deal based on equality and mutual respect. However, some Chinese government advisers have urged Beijing to renegotiate the deal, citing a more favorable agreement.

site_title: P&O Ferries cuts 1,100 jobs as virus impacts
summary: P&O Ferries is laying off around 1,100 staff due to the impact of the coronavirus pandemic on its business. The shipping company, which employs 4,000 people, had previously furloughed 1,100 staff onto a government pay scheme. The layoffs are part of a plan to "right-size" the business and become "viable and sustainable" during the pandemic. Unions have expressed alarm at the development, calling it "devastating" and an "appalling betrayal" of the workforce. The company transports around 15% of urgently needed goods to the UK, primarily food and medicines.

site_title: China halts beef imports from 4 Australian firms as Covid-19 spat sours trade
summary: China has suspended beef imports from four Australian meat processors amid souring trade ties due to a dispute over the Covid-19 pandemic. The move follows Australia's call for an independent inquiry into the virus's origins and China's proposal for an 80% tariff on Australian barley shipments. Trade Minister Simon Birmingham described the suspension as "disappointing" but denied it was retribution. The suspension is the latest escalation in a trade war between the two countries.

images.alt_text: China has suspended beef imports from four of Australia's largest meat processors, as the trade of several key agricultural commodities suffers in the wake of souring ties stemming from a dispute over the Covid-19 pandemic.

site_title: Wuhan to test entire population after new virus cluster
summary: Wuhan, China plans to conduct coronavirus tests on its entire population of 11 million after a cluster of new Covid-19 infections emerged in the city. The tests are to be administered within a 10-day time limit. However, the need for universal testing has been disputed by the Chinese Center for Disease Control and Prevention's chief epidemiologist, Wu Zunyou, who suggested that neighborhood screenings should focus on key jobs and other criteria rather than every person. The move comes as China has been on edge about a potential second wave of the virus.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed 2.38 points lower at 1,379.93 on Tuesday, with 456 losers outnumbering 437 gainers. Volume reached 6.366 billion lots worth RM3.717 billion.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets drop at open
summary: European stock markets declined at the start of trading on Tuesday, with London's FTSE 100 dropping 0.3% to 5,921.90 points, and the eurozone's DAX 30 and CAC 40 indices falling 0.4% each. The losses were triggered by fears of a possible second wave of the coronavirus. The declines come ahead of US-EU trade talks and amid ongoing tariff threats.

site_title: Singapore testing all migrant workers in dorms, to clear them to return to work
summary: Singapore is testing all 300,000-plus migrant workers in dormitories for Covid-19, with the goal of allowing them to return to work when the time comes. The number of foreign workers reporting acute respiratory illness has decreased, but mass testing will continue to drive high daily case numbers. The taskforce plans to gradually reopen the economy, starting with essential services, and will reassess measures if the outbreak worsens. As of Tuesday, 884 new cases were confirmed, mostly among foreign workers in dormitories, with over 32,000 workers tested so far.

site_title: Troubled Hin Leong's Ocean Tankers granted interim judicial management
summary: Singapore's largest oil tanker operator, Ocean Tankers Pte Ltd, has been granted interim judicial management by the Singapore High Court. The company, part of the troubled Hin Leong empire, is exposed to claims worth US$2.07 billion and has over 35 creditors. Interim judicial managers Angela Ee and Purandar Rao will assess whether Ocean Tankers can be restructured or rehabilitated within eight weeks. The company, led by CEO Evan Lim Chee Meng, operates over 150 vessels and counts major oil majors and traders as customers.

site_title: UMS announces interim dividend as Q1 net profit rises 53% to S$10.7m
summary: UMS Holdings reported a 53% rise in Q1 net profit to S$10.7m, driven by improved performance in its core semiconductor business. The company announced an interim dividend of one Singapore cent per share. Despite a strong start, UMS warned of market uncertainty and supply-chain disruptions due to the coronavirus outbreak, which may moderate the company's growth. Revenue rose 22% year-over-year to S$34.9m, but declined quarter-over-quarter due to the halted operations in Malaysia.

site_title: Nine multi-storey carpark rooftops in Singapore to be converted to urban farms
summary: Singapore plans to convert nine multi-storey carpark rooftops into urban farms, aiming to increase local food production as part of its 30 by 30 goal to produce 30% of the country's nutritional needs locally by 2030. The tender for the sites was launched by the Singapore Food Agency (SFA) and the Housing Board (HDB), with successful tenderers awarded a three-year contract. The move aims to reduce the country's reliance on food imports and strengthen its supply chain resilience, with the government also exploring other spaces for commercial farming, including industrial sites.

site_title: Australia: Shares fall on fear over new coronavirus cases, China's beef import ban
summary: Australian shares fell 1.07% to 5,403 on May 12, 2020, due to concerns over a second wave of coronavirus cases in several nations, including France and Germany, and a partial ban by China on Australia's beef imports.

site_title: Software maker Chef hires Guggenheim to help raise funds
summary: Chef, a software development startup, hires Guggenheim Partners to help raise funds amid the coronavirus pandemic. The company has raised about $105 million to date and is generating cash and profit. Chef's Chief Marketing Officer, Brian Goldfarb, stated that the company is "cautiously optimistic" about Q2, with no plans to reduce its workforce. The hiring of Guggenheim Partners comes after Chef explored a potential sale earlier this year, valuing the company at over $360 million.

site_title: Seoul: Shares end lower on coronavirus resurgence worries
summary: South Korean shares ended 13.23 points, or 0.68%, lower at 1,922.17, due to worries over a possible second wave of Covid-19 infections. The country reported 27 new cases, linked to nightclubs in Seoul's biggest clusters. This comes amid efforts to re-open economies, sparking concerns about the resurgence of the virus.

site_title: Tencent's absence is a drag for lagging Asia tech stocks
summary: US technology stocks, led by the Nasdaq 100 Index, have rallied 33% since March due to investor demand for tech and biotech shares during the coronavirus pandemic. However, Asian tech stocks, including Tencent, lag behind, with the MSCI Asia Pacific Information Technology Index up only 24% since mid-March. Tencent's absence from the index and strong revenue growth are contributing to its outperformance, with shares up 14% for the year. Despite the pandemic's negative impact on chipmakers, global mobile game sales have reached a record, and growth is expected to continue.

site_title: US core consumer-price index posts record 0.4% monthly decline
summary: The US core consumer-price index (CPI) fell 0.4% in April, the largest monthly decline on record since 1957, amid the coronavirus pandemic. This drop is attributed to a demand shock, with gasoline prices plummeting 20.6% and energy prices decreasing 10.1% from March. The core CPI also showed an annual gain of 1.4% in April, the smallest since 2011, and annual inflation slowed to 0.3%. A sustained trend of declining prices raises concerns about deflation and a slow economic recovery.

site_title: Hong Kong police chief admits 'undesirable' behaviour towards media at protest
summary: Hong Kong's police chief, Chris Tang, admitted that his officers displayed "undesirable" behavior towards media during recent protests, including pepper-spraying journalists and restricting their movement. The incidents occurred during a Sunday protest where hundreds gathered in shopping malls, defying a ban on groups of more than eight. Tang expressed regret over the media experience, acknowledging that his officers should have been more professional. The police arrested around 230 people during the protests.

site_title: UK to unveil changes to furloughing scheme
summary: The UK is set to announce changes to its Coronavirus Job Retention Scheme, which pays 80% of workers' wages during the pandemic. Finance Minister Rishi Sunak will make a statement on the economic package, amid concerns that the scheme cannot last forever. Health Minister Matt Hancock hinted that the government may cut payments to 60% of earnings, but did not confirm the details. The changes are expected to impact over 6 million workers.

site_title: 877 of 884 new cases in S'pore are migrant workers from dormitories
summary: Singapore reported 884 new COVID-19 cases, with 877 migrant workers from dormitories accounting for the majority. Two non-COVID-19 related deaths were announced, bringing the total deaths due to complications from COVID-19 to 21. The Ministry of Health attributes deaths to COVID-19 only when the primary cause is confirmed. The total COVID-19 cases in Singapore now stand at 24,671, with 626 patients discharged, bringing the total to 3,851.

images.alt_text: The Ministry of Health (MOH) announced 884 new Covid-19 cases in Singapore as of Tuesday noon (May 12), with migrant workers living in dormitories once more forming the majority of cases.

site_title: Saudi Aramco Q1 profit dives, says virus to hit 2020 results
summary: Saudi Aramco reported a 25% decline in Q1 net profits to 62.5 billion riyals (S$23.52 billion) due to low oil prices and the coronavirus crisis. The company attributed the drop to declining crude oil prices and shrinking margins in refining and chemicals businesses. The Q1 results are expected to be impacted by the crisis, with the company warning that full-year earnings will be dampened.

site_title: BHP completes first yuan-based iron ore sale to China's Baosteel
summary: BHP, the world's top listed miner, has completed its first yuan-based iron ore sale to China's Baosteel, valued at nearly 100 million yuan (S$20 million). This deal follows Baosteel's previous purchase of iron ore from Vale in January. BHP plans to explore using blockchain technology for such transactions in the future. China, the largest iron ore consumer, aims to gain influence over pricing to help its steel firms weather market fluctuations. Baowu Steel Group, China's biggest steelmaker, has now struck yuan-based deals with the four major iron ore miners, including BHP and Rio Tinto.

site_title: India suspends 39 import licenses for refined palm oil
summary: India has suspended 39 import licenses for refined palm oil, impacting 452,303 tonnes of imports, following a surge in duty-free purchases from Nepal and Bangladesh. The suspension could reduce India's palm oil imports and pressure Malaysian palm oil futures, but may boost shipments of soyoil and sunflower oil. The move aims to curb imports of refined palm oil, which India has restricted since January, and is expected to have minimal impact on domestic markets due to a 40% decline in consumption.

site_title: Window for this bullish Hong Kong dollar trade is closing
summary: Hedge funds have weeks left to profit from the long Hong Kong dollar carry trade, as the city's liquidity pool approaches a threshold of HK$100 billion, which would narrow the yield advantage of the Hong Kong dollar over the US dollar. The trade, which has persisted since November, now ranks seventh in the region, and rapid unwinding could lead to a selloff and a drop in the currency to the weak end of its trading band, predicted by Bank of America to reach 7.85 per greenback by year-end.

site_title: Thyssenkrupp's rising debt gnaws at US$19b elevator lifeline
summary: Thyssenkrupp's net after-tax loss widened to 1.31 billion euros in the six months to March 31, with net debt surging 56% to 7.55 billion euros. The company's elevator sale, meant to fund a turnaround, is now at risk due to reduced cash. CEO Martina Merz said the pandemic will significantly reduce the company's leeway, and it may lose up to one billion euros in the fiscal third quarter. Thyssenkrupp is struggling with a slowdown in manufacturing, rising pension costs, and falling demand for European steel.

site_title: What to do with 50 pounds of potatoes? The quandaries of bulk buying
summary: During the COVID-19 pandemic, bulk buying has become a common practice among some shoppers, driven by the need to stock up on essentials and reduce shopping trips. Many are buying in excess of what they can consume, with some purchasing 50 pounds or more of staples like potatoes, beans, and flour. This trend is attributed to a combination of factors, including hoarding, panic-buying, and a desire to be prepared for uncertain times. While some see this as a challenge, others have found creative ways to use up their bulk purchases, such as experimenting with new recipes and meal planning.

site_title: Petrol falls below S$2 a litre in Singapore
summary: Petrol prices in Singapore have fallen below S$2 a litre for the first time in several years. The 95-octane petrol price has dropped to S$1.99 a litre, a 20-25% reduction from wholesale fuel prices. Diesel remains unchanged at S$1.64.
