The price cuts are attributed to the recent drop in crude oil rates, with oil consultant Ong Eng Tong suggesting that demand for jet fuel remains low due to lockdowns worldwide. This is the second price cut in two weeks, with the last time multiple petrol grades were below S$2 occurring in 2015.

site_title: Thailand, Malaysia, Singapore may see recovery in Q1 2021: report
summary: A report from Morgan Stanley suggests that export-oriented economies in Southeast Asia, including Thailand, Malaysia, and Singapore, may not recover until the first quarter of 2021 due to the coronavirus-led slowdown. In contrast, countries like the Philippines and Indonesia are expected to recover sooner, while East Asian economies of Korea and Taiwan may hinder their recovery. China is likely to return to pre-Covid-19 levels of economic growth by the third quarter of 2020, according to the report.

site_title: South Korea deploys mobile data, police to tackle nightlife virus cluster
summary: South Korean authorities are using mobile phone data to track nightclub visitors amid a coronavirus cluster in Seoul's Itaewon district, including several gay clubs. The country has reported 27 new cases, bringing the total to 10,936, and 101 cases have been linked to the cluster. Authorities have secured a list of 10,905 people who visited the area and are deploying thousands of police to track down those who cannot be identified. Anonymity is promised to those being tested due to stigma surrounding homosexuality, and fines of up to 2 million won have been imposed for those who avoid testing.

site_title: Airlines start to recover with more growth in China, Hong Kong
summary: Airlines globally added 600,000 seats to their flight schedules, a 2% increase, as the industry starts to recover from the COVID-19 pandemic. China and Hong Kong led the recovery, with China adding 1 million seats and Hong Kong's Cathay Pacific Airways increasing frequency by 120 flights. Domestic capacity in China stands at 75% of January's level, while the US is at 27% and Russia at 49%. Some markets, such as South Asia, remain on a downtrend due to travel restrictions.

site_title: German insurer Allianz profit slumps on virus impact
summary: German insurer Allianz reported a 29% plunge in quarterly profits due to claims from Australian wildfires and COVID-19-related losses. The group abandoned 2020 targets due to global economic uncertainties caused by the pandemic. Revenues rose 6% to 42.6 billion euros, driven by new business in its life and health insurance arm. The company's asset management division saw a jump in operating profits. Allianz will announce a revised profit target for 2020 once the pandemic's impact is better assessed.

site_title: Home anime: Ghibli producer offers Totoro lesson online
summary: Studio Ghibli producer Toshio Suzuki offers an online tutorial for drawing Totoro, a beloved character from his studio's film My Neighbor Totoro. The tutorial, posted on a website to support children stuck at home due to the coronavirus outbreak, features Suzuki's step-by-step instructions on drawing the character's distinctive features. Suzuki, former president of Studio Ghibli, is also a producer of other popular Studio Ghibli films, including Kiki's Delivery Service and Spirited Away. The tutorial aims to bring joy and creativity to children during the pandemic.

site_title: Honda declines to give outlook as profit slides amid coronavirus pandemic
summary: Honda Motor Co. reported its lowest operating profit in four years, falling 13% to 634 billion yen (S$8.37 billion) for the year ended in March. The company declined to provide an earnings outlook due to the ongoing coronavirus pandemic, citing uncertainty over the pandemic's duration and regional developments. This fell short of a consensus estimate of 669 billion yen profit.

site_title: Spark New Zealand to manage part of country's 5G allocation
summary: Spark New Zealand has secured management rights to 60 megahertz of 3.5 gigahertz spectrum for its 5G rollout, a move expected to drive significant investment in the technology over the next year. The decision comes after the company abandoned plans to exclusively rely on Huawei, citing concerns over national security. Spark CEO Jolie Hodson sees 5G as crucial for New Zealand's economic recovery from the Covid-19 pandemic, and plans to roll out services in major centers over the next year.

site_title: Aramco is alone among Big Oil in keeping media out of AGMs
summary: Saudi Aramco holds its first AGM since a record IPO in December, with journalists not invited, unlike its Big Oil rivals. The company will release first-quarter earnings, but no conference call or press presentation will be held. Aramco's decision to keep media out of the AGM is unusual, as its rivals plan to provide open web access to AGM proceedings. The company's CEO and finance head last briefed analysts on a conference call, but media were not allowed to attend.

site_title: China suspends imports from four Australian abattoirs as ties sour trade
summary: China has suspended imports from four Australian abattoirs due to labelling issues, citing health certificate errors. The move affects thousands of jobs and farmers reliant on these facilities. The decision is not related to Australia's call for a coronavirus inquiry, but rather a result of past labelling issues in 2017. This comes just days after China proposed an 80% tariff on Australian barley shipments, further straining bilateral trade ties.

site_title: China announces new list of US imports eligible for tariff waivers
summary: China's finance ministry announced a new list of 79 US products eligible for import tariff waivers for one year, effective May 19, 2020, and ending May 18, 2021. The list includes rare earth ore and other US imports. The waivers are part of China's efforts to ease tensions in the trade war with the US.

site_title: Hyatt to lay off 1,300 employees as pandemic cripples travel
summary: Hyatt Hotels Corp announced plans to lay off 1,300 employees globally due to the coronavirus crisis, which has severely impacted the travel industry. The hotel chain reported a wider-than-expected quarterly loss and suspended its dividend and share buyback program. The layoffs will begin on June 1, 2020, and eligible employees will receive severance pay. This decision comes as the hotel industry estimates a loss of US$1.4 billion in revenue every week due to the outbreak.

site_title: Toyota expects 79.5% annual operating profit drop due to virus
summary: Toyota expects a 79.5% drop in its annual operating profit to 500 billion yen (S$6.59 billion) due to the significant impact of the coronavirus pandemic on its business. This represents a decline of 79.5% from the previous year's operating profit of 2.44 trillion yen. The company attributed the decline to "wide-ranging, significant and serious" fallout from the crisis.

site_title: Tentative restart for Indian trains even as virus cases surge
summary: India's railway network is gradually resuming operations after a month-long lockdown, with 30 trains set to depart on Tuesday, despite a surge in new coronavirus cases. The country reported over 3,600 new infections on Monday, with some states experiencing record jumps. Experts say India is ill-prepared for a major outbreak due to inadequate testing. Prime Minister Narendra Modi has eased restrictions, citing a relatively modest 70,000 cases and 2,000 deaths, but warns that the measures needed in the first phase may not be needed in the subsequent phases.

site_title: India billionaire behind IndiGo weighing Virgin Australia bid: source
summary: India's Rahul Bhatia, the largest shareholder of IndiGo, is considering a bid for Virgin Australia Holdings, following the airline's struggles due to the coronavirus pandemic. Bhatia's holding company, InterGlobe Enterprises, is evaluating data and finalizing a strategy, but no decision has been made. This move is part of a growing trend of suitors capitalizing on Asia's airline casualties. IndiGo previously denied plans to bid for Virgin Australia, with the proposal being prepared by InterGlobe Enterprises, not the airline itself.

site_title: M1 fibre services down in some areas in western, central and eastern Singapore
summary: M1 fibre services experienced technical difficulties in western, central, and eastern Singapore on May 12, 2020, with reports of disruptions starting at 4.27am. The issues led to 1,185 and 1,432 reports on Down Detector by 7.27am and 8.42am, respectively. Customers, including Lim Jing Hong, reported difficulties in accessing the internet, resulting in missed work meetings and inconvenience. M1 apologized and stated that its engineers were working to resolve the issue, but a timeline for resolution was not provided.

images.alt_text: Users trying to access the Internet on M1 fibre services on Tuesday morning may experience technical difficulties.

site_title: New Zealand sticks with support for Taiwan at WHO despite Chinese rebuke
summary: New Zealand has reaffirmed its support for Taiwan's participation at the World Health Organization (WHO) as an observer, despite China's rebuke. New Zealand's foreign minister Winston Peters said the country must stand up for itself, citing Taiwan's success in limiting the spread of the novel coronavirus. Peters stated that New Zealand's position is based on Taiwan's health response to Covid-19, not on diplomatic ties with China. The decision is seen as a significant move, with Taiwan having reported low coronavirus cases and deaths.

site_title: Revolut hires new Singapore executives as it ramps up regional growth
summary: Revolut has appointed James Shanahan as its Singapore CEO to lead regional growth, bringing over 25 years of experience in Asia. The firm has also hired Rayson Tan as chief compliance officer, chief risk officer, and head of legal, and Pam Chuang as head of growth. These hires come as Revolut aims to expand its product suite in Singapore, Japan, and Australia by the end of the year, with a focus on achieving product parity in these markets.

site_title: Pandemic politics costing lives in Brazil
summary: Brazil is divided over its response to the COVID-19 pandemic, with President Jair Bolsonaro downplaying the danger despite a death toll exceeding 10,000. Bolsonaro's stance has been at odds with other officials, leading to a heavy human toll. The country's political divide is hindering efforts to contain the virus, with many calling for stricter measures. The situation is taking a toll on the nation, highlighting the challenges posed by the pandemic in Brazil.

site_title: Egypt coaxes wheat from local farmers as foreign suppliers balk
summary: Egypt is boosting purchases from local farmers to stockpile wheat amid international supply risks due to the coronavirus pandemic. The country bought 1.6 million tons of local wheat in the first three weeks of the harvesting season, nearly double the amount bought last year. The government is offering higher prices to farmers, aiming to produce enough state-subsidized bread for its 100 million people. This move comes as major grain producers like Russia curb exports to protect their food security.

site_title: The good news for Marriott and Hilton is that April is finished
summary: Marriott International Inc reported a 90% decrease in revenue per available room in April, the worst month in hotel industry history, due to the Covid-19 pandemic. The company's adjusted earnings per share fell to 26 cents, significantly lower than analyst estimates. Despite a stabilization in occupancy at limited-service hotels in North America, roughly a quarter of Marriott's 7,300 hotels are closed. The company's business in Greater China is showing signs of recovery, with occupancy at 25% in April. The pandemic's impact on the industry is considered severe, surpassing previous crises.

site_title: Changi Airport to close T4 from May 16 as part of further consolidation
summary: Changi Airport will temporarily suspend operations at Terminal 4 (T4) starting May 16 due to low flight demand. The move is part of further consolidation efforts to save on running costs. Cathay Pacific and Korean Air will operate at Terminal 1. T4's operations will resume when air travel demand picks up, and airlines request to relaunch flights. The temporary closure will last for 18 months amid the novel coronavirus pandemic.

site_title: Shut casinos hit Caesars as Covid-19 puts gambling industry in survival mode
summary: Caesars Entertainment Corp missed quarterly revenue estimates due to nationwide lockdowns from the Covid-19 pandemic, shuttering its casinos. The company reported a 11.5% decline in casino revenue to $958 million and a 13.6% decline in net revenue to $1.83 billion. Caesars implemented a phased reopening of its properties and furloughed 90% of its employees in North America. The company has over $2.6 billion in liquidity and warned of an estimated daily cash burn of $9.3 million.

site_title: China's factory deflation deepens as pandemic hits demand
summary: China's factory prices fell 3.1% in April, the sharpest rate in four years, due to weakening industrial demand amid the coronavirus pandemic. The producer price index (PPI) decline was faster than expected, highlighting the need for more forceful measures to spur demand. The data also showed a 51.4% year-on-year price fall in oil and gas extraction, while Chinese manufacturers face rising inventories and falling profits. The central bank has extended 1.7 trillion yuan in new loans, and analysts expect further monetary easing soon.

site_title: WeWork directors seek to preserve right to sue owner SoftBank
summary: WeWork directors filed a motion in Delaware to preserve the special committee's authority to pursue a lawsuit against SoftBank Group over an abandoned $3 billion tender offer. The committee, representing minority shareholders, contests SoftBank's decision to walk away from the tender offer. A judge has set a trial date for early January, and the motion seeks to maintain the status quo pending the outcome of the case. WeWork's board voted to retain a search firm to identify independent directors, amid a heated legal dispute between the two sides.

site_title: Simon to reopen half of retail properties by next week amid tenant bankruptcies
summary: Simon Property Group, the largest US mall operator, plans to reopen about half of its 200 retail properties in the US within the next week, following the COVID-19 pandemic. The company reported a 20% decline in quarterly profit and scrapped its annual forecast due to tenant bankruptcies, including J Crew and Neiman Marcus. Despite this, CEO David Simon expressed confidence in the safe reopening of malls, citing science and the easing of lockdown restrictions. The company will continue to pay a second-quarter dividend and pay out 100% of taxable income in cash.

site_title: SPH launches Tamil Murasu and The Straits Times news tablet bundle package
summary: SPH launches a Tamil Murasu and The Straits Times news tablet bundle package at S$29.90/month, with a 10.1 inch Samsung Galaxy Tab A tablet and auto-login news app. This comes after successful launches of similar packages for The Straits Times, Chinese, and Berita Harian news tablets, with over 27,000 subscribers.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open slightly higher on Tuesday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened slightly higher on Tuesday, with the Nikkei 225 index gaining 0.17% and the Topix index up 0.06%. Investors are cautiously optimistic about economic restarts after business shutdowns due to the coronavirus outbreak.

site_title: Author Haruki Murakami to DJ 'Stay Home' radio special as virus shutdown continues
summary: Haruki Murakami, a renowned Japanese novelist, will host a 'Stay Home Special' radio show to boost Japan's spirits amid the ongoing COVID-19 state of emergency. The show will feature Murakami playing his favorite songs and welcoming listener comments. Tokyo Governor Yuriko Koike's plea for residents to stay home is reflected in the special's name. Murakami aims to lift the nation's spirits through the power of music, hoping it can alleviate some of the coronavirus-related blues. The radio show is set to air during the ongoing virus shutdown.

site_title: Cromwell E-Reit's Q1 operational performance improves due to new acquisitions
summary: Cromwell European Real Estate Investment Trust (Cromwell E-Reit) reported improved Q1 operational performance, with gross revenue increasing 21.4% to 48.5 million euros (S$74.3 million) and net property income (NPI) rising 17.2% to 31 million euros. Total returns attributable to unitholders also increased 13% to 17.5 million euros. These results are attributed to new acquisitions.

site_title: Qatar Airways giving away 100,000 free tickets to healthcare workers
summary: Qatar Airways is giving away 100,000 free economy class return tickets to frontline healthcare workers worldwide to thank them for their work during the Covid-19 pandemic. The giveaway started on May 12 and ends on May 18, with daily allocations based on each country's population size. Tickets must be booked by Nov 26 and travel until Dec 10, 2020, with unlimited destination or date changes. A 35% discount voucher is also offered at Qatar Duty Free retail outlets in Doha. Healthcare professionals must register at qatarairways.com/ThankYouHeroes to receive the promotion code.

images.alt_text: Qatar Airways on Monday said it is giving away 100,000 free tickets to frontline healthcare workers around the world to thank them for their work during the Covid-19 pandemic.

site_title: Utz is in merger talks with blank-check firm Collier
summary: Utz Quality Foods, a US-based potato chip-maker, is in talks to be acquired by Collier Creek Holdings, a blank-check company, for over $1 billion. The deal, which could be finalized this month, would value Utz at more than $1 billion, including debt. The companies have been in talks since before the pandemic, and negotiations are ongoing. Utz, founded by Bill and Salie Utz, is the largest independent privately held snack brand in the US and has made other acquisitions in recent years. A final decision has not been made, and the deal could fall through.

site_title: Singapore's April condo resale volume falls 57.3% amid 'circuit-breaker' period: SRX
summary: Singapore's condo resale volume plummeted 57.3% in April to 309 units, a 62.2% year-on-year drop from the five-year average. Prices fell 0.2% from March and 0.7% from a year ago. The OCR accounted for 58.1% of resale volume, with OCR prices dropping 1.6%. The highest transacted price was S$27.7 million for an apartment at Ardmore Park. The overall transaction over X-value (TOX) was negative S$11,000, indicating buyers were underpaying for properties.

site_title: Frasers Centrepoint Trust issues S$200m 3-year notes at 3.2%
summary: Frasers Centrepoint Trust issued S$200 million 3-year notes with a 3.2% fixed-rate coupon, priced at 3.2%. The Series 001 notes are part of its S$3 billion multicurrency debt issuance programme. Net proceeds will be used for refinancing existing borrowings and general working capital.

site_title: Infections near US meat plants rise at twice national rate
summary: The coronavirus spread at more than twice the national rate in US counties with major meatpacking plants in the first week after their reopening, according to a Bloomberg News analysis. Confirmed Covid-19 cases jumped 40% in these counties, compared to a 19% rise nationally. The counties accounted for 10% of new confirmed cases, despite representing just 7.5% of the US population. The US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention has concluded that conditions at meatpacking plants, including difficulty maintaining social distance, contributed to the spread of the virus.

site_title: Brazil chicken exports fall yet prospects good due to China, halal market
summary: Brazil's chicken export volumes fell 4.7% to 343,300 tonnes in April due to reduced working days from holidays. However, demand remains strong from China, which imported 18% of Brazil's total chicken exports, and the Middle East, particularly Saudi Arabia, which purchased 34,600 tonnes in April. The Arab countries' decision to delay substituting imports with locally produced meat due to the Covid-19 pandemic is expected to maintain demand for Brazilian chicken. Despite the decline, Brazil's chicken exports were up 5.1% from January to April.

site_title: Australia business conditions sink further, confidence lifts off the floor
summary: Australia's business conditions worsened in April, with the National Australia Bank's index sinking to -34, a record low, due to coronavirus-induced lockdowns. Sales, profit, and employment suffered, and business confidence remained below the long-run average at -46. This marks a significant decline from March's -66. The decline is worse than during the global financial crisis.

site_title: China steps up American soybean buying with million-ton purchase
summary: China has purchased over 1 million metric tons of US soybeans in the past two weeks, exceeding its initial pledge under the trade deal with Washington. This surge in soybean buying is driven by Brazil's declining sales and China's need to meet its commitments. The purchases were made using tariff waivers and are expected to reach 30-35 million tons this year, according to Archer-Daniels-Midland Co. The deal aims to boost US agricultural exports, but the COVID-19 pandemic has slowed the pace of purchases. China's top trade negotiators have pledged to cooperate on the economy and public health.

site_title: Vietnam exemplary in handling of Covid-19: report
summary: Vietnam has successfully handled the Covid-19 pandemic, earning it a spot among the "learners" in Asia, according to a report by Control Risks. The country's toned-down authoritarianism and targeted resourcing have flattened its infection curve, with Vietnam outperforming its wealthier neighbors. China remains the poster child for effective infection suppression, while Indonesia is facing a "somewhat scary control experiment" with a major economic impact. The report highlights Vietnam's low-cost, low-economic impact campaign and its focus on keeping the country's export-oriented manufacturing sector open.

site_title: Australian, New Zealand dollars hit by virus unease, China trade tensions
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars fell on Tuesday due to concerns over a second wave of coronavirus infections and China's restrictions on Australian beef exports. The Aussie dollar dropped 0.6% to US$0.6445, while the kiwi dollar shed 1.1% to US$0.6065. China's actions have added to trade friction, and the Australian government's huge borrowing needs have led to a rush of issuance, including a new 2030 bond.

site_title: Australia's Victoria state to reopen classrooms earlier than expected
summary: Australia's Victoria state will resume face-to-face teaching from May 27, weeks earlier than expected, after a school shutdown to halt the spread of COVID-19. The state will take a staggered approach, starting with teenagers and younger pupils from June 9. The decision brings forward a previous recommendation to keep students at home until mid-year, following a decline in new infections.

site_title: 'Likely' a US airline will go under from coronavirus: Boeing chief
summary: Boeing CEO David Calhoun stated it's "most likely" a major US airline will go out of business due to the coronavirus pandemic's devastating impact on the aviation industry. He predicted traffic levels won't return to 100% even by September, with possible adjustments by the end of the year. Boeing itself is struggling, with travel restrictions depriving the company of clients and jeopardizing its order book. The pandemic has caused significant damage to the global air transport industry, leading to potential airline bankruptcies.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 0.75 points, or 0.05%, to 1,383.06 on Tuesday, driven by gains. The index had 248 gainers versus 84 losers, with a trading volume of 196.63 million lots worth RM77.16 million.

site_title: Oil rebounds in Asia after Saudi Arabia output cut
summary: Oil prices rebounded in Asian trade after Saudi Arabia cut its output by 1 million barrels per day, bringing daily production to nearly 7.5 million barrels. The move provided relief and encouraged other OPEC+ members to comply with output cuts. US benchmark West Texas Intermediate rose 1.37% and global benchmark Brent 0.71% in morning trade. However, doubts remain about the producers' ability to sustain the cuts, with analysts warning of a risk of second wave of virus infections as businesses reopen.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Wilmar, CDL, MNACT, Sembcorp, F&N, SIA Engg, Cromwell E-Reit
summary: Several Singapore-listed companies reported new developments on May 12, 2020, that may impact trading. Wilmar International saw its Q1 profit decline due to mark-to-market losses, while City Developments Ltd (CDL) sold 185 units worth S$278.1 million. Mapletree North Asia Commercial Trust issued a scrip dividend, and Sembcorp Industries signed a 25-year power purchase agreement. Fraser and Neave's net profit dipped, and SIA Engineering Company expects a challenging recovery in the aviation industry.

site_title: Singapore shares open lower on Tuesday; STI down 1.1%
summary: Singapore shares opened lower on Tuesday, with the Straits Times Index losing 1.1% to 2,582.20, after US markets finished mixed overnight. The local healthcare sector was among the most traded, with Clearbridge, Biolidics, and Healthway Medical rising. Meanwhile, the three local banks, DBS, OCBC, and UOB, declined. This follows a mixed US market, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average down 0.5%, while the Nasdaq Composite Index rose 0.8%.

site_title: BT's new Covid-19 mental health video series
summary: BT launches a new corporate mental health video series, featuring psychologist Maria Micha, who shares simple tips for managing work-related stress and anxiety during the Covid-19 crisis. Micha, with over 20 years of corporate counseling experience, offers advice on coping with psychological challenges. The series aims to help individuals function more effectively during difficult times, as many corporations are battling high anxiety and stress among employers.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares start Tuesday's session with losses
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened sharply lower on Tuesday, with the Hang Seng Index sinking 0.99% to 24,358.00, following recent gains and concerns over a possible second wave of infections in Asia. The Shanghai Composite Index eased 0.14% and the Shenzhen Composite Index remained flat. Investors are also monitoring US-EU trade talks and tariff threats.

site_title: P2P lending platform Validus raises US$20m in Series B+ round
summary: Singapore-based P2P lending platform Validus Capital has raised US$20 million in its Series B+ funding round led by Vertex Growth Fund and the Kuok Group's Orion Fund. The fresh funds will support technology investments, expansion to Thailand, and solidify its position in Singapore, Indonesia, and Vietnam. Validus has disbursed over S$453 million in loans to date and has a non-performing loan ratio of 2.69%. The company expects to see a healthy demand for short-term financing during the Covid-19 outbreak.

site_title: Europe, New York start emerging from lockdown as fresh cases hit Asia
summary: Europe and New York are starting to emerge from lockdowns as fresh COVID-19 cases are reported in Asia. In Europe, France, Spain, and Greece reopened, while Britain unveiled a "cautious roadmap" for new freedoms. New York state gave the go-ahead for a gradual reopening, despite New York City remaining closed. However, China and South Korea reported new cases, raising concerns about a second wave of infections, and prompting governments to take precautions. The global death toll has surpassed 283,000, with millions out of work and economies badly bruised.

site_title: 'Trump Death Clock' counts preventable US coronavirus deaths
summary: A billboard in New York's Times Square, known as the "Trump Death Clock," estimates that over 48,000 US coronavirus deaths could have been prevented if President Trump had acted sooner, with 60% of those deaths preventable with mandatory social distancing and school closures one week earlier. The "clock" was created by filmmaker Eugene Jarecki, who believes that if the Trump administration had implemented these measures on March 9 instead of March 16, the number of deaths would be significantly lower.

site_title: Binance invests in Indonesian cryptocurrency exchange Tokocrypto
summary: Binance has invested in Indonesian cryptocurrency exchange Tokocrypto, providing an undisclosed amount of capital to expand its staff, launch new products, and enhance technology. Tokocrypto will use the funds to hire new talent and set up remote offices in Indonesia. The two-year-old startup earns revenue from transaction fees and has an average daily transaction volume of about $700,000. Binance's investment aims to protect customers' assets and explore opportunities in the Indonesian market with a regulated local partner.

site_title: Musk 'restarting' California Tesla factory, defying authorities
summary: Elon Musk announced on Twitter that Tesla is restarting production at its California auto assembly plant, defying Alameda County authorities. The move comes amid a dispute over the pace of easing lockdowns to contain the coronavirus outbreak. Musk claims California's restrictions violate "our Constitutional freedoms & just plain common sense!" and threatens to move Tesla's headquarters and factory to Texas or Nevada if the issue isn't resolved. US Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin has voiced support for Tesla's effort to reopen its factory, while a Texas county has welcomed the firm.

site_title: Virgin Australia has 19 potential buyers in data room: administrator
summary: Virgin Australia's administrator reported 19 potential buyers have accessed a data room, with non-binding indicative offers due on May 15. The airline, owing A$7 billion, aims to agree a deal by the end of June. With 117 leased planes and engines, only 50 are operational due to low demand caused by the pandemic. The airline's administrators are seeking a buyer to reduce its debt and operational costs.

site_title: Biden and Democrats raise US$60.5m in April
summary: US President Joe Biden's Democratic campaign and party raised US$60.5 million in April, exceeding a record total of US$46.7 million in March. The fundraising figure comes despite the coronavirus health crisis and economic uncertainty. Biden attributed the success to online donations averaging US$32.63, made by supporters who have made sacrifices during the pandemic. This marks a significant improvement from early struggles, with Biden now playing catch-up to Republican President Donald Trump's war chest, which has been amassing funds since 2017.

site_title: Airport screening ineffective against Covid-19: US health agency
summary: US health agency CDC finds airport screening for Covid-19 ineffective due to asymptomatic transmission. Despite 12,000 passengers screened between February and March, only three matched with reported cases. The agency concludes that screening may not be beneficial for detecting the virus, unlike Ebola screening, which was more effective due to obvious symptoms. The White House considers reviving fever checks at 20 airports, but CDC officials express concerns over the plan's effectiveness and potential misuse of agency resources.

site_title: AIMS Apac Reit cuts Q4 DPU by 27.3% to S$0.02
summary: AIMS Apac Reit's distribution per unit (DPU) fell 27.3% to S$0.02 in Q4 2020 due to lower gross revenue and rental income. The Reit's gross revenue decreased 5.7% to S$28.2 million, while net property income grew 0.9% to S$20.5 million. Distributions to unitholders declined 25.6% to S$14.1 million, with the Reit retaining S$2.9 million to conserve cash.

site_title: Trump rules out renegotiating China trade deal
summary: US President Donald Trump has ruled out renegotiating the trade agreement signed with China in January. When asked about reports that China was looking to reopen talks, Trump stated, "I'm not interested in that. Not even a little bit. Let's see if they live up to the deal that they signed." This decision comes after China's GDP growth is expected to slow, raising pressure on policymakers.

site_title: US oil producers struggle to stay afloat in sea of excess
summary: US oil producers, particularly those in the Permian Basin, are struggling to stay afloat due to the crash in oil prices caused by the Covid-19 pandemic. Companies like Capitan Energy, which produces 15,000 barrels of oil a day, have seen production decline to 6,000 barrels a day. To cope, the company has cut costs by 50%, including wages and contractor fees. However, owners fear they will have to lay off employees in the coming months unless oil prices recover to around $50 a barrel.

images.alt_text: For the companies that drill the highest-producing deposit of oil and natural gas in the world, straddling the border between Texas and New Mexico, the crash in oil prices has led to spectacular losses.

site_title: US coronavirus death toll passes 80,000: Johns Hopkins tally
summary: The US coronavirus death toll has surpassed 80,000, according to Johns Hopkins University, with over 1.3 million cases reported nationwide. New York has been the hardest hit state, with over 26,600 declared deaths.

site_title: CDL almost halves sales value, temporarily closes 30% of hotels in Q1
summary: CDL reported a significant decline in sales value for its first quarter, with 185 units sold for S$278.1 million, down from 173 units sold for S$516.3 million in the same period last year. The company attributed the decline to a slowdown in new home sales in China, the UK, and Australia due to the COVID-19 pandemic. Its hospitality portfolio was also impacted, with 30% of its 152 hotels globally temporarily closed, resulting in a 28.8% decline in revenue per available room in Singapore.

site_title: US airlines balance fewer flights with angry travellers seeking social distance
summary: US airlines are struggling to balance the number of flights with the demand for travel, leading to crowded planes and social distancing concerns. Despite a 90% decline in carrier traffic, over 215,000 people passed through security checkpoints on May 8, prompting airlines to fill more seats. Many passengers are complaining about the lack of social distancing, with some airlines offering rebooking options or travel credits to alleviate the issue. Load factors, or percentage of seats filled, averaged 22% in May, with some airlines reporting higher load factors, but still far below pre-pandemic levels.

images.alt_text: US airlines are grappling with one outcome of the deep schedule cuts they've made in response to near-zero travel demand: Many of the flights that remain are starting to fill up, complicating social distancing guidelines and angering some passengers.

site_title: UK government sets out phased plan to ease virus lockdown
summary: The UK government has released a 50-page plan to ease the seven-week coronavirus lockdown in England, recommending people wear facemasks in some public settings and reintroducing unlimited outdoor exercise from Wednesday. The plan also includes encouraging people to return to work in construction and manufacturing, with schools and nurseries potentially reopening from June 1. However, devolved governments in Scotland and Wales have opted for a more cautious approach, and Northern Ireland's recommendations are due to be published soon.

site_title: Low credit ratings most pervasive among hospitality, retail SMEs
summary: A study by Experian found that Singapore small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) in the hospitality, retail, construction, communications, and services sectors had the highest proportions of low credit ratings, with 81% of hospitality businesses and 70% of retail, construction, and services businesses at risk of defaulting on loans.

site_title: Tech giants show how immune they are to coronavirus fallout
summary: Tech giants, including Microsoft, Facebook, Google, Amazon, and Apple, have shown resilience in the face of the COVID-19 pandemic, with robust gains in sales despite the shrinking economy and skyrocketing unemployment. This is due to their ability to adapt and thrive in the software industry, where marginal costs are zero and unlimited upside is possible. Big tech companies are dominating in size and functionality, with the largest players investing heavily in talent acquisition and research and development. Meanwhile, smaller companies are struggling, with many forced to lay off employees or furlough staff.

site_title: France sees daily virus toll rise as lockdown eased
summary: France reported 263 new COVID-19 deaths, bringing the total to 26,643, amid the country's first easing of a two-month lockdown. The increase in deaths is a sharp rise from the previous day's 70, and comes as hundreds gathered in Paris to enjoy the sunny weather, despite the government's ban on alcohol in the area. Interior Minister Christophe Castaner criticized the "irresponsible behavior" and warned that the lockdown could be reimposed if cases surge again.

site_title: Zinc-hydroxychloroquine found effective in some Covid-19 patients: study
summary: A new study by the NYU Grossman School of Medicine found that combining zinc sulfate with hydroxychloroquine and azithromycin significantly improved treatment outcomes for COVID-19 patients, with those receiving the triple-drug combination having a 1.5 times greater likelihood of recovery and 44% lower mortality rate compared to those receiving the double-drug combination. However, the study's findings have not been peer-reviewed and a controlled experiment is needed to prove the benefits beyond doubt.

site_title: US says Chinese hacking vaccine research: reports
summary: The US Federal Bureau of Investigation and cybersecurity experts believe Chinese hackers are targeting research on COVID-19 vaccine development, including information on treatments and testing. US officials claim the hackers are linked to the Chinese government, prompting a potential official warning. China has rejected the allegations, with Foreign Affairs minister Zhao Lijian stating China opposes cyber attacks and will not engage in immoral behavior. The US warning could be a precursor to officially-sanctioned counterattacks by US agencies, amid a rise in cyber attacks against health professionals and medical research organizations.

site_title: WHO urges 'extreme vigilance' as countries exit lockdown
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) urges countries to show "extreme vigilance" as they begin to loosen COVID-19 lockdowns, despite declining infection and death rates in some countries. Over 280,000 people have died worldwide, and the WHO warns that widespread fears of fresh waves of transmission remain. The organization urges countries to boost public health responses, including testing and tracing, to avoid a major second wave. The WHO also notes that even if a country achieves "herd immunity," it does not mean that the disease will not spread again.

site_title: Trump says may limit contact with Pence over virus scare
summary: US President Donald Trump said he may limit contact with Vice President Mike Pence due to a coronavirus scare, despite Pence testing negative. Trump suggested Pence was in quarantine after his press secretary tested positive, but Pence's spokesman denied this, stating he was not in quarantine and had tested negative every day. The White House has instructed staff to wear masks, and Trump will likely discuss the situation with Pence.

site_title: BOJ appoints first female executive director
summary: The Bank of Japan has appointed its first female executive director, Tokiko Shimizu, in a move to diversify its management. Shimizu, 55, becomes the first woman to fill one of the bank's six executive director posts. The appointment is seen as part of the central bank's efforts to increase female representation, with only 13% of senior managerial posts filled by women. The move is also expected to influence the bank's monetary policy decisions.

site_title: Europe: Cyclical stocks knocked as virus fears resurface
summary: European stocks fell 0.4% on Monday as concerns about a second wave of coronavirus cases resurfaced, particularly in Germany and South Korea. Cyclical sectors such as banks, miners, and travel stocks took a hit, while French stocks declined due to a decline in Airbus shares. Despite a 26% recovery since mid-March lows, investors are cautious about the pace of economic recovery, with some predicting a V-shaped recovery will not be as fast as expected.

site_title: IMF approves US$2.77b emergency virus loan for Egypt
summary: The IMF approved a US$2.77 billion emergency loan for Egypt to help the country cope with the economic impact of the coronavirus pandemic. The loan, aimed at containing and mitigating the economic impact, will help finance targeted and temporary spending. However, the IMF warned that Egypt will need additional financial support to close its balance of payments gap and preserve its macroeconomic stability. This is the 50th loan approved by the IMF to help developing countries deal with the pandemic, with over 100 requests received so far, totaling around US$2.5 trillion.

images.alt_text: The IMF board approved US$2.77 billion in emergency aid for Egypt on Monday, to help the country deal with the impact of the coronavirus pandemic, but said the government will need more financial help.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Singapore-listed companies reported mixed earnings and results. Kimly's first-half net profit rose 5.3% to S$10.5 million, while Lian Beng Group won a S$174 million contract. Clearbridge Health expects a positive impact from distributing Biolidics' coronavirus antibody test kits. Ezion Holdings warned of a significant net loss due to asset impairments. Sakae Holdings will receive S$3.21 million from a shareholder return. The companies' financial outlook and dividend payments are set to be released in the coming weeks.

site_title: Oil falls on fears of second coronavirus wave
summary: Oil prices fell on Monday, with Brent crude futures losing 4.4% to $29.60 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate crude falling 2.4% to $24.14 a barrel, due to concerns over a second coronavirus wave. However, new output cuts from Saudi Arabia limited price losses. Global oil demand has slumped by 30% due to the pandemic, leading to growing inventories. Despite a 55% decline in crude futures this year, prices have rebounded slightly over the past two weeks.

site_title: Companies need to come up with convincing plans for post-Covid future
summary: Companies in Singapore are struggling to adapt to a post-Covid-19 future, with many relying on government aid to survive the economic downturn. As the government loosens movement restrictions, businesses must prepare for a new reality where core assumptions have been tested. Retailers, restaurants, and airlines must consider safe distancing options and adjust their business models to accommodate wary customers. Airlines are particularly vulnerable, with blocked middle seats and reduced capacity potentially crippling their ability to recover and driving up airfares. Companies must develop long-term strategies to thrive in a changed market.

site_title: Oil prices fall on supply glut, fears of 2nd virus wave
summary: Oil prices fell by over 1% on Monday, with Brent crude futures down 51 cents to $30.46 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate crude futures down 49 cents to $24.25 a barrel. Concerns over a persistent supply glut and fears of a second wave of coronavirus infections in North-East China and South Korea drove the decline, despite easing pandemic restrictions in some countries. Oil production worldwide is declining, and global demand has plunged by 30% due to the pandemic, building up inventories.

site_title: Tech is changing the way people help each other
summary: During the COVID-19 pandemic, technology has enabled people to quickly mobilize and help each other, lowering barriers to starting and supporting initiatives. Online social networks and cloud-based sharing platforms have facilitated crowdsourcing and crowdfunding, allowing individuals to find jobs, promote businesses, and access resources. This trend reflects "generalised reciprocity," where people feel more willing to help in the virtual world due to the ability to link with others as part of a larger community. As a result, tech platforms have made it easier to quantify the impact of the pandemic on specific sectors, and online initiatives have raised funds and provided aid to those in need.

site_title: PBOC vows to offset virus impact with 'more powerful' policies
summary: The People's Bank of China (PBOC) has vowed to implement "more powerful" policies to counter the economic impact of the coronavirus pandemic, which has brought unprecedented challenges to the country. The central bank will balance economic growth and jobs while managing inflation and financial stability, with a focus on helping the real economy resume development. The PBOC has not specified the exact measures it will take, but has emphasized the need for more flexible monetary policy and targeted relending to virus-hit sectors.

site_title: HC Surgical: Minority shareholder wants to sue CEO on behalf of the firm
summary: A minority shareholder, Serene Tiong, is planning to sue HC Surgical Specialists' CEO, Heah Sieu Min, on behalf of the company for allegedly breaching his duties as a director. Tiong claims the CEO breached his duties in the acquisition of a 19% interest in Dr. Julian Ong's private practice in 2019. HC Surgical has described the allegation as "frivolous" and "without merit." The company has constituted a litigation committee and is liaising with its legal advisers.

site_title: Sembcorp inks power purchase deal for PUB floating solar farm
summary: Sembcorp Industries has signed a 25-year power purchase agreement for a floating solar farm on Tengeh Reservoir in Singapore. The 60 megawatt-peak system, set to be fully operational by 2021, will meet 7% of PUB's energy needs. Sembcorp Solar won the contract to design, build, own, and run the project, and will install over 146,000 solar panels on food-grade floats. The deal is not expected to impact the company's earnings or net asset value.

site_title: SGX RegCo to drop minimum trading price rule on June 1
summary: The Singapore Exchange Regulatory Committee (SGX RegCo) announced that it will drop its minimum trading price rule for mainboard-listed companies on June 1. This rule, in place since 2016, required companies to have a six-month volume-weighted average share price of at least S$0.20 and an average daily market value of at least S$40 million. Additionally, the exit criteria for the financial watch list will be tightened, effective the same day.

site_title: F&N H1 net profit dips 2.7% to S$71.8m
summary: Fraser and Neave (F&N) reported a 2.7% year-on-year decline in H1 net profit to S$71.8 million, despite a 4.8% increase in revenue to S$976.7 million. The decline was attributed to higher finance costs related to its investment in Starbucks Thailand. The company warned of weaker consumer demand for beverages and dairy products in the second half of its financial year, but remains positive about its strong fundamentals and banking facilities.

site_title: For central banks, hope for precision fades amid pandemic uncertainty
summary: Central banks are struggling to provide precision in their guidance due to the ongoing pandemic's uncertain trajectory. With a range of possible economic outcomes, including depression and recovery, central bankers are offering broad support for years to come but lack clarity on specifics. This lack of precision is hindering their efforts to influence households and investors.

site_title: Some Singapore Racecourse space to be converted into Covid-19 recovery facilities
summary: The Singapore Turf Club and the Tote Board are collaborating with government agencies to convert areas of the Singapore Racecourse at Kranji into community recovery facilities for foreign workers recovering from Covid-19. The selected areas include a multi-storey carpark and Carpark B, as well as a sheltered area at the riding centre. The facilities are expected to be completed by end-May 2020 and will provide isolation for patients who are past the critical stage but still need to be isolated to reduce transmission risk.

site_title: UK quarantine plan will worsen pain, says aviation industry
summary: UK's plan to quarantine international arrivals could worsen the financial pain of the aviation industry, according to British Airways owner IAG. The company's CEO said it has exhausted all avenues to shore up its finances and will burn through cash if the government proceeds with the plan. The quarantine, set to start in late May, would add to pressure on the group, which is already facing a battle to survive with most flights grounded since March. Airlines are urging the government to come up with an alternative, warning the proposal could destroy hopes of a swift recovery for the sector.

site_title: Wilmar Q1 profit down 12.7% on market slide in investments
summary: Wilmar International reported a 12.7% decline in Q1 net profit to US$224.3 million due to mark-to-market losses on investment securities. Despite this, core profit increased 22.5% year-over-year, driven by stronger sales of consumer products and tropical oil downstream operations. Revenue rose 4.6% to US$10.9 billion. The company's market slide in investments contributed to the profit decline.

site_title: The billionaire poker club behind China's most indebted developer
summary: Billionaire Hui Ka Yan, chairman of China Evergrande Group, is navigating the company through its worst economic slump in decades. He is receiving support from fellow Chinese property tycoons, including increased financial ties with their real estate empires. China Evergrande has formed financial connections with three other Chinese magnates, according to company filings and reports.

site_title: Changing hands
summary: Oil prices rose over 2% amid market uncertainty, with investors weighing tariffs, sanctions, and market outlook. In business news, NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was oversubscribed 9.8 times, while Creative Technology warned of potentially lower-than-target H2 revenue and similar operating losses. US stocks edged down from records amid tariff threats, and London's Heathrow airport considered increasing fees for a £10 billion upgrade. In other news, Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a graft case involving 285 trillion rupiah.

site_title: India bond yields surge as government borrowing rises to cushion pandemic blow
summary: India's benchmark 10-year bond yield surged as the government increased market borrowing to 12 trillion rupees (S$226.5 billion) to cushion the economy's blow from the coronavirus pandemic. Analysts predict a fiscal deficit of at least 5.5% of GDP, pushing yields to 6.17%. The Reserve Bank of India's support through open market operations is crucial, and markets await a second stimulus plan to gauge the likely budget shortfall.

site_title: A Covid-19 survival guide
summary: A global recession looms due to the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic, which may impact small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) in Singapore. SMEs face challenges such as cashflow, resource, and talent constraints, making it difficult to obtain financing and adapt to uncertainties. A survey of 3,000 SMEs found sentiments at a historical low, indicating a dire situation. With over 99% of companies in Singapore being SMEs, the impact could be severe, highlighting the need for resilience and smart navigation in challenging times.

site_title: Money FM podcast: The good, the bad, the ugly of S-REITs
summary: The article discusses various financial and market-related topics. A low-profile property trust, NTT DC Reit, oversaw a 9.8 times oversubscribed public offer for its Singapore listing. Meanwhile, a Jack Ma-backed company, Ant, plans to add a stablecoin to its global network. Analysts from Amundi predict massive ETF growth driven by retail investors in Asia and Europe. Productivity gains and de-dollarisation are also key to wealth creation, with markets continuing to rise despite trade tensions.

site_title: US: Stocks end mixed as more states restart economic activity
summary: US stocks ended mixed on Monday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average down 0.5% and the S&P 500 essentially flat. Most US states have reopened parts of their economy, but some states like Georgia and Texas are expected to see an increase in Covid-19 cases. Investors are looking to the prospects of resuming economic activity, with Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell set to update investors on stimulus programs this week. Individual companies like Marriott International and Under Armour reported significant losses due to pandemic shutdowns, but some saw improvements in sales.

site_title: Singapore firms see mixed recovery as China lockdown thaws
summary: Singaporean companies in China are experiencing mixed recovery levels as the country lifts social distancing measures and lockdowns. Consumer-facing sectors, such as restaurants, are still struggling with reduced sales, with Paradise Group seeing takings only a third of pre-pandemic levels. However, online sales have helped some companies, like baby bottle manufacturer Hegen, which saw e-commerce sales more than double last year. Economists caution against hopes for a quick economic rebound, citing ongoing strict social distancing measures and concerns of a second wave of infections.

site_title: Oil price gyrations - was it all just a bad dream?
summary: Oil prices have surged to a 2-year high, reaching $30/barrel, after a gradual easing of lockdowns in several countries. The July Brent futures contract has seen a significant uptick, with the June US light, sweet futures contract flirting with $25/barrel. However, analysts caution that this optimism is premature, as global demand destruction is still estimated at 19 million barrels per day. The Opec+ coalition has agreed to implement a 9.7 million barrel production cut, which is expected to help balance supply and demand.

site_title: Coronavirus interrupts world's longest-running cartoon
summary: The world's longest-running cartoon, Sazae-san, which first aired in 1969, has been interrupted by the coronavirus, forcing the broadcast of re-runs for the first time in decades. The anime revolves around the life of Mrs. Sazae, a cheerful but klutzy full-time housewife. Due to the pandemic, the production has been halted, resulting in the re-broadcast of classic episodes.

site_title: Jem mall to host Ikea's first small-store concept in Asean
summary: Ikea will open its first small-store concept in South-east Asia in Jem shopping centre, Jurong East, Singapore in 2021. The 6,500 sqm outlet will span three floors, offering the full Ikea product range despite a smaller format. The store will feature a single department layout and will house Ikea's restaurant, serving Swedish meatballs and other popular items. The move aims to bring Ikea closer to its customers and capitalize on the renewed interest in home comfort and sustainability.

site_title: SIAEC braces for slow, difficult recovery in battered aviation industry
summary: SIA Engineering Company (SIAEC) expects a slow and difficult recovery in the aviation industry due to the Covid-19 pandemic. The company's core business relies on flying hours and aircraft maintenance cycles, which are expected to take time to recover. SIAEC's management is reviewing its cost structure, focusing on building internal capabilities and upskilling staff to create new job opportunities. Despite a 20.4% increase in net profit for the full financial year ended March 31, 2020, the company is concerned about the long-term impact of the pandemic on the aviation industry and its ability to maintain profitability.

site_title: An American eulogy
summary: The US, known for its exceptionalism, is facing unprecedented challenges due to the COVID-19 pandemic, which has exposed the country's vulnerabilities and weaknesses. Despite its strong institutions and research centers, the US struggled to respond effectively to the crisis, with a slow and ineffective federal response, inadequate testing and medical supplies, and a collapsing economy. The country's deepening political polarization and tribalization have also hindered its ability to unite behind a clear policy to address the crisis. President Trump's leadership style and divisive rhetoric have exacerbated the situation, and it remains uncertain whether the US can recover from this crisis.

site_title: JLD concept plans not up for review
summary: The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) has clarified that the concept plans for Jurong Lake District (JLD) are not up for review, contrary to an earlier statement. The URA is instead seeking a marketing consultant to develop a marketing strategy for JLD, which will focus on attracting businesses to the district. The blueprint for JLD was unveiled in 2008, and the area has seen significant developments, including the opening of the first phase of Jurong Lake Gardens and new attractions such as the Science Centre.

site_title: Frozen fare cold comfort for fishing industry battered by coronavirus
summary: The coronavirus crisis has severely impacted the global fishing industry, with lockdowns and travel restrictions leading to a sharp decline in demand for fresh seafood. The industry's total sales have plummeted, with US$161 billion in annual revenue at stake. Many fishermen and seafood firms are struggling to survive, with some calling for government aid. In response, some companies are adapting by developing packaged seafood products and shifting focus to home consumption. The crisis may also provide a brief window for depleted fish stocks to recover, but the immediate challenge is to survive until demand returns.

site_title: SPD Bank donates curry puffs to migrant workers
summary: SPD Bank in Singapore donated 5,000 Old Chang Kee curry puffs to over 260 migrant workers' dormitories, reaching out to more than 12,000 workers from India, Bangladesh, and China. The initiative, supported by Alliance of Guest Workers Outreach and Singapore Press Holding's Lianhe Zaobao, aimed to provide daily essentials and show appreciation for the workers' contributions to the country's economy. The donation was part of the bank's efforts to support the well-being of migrant workers, who are integral to Singapore's social and economic fabric.

site_title: UK plan to lift lockdown shatters political consensus
summary: UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson unveiled a roadmap to ease the country's lockdown, but the plan has been met with criticism for its lack of clarity and short notice. Johnson announced that workers in construction and manufacturing should return to work on Monday, but many business leaders and trade unions have expressed concerns about the safety and logistics of this move. The plan also includes a new quarantine policy for people arriving from overseas and a phased re-opening of shops and schools. The Welsh, Scottish, and Northern Irish administrations will not be following the changes, and Johnson's announcement has shattered the political consensus on the pandemic, with Labour leader Keir Starmer calling it "a recipe for chaos".

site_title: Bigwigs circling for fintech quarry as pandemic turns off cash tap
summary: Fintech startups are being targeted by corporate and tech bigwigs as the pandemic reduces funding for these companies. Analysts expect a stronger appetite for acquisitions, allowing fintechs to expand their offerings and gain access to larger customer markets through their parent companies. A Fitch Solutions report notes the pandemic will lead to lower funding levels for fintech players, making these deals more attractive.

site_title: HK protests reappear across the city
summary: Hong Kong's central bar district returned to normalcy, but fresh pro-democracy protests flared across the city, with over 200 arrests made on Sunday for violating coronavirus-related gathering restrictions. Police enforced the ban selectively, arresting protesters but not others, sparking concerns of a double standard. The government is trying to get Hong Kong back to normal after a recession, but renewed unrest could hamper the city's recovery, and protesters warn of a repeat of last year's unrest.

site_title: Boom time for Bangkok's online food delivery industry amid lockdown
summary: Bangkok's online food delivery industry has seen significant growth during the COVID-19 pandemic, with deliveries doubling overnight during the lockdown. The industry's growth began in 2019, driven by increased competition, cyber-banking adoption, and the popularity of motorcycle delivery drivers. The pandemic has accelerated this growth, with platforms like Food Panda, GET, and GrabFood experiencing rapid expansion. However, the industry faces challenges, including ensuring riders make a decent income and maintaining restaurant margins. As a result, many restaurants are adapting their business models to focus on delivery and online sales.

site_title: Tackling pandemic in Malaysia: Politicking gets in the way
summary: Malaysia's Prime Minister Muhyiddin Yassin's decision to ease the Movement Control Order (MCO) was met with resistance from six states, citing a need for more time to decide. The move is part of the government's efforts to mitigate the economic damage caused by the pandemic, but politicking is getting in the way. The Perikatan Nasional government, led by Muhyiddin, has been plagued by disputes over loyalty and legitimacy, with some parties questioning the prime minister's claim to majority support. The situation has sparked a debate on extending Parliament's session and a motion of no-confidence against Muhyiddin.

site_title: SMEs get more help for digital marketing
summary: Singapore's Enterprise Singapore (ESG) has enhanced the E-Commerce Booster Package to provide funding and support for digital marketing services and manpower for small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs). The package offers 90% subsidies for digital marketing advisory services and hiring staff to build in-house capabilities. The goal is to help SMEs adapt to customer preferences, increase customer loyalty, and attract new customers online. The program is available until September 30, 2020, and aims to support more than 2,000 heartland micro-SMEs and SMEs.

images.alt_text: "Retailers must strengthen their ability to understand how to better leverage digital marketing to attract and engage customers online, especially on social media," says Mr Tan.

site_title: Wear face coverings, UK says, as lockdown easing mired in confusion
summary: UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson has set out a cautious plan to ease the coronavirus lockdown, advising the public to wear homemade face coverings in enclosed spaces where distancing is impossible. The plan, which includes staged reopenings of businesses and an 14-day quarantine for most international arrivals, has been met with criticism and confusion, particularly from opposition parties and trade union leaders, who argue that the messaging is unclear and contradictory. The UK has the world's second-highest official Covid-19 death toll, and Johnson is wary of triggering a second deadly wave of infection.

site_title: US$ rises, yen falls behind as more countries ease lockdowns
summary: The US dollar rose against other major currencies, including the yen, as investors sought safety due to concerns over a slower-than-expected economic recovery from the COVID-19 pandemic. Japan and New Zealand eased lockdowns, while the UK and France also announced plans to relax restrictions. South Korea warned of a second wave of infections, and tensions between the US and China remained a concern. The dollar rose 0.3% against a basket of currencies, while the yen fell to a 10-day low versus the dollar.

site_title: US has no need to buy back debt, will take advantage of low interest rates, says Mnuchin
summary: US Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin stated there's no need for the US to buy back debt, as low interest rates will be taken advantage of to borrow money long-term. The country plans to refinance all its debt to lock in low rates, with a focus on long-term maturities. Mnuchin expressed optimism about businesses reopening over the summer and believes May unemployment numbers will improve, despite initial concerns. The US Treasury will borrow $3 trillion during the April-June quarter to fund coronavirus economic rescue programs and cover a massive drop in revenues.

site_title: Corporate altruism helps build a more resilient economy and society
summary: At least 32 firms in Singapore have returned their April payouts under the Jobs Support Scheme (JSS), freeing up S$35 million in public funds. The gesture, which also includes donations from other firms, demonstrates corporate social responsibility (CSR) during the COVID-19 pandemic. The returned payouts will be used for future payouts to firms struggling, making a real marginal difference in supporting local jobs. This move challenges the view of firms as heartless profit-maximizing machines, highlighting the potential benefits of corporate altruism in building a more resilient economy and society.

site_title: WHO should take the lead on virus study in China
summary: China's foreign ministry has expressed willingness to cooperate with the World Health Organization (WHO) on an open investigation into the origin of the Covid-19 virus, a shift from previous rejections. The Chinese government is proposing a "review" rather than an "independent investigation," but experts argue that the WHO should lead the study to ensure credibility. A second WHO mission to China is also being discussed, with the aim of determining the virus's animal origin. China's cooperation could lead to a resolution on the issue by the WHO's annual meeting next week.

site_title: From slippers to video clips, museums preserve lockdown life
summary: Museums worldwide are collecting objects and stories from people's lives during the COVID-19 lockdown to preserve a record of the pandemic's impact. The Museum of London launched an appeal for Londoners to donate items such as personal items, homemade goods, and videos of daily life. Curators are seeking to understand the emotions and experiences of those in isolation, including feelings of loss, fear, and hope. Similar initiatives are underway globally, with online archives and virtual museums being established to document the pandemic's effects.

images.alt_text: In Stockholm, children's reflections of how their daily lives have changed and how they see the future are being collected by the Nordic Museum.

site_title: Saudi to cut oil output by another 1m barrels a day
summary: Saudi Arabia announced plans to cut oil output by an additional 1 million barrels per day from June, reducing production to 7.5 million barrels per day. This move aims to support oil prices, which have crashed due to the coronavirus crisis. Neighboring Kuwait and the UAE have also pledged to cut production to support the initiative. The cuts are part of a record 9.7 million barrel reduction agreed upon by Opec+ members last month, with the goal of stabilizing the global oil market.

site_title: Volunteers assemble Hari Raya care packs
summary: Standard Chartered employees in Singapore assembled and distributed over 750 care packs to low-income families ahead of Hari Raya, despite a reduced volunteer pool due to safety precautions. The packs included rice, canned food, and cookies, provided by 15 non-profit organisations. This initiative demonstrates the bank's commitment to giving back to the community.

site_title: At least 38 Airbnb Singapore employees axed in global layoff
summary: Airbnb has laid off at least 38 employees in Singapore as part of its global restructuring, affecting about 12.7% of its workforce in the country. The layoffs come as the company seeks to slash 1,900 employees, or a quarter of its workforce globally, due to the impact of COVID-19 on the global travel market. Affected employees include executives in various roles, and those outside the US will receive at least 14 weeks of pay. The company has also dropped the one-year cliff on equity for laid-off employees.

site_title: HK's Goldin Financial sells residential land at HK$2.6b loss
summary: Hong Kong-based Goldin Financial Holdings sold a residential land parcel at a loss of HK$2.6 billion (S$475.3 million) to reduce debt amid an uncertain property market. The firm's stock rose 4.2% following the announcement. This rare move aims to stabilize the company's financial situation in the face of economic downturn.

site_title: Ezion board guides for Q1 'significant net loss' on the back of asset impairments
summary: The board of Ezion Holdings has guided for a significant net loss in the first quarter due to asset impairments stemming from the coronavirus pandemic and plummeting oil prices. The impairment assessment was conducted after the group's restructuring plans were hindered. The unaudited financial results are set for release this Thursday. Trading in Ezion shares was voluntarily suspended in 2019, and hearings for two subsidiaries will be rescheduled due to the circuit breaker controls in Singapore. The company will inform shareholders of material developments.

site_title: Singapore shares drift up amid continued confusion over SIA value
summary: Singapore shares rose 0.75% on Monday, mirroring Wall Street gains, as countries reopen their economies amid the Covid-19 pandemic. The Straits Times Index opened at 2,597.85 and closed at 2,611.31. Brokers reported confusion over the intrinsic value of Singapore Airlines' (SIA) mandatory convertible bonds (MCBs) issued with its rights issue. The MCBs, priced at S$1 each, may be converted into shares if not redeemed before maturity. Analysts warn that the next couple of weeks will be crucial in assessing the sustained Covid-19 impact on global economies.

site_title: Halcyon Agri to cut US$10m in operating, capital expenditure amid pandemic
summary: Halcyon Agri Corporation is reducing its US$10 million operating and capital expenditure for 2020 to mitigate the economic impact of the Covid-19 pandemic. The company is also managing its treasury operations, raising committed green financing, and enhancing credit by developing a digital borrowing base. This move aims to maintain sufficient liquidity across its operating entities.

site_title: At least 38 Airbnb employees laid off in Singapore as part of global retrenchment
summary: Airbnb has laid off at least 38 employees in Singapore as part of its global workforce reduction of 1,900 staff, a quarter of its workforce. The layoffs, announced on May 5, affect executives in various roles, including customer service, sales, marketing, IT, design, and business development. The company cited the impact of Covid-19 on the global travel market as the reason for the restructuring, aiming to adopt a more focused business strategy. Laid-off employees outside the US will receive at least 14 weeks of pay and equity vesting on May 25.

site_title: Deloitte flags 'going-concern' uncertainty in IEV Holdings financial statements
summary: IEV Holdings, a Catalist-listed oil-and-gas engineering group, has faced uncertainty over its ability to continue as a going concern due to significant current liabilities exceeding current assets by RM13.8 million. However, the company's board cites a recent share-subscription exercise and a 15-month cash flow forecast that suggests sufficient cash to meet working-capital requirements and obligations. Despite this, the independent auditor, Deloitte, flagged material uncertainty, and the IEV board believes it is appropriate to prepare and present audited statements on a going-concern basis.

site_title: Mapletree North Asia Commercial Trust prices scrip dividend at S$0.8752 per unit
summary: Mapletree North Asia Commercial Trust has announced a scrip dividend of S$0.8752 per unit, representing a 1.9% discount on the volume-weighted average traded unit price. The dividend is part of the trust's distribution reinvestment plan, allowing unit holders to opt for fully paid units instead of cash. The notice of election will be sent to unit holders on May 18, with a deadline of June 4.

site_title: 230 arrested in Hong Kong's first major protests since virus began
summary: Hong Kong police arrested 230 people, including a 12-year-old boy, during weekend democracy protests in the city's first major unrest since the coronavirus outbreak began. Riot police used pepper spray and batons against protesters and bystanders in Mong Kok, leading to 18 people receiving treatment for injuries. The arrests came after pro-Beijing leader Carrie Lam vowed to overhaul the city's education system, citing the liberal studies curriculum as a factor in last year's protests.

site_title: Trek 2000 board guides for Q1 net loss
summary: Trek 2000 International, a manufacturer of thumb drive devices, is expected to post a first-quarter net loss due to a lower fair value of its investments. The company attributes the loss to the negative impact of the coronavirus pandemic on the investment and equity market. The board's preliminary review of the unaudited results has not yet been audited and will be released by Friday.

site_title: Actor and comedian Jerry Stiller dies at 92
summary: Veteran actor and comedian Jerry Stiller, known for his roles on Broadway and in "Seinfeld," has died at 92 due to natural causes. He starred alongside his wife Anne Meara and later played Frank Costanza in "Seinfeld," earning a Funniest Male Guest Appearance award in 1989. Stiller also appeared in "The King of Queens" and the "Zoolander" films, alongside his son Ben. His son confirmed his passing, praising Jerry as a great father, husband, and grandfather.

site_title: S Korea scrambles to contain new Covid-19 cases
summary: South Korea is scrambling to contain a new COVID-19 outbreak linked to nightclubs and bars in Seoul, with officials searching for thousands of potential infected individuals. The resurgence of cases has raised concerns about a second wave of infections, despite the country's previous success in reducing new cases. Authorities are taking swift action to contain the outbreak and prevent a second wave of infections.

images.alt_text: Workers wearing protective suits and masks spraying disinfectant in the Itaewon area of Seoul, on Monday.

site_title: Lian Beng bags S$174m deal to build Sims Drive condo
summary: Lian Beng Group won a S$174 million contract to build a 566-unit private-home project in Sims Drive, Singapore, with a 36-month completion period. The project, valued at S$383.5 million, will be built on government land sold by City Developments Ltd and Hong Leong Holdings. The contract is expected to have a positive impact on Lian Beng's financials, with the company's order book reaching S$1.7 billion.

site_title: Sembcorp unit signs power purchase agreement for Tengeh Reservoir solar farm project
summary: Sembcorp Industries, a utilities group, has signed a 25-year power purchase agreement for its 60 megawatt-peak floating solar farm project on Tengeh Reservoir in Singapore. The project, set to be operational by 2021, will meet the energy needs of PUB's five local waterworks and make all of Singapore's waterworks renewable-powered. The agreement is not expected to impact Sembcorp's earnings and net asset value.

site_title: US: Wall St falls on fears of new infection wave
summary: US stocks fell on Monday due to concerns over a potential second wave of coronavirus infections as economies reopen. The Dow Jones Industrial Average, S&P 500, and Nasdaq Composite opened lower, with the Dow down 0.31%, S&P 500 down 0.49%, and Nasdaq down 0.73%. Investors are worried about the impact of reopening on public health and the economy.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks start week with gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 1.53% on Monday, extending last week's advance as countries reopen their economies. The Hang Seng Index closed at 24,602.06, while the Shanghai Composite Index remained flat. This trend is attributed to slowing death rates and a recovery in economies from lockdowns.

site_title: Hyphens Pharma to pay out FY2019 dividend on June 8; Q1 net profit up by 48.6%
summary: Hyphens Pharma International, a Catalist-listed healthcare-products group, will pay out its FY2019 dividend on June 8, with a payout of S$0.01 per share. The company's Q1 net profit surged 48.6% year-over-year to S$2.12 million, driven by a 16.4% increase in revenue to S$31.4 million. The dividend payout was previously scheduled for the annual general meeting, which was delayed due to the coronavirus pandemic.

site_title: India startups get creative amid funding crunch
summary: India's startup ecosystem is facing a severe funding crunch due to the COVID-19 pandemic and global economic slowdown. Venture capital and private equity investment is expected to fall by 45-60% this year, leaving many startups struggling to stay afloat. To cope, Indian startups are considering alternative revenue streams, such as offering virtual services, reducing costs, and focusing on profitability. The funding freeze has also led to a shift in priorities, with investors advising startups to prioritize reducing cash burn and exploring new business models to survive.

site_title: Sakae Holdings to get some S$3.21m from troubled liquidated associate
summary: Sakae Holdings, a restaurant operator, will receive a net return of S$3.21 million from the liquidation of its associate Griffin Real Estate Investment Holdings. The High Court approved the partial return of capital to shareholders after Griffin was ordered to be liquidated in 2017 due to a legal dispute. Griffin had invested in properties such as the Bugis Cube shopping mall. The decision marks a significant development for Sakae, which will continue to update shareholders on material developments.

site_title: UK's plan to ease lockdown mired in confusion
summary: UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson unveiled a cautious plan to ease the coronavirus lockdown, advising people to wear homemade face coverings. The move was met with confusion, with many questioning the timing and effectiveness of the plan. The UK has the world's second-highest official Covid-19 death toll, and Johnson is wary of triggering a second deadly wave of infection. The plan is part of a broader effort to get Britain back to work, but it comes as the UK economy shrinks for the second month in a row, adding to the challenges faced by the government.

images.alt_text: "This is not the time simply to end the lockdown this week," Mr Johnson said, while unveiling a "conditional plan" to gradually ease the measures in England.

site_title: 68-year-old Singaporean man dies from Covid-19; death toll now at 21
