summary: A 68-year-old Singaporean man with a history of hypertension and hyperlipidaemia died from Covid-19 complications, bringing Singapore's death toll to 21. A 53-year-old Indian national also died after testing positive, with his death classified as coronary thrombosis. Singapore reported one of its lowest daily increases in new infections, with 1,000 cases in the past week, partly due to fewer tests being processed. The country's total count is now 23,787, the highest in South-east Asia, with three new clusters announced.

site_title: Singapore shares drift up, confusion over SIA value
summary: Singapore shares rose 0.75% on Monday, mirroring US market gains, as countries reopen their economies. The Straits Times Index closed at 2,611.31, with 1.42 billion securities worth S$1.20 billion changing hands. Brokers reported confusion over Singapore Airlines' (SIA) mandatory convertible bonds, with some waiting to sell their rights. SIA raised S$11.3 billion through its rights issue and MCBs. Experts warned of uncertainty and risks from the COVID-19 pandemic and US-China tensions in the coming weeks.

site_title: Clearbridge Health to distribute Biolidics spin-off's coronavirus test kits regionally
summary: Clearbridge Health, a controlling shareholder of Biolidics, has agreed to distribute the company's coronavirus antibody test kits regionally in the Philippines, Indonesia, Myanmar, and Vietnam. The distribution deal, which will last for a year, is expected to positively impact Clearbridge's revenue. However, the board warns it cannot quantify the financial impact due to uncertain demand. Regulatory approvals from local authorities are also required for the import and sale of the test kits in these markets.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Airbnb laid off at least 38 employees in Singapore as part of global retrenchment. The Singapore Exchange (SGX) will drop its minimum trading price rule starting June 1, but tighten financial watch-list criteria. Market turnover value of ETFs doubled to S$469m in April. Lippo Malls Indonesia Retail Trust is reviewing deferring a perp coupon in June due to cash-flow uncertainty. DBS Bank joined blockchain trade-finance network Contour. Biotech startup Hummingbird raised US$6m in extended Series B funding. Singapore shares rose 0.75% in the STI index, while Vietnam was surprised by Trump's tariff announcement.

site_title: Kimly H1 net profit up by 5.3% to S$10.5m; group doubles down on food stall ownership plans
summary: Kimly, a CATALIST-listed coffee shop operator, reported a 5.3% increase in net profit to S$10.5 million for the first half of the year, driven by revenue growth from new coffee shops and food stalls. Despite the COVID-19 pandemic, Kimly remains committed to long-term direct ownership of food outlets and has a S$55.8 million deal to buy a portfolio of eateries. The company expects to stay in the black for the year and has halved its proposed interim dividend.

site_title: Singapore reports 486 new Covid-19 cases; 68-year-old man is 21st death
summary: Singapore reported 486 new Covid-19 cases, bringing its total to 23,822, with a 68-year-old man becoming the 21st death. The country's death toll is classified according to the primary or underlying cause of death, with only cases where Covid-19 is attributed as the cause being added to the count. Cases have fallen below 1,000 in the past week, with fewer tests being processed due to equipment faults, and the number of local cases excluding dormitory residents continues to fall.

site_title: Medical tourism drop hits core of Thailand's Bumrungrad Hospital
summary: Bumrungrad Hospital, a major healthcare operator in Thailand, has seen a significant drop in medical tourists due to the coronavirus pandemic, with over 50% of its patients coming from overseas. The hospital has adapted by increasing telemedicine services and implementing new residence programs for quarantine and physical distancing. Thailand's borders remain mostly closed, leading to a 76% decline in foreign tourist arrivals in March and a projected 42% drop in arrivals for the full year. The hospital's shares have been downgraded by analysts, with some recommending a switch to local market-focused stocks.

site_title: F&N H1 net profit dips 2.7% to S$71.8 million
summary: F&N, a MAINBOARD-LISTED drinks maker, reported a 2.7% year-on-year dip in net profit to S$71.8 million for the six months to March 31, despite a 4.8% revenue rise. The company attributed the decline to finance costs for Starbucks Thailand investments. Despite this, F&N expects weaker consumer demand for beverages and dairies in the second half due to Covid-19's ongoing economic impact. The company plans to focus on execution of route-to-market initiatives and distribution growth. An interim dividend of 1.5 Singapore cents per share was proposed.

site_title: Wilmar Q1 net profit down 12.7% on investments, but coronavirus fuels consumer staples demand
summary: Wilmar International reported a 12.7% year-on-year decline in net profit to US$224.3 million in Q1 due to mark-to-market losses on investment securities. However, core net profit rose 22.5% to US$306.5 million driven by stronger consumer product sales and tropical oil downstream operations. The company remains on track to list its China business in the second half of the year, and is cautiously optimistic about its Q2 operations. Demand for consumer staples like rice and cooking oil surged during the pandemic, offsetting a decline in sales to hotel and food-processing industries.

site_title: China raps state miner Minmetals for renewed environmental failures
summary: China's Ministry of Ecology and Environment criticized state miner Minmetals Corp for environmental failures, citing over 120 penalties in 11 provinces since 2015. The report highlighted a lack of urgency and cooperation from subsidiaries, including rare earths unit Ganxian Hongjin Rare Earth Ltd Co, which was accused of environmental offenses. Minmetals has set energy-saving targets, but lacks specific implementation measures. The ministry's findings come as China aims to clean up its heavy industry sector, with Minmetals being one of two state-owned enterprises subject to a central government audit.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Monday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed higher on Monday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 5.38 points to 1,382.31. Volume reached 4.683 billion lots worth RM2.737 billion, with 540 gainers and 340 losers.

site_title: More than 2,000 Singapore SMEs, heartland retailers to benefit from new e-commerce solution
summary: A new mobile commerce solution will benefit over 2,000 Singapore SMEs, including heartland retailers, by helping them set up virtual stores and connect with customers. The initiative, developed by Nanyang Polytechnic, Nets, and SCash, aims to support SMEs affected by the Covid-19 pandemic. The solution allows customers to order through a URL or QR code at physical stores, and retailers can engage with customers through loyalty rewards and discount vouchers. Nets and SCash are waiving service fees, and a one-day workshop will be provided to help SMEs sustain their business operations.

site_title: Be your own spin class
summary: Indoor cycling enthusiasts are finding ways to replicate the spin class experience at home due to gym closures. Streaming live classes or using pre-recorded sessions on Peloton's website is a popular option. Alternatively, indoor cycling equipment such as bikes and apps can be used at home. Some people are also using bike rollers or indoor bike trainers to simulate a spinning class experience. Another option is to ride outdoors while following traffic laws and social distancing guidelines. Many spin classes can be adapted to an individual's fitness level and goals, allowing people to stay active and connected with others despite the pandemic.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets climb at open
summary: Europe's main stock markets rose at the start of trading on Monday, with the FTSE 100 index up 0.8% to 5,984.44 points, and the Paris CAC 40 index rising 0.2% to 4,560.51 points. Frankfurt's DAX 30 climbed 0.4% to 10,948.72 points, as Britain set out a path for easing its lockdown and eurozone nations lifted restrictions. The gains follow the long holiday weekend in the UK.

site_title: SGX to drop minimum trading price rule from June 1, but tightens financial watch-list criteria
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) will drop its minimum trading price rule for mainboard-listed companies on June 1, citing broad support from market participants. The rule, which required a six-month volume-weighted average share price of at least S$0.20 and average daily market value of at least S$40 million, will be scrapped. However, the SGX will tighten its financial watch-list criteria, requiring companies to maintain a six-month average daily market value and post no pre-tax losses for three consecutive years. Non-recurrent income and modified audit opinions will also no longer count towards profitability requirements.

site_title: Singapore Racecourse areas to serve as Covid-19 recovery facilities
summary: The Singapore Turf Club and the Tote Board are temporarily converting areas of the Singapore Racecourse at Kranji into community recovery facilities for foreign workers recovering from COVID-19. The facilities, expected to be completed by end-May, will house patients who are past the critical stage and unlikely to need further medical care. This is part of the government's efforts to curb the spread of the novel coronavirus, following the suspension of all race meetings until June 1.

site_title: Seoul: Shares end lower as exports drop, coronavirus cases rise
summary: South Korean shares ended lower on Monday, down 10.42 points or 0.54%, at 1,935.40, due to a decline in exports and rising coronavirus cases. The country reported 35 new cases, its highest in over a month, amid concerns about a second wave of the pandemic. Foreigners were net sellers of $115.61 million worth of shares. This marks the KOSPI's 11.93% decline so far this year.

site_title: Dozens of local food banks spring up in Thailand as virus hits incomes
summary: In Thailand, the COVID-19 pandemic has led to the creation of dozens of local food banks, with over 150 cabinets set up across 44 provinces. The initiative, inspired by a US-based model, aims to provide essential items such as instant noodles, canned food, rice, and soap to those struggling with income and food insecurity. The "Pantry of Sharing" project was initiated by Supakit Kulchartvijit, who recognized the crisis faced by many Thais due to the lockdown. The project's goal is to support those in need and promote community resilience.

images.alt_text: Villages and urban communities in Thailand have turned to helping neighbours left jobless due to the coronavirus lockdown by creating dozens of local food banks comprising instant noodles, canned food, rice grains and soap bars.

site_title: Australia: Shares rise as country's biggest state unveils reopening plan
summary: Australia's shares rose 1.3% on Monday, driven by a plan to gradually reopen New South Wales, the country's most populous state, after a weeks-long lockdown. The S&P/ASX 200 index reached 5,461.2 points, its third straight weekly gain. Financial stocks, including the "Big Four" banks, advanced, while export-oriented mining stocks and gold stocks also rose. The reopening plan, which includes the reopening of restaurants, playgrounds, and outdoor pools, boosted economic activity hopes.

site_title: Heathrow, easyJet want early exit from UK quarantine rules
summary: UK airlines easyJet and Heathrow Airport urge the government to reconsider its new 14-day quarantine rules for international air travel. The rules, set to prevent a second peak of the coronavirus pandemic, are expected to deter travel and further strain the aviation industry already reeling from the pandemic. easyJet calls for a short-lived quarantine, while Heathrow Airport advocates for a plan to reopen borders and implement common international standards for low-risk countries.

site_title: Indian travel agents squeezed as fliers demand cash refunds
summary: Indian travel agents are facing financial strain due to the coronavirus pandemic, with customers demanding cash refunds for flights that were cancelled or rescheduled. While airlines are required to repay passengers in cash, travel agents are only receiving virtual money from airlines to be used for future bookings, leaving them to dig into their own pockets to appease customers. The strain on the travel industry is exacerbating the damage caused by the pandemic, with thousands of jobs and billions of dollars in revenue at risk.

site_title: Money Hacks: How to invest in Reits through robo-advisors like Syfe (Ep 71)
summary: A podcast episode, "Money Hacks: How to invest in Reits through robo-advisors like Syfe", provides tips on investing in Real Estate Investment Trusts (Reits) for hassle-free property ownership. Host Chris Lim discusses basic starter tips, including understanding what Reits are, why they're a hassle-free investment, and the importance of diversifying a Reit portfolio. The episode also compares DIY Reit ETF investing with using Syfe's Reit+ portfolio, which can replicate the performance of a specific Reit index. The episode is intended for Singaporean investors only and advises consulting a financial adviser before making investment decisions.

site_title: US landlords, retailers play hardball as mall rent collections plunge
summary: US retailers, including Tapestry Inc, are negotiating lower rents with landlords amid declining mall rent collections due to the COVID-19 pandemic. Collecting only 15% of April rent, mall operators' collections are expected to worsen for May. Major retailers like Gap Inc and Coach are using their brands' power to draw in mall traffic as leverage, while some landlords are deferring rent payments. Experts warn that if rent payments don't improve, it could lead to store closures and a significant decline in the US retail landscape.

site_title: 486 new coronavirus cases, taking tally in Singapore to 23,822
summary: Singapore reported 486 new COVID-19 cases, bringing the total to 23,822. The cases include two Singaporeans and permanent residents, with migrant workers in dormitories making up the majority. The number of cases has been declining, with fewer tests being processed due to a lab recalibrating its apparatus. A recent imported case, a 61-year-old Singaporean man, was the first in over two weeks. Additionally, 33 previously reported cases were reclassified as false positives due to a calibration issue, and the lab has stopped all tests to rectify the situation.

site_title: Iran warship accidentally 'hit by missile' during exercises: state TV
summary: An Iranian warship, the Konarak vessel, was accidentally hit by a missile during naval exercises in the Gulf of Oman, killing one and injuring others, state TV reported. The incident occurred when the vessel moved a practice target to its destination without sufficient distance, state TV stated. The incident is under investigation.

site_title: Frozen fare cold comfort for fishing industry battered by coronavirus
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has severely impacted the global fishing industry, with lockdowns and social distancing measures forcing a shift from restaurants to supermarkets. Sales have plummeted, with demand at 10-20% of pre-pandemic levels. The US fishing industry is seeking $1 billion in aid, while China's aquaculture exports have fallen 21% due to the pandemic. Some depleted fish stocks may have a brief chance to recover, but the industry faces a long-term challenge to survive until demand returns or adapt to new tastes.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close higher on virus hopes in Japan
summary: Tokyo stocks rose on Monday, driven by expectations that Japan's government will lift a state of emergency in parts of the country later this week. The Nikkei 225 index gained 1.05% and the Topix index rose 1.53%. The positive sentiment was attributed to the potential lifting of the emergency, which has been in place since March.

site_title: Singapore seeks swab testers, blood takers as Covid-19 cases grow
summary: Singapore is increasing its COVID-19 testing capacity amid a surge in infections, aiming to conduct 40,000 tests daily, fivefold from 8,000. The government is seeking healthcare operations support staff, including those with no prior healthcare experience, to perform nasal swabs and blood tests. Over 11,000 have signed up for the "SG Healthcare Corps" program, with 800 already matched to roles. Officials emphasize selective testing, focusing on symptoms, close contacts, and quarantine efforts, with no plans for mass testing.

site_title: Cement maker LafargeHolcim's deal to sell Philippines business collapses
summary: LafargeHolcim's deal to sell its Philippines business valued at US$2.15 billion has collapsed after the country's competition authority failed to approve the sale on time. The Swiss cement maker had announced the sale in May 2019, but the Philippines Competition Authority did not issue an approval within the required timeframe. LafargeHolcim will now focus on strengthening its operations in the Philippines, which includes three of its four plants that had been shut down due to the coronavirus crisis.

site_title: Market turnover value of ETFs more than doubles to S$469m in April: SGX
summary: Market turnover value of exchange-traded funds (ETFs) on the Singapore bourse surged to S$469 million in April, more than doubling from the previous year, driven by strong investment interest and capital inflow to Asia. Total securities market turnover value rose 35% to S$29.6 billion, with equity index futures trading volume falling 25% to 12.3 million contracts. Foreign exchange futures trading volume increased 13% to 1.7 million contracts, while commodities derivatives volume declined 9% to 1.7 million contracts.

site_title: Indonesia drafts US$1b rescue plan to save flag carrier
summary: Indonesia is finalizing a $1 billion bailout plan for its flag carrier, Garuda Indonesia, to avoid a debt default due to the coronavirus crisis. The plan includes restructuring a $500 million sukuk and arranging new bridge loans of up to $500 million to meet working capital requirements. Garuda will propose an extension of the sukuk's maturity by three years or a staggered repayment to investors on May 18. The airline had asked bondholders to begin talks with its financial adviser due to the "extremely challenging environment for airlines" following the virus outbreak.

site_title: Lippo Malls Indonesia Retail Trust 'reviewing' if it should defer perp coupon in June
summary: Lippo Malls Indonesia Retail Trust (LMIRT) is reviewing whether to defer a distribution to perpetual securities holders on June 19, citing uncertainty over cash flow due to the COVID-19 pandemic. The trust has not accrued distributions to perpetual holders, contrary to its previous practice, and may need to cut equity dividends until distributions resume. A "dividend stopper" clause in the trust's contract would prevent it from declaring dividends to unitholders in August if it fails to pay perpetual holders in June.

site_title: China stainless steel hits nine-month high as domestic demand recovers
summary: Chinese stainless steel futures surged 4.0% to a nine-month high of 13,675 yuan (S$2,730.18) a tonne on the Shanghai Futures Exchange, driven by improving domestic demand after coronavirus-related shutdowns. Analysts attribute the surge to strong purchasing demand from downstream sectors. The move marks the highest level since August 1, 2020.

images.alt_text: Chinese stainless steel futures surged on Monday, hitting their highest level in over nine months as domestic demand continued to pick up after coronavirus-related shutdowns.

site_title: 'Hidden' defaults set to soar as recession squeezes firms
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic and low oil prices are prompting indebted companies to pursue "hidden" defaults, known as distressed debt exchanges, to overcome liquidity problems. Rating firms predict an increase in such exchanges, which can result in losses for creditors and are often counted as defaults. Moody's forecasts a rise in distressed exchanges, and experts estimate that up to 40% of them end in bankruptcy within three years. Investors may agree to these exchanges to avoid immediate liquidation, but ultimately, the company benefits at the expense of the investor.

site_title: Commodities trader Phoenix goes into liquidation due to coronavirus: documents
summary: Phoenix Commodities Pvt Ltd, a trader of agricultural products, is being liquidated due to over US$400 million in potential trading losses. The company, founded 20 years ago, grew into a US$3 billion revenue generator before the coronavirus outbreak caused financial market volatility. The liquidation process was triggered by currency fluctuations affecting financial derivatives linked to the US dollar and other currencies. The company's holding company is based in the British Virgin Islands, and a meeting with creditors has been scheduled. The business employed over 2,500 employees globally.

site_title: Broker's take: KGI resumes coverage on FCT with 'outperform' call
summary: KGI Securities has resumed its coverage on Frasers Centrepoint Trust (FCT) with an "outperform" call and a target price of S$2.39. Analyst Joel Ng expects FCT's suburban malls to recover faster than peers due to natural catchment of foot traffic. The retail Reit's conservative gearing ratio and significant debt headroom provide growth opportunities. KGI forecasts FCT's distribution per unit to fall 17% in FY2020 but rise 15% in FY2021 and recover to above 12 cents in FY2022.

site_title: Biotech startup Hummingbird raises extra US$6m in extended Series B funding
summary: Singapore-based biotech startup Hummingbird Bioscience has raised an additional US$6 million in its extended Series B funding round, bringing the total to US$25 million. The new round was co-led by Mirae Asset Venture Investment and GNTech Venture Capital, with participation from existing shareholders. The funds will be used to accelerate the development of new candidates into clinical trials and strengthen research capabilities. Regulatory submissions for Phase 1 studies of its lead candidates are expected in the second half of 2020.

site_title: Singapore hawker won't let virus write 'tragic' end to family business
summary: Singaporean noodle stall owner Kristen Choong is battling a 90% drop in business due to the COVID-19 pandemic. Despite this, she is working to reassure customers that the stall will survive. Choong's family business, Ji Ji Noodle House, has been a staple for decades, and she is determined to keep it going, saying it would be "tragic" if it were to close.

site_title: Shanghai Disneyland reopens after three-month coronavirus closure
summary: Shanghai Disneyland reopened on May 11, 2020, after a three-month coronavirus closure, marking the first of Disney's six main resorts to do so. The park welcomed a limited number of visitors who underwent temperature checks and showed a government QR code. Measures included increased sanitization, limited character interactions, and social distancing reminders. Despite concerns, tickets sold out within minutes, with the park's senior vice president stating that "vast majority" of attractions were open and more to be added. This reopening comes as China moves towards normality and Disney seeks to mitigate pandemic losses.

site_title: Masks and no touching: Indonesia aims to keep traditional markets alive
summary: Indonesia's Salatiga market has implemented social distancing measures, requiring vendors and visitors to wear masks and maintain at least 3.3 feet of distance to combat the spread of COVID-19. The market, with 857 vendors, has moved outdoors with stalls set apart to mitigate the virus. Authorities expect cases to peak in late May and taper off if the country avoids a second wave. This approach is part of Indonesia's strategy to safely maintain traditional markets, which are essential to the country's economy and social fabric.

site_title: China's April passenger car retail sales down 5.6% y-o-y: industry body
summary: China's passenger car retail sales in April dropped 5.6% year-over-year to 1.43 million, according to the China Passenger Car Association. The decline is attributed to the country's gradual recovery from the coronavirus. However, the association noted that the overall sales trend is showing a quick recovery.

site_title: JPMorgan sees cemented online habits doubling Asian tech stocks
summary: JPMorgan Asset Management predicts Asian tech stocks could double in value in 3-5 years due to the pandemic's acceleration of online habits. The fund has invested in companies like Alibaba, Tencent, and JD.com, expecting 15-25% annualized returns. JPMorgan believes technology trends have been accelerated, and digital products will gain market share faster than traditional banks and insurers. However, the fund manager notes risks from coronavirus infections and escalating US-China trade tensions.

site_title: Saudi Arabia triples VAT, halts government handouts in austerity drive
summary: Saudi Arabia has introduced new austerity measures to address its economic slump, triggered by the coronavirus and low oil prices. The country will triple its Value Added Tax (VAT) from 5% to 15% and halt monthly handout payments to citizens, starting from June 2020. The move aims to reduce a huge budget deficit, with the government expecting to lose half of its oil income. This decision comes after the International Monetary Fund projected a 2.3% contraction of the Saudi economy this year. The government plans to borrow $60 billion to plug the deficit.

site_title: Stocks to watch: IHH, Venture, SIAEC, FHT, Tuan Sing, Boustead Projects, HC Surgical
summary: Key developments in Singapore stocks on Monday include: IHH Healthcare's CEO Kelvin Loh expressing confidence in the group's ability to handle the Covid-19 pandemic, Venture Corporation's net profit shrinking 33% year-over-year, and SIA Engineering Company's Q4 net profit rising 5.9% year-over-year. Other companies, including Frasers Hospitality Trust, Tuan Sing Holdings, Boustead Projects, and HC Surgical Specialists, reported varying results due to the pandemic's impact on their businesses.

site_title: Oil stockpiles have stopped growing in the world's biggest buyer
summary: China's crude oil inventories have stopped growing after reaching record levels, according to satellite observations and analysts. Supplies have been drawn out of storage as refineries ramp up operations to meet rising demand from an emerging economy. Inventories dwindled in April despite increased oil imports, indicating rebalancing in the global oil market. Refineries are processing oil into gasoline and diesel, driven by traffic congestion in Chinese cities. This trend suggests the "great oil glut" of 2020 may have peaked, with analysts attributing the decline to strong refining activity.

site_title: Green revolution seen turning around Australia's steel industry
summary: Australia's steel industry is expected to turn around with the help of its abundant renewable energy resources. The Grattan Institute policy think tank suggests harnessing iron ore and producing "green steel" using hydrogen from wind and solar power. This could capture 6.5% of the global steel market, generating A$65 billion in annual export revenue and creating tens of thousands of jobs. The technology is still in its infancy, but efforts in Europe are advancing the cause, with demonstration projects led by Air Liquide, ThyssenKrupp, and Royal Dutch Shell.

site_title: Ikea to open third Singapore outlet at Jem in 2021
summary: Ikea to open its third Singapore outlet at Jem shopping centre in 2021, featuring a small-store concept with three floors and 6,500 sq meters of space. The store will offer the full Ikea product range and its restaurant, despite being smaller than its iconic warehouse-format blue buildings. The move aims to bring Ikea closer to millions of customers in Singapore, with the company seeing a bright future ahead for the new store.

site_title: China cut interest rates for standing lending facility loans in April
summary: China's central bank, the People's Bank of China (PBOC), cut interest rates on its standing lending facility (SLF) loans by 30 basis points in April, bringing borrowing costs to 3.05%, 3.2%, and 3.55% for overnight, seven-day, and one-month loans, respectively. This move aims to boost financial system liquidity and lower financing costs amid the coronavirus-hit economy. The PBOC has been rolling out measures to support the economy, including cutting key policy rates and reducing reserve requirements.

site_title: China's ground zero reports virus infections
summary: China reported new cases of coronavirus in Wuhan, the city where the virus first emerged, after a month without new infections. Authorities acknowledged one person tested positive on Sunday and five more cases were reported on Monday, all linked to a residential compound in Wuhan. This development comes as the US and Europe ease restrictions, sparking concerns of a potential second wave of infections. Health experts warn that too hasty a return to normal could lead to a resurgence, emphasizing the need for continued restrictions until a vaccine is available.

site_title: Tencent's US$40b gain masks a deeper long-term threat
summary: Tencent Holdings, the Chinese tech giant, is expected to report an 18% revenue rise in the first quarter, despite the COVID-19 pandemic. The company's dominance in online spheres has helped it weather the crisis, but analysts warn of a growing threat from rivals such as Alibaba Group and ByteDance. ByteDance is expanding its gaming division and social platforms, while Alibaba is developing its own lite-app universe. Tencent is looking to overseas growth and new markets to boost revenue, but faces challenges from its aging games and declining offline payments.

site_title: Hong Kong leader vows education overhaul after protests
summary: Hong Kong's Chief Executive Carrie Lam has vowed to overhaul the city's education system, citing the liberal studies curriculum as a contributing factor to last year's violent pro-democracy protests. She described the current curriculum as a "chicken coop without a roof" and promised to introduce clearer guidelines within the year. The move is seen as a response to Beijing's push for stricter control over Hong Kong, with the city facing rising tensions and opposition to laws outlawing insulting China's national anthem and anti-sedition legislation.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong's pro-Beijing leader on Monday vowed to overhaul the city's education system, arguing its liberal studies curriculum helped fuel last year's violent pro-democracy protests.

site_title: How to build agile, resilient supply chains against global disruptions
summary: Global supply chains face disruptions due to the COVID-19 pandemic, labor restrictions, and fluctuating consumer demand. Manufacturers in Southeast Asia, a key manufacturing hub, rely heavily on China for intermediary products, exacerbating the impact. To build resilient supply chains, organizations must develop an effective response within two weeks, mobilize a crisis task force to identify critical components and gaps, and reassess demand forecasts and transportation restrictions. This requires scenario planning, risk intelligence monitoring, and investment in digital twin technology, advanced analytics, and early warning systems. Organizations must prioritize building supply chain resiliency today to mitigate future disruptions.

site_title: From coffee filter to safety mask, in a hurry
summary: German company Melitta, known for coffee filters, has produced over 10 million face masks in just a month, meeting Germany's need for quality masks during the coronavirus pandemic. The company's expertise in producing microfibre filters, which filter small particles, has enabled it to meet the demand. Melitta's masks have a high bacterial filtration efficiency of above 98% and are made from a triple layer of melt-blown and spun-blown microfibre. The company plans to supply these masks to hospitals and eventually sell them to the broader market, aiming to compete with masks produced in Asia.

site_title: Asia: Stocks rally as restrictions are eased and death rates drop
summary: Asian stocks rallied on Monday as governments eased virus lockdown measures and death rates fell in some countries, with traders focusing on the improving economic outlook. Official job losses in April showed a slight drop, and Wall Street ended a healthy week with strong gains. However, concerns of a second wave hitting South Korea and China, as well as the uncertainty of how quickly economies can bounce back, tempered the optimism.

site_title: Japan appoints first female central bank executive director
summary: Japan's central bank, the Bank of Japan, appointed its first female executive director, Tokiko Shimizu, in a personnel reshuffle on Monday. Shimizu, 55, a career central banker, will oversee international affairs, potentially influencing monetary policy decisions. The move aims to diversify management and follows a trend where 47% of BOJ staff are women, but only 13% of senior managerial posts are held by women. The appointment is seen as a step towards promoting more women in key roles within the institution.

images.alt_text: Japan's central bank saw some sweeping changes in a personnel reshuffle on Monday, including the appointment of its first female executive director in the male-dominated institution.

site_title: US adds 776 coronavirus deaths in 24 hours: tracker
summary: The US reported 776 coronavirus deaths in the past 24 hours, bringing the total to 79,522, according to Johns Hopkins University. This marks the lowest daily tally since March. The country has also confirmed 1,329,072 cases.

images.alt_text: THE United States recorded 776 coronavirus deaths in the past 24 hours, bringing the total to 79,522, according to the real-time tally by Johns Hopkins University at 8.30pm Sunday (0030 GMT Monday).

site_title: Nightlife cluster gives South Korea largest case rise in a month
summary: South Korea reported its highest number of new coronavirus cases in over a month, driven by a cluster in a Seoul nightlife district, as the country loosens restrictions. The capital, Gyeonggi province, and Incheon city ordered the closure of clubs and bars after a surge in cases. This comes as Europe re-opens cautiously, with health experts warning of a surge in infections if restrictions are lifted too quickly.

site_title: Collapse in rubber prices drags Halcyon Agri into the red for Q1
summary: Halcyon Agri Corporation reported a core operating loss of US$2.6 million for the first quarter ended March 31, 2020, reversing from a core operating profit of US$5.6 million last year. The company attributed the loss to a collapse in rubber prices, which fell from US$1,450 to US$1,038, and a reduction in unit gross margin to US$103 per tonne. The lower earnings were due to the company's strategy to reduce natural rubber production during the Q1 wintering season.

site_title: With prices down and jobs leaving, US oil workers learn patience
summary: Oil workers in Carlsbad, New Mexico, face a dilemma as prices drop and jobs leave. Despite exceptionally high salaries, many have lost their jobs or seen their hours cut due to the collapse in demand caused by the coronavirus pandemic. Thousands of workers live in "man camps" and pay $600-$900 per month for a spot to park their camper and pickup truck. The region's economy is not immune to fluctuations, with prices falling before in 2016 and again in the current downturn, leaving workers anxious about their future.

site_title: HK's Goldin Financial sells residential land at loss citing market outlook concern
summary: Hong Kong's Goldin Financial Holdings Ltd sold a residential land parcel at a loss of HK$2.6 billion (S$473 million), citing an uncertain property market amid economic downturn. The firm had bought the land in 2018 for HK$8.9 billion. The sale, which was agreed with Top Family Group, is unusual and marks the second time in a year Goldin has dropped a land purchase deal due to economic concerns. The move aims to reduce debt and retain cash for the group's existing business.

site_title: Qantas pauses plane deliveries from Airbus, Boeing due to virus
summary: Qantas has paused deliveries from Airbus and Boeing due to the coronavirus pandemic, citing uncertainty in the market. The airline had expected to add new planes to its fleet by the end of 2020, but now does not expect to take delivery in the near term. Qantas had planned to receive 18 Airbus A321neos and three Boeing 787-9 jets, but the pandemic has led to a significant decline in demand, with the airline flying only 5% of its pre-crisis domestic network and 1% of its pre-crisis international network.

site_title: New Zealand business confidence sees small bounce in May: ANZ survey
summary: New Zealand business confidence showed a small bounce in May, according to an ANZ Bank survey, with a net 45.6% of respondents expecting the economy to deteriorate over the year ahead. This represents a decrease from 66.6% in April. The number of respondents expecting weaker activity for their businesses also decreased, from 55.1% to 42.0%. Despite the slight improvement, levels of pessimism remain low due to coronavirus concerns.

site_title: Broker's take: DBS downgrades SingPost to 'fully valued', lowers FY21/22 forecast
summary: DBS Group Research downgraded SingPost to "fully valued" from "hold" with a revised target price of S$0.64, citing margin concerns due to an "accelerated decline" in domestic mail revenue. Analysts lowered earnings forecasts for FY2021 and FY2022 by 20% and 19% respectively, projecting a 13% drop in operating profit for FY2021 and 4% growth for FY2022. The downgrade comes amid the impact of the Covid-19 situation on SingPost's operating profit.

site_title: After the triumph of Animal Crossing, a thin pipeline for Nintendo
summary: Nintendo's Switch console lacks upcoming titles, overshadowed by the success of Animal Crossing: New Horizons. The company has refrained from outlining new releases since the COVID-19 outbreak, citing a conservative stance. Despite this, the Switch's growing back catalogue and strong sales of older titles like Legend of Zelda: Breath of the Wild contribute to Nintendo's financial stability. The company's shares fell 3.5% in early trading, while CEO Shuntaro Furukawa expects disruption to ease by summer, with 85% of fourth-quarter software sales being Nintendo-developed titles.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Monday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 5.38 points, or 0.39%, to 1,382.31 on Monday, driven by gains in the market. Volume reached 4.68 billion lots worth RM2.74 billion.

site_title: Earthquake hits off coast of eastern Japan, no tsunami warning
summary: An earthquake with a preliminary magnitude of 5.5 struck off the coast of eastern Japan on May 11, 2020, but no tsunami warning was issued. The epicenter was located off the coast of Ibaraki prefecture, approximately 50km deep. There were no immediate reports of damage or casualties.

site_title: Oil down in Asia after big gains last week
summary: Oil prices declined in Asian trade on Monday, down 2.95% to US$24.01 a barrel for West Texas Intermediate and 2.26% to US$30.27 a barrel for Brent. The decline follows last week's 25% gain on reduced output cuts and easing of coronavirus lockdown measures. Analysts expect the decline to be limited, citing increasing supply cutbacks and improving macroeconomic conditions. The US shale oil industry has been impacted by lower prices, with drilling activity curtailed sharply.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares jump at Monday's open
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose at the open on Monday, with the Hang Seng Index increasing 0.99% to 24,470.18, following gains across Asia. This comes as some countries reported a slowdown in coronavirus deaths, boosting market sentiment. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also saw gains, rising 0.22% and 0.43% respectively. The rally is attributed to a decrease in coronavirus-related concerns and positive economic indicators.

site_title: Australian children slowly resume school as coronavirus curbs eased
summary: Australian children in New South Wales and Queensland states began returning to school on a limited basis, easing coronavirus curbs. The move aims to reduce the risk of spreading the illness. Schools in both states have received soap, hand sanitiser, and personal protective equipment. Temperature monitors are also in place to ensure student safety. The easing of restrictions follows a slowing rate of new infections in the country.

site_title: Quantum computing software startup Entropica raises S$2.6m
summary: Singapore-based startup Entropica Labs has raised S$2.6 million in seed funding led by Elev8 to expand its technical team and develop proprietary quantum computing software architectures. The funding will also give Entropica access to growing quantum computing systems, enabling it to tackle complex problems that conventional computers cannot solve. The company, co-founded by alumni of Singapore's Centre for Quantum Technologies, has partnered with leading quantum hardware manufacturers, including Rigetti Computing and IBM, to integrate its software with cloud quantum computing platforms.

site_title: New Zealand media giant makes one-dollar bid for rival
summary: New Zealand media giant NZME has made a symbolic NZ$1.00 takeover bid for rival Stuff Limited amid the coronavirus-induced downturn. The bid was swiftly rebuffed by Stuff's Australian owner, Nine Entertainment, which has terminated further engagement with NZME. NZME's proposed acquisition aims to consolidate the country's news industry, citing declining advertising revenue and economic conditions. The move follows similar attempts by NZME and Stuff to merge in 2017, which were rejected by the competition watchdog due to concerns about market dominance.

site_title: GrabFood bent on serving hawkers despite major barriers
summary: GrabFood Singapore aims to support local hawkers despite economic challenges. The platform plans to help hawkers digitalize their operations and maintain a diverse food selection during the Covid-19 pandemic. This move is seen as a way to preserve the unique aspect of Singapore's food scene. GrabFood's efforts aim to ensure users can access affordable food options online while supporting the local hawker community.

site_title: Indian startups get creative as coronavirus crisis fuels funding crunch
summary: India's startup ecosystem is facing a severe funding crunch due to the coronavirus crisis, with venture capital investments expected to fall by 45-60% this year. Many startups, which had received billions of dollars in funding last year, are now struggling to stay afloat. To survive, they are being forced to focus on profitability and reducing cash burn, with some considering new business models such as selling masks as a fashion accessory. The funding freeze has been compounded by India's move to scrutinize overseas investments and a slowdown in funding from major backers like SoftBank.

site_title: DBS Bank joins blockchain trade-finance network Contour
summary: DBS Bank has joined Contour's blockchain trade-finance network, becoming the first Singapore bank to do so. The network, built on R3's Corda, digitizes global trade processes such as letters of credit. Contour partners include BNP Paribas, Bangkok Bank, ING, HSBC, and Citi Ventures, ahead of its full launch later this year.

site_title: The billionaire poker club behind China's most indebted developer
summary: Billionaire Hui Ka Yan, the chairman of China Evergrande Group, is receiving financial support from fellow property tycoons, including Joseph Lau of Chinese Estates Holdings and Henry Cheng of New World Development Co, in a move known as the "Big Two Club" due to their frequent involvement in Chinese poker games. The Big Two Club members have invested billions of dollars in each other's companies over the past decade, including US$16 billion in transactions tracked by Bloomberg. Despite facing significant debt and economic challenges, Evergrande's chairman has attributed the company's recent stock slide to the economic fallout from the pandemic and "unfair" media coverage.

images.alt_text: AS billionaire Hui Ka Yan steers China's most indebted real estate company through the worst economic slump in decades, he's getting support from some familiar faces: his fellow property tycoons.

site_title: Cabs ferry US$300 steaks, boxes use plane seats in virus-hit Japan
summary: Japan's transport sector is finding novel ways to generate revenue amid the COVID-19 pandemic, including using taxi seats for delivery services and cargo space. Nihon Kotsu, Tokyo's largest taxi company, is delivering US$300 steaks from Wolfgang's Steakhouse, while ANA Holdings is transporting medical equipment and cargo to meet demand. The move aims to keep business activity going despite a decline in passenger traffic and reduced taxi revenue, with some restaurants seeing an increase in demand for high-end meals.

site_title: Virgin Atlantic to pitch to investors amid administration risks
summary: Virgin Atlantic Airways is pitching to potential investors as it seeks to avoid collapse amid the COVID-19 pandemic. The airline, founded by billionaire Richard Branson, has enough cash to survive through the summer but may need a £500 million state support bid to secure its viability. Virgin Atlantic has hired restructuring specialist Alvarez & Marsal to develop contingency plans, including a pre-pack administration, and will present its survival plans to 12 firms. The airline's CEO, Shai Weiss, is exploring all available options to obtain additional external funding, including loan guarantees and equity stakes.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on Monday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Monday, driven by expectations of a potential lift in Japan's state of emergency later this week. The Nikkei 225 index rose 0.67% to 20,313.97, while the Topix index gained 0.78% to 1,469.70. This follows a broader trend of gains across Asian markets, which have been boosted by optimism over economic recovery and US-EU trade talks.

site_title: Oil prices fall 1% as glut weighs
summary: Oil prices fell 1% due to a persistent glut and eroded global oil demand, despite some governments easing lockdowns. Brent crude dropped 29 cents to $30.68 a barrel, while US oil fell 26 cents to $24.48 a barrel. Global oil demand plummeted 30% due to the coronavirus pandemic. Analysts expect a severe shortage of storage capacity in North America, which may lead to a US oil shortage. However, some countries have eased restrictions, leading to modest increases in fuel demand.

site_title: Elite Commercial Reit posts Q1 DPU of 0.74 pence, 1.4% above forecast
summary: Elite Commercial Reit reported a Q1 distribution per unit (DPU) of 0.74 pence, 1.4% above its initial public offering (IPO) forecast. Revenue was £3.52 million, and net property income was £3.4 million. The Reit's assets remain well-capitalized, and it has received three months of advanced rent. The group's 97 assets are predominantly leased to the UK government, with 82.5% used by the Department for Work and Pensions. The Reit expects to provide a stable income to investors, unaffected by the COVID-19 situation. Units traded flat at 67.5 pence.

site_title: US Fed flying blind on economic outlook as businesses slowly reopen
summary: The US Federal Reserve is struggling to predict the economic outlook due to the ongoing coronavirus pandemic, making it difficult to decide on stronger forward guidance or asset purchases. Despite the Fed's efforts to ease the economic plight of millions of idle workers, forecasters face "enormous uncertainty" and policymakers are hesitant to form a clear outlook. The Fed will debate these options at its next meeting, with officials warning that the nation's slow reopening and potential second wave of infections could lead to a painful economic contraction.

site_title: Suncorp to take A$133m hit from coronavirus
summary: Australian insurer Suncorp Group expects to take a A$133 million hit from the coronavirus pandemic due to negative impacts on gross written premiums. The insurer has already provided discounts and premium waivers to 12,300 customers and approved A$4.05 billion in loan deferrals. Suncorp's 2020 group costs are estimated to be slightly above A$2.7 billion, including pay and leave entitlements remediation. The insurer will adopt a conservative mindset when making decisions about final dividend payouts.

site_title: New York leaders sounds alarm over potentially Covid-linked syndrome
summary: New York Mayor Bill de Blasio expressed concern over a pediatric syndrome linked to COVID-19, with 38 confirmed cases in NYC and 85 suspected statewide. The syndrome, similar to Kawasaki disease, causes fever, rash, and inflammation. At least five deaths have been linked to the syndrome, including a 5-year-old boy. Governor Andrew Cuomo announced new regulations for nursing homes and emphasized research into the Remdesivir drug therapy.

site_title: India to 'gradually' restart rail operations in lockdown easing
summary: India's Indian Railways will gradually restart passenger train operations on May 12, 2020, with 30 train journeys running from New Delhi to cities like Mumbai, Bangalore, and Chennai. Passengers must wear face masks and undergo screening. The move comes as India eases its coronavirus lockdown, with over 60,000 cases and 2,000 deaths reported. Special trains carrying migrants have already been operating since early May, with plans to increase services.

site_title: Singapore shares inch higher at Monday's open; STI up 0.2%
summary: Singapore shares opened slightly higher on Monday, with the Straits Times Index rising 5.7 points to 2,597.6, a 0.2% gain. The rally follows a positive US equities performance, which rebounded after a grim April jobs report. Gainers outnumbered losers 124 to 28, with about 81.1 million securities changing hands.

site_title: Global deaths from coronavirus pass 280,000
summary: Global coronavirus deaths surpass 280,000, with the majority in Europe and the US. Europe accounts for 156,095 deaths, followed by the US with 78,862. The top five countries are Britain (31,855), Italy (30,560), Spain (26,621), and France (26,380).

site_title: Ellipsiz unit in joint venture to offer temperature screening, facial recognition solutions
summary: Ellipsiz Distribution & Services Solutions (Ellipsiz DSS) has entered into a joint venture with Aitech Robotics and Automation to establish EllipTech Solutions, offering temperature screening, facial recognition, and security solutions. The JV aims to develop customized solutions for various sectors, addressing health and safety issues caused by the Covid-19 pandemic. Ellipsiz DSS holds a 50% stake in the JV, with Aitech also holding 50%. The subscription of shares was funded through Ellipsiz's internal resources, with no expected impact on earnings per share and net tangible assets.

site_title: BT BAF celebrates 15 years of transforming lives
summary: The Business Times Budding Artists Fund (BT BAF) celebrates its 15th anniversary, having served over 19,000 beneficiaries through arts programs at The Little Arts Academy and 10 Square Youth training centers. The fund has helped nurture Singapore's next generation of artists and creative professionals, with many alumni pursuing tertiary education and developing essential life skills. Despite the ongoing circuit breaker, 500 beneficiaries continue their lessons online, with some even sharing their knowledge with students at home.

site_title: HC Surgical forms litigation committee, shareholder plans to sue CEO
summary: HC Surgical Specialists (HCSS) has formed a litigation committee in response to allegations by minority shareholder Serene Tiong that CEO Heah Sieu Min breached his duties by acquiring a 19% stake in his private practice. HCSS believes the allegations are "frivolous" and "without merit." Tiong has given notice to apply to court under Section 216A of the Companies Act to bring an action against the CEO on behalf of the company. The matter is set to go to court, with the company's shares remaining flat at S$0.34.

site_title: Driving adoption of real-time payments in Asean
summary: Real-time payments in Asean are rapidly gaining adoption, driven by the region's young and connected population. Seven of the 10 countries in the grouping have introduced sophisticated real-time instant payment systems, with governments and financial regulators connecting these systems to enable seamless cross-border transactions. The integration of tokenisation and standardised QR codes is also enhancing the user experience. As the demand for cross-border instant payments grows, interoperability between domestic real-time payment systems is crucial to create a fully digital payment experience for consumers, with the potential to enable seamless payments across borders in the next few years.

site_title: Colombian airline Avianca files for Chapter 11 bankruptcy in US
summary: Avianca, the second-largest airline in Latin America, filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy in the US due to the unpredictable impact of the coronavirus pandemic. The airline's operations have been dramatically affected, with a 80% reduction in consolidated income and significant pressure on liquidity. Avianca temporarily suspended all passenger operations and asked the New York court for authorization to fulfill work commitments and maintain employee compensation. The company aims to reorganize its debt and restructure its operations, which has been heavily impacted by the pandemic.

site_title: Europe ready to ease virus lockdowns but UK wary
summary: European countries are easing lockdowns, with France and Spain allowing people to meet outside and shops to reopen. However, the UK, citing fears of a second wave, has delayed its lockdown easing, with Prime Minister Boris Johnson saying it's "madness" to move too soon. Despite this, other countries such as Iran and Turkey have relaxed restrictions, while the US continues to struggle with high infection rates, with over 10,000 deaths reported. The easing of lockdowns is seen as a crucial step towards reopening economies, but concerns about a second wave of the pandemic persist.

images.alt_text: Britain extended a national lockdown to at least June 1 on Sunday rather than following European neighbours France and Spain, where millions of people are counting down the hours to a relaxation of the stay at home rules.

site_title: Technology to help foreign workers in dorms monitor health: Josephine Teo
summary: The Singapore government has launched a telemedicine system to help foreign workers in dorms monitor their health, with about 8,000 pulse oximeters distributed so far. The system includes tele-consultation services through mobile phones, allowing workers to consult doctors remotely. A medical post facility at JTC Space @ Tuas will provide on-site medical care, and swab isolation facilities are available for those awaiting test results. The move aims to strengthen health monitoring and surveillance in dormitories to facilitate workers' recovery and eventual return to work.

site_title: Riot police chase Hong Kong Mother's Day protesters
summary: Riot police in Hong Kong chased protesters through shopping malls and streets on Mother's Day, as democracy activists demanded independence and leader Carrie Lam's resignation. Small flash mob rallies broke out in at least eight malls, prompting arrests and on-the-spot fines for those allegedly breaching virus measures. The protests, which had been largely absent since the pandemic, signal a resurgence of pro-democracy movement in the city. Authorities have responded with force, sparking concerns about the city's fragile social stability.

site_title: Gold likely to reach US$1,800
summary: Gold prices are expected to reach US$1,800 due to the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic, which has led to widespread lockdowns and economic disruption. The US reported 3.1 million jobless claims in May, highlighting the struggling economy. Investors are seeking safe-haven assets, driving gold prices upward.

site_title: Dubai Reit says irregular trading caused plunge in share price
summary: Dubai-based Emirates Reit reported irregular trading activity contributing to its low share price, trading at US$0.20 per share compared to a NAV of US$1.57. The company found evidence of potentially abusive market practices and reported it to regulatory authorities. The downturn in the UAE real estate sector and investor sentiment also affected the trust value. Emirates Reit is evaluating options to increase share liquidity and considering buying back sukuk to improve its balance sheet. The company holds US$44 million in cash and plans to report revenues and NAV quarterly.

site_title: Covid-19 impact 'largely confined' to hospitality ops: Tuan Sing
summary: Singapore property developer Tuan Sing Holdings reported that the impact of the Covid-19 outbreak on its business operations is "largely confined" to its hospitality segment, which accounts for less than 15% of its asset portfolio. The company's diversified portfolio across segments and regions has ensured a "high degree of resilience."

site_title: UK unveils phased plan to exit lockdown
summary: British Prime Minister Boris Johnson announced a phased plan to ease the nationwide coronavirus lockdown, starting with schools and shops reopening from June 1, as long as infection rates stay low. The plan includes unlimited outdoor exercise, nurseries and children up to 11 returning to school by June 1, and some non-essential shops reopening. However, pubs are unlikely to reopen until months later, and older school children may not return to classes until September. The government will closely monitor infection rates and introduce quarantine for people arriving in Britain by air if necessary.

images.alt_text: BRITISH Prime Minister Boris Johnson on Sunday announced a phased plan to ease a nationwide coronavirus lockdown, with schools and shops to begin opening from June 1 - as long as infection rates stay low.

site_title: Money FM podcast: MaritimeSG Together Package
summary: The Money FM podcast "MaritimeSG Together Package" discussed the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on the global economy, including a potential slowdown in China's GDP growth. Meanwhile, the US raised tariffs on Asian garments, and Citigroup predicted a target of 1,150 for MSCI's global equity index by mid-2026. In other news, Malaysia seized assets worth RM3 billion from Daim Zainuddin, and the Thai court is expected to clear Thaksin Shinawatra's daughter of ethics charges. The UK economy shrank for the second month, and ASEAN agreed that the Myanmar election is not a priority.

site_title: Is GrabFood Singapore chasing a pipe dream?
summary: GrabFood Singapore faces challenges in finding an optimized food delivery business model due to high operating costs and strong competition. The company's top executive, Dilip Roussenaly, acknowledges the need for a sustainable model but emphasizes the complexity of balancing consumer, delivery partner, and merchant needs. Despite efforts to increase efficiency and scale, the company's food delivery segment continues to struggle, with logistics player Lalamove and restaurant booking app Chope emerging as new competitors. GrabFood's ability to turn a profit remains uncertain, with venture capital-backed players continuing to experiment in search of a "sweet spot."

site_title: Uplifting governance of private companies
summary: Singapore's private companies face scrutiny over lack of accountability and transparency, with a rise in corporate failures and insolvencies. The number of private companies has grown, but many lack basic reporting and audit requirements. A similar code to the UK's Wates Principles could help increase accountability and confidence among stakeholders. The Singapore government has introduced legislation requiring larger private companies to publish corporate governance statements, but more needs to be done to address the issue.

site_title: Malaysia's conditional movement control order extended for another four weeks to June 9
summary: Malaysia's Prime Minister Muhyiddin Yassin extended the country's conditional stay-at-home order by four weeks to June 9, citing the ongoing fight against COVID-19. New cases are lower, but the government advises caution, warning that the risk of infection is higher as more people return to work. Social distancing measures and mask-wearing are still mandatory, and large gatherings remain banned. The country's recovery rate stands at 74.8% of confirmed cases, with 108 deaths reported.

site_title: Carlyle, GIC backing out of American Express deal
summary: The Carlyle Group and Singapore's Government Investment Corporation (GIC) are backing out of a deal to buy a 20% stake in American Express Global Business Travel. The deal, valued at $5 billion, was set to close last week but failed to reach an agreement on terms. The parties had agreed to purchase a 20% stake and American Express would retain 50% ownership. The decision comes as the global pandemic has hit the travel industry hard, affecting the deal's viability. The exact reasons for the withdrawal are not specified.

site_title: China regulator issues rules on online bank lending to curb risks
summary: China's banking and insurance regulator has issued draft rules to curb risks in online bank lending. The rules ban online loans from being used for riskier investments and cap consumer credit lines at 200,000 yuan. The move aims to protect borrowers' interests, rectify misuse of credit, and prevent rapidly expanding household debt. The regulator also tightened regulations on co-lending between banks and micro lenders, and banned co-lending with unlicensed institutions. The rules are expected to help rein in financial risks in banks' online lending business.

site_title: Higher forced liquidations this year, with pandemic yet to do its worst
summary: Singapore saw a 51% increase in compulsory liquidations in the first four months of 2020, with 102 companies forced to wind up compared to 67 in the same period last year. Observers expect the numbers to rise further in the third quarter as subsidies and legal reprieve expire. The hardest-hit sectors include commodities, construction, and retail, highlighting the pandemic's ongoing impact on the global economy.

site_title: Swiss National Bank battling enormous pressure on safe-haven franc
summary: The Swiss National Bank (SNB) is maintaining its ultra-expansive monetary policy due to the coronavirus crisis, which has led to enormous appreciation pressure on the safe-haven Swiss franc. Chairman Thomas Jordan said the SNB has no choice but to keep negative interest rates, currently at -0.75%, to avert major damage to Switzerland's economy. The SNB is also stepping up foreign currency purchases to dampen the franc's rise, and sight deposits have risen by nearly 77 billion Swiss francs this year. The goal is to prevent the franc from strengthening, hurting Switzerland's export-orientated economy and triggering deflation.

site_title: Emirates Group profit drops 28% on Covid-19
summary: Emirates Group reported a 28% decline in full-year profit to 1.7 billion dirhams due to the impact of the Covid-19 pandemic. Revenue dropped to 104 billion dirhams, impacted by the Dubai International airport runway closure in the first quarter and the pandemic in the fourth quarter. The airline's net income was down from 2.3 billion dirhams the previous year. The decline was largely attributed to the Covid-19 pandemic's effect on the airline's operations and revenue.

site_title: 32 companies return Jobs Support Scheme payouts worth S$35m
summary: Thirty-two Singaporean companies have returned or donated their Jobs Support Scheme payouts worth S$35 million, as a form of solidarity with the local community amid the Covid-19 outbreak. The companies, including multinational corporations and financial institutions, pledged to redirect their payouts to approved institutions of public character or the Singapore government for causes that benefit the local community. Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat expressed his support for these actions, noting that they demonstrate the "SG Together spirit" of stepping forward and overcoming challenges together.

site_title: Optimism holding up despite dismal US jobs data
summary: US stocks rose despite a record 14.7% unemployment rate in April, with the Dow Jones climbing 1.91% and the S&P 500 Index rising 1.69%. However, economists warn that optimism may be short-lived due to weak fundamentals and a reliance on "flimsy" confidence. The US government is intensifying efforts to prop up the economy, including the Paycheck Protection Program, which has approved $187.1 billion of the $310 billion available. Market watchers expect the program to need adjustments, and the US Treasury Department's announcement of $20 billion in 20-year Treasuries is seen as supportive of the US dollar.

site_title: 'Hidden' defaults set to soar as recession squeezes companies
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic and low oil prices are prompting indebted companies to default on their debts through "hidden" distressed debt exchanges, where they swap or buy back debt at steep discounts. Moody's Investors Service predicts an increase in such exchanges, which often result in losses for creditors. Experts estimate that up to 40% of distressed exchanges end in bankruptcy within three years, with the practice being more common during economic downturns, such as the global financial crisis.

site_title: Showing care and concern
summary: Employers can best support their staff's mental well-being, especially in a crisis, by taking a compassionate approach that prioritizes communication, inclusivity, and employee empowerment. Key strategies include: (1) amplifying two-way communications and support, (2) providing resources and benefits for mental health, (3) fostering an environment where employees feel safe discussing their mental health, and (4) encouraging self-care and work-life balance. Companies can also demonstrate responsible leadership by being transparent, empathetic, and actively engaged with their employees, and by providing opportunities for social connections and community building.

site_title: Malaysia's conditional movement control order extended to June 9
summary: Malaysia's Prime Minister Muhyiddin Yassin has extended the country's conditional stay-at-home order until June 9, four weeks after the previous deadline. The order, which was first imposed on March 18, aims to combat the spread of COVID-19, with schools and non-essential businesses remaining shut. While new cases have decreased, the Prime Minister warned that the fight is not yet over, and restrictions on travel and large gatherings will remain in place.

site_title: Google affiliate axes plans for futuristic community
summary: Google affiliate Sidewalk Labs has abandoned plans to build a futuristic community in Toronto, citing economic uncertainty. The project, which aimed to create a carbon-neutral community with robots for delivering mail and collecting garbage, had received a provisional green light in 2019. CEO Dan Doctoroff cited the economic uncertainty as the reason for abandoning the project, stating that it was no longer financially viable without sacrificing core parts of the plan. The project's conceptual innovations will still be considered a meaningful contribution to tackling big urban problems.

site_title: Shortened trading week; AGMs, earnings in focus
summary: The Straits Times Index declined 1.2% over a shortened trading week, bringing its 2020 total return to 19.1%. Nine primary-listed stocks conducted share buybacks totaling S$1.5 million, with Singapore Press Holdings, Global Investments, and Hong Fok Corporation leading the consideration tally.

site_title: Healthcare giant IHH remains in good health despite pandemic
summary: Healthcare giant IHH remains financially stable despite the pandemic, with CEO Kelvin Loh stating the business will recover from short-term setbacks. The company faces challenges from reduced medical tourism, overcapacity, and lower volumes due to travel bans and lockdowns. However, Loh is optimistic, saying the business remains resilient and is actively seeking opportunities to grow.

images.alt_text: According to Dr Loh, IHH is aiming to double return on equity (ROE) in five years. In 2019, the group's ROE stood at 2.5 per cent from 2.9 per cent in 2018.

site_title: China extends anti-dumping duties on US, EU steel tubes and pipes for 5 years
summary: China has extended anti-dumping duties on US and EU steel tubes and pipes for five years, starting May 10. Duties of 101.0% to 147.8% for US companies and 57.9% to 60.8% for European firms remain in place. The decision is part of a final review of anti-dumping duties that had been in place since 2014. The move aims to protect China's domestic steel industry from unfair imports.

site_title: Global virus cases top 4 million
summary: The number of coronavirus cases worldwide surpassed 4 million, with some countries readying to lift lockdown restrictions despite concerns about a second wave of infections. Hard-hit countries like France, Spain, Belgium, and Germany are easing restrictions, while others, such as South Korea, are taking stricter measures. The US and Australia are also moving forward with reopening plans, with the global death toll nearing 277,000. Economies are facing historic downturns, with millions unemployed, and policymakers scramble to balance relief with preventing a second wave of infections.

site_title: US dollar gains against euro, other currencies, after US jobs report
summary: The US dollar strengthened against major currencies, including the euro and Swiss franc, after a weaker-than-expected jobs report in April. The dollar rose 0.4% against the yen and posted its largest weekly gain versus the euro in over a month. Despite a 20.5 million job loss, the unemployment rate fell to 14.7%, lower than expected. Market analysts attribute the dollar's gain to risk appetite and a lack of concern over the job losses, which they believe will be short-lived without a vaccine.

site_title: Nike's rivals play catch-up in marathon shoe wars
summary: Nike's rivals are responding to the company's success with the release of their own carbon-fibre marathon shoes. Adidas, Asics, Brooks, Hoka, New Balance, and Saucony have created similar shoes, sparking debate over whether they are a technical advancement or a form of "mechanical doping." The new shoes aim to improve performance and are valued at billions of dollars. Several companies, including Adidas and Puma, are also exploring a revival in the running shoe market due to looming tariff threats. The competition is seen as a significant response to Nike's recent success.

site_title: Looking forward to the post-pandemic world
summary: Global economies are restarting post-pandemic, with countries like Malaysia and Thailand easing restrictions. Hairdressers and other businesses are set to re-open in Singapore on May 12. Meanwhile, investors are weighing market outlooks, tariffs, and sanctions, leading to a 2% rise in oil prices. In the US, stocks are down, with concerns over US-EU tariffs and a possible operating loss for Creative Technology. Additionally, Indonesia has detained a Trafigura employee in a graft case involving 285 trillion rupiah.

site_title: India's fuel demand nearly halves in April amid lockdown
summary: India's fuel demand nearly halves in April, with consumption of fuel totaling 9.93 million tonnes, its lowest since 2007, due to the nationwide lockdown and travel curbs. State fuel retailers sold 50% less refined fuel in the first two weeks of April compared to the same period last year. The International Energy Agency predicts India's annual fuel consumption will decline 5.6% in 2020, citing the lockdown's impact on economic activity. Fuel demand is expected to recover with easing restrictions on industrial activity and transport.

site_title: Conducting company general meetings amid Covid-19 outbreak
summary: During the COVID-19 outbreak, the Singapore government legislated alternative arrangements to enable listed companies to conduct general meetings while adhering to safe distancing measures. Companies can hold general meetings through electronic means, allowing shareholders to observe proceedings via audio and video or audio only. Shareholders must vote by proxy only, with the chairman as the proxy, and submit proxy forms electronically. All documents and minutes related to the general meeting are published on SGXNET and the issuer's corporate website.

site_title: 32 companies return Jobs Support Scheme payout in April totalling S$35 million
summary: In response to the COVID-19 outbreak, 32 Singaporean companies have returned their Jobs Support Scheme (JSS) payouts totaling S$35 million in April. Another 29 companies have pledged to decline future JSS payouts. Companies such as Boehringer Ingelheim and DSM have redirected their payouts to donate to local organizations, citing a desire to support the community. The government has welcomed these actions, stating they reflect the "SG Together spirit" of stepping forward to overcome challenges together.

site_title: Over 8,600 businesses ceased and filed to cease operations in April
summary: Over 8,600 businesses in Singapore ceased operations in April, with 3,771 officially closed and 4,892 in the process of shutting down, amid the COVID-19 pandemic. Economists warn that more businesses will go under after the government cuts wage support for most sectors, leading to expected job losses of 60,000 to 80,000 in the second quarter. The pandemic is expected to have a deeper and worse impact than the 2003 SARS outbreak and the 2008-2009 Great Recession.

images.alt_text: A total of 8,663 business entities closed in April - more than double the number of cessations in March, as the novel coronavirus pandemic continues to bite.

site_title: Australia's biggest states hold off relaxing COVID-19 lockdowns
summary: Australia's most populous states, New South Wales and Victoria, have delayed easing COVID-19 restrictions, while other states like South Australia and the Northern Territory have begun to relax measures. Some states allowed small gatherings and restaurant reopenings, but the federal government's three-stage plan for reopening businesses is expected to be completed by July. Australia's total deaths from COVID-19 remain below 100, with nearly 1 million people expected to return to work.

site_title: Britain to introduce two-week quarantine for arrivals: reports
summary: Britain plans to introduce a 14-day mandatory quarantine for most international arrivals, reports said Saturday. The rule, enforced by spot-checks, applies to people coming into Britain by air, sea, and rail, except those entering from Ireland. The quarantine restriction is set to be brought in at the end of May, with possible penalties including fines of up to 1,000 pounds. Prime Minister Boris Johnson will announce the measures on Sunday.

site_title: IMF head downbeat on global economic forecast, warns against protectionism
summary: IMF head Kristalina Georgieva signals a possible downward revision of global economic forecasts, warning against protectionism as the world struggles to recover from the coronavirus pandemic. The IMF projects a 3% contraction in 2020, with the US economy particularly hard hit, and warns that rising US-China tensions could weaken the global economy. Georgieva emphasizes the importance of resisting protectionism to ensure a global economic recovery, citing the need for international trade to boost incomes and reduce costs.

site_title: Pandemic fuels historic US job losses, EU wants borders kept shut
summary: The US recorded its steepest job losses in history, with half of the global workforce restricted due to the coronavirus pandemic. Europe has kept its borders shut for another month amid rising deaths. The global economy has suffered its most acute downturn in nearly a century. A new at-home saliva test was approved to speed up diagnosis for Covid-19. The pandemic has claimed over 270,000 lives worldwide, with economic and social impacts still being felt.

site_title: McDonald's resumes delivery, takeaway and drive-through services
summary: McDonald's in Singapore resumes delivery, takeaway, and drive-through services from May 11, 2020, with most restaurants open from 7am to 9pm. Some restaurants will have different hours, and those in parks and tourist attractions will remain closed. The company is urging customers to follow safety measures, such as temperature taking and safe distancing, and to use contactless payment methods. McDonald's had closed all branches in Singapore on April 19 after seven staff members tested positive for COVID-19.

site_title: Chinese drugmaker in talks to test virus vaccine globally
summary: Chinese drugmaker Sinovac Biotech is in talks to conduct late-stage trials of its COVID-19 vaccine globally, aiming to launch phase III clinical trials in regions with high virus transmission. The company is in discussion with the World Health Organization and regulators in other countries, including the US, to test its vaccine candidate. Sinovac's CEO, Yin Weidong, expressed the need for international cooperation to test the vaccine in countries with ongoing outbreaks, citing the US as a potential location due to its developed biotech industry and regulatory framework.

site_title: Germany sees increased risk of hard Brexit if Britain refuses to extend deadline
summary: German Foreign Minister Heiko Maas warns of a growing risk of a hard Brexit due to Britain's refusal to extend the deadline for negotiations on a new trade relationship with the EU. Talks have yielded little progress, and a comprehensive trade deal remains elusive. Maas states that if Britain does not extend the deadline, Germany will have to deal with Brexit alongside the coronavirus pandemic at the turn of the year. This development increases pressure on the EU to reconsider its stance.

site_title: Airbnb-backed Zeus's value halved in new funding round
summary: Zeus Living, a corporate-housing startup backed by Airbnb, has raised $15 million in equity and debt at a valuation of $110 million, roughly half its previous valuation of $205 million. The funding round was due to Zeus not having enough cash to comply with a loan covenant from Soros Fund Management. Despite a decline in valuation, Zeus has seen increased occupancy with over 70% of its 2,000 homes rented, and its corporate partners continue to maintain contracts with the company.

site_title: Impact of Covid-19 'largely confined' to Tuan Sing's hospitality segment, says group
