summary: Tuan Sing Holdings' business operations were largely impacted by the Covid-19 outbreak, mainly affecting its hospitality segment. However, the group's diversified portfolio across segments and regions has provided a high degree of resilience. Its commercial and residential segments account for over 80% of its asset portfolio, while its hospitality segment comprises less than 15%. Revenue and profit from its other investments have outperformed year-on-year, and the company is exploring further dividend opportunities in the second half of 2020.

site_title: Kingsoft Cloud jumps in first big US IPO since Luckin fall
summary: Kingsoft Cloud Holdings, a Beijing-based cloud computing service company, successfully raised US$510 million in its initial public offering (IPO) in the US, pricing its shares at US$23.84. The IPO, the biggest by a Chinese company in the US this year, comes at a tense moment in the US-China relationship. Kingsoft Cloud's shares rose 40% in their first trading day, despite concerns following Luckin Coffee's accounting scandal. The company's market value is now US$4.77 billion, with Xiaomi owning a 14% stake after the offering.

site_title: Chicken-rearing craze sweeps cooped-up Belgium
summary: A chicken-rearing craze is sweeping Belgium, with many people buying hens to produce fresh eggs or to entertain children during the coronavirus lockdown. The demand has been extraordinary, with sales booming at the Elevage de Limal farm, where customers are buying up to 600 chickens per Saturday. The farm's owners, Martine and Christopher Denis, are struggling to keep up with the demand, with stock running low for some breeds of egg-layers and henhouses. The trend is driven by people looking for alternative ways to keep their children occupied and to produce their own food.

site_title: Pfizer to outsource some drug production, focus on coronavirus vaccine
summary: Pfizer is outsourcing some of its medicine production to outside contractors, including Catalent Inc and Lonza Group AG, to focus on large-scale production of its experimental coronavirus vaccine. The shift will help prevent disruptions in supply of existing medicines while preparing for potential emergency use authorization from the US FDA. Pfizer aims to produce up to 20 million doses by the end of 2020 and potentially hundreds of millions next year, with a potential cost of $150 million to gear up its facilities.

site_title: Europe: Stocks end higher on US-China talks, earnings optimism
summary: European shares closed higher on Friday, with the STOXX 600 index rising 0.9% as improved US-China relations boosted investor optimism. Automobile stocks led gains, while strong earnings from ING Groep NV and Siemens also contributed to the increase. The STOXX 600 added 1.1% for the week, despite weak economic readings due to the coronavirus. Basic resources stocks performed well, but bank stocks lagged, with Italy's bank-heavy index losing 1.5% due to concerns over the country's sovereign debt.

site_title: United Air pulls US$2.25b junk-bond deal on weak demand
summary: United Airlines Holdings is abandoning a $2.25 billion junk bond deal due to weak demand from investors, citing concerns over the airline's aging fleet of jetliners pledged as collateral. The deal fell flat despite the airline increasing the yield to 11% and adding a clause to repay the bonds at a premium if it files for bankruptcy. United is rushing to raise additional money amid the worst crisis in the airline industry, with passenger totals tumbling over 90% due to the Covid-19 pandemic.

images.alt_text: United Airlines Holdings is abandoning a US$2.25 billion (S$3.18 billion) sale of junk bonds after the deal fell flat with investors on concerns about the planes backing the debt.

site_title: Myanmar factories face 'irreversible' harm if shutdown extended
summary: Myanmar's 60,000 registered factories face "irreversible damage" if shutdown measures due to the Covid-19 pandemic are extended beyond May 15, according to the president of the Myanmar Industries Association. The nation has 176 confirmed cases and six deaths, with concerns about a potential outbreak among laborers. Myanmar's de facto leader Aung San Suu Kyi expressed concern about a possible outbreak, but the trade group's president urged the government to consult with business leaders before making any decisions. If factories remain unproductive for three months, many may shut down, severely harming the economy.

site_title: Trump 'torn' over US-China trade deal as officials push to fulfill its terms
summary: US President Donald Trump expressed uncertainty about ending the Phase 1 US-China trade deal, citing his "very torn" feelings. Despite this, top trade officials from both countries reaffirmed their commitment to implementing the agreement, which took effect in mid-February. US Trade Representative Robert Lighthizer and Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin stated that both sides expect to meet their obligations in a timely manner, despite the global health emergency. The officials set aside deteriorating US-China relations to discuss progress on the deal.

site_title: SingPost delivers net profit of S$7.2m for Q4; no need for capital calls
summary: SingPost delivered a net profit of S$7.2m for Q4, surpassing expectations, as it avoided one-off impairment charges for its US subsidiaries. The company attributed the better result to strong demand for logistics and delivery services. CEO Paul Coutts emphasized the need to maintain a sustainable cost base amid the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic.

site_title: Golden globalist
summary: Marsha Vande Berg, a corporate luminary, emphasizes the opportunity for investors to create a better world while generating profits. She advocates for sustainability investing and corporate responsibility, particularly in light of the COVID-19 pandemic. Vande Berg, a former CEO of Pacific Pension & Investment Institute, believes the pandemic will accelerate the shift towards sustainability investment and corporate governance. She credits her upbringing in a small town in South Dakota and her experiences in journalism and business to her liberal values and internationalist orientation. Vande Berg notes that globalization has promoted social and political change, especially in Asia, and that a more diverse and younger generation of businesspeople is driving this change.

site_title: Gold tug of war between easing lockdowns and weak economic data
summary: Gold futures have been consolidating around the $1,700 level, pressured by European and US states reopening their economies from lockdowns. California relaxed its lockdown, while Italy and Spain also took action. Central bankers, including the European Central Bank, expressed support for gold, citing efforts to help the euro zone through the coronavirus crisis. The easing of lockdowns and comments from central bankers have led to a gold tug-of-war between easing lockdowns and weak economic data.

site_title: No 'V'-shape return from devastating US job loss, Fed policymakers say
summary: US Federal Reserve officials say Americans shouldn't expect a quick 'V'-shaped recovery from the devastating job losses caused by the coronavirus. Despite a vaccine and effective treatment unlikely for a year or two, the economy is expected to experience a slow, long recovery. The US economy shed 20.5 million jobs in April, and Fed policymakers are urging caution, warning that the virus must be brought under control before the economy can rev up.

site_title: Singapore banks brace themselves for tough months ahead
summary: Singapore banks posted lower earnings in Q1 due to higher provisions to cushion against economic stresses from the virus outbreak and oil-and-gas exposure. The banks expect flattish growth for the rest of the year and may see further impairments. DBS's return on equity fell to 9.2%, while OCBC's was 6% and UOB's was 8.8%. The banks have extended moratorium relief and loan facilities to support individuals and businesses, but credit costs are expected to rise to 100-130 basis points over two years.

site_title: Manulife US Reit portfolio occupancy rises to 96.5% in Q1
summary: Manulife US Reit reported a 96.5% occupancy rate in Q1 2020, up from 95.8% in the previous quarter. The Reit's weighted average lease expiry (WALE) stands at 5.7 years, with only a minimal 4% of its portfolio expiring in 2020.

site_title: Oil rises 5% in second weekly gain on output cuts, demand hopes
summary: Oil prices rose 5% in their second consecutive week, driven by US producers cutting production and demand hopes as states relax lockdowns. The number of operating oil rigs fell to a record low of 374, with North American companies expected to withdraw 1.7 million barrels per day by June's end. Brent crude gained 5.1% to $30.97 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude futures rose 5% to $24.74 a barrel. However, analysts express skepticism about the sustainability of the gains due to increasing coronavirus cases and a steep US crude surplus.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Frasers Hospitality Trust's second-quarter distribution per stapled security fell 68.1% to 0.3137 Singapore cents due to the COVID-19 pandemic's impact on travel demand. Gross revenue shrank 41.5% to S$20.2 million, while net property income dropped 52% to S$12.1 million. The trust retained 80% of income for critical capital commitments, reducing the distribution rate for H1 FY2020 to 0.3287 cents per stapled security.

site_title: Quiet billionaire brothers face the roar of UK football fans
summary: Quiet billionaire brothers David and Simon Reuben are set to take control of Newcastle United Football Club if their takeover bid is approved by the Premier League. The Reuben family, led by the 81- and 79-year-old brothers, will partner with Saudi Arabia's Public Investment Fund to buy the UK football team. This marks a significant shift from the previous owner, Mike Ashley, who has been divisive among fans. The Reubens have maintained a low profile despite running a large portfolio of high-end properties, including London real estate, and have recently expanded into New York.

site_title: Coronavirus deals US job losses of 20.5m, historic unemployment rate in April
summary: The US economy lost 20.5 million jobs in April, the largest monthly decline since the Great Depression, with the unemployment rate surging to 14.7%. The pandemic's lockdowns led to a recession, with economists expecting a slow recovery. Despite the bleak numbers, investors showed optimism due to lower-than-expected job losses and easing US-China friction. President Trump expressed confidence that employment numbers would rebound quickly, while experts warned that the economy is on life support and will need time to recover.

site_title: German exports plunge 11.8% in March as virus hits demand
summary: Germany's exports plummeted 11.8% in March, the largest decline since 1990, due to the coronavirus crisis reducing demand. Imports fell 5.1% seasonally, and the trade surplus narrowed to 12.8 billion euros. The economy is expected to shrink by 6.3% post-World War II, with a slow recovery dependent on European neighbours and other trade partners emerging from the crisis.

site_title: Singapore oil trader ZenRock placed under judicial management; raided by police
summary: The Singapore High Court has granted HSBC's application to place ZenRock Commodities Trading under judicial management due to its secured debt pile of nearly US$190 million. The court lifted ZenRock's debt moratorium and appointed KPMG's Martin Wong, Bob Yap, and Toh Ai Ling as interim judicial managers. The move follows a police raid on ZenRock's office by the Singapore police after HSBC accused the company of "dishonest" or "extremely suspicious" trade practices. ZenRock faces significant debt and has not contested HSBC's allegations.

site_title: Firms prepare for changes in events landscape
summary: Singaporean companies are adapting to the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic by developing online alternatives to traditional MICE (meetings, incentive travel, conventions, and exhibitions) events. Firms like The Fun Empire and motion have successfully launched digital events, including virtual workshops and escape room games, which have seen a "good pick-up rate" from consumers and corporate clients. Others, such as Informa Markets and SingEx Holdings, are exploring digital twinning platforms and online events to complement their physical events, recognizing the need for business agility and collaboration to recover from the crisis.

images.alt_text: With restrictions on large events likely to continue even after the end of the circuit breakers, some companies are developing ways to take events online.

site_title: Reits (May 09-10, 2020)
summary: Realtors and investors are bracing for a Q3 wave of condo launches in Singapore, which may test demand for prime projects above the S$3,000 per square foot (psf) benchmark. US mortgage rates rose after five straight weeks of declines, while UK homebuyer demand rebounded to a six-month high. Manhattan rents reached a record, with more increases anticipated. New World is selling China property assets following a loan deal, and WeWork secured new tenants at 21 Collyer Quay in Singapore after its bankruptcy. These developments signal a shift in the global real estate market.

site_title: Boeing expects to start 737 MAX production in May
summary: Boeing expects to resume 737 MAX production in May, according to CEO David Calhoun. This follows plans announced in April to start production at low rates during the second quarter and resume deliveries in the third quarter after regulatory approvals. The company had grounded the aircraft following the 737 MAX crashes in 2018 and 2019.

site_title: Social distancing and personalised service make poor bedfellows
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has significantly impacted the travel and hospitality industries, with hotels and airlines exploring ways to maintain social distancing while offering personalized service. Architects and designers are reimagining hotel blueprints with wider corridors, improved ventilation, and energy-saving natural light. Airlines are introducing protective uniforms and advanced technologies, such as facial recognition and contactless routes. However, many experts believe that social distancing and personalized service are mutually exclusive, with Giovanni Angelini stating that "social distancing and personalised service make poor bedfellows." Luxury brands may benefit from the shift in safety perceptions, while destinations like Thailand and Vietnam could emerge as post-pandemic beneficiaries.

site_title: Luxury industry to contract 20-35% in 2020
summary: The global luxury industry is expected to contract 20-35% in 2020 due to the COVID-19 pandemic. The market for personal luxury goods declined 25% in the first quarter of 2020, according to a Bain & Company report. This decline is attributed to reduced consumer spending and travel restrictions.

site_title: Firms 'should not rush to reopen' without safeguards
summary: Singapore's National Development Minister Lawrence Wong urged firms reopening on May 12 to prioritize safe management practices, warning against rushing to reopen without adequate precautions. Government inspectors will monitor and penalize firms with inadequate measures. Even after the circuit breaker ends, the easing of measures will be gradual and calibrated, with vulnerable elderly residents of nursing homes to be tested and staff to stay on-site or in hotels.

site_title: Stock markets looking good? Beware the snapback
summary: The US stock market, particularly the Dow Jones, has experienced its best monthly performance in decades, with a 35% recovery since March. However, the economic outlook remains grim due to high unemployment, shuttered shops, and business closures. Investors face the risk of a violent snapback, where the market rapidly retreats to match the economic outlook. The Dow's horizontal support line at 23,500 is being closely watched, and a sustained fall below this level could lead to a retest of 2018 and 2020 lows. Private investors have an advantage over institutional peers due to their ability to wait for a clear direction before making decisions.

site_title: MICE companies struggling to survive, request more support
summary: Singapore's MICE (meetings, incentive travel, conventions, and exhibitions) industry is struggling to survive due to the COVID-19 pandemic. Revenue has almost dried up since February, and companies are facing pay cuts, no-pay leave, and potential closures. Industry leaders are urging the government to extend 75% wage subsidies to all companies in the MICE ecosystem, not just those in the highest subsidy tier. If support is not enhanced, more than half of MICE companies may go under by the end of 2020. The government has allocated S$60 billion in aid, but industry leaders are calling for more urgent financial assistance to survive and prepare for a changed events landscape post-pandemic.

site_title: Biolidics appoints non-exclusive distributor for Covid-19 test kits in Thailand
summary: Biolidics, a Singapore-based medtech firm, has appointed Mediproud as a non-exclusive distributor for its Covid-19 test kits in Thailand. The agreement, which began on May 7, 2020, allows Mediproud to assist Biolidics in obtaining necessary permits and licenses to import and sell the test kits in Thailand. The test kits are for qualitative detection of SARS-CoV-2 antibodies and have regulatory approval in several countries, including the US, EU, and Singapore.

site_title: Outlook for long-term capital market returns optimistic
summary: JP Morgan Asset Management has published an optimistic assessment for long-term capital market returns, despite the bleak economic outlook due to Covid-19. Expected returns for stocks have risen by 100-250 basis points, with trend earnings linked to long-term potential growth. US Treasuries are expected to decline, while euro government bonds are expected to rise 30 basis points. Credit markets have also seen improved returns, approaching those available in equity markets. The study's author notes that the more bearish investors are today, the more bullish they should be about long-run returns, with fiscal stimulus and expansionary monetary policies expected to support equities over bonds.

site_title: STI up 0.01% on Friday, 1.23% lower for the week
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) closed at 2,591.88 points, up 0.01% on Friday but 1.23% lower for the week. AEM Holdings rose 19.4% to S$3.08 after research houses recommended a "buy" call. StarHub declined 4% to S$1.43, while Singtel fell 1% to S$2.72. Asian markets, led by the Nikkei 225, rose amid easing tensions between the US and China.

site_title: Trump says jobs report not surprising and predicts quick rebound
summary: President Donald Trump said a US job loss report of 20.5 million jobs in April, with a 14.7% unemployment rate, isn't a surprise and that employment numbers will rebound quickly. He attributed the economic collapse to social-distancing practices and criticized the slow response to the virus. Trump expressed confidence that jobs will return and predicted a "phenomenal year" next year, despite criticism of his handling of the pandemic.

site_title: Singapore Reits: Faltering but not falling
summary: Singapore Reits are experiencing a volatile phase amid the ongoing pandemic, with retail and hospitality Reits more vulnerable due to footfall and tenant sales. Retail Reits are expected to recover earlier as new tenants move in, while hospitality Reits are more diversified but still face uncertain revenue generation. Industrial Reits are expected to be more resilient due to essential industry sectors. Reits can bolster themselves by drawing down committed credit facilities, seeking bank loans, and tapping their sponsors for assistance. Despite the challenges, dividend payments are largely insulated by debt obligations, and investors should consider diversification at the asset allocation and property type levels.

site_title: Firms shouldn't rush to reopen from May 12 without safe practices: Lawrence Wong
summary: National Development Minister Lawrence Wong emphasized that businesses reopening from May 12 should prioritize safe management practices. Firms will be inspected, and those with inadequate precautions may face penalties. Measures such as safe distancing and mask-wearing will remain even after June 1. Some services, including retail laundry services, barbers, and pet supply retailers, will reopen from May 12, while manufacturing and food preparation will also be allowed. However, the government will continue to fight the virus on two fronts, including migrant-worker dormitories and the broader community.

site_title: SIA to post first yearly loss; analysts foresee more pain ahead
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) expects to report its first yearly loss, with a net loss of over S$800 million for FY20/21 due to the Covid-19 pandemic's impact on air travel and fuel hedging losses. The airline has already cut capacity by 96% and expects operating cashflow to remain negative for the quarter ending June 2020. Analysts forecast a near full recovery in the domestic market, but international recovery may take a few years. SIA is taking steps to bolster its liquidity and balance sheet, including a S$8.8 billion rights issue and adjusting aircraft delivery streams.

site_title: SCAL to raise S$1m to help smaller construction firms cope with Covid-19
summary: The Singapore Contractors Association Ltd (SCAL) has established a S$1 million Covid-19 assistance fund to support its small and medium-sized enterprise (SME) member companies affected by the pandemic. The fund, which will be contributed to by SCAL members, the Building and Construction Authority, and Enterprise Singapore, aims to help these firms cope with the economic impact of the virus. The association will work with the BCA and Enterprise Singapore to utilize the SG Together Enhancing Enterprise Resilience programme.

site_title: How to have a fulfilling staycation when you're sick of your house
summary: During the COVID-19 pandemic, many Americans are opting for staycations due to travel restrictions. To make the most of a staycation, experts suggest taking walks, exploring local areas, and trying new skills. Local staycations can replicate the travel experience without the need for extensive planning or expenses. Practicing slow travel, which encourages close interaction with local communities, can also provide a mental and physical break. Staycations offer a chance to be productive and creative, and experts recommend implementing micro-breaks or restructuring workdays to prioritize personal needs.

site_title: US: Stocks open higher despite historic job losses
summary: US stocks opened higher on Friday, despite a historic spike in job losses and unemployment in April, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average up 1.4% to 24,209.65. The S&P 500 climbed 1.2% to 2,914.73, and the Nasdaq Composite Index rose 0.9% to 9,055.55. Markets appear to be focusing on positive economic news, including the gradual restart of economic activity in the US and Europe.

site_title: Living through a once-in-a-lifetime event
summary: Singapore is 14 weeks into its COVID-19 crisis, with 21,707 cases reported, mostly among migrant workers in dormitories. The government has implemented "circuit breaker" measures to control community spread, reducing unlinked cases to 11 daily. Despite challenges, private-public cooperation has been praised, and the healthcare system has shown resilience. The country is racing to develop a vaccine, with the US and China competing for a vaccine, and is facing a combination of health, economic, and psychological crises. Amidst the crisis, there are silver linings, including increased family bonding, reduced costs, and a shift towards remote work, offering opportunities for re-examination and realignment of values, priorities, and prowess.

site_title: HDB resale flat volume falls 78% in April; only 423 units changed hands
summary: HDB resale flat volumes plummeted 78.3% in April, with only 423 units changing hands, likely a historical low due to circuit breaker measures. Prices also fell, with declines of 1.5% for three-room flats, 0.2% for four-room flats, and 1.8% for executive flats. Resale prices were 0.04% lower than March and 1% higher than April last year. Experts say sales demand may moderate during an economic crisis, but the low transaction volume may be unprecedented, with potential for a 25% decrease in HDB resale transactions this year.

site_title: ARA H-Trust Q1 profit misses IPO forecast by 47.8% at US$8.1m
summary: ARA H-Trust posted a Q1 gross operating profit of US$8.1 million, missing its IPO forecast by 47.8% and its gross revenue and net property income forecasts by 24.5% and 68.2%, respectively. The trust's occupancy rate stood at 54.8% due to the Covid-19 outbreak, and its managers have taken measures to protect the trust's financial position, including temporarily suspending or consolidating hotel operations and identifying new sales opportunities. The trust has adequate liquidity and remains in compliance with loan covenants.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Friday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed higher on Friday, rising 5.38 points to 1,382.31. The index saw a significant gain with 540 gainers outnumbering 340 losers. The volume was 4.683 billion lots worth RM2.737 billion.

site_title: Venture's Q1 profit down 33%; revenue impacted by global supply chain disruptions
summary: Venture Corp's Q1 net profit declined 33% to S$60.3 million due to global supply chain disruptions and factory lockdowns. Revenue fell 27.5% to S$673 million, while earnings per share dropped 34% to 20.8 cents. Despite the decline, Venture's net cash position improved 19.5% to S$852.5 million. The company expects robust demand for medical and wellness products, and its essential products are in strong demand during the COVID-19 pandemic. Shares fell two cents to close at S$15.74.

site_title: Boustead Projects bags design-and-build contract in Malaysia
summary: Boustead Projects' subsidiary BP Engineering Solutions has secured a design-and-build contract for a high-tech industrial facility in Penang, Malaysia. The project is valued at S$710 million and is expected to be completed in H1 2021. The contract boosts Boustead Projects' order book backlog and shares rose 0.5 cents to 74 cents. Managing director Thomas Chu emphasized the company's efforts to maintain business continuity during the pandemic.

site_title: FHT reports DPS of 0.3137 S'pore cts for Q2, down 68.1%
summary: Frasers Hospitality Trust (FHT) reported a 68.1% decline in distribution per stapled security (DPS) to 0.3137 Singapore cents for the second quarter, driven by a significant hit in travel demand due to the Covid-19 pandemic. Gross revenue shrank 41.5% to S$20.2 million, while net property income dropped 52% to S$12.1 million. The trust retained 80% of income available for distribution for the first half of FY2020 to conserve cash.

site_title: Europe's top football leagues on the road to resumption
summary: European top football leagues are resuming their seasons, with Germany's Bundesliga set to start on May 16, followed by England's Premier League, Italy's Serie A, and Spain's La Liga. France's Ligue 1 season was cancelled due to the coronavirus, while the Dutch Eredivisie was also scrapped. Germany's Bundesliga will resume with around 300 people in and around stadiums, while England's Premier League plans to resume training in small groups. Italy and Spain are also making plans to resume their seasons, with Serie A teams hoping to start in June and La Liga aiming for June 13.

site_title: Venture Q1 profit down 33.6%
summary: VENTURE Corp reported a 33.6% year-on-year decline in first-quarter net profit to S$60.3 million, due to supply chain disruptions and factory lockdowns. Revenue fell 27.5% to S$673 million. Despite this, the company expects robust demand for its medical and wellness products, and sees opportunities in the realigned global supply chain. Shares fell two cents to close at S$15.74 on Friday.

site_title: Indonesia eases coronavirus travel ban despite fears it's too early
summary: Indonesia has eased its two-week coronavirus travel ban, allowing flights and public transport to resume conditionally. Those who work in security, defence, and health services, or have emergency health reasons, can travel if they test negative for the virus and have documentation from their employer. Migrant workers going home are also permitted to travel. The decision has been criticized by civil society groups, who claim the government is prioritizing the economy over public health.

site_title: Former Garuda Indonesia CEO jailed 8 years for bribery
summary: A former CEO of Garuda Indonesia, Emirsyah Satar, has been jailed for 8 years and fined US$1.4 million for bribery and money laundering related to the procurement of planes and engines from Airbus and Rolls-Royce. The sentence was handed down by Indonesia's corruption court, which also indicted Satar over payments from a businessman for the procurement of planes by Garuda Indonesia and its unit, Citilink Indonesia. Satar, who had previously denied wrongdoing, will decide next week whether to appeal against his sentence.

site_title: Traders cry foul over losses from SocGen actions on SIA shorts
summary: Traders in Singapore Airlines' (SIA) 5x Short Daily Leveraged Certificates (DLCs) lost positions after SIA shares rose 20% on Wednesday, triggered by Societe Generale's (SocGen) adjusted theoretical ex-rights price (TERP) of S$3.71. The new formula, which assumes all mandatory convertible bonds (MCBs) will be fully converted into shares at S$4.84, was used despite SIA's original TERP of S$4.16, calculated without MCBs. The move led to a short squeeze, with over 1.8 million short DLCs worth S$1.4 million affected, resulting in significant losses for traders.

site_title: Facebook to allow employees to work remotely until year end
summary: Facebook will allow employees to work remotely until the end of the year due to the ongoing coronavirus pandemic. Most offices are expected to remain closed until July 6, with the social media giant adopting a remote work arrangement. This shift reflects the changing work landscape as governments extend stay-at-home orders to curb the spread of the virus.

site_title: Coronavirus deals US job losses of 20.5 million in April
summary: The US economy lost 20.5 million jobs in April, the largest decline since the Great Depression, with the unemployment rate surging to 14.7%. The report highlights the devastating impact of the novel coronavirus pandemic, which has battered the world's biggest economy. Economists expect a slow recovery from the recession, with some predicting the underlying recession will extend through the third quarter. The bleak numbers add to concerns about President Donald Trump's bid for re-election and the country's economic prospects.

images.alt_text: The US economy lost a staggering 20.5 million jobs in April, the steepest plunge in payrolls since the Great Depression and the starkest sign yet of how the novel coronavirus pandemic is battering the world's biggest economy.

site_title: Overcoming shyness to go online
summary: Florence Low, founder of Lux Lexicon, shares her experience of pivoting to online sales during Singapore's Circuit Breaker period. Initially, the business only had an Instagram presence, but they quickly launched IGTV, WhatsApp messaging, and Facebook Live streaming to maintain customer engagement. Low overcame her shyness to appear on camera and her team had to adapt to a new digital engagement strategy. The business successfully maintained sales and customer engagement, and Low emphasizes the importance of dedicating sufficient resources to a consistent physical and virtual presence.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: SIA expects a small operating profit but a net loss for the full year due to fuel hedging losses. Singapore banks posted lower Q1 earnings due to increased provisions. IPOS chief Daren Tang was appointed as the top job at Wipo, starting October 1. Traders lost positions in SIA leveraged shorts due to ex-rights pricing. Impossible Foods now allows F&B outlets to resell its patties. MAS banned 4 individuals for fraud and dishonest conduct. The STI was marginally up 0.01% on Friday, with the Asian markets slightly higher.

site_title: Japan tightens rules on foreign stakes in 518 firms, citing national security
summary: Japan has tightened rules on foreign stakes in 518 firms, citing national security concerns. The move affects companies in 12 key sectors, including oil, railways, and cybersecurity, with stricter regulations on foreign investment. Foreign investors now face pre-screening for stakes of 1% or more, compared to 10%. The revised law aims to protect technology and patents from leaks, while critics argue it discourages foreign investment and runs counter to government efforts to boost the economy. Exemptions include foreign financial institutions and certain sovereign wealth funds.

site_title: STI almost flat on Friday, 1.23% lower for the week
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) ended the week 1.23% lower, despite a 0.01% gain on Friday. The best performer was AEM, which rose 19.38% to S$3.08. Telco StarHub was the worst performer, shedding 4.03% to S$1.43, due to concerns over its near-term guidance and removal of earlier guidance. Most Asian markets, including the Nikkei 225, Hang Seng Index, and Shanghai Composite Index, saw gains, driven by easing tensions between the US and China.

site_title: Singapore police raid oil trader after HSBC allegations
summary: Singapore's police force raided the office of oil trader ZenRock Commodities Trading following allegations by HSBC that the company was involved in "dishonest" transactions, including using the same cargo of oil to obtain multiple loans. The raid came after a hearing in Singapore's High Court, where HSBC sought to have ZenRock placed under judicial management. HSBC alleges that ZenRock engaged in "highly dishonest transactions" and reported the company to Singapore's Commercial Affairs Department on April 28. The police declined to comment on the matter.

site_title: Top EU court says it alone decides if EU bodies are breaking bloc's rules
summary: The European Union's top court, the Court of Justice of the European Union (CJEU), has ruled that it has the sole authority to decide if EU bodies are breaking the bloc's rules. The CJEU rejected a German Constitutional Court's decision that the European Central Bank (ECB) overstepped its mandate with trillion-euro bond purchases. The CJEU stated that national courts should defer to its authority to ensure uniform application of EU law, as divergent rulings could jeopardize the EU's unity. The ruling may lead to increased tensions between national constitutional courts and the CJEU.

images.alt_text: EU Commissioner for Economic and Financial Affairs Paolo Gentiloni said separately on Friday that he did not think the ruling would weigh on the euro zone's monetary policy, stressing the independence of the ECB.

site_title: Vietnam seeks to resume international flights from June 1: VnExpress
summary: Vietnam's civil aviation authority is seeking government approval to partially resume international flights from June 1, aiming to revive the hit-hard aviation industry. With no coronavirus community transmission in over three weeks, Vietnam has proposed reconnecting international flights with limited frequency, prioritizing foreign experts and investors. The country has registered 288 cases and zero deaths, making it on track to revive its economy sooner than most others.

site_title: German ECB ruling could threaten Euro's survival, Schaeuble says
summary: Germany's constitutional court ruled that the European Central Bank's $2.9 trillion bond-buying program may be unconstitutional, posing a threat to the euro's survival. Former German finance minister Wolfgang Schaeuble stated that the ruling could lead to other EU member states questioning the euro's existence. ECB President Christine Lagarde remains committed to her mission, despite the ruling, stating the central bank is "undeterred" in its efforts to revive euro-area inflation. The German court's decision has sparked uncertainty, with Schaeuble suggesting that the euro's future is now "put into question" in other EU member states.

site_title: Taiwan warns on China-US trade frictions as exports tick down
summary: Taiwan's exports fell 1.3% in April to $25.24 billion, marking a second consecutive month of decline. The government expects a tough second quarter due to the coronavirus pandemic and US-China trade frictions, with exports potentially dropping 4-6% in May. This would be a significant downgrade from the ministry's earlier forecast of a 2.5% yearly growth. The government is rolling out an economic stimulus package and seeking to lure manufacturers to move production from China to mitigate the impact of the trade uncertainty.

site_title: Coronavirus came from bats, can infect cats, ferrets: WHO
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) scientist, Peter Ben Embarek, stated that COVID-19 originated from bats and can infect cats and ferrets. The virus likely entered humans through contact with animals raised for food, but the exact species is still unknown. Studies have shown that cats and ferrets are susceptible to the virus, and a new mission to China is being considered to gather more information on the virus's animal origin. This contradicts US President Donald Trump's claim that the virus came from a lab in China.

site_title: MOM fines 29 workplaces a total of S$29,000 for breaching safe-distancing rules
summary: The Singapore Ministry of Manpower (MOM) has issued composition fines totaling S$29,000 to 29 workplaces for breaching safe-distancing measures during the circuit-breaker period. The fines were for failure to ensure safe distancing, crowd management, and temperature screening. Additionally, 29 work pass holders were revoked and permanently banned from working in Singapore for breaching circuit-breaker measures, while nine employers had their work-pass privileges suspended for failing to ensure employees complied with Stay-Home Notice requirements.

site_title: Sony to make, donate face shields to Japan hospitals
summary: Sony will manufacture and donate medical face shields to hospitals in Japan, amid the coronavirus pandemic. The company has begun producing face shields repurposed from eye shields used by surgeons and plans to mass produce ventilators by July. Sony joins a growing list of global companies helping to provide hospitals with protective equipment. Japan has reported over 16,000 coronavirus cases and 603 deaths.

site_title: Asia's oncoming labour pangs to be "unprecedented"
summary: Asia's labor market is expected to face "unprecedented" challenges due to the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic, with unemployment rates potentially dwarfing those during the 2008 global financial crisis. Economies with large informal sectors, such as Indonesia and India, are expected to be particularly hard hit. The International Labour Organisation estimates that 56-80% of employment in these countries is in the informal non-agriculture economy. Policymakers have taken steps to address this risk, but long-term business prospects remain uncertain, suggesting that unemployment rates will not quickly return to pre-pandemic levels.

site_title: Covid-19 pandemic is transforming wealth management industry: UBS
summary: The Covid-19 pandemic has dramatically transformed the wealth management industry, with clients becoming more cautious, digitally savvy, and interested in sustainable investments. According to UBS Group executive Amy Lo, the pandemic has led to a shift towards diversification and navigating volatility, with clients seeking to preserve their wealth and re-balancing portfolios. UBS's digital platform has seen significant growth, allowing clients to interact with the bank online, and the bank has reported a 41% jump in first-quarter operating profit at its global wealth management unit.

site_title: UBS offers negative rate holiday to some clients after outflows
summary: UBS, the world's largest wealth manager, is offering a temporary payment holiday to some of its wealthiest Swiss clients to attract assets amid the coronavirus crisis. The move comes after the bank previously passed on negative interest rates to rich clients, leading to outflows of $16 billion in the first quarter. UBS plans to recoup lost interest by boosting lending, and the bank is discussing the payment holiday on a case-by-case basis. Despite this, UBS still posted $12 billion of inflows across its global wealth management unit in the first quarter.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks close on positive note
summary: Hong Kong stocks closed on a positive note, with the Hang Seng Index rising 1.04% to 24,230.17. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also saw gains, with increases of 0.83% and 1.17%, respectively. The positive momentum is attributed to governments easing lockdown measures, which have impacted the global economy.

site_title: IPOS chief officially appointed to top job at Wipo, to start on Oct 1
summary: Daren Tang, the CEO of Intellectual Property Office of Singapore (IPOS), has been officially appointed as the next director general of the World Intellectual Property Organization (Wipo) starting October 1. This marks the first time a Singaporean and the first director general from Asia will lead the UN agency. Tang will succeed Australia's Francis Gurry and brings six years of experience in driving Singapore's IP enforcement and dispute resolution.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets head higher at open
summary: European stock markets rose at the start of trading on Friday, driven by an upbeat outlook in Asia. The DAX 30 index in the eurozone gained 1.1% to 10,880.98 points, while the Paris CAC 40 added 0.81% to 4,538.09. The London Stock Exchange was closed for the 75th anniversary of the end of World War II in Europe.

site_title: Impossible Foods lets F&B outlets resell patties to consumers; hints at retail launch
summary: Impossible Foods, a plant-based meat company, is allowing food and beverage outlets in Singapore to resell its patties directly to consumers. This move, effective immediately, enables consumers to purchase the company's "Impossible burger brick" packs from local restaurants and distributors. The initiative aims to provide restaurants with an additional revenue stream and gauge consumer interest in cooking Impossible at home, potentially paving the way for a retail launch in the region.

site_title: Australia: Shares rise on easing virus curbs, US-China trade talks
summary: Australian stocks rose for the second straight week, ending 0.5% higher at 5,391.1, as the government announced plans to end most coronavirus restrictions by July and as US-China trade talks lifted sentiment. Mining stocks, particularly Fortescue Metals Group, drove the gains, while China's iron ore prices reached a nine-month peak. The market also received relief from a government inquiry's recommendations on financial misconduct, which will be deferred by six months.

site_title: China-backed AIIB approves US$500m loan for India's Covid-19 response
summary: The Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank (AIIB) has approved a $500 million loan to India to aid its COVID-19 response. The loan will support the strengthening of India's public health system, medical equipment purchases, and research. This is part of a $10 billion funding facility announced by AIIB to help public and private sector entities cope with the pandemic. The loan is co-financed by the World Bank.

site_title: China says it supports WHO-led review of global pandemic response
summary: China supports a World Health Organization-led review of the global pandemic response, but only "after the pandemic is over," according to Foreign Ministry spokesperson Hua Chunying. China emphasizes the review should be conducted transparently and based on the International Health Regulations, under WHO leadership. This comes amid global pressure for greater transparency on China's handling of the virus, with numerous countries calling for an international inquiry into the pandemic's origins. China has previously rejected similar calls, accusing the US of politicizing the issue.

site_title: Australia annoyed as US pushes Wuhan lab Covid-19 theory
summary: Australian officials are frustrated with the US pushing the theory that the COVID-19 coronavirus originated from a Chinese lab, undermining their push for an independent inquiry. The US move has given China leverage to argue that Australia's request is part of a US-led agenda to blame it. This comes as Australia navigates strained relations with China, its major trading partner, while successfully managing the pandemic and planning to reopen its economy.

site_title: German spy agency doubts US 'China lab' coronavirus accusations: report
summary: Germany's BND spy agency has cast doubt on US allegations that the COVID-19 coronavirus originated in a Chinese laboratory, citing lack of evidence from the "Five Eyes" intelligence alliance. US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo made the accusation, but none of the alliance's members, including the US, supported it. The German report suggests the accusations are an attempt to divert attention from US failure to control the disease.

site_title: Seoul: Shares end higher on hopes of easing in US-China tensions
summary: South Korean shares rose 0.89% on Friday, closing at 1,945.82, driven by hopes of easing US-China tensions and optimism over the re-opening of economies. A phone call between top US and Chinese trade representatives discussed their Phase 1 trade deal, with China agreeing to improve the atmosphere for its implementation. Foreigners were net buyers of $35.91 million worth of shares, and the KOSPI has gained 23.1% in the past 30 trading sessions, despite a 11.46% decline this year.

site_title: MAS bans 2 ex-bank staff, 2 ex-insurance agents for fraud, dishonest conduct
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has issued prohibition orders against four former financial professionals for fraudulent and dishonest conduct. Kale Jagdish Purushottam, a former bank representative, was banned for 25 years for forging signatures and transferring $10 million from clients' accounts. Liaw Tick Kwan, a former bank representative, was banned for 10 years for using a client's bank account without authorization. Priscilla Tien Ling and Mike Chew Jun Yong, former insurance agents, were banned for six years each for cheating their employer of $3,700 and $1,750.

site_title: Broker's take: DBS downgrades NetLink to 'hold' on limited upside
summary: DBS Group Research downgraded NetLink NBN Trust to "hold" and raised its target price to S$1.02, citing limited upside potential. The stock has outperformed the Straits Times Index by 25% year-to-date, driven by its decent 5.2% yield and lower gearing. Analysts expect the yield to rise modestly over the next 12 months, but NetLink's regulatory weighted average cost of capital may be revised down, potentially cutting future distributions. The stock is expected to benefit from StarHub's fibre migration and growing market share in the non-residential fibre business.

site_title: Shanghai Disneyland tickets sold out in minutes for reopening
summary: Shanghai Disneyland sold out of tickets for its May 11 reopening, with tickets selling out in minutes, indicating consumer readiness to spend as China recovers from the coronavirus pandemic. The theme park is limiting visitors to one-third of its normal capacity due to safety measures, including social distancing and increased sanitization. The sellout marks a tentative step toward Disney's recovery from the global health crisis, which affected its US$1.4 billion profit last quarter.

site_title: SIAEC Q4 net profit up 5.9%, operating performance helped by govt support schemes
summary: SIA Engineering Company (SIAEC) reported a 5.9% year-on-year rise in net profit to S$52.2 million for the Q4 period, driven by government support schemes. Revenue fell 10.4% to S$229.3 million, while expenditure decreased 9.1% due to reduced staff costs. The company cut its final dividend to five cents per share, citing the need to conserve cash amid the Covid-19 pandemic. For the full year, net profit increased 20.4% to S$193.8 million. SIAEC's recovery will depend on the return of air traffic movement at Changi Airport.

site_title: Japan's Nomura posts Q4 loss as global markets tumble
summary: Japan's Nomura Holdings, the country's largest brokerage and investment bank, reported its first quarterly loss in five quarters due to the coronavirus pandemic's impact on global stock markets. The company posted a Q4 net loss of 34.5 billion yen, with its asset management division and wholesale segment experiencing losses. However, the retail division saw a significant increase in pretax income, more than 5 times that from the previous year. Net profit for the year ended March came in at 217 billion yen, lower than the estimated 276 billion yen.

site_title: Bitcoin tops US$10,000 for first time since February pre-halving
summary: Bitcoin surpassed US$10,000 for the first time since February 24, reaching a high of US$10,070, before falling to US$9,974. The cryptocurrency's price surge is attributed to sentiment-driven trading ahead of its upcoming halving on May 12, when miner rewards will be cut in half. Institutional investors, including Paul Jones, have shown interest in Bitcoin as a hedge against inflation, despite the cryptocurrency's volatility. Experts predict a short-term pullback after the halving, but expect significant price appreciation in the longer term, with some predicting a price increase toward the end of 2020 and early 2021.

site_title: South Korea tracks new coronavirus outbreak in Seoul nightclubs
summary: South Korea is investigating a growing coronavirus outbreak linked to several Seoul nightclubs, with at least 15 confirmed cases. Authorities have identified 1,500 people who visited the clubs and are urging them to self-isolate and get tested. The cluster has raised concerns over the potential impact of South Korea's contact tracing measures, which include disclosing personal information of those infected, and the possible unintended side effects of stigmatizing the LGBTQ community. The government has asked people to refrain from visiting the clubs and has amended headlines to remove references to "gay bars."

site_title: US drillers expected to slash operating oil and gas rigs to lowest ever
summary: US oil and gas drillers are expected to slash operating rigs to the lowest ever, with the current count expected to hit a record low of 404 units, according to Baker Hughes. The industry has cut an average of 55 rigs per week since mid-March due to a 30% decline in global fuel demand and a global glut. Analysts project companies will keep pulling rigs for the rest of the year and be hesitant to activate new units in 2021 and 2022, with some expecting the oil and gas rig count to collapse from 800 to 200 by the end of 2020.

site_title: Asia: Stocks rise as reopening, easing China-US tensions trump bad data
summary: Global stocks rose Friday as investors looked past disappointing economic data and focused on easing lockdown measures and China-US tensions easing. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq hit fresh records, with the Nasdaq running into positive territory for 2020. China and the US agreed to implement a partial trade deal, boosting markets. Economists warn of more pain to come, but analysts say gains could continue as economies reopen.

images.alt_text: Moves to ease lockdown measures and reopen economies around the world fired equity markets Friday as investors looked past a string of depressing data suggesting the planet is heading for its worst downturn since the Great Depression.

site_title: Australian banks defer payments on A$200b of loans
summary: Australian banks have deferred payments on at least A$200 billion in loans due to the economic shutdown caused by the novel coronavirus. A total of 643,000 loans have been deferred, with 100,000 in the last week alone. The Reserve Bank of Australia forecasts economic output will dive by 10% in the first half of the year, with unemployment almost doubling to around 10%. Major banks have lifted loss provisions, cut dividends, and raised fresh capital to tide through the crisis. The economic shutdown continues to impact households and businesses across the country.

site_title: Japan eyes another stimulus package as pandemic crushes economy
summary: Japan is considering another stimulus package as the country's economy continues to suffer from the coronavirus pandemic. The government has already compiled a $1.1 trillion economic stimulus package in April and is looking into additional measures, including rent relief for businesses and help for university students. However, the ruling coalition lawmakers are pushing for more assistance, and the sticking point is how to pay for it, with some lawmakers demanding a second supplementary budget. The economy is expected to shrink for a second straight quarter, meeting the technical definition of a recession.

site_title: 768 new coronavirus cases in Singapore, taking total past 21,000
summary: Singapore has reported 768 new coronavirus cases, bringing the total to 21,707. The majority of cases are among migrant workers living in dormitories. Singapore now has the highest number of coronavirus cases in South-east Asia, following a surge in recent weeks.

site_title: Siemens sees bigger hit from coronavirus impact coming as Q2 profit plunges
summary: Siemens has significantly revised its Q2 profit expectations due to the ongoing coronavirus pandemic, citing a 18% drop in industrial profit and a "moderate decline" in comparable full-year revenue. The company's flagship factory automation unit and smart infrastructure business are expected to be the hardest hit. Siemens has ditched its previous guidance and now anticipates even stronger impacts from the pandemic in the coming weeks.

site_title: India firms leaning more on Japan banks amid funding freeze
summary: India's top companies are increasingly turning to Japanese lenders for funding due to a dollar market freeze. The nation's biggest firms have raised a record 181 billion yen (S$2.41 billion) from yen-denominated loans this year. With benchmark sovereign yields in Japan falling below zero, Japanese banks are seeking higher-yielding assets, making yen loans relatively cheap. Indian companies, struggling to access overseas loans for refinancing, are relying on Japanese banks to meet their debt needs, with offshore debt bill reaching an unprecedented US$31 billion this year.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close higher on virus hopes
summary: Tokyo stocks closed higher on Friday, driven by hopes for easing US coronavirus lockdown measures. The Nikkei 225 index rose 2.56% to 20,179.09, while the Topix index increased 2.21% to 1,458.28. Investors focused on the potential relaxation of lockdowns in parts of the US, overshadowing grim economic news.

site_title: South Korea virus response pushes Moon rating to historic high
summary: South Korean President Moon Jae-in's approval rating reached a record high of 71% in a Gallup Korea tracking poll, surpassing previous records. The surge in support comes as new infections in South Korea have fallen to single digits, allowing the government to ease social distancing measures and reopen schools. The increase in support is attributed to the government's effective handling of the coronavirus outbreak and the largest parliamentary election victory for Moon's progressive ruling coalition since the end of military-backed rule.

site_title: After surprise apology, Samsung heir pressed to explain family's intentions
summary: Samsung Group heir Jay Y. Lee made a surprise apology and announced he will not pass the company founded by his grandfather to his children, vowing to end dynastic succession. However, the move sparked skepticism over its effectiveness in preventing future misconduct, with critics calling for more specific details on how Lee plans to prevent misconduct. The announcement sent shockwaves through South Korea's corporate elite, dominated by a handful of families that wield huge political and economic power.

site_title: Expats in Singapore ask for rent cuts as employers face squeeze
summary: Singapore expats are seeking rent cuts due to salary reductions caused by the COVID-19 pandemic. Seven expats have requested rent reductions, with four being successful, with some seeing a 7% reduction. The city-state's expensive property market, dominated by overseas renters, is exacerbating the issue. Landlords are often unwilling to accept large rent reductions, with some citing short supply of apartments or mortgage payments. The government's support measures primarily target local citizens, leaving expats to seek alternative solutions.

site_title: Traders cry foul from loss on SIA leveraged shorts over ex-right pricing
summary: Traders in Singapore's 5x Short Singapore Airlines (SIA) daily leverage certificates (DLCs) lost their entire positions when SIA shares rose 20% after trading ex-rights. The issue lies with Societe Generale's (SocGen) formula to adjust for ex-rights, which gave traders little time to hedge. The unexpected price adjustment, announced before market hours, resulted in significant losses for traders. This has raised concerns about the fairness of the process and the potential for future disputes.

site_title: Malaysian Speaker accepts Mahathir's request for no confidence motion against Muhyiddin
summary: Malaysia's former Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad has received approval from Parliament's Speaker to start a no-confidence motion against his successor Muhyiddin Yasssin. The motion, which Mahathir requested, will be presented at a future session, likely on May 18. Mahathir's abrupt resignation in February led to Muhyiddin's appointment as prime minister, which Mahathir called a betrayal. The opposition coalition, led by Anwar Ibrahim, had previously decided to delay the motion to focus on the coronavirus pandemic and economic recovery.

site_title: Kingsoft IPO raises US$510m, in first China IPO in US since virus outbreak
summary: Chinese cloud computing company Kingsoft Cloud Holdings raised US$510 million in its US initial public offering (IPO), the first Chinese company to list in the US since the coronavirus pandemic. The IPO, priced at US$17 per share, valued the company at US$3.7 billion. Kingsoft offers cloud infrastructure, enterprise cloud, and artificial intelligence services, which have seen increased demand due to the pandemic. The company's shares will trade on the Nasdaq stock exchange under the symbol "KC."

site_title: Uber leads US$170m investment in e-scooter rental firm Lime
summary: Uber has led a $170 million investment in e-scooter rental company Lime, valuing the company at $510 million. As part of the deal, Lime acquired Uber's Jump bike-sharing business operations and the two companies will expand their mobile app integration. Lime's new CEO, Wayne Ting, previously worked at Uber, and the investment is seen as a bet on Lime's future success. The company is reeling from declining customer numbers and company-wide layoffs, but expects to be profitable by next year as cities begin to adopt more sustainable transportation options.

images.alt_text: Uber Technologies is leading an investment round of US$170 million in e-scooter rental company Lime, a lifeline for a startup reeling from plunging customer numbers and company-wide layoffs.

site_title: Thai Q1 GDP 'not good'; Q2 will be worse: deputy PM
summary: Thailand's economy in the first quarter is not good, with exports and tourism being key drivers that are weak due to the global economic downturn caused by the coronavirus pandemic. Deputy Prime Minister Somkid Jatusripitak stated that the domestic economy needs to be boosted, without providing specific forecasts. The country's official first-quarter GDP data will be released on May 18, and it is expected to worsen in the second quarter.

site_title: Buyout giant CVC eyes soccer deals from Germany to France: sources
summary: European buyout giant CVC Capital Partners is considering investments in German, French, and Italian soccer leagues, including the Bundesliga and Ligue 1, amid the coronavirus pandemic. CVC has offered financial support to the German national soccer league DFL, potentially buying a stake in its commercial arm or providing debt financing. The firm is also examining a potential purchase of a stake in French soccer team AS Monaco. These deals could help sports businesses cope with revenue pressures due to the pandemic, which has led to the cancellation of several sports seasons and a decrease in broadcast revenues.

site_title: Air New Zealand to boost capacity as virus curbs ease, but higher fares expected
summary: Air New Zealand plans to increase domestic capacity to 20% of usual levels once pandemic restrictions are eased, but will not offer its lowest fares due to social distancing measures. The airline will operate to most domestic airports at Alert Level 2, but will sell only 65% of seats. The International Air Transport Association (IATA) has opposed the practice of leaving middle seats empty. Air New Zealand's domestic flight frequencies will remain reduced, and the airline is facing financial challenges due to the pandemic, with nearly 300 pilots made redundant or taking early retirement.

site_title: Australia to defer banking inquiry recommendations for 6 months
summary: Australia's conservative government has deferred the implementation of 76 recommendations from a 2019 inquiry into the country's financial sector for six months, citing the need to support customers through the Covid-19 pandemic. The decision allows banks to focus on supporting customers rather than implementing the recommendations. The government cited the expected unemployment rate of over 10% and the need for banks to prioritize customer support during this time. The implementation of the recommendations is now expected to occur in February 2021.

site_title: UN chief says coronavirus has sparked 'tsunami of hate and xenophobia'
summary: UN Secretary-General Antonio Guterres has called for an "all-out effort" to end the "tsunami of hate and xenophobia" sparked by the coronavirus pandemic. He cited a surge in anti-foreigner sentiment, anti-Semitic conspiracy theories, and attacks against migrants and refugees. Guterres also targeted online hate speech, calling on social media companies to remove racist content and educational institutions to teach digital literacy. He appealed for a global effort to combat hate speech, particularly towards vulnerable groups, and journalists doing their jobs.

site_title: Japan businesses reopen as govt eyes end to emergency measures in some regions
summary: Japan is easing coronavirus restrictions in some regions as the number of new infections significantly falls. Economy Minister Yasutoshi Nishimura announced plans to lift lockdown measures in prefectures with zero daily infections. Businesses, including Uniqlo and Aeon, have begun reopening operations, with 8 prefectures already lifted and 17 planning to do so next week. Japan has confirmed 15,500 infections and 590 deaths, and the government will reassess the situation on May 14.

site_title: HDB resale flat volume falls 78.3% in April; only 423 units changed hands amid circuit breaker measures
summary: HDB resale flat volumes plummeted 78.3% in April, with only 423 units sold amid circuit breaker measures. This represents a 78.1% drop from last year. Resale prices also fell, with declines of 1.5% for three-room flats, 0.2% for four-room flats, and 1.8% for executive flats. Experts predict flat sales will pick up when house viewings resume, with possible decreases of up to 25% this year.

site_title: Jobless Americans can only hang on as pandemic rages
summary: The US economy is struggling due to the coronavirus pandemic, with unemployment skyrocketing and many Americans losing their jobs. Three individuals, Laya Hamilton, Sandra Mahesh, and Evan White, share their personal stories of job loss and financial struggles. Hamilton, a 23-year-old bartender, is surviving on her savings after her unemployment claim was delayed. Mahesh, a 57-year-old former front desk worker, is fighting to receive unemployment benefits after being cut off due to a supposed job change. White, a 35-year-old sommelier, is working remotely and taking classes on wine certification while waiting for the restaurant industry to recover. The pandemic has left many Americans feeling uncertain about their financial futures.

site_title: China, US commit to implement trade deal despite virus row: official
summary: China and the US have agreed to create favorable conditions for the implementation of their phase one trade deal, despite recent tensions over the coronavirus pandemic. Chinese Vice Premier Liu He held a call with US Trade Representative Robert Lighthizer and Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin, emphasizing macroeconomic and public health cooperation. The agreement comes after US President Donald Trump threatened new tariffs against China, citing evidence linking Covid-19 to a Chinese lab. China had agreed to import $200 billion in US products over two years in January, marking a truce in the trade war.

images.alt_text: Chinese and US trade representatives agreed on Friday to "create favourable conditions" for the phase one trade deal signed in January, Beijing officials said, despite recent tensions over the coronavirus pandemic.

site_title: Australia to provide Pacific nations rapid Covid-19 test kits
summary: Australia has provided Pacific island nations with rapid Covid-19 test kits, in a joint initiative with the World Health Organization, US, and New Zealand. The kits arrived in Fiji, Kiribati, Papua New Guinea, and Nauru, with supplies to reach nine more countries in the next two weeks. The equipment, procured and delivered with Australian support, enables faster and more effective testing, with results expected in under an hour. The move aims to support Pacific Island countries with limited in-country testing capacity.

site_title: Coronavirus deals 'powerful blow' to Putin's grand plans
summary: Russia's COVID-19 pandemic has dealt a significant blow to President Vladimir Putin's plans, including a cancelled military parade and constitutional reforms that could have prolonged his rule. The crisis has crippled Russia's economy, hospitalized the prime minister, and slashed Putin's approval ratings to a historic low of 59%. The pandemic has also led to widespread discontent among Russians, with many struggling to survive due to lockdowns and economic uncertainty, potentially fueling social unrest and protests.

site_title: US withdrawing some Patriot missile batteries from Middle East
summary: The US has removed two of its four Patriot antimissile batteries from Saudi Arabia, partly due to eased tensions with Iran, and is replacing them with Saudi Patriot batteries. The move follows a delayed redeployment schedule and a net loss of two 12-aircraft units in the region. Despite this, the US maintains robust air defense capabilities in the Middle East to address any Iran-related contingencies. The decision comes amid ongoing tensions with Iran and a long-term effort to boost regional air defenses.

images.alt_text: The US has removed two of its four Patriot antimissile batteries from Saudi Arabia and another two in the Mideast partly because tensions with Iran have eased from a peak earlier this year, according to a US official.

site_title: Indonesia weighs easing lockdown from early June to save economy
summary: Indonesian officials are considering easing the partial lockdown in early June to save the country's economy, which has grown at its lowest pace in almost two decades. The proposed "exit strategy" calls for removing social-distancing rules in five phases, with the economy completely reopened by late July or early August. The decision will be influenced by the trajectory of the virus spread, with President Joko Widodo's administration aiming to gradually reopen economies while containing the pandemic.

site_title: US: Stocks end higher, overlooking latest layoff data
summary: US stocks rose 0.9% to close at 23,875.89, driven by a focus on the economy's gradual reopening and a positive catalyst from Moderna's FDA clearance for a COVID-19 vaccine. Despite 3.2 million new jobless claims, investors looked past the data, with PayPal, Peloton, and other tech companies gaining. The S&P 500 advanced 1.2% to 2,881.19 and the Nasdaq Composite jumped 1.4% to 8,979.66.

site_title: US coronavirus deaths rise by 2,448 in 24 hours: tracker
summary: The US recorded 2,448 coronavirus deaths in the past 24 hours, bringing the total to 75,543, according to Johns Hopkins University. The country has also confirmed 1,254,750 cases.

site_title: Raffles Infra clinches Bangladesh township project valued at about US$800m
summary: RAFFLES Infrastructure Holdings clinched a US$800 million township project in Bangladesh, known as the Trust Green City project, after signing a non-binding memorandum of understanding with the Bangladesh Army Welfare Trust. The project involves 50 acres of land in Zones 2, 3, and 4 of Baunia, Dhaka.

site_title: Venezuela opposition negotiated Maduro overthrow plan with security firm: report
summary: Venezuela's opposition, led by Juan Guaido, allegedly negotiated a $213 million deal with US security firm Silvercorp USA to overthrow President Nicolas Maduro. The plan, described in a 42-page document, includes tactical details but raises questions about its feasibility. Maduro's government arrested over a dozen people, including Americans working for Silvercorp, following a failed incursion. Guaido denies any links to Silvercorp or involvement in the plot, which has damaged his credibility. Maduro's government claims the plan was a disinformation campaign by the US government.

site_title: Neighbours help out as fighting virus trumps old rivalries
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has sparked cooperation between longtime rivals in various parts of the world. In Northern Ireland, the unionist Orange Order secured a shipment of personal protective equipment for distribution across the border with the Republic of Ireland, despite their usual wary relationship. Similar acts of goodwill have been seen in Cyprus, where the government sent aid to the breakaway north, and in the Middle East, where the UAE dispatched medical supplies to Iran and Syria, despite tensions with the US and Iran. These gestures may be driven by pragmatism and a shared interest in containing the virus.

site_title: ARA H-Trust Q1 profit misses IPO forecast by 47.8% at US$8.1m
summary: ARA US Hospitality Trust (ARA H-Trust) reported a gross operating profit of US$8.1 million for its first quarter, missing its initial public offering forecast by 47.8% due to the COVID-19 outbreak's impact on the hotel industry. The trust's occupancy rate was 54.8% and gross operating profit margin was 25.5%. Despite this, the trust has adequate liquidity and has taken steps to protect its financial position, including temporarily suspending hotel operations and identifying new sales opportunities.

site_title: Australia to ease Covid-19 curbs in 3 stages, targets July for full removal
summary: Australia plans to ease COVID-19 curbs in a three-step process, aiming to fully remove restrictions by July. The country's states and territories will decide when to begin implementing each stage. Australia imposed strict social distancing measures in March, which slowed the spread of the virus. The move follows a drastic reduction in new infections. Prime Minister Scott Morrison announced the plan, but details on the stages and timelines have not been specified.

site_title: SingPost posts Q4 net profit of S$7.2m on absence of impairment
summary: SingPost posted a Q4 net profit of S$7.2 million, reversing losses from a year ago due to the absence of impairment charges from US e-commerce subsidiaries that filed for bankruptcy. The company's top line decreased 2.7% year-over-year to S$312.2 million, while revenue from post and parcel dropped 5.7%. The board recommended a final dividend of 1.2 cents per share, less than the previous year. CEO Paul Coutts expressed concerns about the economic fallout from the COVID-19 pandemic and the need to maintain a sustainable cost base.

site_title: Global luxury industry to contract between 20% and 35% in 2020: report
summary: The global luxury industry is projected to contract between 20% and 35% in 2020 due to the novel coronavirus pandemic. The market for personal luxury goods declined by 25% in the first quarter of 2020, with accessories being the most resilient category. Watches saw the largest decline due to a lack of online sales platforms. Recovery is expected to occur in 2022 or 2023, with an estimated market growth of 320-330 billion euros by 2025, with China leading the way for recovery and online sales increasing to up to 30% of the market by 2025.

site_title: Missing Bangkok, Paris tourists omen of global wheat demand collapse
summary: Bangkok and Paris tourists, major drivers of demand for Thai noodles, pastries, and pasta, have largely disappeared due to travel restrictions during the coronavirus pandemic. This decline in tourism has severely impacted the sales of Permruedee Labnongsaeng's cafe in Bangkok, with daily sales plummeting to 5% of normal levels. The collapse in global wheat demand is seen as a significant consequence of the pandemic's impact on international travel and trade.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares start Friday with gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose in the opening minutes of trade on Friday, gaining 0.89% in the Hang Seng Index to 24,193.36. Investors focused on the lifting of virus-induced lockdowns, despite bleak US jobs data. The Shanghai Composite Index added 0.39% and the Shenzhen Composite Index rose 0.48%. This uptrend comes as traders brush off new US threats to extend the stocks rally, with Asia markets generally stable amidst the uncertainty.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Singapore Airlines, OCBC, SingPost, StarHub, DBS, NetLink
summary:

site_title: Trump administration agrees to help wind farms with subsidy tweak
summary: The Trump administration has agreed to modify rules governing renewable energy tax credits, a move aimed at helping wind farm owners claim subsidies due to the coronavirus pandemic's impact on project timelines. The Treasury Department plans to extend the deadline for claiming credits for projects that started construction in 2016 or 2017. This change is expected to benefit wind energy projects primarily, with the goal of supporting the renewable sector during the economic downturn.

site_title: SIA warns of first yearly loss due to Covid-19 and fuel hedging losses
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) expects its first yearly loss due to COVID-19 and fuel hedging losses. The airline reported a net loss for the full year ending March 31, 2020, despite a small operating profit. Fuel hedging losses, exacerbated by the collapse of fuel prices, and an over-hedged position for FY2021, contributed to the loss. SIA has taken measures to cut costs, conserve cash, and adjust its delivery stream for existing aircraft orders. The airline also expects operating cash flows to remain negative during the ongoing quarter.

site_title: Tesla and Detroit automakers get green light to reopen plants
summary: Michigan Governor Gretchen Whitmer and California Governor Gavin Newsom have allowed manufacturers to reopen factories in the US, giving a boost to Tesla and Detroit's three major carmakers. Production is set to resume on May 11 and May 18 for Ford Motor, General Motors, and Fiat Chrysler Automobiles, respectively. The decision comes after weeks of uncertainty, with auto output halted in mid-March to slow the spread of the coronavirus. Manufacturers must implement safety protocols, including daily screenings and temperature checks, to protect workers.

site_title: Evacuation area around India LG Chem plant widened after deadly gas leak
summary: A deadly gas leak at the LG Chem plant in Andhra Pradesh, India, has killed at least 11 people and sickened hundreds more. The evacuation area was widened to 5km after concerns about renewed emissions from the plant, but LG Chem claims there was no second leak. The company is taking precautions, including putting water into the tank, and shares have fallen 2.4% in early trade. The leak occurred while the plant was reopening after a lockdown due to the COVID-19 pandemic.

site_title: New Zealand says it backs Taiwan's role in WHO due to success with coronavirus
summary: New Zealand's Finance Minister Grant Robertson expressed support for Taiwan's role in the World Health Organization (WHO) due to its success in limiting the spread of the coronavirus. Despite China's objections, Taiwan has been an observer at the WHO in the past and has employed effective methods of dealing with the virus. Robertson stated that Taiwan has a lot to offer, particularly its epidemiologists and public health experts, and that there is room for them to be part of the WHO again, especially in the post-Covid-19 crisis.

site_title: Vegan rivals smell blood as virus hits meat supply
summary: US slaughterhouse closures due to the coronavirus have led to a surge in prices of conventional protein, creating an opportunity for plant-based meat producers to gain market share. At least 18 meat processing plants have been temporarily closed, increasing demand for plant-based alternatives. This shift in consumer behavior could benefit champions of plant-based meat, allowing them to win over a broader set of shoppers.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Friday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 10.77 points, or 0.78%, to 1,387.70 on Friday, driven by a higher opening. The index saw 158.52 million lots traded worth RM58.98 million, with gainers beating losers 259 to 55.

site_title: Singapore banks see hefty provisions yank down Q1 earnings
summary: Singapore banks reported lower Q1 earnings due to hefty provisions to cushion against economic stresses from the virus outbreak and oil exposure. OCBC posted a 43% drop in net profit, while DBS and UOB also saw declines. The banks expect elevated credit costs over the next 12 months, with provisions set aside for loan moratoria and potential defaults. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) provided guidance on accounting for credit losses, allowing banks to consider extraordinary fiscal support. The banks' full-year growth is expected to be flat, with a focus on maintaining a strong balance sheet and achieving sustainable earnings.

site_title: Singapore stocks edge up at Friday's open; STI up 0.1%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.1% or 1.34 points to 2,592.94 on Friday, driven by overnight gains on Wall Street and Europe.
