After assessing eight complaints, the ASA concluded that the ad was unlikely to mislead consumers.

site_title: Over 30 firms join alliance calling for 'open' 5G systems
summary: More than 30 technology and telecom firms have formed an alliance to advocate for "open and interoperable" 5G wireless systems, aiming to reduce reliance on a single supplier. This move comes as the global debate over 5G deployment continues, with Huawei, Nokia, and Ericsson leading the market. The alliance seeks to promote a more collaborative approach to 5G development, potentially challenging the dominance of these companies.

site_title: US reaches settlement to recover over US$49m involving Malaysia's 1MDB
summary: The US Department of Justice has reached a settlement to recover over $49 million involving Malaysia's 1MDB, a sovereign wealth fund. The settlement involves assets acquired by former IPIC managing director Khadem al-Qubaisi, who was sentenced to 15 years in prison for his role in the scandal. This brings the total recovered assets to nearly $1.1 billion, the largest civil forfeiture ever concluded by the agency. The settlement also requires the trustee, al-Qubaisi's wife, to cooperate in the transfer and management of the assets.

images.alt_text: The United States has reached a settlement to recover more than US$49 million involving Malaysian sovereign wealth fund 1MDB, the Department of Justice said.

site_title: Home-flipping startup Opendoor says time to resume buying
summary: Opendoor, a home-flipping startup backed by SoftBank, plans to resume buying homes in Phoenix this week and expand to over 20 additional markets. The company, which halted operations in March due to the coronavirus, aims to capitalize on the appeal of its no-physical-views service in the age of social distancing. However, resuming operations comes with risks, including debt and potential losses if the US enters a recession or experiences a second wave of the virus.

site_title: NetLink C-suite to take 8% pay cut amid Covid-19 even as payout rises
summary: NetLink NBN Trust reported a net profit of S$12.5 million for the fourth quarter, down 37.7% from the same period last year, due to a write-off of S$15.4 million in capitalised project costs. Despite the delay in fulfilling service requests, revenue rose 5.2% to S$92.4 million, driven by residential and non-residential connections. The trust's board members and top executives will take an 8% pay cut, while unitholders will receive a higher distribution of 2.53 Singapore cents per unit.

site_title: Singapore restarts mask production to secure supply for frontline medical staff
summary: Singapore has restarted local production of medical-grade surgical face masks to ensure a stable supply for its medical staff, with the goal of building up a sufficient stockpile to cater to the needs of healthcare workers. The masks will be sourced from both local and external sources, with the government prioritizing securing face masks for healthcare workers. The production ramp-up is part of efforts to maintain a sustainable healthcare system and prevent a second wave of the pandemic.

site_title: UOB's Q1 net profit falls 19% on lower margin, rising impairment
summary: United Overseas Bank (UOB) reported a 19% fall in Q1 net profit to S$855 million, driven by declining margins and a surge in impairment charges. The bank expects elevated credit costs until mid-2021 due to delayed recognition of non-performing loans. Analysts, including Citi, have raised UOB's credit cost estimates to the upper end of 50-60 basis points, citing weaker macro conditions. Despite this, the bank's CET1 ratio remains above 13.5%, supporting its dividend payout.

site_title: China's BGI gets Australian foothold through mass Covid-19 test delivery
summary: Australia has purchased 10 million novel coronavirus test kits from Chinese genomics company BGI, despite strained relations between the two countries. The deal was struck to combat the pandemic, with BGI's technology approved by Australian security agencies for use in pathology labs. Researchers hope the deal will lead to greater price competition in the biotech market, dominated by US rival Illumina Inc. BGI has faced concerns over its work in China, including gene technology used for surveillance of the Uighur ethnic minority, but Australian authorities say patient data will be protected.

images.alt_text: BGI has one lab in Australia and had been seeking to expand its genome sequencing services.

site_title: London's best offices face 15% plunge in values from pandemic hit
summary: London's top offices are forecast to decline in value by up to 15% this year due to the coronavirus pandemic's economic impact. The lockdowns will reduce prime rents by about 10% and vacancy rates are expected to rise. Shopping malls will be the worst affected, with rent declines of 12% across Europe. Apartment and warehouse rents will be more resilient, with declines of 4% and 5%, respectively. The pandemic threatens to halt a decade-long bull run for commercial property, with the global co-head of DWS Group warning of increased job losses and business failures.

site_title: Bond-buying risks could outweigh rewards for emerging market central banks
summary: Emerging market central banks are launching asset purchase programs to combat the economic impact of coronavirus, a test of unconventional policy tools. A dozen countries, including Chile and the Philippines, have launched or boosted quantitative easing schemes to buy government bonds and stimulate lending and investment. However, some former policymakers warn that these programs could have unintended consequences, such as deterring foreign investors and increasing credit risk. Analysts caution that emerging markets lack the domestic savings pools seen in developed countries, making them vulnerable to market fluctuations and inflation.

site_title: Young May Day travellers raise hope for China's tourism
summary: China's tourism sector showed signs of recovery over the May Day holiday, with 115 million trips made, a 41% drop from last year. The majority of travelers (60%+) were by car, and over half of bookings for Trip.com's holiday packages were made by those born in 1990 or later. This marks a hopeful sign for the industry, with travel operators and authorities expressing confidence in the sector's recovery. Revenue earned by travel operators reached 47.56 billion yuan (S$9.66 billion) over the holiday.

site_title: DBS prices Singapore's first notes referencing Sora benchmark
summary: DBS Bank has priced its first Singapore Overnight Rate Average (Sora)-referenced floating-rate notes, an industry first. The S$20 million notes, due in 2021, will bear a coupon rate of compounded daily Sora + 0.65 percentage point per annum. This move is in line with Singapore's roadmap to develop Sora-based markets, following the discontinuation of the London Interbank Offered Rate (Libor) at end-2021. DBS will use the net proceeds for general business purposes, and the bank's group corporate treasurer said it's an important step in promoting Sora-based products.

site_title: Innosparks to focus on making masks for local use for now
summary: Singapore's Innosparks, a unit of ST Engineering, is focusing on producing surgical face masks for local medical workers due to the COVID-19 pandemic. The company, which has been supplying N95 masks internationally since 2015, has shifted its priority to meet the local demand. Innosparks aims to supply all healthcare workers in Singapore with surgical masks, despite initial challenges in securing raw materials. The company is "on track" to meet its goal, citing its track record of innovation and expertise in respiratory mask manufacturing.

images.alt_text: ST Engineering unit Innosparks, which according to Trade and Industry Minister Chan Chun Sing has "made possible" the local production of surgical face masks, is not ruling out exporting its masks globally.

site_title: South-east Asia's tech sector will bounce back
summary: Singapore's tech sector is expected to bounce back first among the region, despite the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic. The country's preparedness from past outbreaks, such as Sars and avian flu, will aid its recovery. In contrast, growth in the Asian region is expected to slow sharply to around 2% this year.

site_title: Australia targeting Covid-19-safe economy by July: Prime Minister
summary: Australia aims to have a Covid-19-safe economy up and running by July, with cafes, restaurants, and retail expected to reopen first under strict social distancing rules. The country has had fewer than 7,000 confirmed cases and 96 deaths. A three-stage reopening plan is in place, with pubs likely to be among the last to fully reopen. The government seeks to get one million unemployed people working again, with the goal of achieving a sustainable Covid-19-safe economy.

site_title: Kondo eyes tidying up your work arena too
summary: Marie Kondo, a Japanese minimalist, is releasing a new book titled "Joy At Work" that aims to tidy up employees' workspaces and job satisfaction. According to Kondo, studies show that organized workers are more likely to gain trust and get promoted. Local life coaches and HR experts offer tips on incorporating her advice into work routines, despite some skepticism about its effectiveness.

site_title: Australia ties up with airlines to carry produce, seafood to Asian markets
summary: Australia has reached agreements with Singapore Airlines and Qantas Airways to carry produce and seafood to Asian markets, as part of a government initiative to support businesses affected by the coronavirus. Qantas will begin a weekly flight from Queensland to Hong Kong on Thursday, while Singapore Airlines will carry produce from South Australia. This move aims to increase exports and stimulate economic growth in the country.

site_title: HK testing travellers' saliva in fight to control Covid-19
summary: Hong Kong has begun testing travelers' saliva to control COVID-19, raising concerns about the collection and use of sensitive biodata. The practice, which started with non-residents, involves passengers spitting into a container and having their samples analyzed for the virus. The data, including the results, will be stored in a government database, sparking worries among privacy experts that the information could be accessed by hackers or repressive governments. The Hong Kong government claims it will dispose of the saliva samples according to laboratory protocols, but critics argue that the practice could lead to permanent surveillance and erosion of personal privacy.

site_title: Trump pivots to 'phase two' of reopening, risking more deaths to save economy
summary: US President Donald Trump announced a plan to "phase two" of reopening the nation, despite acknowledging that it would cause more illness and death from the pandemic. He will disband the White House task force of public health experts, shifting the focus to economic recovery. Trump insists that the economic cost is worth the risk, despite warnings from health experts. The move is seen as a significant shift in his approach to the pandemic, prioritizing economic growth over public health concerns.

site_title: Singapore digibank hopefuls staying the course amid pandemic
summary: Singapore's Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has confirmed that 21 digital banking applicants remain in the running for licenses despite the COVID-19 pandemic. Seven are vying for digital full bank licenses, while 14 are competing for digital wholesale bank licenses. The MAS has stated that the applicants' financial strength will be a key consideration, with a "path towards profitability" required for full bank licenses. The MAS has also maintained its plan to issue up to two digital full bank and three digital wholesale bank licenses, with a focus on fintechs, e-commerce, and technology companies.

site_title: StarHub CEO hopes for year-end pick-up as management scraps earnings guidance
summary: StarHub's first-quarter earnings fell 25.7% to S$40.2 million, despite mobile and broadband subscriber gains. Revenue declined 15.2% to S$506.2 million, with service revenue down 8.9% and the enterprise segment being the only division to post turnover gains. The company scrapped its earnings guidance, citing the impact of the coronavirus pandemic. CEO Peter Kaliaropoulos expects users to return to bundles as new handsets hit the market, but warned that revenue will fall in most lines of business.

site_title: Fintech startup Nium in fresh round of equity funding that also ropes in new investors Visa, BRI Ventures
summary: Fintech startup Nium has secured a fresh round of equity funding, joined by new investors Visa and BRI Ventures. The funding will be used to broaden its reach in new and existing markets, product development, and acquisitions. Nium aims to be profitable by the second half of next year and hit $100 million in revenue by 2023, potentially paving the way for a public listing. The company, which operates in over 90 countries, expects a 15-20% softening of gross merchandise value in the second quarter but anticipates transactions to pick up in the third quarter.

site_title: Indonesia warns of Covid-19 poverty setback
summary: Indonesia's finance minister, Sri Mulyani Indrawati, warns that COVID-19 has set the country's poverty eradication efforts back by a decade, with 2 million people losing their jobs in six weeks. The poverty rate, which was 9.22% in September 2019, is now expected to increase, and economic growth is forecast to slow to 2.3% this year. The government has postponed regional elections due to concerns about the spread of the virus, and President Joko Widodo has ordered measures to flatten the epidemiological curve to revive economic activity.

site_title: US, UK probing hacking into Covid-19 research
summary: The US and UK are investigating hacking incidents targeting organizations involved in Covid-19 research, including pharmaceutical companies and universities. Advanced Persistent Threat (APT) groups, likely backed by nation-states, are actively targeting these organizations to obtain sensitive data and intelligence on Covid-19 policy and research. The joint alert warns of increased cyber-attacks, including ransomware and phishing campaigns, as hackers seek to capitalize on the pandemic. Hackers use password spraying techniques to breach computer networks, posing a threat to organizations involved in Covid-19 research.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: First Reit posted a distribution per unit (DPU) of 1.86 Singapore cents for the three months ended March 31, 2020, down from 2.15 cents a year ago. Frasers Property announced leadership changes for its Australia business, with Anthony Boyd taking over as CEO and Rod Fehring becoming executive chairman. SPH Reit granted full rental waivers for April and May to eligible tenants, funded by the Reit itself, and will pass on government property tax rebates to tenants.

site_title: Regulators allow rights, takeover documents to disseminate electronically till Sept 30
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore, the Securities Industry Council, and the Singapore Exchange Regulation have introduced temporary measures allowing companies to disseminate rights, takeover, and merger documents electronically until September 30. Listed issuers can publish documents on SGXNet and corporate websites, reducing physical manpower requirements and aligning with COVID-19 measures. Issuers must still send hardcopy notifications and application forms, encouraging electronic methods. This move aims to minimize disruptions and facilitate the dissemination of important information.

site_title: Volkswagen's demand in China rebounds
summary: Volkswagen reports a rebound in demand in China, with sales exceeding year-earlier levels in the last week of April, driven by customers switching from public transport to personal vehicles. However, the company warns that sales will not recover as quickly in other parts of the world, including Europe, where demand is patchy and expected to take longer to recover. In contrast, northern European countries are experiencing stronger demand, with pre-booking for Volkswagen's ID 3 electric car reaching 37,000 vehicles, mainly in Germany.

site_title: Bangkok's millionaires' club enjoys lockdown luxury
summary: Thailand's wealthy elite continue to enjoy luxury during the pandemic, with high-end meals delivered by butlers in black sedans. The Silver Voyage Club, a concierge company, offers gourmet takeaways from top restaurants to its high-net-worth clients, who have at least $1 million in their bank accounts. The company donates 1,000 meals daily to frontline workers. Despite economic contraction forecasts, the pandemic has not deterred Bangkok's millionaires from their lavish lifestyle, with some restaurants struggling to survive due to reduced customer numbers and high commission fees.

site_title: Jack Ma's online bank plans lending spree of 2 trillion yuan
summary: Jack Ma's online bank, MYbank, is on track to issue a record 2 trillion yuan (S$400 billion) in new loans to small and medium-sized companies this year, up 18% from 2019. The move aims to revive China's economy from its pandemic-induced slump, but raises concerns about risk for MYbank and its largest shareholder, Jack Ma's Ant Financial. Analysts note that the lending surge aligns with Chinese government efforts, but also tests MYbank's loan algorithms and credit quality, which have seen a recent uptick in delinquencies.

site_title: Storm clouds gather as EU-China mark 45 years of diplomatic ties
summary: The European Union and China mark 45 years of diplomatic ties, but tensions have risen due to the novel coronavirus crisis. EU foreign affairs chief Josep Borrell accused Beijing of pressuring Brussels to dilute criticism of China's disinformation in an EU report. The crisis has fueled concerns in Brussels that China is "dividing and ruling" to undermine the continent's collective interests. Despite tensions, both sides stress areas of common interest, such as an open multilateral trading system and cooperation on climate change, which they see as a key driver of the Paris agreement.

site_title: Higher fares and uncertainty could delay air travel's return to normalcy
summary: Global air travel's return to normalcy is uncertain due to higher fares and safety concerns. Aviation experts predict it may take 18-24 months for demand to pick up, and a safe and effective vaccine is needed for travelers to feel confident flying. Airlines are implementing safety measures such as mask mandates, screening, and deep cleaning, but the International Air Transport Association (Iata) has rejected the idea of restricting middle seat sales, citing low risk of virus transmission. The industry is caught in a "no-man's land" where travelers are hesitant to fly due to costs and airlines struggle to operate with reduced capacity.

site_title: STI continues climb in line with most key indices in Asia
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) rose 19.24 points or 0.75% to 2,591.60 on Wednesday, following Tuesday's slim gains. Jardine Matheson Holdings led the STI's best performers, while Singapore Airlines saw its shares close 5.7% above the theoretical ex-rights price after ex-rights trading began. In contrast, Japan Foods shed 5 cents to S$0.30, with RHB Securities Singapore cutting its earnings forecasts due to ongoing safe distancing measures affecting the company's food and beverage brands.

site_title: Australia's March retail sales surge, mostly due to price jump
summary: Australia's retail sales surged in March due to panic buying of essentials like toilet rolls and food, with prices driving the increase rather than volume. This economic windfall was short-lived, as strict social distancing measures and business closures likely led to a decline in sales in April. The Reserve Bank of Australia will closely monitor the situation.

site_title: Euro zone business activity grounds to near-halt in April
summary: Euro zone business activity nearly came to a halt in April due to government-imposed lockdowns to combat the coronavirus, with factories shutting, shops and restaurants closing, and recreational activities ceasing. The coronavirus has infected over 3.6 million people and killed over 250,000 globally. This significant economic downturn has severely disrupted supply chains.

site_title: More mortgagee listings go under hammer but buyers come up empty as sellers refuse to blink
summary: Singapore's mortgagee listings and auction sales declined 31.1% in Q1 2020, with only one property sold at auction, as sellers refuse to lower prices due to economic uncertainty. Buyers expect 5-8% price drops, but Knight Frank says the market is at a standstill, with banks holding back on mortgage repayments. Mortgage relief measures will last until Dec 31, and the market is expected to follow a "Nike swoosh" recovery, with prices dropping gently. Chinese buyers, in particular, are shying away from Hong Kong and preferring Singapore, where they seek spacious landed properties and are willing to pay up to S$8-9 million.

site_title: Hong Leong approves loan-relief application from 500th customer, closes 20 branches
summary: Hong Leong Finance has approved loan-relief applications from 500 customers, including 300 local businesses and 200 retail customers, to date. The finance company has made available loan-payment deferment relief and reduced interest rates for certain loans, with more customers opting to go digital during the circuit-breaker period. As a result, Hong Leong Finance has closed 20 branches and seven SME Centres, but remains open with shortened operating hours. The company aims to support customers with loan-relief schemes to weather the crisis.

site_title: US private payrolls dive by a record 20.2 million
summary: US private employers laid off a record 20.236 million workers in April due to mandatory business closures in response to the COVID-19 pandemic. The job losses were across small, medium, and large enterprises, with the leisure and hospitality industry accounting for 40% of the private sector job losses. Economists predict a long recovery, with some forecasting the economy may not return to normal within the next couple of years.

site_title: Disney tests reopening strategy at Shanghai Disneyland next week
summary: Disney is set to reopen Shanghai Disneyland on May 11 with limited capacity, adhering to strict social distancing measures and government health protocols. The park will operate at 24,000 daily guests, below the Chinese government's limit of 80,000. Disney aims to test new procedures, including advanced reservation and entry systems, to recover from the pandemic. Other parks and stores are expected to reopen, but timing is uncertain, and the company has furloughed over 120,000 employees to reduce overhead costs.

site_title: Redas donates 200,000 care packs, 800 fans to Migrant Workers Centre
summary: Redas, the Real Estate Developers Association of Singapore, donated 200,000 care packs and 800 standing fans to the Migrant Workers Centre. The gifts were given to foreign workers living in factory-converted dormitories affected by the Covid-19 pandemic. The initiative was made possible through a fund set up by Redas to support those in the community most affected by the pandemic. The donations aim to provide essential items to migrant workers.

site_title: Great Eastern Q1 earnings tumble 90% on non-operating losses
summary: Great Eastern Holdings reported a 90% drop in net profit to S$33.9 million in Q1 2020, primarily due to non-operating losses of S$222.8 million. Despite this, operating profit doubled to S$298.6 million, driven by increased contributions from core markets and a reduction in insurance contract liabilities. The group expects new business activity to be dampened by the Covid-19 outbreak, but its digital and technology initiatives have helped cushion the impact.

site_title: Australia ties up with SIA, Qantas to carry produce, seafood to Asian markets
summary: Australia has reached agreements with Singapore Airlines (SIA) and Qantas Airways to carry produce and seafood to Asian markets, supporting local exporters hit hard by the coronavirus pandemic. Qantas will begin a weekly flight from Queensland to Hong Kong, while SIA will carry food from South Australia to Singapore and later to Hong Kong, Thailand, and China. The A$1 billion government fund will support regions and industries affected by the pandemic. This move aims to re-establish direct freight routes and help exporters navigate the post-pandemic market.

site_title: Uber reducing workforce by 14%, signals more cuts
summary: Uber is reducing its workforce by 14% through 3,700 job eliminations and permanently closing 180 driver service centers, mainly in support and recruiting roles. This move is part of the company's cost-cutting measures in response to the coronavirus pandemic, which has significantly reduced ridership. The closures of 40% of Uber's 450 driver centers, known as Greenlight Hubs, will also be implemented. The company's CEO, Dara Khosrowshahi, has signaled that more "difficult adjustments" will be made in the coming weeks.

site_title: HSBC targets Singapore oil trader as loan concerns escalate
summary: HSBC is seeking judicial management of Singapore-based oil trader ZenRock Commodities Trading Pte Ltd due to a $600 million loan exposure, amid escalating concerns over Hin Leong's $4 billion debt to 23 banks. ZenRock has denied insolvency and is negotiating a consensual restructuring with other creditor banks. The move highlights tensions between traders and banks due to plunging oil prices and a pandemic slump in crude demand.

site_title: Tough times to shutter Robinsons' Jem outlet
summary: Robinsons Singapore is closing its Jurong outlet in Jem, a suburb in Jurong East, by the end of August. This move follows discussions with its landlord Lendlease, which started in November. The department store, with a 162-year history, is trimming its physical footprint. The decision marks another sign that the department store model may be becoming increasingly untenable. Robinsons Singapore has not disclosed the reasons behind the closure.

site_title: What Covid-19's damage to emerging economies means
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic is having a devastating impact on emerging economies in Asia and Africa, with major retail corporations in developed markets cancelling orders with suppliers in countries like Bangladesh and Vietnam, affecting millions of employees. This disruption is likely to lead to mass unemployment, a grim economic outlook, and a shift in politics, with social development and modernization being put on hold. As a result, social divisions will increase, leading to more authoritarianism, and corporates will need to better understand their supply chains, including security and political risks.

site_title: EU faces historic recession as China, US spar over virus origins
summary: The European Union forecast a historic 7.7% recession due to the COVID-19 pandemic, with the eurozone economy expected to contract. Governments worldwide are lifting lockdown measures, but a deadly second wave of the virus is a concern. China and the US are in a war of words over the virus origins, with China denying allegations of a lab origin. The US Secretary of State claims "enormous evidence" supports the theory, while China's envoy to the UN says an investigation should wait until the crisis is over.

site_title: WHO warns of new lockdowns if transition not managed carefully
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) warns that returning to lockdowns is a risk if countries don't manage the transition from pandemic restrictions carefully and in a phased approach. Director-General Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus listed steps needed before lifting measures, including surveillance controls and health system preparedness.

site_title: Full extent of Covid-19 damage will emerge after relief measures expire
summary: Singapore's Covid-19 relief measures are set to expire, potentially revealing the full extent of the pandemic's economic damage. The Covid-19 (Temporary Measures) Act provides liquidity support to struggling companies, but experts warn that this will only delay the inevitable, with companies likely needing restructuring or liquidation. As the support measures run out, companies may face permanent change, loan impairments, and job losses, with lenders playing a key role in deciding which companies survive. The true extent of the damage is expected to emerge in October, when the six-month statutory demand period ends.

site_title: Sentosa Development Corporation to get new CEO from June 1
summary: The Sentosa Development Corporation (SDC) will appoint Ms Thien Kwee Eng, 49, as its new CEO on June 1, succeeding Mr Quek Swee Kuan, 55, who will retire on May 31. Ms Thien is currently the executive vice-president of the Economic Development Board (EDB) and has held various leadership roles in investment promotion and industry development. Her appointment is seen as a strategic move to strengthen Sentosa's value proposition and increase visitor numbers.

site_title: Shopify sales surge shows business embraced online reality
summary: Shopify reported first-quarter revenue of US$470 million, exceeding analyst estimates by 6.3%, as businesses rapidly shifted online during the coronavirus pandemic. Sales grew 47% from the same quarter last year, with gross merchandise volume increasing 46% to US$17.4 billion. Despite this, Shopify noted a drop in point-of-sale purchases from bricks-and-mortar stores and questioned the sustainability of some online switches. The company's market value reached C$113.4 billion, making it the second-most valuable Canadian company.

site_title: Cedele, Goodman Environmental Group fined for breaching Covid-19 safe distancing measures
summary: Singapore's Enterprise Singapore fined two companies, Goodman Environmental Group and The Bakery Depot (Cedele), S$1,000 each for breaching Covid-19 safe distancing measures at their workplaces. Goodman Environmental Group failed to enforce health checks and 1m safe distancing, while Cedele cross-deployed employees and failed to enforce mask-wearing and safe distancing. The government is stepping up checks ahead of the gradual resumption of economic activity, with fines and stop-work orders possible for non-compliant workplaces.

site_title: Streamed plays offer big-name actors a chance to give back
summary: Broadway producer Jeffrey Richards is launching "Spotlight on Plays," a series of online play readings featuring big-name actors, to raise money for the Actors Fund and keep theatre alive during the pandemic. The first reading, starring John Malkovich and Patti LuPone, will be streamed on May 7, followed by productions of Joshua Harmon's "Significant Other" and Bryan Cranston and Sally Field's "Love Letters." The shows will be free, but viewers are encouraged to contribute to the Actors Fund, a nonprofit providing financial assistance to performing arts professionals.

site_title: Developers get reprieve on completion, sale, ABSD, QC deadlines
summary: The Singapore government has granted developers a 6-month extension on deadlines for project completion, sale, and ABSD (Additional Buyer Stamp Duty) remission, effective immediately. To qualify, developers must have purchased land on or before June 1, 2020, and have original timelines for completion and sale expire on or after February 1, 2020. The measures aim to provide relief from the Covid-19 pandemic's impact on the property sector, while maintaining price consistency with economic fundamentals.

images.alt_text: For their part, developers are expected to provide relief and support to their main contractors - especially during the circuit-breaker period - when work progress is disrupted.

site_title: US: Wall Street climbs on hopes of easing restrictions
summary: US stocks rose on Wednesday, driven by hopes of easing coronavirus restrictions and a pickup in business activity. The Dow Jones Industrial Average climbed 0.40%, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also opened higher, reaching fresh records. Investors looked past a disappointing 20 million decline in US private payrolls last month. The gains came as states began to ease curbs, boosting optimism for economic recovery.

site_title: Coronavirus hits GM Q1 profit hard
summary: General Motors reported a 88% decline in Q1 profit to $247 million, or 17 cents per share, due to the coronavirus pandemic. The company suspended production in North America and cut costs, including suspending dividends and share buybacks. GM hopes to restart most North American production on May 18. The company also added $16 billion to its cash position and suspended its 2020 profit outlook. Despite a decline in US sales, GM's Chinese sales rebounded in April, offering a glimmer of hope for the US market.

site_title: MAS, SIC, SGX RegCo to allow electronic rights issue and take-over documents
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore, Securities Industry Council, and Singapore Exchange Regulation have introduced measures allowing listed companies to temporarily distribute rights issue and take-over documents electronically. The documents can be published on SGXNet and corporate websites, reducing physical manpower requirements. Issuers must still send a hardcopy notification to shareholders and a hardcopy application form, but encourage electronic methods of application and acceptance. This measure is in line with efforts to reduce the spread of Covid-19 at workplaces. The temporary measures will be in effect until September 30, 2020.

site_title: E-cigarette maker Juul Labs to exit South Korea after year of health controversies
summary: US e-cigarette maker Juul Labs is exiting South Korea after a year of struggling to gain traction due to government health warnings. The company cited a restructuring process and failed product innovations as reasons for its decision. Juul Labs aims to significantly reduce costs and re-establish a viable business in South Korea, but ultimately intends to cease operations.

site_title: SPH Reit to give eligible tenants two more months off rentals
summary: SPH Reit will grant eligible non-trading retail and medical tenants full rental waivers for April and May, totaling 2.3 months in rebates, funded by the Reit itself. Additionally, the Reit will pass on government property tax rebates to tenants, equivalent to 100% of property tax payable for retail and medical tenants and 30% for office tenants. This support aims to help tenants navigate the COVID-19 crisis.

site_title: No talking or goal celebrations as South Korea reboots virus-hit football
summary: South Korea's K-League, Asia's first major football competition to resume, kicks off on Friday after a two-month delay due to the novel coronavirus. The season will be played behind closed doors with stringent new safety guidelines, including no goal celebrations, handshakes, or talking, to prevent contagion. The K-League has shared its response manual with 40 professional football competitions worldwide, including the Premier League and Bundesliga, but questions have been raised about the new safety measures. The season will be livestreamed internationally and spectators will be allowed back into stadiums as the government eases quarantining measures.

images.alt_text: Shin Hyung-min (middle) of Jeonbuk Hyundai Motors FC fighting for the ball with Yu Hai (right) of Shanghai SIPG during their AFC Champions League Round of 16 football match in Shanghai last year.

site_title: STI extends gains, up 0.75% to 2,591.60
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.75% to 2,591.60 on Wednesday, driven by gains from Jardine companies. Jardine Matheson Holdings led the advancers table with a US$0.81 gain, followed by Jardine Strategic Holdings and Jardine C&C. This marks the fifth consecutive day of gains for STI, ahead of upcoming GDP data.

site_title: Trump willing to risk more deaths to save economy
summary: President Donald Trump has shifted his stance on reopening the US, acknowledging that easing stay-at-home rules will cause more illness and death from the pandemic, but prioritizing economic recovery. He's willing to accept this cost to get the economy back on track, despite the nation still enduring the largest coronavirus outbreak in the world. Trump has disavowed the White House coronavirus task force and plans to pivot to "phase two" of the nation's response, which will include disbanding the task force.

site_title: First Reit Q1 DPU down 13.5% to 1.86 S'pore cts
summary: First Reit reported a Q1 DPU of 1.86 Singapore cents, down 13.5% from last year. Rental and other income rose 0.8% to S$28.89 million, while net property and other income increased 0.6% to S$28.21 million. Income available for distribution fell 6.7% to S$15.92 million. The company attributed the decline to the COVID-19 crisis, which is expected to impact the second quarter, and has implemented cost-management strategies to navigate uncertain times. The payment date for the DPU is June 18.

site_title: Digital marketing support for SMEs added to E-Commerce Booster Package
summary: Enterprise Singapore (ESG) has enhanced the E-Commerce Booster Package to provide funding for digital marketing services and manpower for small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) in Singapore. The package offers 90% subsidies for digital marketing advisory services and manpower costs for three months. The aim is to help SMEs strengthen their digital marketing skills, remain agile, and adapt to customer preferences to increase customer loyalty and attract new customers. The program is open for registration until September 30, 2020.

site_title: StarHub Q1 net profit plunges 25.7% to S$40.2m; management pulls FY2020 earnings guidance
summary: StarHub's Q1 net profit dropped 25.7% to S$40.2 million, with revenue declining 15.2% to S$506.2 million. The telco is withdrawing its FY2020 earnings guidance, citing the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic and changing market conditions. This decision also scrapes its plan to maintain an annual dividend of S$0.09 per share.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed lower on Wednesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 12.62 points to 1,376.93. The decline occurred despite a higher volume of 5.887 billion lots worth RM2.800 billion. Gainers outnumbered losers 445 to 441.

site_title: Two more deaths from Covid-19, bringing S'pore's death toll to 20
summary: Two more deaths from Covid-19 have been reported in Singapore, raising the death toll to 20. The victims, a 97-year-old woman and a 73-year-old man, both had underlying health conditions and were confirmed to have Covid-19 on April 7. The Ministry of Health also reported 759 new cases, with 788 total cases, mostly among foreign workers in dormitories, and no imported cases. The number of new cases has been below 1,000 for 13 consecutive days, with the total number of cases reaching 20,198.

images.alt_text: The Ministry of Health (MOH) said on Wednesday (May 6) that two more people have died from complications due to Covid-19 raising the death toll to 20.

site_title: Pompeo has no evidence about virus lab leak: China
summary: China has denied US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo's claims that the coronavirus originated in a lab in Wuhan, stating he "doesn't have any" evidence. The US government has been investigating the origins of the virus, which emerged in China late last year and has since become a global pandemic. China has repeatedly clashed with the US over the issue, with conspiracy theories surrounding a maximum-security virology lab in Wuhan gaining traction in recent months. The dispute highlights ongoing tensions between the two countries.

site_title: Govt rolls out temporary relief measures for property sector amid pandemic
summary: The Singapore government has introduced temporary relief measures for the property sector amid the ongoing pandemic. The measures include a six-month extension of project completion periods for residential, commercial, and industrial projects, as well as a six-month extension for the sale of housing units. These measures aim to mitigate the disruptions caused by the circuit breaker and public health measures. To qualify, developers and buyers must meet specific criteria, including purchasing land on or before June 1, 2020, and starting residential development on or after February 1, 2020.

site_title: Australia: Shares snap two sessions of gains as financials drop
summary: Australian shares ended lower, snapping two sessions of gains, as the financials sector fell 1.1% due to the "Big Four" banks' losses. The S&P/ASX 200 index closed 0.42% lower at 5,384.6 points, despite easing coronavirus restrictions. Analysts estimate credit losses from the country's recession could be higher than initially warned, with retail sales figures for April expected to dive due to coronavirus-induced restrictions.

site_title: Credit Suisse staff told to expect return to work in phases
summary: Credit Suisse Group employees are expected to return to work in phases, starting with a limited number of essential staff, followed by alternating groups, and eventually a full return. The bank's executive leadership has outlined a four-phase plan, with regional management deciding when to move between phases. Around 70% to 80% of Credit Suisse employees are currently working remotely, with health measures in place for staff in offices. The bank did not provide a specific timeline for when employees will begin returning to work, similar to other banks such as UBS and Capital One Financial.

site_title: Adam Neumann, WeWork's former chief, sues SoftBank
summary: Adam Neumann, WeWork's former CEO, sued SoftBank, accusing it of breaching a contract by withdrawing a $3 billion stock offer. The offer was part of a bailout that saved WeWork from financial collapse last year. Neumann claims SoftBank secretly undermined the deal, while SoftBank denies the claims, stating it will vigorously defend itself. Under the original deal, Neumann was set to receive $185 million and sell $1 billion of shares.

site_title: UK competition watchdog blocks JD Sports takeover of Footasylum
summary: UK's competition watchdog blocks JD Sports' 86 million pound takeover of Footasylum, citing it would leave shoppers worse off and require JD to sell the chain. The decision comes amid the coronavirus-driven pressures on retailers, with the CMA stating consumers have shifted their spending exclusively online, leading to long-term societal and behavioral changes in shopping habits. JD Sports chairman Peter Cowgill expressed surprise at the decision, while Footasylum faces an uncertain future with 2,500 employees at risk.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks close with more gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose over 1% on Wednesday, driven by easing virus lockdowns and signs of the disease easing, outweighing concerns about China-US tensions. The Hang Seng Index increased 1.13%, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also rose.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong stocks rose more than one per cent Wednesday as an easing of virus lockdowns and signs the disease is easing trumped concerns about brewing China-US tensions.

site_title: Philippine lawmakers vow to get broadcast giant ABS-CBN back on air
summary: Philippine lawmakers are pushing to get broadcast giant ABS-CBN back on air after the National Telecommunications Commission (NTC) ordered the station to cease operations due to its expired 25-year license. The move has sparked widespread shock and dismay, with thousands of jobs at risk. Lawmakers are urging Congress to intervene and grant ABS-CBN a provisional franchise, with some lawmakers saying the NTC's decision is a "pointless" move. The company's shares have plummeted, and its main rival GMA Network surged to a one-year high.

site_title: Netlink C-suite to take 8% pay cut amid Covid-19 even as DPU rises
summary: NetLink NBN Trust reported a net profit of S$12.5 million in Q4, down 37.7% from the same quarter last year, due to a write-off of S$15.4 million in capitalised project costs. Excluding the write-off, the net profit would have risen 39.5%. Revenue rose 5.2% to S$92.4 million, driven by residential connections and non-residential connections, with close to 1.43 million residential connections as of March 31, 2020. Unitholders will receive a distribution of 2.53 Singapore cents per unit, a 3.1% increase from the same period last year.

site_title: Russia sees over 10,000 new virus cases for fourth day in row
summary: Russia has reported over 10,000 new coronavirus cases for the fourth consecutive day, surpassing Germany to become the country with the sixth-highest number of confirmed infections. The total number of infections has risen to 165,929, with 1,537 deaths. Moscow, the epicenter of the pandemic, has recorded 85,973 cases and 866 deaths. Russia's official fatality rate remains low compared to other countries, but critics question the accuracy of the numbers, citing widespread testing and tracking. The government is set to discuss a gradual withdrawal from lockdown measures.

site_title: DBS prices S$20m SORA-referenced notes
summary: DBS Bank has priced its first S$20 million floating-rate notes with the Singapore Overnight Rate Average (SORA) as the reference rate for interest calculation, marking the industry's first note to be priced this way. The notes, due in 2021, will bear a coupon rate of compounded daily SORA + 0.65% per annum. This move is in line with the roadmap of the Association of Banks in Singapore and the Singapore Foreign Exchange Market Committee (ABS-SFEMC) for developing new SORA-based markets.

site_title: Seoul: Shares end higher as many nations ease lockdowns
summary: South Korean shares rose 1.76% on Wednesday, closing at 1,928.76, driven by optimism over eased lockdowns in several countries, including Italy and the US. Despite US-China tensions and recession worries, higher oil prices and re-opening of economies boosted sentiment. South Korea relaxed social distancing rules and allowed phased business re-opening. Foreigners sold $252.61 million worth of shares, but the KOSPI has gained 19.1% in the past 30 trading sessions.

site_title: Asset manager DWS expands Singapore logistics footprint with warehouse buy
summary: DWS, a German asset manager, has acquired a Grade A logistics facility in Jurong, Singapore, as part of its "Asia core real estate strategy". The facility, occupying 403,000 square feet, serves as the Asia-Pacific headquarters for a third-party logistics operator. The acquisition is expected to deliver long-term stable cash returns for investors, and follows previous purchases in Australia and Singapore. The deal reflects Singapore's resilient industrial sector, driven by growing e-commerce trends and changing demographics.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary:
Here is a summary of the article content in 100 words or less:

Multiple developments were reported today. Robinsons department store announced it will close its Jem mall outlet by the end of August, after discussing the exit with landlord Lendlease since November. The US announced a tariff on Vietnam, causing surprise, while the Asian garment industry prepares for potential higher tariffs. In other news, a Malaysian agency plans to seize RM3 billion of assets from Daim Zainuddin, and China's GDP growth is expected to slow, raising pressure on policymakers. Additionally, Citigroup set a target for the MSCI global equity index and Thaksin expressed confidence in his daughter's Thai court case.

site_title: US may require masks at airports in changes to limit coronavirus
summary: The US Transportation Security Administration (TSA) is considering requiring masks for passengers at airport checkpoints to limit the spread of the coronavirus. This move comes as the number of air travelers has decreased significantly since lockdowns began, and the industry is grappling with how to operate safely. Other changes include additional barriers, more extensive cleaning regimes, and upgraded screening equipment to speed travelers through lines faster. The TSA has reviewed the legality of requiring masks and has not reached a final decision, but some US airports and airlines have already implemented face covering requirements.

images.alt_text: The lead US airport security agency is weighing the possibility of requiring masks or face coverings for passengers who pass through checkpoints, according to a US official and two people familiar with the deliberations.

site_title: Why society can no longer ignore the call for entrepreneurship
summary: Entrepreneurship is evolving beyond financial gain, with a growing emphasis on emotional security, compassion, and social responsibility. The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the importance of innovation and adaptability, as well as the need for a supportive ecosystem to encourage entrepreneurship. Dr. Alex Lin, interim CEO of NTUitive, argues that entrepreneurship can be a powerful tool for creating positive change in society. The article suggests that the traditional definition of entrepreneurship, which focuses on financial wealth, is no longer sufficient, and that entrepreneurs must adopt a more resilient and adaptive mindset to thrive in today's fast-changing world.

site_title: UK scientist behind lockdown quits after breaking rules
summary: UK scientist Professor Neil Ferguson, a key advisor on coronavirus lockdown measures, resigned from a government panel after admitting to breaking social distancing rules. He allowed a woman to visit him at home during the lockdown, citing a "mistake of judgement" and "wrong course of action." Ferguson, an epidemiologist, had previously warned that Covid-19 infections and deaths would spiral without drastic action, and his resignation comes as the UK considers lifting strict lockdown rules. He apologized for any undermining of the need for social distancing.

site_title: South Korea spy agency says no signs North Korea's Kim received heart surgery
summary: North Korea's leader Kim Jong Un has not received heart surgery, according to South Korea's National Intelligence Service (NIS), contradicting previous reports. The NIS assessed that Kim Jong Un did not undergo any heart-related procedure or surgery, and his reduced public activity was due to coronavirus concerns. Kim Jong Un has made only 17 public appearances this year, compared to an average of 50 in previous years, as the country takes stringent measures to prevent the spread of the disease.

site_title: 788 new coronavirus cases in Singapore, taking total past 20,000
summary: Singapore has reported 788 new coronavirus cases, taking the total count past 20,000, with 11 Singaporeans and permanent residents among the new cases. Migrant workers in dormitories form the majority of the remaining cases. The recent spike is largely driven by increased cases in dormitories and active testing. As of Tuesday, 16,998 migrant workers have tested positive, and 1,513 patients have fully recovered.

site_title: More Singapore properties go under the hammer but fail to sell as sellers cling on
summary: Singapore's property market continues to struggle as more homes go under the hammer but fail to sell, with a 31.1% decline in total auction listings in Q1 2020. Mortgagee sales grew 2.6% year-on-year, but the auction success rate declined to 1.6%, indicating a cautious buyers' market. Sellers are holding out, with 17,000 people deferring mortgage repayments, and buyers expect price reductions due to the economic difficulties caused by Covid-19. Experts predict a "tick-shaped recovery" in the mortgagee sale outlook, with buyers grabbing properties if prices drop 5-8% from banks' valuation.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets steady at open
summary: European stock markets steadied at the start of trading on Wednesday, following a rally the previous session. The FTSE 100 index gained 0.1% to 5,852.10 points, while the DAX 30 and CAC 40 indices eased 0.2% and 0.1% respectively. Despite weak business data and lockdown easing, markets are pricing in a recovery, with Germany set to take steps towards normalisation in May. Analysts warn, however, that the road to recovery will be "rocky" due to growing job losses and changes in industries such as aviation and retail.

site_title: JPMorgan strikes logistics deal in China as e-commerce takes off
summary: JPMorgan Asset Management's alternative investment arm has partnered with New Ease China to invest in logistics properties across China, capitalizing on the nation's booming logistics sector. The initial portfolio consists of $600 million worth of logistics facilities in cities including Shanghai, Nanjing, and Suzhou. The move comes as e-commerce continues to surge in China, with lingering fear of infection keeping people at home. High-quality logistics properties remain in short supply, making this investment opportunity attractive, according to JPMorgan Global Alternatives' chief investment officer.

site_title: Samsung heir apologises over succession, labour controversy
summary: Samsung heir Jay Y Lee apologized for the company's failure to abide by the law and ethics, acknowledging "disappointments and concerns" over succession plans and labor controversy. Lee, 51, expressed regret and vowed not to hand over management rights to his children, citing a reluctance to make it public. The apology comes amid a bribery scandal involving Lee and South Korea's impeached president, with the possibility of a tougher sentence and potential return to jail for Lee.

site_title: A COVID-19 Survival Guide for SMEs
summary: A global recession looms, with the COVID-19 pandemic exacerbating economic uncertainty. Small and Medium Enterprises (SMEs) in Singapore, comprising 99% of the country's businesses, face significant challenges, including cashflow constraints and limited access to financing. To survive, SMEs must prioritize cashflow management, cost-cutting, and customer experience. They can also pivot to new business models, leverage technology, and focus on their most important assets: their people. By adopting these strategies, SMEs can emerge from the challenges stronger and more resilient, positioning themselves for growth in a post-COVID-19 economy.

site_title: Fintech startup Nium raises equity round; new investors Visa, BRI Ventures
summary: Fintech startup Nium has raised an undisclosed amount of equity funding, joined by new investors Visa and BRI Ventures, to broaden its reach and product development in new and existing markets. The additional capital will be used to expand its payment infrastructure offering and acquire businesses to compress time to market. Nium aims to be profitable in the second half of next year and hit $100 million in revenue by 2023, with plans for a potential public listing.

site_title: Volkswagen sees multi-speed coronavirus rebound led by China
summary: Volkswagen reports a multi-speed coronavirus rebound, led by a strong demand in China, where sales of passenger cars surpassed year-earlier levels in the last week of April. In contrast, Europe's sales are expected to take a longer time to recover, with a "bathtub-shaped" recovery curve, and Germany's sales are down 60% compared to the year-earlier period. Volkswagen is adapting its financing and leasing offers to make downpayments more palatable, with a focus on making financing the main instrument for the industry in the months to come.

site_title: Yum China keeps bets on dine-in, sticks to expansion plans after virus
summary: Yum China, parent company of KFC and Pizza Hut, plans to expand in China's smaller cities despite the coronavirus crisis, betting on dine-in preference. CEO Joey Wat cited limited Western dining options and fewer competitors in fourth and fifth-tier cities. The company aims to open more outlets, driven by increased demand for Western food and coffee.

site_title: Beijing allows asset investment companies to conduct asset management business
summary: China allows asset investment companies (AICs) to conduct debt-to-equity asset management business, aiming to expand equity financing and reduce leverage in the economy. Major state-owned banks have set up AICs to conduct debt-to-equity swaps, and AICs can now invest in market-oriented debt-to-equity assets, including convertible bonds and ordinary shares. AICs can raise funds through private fundraising from qualified investors, including insurance funds and pension funds, as China seeks to channel personal savings into infrastructure projects. This move aims to revive the economy and balance liquidity with risks of higher inflation.

site_title: Perennial, SPH consortium to sell half stake in AXA Tower to Alibaba
summary: Perennial Real Estate, a consortium including Singapore Press Holdings, will sell half of its stake in Grade A office building AXA Tower to Alibaba Group's Singapore subsidiary. The sale is expected to complete in June, with Perennial retaining a 20% stake in the property through a new consortium, PRE 13. The deal will see Alibaba Singapore transfer a loan to the consortium and redevelop the building, increasing its gross floor area to 1.24 million sq ft. The transaction is part of Perennial's capital recycling strategy and will not impact SPH's earnings or net tangible assets.

site_title: Brazil ministers to be questioned in Bolsonaro probe
summary: Brazil's Supreme Court has granted investigators access to three top ministers of President Jair Bolsonaro, including Internal Security Minister Augusto Heleno, Chief of Staff Walter Braga Netto, and Secretary of Government Luiz Eduardo Ramos, in a probe into allegations of obstruction of justice. The probe stems from accusations by former justice minister Sergio Moro, who resigned after Bolsonaro fired the federal police chief. Moro's leaked deposition details discussions with Bolsonaro on replacing the police chief, with Moro saying the president wanted him to ensure a new superintendent would be named in Rio de Janeiro, where Bolsonaro's son is under investigation.

site_title: BMW reports first-quarter profit rise as coronavirus saps demand
summary: BMW reported a 133% rise in first-quarter profit to 1.38 billion euros due to the absence of a one-off provision in the year-earlier period. However, the company warned that the impact of the coronavirus could erode demand and profit. The earnings before interest and taxes margin for its autos division improved to 1.3% from a negative 1.6% margin in the previous year. The profit rise was largely driven by the absence of a provision in the previous year, but BMW cautioned that the pandemic's impact on demand would be felt in future periods.

site_title: Dubai hotel mogul says 'bleeding' firms need economy to reopen
summary: Dubai hotel mogul Khalaf Al Habtoor stated that his companies, including hotels and car dealerships, are "bleeding" due to the coronavirus pandemic and are in need of an economic reopening. Despite not cutting jobs yet, Al Habtoor emphasized the need to protect employees from the virus while allowing businesses to operate. He cited examples of economies in Europe beginning to reopen, stating that his group cannot wait for a vaccine until the end of the year.

site_title: South Korea returns largely to normal as outbreak controlled
summary: South Korea has largely returned to normal after controlling its COVID-19 outbreak, with new cases dropping to a trickle and strict social distancing rules eased. The country's "trace, test and treat" program has been praised for its success, with a death toll of just over 250 and only 13 new cases in the past three days. Museums, libraries, and workplaces reopened on Wednesday, with schools set to reopen in stages starting May 13. South Koreans are still encouraged to wear face masks and follow hygiene guidelines, but life is returning to normal after a prolonged period of restrictions.

site_title: Credit Agricole Q1 profit falls 16% as it triples provisions
summary: Credit Agricole, France's second-largest listed bank, reported a 16.4% decline in Q1 profit to 638 million euros, as it tripled provisions to protect against potential loan defaults due to the coronavirus crisis. Revenue rose 7.1% to 5.2 billion euros, while markets activities increased 14%. The bank avoided equity trading losses, unlike rivals BNP Paribas and Societe Generale. CEO Philippe Brassac attributed the results to the bank's prudent assumptions and ability to absorb the increased cost of risk.

site_title: Students in China's virus centre Wuhan return to school
summary: Chinese students in Wuhan, the global virus epicentre, returned to school on Wednesday, marking the city's gradual return to normalcy after the coronavirus pandemic. Senior students in 121 institutions resumed classes, wearing masks and following social distancing measures. The reopening comes as the province reports no new cases for over a month, and China's major cities are gradually returning to normal after strict travel restrictions. Students must undergo virus tests and undergo 14-day quarantine for Chinese nationals returning home.

site_title: Morgan Stanley-backed fund to buy virus-hit South African firms
summary: Capitalworks Investment Partners, backed by Morgan Stanley, plans to invest 5 billion rand (S$383.4 million) in mid-sized South African companies hit by the pandemic. The firm raised 25% more than planned for its Private Equity Fund III from institutional investors and wealthy families. The investment will focus on businesses with enterprise values from 250 million to 4 billion rand in industries such as financial services, food, and health. Capitalworks founder Chad Smart believes undervalued companies can gain market share during a crisis.

site_title: China says Hong Kong will never be calm unless violent protesters removed
summary: China's Hong Kong affairs office warned that Hong Kong will never be calm unless "black-clad violent protesters" are removed, describing them as a "political virus" that seeks independence from Beijing. The statement comes amid concerns China is tightening its grip over the former British colony, and amid a lockdown that has kept the movement off the streets. Beijing rejects criticism that it is seeking to encroach on Hong Kong's freedoms, but the office's statement has fueled worries of a revival of anti-government protests.

site_title: Italy's top bank UniCredit posts larger-than-expected 2.7b euro Q1 loss
summary: Italy's UniCredit, the country's largest bank, posted a 2.7 billion euro (S$4.15 billion) loss in the first quarter due to loan writedowns related to the COVID-19 pandemic. Revenues fell 8% to 4.38 billion euros, and the bank took a 1.3 billion euro hit to prepare for 5,200 layoffs. This is part of UniCredit's efforts to address the economic impact of the pandemic, which has ravaged Italy's economy and led to concerns of a recession.

site_title: Bitcoin is staging a comeback reminiscent of 2017 bubble frenzy
summary: Bitcoin is experiencing a comeback, with its price rising to near $9,000 in anticipation of its upcoming halving, which is set to occur on May 12. The event is expected to slow down the rate at which new Bitcoin is created, potentially leading to a surge in price. Historically, Bitcoin has bottomed 459 days prior to the halving, risen leading into the event, and exploded to the upside afterward. Experts, including Raoul Pal and Christopher Wood, predict that Bitcoin could reach $1 million and $50,000, respectively, in the next few years, citing its limited supply and growing adoption.

site_title: French power producer Neoen to build Australia's biggest solar farm
summary: French power producer Neoen plans to build Australia's largest solar farm in southeast Queensland, valued at A$570 million. The Western Downs solar farm will generate 320-352 megawatts of power, supporting Queensland's 50% renewable energy target by 2030. Construction is set to begin in July 2020, with electricity generation starting in early 2022. Neoen already operates six solar farms and several other renewable energy projects in Australia.

site_title: More reliability for Circle Line with inking of 16-year servicing pact between SMRT, Alstom
summary: Singapore's Circle Line is set to become more reliable with a 16-year servicing pact between SMRT and Alstom. The agreement, announced on May 6, 2020, ensures the continued reliability and availability of the control systems that run the Circle Line. Alstom will provide spare parts, repairs, and technical support until 2035, and a local team will work closely with SMRT to maintain the train control system. The partnership aims to provide safe and reliable service for commuters.

site_title: Jack Ma's online bank plans a US$282b lending spree
summary: MYbank, an online lending platform backed by billionaire Jack Ma, plans to issue a record 2 trillion yuan ($399 billion) in new loans to small and medium-sized companies in 2020, up 18% from 2019. The move aims to boost China's economy from its pandemic-induced slump, but poses risks for MYbank and its biggest shareholder, Ant Financial. Analysts warn that the model has yet to be tested in a full credit cycle, and a surge in defaults could impact profitability.

site_title: Broadcaster ABS-CBN shutdown crosses dangerous line for Philippines
summary: The Philippines' top broadcaster, ABS-CBN, was shut down on Tuesday, marking the first time a major, independent outlet was halted since President Rodrigo Duterte took office. The shutdown, triggered by a stalled operating license renewal, sends a warning to those who risk angering the president and erodes the nation's democracy. Watchdog groups say the move echoes the country's grim authoritarian past, with critics accusing Mr. Duterte of silencing critical media and intimidating others into submission. The shutdown has sparked concerns about the country's freedom of the press and its democratic institutions.

site_title: HSBC seeks judicial management for Singapore oil trader Zenrock: sources
summary: HSBC has filed an application to the Singapore High Court to place Zenrock Commodities Trading, a Singapore-based oil trader, under judicial management. The move follows revelations of hundreds of millions of dollars of losses by Hin Leong Trading, one of Asia's largest oil traders. Zenrock and Winson Group, another oil trader, had previously stated that they were not under financial duress, but the latest development suggests financial difficulties. An independent judicial manager will be appointed to manage Zenrock's affairs.

site_title: Singapore restarts local production of surgical face masks
summary: Singapore has restarted local production of surgical face masks, with Trade and Industry Minister Chan Chun Sing stating the country is "on track" to meet healthcare workers' needs. The government plans to distribute free improved cloth masks in June, using both volunteers and vending machines. Singapore has also ramped up production to meet domestic demand and contribute to the national stockpile, while continuing to diversify its foreign face mask supply. The move aims to ensure a steady supply of face masks for healthcare workers in the fight against the coronavirus pandemic.

site_title: Europe's fresh food prices in flux as virus impact bites
summary: Europe's fresh food prices are increasing due to the impact of the coronavirus pandemic on supply chains and demand. Lockdowns have led to shortages and higher costs for growers, resulting in higher prices for consumers. This affects not just peppers but other fresh produce as well. The ripple effects of the pandemic are being felt across the continent, impacting food prices and availability.

site_title: Hong Kong's jobless rate understates harsh reality
summary: Hong Kong's official jobless rate of 4.2% is understating the city's economic crisis. The actual unemployment rate may be as high as 10%, according to economist Iris Pang, due to the exclusion of self-employed and informal workers. The city's economy contracted 8.9% in the first quarter, the steepest fall since 1974, and retail sales plummeted 42% in March. The government's revised GDP forecast now predicts a 7% decline, highlighting the dire situation.

site_title: Bank Indonesia to support GDP growth by providing liquidity: governor
summary: Bank Indonesia Governor Perry Warjiyo pledged to provide liquidity to support economic growth, citing 2.97% first quarter GDP growth below expectations. He prioritized rupiah stability over interest rate policy, stating that liquidity injection is more effective in weathering the coronavirus pandemic. The governor's stance remains loose, with a possible weaker full-year 2020 GDP growth rate of 2.3%.

site_title: HC Surgical shareholder says CEO breached duties in Julian Ong stake buy
summary: Serene Tiong, an HC Surgical Specialists shareholder, alleges that CEO Heah Sieu Min breached his duties by acquiring an additional 19% interest in Dr. Julian Ong's private practice. Tiong claims this move was not in the best interest of the company. HC Surgical has responded by stating the allegation is "frivolous" and "without merit" and is consulting its legal adviser. The company denies any wrongdoing, and the matter is currently being investigated.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares flat at start of day
summary: Hong Kong stocks remained flat at the start of the day on Wednesday, with the Hang Seng Index inching down 0.64 points to 23,868.02. Meanwhile, mainland Chinese markets, including the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index, declined 0.99% and 0.92%, respectively. Investors returned to work after a week-long break, contributing to the market's sluggish performance.

site_title: Twitter tests new layout options for some iOS, web users
summary: Twitter is testing a new layout for long threads of conversation, featuring indentations to separate comments, similar to Reddit. The test also includes prompts to revise replies deemed harmful. Additionally, Twitter is experimenting with combining functions for liking, retweeting, and replying behind a single tap. These changes aim to improve the user experience and reduce misinformation and destructive content on the platform.

site_title: Robinsons to close Jem mall outlet by end August
summary: Robinsons Singapore will close its Jem mall outlet by the end of August due to discussions with landlord Lendlease since last November. The department store operator will maintain two other outlets and focus on refining its online capabilities, including e-commerce solutions. This decision comes amid stiff competition and disruption in Singapore's retail scene, following a 13.3% year-on-year decline in retail sales in March.

site_title: PM Ardern touts New Zealand as 'safe haven' for investment
summary: New Zealand Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern has touted the country as a "safe haven" for investment, citing its successful efforts in curbing the coronavirus. With just two new infections this week, Ardern announced that New Zealand is ready to welcome quality investments and offer a safe place for operations. Microsoft has recently announced plans to set up its first datacentre region in New Zealand, and Ardern's government is making efforts to spread the word about the country's investment opportunities. Ardern aims to reboot the US$200-billion economy dependent on trade and tourism, which is expected to slow significantly.

site_title: Leadership changes at Frasers Property Australia from Oct 1
summary: Frasers Property Australia announced leadership changes effective October 1, 2020. Anthony Boyd, current CFO, will become CEO, succeeding Rod Fehring, who will remain as executive chairman. Fehring will also continue to chair Frasers Property Industrial and UK management boards, and provide oversight of Frasers Logistics & Commercial Trust. Olivier Lim will step down as non-executive chairman and remain as adviser to the group. The changes are part of a planned succession, according to group CEO Panote Sirivadhanabhakdi, who praised Fehring's leadership over the last five years.

site_title: US coronavirus deaths rise by 2,333 in 24 hours: Johns Hopkins
summary: The US coronavirus death toll rose by 2,333 in 24 hours, reaching a total of 71,022 deaths, according to Johns Hopkins University. This is more than twice the number of fatalities recorded the previous day. The country's daily death toll has fluctuated, with a record low of 1,015 fatalities on Monday.

site_title: Australia retail sales surge has sting in the tail as prices jump
summary: Australia's retail sales surged 8.5% in March, driven by panic buying of essentials like food and toilet rolls, but the economic gain was largely due to price increases rather than volume sales. Food sales jumped 24%, while household goods and work-from-home items also saw significant gains. However, sales declined in other sectors, and adjusted for inflation, total sales only rose 0.7%, limiting the contribution to GDP.

site_title: Hot stock: Medtecs shares climb 26.3% after Q1 profit surge
summary: Medtecs International Corporation, a CATALIST-listed healthcare products and services provider, saw its shares surge 26.3% to 14.4 Singapore cents after reporting a Q1 net profit of US$3.7 million, more than 16 times the year-ago amount. Revenue more than doubled to US$39.8 million, with gross profit nearly tripling to US$7.2 million. The company attributes the surge to increased demand for personal protective equipment and anti-epidemic products amid the COVID-19 pandemic. Medtecs expects revenue and profit growth in the second quarter and remains profitable for the financial year.

site_title: Australia seeks to re-start economy by July as Covid-19 curbs lift
summary: Australia aims to re-open locked-down businesses by July as COVID-19 curbs lift, with Prime Minister Scott Morrison seeking to regain 1 million jobs lost since mid-March. The government will discuss health protocols at a National Cabinet meeting, potentially enabling businesses to open in a "Covid-safe environment." Three stages of easing restrictions will be implemented, starting with cafes, restaurants, and retail. Australia has had fewer than 7,000 confirmed cases and 96 deaths, with most states moving at their own pace towards reopening by July.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened lower on Wednesday, down 2.93 points or 0.21% to 1,386.62. Volume was 227.41 million lots worth RM64.49 million. Gainers beat losers 229 to 50.

site_title: US set for historic unemployment surge
summary: The US economy is expected to experience a historic unemployment surge, with the unemployment rate potentially soaring to 20% or higher, according to the April employment report. At least 30 million workers lost their jobs due to the coronavirus pandemic, with the job losses spreading rapidly from airlines, hotels, and restaurants to factories. Despite trillions of dollars in financial aid and liquidity provided by the Federal Reserve, economists fear some of the economic damage may be permanent, with the economy contracting by 4.8% in the first quarter and potentially plunging by twice that amount in the second quarter.

site_title: Australia: Shares snap two days of gains, New Zealand rises
summary: Australian shares fell 0.8% to 5,362.3, snapping a two-day gain streak, amid weakness in the financial sector. Energy stocks rose 2.3% on a surge in oil prices, driven by easing lockdown measures. The financial sector, led by "Big Four" banks, fell 1-1.6%. Gold stocks also rose, while electronics retailer JB Hi-Fi jumped 7.8% on strong sales growth. In New Zealand, the benchmark index rose 0.82% to 10,576.8, boosted by Pushpay Holdings.

site_title: Hot stock: Singapore Airlines sees high trading volume as shares go ex-rights
summary: Singapore Airlines' shares saw active trading on their first day of ex-rights trading, with 21.3 million shares changing hands. The stock opened at S$4.235, 28.3% lower than the previous day's close, before rising to S$4.77 by midday. The airline's rights issue aims to raise S$8.8 billion, with a three-for-two rights issue and 10-year mandatory convertible bond issue. The ex-rights price is now S$4.164, calculated based on the stock's closing price on Tuesday.

images.alt_text: Singapore Airlines (SIA) shares sank on the counter's first day of ex-rights trading, ahead of the flag carrier's S$8.8 billion fundraising.

site_title: UOB's O&G exposure under 4%; Q1 profit at 2-year low on impairment surge
summary: United Overseas Bank (UOB) reported a 19% fall in Q1 net profit to S$855 million, the lowest level in over two years, due to declining margins and a surge in impairment charges. The bank's Q1 net interest income was flat, while total credit costs rose 12 basis points. UOB's exposure to oil and gas loans, primarily to downstream players, stood at 3.6% of total loans. The bank has approved S$4 billion in loans under a government-assisted program for mid-sized enterprises affected by the Covid-19 pandemic.

site_title: TPG gives free Internet access to low-income families affected by Covid-19
summary: TPG Telecom is providing free Internet access to low-income families affected by the Covid-19 pandemic through 50GB SIM-only plans and mobile WiFi routers. The telco has reached over 800 recipients, aiming to support students from low-income families with home-based learning programs due to a lack of laptops and Internet access.

site_title: Bangkok's millionaires' club enjoys lockdown luxury
summary: Thailand's wealthy elite continue to enjoy luxury despite the country's lockdown, with high-end meals delivered by butlers in black sedans. The Silver Voyage Club offers gourmet takeaway from top-tier restaurants to clients with a minimum bank account balance of $1 million. The company, which has seen a surge in demand, also donates meals to frontline workers. The pandemic has exacerbated the country's income inequality, with 22 million people registering for government aid.

site_title: Asia: Stocks enjoy further gains as virus restrictions are eased
summary: Stocks in Asia rose on Wednesday as countries eased virus restrictions, offering a cautiously optimistic outlook. Data showed a slowdown in infections and deaths, allowing nations to relax lockdowns. Federal Reserve Vice-Chairman Richard Clarida predicted positive US economic growth in the second half of the year, contingent on virus containment. Despite this, global markets were influenced by concerns over US-EU trade tensions and the ongoing pandemic.

images.alt_text: Most equities rose again on Wednesday as investors grew increasingly, but cautiously, hopeful that the worst of the coronavirus had passed and as countries begin to slowly open up from lockdown.

site_title: Home-grown sofa maker HTL files for insolvency protection, cites cash flow problems
summary: Singapore-based sofa maker HTL International has filed for insolvency protection, citing cash flow problems due to the Covid-19 pandemic. The company owes US$46 million to various banks and has more than 5,000 employees worldwide. HTL is seeking judicial management after DBS issued a demand for full repayment of its banking facilities.
