The company's core manufacturing activities in China were severely affected by factory closures and movement restrictions, leading to serious cash-flow problems.

site_title: Singapore shares edge up at Wednesday's open; STI up 0.1%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 0.1% to 2,573.97 on Wednesday, driven by rallies in US and European markets. Gainers outnumbered losers 74 to 49, with active counters including CapitaLand and UOB. Banking stocks were mixed, with DBS up 0.1% and OCBC Bank down 0.3%. The US and European markets ended higher on Tuesday, with optimism about reopening the US economy and easing coronavirus lockdown restrictions.

site_title: Singapore digibanks applicants stay the course, with finances still key amid Covid-19
summary: Singapore's digital banking applicants, 21 in total, have maintained their interest in obtaining licenses despite the COVID-19 pandemic. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) emphasizes financial strength as a key consideration in the application process. Applicants must demonstrate a "path towards profitability" based on a five-year financial projection. MAS has not changed its plans to issue up to two digital full bank and up to three digital wholesale bank licenses, with the majority being consortia of entities from various industries.

site_title: Trump visits masks factory but declines to wear one
summary: US President Donald Trump visited a mask-making factory in Phoenix, Arizona, on Tuesday, but declined to wear a face covering despite being surrounded by masked workers. Trump downplayed the need for masks, citing his frequent testing for the coronavirus, and instead focused on reopening the economy. His comments come amid a growing divide over the pandemic, with some Republicans seeing mask-wearing as a threat to individual liberty and Democrats promoting it as a sign of shared responsibility.

site_title: Disney tests reopening strategy at Shanghai Disneyland
summary: Disney is testing its reopening strategy at Shanghai Disneyland, set to reopen on May 11 with limited attendance and strict social distancing measures. The park will have a phased approach, with guests required to purchase admission tickets valid on a selected date and make reservations prior to arrival. Masks will be mandatory, and temperature screenings and contact tracing systems will be in place. The goal is to reopen locations that will not lose money, with the company exploring technology to help with efforts. Disney has already furloughed over 120,000 employees and has seen a US$1 billion loss in operating profits due to the pandemic.

site_title: Banyan Tree says able to repay S$100m 4.85% notes due June 5
summary: Banyan Tree Holdings, a Singapore-based hospitality group, says it can repay its S$100 million 4.85% notes due June 5, 2020, using its working capital, cash, and bank facilities. The company is exploring options, including equity capital fundraising, amid a global liquidity crunch caused by the Covid-19 pandemic. Banyan Tree will seek shareholders' approval for a general share issuance mandate at its upcoming annual general meeting to facilitate equity capital fundraising. The company is also implementing cash conservation measures to save S$70 million by the end of 2020.

site_title: Stocks to watch: UOB, Great Eastern, Singtel, OUE C-Reit, Koufu, Banyan Tree, HC Surgical
summary: Singapore stocks saw mixed developments on Wednesday, with some companies posting smaller-than-expected losses. United Overseas Bank reported a 19% drop in first-quarter net profit, while Great Eastern Holdings saw a 90% drop due to non-operating losses. In contrast, OUE Commercial Real Estate Investment Trust's distribution amount rose 44.5% year-over-year. Other notable announcements included Singtel's video streaming subsidiary winding up and appointing a provisional liquidator, and Banyan Tree Holdings repaying its S$100 million fixed-rate notes.

site_title: Great Eastern Q1 profit tumbles 90% on non-operating losses
summary: Great Eastern Holdings reported a 90% drop in net profit to S$33.9 million for Q1 2020, primarily due to non-operating losses of S$222.8 million. Operating profit doubled to S$298.6 million, driven by increased contributions from core markets and reduced insurance contract liabilities. The decline was attributed to unfavorable financial market conditions.

site_title: Australia's CSL to start work on immunoglobulin product to treat Covid-19
summary: Australian biotech firm CSL Ltd will start local development of an immunoglobulin product to treat serious cases of Covid-19. The product, made from antibodies from plasma collected from recovered individuals, is expected to treat 50-100 seriously ill people. CSL expects around 800 plasma donations to be needed for production, which will be conducted at its Melbourne-based Broadmeadows facility.

site_title: IBM, Samsung, M1 team up for 5G smart-manufacturing trial in Singapore
summary: IBM, Samsung, and M1 are partnering for a 5G smart-manufacturing trial in Singapore. The trial, to be conducted at an IBM facility in Changi Business Park, aims to test and display factory solutions. Successful solutions could be commercialized abroad and deployed globally. The Infocomm Media Development Authority (IMDA) will share insights with Singapore manufacturers, with the goal of improving operations across various markets and sectors.

site_title: Video game titans earnings climb as people play at home
summary: US video game titans Activision and Electronic Arts reported strong earnings as the coronavirus pandemic drives people to play games online. Activision saw an average of 102 million players per month, with Call of Duty: Warzone reaching 60 million players since its launch. This growth underscores the importance of gaming as a form of entertainment during the pandemic.

site_title: Five-year-old pulled over in US while driving to California
summary: A 5-year-old boy in Utah was stopped by police after being pulled over while driving an SUV to California to buy a Lamborghini. The boy claimed he took the car after an argument with his mother and had only $3 to purchase the vehicle. He managed to drive about 3-5 kilometers before being stopped. Fortunately, no one was hurt, and no property was damaged during the incident. The boy's sibling had fallen asleep while watching him, and the keys were left unattended on a hook at home.

site_title: Malaysia's central bank cuts key interest rate to 2%, lowest since 2009
summary: Malaysia's central bank, Bank Negara Malaysia, cut its key interest rate to 2% on May 5, 2020, its lowest since 2009, to combat the coronavirus pandemic's economic impact. The rate cut is the third in as many policy meetings and aims to cushion the economic impact on businesses and households. The decision complements other monetary measures, and the central bank expects the economy to suffer its worst performance in over a decade.

site_title: UK and US warn of cyber threat to health sector fighting virus
summary: The UK and US have warned of a rise in cyber attacks targeting health professionals and organizations involved in the coronavirus response. Organized criminals, often linked to state actors, have been detected using "password spraying" tactics to gain access to accounts. The National Cyber Security Centre and the US Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency have issued a joint warning, advising healthcare staff to change passwords and implement two-factor authentication to reduce the risk of being hacked. The agencies believe the aim of these attacks is to gather information related to the pandemic.

site_title: ECB stands firm after shock German ruling on bond buying
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) has reaffirmed its commitment to its massive bond-buying stimulus scheme despite a shock ruling by Germany's Constitutional Court. The court gave the ECB three months to clarify key elements of its support to the eurozone, but stopped short of overturning the crisis-era bond-buying scheme. The ECB vowed to do "everything necessary" to maintain price stability and ensure its monetary policy action filters through to the real economy. The ruling did not directly affect the ECB's new Pandemic Emergency Purchase Programme, which was launched to fight the coronavirus impact.

site_title: France daily coronavirus deaths rise to 330
summary: France reported 330 new coronavirus deaths, bringing the total to 25,531, according to Health Minister Jerome Salomon. This rise in daily toll is higher than Monday's 306 fatalities. Despite this, pressure on intensive care units is easing, with 266 fewer patients receiving urgent treatment. France is set to emerge from a lockdown on May 11, with officials warning the country must remain cautious to avoid a second wave.

site_title: UOB posts smaller-than-expected 19% drop in Q1 profit
summary: UOB reported a 19% drop in Q1 net profit to S$855 million, lower than the estimated S$739.3 million. The bank's impairment charges rose to S$286 million, and it booked an additional regulatory loss allowance reserve of S$260 million. This marks the lowest profit level in over 2 years, mainly due to the worsening economic conditions caused by the novel coronavirus outbreak.

site_title: Mattel reports big loss on weak sales amid virus
summary: Mattel reported a US$210.7 million loss in the first quarter due to a 13.8% decline in revenues, primarily caused by the coronavirus pandemic. Sales of most toys fell, with dolls and Fisher-Price experiencing significant declines. However, Hot Wheels sales rose 1%. Mattel withdrew its annual financial forecast and plans for increased demand in the second half, citing an improved holiday season. Shares fell 8.2% in after-hours trading.

site_title: California sues Uber and Lyft for calling drivers 'contractors'
summary: California has sued ride-sharing companies Uber and Lyft, alleging they misclassified drivers as contractors instead of employees, violating state law. The lawsuit, joined by cities like San Francisco and Los Angeles, seeks to require the companies to compensate drivers and pay penalties totaling hundreds of millions of dollars. The classification requirements, known as Assembly Bill 5, aim to cover gig-economy freelancers under minimum wage and benefit rules. Uber and Lyft have challenged the law, with the companies planning to contest the latest court action and organize a referendum to overturn the law.

images.alt_text: California on Tuesday sued rideshare operators Uber and Lyft for "misclassifying" drivers as contractors instead of employees in violation of a state law.

site_title: As US reopens, businesses want protection from lawsuits
summary: US businesses are seeking protection from lawsuits as the country reopens, amid concerns over workplace safety during the COVID-19 pandemic. A Walmart employee who died from the virus is suing the company, citing negligence. The US Chamber of Commerce and some business groups support shielding companies from liability, citing health privacy concerns and limited personal protective equipment. However, Senate Democrats and labour unions oppose the measures, arguing that companies have a responsibility to protect their workers.

site_title: Tokyo: Markets closed on Wednesday for holiday
summary: Financial markets in Japan closed on May 6, 2020, for a public holiday. In contrast, US stocks edged down from records on July 12, 2025, amid tariff threats. European markets also declined, with mining and healthcare sectors propelling shares upward. US-EU trade talks were in focus. Meanwhile, Singapore stocks notched a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data, and a mandatory offer was made for the rest of PSC at S$0.40 a share.

site_title: New Zealand Q1 jobless rate inches up but coronavirus shock to be reflected in next quarter
summary: New Zealand's jobless rate rose to 4.2% in Q1 due to a strict lockdown enforced to limit the spread of the novel coronavirus. Employment increased 0.7% quarter-over-quarter, while private sector wages rose 2.5% year-over-year. The data reflects the labour market before the lockdown, with economists expecting a more significant impact on future job losses due to the pandemic. The government aims to keep unemployment below 10% and return to 5% in 2021 with additional support.

site_title: Disney to see at least US$1.4b impact from coronavirus
summary: Disney reported a 91% plunge in profit to $475 million in the current fiscal quarter, citing a massive hit from the coronavirus pandemic. Total revenues rose 21% to $18 billion, with media operations showing strong growth. The company's "Parks, Experiences and Products" division fell 10% in revenue and segment operating income fell 58%. Disney+ has 33.5 million subscribers, but the unit lost $812 million due to expenses from its rollout. The company expects a gradual return to normalcy as it maintains a cautious approach in reopening its facilities.

site_title: Microsoft to invest US$1b in Poland cloud
summary: Microsoft is investing US$1 billion in Poland to expand its cloud operations, including the creation of a new regional cloud-computing data hub. The seven-year project aims to provide cloud solutions for industries and companies in Poland. This investment is seen as a significant step towards Poland's digitization and economic development, with Polish Prime Minister Mateusz Morawiecki describing it as the largest in the region.

site_title: Qatar Airways warns of 'substantial' job losses
summary: Qatar Airways has warned of "substantial" job losses due to the coronavirus pandemic, which has led to a collapse in air travel demand. The airline, which has over 30,000 staff, has had to slash passenger services to just 35 destinations. A memo to cabin crew stated that the airline cannot sustain current staff numbers and will need to make redundancies, including those in cabin crew. The airline will work closely with affected employees to offer support during this difficult time.

site_title: More than 30 firms join alliance calling for 'open' 5G systems
summary: More than 30 technology and telecom firms have formed the Open RAN Policy Coalition to push for "open and interoperable" 5G wireless systems, eliminating reliance on a single supplier. The alliance aims to promote policies standardizing and developing open interfaces, ensuring interoperability and security. The move comes amid US-led efforts to ban Huawei from American networks and follows successful examples of open 4G and 5G deployments in Japan, India, and other countries.

site_title: Money FM podcast: Mental wellbeing of our seniors
summary: Claressa Monteiro on Money FM 89.3's Workday Afternoon podcast discusses the mental wellbeing of seniors in Singapore, particularly those affected by the circuit breaker. Tan Rui Qi, associate consultant at Changi General Hospital, shares warning signs and valuable information to help seniors and caregivers. The conversation highlights the challenges of social isolation on mental health and the importance of engaging seniors in activities that promote mental wellbeing.

site_title: Airbnb slashes staff in effort to ride out pandemic
summary: Airbnb is slashing one-fourth of its workforce, approximately 1,900 people, in an effort to survive the pandemic's impact on the travel industry. CEO Brian Chesky stated that the company needs to weather the crisis until travel resumes. This move aims to ensure the platform's survival until the travel industry recovers.

images.alt_text: Home-sharing platform Airbnb said on Tuesday it will slash one-fourth of its workforce - some 1,900 people - as the coronavirus pandemic crushes the travel industry.

site_title: Amazon worker at New York warehouse dies of Covid-19
summary: An Amazon worker at a Staten Island, NY warehouse has died of Covid-19, according to the company. The worker's death comes as Amazon faces protests from warehouse workers and activists who claim the company has failed to prioritize their safety. New York Attorney General Letitia James had previously called for an investigation into Amazon's handling of the pandemic, and an Amazon vice-president had resigned in protest over the company's treatment of staff. The Staten Island facility has seen a significant number of Covid-19 cases, with over 50 employees reportedly infected.

site_title: China donates 600,000 masks to Singapore
summary: China has donated 600,000 surgical masks and 100,000 KN95 masks to Singapore's national stockpile to aid in managing the Covid-19 outbreak. Senior Minister of State Lam Pin Min expressed appreciation for the contribution, highlighting the importance of international cooperation. Meanwhile, Xiaomi Foundation and Raduga Pte Ltd have donated 100,000 masks to the National Council of Social Service. These donations follow Xiaomi's pledge to distribute a million face masks across Europe.

site_title: Europe: Shares end stronger on energy sector earnings, lockdown exit hopes
summary: European stocks closed 2.2% higher on Tuesday, driven by positive earnings and easing of coronavirus lockdown restrictions. Germany's top court ruled that the European Central Bank must stop buying bonds under the stimulus scheme if the ECB cannot justify the purchase, but this ruling does not apply to the Pandemic Emergency Purchase Programme. The energy sector led gains, with oil prices surging on expectations of recovering fuel demand. Some companies reported strong results, including Total SA and Repsol, while others declined, including Swedish real estate firm Samhallsbyggnadsbolaget.

site_title: Shell's Philippines unit to suspend refinery operations for one month
summary: Shell's Philippines unit to suspend refinery operations for one month due to the coronavirus pandemic's decline in oil demand. The Tabangao refinery, which operates at 110,000 barrels per day, will shut down from mid-May 2020. The move aims to conserve cash and protect against further declines in refining margins. The shutdown will comply with the government's minimum inventory requirement, and Shell may switch to importing petroleum products if necessary.

site_title: Darco's deputy chairman to make mandatory general offer
summary: Darco Water Technologies' deputy chairman Wang Zhi is launching a mandatory conditional cash offer for the shares he does not own in the company at S$0.17 per share, representing a 14.27% stake. He has acquired 13.39 million shares from Wuhan Liankai Investment Co for about S$2.28 million. Prior to this, Wang held or controlled 27.68 million shares, or 29.5% of Darco.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Singtel's subsidiary HOOQ Digital Mauritius Private Limited has petitioned the Bankruptcy Division of Mauritius' Supreme Court to wind up HOOQ M, citing no material impact on Singtel's net tangible assets or earnings per share. Meanwhile, Hawker Management (HM) will exit its contract to manage Jurong West Hawker Centre in Singapore after its expiration on Aug 6, 2020, due to unsatisfactory performance. HM will provide rental waivers and relocation fees to affected stallholders.

site_title: Joe Biden's main problem: himself
summary: Joe Biden's presidential campaign is facing scrutiny over his handling of past controversies, including a recent accusation of sexual assault. The 77-year-old candidate has been criticized for his tendency to make gaffes and his age. This criticism comes as the #MeToo movement continues to bring attention to sexual transgressions by powerful men in politics and business. The focus on Biden's past comes as he prepares to face off against Donald Trump in the upcoming presidential election.

site_title: Cautious optimism on container shipping
summary: Cargo accumulation builds up in European and North American warehouses due to lockdowns and decreased retail demand. International freight insurer TT Club warns of increased risk for operators, while full container yards and warehouses negatively impact container shipping lines. The pandemic's delayed effects between sourcing regions in Asia and consuming markets in Europe and North America have contributed to the buildup, causing significant stockpiles of unsold goods. This disrupts global supply chains and poses challenges for the container shipping industry.

site_title: New Delhi imposes 70% 'special corona fee' on alcohol to deter large crowds
summary: New Delhi, India has imposed a 70% 'special corona fee' on retail liquor purchases to deter large crowds and prevent social distancing violations. The tax aims to raise revenue as the city eases its six-week lockdown. Police responded to chaos at liquor shops, and other states have also increased prices. India reported 3,900 new infections, its highest single-day rise, with a total of 46,432 cases and 1,568 deaths. The decision follows concerns from health experts that the daily increase shows India remains at risk despite the lockdown.

site_title: US: Stocks finish higher on hopes for rebound
summary: US stocks finished higher on Tuesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average gaining 0.6% to 23,883.09, the S&P 500 climbing 0.9% to 2,868.44, and the Nasdaq Composite Index advancing 1.1% to 8,809.12. Optimism about US state reopenings and oil price rallies drove the gains, despite weak earnings and economic data. Travel companies were major losers, with Expedia, United Airlines, and Boeing shedding 4.4%, 4.5%, and 4.6% respectively.

images.alt_text: Wall Street stocks finished higher on Tuesday on continued optimism about steps to reopen the US economy and as oil prices rallied on expectations for a bounce in demand.

site_title: Australia's central bank sees steep contraction, keeps rates unchanged
summary: The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) forecasts Australia's economy will contract by 10% in the first half of 2020 and 6% for the full year, with the unemployment rate expected to double to around 10% and remain above 7% by the end of next year. Despite this, the bank sees a possible recovery if the coronavirus is contained and normal economic activity resumes. Interest rates remain unchanged at a record low of 0.25%, and the bank will continue to buy government debt to keep bond yields low.

site_title: Sustainable infrastructure a key ingredient for a green economic recovery in Asean
summary: The International Monetary Fund has predicted zero growth for Asian economies in 2020 due to the COVID-19 pandemic. Asean governments face an opportunity to reframe infrastructure planning and focus on sustainable development, with the region requiring $210 billion in annual investment until 2030. However, a lack of common understanding around sustainable infrastructure and green financing poses challenges. Experts suggest that governments, financial institutions, and project developers must work together to promote bankable and sustainable infrastructure projects, and that reframing infrastructure planning through a sustainable lens could make Asean economies more robust and resilient to future external shocks.

site_title: Oil prices surge as coronavirus lockdowns ease
summary: Oil prices surged on Tuesday as lockdowns eased in Europe, Asia, and the US, with Brent crude rising 13.9% to $30.97 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate gaining 20.5% to $24.56 a barrel. Despite industry data showing a larger-than-expected build in US crude inventories, fuel demand worldwide is rising modestly due to efforts to lift travel restrictions. Experts warn that the production pullback is just beginning, and a storage crunch may be abating, with some predicting a year-on-year drop of over 8 million barrels per day.

site_title: Lendlease Global Reit's Q3 DPU 0.7% higher than forecast
summary: Lendlease Global Reit reported a 0.7% increase in its third-quarter distribution per unit (DPU) to 1.28 Singapore cents, surpassing the initial public offering (IPO) forecast of 1.27 cents. The Reit's gross revenue rose 2.2% to S$21.7 million, driven by rental income from 313@somerset and Sky Complex in Milan. The Reit's net property income increased 4% to S$16.6 million, with distributable income to unitholders at S$15 million. The Reit has not declared a distribution for the period and plans to distribute semi-annually.

site_title: White House readies to scrap Trump's coronavirus task force
summary: The White House is set to disband the emergency coronavirus task force led by Vice-President Mike Pence, citing the pandemic as no longer its top daily priority. The task force, established by President Trump, will likely be shut down by the end of May or early June, according to Pence. This move suggests a decrease in the administration's focus on the pandemic, which has been ongoing since the beginning of 2020.

site_title: Rediscovering the value of blue chips
summary: Investors are rediscovering the value of blue-chip stocks as the COVID-19 crisis strains working capital and funding for companies. In contrast to the past 15 years, where disruption and low policy rates favored mid-cap and private equity investments, the current environment may favor larger, more diversified businesses. As the pandemic recedes, investors will prioritize durability and resilience, leading to a potential resurgence of blue-chip stocks. This shift may favor traditional businesses with latent productivity gains and the ability to deliver value across a broader set of stakeholders.

site_title: Pandemic may lop up to 20% off BNP Paribas 2020 earnings
summary: BNP Paribas warned that its 2020 earnings could be 15-20% lower than in 2019 due to the coronavirus outbreak, citing a US$1 billion in charges and writedowns, including 502 million euros for future bad credit. The bank's equities trading revenue declined 80% due to market volatility, and its net income fell by about a third from a year earlier. The warning follows Societe Generale's similar forecast, and the bank's chief financial officer noted that the economy's recovery is expected to happen at best by the end of the year.

site_title: Victoria's Secret sale to private equity firm falls apart
summary: Victoria's Secret's planned sale to private equity firm Sycamore Partners has been terminated after the buyer attempted to back out due to disagreements over the lingerie brand's response to the COVID-19 pandemic. The deal, valued at $525 million, was expected to close in the second quarter but was mutually terminated after Sycamore filed a lawsuit to terminate the agreement. L Brands, the parent company of Victoria's Secret, will instead focus on navigating the challenging business environment and positioning its brands for success.

site_title: Upholding ethics and integrity - but of course money trumps values
summary: A colorectal surgeon and psychiatrist, Julian Ong and Chan Herng Nieng, allegedly colluded to take advantage of vulnerable female patients. A woman lodged a complaint in 2018, which led to a defamation suit by Dr Ong being dismissed last month. Despite the complaint, Dr Ong's practice contributed significantly to his employer's revenue and profits. The Ministry of Health and Singapore Medical Council (SMC) are under scrutiny for their handling of the case, with critics arguing that the SMC's silence and lack of disciplinary action compromise patient safety.

site_title: Vicki Zhao's husband buys S$28m penthouse
summary: Chinese actress Vicki Zhao's husband, businessman Huang Youlong, has bought a S$27.65 million penthouse at Ardmore Park condo in Singapore for about S$3,164 per square foot. The penthouse, on levels 29 and 30, was sold to Huang as trustee, with his daughter potentially as the beneficiary. This purchase comes after Huang previously bought a four-bedroom apartment in the same development. The sale price was considered high at the time of the initial purchase in 2017, but current market conditions may justify the price.

site_title: Berlin Philharmonic tests a musical path out of lockdown
summary: The Berlin Philharmonic conducted a live-streamed concert in an empty hall, adhering to local health regulations, with musicians spaced 2-5 meters apart. The event, held on May 1, featured a chamber orchestra setup, with no more than 15 musicians on stage at a time. The performance included works by Arvo Pärt, György Ligeti, Antonín Dvořák's Barber, and Gustav Mahler's Fourth Symphony, with the musicians performing without masks. This event marked a gradual path out of lockdown for orchestras in Germany, with the aim of finding ways to make live art while maintaining safety.

site_title: Welcome to world of stagflation
summary: The world is facing a unique economic scenario, stagflation, characterized by stagnant output, rising unemployment, and inflation. This combination is expected to occur due to debt-trapped demand, productivity rebound, and labor force attrition. The pandemic will lead to a decline in low-to-middle income households requiring state support, and easy credit will not rescue debtors. Inflation will be the solution to debt, with nominal income growing while real income stagnates. Policy-makers will have to decide between erasing inflation through higher unemployment or validating higher inflation to save jobs and manage state debt.

site_title: Singapore law firms tighten purse strings, adapt to changes in demand
summary: Singapore law firms are adapting to the COVID-19 crisis, with many implementing cost-cutting measures such as pay cuts, delayed bonuses, and reduced hours. Despite this, demand has surged for restructuring and insolvency, commercial disputes, international arbitration, employment, and private wealth investments. Law firms expect a steady stream of work in these areas, which will help companies build resilience and right-size to bounce back. However, corporate and commercial law transactions have slowed, with valuations declining and parties reevaluating their positions.

site_title: 632 new Covid-19 cases in Singapore; nine new clusters
summary: Singapore reported 632 new Covid-19 cases, with 605 being foreign workers in dormitories, bringing the total to 19,410 cases. The Ministry of Health (MOH) also announced nine new clusters. There were no imported cases, and the number of new daily cases remains below 1,000 for the 12th consecutive day. A 44-year-old Bangladeshi national died due to an acute myocardial infarction, and globally, the outbreak has infected over 3.58 million people, with 250,000 deaths.

site_title: Indonesia's Q1 GDP growth is weakest since 2001, recession looms
summary: Indonesia's economy experienced its weakest growth since 2001 in the first quarter, with consumption, investment, and commodity exports declining due to the coronavirus pandemic. The central bank is expected to cut interest rates again amid fears of a looming recession. Despite this, Indonesia's growth pace was higher than some regional countries. The pandemic's impact on the economy is ongoing, with concerns about its potential to slow China's GDP growth and affect global markets.

site_title: HC Surgical says put option on Julian Ong's endoscopy clinic safeguards its interest
summary: HC Surgical Specialists (HCSS) has a put option that requires Dr. Julian Ong to repurchase the 70% stake in his endoscopy clinic, Julian Ong Endoscopy & Surgery (JOES), if HCSS exercises the option. The consideration payable under the put option is based on a percentage of the amount HCSS paid for the additional 19% interest, decreasing with each year of Dr. Ong's employment. The put option serves as a safeguard for HCSS's interest, protecting its investment in the event of Dr. Ong's employment termination.

site_title: CapitaLand's jointly owned office building obtains TOP
summary: CapitaLand's 29-storey office building, 79 Robinson Road, has received its temporary occupation permit (TOP) in Singapore. The Grade A office development, jointly owned by CapitaLand, Mitsui & Co, and Tokyo Tatemono, has secured over 70% leasing pre-commitment from multinational companies. Tenants will move in from June 2020, with Bridge+, CapitaLand's co-working business, occupying 56,000 sq ft. The building features energy-efficient and sustainable design, with plans to establish a fintech hub and set up a hub for the fintech community.

images.alt_text: 79 Robinson Road is jointly owned by CapitaLand, Japanese trading house Mitsui & Co and developer Tokyo Tatemono.

site_title: March retail sales down 13.3%; Worse dive expected for April, May
summary: Singapore's retail sales plummeted 13.3% year-on-year in March, the largest decline in two decades, due to the COVID-19 pandemic. Food and beverage services took a significant hit, with takings down 23.7% year-on-year. Economists predict further declines in April and May, with Maybank Kim Eng economist Lee Ju Ye expecting a drop of up to -20%. Retail sales excluding motor vehicles fell 9.7% in March, with online sales accounting for 8.5% of total sales.

site_title: Moody's cuts MCT outlook to negative amid pandemic
summary: Moody's has downgraded the outlook on Mapletree Commercial Trust (MCT) to negative from stable due to the COVID-19 pandemic's impact on retail spending and consumer sentiment, weakening demand for office space and increasing vacancy rates. The credit rating agency also expects MCT's cash flows to be adversely affected by tenant deferment laws and inadequate liquidity over the next 12-18 months. Despite this, Moody's affirmed the Baa1 issuer rating and senior unsecured ratings, citing the trust's diversified tenant profile, improved portfolio diversification, and prudent financial management.

site_title: Twilight prequel coming, written from vampire Edward's perspective
summary: Stephenie Meyer announced a new Twilight prequel, "Midnight Sun", which will be written from vampire Edward Cullen's perspective, exploring his past and first meeting with Bella Swan. The book, which takes on a dark twist, aims to be a welcome distraction from the global Covid-19 pandemic. Meyer hopes it will satisfy fans who have been waiting for a new story, and the news sparked excitement on social media, with many fans expressing their enthusiasm for the upcoming book.

site_title: Biodegradable plastics maker RWDC snags fresh funds of US$133m
summary: RWDC Industries, a Singapore-based biodegradable plastic maker, has secured US$133 million in funding to expand production and research and development. The two-stage Series B funding round was co-led by Vickers Venture Partners, Flint Hills Resources, CPV/CAP Pensionskasse Coop, and International SA. The investment aims to support the company's growth and contribute to the development of sustainable plastic alternatives.

images.alt_text: RWDC has about a dozen contracts in the pipeline, and at least six "very big clients" in industries such as quick-serve F&B, says Mr Wee.

site_title: Singapore corporate tax regime: What's ahead?
summary: Singapore's corporate tax regime is expected to face significant changes due to global uncertainties and the COVID-19 pandemic. The country's economy is projected to contract by 1-4% this year. To support businesses, the government introduced three budgets in 2020. However, companies must consider the looming international tax changes that could impact multinational enterprises. The article highlights the need for businesses to adapt to these changes and find new ways to tackle the pandemic while minimizing disruptions to supply chains.

site_title: Huge valuation mismatch for China's Big Four banks despite headwinds amid Covid-19
summary: China's Big Four banks, including Industrial & Commercial Bank of China, China Construction Bank, Bank of China, and Agricultural Bank of China, face significant challenges amid the COVID-19 pandemic. Despite government efforts to pump liquidity into the system, the banks are struggling with lower net interest margins, higher operating costs, and a surge in credit costs. However, their strong capital positions and exposure to larger national holding companies with government backing provide a buffer against potential losses. Loan growth may be a bright spot, and the banks' attractive dividend yields make them potential yield-plays for income-seeking investors.

site_title: Pandemic response calls for digital and financial inclusion
summary: A pandemic response calls for digital and financial inclusion to address socio-economic and demographic divides. Digital banking platforms can enable continued payment and receipt of wages for remote workers, while contactless transactions can minimize exposure for frontline workers. However, individuals excluded from financial systems and digital platforms are at greater risk of catching the virus or facing poverty. Effective crisis response relies on inclusive access to banking services and financial literacy to receive and use government relief. This highlights the need to address unequal access to financial services and digital platforms during times of crisis.

site_title: Top German court opens door to 'dieselgate' compensation
summary: A German top court has ruled that a Volkswagen driver may be entitled to compensation for his car, which was equipped with illegal emissions cheating software, in a landmark "dieselgate" case. The court's preliminary opinion suggests that the driver, Herbert Gilbert, may be eligible for some compensation, but likely not a full refund of the car's original purchase price due to his extensive usage. The ruling could set a legal precedent for tens of thousands of other "dieselgate" plaintiffs.

site_title: Tesla CEO puts two California homes on market
summary: Tesla CEO Elon Musk has listed two California homes for sale, including one previously owned by Gene Wilder, for a combined US$39.5 million. The listings come as Musk announced he is selling "almost all" of his possessions. The homes are part of a five-house collection Musk owns in Bel-Air, which he bought in 2012 and 2013 for about US$24 million. The sale of these properties may be a challenge given the current state of the Los Angeles luxury real estate market, which is struggling due to supply and demand issues amid the coronavirus pandemic.

site_title: A Personal Edition just for BT readers
summary: The Business Times (BT) has launched its first subscription package, BT Personal Edition, aimed at individual readers, priced at S$9.90 a month with no contract lock-in. The package offers full access to digital content, including premium stories, podcasts, and newsletters, and is designed for readers who want to track the impact of Covid-19 on their work and jobs. The launch follows the revamp of BT's mobile apps, which provide a focused reading experience. The Personal Edition offers one Web login and one app login, making BT more accessible to everyone.

site_title: Singapore clocks 4th straight record year for tourism arrivals and receipts in 2019
summary: Singapore achieved its fourth consecutive record year for tourism in 2019, with 19.1 million international visitor arrivals and S$27.7 billion in tourism receipts. The fourth quarter saw a 6.9% year-on-year increase in visitor arrivals and a 12.8% increase in receipts. Key markets, including mainland China, Indonesia, and India, accounted for the largest shares of tourism receipts and visitor arrivals, with China remaining the top source of tourism receipts in Q4.

site_title: Near-term global conflict unlikely, despite decaying post-war order
summary: The article discusses the current state of global politics, 75 years after World War II, and the likelihood of a near-term global conflict. Despite rising tensions between China and the US, and other geopolitical tensions, the odds of a major power war are lower than in the first half of the 20th century due to the presence of nuclear weapons, the resilience of post-war international institutions, and the lingering memories of World War I and II. However, the erosion of the post-1945 international order and the US's "America First" foreign policy stance pose significant risks, making the 2020s a volatile and potentially unstable period.

site_title: EU backs call for independent probe into coronavirus origins
summary: The European Union is set to propose an independent probe into the origins of the coronavirus at the World Health Assembly on May 18, backed by Australian Prime Minister Scott Morrison. This move comes amid tensions with China, which has dismissed calls for an independent investigation. The proposal aims to address concerns about the virus's origins and prevent future pandemics. Meanwhile, the US has also pushed for Taiwan to be reinstated as an observer at the assembly, which China views as a province.

site_title: US household debt reached US$14.3t, credit standards tightened in Q1
summary: US household debt reached a record US$14.3 trillion in Q1, with American households adding US$155 billion of debt. Mortgage balances rose by US$156 billion, while credit card balances and other types of debt declined by US$39 billion. Credit standards tightened slightly, with higher median credit scores for new auto loans and mortgages. Researchers note that the data may not fully reflect the effects of the pandemic, and further analysis is needed to determine the impact of the pandemic on household balance sheets.

site_title: Euro drops after German court ruling fuels uncertainty
summary: The euro dropped 0.7% to US$1.0826 after a German constitutional court ruled that the Bundesbank must stop buying government bonds unless the European Central Bank can prove the purchases are needed. The decision unsettled financial markets, fueled by uncertainty and exacerbated by a large long position in the single currency. The euro has weakened by over 5% from its one-year highs in March, with some strategists predicting it could drop to US$1.06 in the coming months.

site_title: Errant real estate agencies, agents face higher maximum fines
summary: Singapore has increased the maximum fines for errant real estate agencies and property agents to S$200,000 and S$100,000 respectively, under the Estate Agents (Amendments) Bill passed in Parliament. The increase aims to better reflect the higher commissions real estate agencies can earn compared to individual agents. The bill also requires the industry to prevent money laundering and terrorism financing, following a 2016 Ponzi scheme that was partially funded by seized funds in Singapore. The new regulations will also enhance the Council for Estate Agencies' investigative powers and impose harsher penalties for non-compliance.

site_title: Singapore had fourth record year for tourism in 2019
summary: Singapore had its fourth consecutive record year for tourism in 2019, with 19.1 million international visitor arrivals and S$27.7 billion in tourism receipts, up 3.3% and 2.8% respectively. The fourth quarter saw 6.9% year-on-year growth in international visitor arrivals and a 12.8% increase in tourism receipts. However, the Covid-19 pandemic has significantly impacted tourism, with visitor arrivals down 51.1% in February and 84.7% in March.

site_title: How Singapore's keeping credit open to SMEs
summary: Singapore's government-backed credit schemes have successfully flowed to 90-95% of small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs), with 1.9 billion SGD in loans approved since March. Banks have also offered near-zero interest rates, with UOB approving 4 billion SGD in loans and OCBC expecting 1 billion SGD by end-June. The government has removed stigma around relief measures, ensured proportionate provisions, and targeted support at SMEs, keeping credit flowing to the economy. Regulators will closely monitor the effectiveness of support measures and be open to adjustments.

site_title: US, Britain say trade talks big priority; pledge accelerated pace
summary: The US and Britain launched virtual negotiations for a free trade agreement, aiming to "significantly boost trade and investment." The talks, spanning nearly 30 negotiating groups, will accelerate the pace of discussions. The two countries have committed resources to progress at a fast pace, with the goal of reaching a deal in the near future.

site_title: Singapore shares stage mild rebound on the back of Wall Street's rally
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) rebounded 0.34% on Tuesday, closing at 2,572.36, despite a dismal PMI reading on Monday. The rally was fueled by Wall Street's late-session rally as governments relaxed lockdown measures and oil prices increased. However, DBS Equity Research warned that the uptick may not be sustained, citing a potential two-to-four week delay to sell-off due to the circuit-breaker extension. The index's year-end target was lowered to 2,850 from 3,350.

site_title: ARA, John Lim's family office venture into fintech with Minterest stake
summary: ARA Asset Management's family office, JL Family Office, and property arm have acquired a 52.08% stake in crowdfunding platform Minterest for an undisclosed sum. This marks ARA's entry into the fintech sector and is part of the group's wider ambitions in the global real estate credit business. The acquisition is not ARA's first foray into the sector, as the group has been expanding its presence in global real estate credit.

site_title: Hertz gets lenders' forbearance in bid to avert bankruptcy
summary: Hertz Global Holdings has received lenders' forbearance, giving it until May 22 to develop a financing strategy and structure to address the economic impact of the Covid-19 pandemic. The company had missed a debt payment and was preparing to file for Chapter 11 court protection. Hertz shares fell 13% as of Tuesday, following a 36% decline before regular trading. The company expects to not need to acquire new vehicles for its fleet through the remainder of the year.

site_title: Amid Covid-19 pain, Ninja Van eyes e-commerce boom
summary: Ninja Van, a last-mile logistics firm, has raised US$279 million in Series D funding despite the COVID-19 pandemic's impact on its business. The company, which has quadrupled its revenue since 2018, aims to control costs and eventually break even. CEO Lai Chang Wen believes that the surge in e-commerce demand due to social distancing measures will create opportunities for the company to strengthen its position in South-east Asia's cut-throat e-commerce logistics sector. However, cost control and a sustainable business model are key to Ninja Van's long-term success.

site_title: UOB has approved S$4b in loans backed by government to hard hit mid-sized enterprises
summary: Singapore's UOB has approved S$4 billion in loans backed by the government to mid-sized enterprises, including construction, retail, and hospitality sectors, affected by the Covid-19 pandemic. The loans, under Enterprise Singapore's temporary bridging loan programme, have a maximum repayment period of five years and interest rates as low as 2-3%. UOB is the first bank to access the Monetary Authority of Singapore's Singdollar Facility for ESG loans, which offers low-cost funding to eligible financial institutions. The government-backed loans aim to help hard-hit mid-sized firms tide over the pandemic and plan for recovery.

site_title: COE, road tax and other costs will continue to apply to private cars, says Khaw Boon Wan
summary: Singapore's Transport Minister Khaw Boon Wan has stated that private car owners will continue to pay for Certificates of Entitlement (COEs), road tax, and vehicle licensing fees during the circuit breaker period, despite reduced motor vehicle usage due to the COVID-19 pandemic. Owners can still use their vehicles for essential work or personal activities, as long as they have valid insurance coverage and road tax. The Land Transport Authority has made adjustments to land transport services and charges, but the minister acknowledged that public transport operators are under significant financial stress due to plummeting ridership and fare revenues.

site_title: Darco Water Technologies' deputy chairman making conditional cash offer
summary: Darco Water Technologies' deputy chairman Wang Zhi is launching a mandatory conditional cash offer for shares he doesn't own, at S$0.17 per share. He has acquired 13.39 million shares, increasing his stake to 43.77%. The offer, valued at S$2.28 million, is a premium of 30.77% over the last trading price and 33.33% over the 3-month VWAP. The offer is conditional on Wang accumulating at least 50% of Darco's total voting rights by the close of the offer.

site_title: Post-merger OUE C-Reit posts 44.5% jump in Q1 amount available for distribution; virus impact still unclear
summary: OUE C-Reit posted a 44.5% increase in the amount available for distribution to S$37.63 million in Q1 2020, driven by contributions following the merger with OUE Hospitality Trust. Revenue rose 40.5% to S$77.73 million, while net property income increased 42.5% to S$62.08 million. The Reit's manager plans to maintain focus on proactive asset management and capital prudence amid the evolving Covid-19 situation, with plans to rebrand the Mandarin Orchard Singapore as the Hilton Singapore Orchard.

site_title: Fiat Chrysler, PSA retain merger target date
summary: Fiat Chrysler (FCA) and PSA have reaffirmed their commitment to a 50/50 merger by early 2021, despite the challenges posed by the COVID-19 pandemic. The automakers stated that they will continue to push ahead on the merger workstreams and aim to complete the transaction by the end of 2020 or early 2021, creating a leading global mobility company.

site_title: EU court faces 'declaration of war' from Germany's top judges
summary: The European Union's top court, the Court of Justice, faced criticism from Germany's constitutional court in Karlsruhe, which accused the EU judges of overstepping their powers in backing the European Central Bank's quantitative easing programme. The German court deemed the EU judges' 2018 ruling as "objectively arbitrary" and "methodologically no longer justifiable." The ECB has been given a three-month ultimatum to address the measure's flaws. This is seen as a significant attack on the EU court's authority, with some labeling it a "declaration of war."

site_title: Biodegradable plastics maker RWDC snags US$133m to scale up production, R&D
summary: RWDC Industries, a Singapore-based biodegradable plastic maker, secured US$133 million in funding to scale up production and R&D. The two-stage Series B funding round was co-led by Vickers Venture Partners, Flint Hills Resources, CPV/CAP Pensionskasse Coop, and International SA, among others. The investment aims to enhance the company's capabilities and contribute to the growing demand for sustainable plastics.

site_title: Oil prices surge on demand hopes as lockdowns ease
summary: Oil prices surged on Tuesday, with West Texas Intermediate crude futures up 18.1% and Brent crude futures up 11.4%, as lockdown measures eased in some European and Asian countries and US states. This recovery in demand hopes pushed oil prices higher for the fourth consecutive session. The increases are attributed to optimism about a rebound in vehicle traffic and fuel demand.

site_title: UK car sales crash to 1946 low on virus lockdown
summary: UK car sales plummeted to a 1946 low in April, with new registrations dropping 97% to 4,321 vehicles, due to the coronavirus lockdown. This marks the worst performance since February 1946 and a 27% slump from last year. The Society of Motor Manufacturers and Traders (SMMT) forecasts around 1.68 million new cars will be registered in 2020, and calls for car retailers to be among the first to reopen when the lockdown lifts to support economic recovery.

site_title: US service sector activity contracts in April
summary: The US services sector contracted for the first time in nearly 10-1/2 years in April, with the Institute for Supply Management's non-manufacturing activity index falling to 41.8, the lowest level since March 2009. This contraction, along with a 4.8% annualized decline in gross domestic product, suggests the economy is reeling from the novel coronavirus-driven recession. Economists expect the economy to struggle to rebound, with historic job losses and a surge in the unemployment rate predicted.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 12.96 points to 1,389.55 on Tuesday, with gains outnumbering losses 774 to 162. The market saw 5.762 billion lots traded worth RM2.699 billion.

site_title: Hong Kong retail slumps in March as Chinese consumers vanish
summary: Hong Kong's retail sales plummeted 42% in March, the largest decline in over two years, as Chinese tourists largely stayed away due to the ongoing pandemic and anti-government protests. The city's wider economy contracted 8.9% in the first quarter, suffering its worst quarter on record. Retailers are struggling to survive, with some accelerating online ordering and home delivery services. The government expects the city to come out of recession gradually towards the end of the year, but warns of a potentially worst full-year performance on record.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares end firmer as city scales back lockdown measures
summary: Hong Kong shares closed 1.1% higher on May 5, 2020, as the city scaled back lockdown measures. The Hang Seng Index rose to 23,868.66, following Asian markets higher. The Hong Kong government relaxed restrictions on public gatherings and allowed gyms, cinemas, and beauty parlours to reopen later this week. With no local transmissions for over two weeks, the city has recorded zero cases for seven of the past 10 days.

site_title: Post-merger OUE C-Reit reports higher amount for distribution in Q1
summary: OUE Commercial Real Estate Investment Trust (C-Reit) reported a 44.5% year-over-year increase in distribution for Q1 2020, reaching S$37.63 million, driven by contributions from post-merger properties. Revenue rose 40.5% to S$77.73 million, while net property income increased 42.5% to S$62.07 million. The Reit's manager will review Q1 and Q2 2020 results to determine H1 2020 distribution levels amid the evolving COVID-19 pandemic.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Koufu unit to stop managing Jurong West Hawker Centre
summary: Koufu's subsidiary, Hawker Management, will stop managing Jurong West Hawker Centre (JWHC) on August 6, 2020, due to poor performance standards despite efforts to revitalize the centre. The decision prioritizes Koufu's business interests, allowing the company to focus on other CSR efforts. The National Environment Agency (NEA) will conduct a request for proposal to enhance JWHC operations and offerings. Existing stallholders will be relocated to other NEA hawker centres or Koufu's food courts, with rental waivers and relocation fees offered as a gesture of goodwill.

site_title: US trade deficit widens to US$44.4b in March on falling exports
summary: The US trade deficit widened to $44.4 billion in March due to a 10% decline in exports and a 6.2% decline in imports, largely attributed to the impact of the coronavirus pandemic. Many businesses operated at limited capacity or ceased operations, and border travel restrictions limited imports. The decline in exports was more pronounced, with transportation and shipping disruptions worldwide contributing to the widening deficit.

site_title: Hong Kong eases some restrictions as new coronavirus cases dwindle
summary: Hong Kong eases some coronavirus restrictions, allowing gyms, cinemas, and beauty parlors to reopen on May 8 as the city experiences a decline in new cases. The government has also lifted restrictions on public gatherings, allowing groups of eight to meet, and some students will return to school at the end of the month. However, bath houses, karaoke bars, and night clubs remain closed. The move aims to boost the economy and provide relief to restaurants and bars, while also preventing a potential resurgence of anti-government protests.

site_title: Amid pandemic, US renewable power sources have topped coal for 40 days
summary: US renewable power sources have topped coal for 40 consecutive days, according to a report by the Institute for Energy Economics and Financial Analysis. This is due to a seasonal increase in low-cost solar and hydro power generation, alongside reduced electricity demand caused by the coronavirus pandemic. Coal-fired power demand is expected to fall 20% this year, while renewable energy generation is forecast to grow 11%. This shift could accelerate a transition away from coal-fired power, potentially leading to renewables exceeding coal on an annual basis for the first time this year.

site_title: US: Wall St jumps as oil recovers, coronavirus-lockdown eases
summary: US stocks jumped on Tuesday as oil prices recovered and countries eased coronavirus-led restrictions. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.88%, the S&P 500 gained 0.92%, and the Nasdaq Composite increased 1.14%. The recovery in oil prices, combined with easing restrictions, boosted investor confidence and drove gains in the market.

site_title: STI ekes out 0.34% gain to 2,572.36
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.34% to close at 2,572.36 on Tuesday, despite a dismal PMI reading. The gains were attributed to a late-session rally on Wall Street as governments relaxed lockdown measures and oil prices increased. However, DBS Equity Research has cautioned that the uptick may not be sustained, predicting a technical downside risk to 2,300 in the coming months. The index's largest market value stock, DBS Group, was recommended a "buy" call by research houses UOB Kay Hian and Phillip Securities Research.

site_title: India stores cheap oil at sea while onshore tanks are full
summary: India's refiners are storing cheap oil on tankers at sea, taking advantage of low prices, as onshore storage tanks are full. The country has 7 million tonnes of oil stored on board tankers, equivalent to 50 million barrels, amid a collapse in crude prices. India's 25 million tonnes of crude and fuel storage are at capacity due to lower demand, and even the strategic reserve tanks are full. Consumption is expected to improve this month as demand picks up, but refiners may be cautious in planning for future crude volumes.

site_title: Aspire to offer Lazada S'pore merchants working capital loans within 3 hours
summary: Aspire, a Singapore-based lending startup, has partnered Lazada to offer working capital loans to Singapore merchants, providing up to S$100,000 within three hours of application. The aim is to support small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) during Singapore's circuit-breaker period. The loans have no obligation to draw the full amount, and interest rates start at 1% per month, with a processing fee of 2-4%. The offer is open to merchants who have been operating on Lazada for at least three months.

site_title: UK new car sales fall to lowest level since 1946
summary: UK new car sales plummeted 97% in April to their lowest level since 1946, with only 4,321 registrations. The decline is attributed to lockdown measures and coronavirus outbreak, with sales to businesses accounting for 80% of the total. The Society of Motor Manufacturers and Traders (SMMT) downgraded its full-year forecast to 1.68 million sales, the lowest in nearly 30 years. This marks a critical sector's worst performance in living memory, with the SMMT calling for a safe restart and revitalization of demand to unlock manufacturing and economic regeneration.

site_title: Britain and US start post-Brexit trade talks
summary: Britain and the US have begun post-Brexit trade talks via videoconference, with 100 negotiators on each side. The two-week talks will cover issues such as goods and services trade, digital trade, and supporting small businesses. The talks aim to boost bilateral trade worth $275 billion, potentially increasing it by £15.3 billion. The UK and US hope for a free trade agreement to stimulate their economies after the COVID-19 pandemic. The talks follow Britain's departure from the EU on January 31 and are part of a transition period that ends on December 31.

site_title: Carnival plans to sail again in August, maybe
summary: Carnival Corp announced that some of its ships may begin sailing again as early as August, despite criticism over its handling of the coronavirus pandemic. Eight ships, part of Carnival Cruise Line, are scheduled to depart from US ports on August 1, with partial reopening and subject to change. This move comes as a government order banning cruises in the US is set to expire. Other cruise companies, such as Royal Caribbean and Norwegian Cruises, have not set a date for restarting their cruises, but may do so earlier.

site_title: Terrace house on Neil Road up for sale with S$5.86m guide price
summary: A freehold two-storey conservation terrace house on Neil Road in Singapore is up for sale with a S$5.86 million guide price. The 4,813 sq ft property, located within the Blair Plain conservation area, is one of only five such houses sold in the area over the past five years. Potential buyers can restore its original charm, making it a rare opportunity to acquire a heritage house in its original condition. The expression of interest (EOI) exercise will close on June 16.

site_title: Australia: Shares end higher on plans to ease virus restrictions
summary: Australian shares rose 1.64% on Tuesday, driven by optimism over plans to ease COVID-19 restrictions. The S&P/ASX 200 index ended at 5,407.1, despite shedding 20.41% for the year. Australia and New Zealand discussed reopening their borders, and investors looked forward to a slow economic recovery.

site_title: Fintech startup Robinhood raises US$280m in round led by Sequoia Capital
summary: Robinhood Markets Inc, a fintech startup, raised US$280 million in funding led by Sequoia Capital, valuing the company at US$8.3 billion. The round follows increased market volatility and stay-at-home orders due to the coronavirus, leading to new sign-ups. This funding comes as fintech startups are attracting investments, with many expected to go public in 2021, potentially due to the pandemic. Robinhood, founded in 2013, disrupted the discount brokerage space with commission-free trading, forcing incumbent brokers to follow suit.

site_title: United Air to cut at least 30 per cent of managers, administrative staff
summary: United Airlines plans to cut at least 30% of managerial and administrative staff, or approximately 3,500 positions, in October due to a prolonged travel slump caused by the COVID-19 pandemic. Employees in non-operational roles will work a four-day week, and cash severance payments will end for managers who are laid off. The move is part of the airline industry's preparations for mass job losses as the federal government's payroll support ends.

site_title: Jewellery maker Pandora's Q1 profit plummets amid lockdowns
summary: Pandora, a Copenhagen-based jewellery maker, reported a 41% decline in Q1 operating profit due to the COVID-19 pandemic. The company's 90% of stores were closed, but higher online sales and store reopenings in Germany and other countries boosted earnings. Pandora secured funding to sustain store closures and withdrew financial guidance for 2020, halting a planned share buyback.

site_title: Europe: Stocks rebound at open
summary: Europe's major equity indices rebounded at the open on Tuesday, with London's FTSE 100 advancing 1.6% to 5,844.02 points, and the eurozone's Frankfurt DAX and Paris CAC 40 gaining 1.5% and 1.6% respectively. The rebound comes as more nations ease coronavirus lockdowns.

site_title: Tokyo governor to ask businesses to refrain from operating until end of May: NHK
summary: Tokyo Governor Yuriko Koike plans to ask businesses to close until the end of May due to the extended state of emergency in Japan. The Tokyo government will provide financial aid to businesses remaining closed, with details to be announced later. Japan's nationwide state of emergency has been extended to May 31, citing a still-high new coronavirus infection rate.

site_title: Malaysia's central bank cuts key interest rate to 2%, lowest since 2009
summary: Malaysia's central bank, Bank Negara Malaysia, cut its key interest rate by 50 basis points to 2.00% on Tuesday, its lowest since 2009, to help the economy recover from the coronavirus pandemic. The decision complements other monetary measures and supports economic activity. The bank expects the economy to suffer its worst performance in over a decade, with a projected 2% contraction or 0.5% growth this year. The move is seen as a response to the government's easing of curbs and the pandemic's impact on energy exports.

site_title: Australia's central bank sees steep contraction, keeps rates unchanged
summary: Australia's central bank, the Reserve Bank of Australia, has forecast the economy will contract by 10% in the first half of the year due to the COVID-19 pandemic, with the unemployment rate expected to double to around 10% by the end of the year. Despite this, the bank expects a recovery in 2021, with a bounce of around 6% next year. The bank held interest rates at a record low of 0.25% and committed to buying government debt to keep yields down.

site_title: Thai PM says coronavirus impact may last another 9 months
summary: Thai Prime Minister Prayuth Chan-ocha stated that the economic impact of the coronavirus pandemic may last for 9 months, affecting the country's tourism and domestic activity. Estimates suggest a loss of over 1.3 trillion baht (S$56.62 billion) and up to 10 million jobs. This prediction is based on ongoing disruption from the global crisis.

site_title: Airline SAS inks credit facility agreement backed by Sweden, Denmark
summary: SAS, the airline part-owned by Sweden and Denmark, has signed a 3.3 billion Swedish crown (S$474.4 million) three-year revolving credit facility agreement, 90% guaranteed by the governments of Sweden and Denmark. This move aims to help the airline navigate the coronavirus crisis, which has severely impacted the airline industry. The agreement is a result of SAS lining up government guarantees earlier this year. The airline's efforts to secure funding come as it seeks to cut costs and staff to cushion the blow from the pandemic.

site_title: NetEase to have filed for second listing in Hong Kong
summary: NetEase, a Chinese online gaming and entertainment company, has filed confidentially for a second listing in Hong Kong, joining other Chinese tech companies in tapping the city's stock market for new funds. The filing is part of ongoing talks with advisers, with a potential share sale happening as soon as the second half of this year. NetEase, which currently trades on the Nasdaq with a market value of about $43 billion, has not made a final decision on the details of the offering.

site_title: Taiwan rebuffs WHO, says China has no right to represent it
summary: Taiwan's Foreign Ministry has rebuffed the World Health Organization's (WHO) request for Taiwan to attend a meeting as an observer, citing China's objections. China considers Taiwan one of its provinces and views its participation as a threat to the "one China" policy. Taiwan's government argues that only it can represent its 23 million people internationally, as the 1971 decision recognizing China at the UN did not grant China the power to represent Taiwan. The WHO has said Taiwan's attendance is up to its 194 member states, but China is expected to block the move.

site_title: Fever check, hand gel, extra space: Air Canada sets virus rules
summary: Air Canada has introduced a new safety protocol to reduce the risk of Covid-19 exposure, effective May 15. Passengers will have their temperature checked before boarding, receive hand sanitizer, and enjoy more personal space in economy class. The protocol includes electrostatic spraying, mandatory mask wearing, and a safety questionnaire. To ensure social distancing, adjacent seats will be blocked and the total number of seats sold will be capped for each flight. Existing measures, such as cabin disinfection and individual water bottles, will also continue. The protocol aims to provide travelers with confidence in flying safely.

site_title: Italy's prime minister says foreign policy hasn't changed: paper
summary: Italy's Prime Minister Giuseppe Conte stated that foreign policy remains unchanged despite receiving aid from China and Russia for the coronavirus emergency. Conte emphasized that Italy's security pillars remain NATO and the European Union. Defence Minister Lorenzo Guerini also confirmed that the aid received from various countries, including the US, Europe, China, and Russia, has not altered Italy's traditional international reference frame. The comments come after US Defense Secretary Mark Esper accused Russia and China of exploiting the virus outbreak to create divisions in Europe.

site_title: China cloud service provider Kingsoft sets terms for US listing
summary: China's Kingsoft Cloud Holdings plans to sell up to $450 million in stock in a US IPO, which could value the cloud service provider at up to $3.6 billion. This would be the first major US IPO by a company that is neither a biotech firm nor a special purpose acquisition company (SPAC) since the coronavirus outbreak in March. Kingsoft offers cloud infrastructure, enterprise cloud, and artificial intelligence services, which have been boosted by the pandemic as businesses shift to digital operations.

site_title: UOB extends S$4b in loans under government-assisted loan scheme
summary: United Overseas Bank (UOB) has approved S$4 billion in loans under Singapore's Enterprise Singapore loan programme, which offers 90% risk-sharing and interest rates as low as 2-3%. The loans were extended to mid-sized enterprise clients in sectors affected by the Covid-19 pandemic, including construction, retail, and hospitality. UOB is the first bank to access the Monetary Authority of Singapore's Singdollar Facility for ESG loans, passing on funding cost savings to clients.

site_title: Coronavirus will constrain US meat supply despite Trump order: Tyson Foods
summary: US meat production remains constrained due to the coronavirus crisis, despite a Trump order to keep facilities open. Tyson Foods reported lower earnings and revenue, citing reduced restaurant demand and meat sales expected to fall in the second half of the year. The company has temporarily closed several plants and is working to resume operations, but the country's capacity to slaughter hogs has dropped by 50% due to the pandemic.

site_title: Temasek-backed India gym, wellness startup lays off staff: sources
summary: India-based wellness startup cure.fit, backed by Temasek Holdings, has laid off around 800 staff and permanently closed several fitness centers due to the coronavirus lockdown. The company, founded by two former Flipkart executives, had expanded into Dubai and offered state-of-the-art group fitness sessions and celebrity endorsements. Cure.fit has initiated pay cuts and closed operations in smaller cities, with around 90% of its cult trainers remaining. The layoffs come as the company adapts to the prolonged lockdown, with plans to move all classes online.

site_title: Indonesia's farms, plantations to face 'drier than usual' dry season
summary: Indonesia is expected to face a "drier than usual" dry season in key agricultural regions this year, threatening food security and price stability, according to President Jokowi Widodo. The country, the world's top producer of palm oil, coconut, and fourth-largest coffee exporter, will experience harsher dry seasons in 30% of its regions, according to the national weather and climate agency. Measures must be taken to mitigate the impact on work and food prices.

site_title: Finland to let restaurants, theatres reopen from June 1 as curbs ease
summary: Finland to ease coronavirus restrictions starting June 1, allowing restaurants to reopen gradually and public services like libraries and sports facilities to resume. The ban on public meetings will be relaxed from 10 to 50 people, and essential travel to Europe's Schengen area will be permitted from May 14. Professional sports events will restart under "special arrangements" with crowd restrictions. The government aims to move from widespread restrictions to a hybrid strategy of testing, tracing, and treating.

site_title: BNP Paribas warns on profit after US$1.2b virus hit
summary: BNP Paribas has warned that its full-year earnings could be 15-20% lower than in 2019 due to the impact of the coronavirus outbreak. The French lender set aside over $1.2 billion in charges and writedowns, including $502 million for future bad credit, and reported a US$200 million hit at its trading unit. Net income fell by a third and revenue declined by 2.3% due to lockdown measures and market volatility. The bank's chief financial officer attributed the decline to the uncertainty of the economic recovery, expecting a return to normalcy by the end of 2021.

site_title: Brazil fears agriculture protectionism amid pandemic: draft report
summary: Brazil is concerned about potential global agricultural protectionism amid the coronavirus pandemic, according to a draft report from the agriculture ministry. The report warns of countries imposing export restrictions, subsidies, and other policies to favor domestic agriculture industries. Brazil, a major agricultural exporter, expects more state intervention in agricultural markets and urges the government to sign more trade agreements to ensure favorable market access for its farm products. The report also emphasizes the need for Brazil to diversify its exports and strengthen food safety measures.

site_title: Hugo Boss expects virus hit to worsen before recovery
summary: Hugo Boss reports a 17% fall in first-quarter sales to 555 million euros, worse than forecast, due to the coronavirus pandemic. However, the company expects a gradual improvement in the retail environment from the third quarter, positively impacting sales and earnings in the second half of the year. Online sales jumped 39% for the first quarter and accelerated in April. The company is targeting extra cost savings of at least 150 million euros and plans to cut its inventory by at least 200 million euros.

site_title: Singapore retail sales down 13.3% in March
summary: Singapore's retail sales plummeted 13.3% year-over-year in March, the largest decline in two decades, due to the Covid-19 outbreak. Food and beverage services were particularly hard hit, with takings down 23.7% year-over-year. This marks a deeper decline from February's -8.4% fall.

site_title: Insurance policies to cover CCF stays, outpatient telemedicine amid 'circuit breaker'
summary: Singapore has introduced new insurance policies to cover Covid-19 patients in Community Care Facilities (CCFs) and Community Recovery Facilities (CRFs) for up to 14 days after transfer from a hospital. The government will also fully cover costs of treatment and isolation in these facilities. Outpatient telemedicine claims will now be covered under Integrated Shield Plans and group insurance policies. The extended coverage is part of insurer efforts to support policyholders amid the pandemic, and will be in effect until the closure of the last CCF or CRF.

site_title: Razer Fintech organises May 15-17 hackathon to solve financial challenges amid pandemic
summary: Razer Fintech is launching a digital hackathon in Singapore from May 15-17 to address financial challenges exacerbated by the Covid-19 pandemic. The event aims to encourage tertiary students, young professionals, and startups to develop innovative banking solutions. Winning participants can secure full-time employment, internships, investments, or commercial partnerships within Razer Fintech's ecosystem or with its partners. The hackathon will provide a platform for participants to think creatively and develop solutions to critical financial issues.

site_title: Moody's lowers outlook on MCT to negative amid Covid-19 pandemic
summary: Moody's has lowered its outlook on Mapletree Commercial Trust (MCT) to negative due to the impact of the Covid-19 pandemic on retail spending, office space demand, and cash flows. The trust's credit metrics are expected to weaken, and its liquidity is inadequate over the next 12-18 months, with upcoming debt maturities. Moody's has affirmed the trust's Baa1 issuer rating and senior unsecured ratings, citing its diversified tenant profile and track record of prudent financial management.

site_title: Vietnam PM says economy must grow faster than 2.7% IMF forecast
summary: Vietnam's Prime Minister Nguyen Xuan Phuc said the country's economy must grow faster than the 2.7% forecast by the International Monetary Fund, as the economy resumes after a lockdown due to the coronavirus. Despite a slow 3.8% growth in the first quarter, Phuc emphasized the need for faster growth to provide jobs and reduce poverty. The government has set a target of 6.8% growth for the year, and plans to spend up to $42.3 billion on infrastructure projects. Inflation is also expected to be kept below 4%.

site_title: Singapore shares edge up at Tuesday's open; STI up 0.7%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 0.7% to 2,582.64 at Tuesday's open, tracking US gains. Gainers outnumbered losers 140 to 44, with Thai Beverage Public Co, CapitaLand Mall Trust, and Singtel among the top movers. Local banks DBS, OCBC, and UOB also rose. In contrast, European stocks ended lower due to Sino-US tensions, while Hong Kong stocks rose despite data showing its economy suffered its worst contraction on record in the first quarter.

site_title: Christie's sale to help charity's coronavirus fund after Cannes postponement
summary: Auction house Christie's will hold a sale to raise funds for amfAR's COVID-19 research fund after the Cannes Film Festival gala was postponed due to the coronavirus. The sale will feature contemporary artworks donated by leading collectors and artists, with all proceeds going towards amfAR's newly established fund. The auction is set to coincide with Christie's New York spring sales in June. The move aims to bridge the gap in fundraising and address the urgent threat of COVID-19, following amfAR's annual Cannes gala, which raised $15 million last year.

site_title: Doctor who treated first US Covid-19 patient fears second wave
summary: Dr. George Díaz, the US doctor who treated the first Covid-19 patient, fears a second wave of the disease when lockdown measures are lifted. He believes isolation remains the most effective treatment, despite the approval of the anti-viral drug Remdesivir. The US has the highest caseload and deaths, with over 1.2 million cases and 69,000 deaths, and Dr. Díaz worries about the country's ability to handle a second outbreak, citing concerns over resources and the need for continued social distancing.

site_title: Screens at hotel check-in among measures proposed to fight virus
summary: The US Travel Association has released guidelines for the sector's largest trade association, focusing on health and safety measures to reopen hard-hit travel businesses. The guidelines, similar to security measures after 9/11, include plastic screens at hotel check-in desks, social distancing measures, hand-sanitizer kiosks, and sanitizing facilities. The recommendations aim to minimize contact between customers and staff, with a focus on testing workers and keeping those with symptoms at home. The move aims to inspire confidence in travelers and demonstrate leadership to public health authorities.

site_title: Call centres expose fault line in Japan's pandemic fight
