summary: Japan's pandemic fight has exposed a fault line in its approach, as call centres continue to operate despite crowded offices, resulting in confirmed infections. Dozens of call centre employees commute to work, citing concerns about data security and productivity. Japan has taken a less forceful approach than many countries, and companies fear a decline in worker productivity and customer service. The government has targeted a 70-80% reduction in person-to-person contact, but call centres have resisted telecommuting due to fears of data leaks.

site_title: Duterte says sorry to Philippine tycoons, their firms' shares surge
summary: Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte apologized to tycoons Manuel Pangilinan and the Ayala family for his "hurting words" about their companies' regulatory issues, following their help in fighting the coronavirus. The apology led to a surge in shares of conglomerates Ayala and Metro Pacific Investments, owners of the country's two largest water distributors. Duterte expressed a willingness to talk and be reasonable, after repeatedly criticizing the billionaires in the past.

images.alt_text: Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte has apologised for his "hurting words" about two tycoons whom he openly dislikes, responding to their help in fighting the coronavirus by offering an olive branch to settle a costly regulatory row.

site_title: Covid-19's impact felt on Malaysia's export figures
summary: Malaysia's export figures show a 4.7% year-on-year decline in March, while imports fell 2.7% year-on-year, resulting in a stable trade surplus of RM12.3 billion. The decline is attributed to softer end-demand and the implementation of the Movement Control Order (MCO) in March. Economists predict that exports will continue to drag in Q2, with a potential 1% reduction in 2020 GDP if the CMCO remains in place.

site_title: Sequoia India, Alpha JWC lead US$25.4m Series A round for Indonesia online marketplace
summary: Indonesian online marketplace GudangAda secured US$25.4 million in a Series A funding round led by Sequoia India and Alpha JWC Ventures. This investment brings the startup's total funds raised to US$36 million, supporting its growth amid the pandemic. GudangAda, which connects mom-and-pop stores with wholesalers, plans to recruit over 100 employees and strengthen its mid-senior team in technology and product management. The funding is part of a surge in online activity and e-commerce investments globally.

site_title: Home-flipping giant Opendoor says it's time to resume buying
summary: Opendoor, a home-flipping startup, plans to resume buying homes in Phoenix and expand to over 20 additional markets. The company halted operations in March due to the coronavirus pandemic and laid off staff, but CEO Eric Wu believes it's safe to start shopping again. Opendoor uses debt to buy homes and holds them until reselling, which carries risks, especially if the US is in a recession or hit by a second wave of the virus. The company aims to offer virtual tours and limit personal interactions to minimize risks.

site_title: Shell's Philippines unit to suspend refinery operations for one month
summary: Pilipinas Shell Petroleum has announced it will temporarily shut down its 110,000-barrel-per-day Tabangao refinery in the Philippines for one month starting mid-May 2020 due to the COVID-19 pandemic's impact on oil demand. The shutdown will help insulate the company from further potential drops in refining margins and aid in cash conservation initiatives. The refinery's operations will comply with the government's minimum inventory requirement during the shutdown. The move comes as the Philippines, including Manila and parts of Luzon, remains under enhanced community quarantine.

site_title: Indonesia's Q1 GDP growth slows to weakest since 2001 on virus curbs
summary: Indonesia's Q1 GDP growth slowed to 2.97% in January-March, the weakest since 2001, due to the coronavirus pandemic's impact on business activity. This is significantly lower than the forecasted 4.04% and the central bank's predicted 4.3%. The slowdown is attributed to the pandemic's curbs on economic growth, marking a challenging time for Southeast Asia's largest economy.

site_title: New Zealand joins Australia's coronavirus cabinet meeting to discuss travel hub
summary: New Zealand Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern joined Australia's coronavirus cabinet meeting to discuss reopening borders to trans-Tasman travel. Both countries have low Covid-19 mortality rates and are planning to slowly reopen their economies. They aim to establish a travel "hub" between the two countries, with Australia's Premier Gladys Berejiklian expressing hope for a positive economic cooperation. The meeting follows New Zealand's announcement of the "next stage in our economic rebuild" potentially including trans-Tasman travel, as both countries keep their borders closed to other countries.

site_title: L Brands, Sycamore agree to call off Victoria's Secret deal
summary: L Brands has agreed to call off its $525 million sale to Sycamore, averting a legal battle over the deal. The company will instead operate Victoria's Secret and Bath & Body Works as separate units, focusing on navigating a challenging business environment. Sycamore Partners will not be required to pay a termination fee, and both parties will settle pending litigation. L Brands' board has appointed Stuart Burgdoerfer as interim CEO of Victoria's Secret, replacing Leslie Wexner who stepped down earlier this year.

images.alt_text: L Brands Inc said on Monday it has agreed to call off the sale of its majority stake in Victoria's Secret lingerie business to buyout firm Sycamore, averting a bitter legal battle between the two companies over the US$525 million deal.

site_title: Asia: Stocks and oil rally as nations begin to slowly reopen
summary: Asian stocks and oil prices surged as lockdowns in some countries eased, offsetting concerns over the US-China trade row. The death toll from coronavirus surpassed 250,000, but investors saw a glimmer of hope as governments in Europe and Asia-Pacific began to reopen. Oil prices rose as producers cut output, and markets in Hong Kong, Sydney, and Singapore gained 1% or more. However, caution remained due to fears of a second wave of infections and a long recovery from economic destruction.

site_title: Israel isolates coronavirus antibody in 'significant breakthrough': Israeli defence minister
summary: Israel has isolated a key coronavirus antibody, a "monoclonal neutralising antibody," at its main biological research laboratory, the Israeli Institute for Biological Research (IIBR). The antibody, which can neutralise the virus inside carriers' bodies, is being patented and will be mass-produced by an international manufacturer. This breakthrough is a significant step toward a possible treatment for COVID-19. The antibody was developed by testing blood from those who recovered from the virus, and its monoclonal nature makes it potentially more potent than other antibody treatments.

site_title: New York to allow construction and manufacturing to reopen first-governor
summary: New York Governor Andrew Cuomo outlines a phased reopening of business activity, starting with construction and manufacturing in select regions. The plan, set to begin after May 15, will assess four metrics: new infections, hospital capacity, testing capacity, and disease investigators. The reopening will be divided into four phases, with the first phase focusing on low-risk regions such as northern and central parts of the state. Cuomo warns that a rapid reopening could spark a resurgence of the virus, which has killed nearly 20,000 people in the Northeast.

site_title: Smithfield starts to reopen US pork plant shut by coronavirus
summary: Smithfield Foods, the world's largest pork processor, has started to reopen a US pork plant in Sioux Falls, South Dakota, that was shut down due to coronavirus cases among employees. The plant, which accounts for 5% of US pork production, reopened with about 250 of its 3,700 workers returning to work. The company has not resumed slaughtering hogs, and employees are being tested for COVID-19. The reopening is a step towards gradually restarting operations at the facility.

site_title: Meat shortages leave Wendy's diners asking, 'Where's the beef?'
summary: US meat shortages have led to some Wendy's restaurants removing burgers from their menus, despite the chain's marketing of fresh and never-frozen beef. Customers are taking to social media to express their disappointment, referencing the 1980s catchphrase "Where's the beef?" The shortages have prompted concerns about the availability of beef nationwide, with some stores only offering chicken items for takeout or delivery orders.

site_title: Ninja Van raises US$279m in Series D funding round
summary: Ninja Van, a logistics provider, has raised US$279 million in its Series D funding round led by GeoPost and two sovereign wealth funds. The funding will help the company focus on delivery solutions for sellers and customers in South-east Asia, while expanding into the business-to-business sector. Returning investors, including Eduardo Saverin's B Capital Group, also participated in the round. The new capital will support Ninja Van's vision to create an ecosystem providing value-added services to small and medium-sized enterprises and direct-to-consumer brands in the region.

site_title: Hong Kong may open movie theatres, gyms this week: Cable TV
summary: Hong Kong may reopen movie theatres and gyms this week, following two weeks without a locally transmitted coronavirus infection. The city's government is considering further relaxing social distancing measures, including doubling the group gathering limit to eight. Other businesses, such as beauty parlours, may also reopen. The move poses a dilemma for Chief Executive Carrie Lam, as it could facilitate the return of mass anti-Beijing protests. The government will review the feasibility of the measures and make adjustments as needed.

site_title: Qantas extends flight cancellations for 2 more months, raises more debt
summary: Qantas extends flight cancellations through July, raising more debt, and secures A$550 million in funding to support operations through 2021 if the coronavirus crisis prolongs. The airline expects a net cash burn rate of A$40 million a week by June and has short-term liquidity of A$3.5 billion. CEO Alan Joyce states that international travel demand may take years to return to pre-pandemic levels.

site_title: Asia: Markets closed on Tuesday for holiday
summary: Financial markets in China, Japan, and South Korea were closed on Tuesday due to public holidays. In Europe, stocks fell due to bank and healthcare sector declines, with US-EU trade tensions in focus. US stocks also edged down from records amid tariff threats, despite the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reaching fresh highs. Meanwhile, Singapore stocks experienced a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data, and a company made a mandatory offer for the rest of a Singaporean company. Traders largely disregarded new US threats to extend the stocks rally.

site_title: Philippines inflation eases to 5-month low in April
summary: The Philippines' annual inflation rate eased to a 5-month low of 2.2% in April, reflecting the drop in global oil prices and weaker economic activity due to the coronavirus outbreak. This rate is close to the central bank's target of 2% and is slightly above the forecast of 2.1%. Core inflation, excluding food and fuel prices, slowed to 2.8% from 3.0% in March, providing the central bank with greater room to cut interest rates and support growth. Economists expect the central bank to continue easing policies to support the economy.

site_title: General Electric to cut 10,000 aviation jobs
summary: General Electric (GE) is cutting 10,000 aviation jobs, a mix of voluntary departures and layoffs, due to the coronavirus pandemic's impact on the industry. The 25% reduction in aviation employment aims to protect the company's business. This move follows Boeing's 16,000 job cuts and Airbus's production reductions. GE's aviation division saw revenue fall 13% and orders down 14%. The company is part of a US$3 billion savings plan and has frozen hiring and cancelled bonuses.

site_title: Green recovery can revive virus-hit economies and tackle climate change: study
summary: A new study suggests that massive green public investments can be the most cost-effective way to revive virus-hit economies and combat climate change. Co-authored by Nobel laureate Joseph Stiglitz and Lord Nicholas Stern, the study found that green projects such as boosting renewable energy and energy efficiency create more jobs and deliver higher returns compared to traditional stimulus measures. The authors recommend prioritizing sectors like clean physical infrastructure, building efficiency, and climate-friendly agriculture in recovery packages, and caution that governments can choose to pursue net zero emissions targets or lock in a fossil fuel system.

images.alt_text: Massive programmes of green public investment would be the most cost-effective way both to revive virus-hit economies and strike a decisive blow against climate change, top US and British economists said in a study published on Tuesday.

site_title: Apple, Google ban use of location tracking in contact tracing apps
summary: Apple and Google have banned the use of location tracking in contact tracing apps, citing privacy concerns and preventing governments from compiling data on citizens. The companies plan to allow only public health authorities to use the technology, which uses Bluetooth signals to detect encounters. The decision will require public health authorities to rely on unstable workarounds, potentially missing encounters due to battery-saving features. Some apps, like Utah's Healthy Together, plan to stick to their own approaches, while others, like Alberta's ABTraceTogether, have no plans to adopt the system.

site_title: HC Surgical: Julian Ong must get patients' written consent with nurse as witness
summary: Singaporean healthcare group HC Surgical Specialists has implemented new measures to protect its interests following a Singapore Medical Council complaint against surgeon Julian Ong. Ong must now provide patients with a statement of facts and obtain written consent from them, with a nurse present as a witness. The company has also disclosed that it may exercise a put option to repurchase the 70% stake in Ong's clinic, with the consideration payable decreasing over time. The measures are part of a 10-year service agreement between Ong and HC Surgical.

site_title: FSL Trust posts Q1 DPU of 1.5 US cents
summary: FSL Trust posted a Q1 DPU of 1.5 US cents, its second consecutive payment in over seven years. The vessel owner's net profit more than doubled to US$6.7 million, driven by gains from vessel sales and reduced finance expenses. Revenue slipped 3.6% to US$18.4 million due to a smaller fleet. Despite COVID-19's impact on global trade, FSL Trust remains cautiously optimistic, citing strong tanker markets and improved capital structure.

site_title: CapitaLand's jointly-owned office building 79 Robinson Road receives TOP
summary: CapitaLand's 29-storey office building 79 Robinson Road has received its temporary occupation permit (TOP) on April 28, 2020. The 518,000 sq ft office development is jointly-owned by CapitaLand, Mitsui & Co, and Tokyo Tatemono. Tenants will move in from June 2020, with 70% leasing pre-commitment secured from multinational companies. Bridge+, CapitaLand's co-working business unit, will occupy 56,000 sq ft and open in Q4 2020, with plans to establish a fintech hub.

site_title: Property tech startup Cadre plans fund to buy in economic slump
summary: Cadre, a real estate technology startup, plans to launch a new fund to capitalize on opportunities in the economic downturn following the coronavirus pandemic. The fund, which will make commercial real estate bets, is being discussed with key investors and aims to raise several hundred million dollars. Cadre will use its proprietary technology and human expertise to underwrite property deals, analyzing 40,000 variables and 3 million data points. The startup initially focused on standalone property deals but sees the new fund as a way to accelerate growth and deploy capital at a faster pace.

site_title: AMTD International, SGX ink long-term strategic partnership
summary: AMTD International, a Hong Kong-headquartered financial services firm, has entered into a long-term strategic partnership with the Singapore Exchange (SGX) to promote the development of Singapore's capital markets. The partnership aims to enhance access to Singapore and beyond, connecting Singapore, Asean, and other regions. AMTD International will leverage its SpiderNet ecosystem to foster collaboration among partners, including shareholders, clients, and government bodies. This partnership is expected to strengthen the connectivity and growth of Singapore's capital markets.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares open with gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.60% or 141.97 points to 23,755.77, driven by bargain-buying after the previous day's losses. This offset data showing the city's economy suffered its worst contraction on record in the first quarter. Markets in mainland China were closed for a holiday.

site_title: Australia consumers see glimmer of hope, start to spend more
summary: Australian consumers' confidence has shown a slight improvement, rising 5.3% to 89.5 in the latest week, marking the fifth straight week of gains. This comes after the country successfully contained the coronavirus, sparking hopes of easing economic lockdowns. The measure of confidence is still below the long-run average of 112.9, but a significant increase from a record low of 65.3 in late March.

site_title: US coronavirus deaths rise by 1,015 in 24 hours, lowest in a month: Johns Hopkins
summary: US coronavirus deaths rose by 1,015 in 24 hours, the lowest one-day figure in a month, according to Johns Hopkins University. The total number of cases stands at 1.17 million, with 68,689 deaths. President Donald Trump's worst-case scenario of 100,000 deaths may be reached as soon as next month, according to scientific models.

site_title: Time's up for troubled HK businesses
summary: Hong Kong's court presiding over failing businesses is set to reopen after a three-month halt, sparking concerns among creditors that hundreds of small- and medium-sized businesses will be forced into liquidation. The absence of a restructuring regime has left lenders with limited options, and the court's reopening is expected to lead to a surge in petitions. Creditors warn that delinquent directors may siphon off assets, while landlords are advised to consider cutting rents rather than seeking court remedies. The government has announced plans to introduce a corporate rescue regime, but experts are skeptical of its effectiveness.

site_title: Lendlease Global Reit posts Q3 DPU of 1.28 S cents, 0.7% above IPO forecast
summary: Lendlease Global Reit reported a Q3 DPU of 1.28 Singapore cents, 0.7% above its IPO forecast of 1.27 cents. Gross revenue increased 2.2% to S$21.7 million, driven by rental income from 313@somerset and higher contributions from Sky Complex in Milan. Net property income rose 4% to S$16.6 million, largely due to higher gross revenue and lower operating expenses. The results exceeded the manager's initial public offering forecast.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 5.29 points, or 0.38%, to 1,381.88 on Tuesday, driven by gains. Volume was 205.31 million lots worth RM56.63 million.

site_title: France toll tops 25,000 as PM defends post-lockdown plan
summary: France reached 25,201 coronavirus deaths on Monday, surpassing 25,000. Prime Minister Edouard Philippe defended the government's plan to ease the lockdown, citing the need to resume economic life and saying the confinement's social and economic cost is "colossal." Despite criticism from mayors and the Senate, the government plans to unveil final details of the post-lockdown plan on Thursday.

site_title: Australia, New Zealand: Shares rise as US tech rally lifts sentiment
summary: Australian shares rose 0.98% to 5,372.1, driven by a US technology stocks rally and improved local consumer confidence, following a 1.4% gain on Monday. The gains helped counter concerns over Sino-US tensions. US stocks also rose, with major tech companies snapping a two-session losing streak.

site_title: Air France makes masks compulsory for passengers
summary: Air France has announced that masks will be compulsory for passengers starting May 11, 2020, as France emerges from its lockdown. Passengers are required to bring their own masks and the airline will implement physical distancing measures on board. The move follows French government instructions making mask-wearing compulsory on public transport. The airline industry is facing a crisis due to the pandemic, and Air France has received a 7 billion euro loan package to improve profitability and reduce greenhouse gas emissions.

site_title: Hertz prepares to file bankruptcy if Monday deadline is missed
summary: Hertz Global Holdings is preparing to file for bankruptcy as soon as Monday if it fails to rework its debt and secure a grace period from lenders. The company has been struggling due to the COVID-19 pandemic's impact on the travel industry, with a $50 billion bailout plan for airlines not available to Hertz. With dismal demand, a large fleet, and plunging used car prices, Hertz lacks liquidity and has begun laying off workers. A Chapter 11 filing would allow the company to stay in business while reworking a plan to pay creditors.

site_title: Global coronavirus death toll tops 250,000: AFP tally
summary: The global coronavirus death toll has surpassed 250,000, with the majority of deaths occurring in Europe and the US, according to an AFP tally. The US has recorded 68,689 fatalities, while Europe has seen 145,023 confirmed deaths. The virus has infected over 3.5 million people worldwide, causing widespread economic devastation since its emergence in China in December.

site_title: Stocks to watch: AMTD, SGX, Lendlease Global Reit, FSL Trust, CapitaLand, Keppel, HC Surgical
summary:
Here's a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

Several companies saw new developments that may affect trading of their shares on Tuesday. AMTD International, a Hong Kong-headquartered financial services firm, entered into a long-term strategic partnership with the Singapore Exchange. Lendlease Global Reit posted a 0.7% higher distribution per unit, while FSL Trust approved its first distribution payment in over seven years. CapitaLand received its temporary occupation permit for a 29-storey office development. Keppel Corp appointed Evercore Asia as its independent financial adviser. HC Surgical Specialists' surgeon is required to provide a statement of facts regarding a complaint against him.

site_title: Britain needs good trade deal with EU to remove uncertainty for US firms: US Chamber
summary: The US Chamber of Commerce urges Britain to conclude a bilateral trade deal with the EU as quickly as possible to remove uncertainty for US firms, who have invested over $750 billion in the UK to secure access to the EU single market. The group recommends eliminating all tariffs in bilateral trade discussions to boost the long-term outlook for both countries. Redefining Britain's ties to Brussels before working out trade deals with other countries is also advised, but opportunities for advancing global standards in digital economy, financial services, and emerging technologies are noted.

site_title: Olam to terminate sale and revenue share arrangement of US onion, garlic processing plant
summary: Olam International has terminated its sale and revenue sharing arrangement for its onion and garlic facility in Gilroy, California, due to financial challenges caused by the COVID-19 pandemic. The company had sold the facility's real estate assets to Mesirow Financial for $110.3 million in December 2019. However, Mesirow was unable to secure debt and equity financing, leading Olam to mutually agree to terminate the revenue sharing arrangement. Olam will record any difference between the assets' current fair value and the consideration in its financial statements for the half year ending June 30, 2020.

site_title: US Navy ships in Barents Sea near Russia, 1st time since 1980s
summary: The US Navy sent four ships to the Barents Sea near Russia for the first time in over 30 years, conducting Arctic security operations to assert freedom of navigation and demonstrate alliance integration. The move comes amid increased rival challenges from China and Russia, particularly during the coronavirus pandemic. The operation involved US and British vessels, with the US Navy stating its goal is to showcase seamless cooperation among allies in the strategically important Arctic region.

site_title: Niger labour minister died from coronavirus: public TV
summary: Niger's Minister of Employment and Labour, Mohamed Ben Omar, died from complications related to COVID-19, according to public television. The 55-year-old minister had urged workers to protect themselves from the virus before his death. Niger has recorded 755 COVID-19 infections and 37 deaths, with the country having declared a state of emergency and taken measures to contain the spread of the virus. President Mahamadou Issoufou expressed his condolences, describing Ben Omar's death as a "heavy blow".

site_title: Europe: Stocks kick off May on dour note, ThyssenKrupp leads losses
summary: European stocks began May with a 2.7% decline, with the pan-European Stoxx 600 closing lower due to fresh Sino-US tensions and concerns over a potential trade spat between the world's two largest economies. US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo claimed evidence the coronavirus emerged from a Chinese laboratory, prompting China's Global Times to call him a "bluff." European oil and gas stocks fell, and sectors sensitive to economic growth, including automakers and banking, were particularly affected.

images.alt_text: European stocks ended lower on Monday as investors were greeted with fresh Sino-US tensions following a May Day break, after Washington threatened tariffs against China over the coronavirus.

site_title: Chaos outside liquor stores as India eases virus lockdown
summary: India has eased its 40-day coronavirus lockdown, allowing liquor stores to reopen, sparking chaos outside stores as people rush to buy alcohol. Police used batons to control crowds, and some states allowed liquor stores to open earlier, while others remained shut. The government has introduced a 70% "special corona fee" on liquor sales to boost revenue. Despite the lockdown, India has reported relatively modest Covid-19 cases and deaths, but the lockdown has also left millions of workers jobless and dealt a blow to the country's economy.

site_title: US milestone of 100,000 virus deaths likely by June
summary: US President Donald Trump now predicts 100,000 coronavirus deaths, a grim milestone likely to be reached by June, according to scientific models. Trump initially stated a worst-case scenario of 1.2 million deaths, but now says lockdown measures would have prevented a much higher toll. The models do not predict a halt to the virus's spread by summer, contradicting Trump's claim.

site_title: Working in fear, immigrants keep US poultry plants running
summary: US poultry plants continue to operate despite the COVID-19 pandemic, with low-paid immigrant workers like Tina, a 27-year-old Haitian mother, risking their health to maintain production. The industry, which relies heavily on cheap labor, has seen a disproportionate impact, with many workers refusing to stay home due to fear of job loss. Local health authorities are stepping up testing, but concerns remain about worker safety, hospitalization fears, and the language barrier for many Haitians. The US government has designated the sector as essential, but critics argue that more should be done to protect workers.

images.alt_text: Tina says a little prayer every time she heads to work at a Delaware poultry plant, a plea that this will not be the day that the invisible killer picking off her colleagues comes for her.

site_title: US Treasury to borrow record US$2.99t in Q2
summary: The US Treasury announced it will borrow a record $2.999 trillion in the April-June period to finance COVID-19 relief programs, exceeding the total debt issued in most years. This is the largest three-month borrowing in US history, driven by increased expenditures from new legislation and deferred taxes. The government expects to borrow $677 billion in the July-September quarter. Despite the massive amount, the US government is expected to have no problems finding buyers for the debt, seen as a solid investment for domestic and foreign investors.

site_title: Game world star PewDiePie signs exclusive deal with YouTube
summary: PewDiePie, a popular YouTube star, has signed an exclusive deal with the Google-owned video platform, making him its top creator. With 104 million subscribers and over 25 billion views, PewDiePie, whose real name is Felix Kjellberg, will continue to create content and interact with fans on the platform. This move comes as online gaming and video streaming have surged during the pandemic, with YouTube being the largest global gaming platform with over 200 million gamers daily.

site_title: Half of developers likely to cut prices of Singapore new launches
summary: Singapore property developers are likely to lower selling prices of new launches, with 50% anticipating a price cut in the next six months, according to the Real Estate Sentiment Index. The index, which hit a record low in Q1 2020, reflects the impact of the Covid-19 pandemic. A survey also found 54% expect a 2-5% new sale price fall, while 46% anticipate a 5-8% slide in resale prices in 2020. The decline in sentiment and prices may test demand for prime projects above S$3,000 psf.

site_title: Oil up 3% as countries ease lockdowns, production falls
summary: Oil prices rose 3% on Monday as countries eased lockdowns and crude supply cuts took hold. Global fuel demand fell 30% in April due to stay-at-home orders, but analysts expect swift action by major oil producers to reduce supply glut. Brent crude settled at $27.20 a barrel, up 76 cents, while US West Texas Intermediate crude gained 61 cents to $20.39 a barrel. Goldman Sachs raised its 2021 forecast for Brent to $55.63 a barrel, citing lower crude production and a partial recovery in oil demand.

site_title: The pandemic isn't changing everything
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic may accelerate existing trends rather than fundamentally change the world. The pandemic has intensified inward tendencies, such as nationalism, protectionism, and the retreat from globalization, which were already underway. Global trade is projected to fall around 15% in 2020, and the extent of the post-virus recovery could be dampened by divisive trade politics. The shift to an online economy has accelerated, with internet traffic surging 50-70% in developed nations and social media platforms reporting record usage. The pandemic has also accelerated the rise of digital gaming, which could have significant implications for the global economy.

site_title: Government to look into raising housing standards for migrant workers: Teo
summary: Singapore's government will investigate raising housing standards for migrant workers after the COVID-19 outbreak is controlled. Manpower Minister Josephine Teo acknowledged that focusing on rooming arrangements alone may not prevent future outbreaks. The government has set up a task force to coordinate the response, which includes introducing safe-distancing measures, medical operations, and recovery facilities. Teo also noted that the government will review areas where improvements can be made to better prepare for future outbreaks.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Jumbo Group expects to report a significantly lower profit after tax for H1 FY2020 due to the impact of Covid-19 across its markets. Keppel Corp has appointed Evercore Asia as the independent financial adviser on Temasek Holdings' partial offer to acquire an additional 30.55% stake in Keppel. Despite a healthy working capital position, Jumbo Group prioritizes preserving cash until the Covid-19 situation improves.

site_title: US government projects virus deaths to soar in May
summary: The US government projects a significant surge in COVID-19 cases and deaths, with new cases forecast to reach 200,000 per day by June 1 and daily deaths to nearly double to 3,000 by the end of the month. This prediction contradicts President Trump's claim of a 100,000 death worst-case scenario. The White House acknowledged the authenticity of the internal CDC document but claimed it was not part of the president's task force or vetting process. The projection suggests US states may be moving too fast to reopen their economies.

site_title: Fighting the virus with novel weapons
summary: Singaporean company SUTL Environtech, distributor of the US-manufactured self-disinfecting coating sdst, is expanding its offerings to tackle the novel coronavirus outbreak. Demand for sdst has surged, transforming the company from a loss-making SME to barely meeting orders in months. SUTL Environtech plans to become a manufacturer of environmentally friendly products, including a surface disinfectant that won't contaminate water systems, and establish a manufacturing facility in Singapore. The company aims to reduce reliance on overseas brands and supply chains, and expand its reach in South-east Asia, China, and India.

site_title: WHO says has no proof from US on 'speculative' Wuhan lab claims
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) stated that the US has provided no evidence to support its claims that the COVID-19 virus originated in a Chinese lab, describing the claims as "speculative." WHO emergencies director Michael Ryan emphasized the importance of a science-based investigation into the virus's origin, which is believed to have emerged from animals to humans in China. The WHO has offered to assist Chinese scientists in investigating the animal origins of the pandemic, but warned that any investigation should be free from politics and focused on scientific inquiry.

images.alt_text: The World Health Organization said on Monday that Washington had provided no evidence to support "speculative" claims by the US president that the new coronavirus originated in a Chinese lab.

site_title: US Senate returns under new virus guidance
summary: The US Senate convened for its first regular session in five weeks on May 4, 2020, with new coronavirus guidelines in place amid a pandemic that has killed 68,000 Americans and left tens of millions jobless. Lawmakers are expected to address disputes over confronting the outbreak and mitigating its economic impacts. The Senate Majority Leader, Mitch McConnell, emphasized the importance of following safety protocols, while Democrats, including Senator Chuck Schumer, criticized the lack of action on addressing the pandemic's economic impacts.

site_title: US: Stocks end higher, shrugging off early weakness
summary: US stocks ended higher on Monday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average rising 0.1% to 23,749.76, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index rose 0.4% and 1.2% respectively. The gains came despite early weakness and a drop in airline shares, following Florida's reopening of its economy. Investors are encouraged by states' cautious reopenings and a leveling off of coronavirus cases.

site_title: Bobok till you drop: S Koreans roar back to malls as virus curbs ease
summary: In South Korea, a surge in "revenge shopping" has boosted the economy as people rush to make purchases delayed by social-distancing rules. With the easing of coronavirus curbs, malls and beaches have seen a massive influx of shoppers, with some stores selling out quickly. The government plans to relax rules further from May 6, but economists warn that the bounce-back in spending will be short-lived due to a bleak outlook for international trade and dropping corporate investment.

site_title: Living and working in a post-pandemic world
summary: A global pandemic has shifted how we think about home, work, and community, forcing businesses to digitize and adopt remote working measures. As work-from-home measures persist, the long-term effects are likely to change how we think about home and work. Flexibility in home and work arrangements will be key, with people seeking living arrangements that cater to their evolving lifestyle and needs. The pandemic has also highlighted the importance of community, with co-living and other housing options gaining popularity. Businesses specializing in housing will need to evolve and consider innovative tech solutions to meet changing needs.

site_title: Mainland Chinese buyers shy away from HK real estate
summary: Mainland Chinese buyers are shying away from Hong Kong real estate due to the coronavirus pandemic's clouded economic outlook. The pandemic has discouraged investors from traveling to Hong Kong, making it difficult for the city's priciest property market to attract its most important source of inbound investment. This shift in buyer behavior may have significant implications for Hong Kong's property market, highlighting the need for the city to adapt to changing market conditions and attract new sources of investment.

site_title: Australia to pour A$300m into hydrogen projects
summary: Australia's government has allocated A$300 million to support hydrogen projects through the Advancing Hydrogen Fund, aiming to build the industry by 2030. The fund, run by the Clean Energy Finance Corporation, will focus on large-scale, cost-effective hydrogen production. The goal is to reduce production costs to A$2-3 per kilogram, making hydrogen competitive with other energy sources. This move aligns with the government's commitment to renewable energy and aims to create jobs and stimulate economic growth.

site_title: Europe must pull together to tackle coronavirus crisis; reforms at risk
summary: The European Union's response to the novel coronavirus crisis has been criticized for being behind the curve, with the single-currency area economy shrinking at the sharpest pace on record. Eurozone finance ministers will meet to discuss reforms, including a potential 500 billion euro stimulus package, but disagreements over funding remain. The EU's recovery plan, which includes a potential big recovery fund, is at risk due to divisions over debt mutualization and the future of the Schengen area. The European Central Bank forecasts a 15% contraction in the second quarter, and policymakers must now "pull together fast" to address the crisis.

site_title: Crippled by virus, Las Vegas casinos clamour to reopen
summary: Las Vegas casinos are struggling to reopen due to the COVID-19 pandemic, with a tug of war between safety concerns and the need to revive the tourism industry. The Culinary Union, representing 60,000 workers, supports Nevada Governor Steve Sisolak's decision to extend the lockdown, citing the high number of union members who have died from the virus. However, some casino owners, like Tim Brooks, are skeptical of plans to implement social distancing measures, fearing they will be too costly and invasive. The future of Las Vegas' gaming industry remains uncertain, with many questioning whether visitors will return.

site_title: April PMI in negative territory across all segments
summary: Singapore's manufacturing sector contracted in April, with the Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) falling to 44.7 points, its lowest since 2008. The contraction was broad-based, affecting inventory, employment, and finished goods. Analysts expect the pain to persist, with the revival of US-China trade tensions adding fuel to the pandemic's fire. Economists warn of risks to the domestic labor market and predict a dim outlook for Singapore's industrial production, potentially contracting in the second and third quarters of the year.

site_title: Rolls-Royce braces for turmoil with 8,000 jobs on the line
summary: Rolls-Royce Holdings plc is considering a 15% workforce cut, potentially affecting 8,000 jobs, due to the ongoing pandemic's impact on the aviation industry. The company's exposure to the crisis, particularly in the widebody engine market, is expected to lead to a prolonged downturn in demand. Analysts forecast a 12% decline in full-year group sales and an 18% drop in civil aerospace revenue. The company has already lost 57% of its market value this year, and aerospace suppliers worldwide are bracing for a protracted slump.

site_title: Money FM podcast: Mukesh Ambani and India's tech billionaires
summary: The article discusses various global news and economic updates. Mukesh Ambani, India's richest person, was featured on a Money FM podcast discussing India's tech billionaires. Meanwhile, Vietnam reacted to the US's surprise tariff announcement on its garment industry, which is expected to impact Asian manufacturers. China's GDP growth is forecasted to slow, putting pressure on policymakers. Citigroup predicted a mid-2026 target of 1,150 for MSCI's global equity index. In other news, a Malaysian agency plans to seize RM3 billion of assets belonging to Daim Zainuddin, and Thailand's Thaksin Shinawatra expressed confidence in his daughter's suspension as PM being cleared in an ethics case.

site_title: Recovery in emerging Asian currencies halted by US tariff risk
summary: A nascent recovery in emerging Asian currencies is at risk due to escalating US-China tensions. US President Donald Trump's threat of tariffs against China led to steep losses in regional currencies. The US-China trade war has delayed a global economic recovery, putting pressure on policymakers. China's GDP growth is expected to slow, further exacerbating the situation. The People's Bank of China (PBOC) is considering a 1.5 trillion yuan stimulus package to counter US tariffs, but the economic outlook remains uncertain.

site_title: Robo-advisers hold steady as Covid-19 presents first big test
summary: Robo-advisers in Singapore have withstood the first major test of the COVID-19 pandemic, with most reporting steady performance and growing investor interest. Despite market volatility, robo-advisers' portfolios have largely outperformed their benchmarks, with some firms achieving annualized returns that beat benchmarks. Net inflows are still growing, and new investors are on board, particularly first-time investors. However, thin profit margins and concerns over long-term sustainability remain, with industry observers warning of potential challenges ahead if the market downturn persists.

site_title: SSB rate at new low; savings, FD, mortgage rates also slide
summary: Singapore Savings Bonds (SSB) rates have dropped to a new low, with the latest issue offering 0.57% for the first year and an average rate of 1.05% per annum for a 10-year holding period. This is lower than rates offered by ICBC Singapore for one-year fixed deposits and other financial institutions. The decline in SSB rates is attributed to a global interest rate environment, with major central banks easing monetary policy to support sluggish economies.

site_title: Singdollar could weaken to 1.425 against greenback
summary: Fitch Solutions has lowered its forecast for the Singapore dollar's 2020 average exchange rate to S$1.425 per US dollar, citing sustained weakness due to the COVID-19 pandemic. The currency has already weakened further since the firm's February update, and Fitch expects the risks posed by the pandemic to persist through most of 2020, potentially keeping the currency on a weakening path.

site_title: Hong Kong economy contracts 8.9% in worst quarter on record
summary: Hong Kong's economy contracted 8.9% in the first quarter, the worst on record, due to the coronavirus outbreak and ongoing political unrest. The decline surpasses previous records and marks the third straight quarterly contraction, the longest since the global financial crisis in 2009. Economists forecast a further drop in output, with Financial Secretary Paul Chan warning of a worst-full-year performance on record. The impact is expected to be severe, with small and medium-sized enterprises bearing the brunt, and unemployment rising.

images.alt_text: Even as Hong Kong is easing some social distancing measures, the hit to global commerce and the threat of renewed anti-government unrest means that activity is likely to remain depressed.

site_title: Opera impresario Peter Jonas, 73, dies
summary: Peter Jonas, a renowned opera impresario, died on April 22 at 73. He led the English National Opera from 1985 to 1993 and the Bavarian State Opera from 1993 to 2006, promoting innovative productions and high musical standards. Jonas encouraged bold interpretive approaches and championed overlooked works, broadening the repertory and presenting premieres. He was known for his risk-taking approach, "treating opera as a living, breathing art form," and his ability to balance artistic and financial goals.

site_title: Covid-19: An independent investigation is good for China
summary: China's handling of the COVID-19 pandemic has sparked debate over accountability, with some countries calling for an independent investigation into the virus's origin. China argues that it bought time for the rest of the world to prepare through its containment methods, but its own investigation has been rejected by the World Health Organization. Multiple theories, including the possibility that the virus was created in a Chinese lab, have emerged, with US President Donald Trump claiming evidence of its origin in a Wuhan lab. China labels such claims "unfounded and fabricated."

site_title: Firms in social entertainment urged to rethink business model
summary: Singapore's Trade and Industry Minister Chan Chun Sing urges companies involved in social entertainment to rethink their business model for longer-term sustainability before the government can reopen those segments of the economy. The government prioritizes sectors that support the country's position as a financial hub and those that enable global supply chains. Companies must prepare for a safe working environment with safe distancing and higher hygiene standards, and technology will play a key role in enabling interaction and contact tracing.

site_title: Your air travel experience will never be the same
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has permanently scarred the air travel experience, with airlines facing significant challenges in maintaining social distancing and hygiene measures. New health protocols, such as face masks, temperature checks, and reduced food and drink options, will make flying less enjoyable and less profitable. Airlines are burning through cash, with some companies' net borrowings exceeding revenues, and demand is expected to take years to recover. Consolidation is likely to occur, with weaker airlines potentially collapsing, and governments may need to rethink airport expansion plans.

site_title: How to avoid a W-shaped recession
summary: A W-shaped recession, characterized by a premature withdrawal of public-health or economic stimulus measures, is a possible outcome of the Covid-19 pandemic. This scenario is echoed in historical events, such as the Spanish flu pandemic and the 1936 US recession, where premature withdrawal of stimulus measures led to relapses and prolonged economic downturns. To avoid this, policymakers should ensure frequent, free testing on a massive scale, maintain social distancing measures, and continue economic stimulus measures until the health crisis is under control.

site_title: Construction workers classification encompasses a wide range of jobs
summary: A Singaporean fibre broadband provider, NETLINK Trust, disclosed that movement controls on construction workers may impact service delivery, despite operating in the telecom sector. Meanwhile, global markets reacted to various news: oil prices rose over 2%, US stocks edged down from records amid tariff threats, and NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was oversubscribed 9.8 times.

site_title: Coal loses backing from another big bank in Australia
summary: Westpac Banking Corp in Australia has announced its intention to exit the thermal coal sector by 2030, leaving Australia and New Zealand Banking Group Ltd (ANZ) as the last of the country's big four banks to commit to dropping coal investments. This move follows similar announcements from Commonwealth Bank of Australia and National Australia Bank Ltd. The exit is part of a growing trend among global banks to bow to pressure from shareholders and climate groups to avoid coal investments, with Japanese banks also starting to pare back their exposure.

site_title: UOL, UIC retail tenants get rent rebate extension till July
summary: UOL Group and its subsidiary United Industrial Corporation have extended rental rebates for retail tenants until July, providing over S$50 million in relief. The relief package includes full rental waivers for tenants that closed during the "circuit breaker" period and 50% rebates for those still operating. The company has also implemented precautionary measures across its properties to combat the COVID-19 pandemic.

site_title: Internal Chinese report says Beijing faces serious global backlash over virus: sources
summary: China faces a rising wave of global hostility over the Covid-19 outbreak, according to an internal report presented to top Beijing leaders. Global anti-China sentiment is at its highest since the 1989 Tiananmen Square crackdown, posing a risk of confrontation with the US. The report warns of a "serious backlash" from the international community, potentially straining relations with the US. The findings come as China's GDP growth is expected to slow, raising pressure on policymakers.

site_title: Bill passed to pave way for Singapore GE during pandemic if Covid-19 persists
summary: Singapore's Parliament has passed a law allowing special, temporary arrangements for the upcoming General Election (GE) to be held amid the COVID-19 pandemic. The bill, which must be passed by April 14 next year, allows electors subject to movement control orders to vote and excuses others from voting. Special polling stations will be set up for those serving stay-home notices, and aspiring candidates can authorise a representative to file nomination papers. The law aims to keep citizens safe while upholding democracy.

site_title: Changing hands
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

Oil prices rose over 2% as investors weighed market outlook, tariffs, and sanctions. Stocks in Europe and the US declined, with bank and healthcare sectors dragging down the market. The US stock market edged down from record highs amid tariff threats. In Singapore, NTT DC Reit's public offer was oversubscribed 9.8 times. Companies like Creative Technology warned of lower-than-expected H2 revenue and operating losses. London's Heathrow considered increasing airport fees for a £10b upgrade. Meanwhile, Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a graft case related to 285 trillion rupiah.

site_title: Nuclear power getting hammered by green power and the pandemic
summary: Nuclear power is struggling to compete with renewable energy sources due to fluctuating prices and reduced demand caused by the pandemic. The industry's reliance on stable, emissions-free power has made it challenging to adapt to the changing energy landscape. Despite record output from wind and solar, nuclear operators are forced to reduce output or shut down plants due to low prices. The global pandemic has accelerated the shift towards renewables, with global power consumption expected to decline by 5% this year, according to the International Energy Agency.

site_title: Ultra-rich families with cash to spare piling into private debt
summary: Ultra-rich families are increasing their investments in private debt, seeking to take advantage of cheaper valuations and avoid market volatility. Despite a surge in yields on junk-rated US bonds, family offices are cautiously optimistic, with many doubling their private debt holdings since 2015. These loans often focus on real estate, providing asset-backed security and consistent cash flow, and can be used to acquire hotels, offices, or other properties. Family offices, with longer investment horizons and fewer constraints, are driving the growth of private debt, with some lending up to £5 million or more.

site_title: India's Reliance to sell US$750m stake in digital unit to Silver Lake
summary: Reliance Industries Ltd will sell a $750 million stake in its digital unit, Jio Platforms, to private equity firm Silver Lake, as part of its efforts to cut $21.4 billion in net debt by year-end. The deal values Jio Platforms at $65 billion, following a $5.7 billion investment from Facebook Inc. The move adds to Reliance's fund-raising activities, including a $7 billion share sale.

site_title: Shareholders should be updated on key milestones in general offer: SGX RegCo
summary: SGX RegCo advises shareholders to be updated on key milestones in general offers, specifically when the 75% acceptance condition is met and when the issuer loses free float. The regulator emphasizes the importance of clear disclosures, including independent acceptances and issuer's free float, to inform shareholders of potential consequences. Market purchases by independent shareholders can be considered when computing the 75% acceptance condition. SGX RegCo expects takeover professionals to advise clients appropriately, prioritizing minority shareholder protection.

site_title: How SMEs can transform and go green for the future
summary: SMEs in Singapore are transforming to go green, with 33% seeking to improve operational efficiency and 29% wanting to gain a competitive edge. Despite misconceptions that sustainability is costly and only for larger companies, research shows that green finance can reduce costs and that SMEs can be just as effective as larger counterparts in adopting sustainable practices. The property and construction sectors are leading the transition, while traditional SMEs are waking up to the business opportunity of going green and the imperative to realign their business models.

site_title: How sustainable is the retail Reit model?
summary: Singapore's retail real estate investment trusts (S-Reits) face sustainability concerns as the COVID-19 pandemic accelerates structural changes in the retail landscape. S-Reits, which have driven rental income and appreciation for mall owners, are under pressure from tenants seeking rent deferrals and reduced payouts. To mitigate the issue, authorities have allowed S-Reits to delay distributing 90% of taxable income, and some landlords are offering rental rebates to tenants. However, the trend of reduced payouts and increased competition from online platforms may signal the end of the S-Reit model's sustainability, with investors urged to reassess their investments.

images.alt_text: When the first Singapore real estate investment trust (S-Reit), CapitaLand Mall Trust (CMT), was floated nearly 18 years ago, it soon became a stock market darling - rewarding unitholders with not only regular distributions from rental income but also attractive appreciation in unit prices.

site_title: M1, Singtel step up to deliver fibre services as NetLink Trust faces foreign worker crunch
summary: M1 and Singtel have partnered with NetLink Trust to deliver fibre services in Singapore amid a foreign worker crunch and coronavirus disruptions. The telcos have trained staff and provided additional manpower to clear NetLink's service backlog, easing service delivery delays for broadband customers. This cooperation is expected to become an industry trend as telecom operators face challenges such as revenue headwinds and 5G investment. The Singapore government has also encouraged pooling of resources across different operators to maintain essential services.

site_title: Japan's Abe extends state of emergency to May 31
summary: Japan's Prime Minister Shinzo Abe extended the nationwide state of emergency to May 31, citing a lack of decline in the new coronavirus infection rate. The move aims to slow the outbreak, with the government spending $1.1 trillion on stimulus measures. Abe promised to ease restrictions in areas with few infections and reopen libraries and museums. Despite a fall in infection rates, experts note that Japan is only testing at half its daily capacity, and social distancing measures remain crucial.

site_title: Mirae Asset scraps US$5.8b deal to buy US hotels from Anbang
summary: South Korea's Mirae Asset Global Investments has terminated a US$5.8 billion deal to buy 15 US hotels from China's Anbang Insurance Group due to Anbang's failure to remedy breaches of certain obligations. Anbang had filed litigation against Mirae Asset, which denied the claims. The deal collapse is the latest merger or acquisition at risk amid the coronavirus pandemic's impact on travel and tourism industries.

site_title: UOB, SPH, Singtel to provide 250 laptops, digital resources to disadvantaged students
summary: UOB, Singapore Press Holdings (SPH), and Singtel are collaborating to provide 250 laptops and digital resources to disadvantaged students in Singapore, supporting remote learning amid the coronavirus outbreak. The initiative, part of UOB's My Digital Space program, aims to bridge the digital gap for children from disadvantaged backgrounds across the region. Each digital learning kit includes a new laptop, Wi-Fi dongle, and online subscription to a chosen newspaper, with technical support available to beneficiaries. The program will be available in six markets across the region for the first year.

site_title: Dollar surges on worries that US-China trade war will resume
summary: The US dollar surged against major currencies on May 4, 2020, amid fears of a renewed US-China trade war over the novel coronavirus. US President Donald Trump and Secretary of State Mike Pompeo blamed China for the pandemic's origin. This move increased tensions, causing a surge in the dollar's value. The concerns stem from the US-China dispute last year, which was temporarily resolved with a phase one trade deal.

site_title: Japan extends virus state of emergency until May 31
summary: Japan's Prime Minister Shinzo Abe extended the country's state of emergency over the coronavirus until May 31, citing concerns it was too soon to relax restrictions. Abe warned that the measures could be lifted before the end of the month if new infections slow sufficiently. A review of the situation will be conducted in about two weeks.

site_title: Hong Kong economy shrinks record 8.9% in Q1
summary: Hong Kong's economy contracted a record 8.9% in Q1, its worst quarterly decline since 1974, due to the coronavirus outbreak and ongoing recession from political unrest and trade war woes. The financial hub has experienced its third-straight quarter of negative growth, with confirmed infections kept to around 1,000 and six deaths. Officials are easing social distancing measures, but the economy is expected to contract between 4-7% this year. Political tensions remain high, with little sign of reconciliation or compromise between protesters and the government.

site_title: Stocks buckle on first trading day of May, with STI falling 2.3% to 2,563.69
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) in Singapore fell 2.3% to 2,563.69 on its first trading day of May, mirroring a dismal trend in most Asian markets. The decline was attributed to record-low factory output in April, with countries such as India, Taiwan, Japan, and South Korea experiencing their weakest PMI readings since 2009. The Australian market was a rare bright spot, rising 1.41% to 5,319.8.

site_title: Oil-hungry Asian nations pounce on low prices to build stockpiles
summary: Asian nations, including China, Japan, and South Korea, are stockpiling oil in response to low prices caused by the pandemic. China's reserves are estimated to be around 550 million barrels, while Japan's and South Korea's reserves are sufficient for several months. India, however, has limited reserves, equivalent to just 10 days of national consumption. Building strategic reserves is challenging due to high costs, but countries like Australia and China are taking advantage of low prices to develop or expand their reserves. The impact of low prices on regional economies is uncertain, with some economists predicting a positive effect on recovery.

site_title: With global growth absent, signs of life flicker in Asia
summary: Major Asian economies, including China, South Korea, Taiwan, and Hong Kong, are slowly recovering from the Covid-19 pandemic by incrementally unwinding lockdown restrictions. These countries, which experienced initial outbreaks in January, are now showing signs of growth, offering a glimpse into the path towards recovery. The recovery trend is a positive development amidst the global economic and public health challenges posed by the pandemic.

site_title: Post-pandemic offices seek open flow of ideas, not of the virus
summary: Post-pandemic offices are reconfiguring to prioritize worker safety, incorporating features such as hand sanitizers, air filters, and sneeze guards. Designers aim to reduce transmission risk, but experts say a virus-free office environment is impractical. Studies show that slowing transmission comes from letting sick workers stay home and reducing in-person interactions. Companies are exploring alternatives to open floor plans, such as private workstations and outdoor spaces, to promote social distancing. Some are also reconsidering traditional office designs, like cubicles, in favor of safety and cost-effectiveness.

site_title: One of Amazon's most powerful critics lives in its backyard
summary: US Representative Pramila Jayapal, a liberal Democrat, has publicly criticized Amazon for its treatment of workers, citing a lack of transparency and inconsistencies in its policies. Jayapal met with Amazon executives last year but felt her concerns were dismissed, leading her to take a more public stance. Her criticism comes amid growing concerns about Amazon's dominance and treatment of workers, including a report from an undercover journalist about employees urinating in water bottles due to limited bathrooms. Jayapal's district includes many white-collar Amazon employees, making her approach potentially challenging.

site_title: Three factors to consider before Singapore starts reopening economy
summary: Singapore's economy is set to reopen, but a multi-faceted approach will be taken into account, including low community cases, the global pandemic situation, and a system for safe reopening. The government will also require firms to change work practices. Health Minister Gan Kim Yong and National Development Minister Lawrence Wong co-chair the taskforce, aiming to balance economic and health concerns.

site_title: Credibility bookcase is the quarantine's hottest accessory
summary: A bookcase has become a popular prop during the COVID-19 quarantine, serving as a makeshift background for amateurish video feeds to appear more authoritative. This trend is seen as a humorous take on the usual signals of expertise, such as gaudy photographs of skyscrapers. The use of a bookcase as a prop is likely a creative way for individuals to add a touch of professionalism to their videos without the need for expensive or elaborate backdrops.

site_title: Apple falls after skipping forecast for first time in years
summary: Apple reported its first forecast miss in over a decade, with quarterly revenue growing 1% despite a "very depressed" period in late March and early April during the Covid-19 pandemic. CEO Tim Cook attributed the pickup in the second half of the month to a strong recovery. The company raised its dividend and expanded its share buyback plan by $50 billion. This move sparked concern about potential future performance.

site_title: Big Tech's earnings triumph masks the economic pain ahead
summary: Big Tech companies, including Amazon, Facebook, and Google, reported strong earnings in Q1 despite the global economic downturn. Traffic surged on their sites, but advertising declined. Apple's earnings were $11 billion, its highest in over a decade, but it didn't provide a forecast for the first time in over a decade. The strong results suggest these companies remain essential services and have a solid financial foundation to weather the pandemic's impact.

site_title: Biden personnel records can't be released, Senate Secretary says
summary: Senate Secretary Julie Adams stated that personnel records of Joe Biden, including a complaint related to Tara Reade's allegation of sexual assault, cannot be released due to privacy laws. Biden had requested the release of such documents, but Adams' office advised that she has no discretion to disclose the information. This decision has been made despite Biden's denial of the allegations and his request for the results of the search to be made public.

site_title: Intel buys Moovit transit app for US$900m to help develop robotaxis
summary: Intel buys Moovit transit app for US$900m to develop robotaxis, with the goal of launching a small fleet of driverless taxis in countries like Israel, France, and South Korea by 2022. Moovit's technology and data from over 800 million users will be integrated into Intel's Mobileye unit. The acquisition aims to fill gaps in autonomous car development and capitalize on the predicted US$160 billion robotaxis market by 2030. Intel CEO Amnon Shashua believes the COVID-19 crisis presents opportunities, rather than setbacks, for the company's plans.

site_title: Apple launches new MacBook Pro
summary: Apple has launched an updated version of its MacBook Pro, featuring modified keyboards with the "scissor" mechanism to address previous typing-related issues. The new lineup is priced at $1,299 and $1,199 for education-focused models, boosting performance and adding storage. The move comes after Apple discarded the "butterfly" keyboards, which were criticized for sticky and unresponsive keys. The new keyboards are designed to improve typing accuracy and responsiveness.

site_title: Bill passed to pave way for Singapore GE during pandemic if Covid-19 persists
summary: Singapore's Parliament passed a law allowing temporary arrangements for the upcoming General Election to be held during the coronavirus pandemic, with the election set to take place by April 14 next year. The Bill allows some voters to cast their ballots from designated facilities, and aspiring candidates can authorise representatives to file nomination papers. The provisions are deemed temporary and apply only to the parliamentary election, not future elections. The move aims to ensure public safety while upholding democracy.

site_title: US factory orders drop more than expected in March
summary: US factory orders dropped 10.3% in March, exceeding expectations, due to disruptions from the novel coronavirus. This decline could worsen as supply chain fractures and export decreases continue. The revised February data showed a 0.1% decline instead of no change. Economists had forecast a 9.7% decline.

images.alt_text: New orders for US-made goods fell more than expected in March and could sink further as disruptions from the novel coronavirus fracture supply chains and depress exports.

site_title: Gilead Covid-19 drug may exceed US$2b in sales, Piper says
summary: Gilead's COVID-19 treatment, remdesivir, may generate over $2 billion in sales by the end of the year at a price of $4,500 per 10-day treatment, according to analysts at Piper Sandler. The drug's emergency approval and potential mortality benefit justify the price, which is considered reasonable. While some analysts have downgraded Gilead's profit expectations, others see significant sales potential, with some predicting "several billion in sales" due to the ongoing pandemic.

site_title: Singapore Savings Bonds' latest issue offers record low interest rates
summary: Singapore's latest issue of Savings Bonds (SSB) offers record-low interest rates, with a 0.57% rate for the first year and an average rate of 1.05% over a 10-year holding period. The low rates are attributed to a declining interest-rate environment, with Singapore government bond yields falling to 0.89% as of April. Analysts attribute this to global central banks easing monetary policy, making the SSB rates a natural consequence. The SSB issue closes on May 26.

site_title: SMEs apply for S$1.9b of loans in March and April, with high approval rates
summary: Singaporean small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) have applied for around 2,500 loans totaling S$1.9 billion since March, with a high approval rate of 90-95%. The loans, under Enterprise Singapore's financing schemes, aim to help firms with credit and cash flow amid the Covid-19 pandemic. The government takes a 90% risk share on these loans, with banks assuming the remaining 10%. Over 2,500 principal payment deferrals have been processed, benefiting about S$4.5 billion of secured loan facilities.

site_title: CapitaLand sees signs of recovery as China reopens, but pace remains uncertain
summary: CapitaLand, a Singapore-based property group, reports encouraging signs of recovery in its China business as businesses reopen. Residential sales and shopper traffic have improved, with sales of close to 900 million yuan (S$180 million) in March. However, the pace of recovery remains uncertain, with shopper traffic down 52% from a year earlier. CapitaLand expects its near-term operating and financial performance for the China market to lag prior years. The company remains cautiously optimistic about scheduled completions and handovers for fiscal year ending December 2020.

site_title: US: Stocks open lower as airline shares tumble
summary: US stocks opened lower on Monday, with airline shares taking a hit after Warren Buffett's announcement to liquidate his holdings in major US carriers. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 1.1% to 23,452.27, while the S&P 500 dropped 0.9% to 2,804.25, and the Nasdaq Composite Index shed 0.7% to 8,547.67. The decline followed Buffett's move, which led to a sharp decline in airline shares.

site_title: Keppel Corp appoints Evercore Asia as IFA
summary: Keppel Corp has appointed Evercore Asia as its independent financial adviser (IFA) for Temasek Holdings' partial offer to acquire an additional 30.55% stake in the company, valued at S$7.35 per share. The offer price represents a premium of 26% over the last traded price. The IFA review will be conducted within 14 days of the formal offer document's despatch. The pre-conditions for the offer must be satisfied or waived by October 21, 2020, for the formal offer to proceed.

site_title: Norway pledges US$1b for vaccines against Covid-19, other diseases
summary: Norway pledges $1 billion to support the global distribution of Covid-19 vaccines and vaccines against other diseases, as part of a $8.23 billion EU donor conference. The pledge, made by Prime Minister Erna Solberg, will go to GAVI, a global partnership focusing on immunization worldwide, and is part of Norway's long-standing commitment to global health initiatives. The move comes as the US has stopped funding the World Health Organisation, which Norway regrets, but says is necessary for joint crisis management.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Monday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed lower on Monday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 31.19 points to 1,376.59. The decline was attributed to a higher number of losers (599) compared to gainers (284). Total volume was 5.455 billion lots worth RM2.468 billion.

site_title: Jumbo Group issues profit warning
summary: Jumbo Group issued a profit warning due to the impact of Covid-19 on its markets, particularly in China and Singapore. The company reported a significantly lower profit after tax for H1 FY2020, citing reduced footfall in malls and dine-in customers. Despite a healthy working capital position, Jumbo's key priority is to preserve cash until the Covid-19 situation improves. The company will release its unaudited financial results on or before May 15.

site_title: Govt to look into raising housing standards for migrant workers: Josephine Teo
summary: Singapore's Minister for Manpower Josephine Teo announced that the government will look into raising housing standards for migrant workers after the COVID-19 outbreak is brought under control. The government had taken measures to address the spread of the virus among migrant workers, including introducing safe-distancing measures and gazetting certain dormitories as isolation areas. However, the outbreak showed multiple channels of transmission, requiring a multi-faceted approach to deal with. The government will review and improve housing standards for migrant workers, particularly in older dormitories, after the crisis subsides.

site_title: From lockdown to lock-in
summary: Countries are diverging in Covid-19 strategies, with some prioritizing eradication, others aiming for herd immunity, and others focusing on suppression until a vaccine is found. As lockdowns lift, a "lock-in" phase is expected, severely limiting international travel, tourism, and trade, potentially slowing global economic recovery and creating another crisis in small island economies. This divergence in strategies will likely have long-term effects on global economies and travel industries.

site_title: Firms in social entertainment need to rethink business model: Chan Chun Sing
summary: Trade and Industry Minister Chan Chun Sing advises companies involved in social entertainment to rethink their business model for longer-term sustainability before the government reopens those segments of the economy. As Singapore reopens its economy, priority will be given to sectors like pharmaceuticals, biomedical, and electronics that support global supply chains and reinforce Singapore's position as a financial hub. Companies will need to implement contingency arrangements for safe working environments, technology will play a key role in enabling interaction and contact tracing, and workers will continue working from home in the short to medium term.

site_title: UK refuses to comment on intelligence dossier on China's coronavirus response
summary: Britain's Defence Secretary Ben Wallace declined to comment on a US-led Five Eyes intelligence report that claimed China deliberately suppressed or destroyed evidence of the coronavirus outbreak, citing the need to protect individual intelligence bulletins. The 15-page report, published in the Australian Saturday Telegraph, alleged this action "cost tens of thousands of lives." Wallace stated he wouldn't comment on individual intelligence reports, saying it would be "wrong."

site_title: Coal loses backing from another big bank
summary: Westpac Banking Corp has announced it will exit thermal coal financing by 2030, leaving Australia and New Zealand Banking Group as the last of the country's big four banks to commit to dropping the fuel. This move follows similar commitments from Commonwealth Bank of Australia and National Australia Bank, with Japanese banks also starting to pare back their exposure. The decision is part of a growing trend for financial institutions to avoid coal investments due to pressure from shareholders and climate groups.

site_title: Singapore factory sentiment falls for straight third month to end-2008 levels
summary: Singapore's manufacturing sentiment fell to its lowest level since November 2008 in April, with the Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) reading 44.7 points, down 0.7 points from the previous month. The electronics industry was particularly affected, with a sub-index of 42.8 points, its lowest on record. The decline is attributed to the Covid-19 pandemic, order cancellations, and supply chain disruptions. Economists predict a record contraction in GDP and softness in the domestic labor market, with some warning of impending trade tensions between the US and China.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks finish 4.18% lower
summary: Hong Kong shares plummeted 4.18% on Monday due to fears of a renewed China-US trade war. The Hang Seng Index closed at 23,613.80, following Donald Trump's criticism of Beijing's handling of the coronavirus crisis. Mainland Chinese markets were closed for a public holiday, contributing to the losses. The decline follows a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks and comes as US-EU trade talks are in focus, with Trump's threats to extend tariffs adding to market uncertainty.

site_title: Sasseur Reit chalks up 47.2m yuan on Day 1 of annual Spring Sales
summary: Sasseur Reit's four outlet malls in China registered 47.2 million yuan (S$9.62 million) in sales on the first day of its annual Spring Sales, a 411% increase from last year's reopening sales. The sales event, which started in early April, was preceded by online sales and promotional activities. The malls have implemented health and safety precautions, including face mask mandates and temperature screenings, with no reported cases of Covid-19. This success is attributed to strong domestic demand driven by China's large population base.

site_title: Commercial unit at Upper Thomson up for sale with S$19.5m guide price
summary: A freehold commercial unit at Thomson Imperial Court in Singapore is up for sale with a guide price of S$19.5 million, or S$1,771 per square foot. The 11,011 square foot unit represents about 23% of the strata area and is being marketed via an expression of interest (EOI) exercise by sole marketing agent SRI.

site_title: Rich nations must make pandemic recovery plans green: global investors
summary: Leading global investor groups have urged the world's richest nations to ensure their Covid-19 recovery plans are sustainable and align with the Paris climate accord goals. The groups, which manage trillions of dollars in assets, warned that prioritizing short-term emissions-intensive projects could expose investors and national economies to financial, health, and social risks. They recommend focusing on creating jobs and sustainable infrastructure to meet the goal of net zero carbon emissions across sectors, including energy and transport.

site_title: Shareholders should be updated on key milestones in a general offer: SGX RegCo
summary: Singapore Exchange Regulation (SGX RegCo) CEO Tan Boon Gin advises shareholders to be updated on key milestones in a general offer, including when the 75% acceptance condition is met and when the issuer loses free float. Shareholders should receive clear disclosures on independent acceptances and free float implications, including potential consequences. Market purchases from independent shareholders can be considered when computing the 75% acceptance condition. SGX RegCo aims to ensure shareholders have all necessary facts to make an informed decision on a general offer.

site_title: All sectors will have to change work practices to allow reopening: Lawrence Wong
summary: Minister for National Development Lawrence Wong stated that all sectors will need to change work practices after the lifting of "circuit-breaker" measures to prevent the spread of Covid-19.
