However, not all funds performed well, with some, like David Einhorn's Greenlight Capital, extending losses, and investors expressing concerns about the industry's outlook.

site_title: US Soccer scores victory in equal pay suit with women's team players
summary: A US District Court judge dismissed the US women's soccer team's claims for equal pay, but allowed complaints of unfair medical, travel, and training treatment to proceed to trial. The team had sought $66 million in damages under the Equal Pay Act. The judge found that the women's team had been paid more on a cumulative and average per-game basis than the men's team. The trial date is set for June 16, and the players plan to appeal the decision, stating they will not give up their fight for equal pay.

site_title: NASA, SpaceX target historic spaceflight despite pandemic
summary: NASA and SpaceX are set to launch astronauts to space from US soil for the first time in nearly a decade on May 27, despite the coronavirus pandemic. The "Demo-2" mission, crewed by Robert Behnken and Douglas Hurley, will see the SpaceX Crew Dragon capsule become the fifth US spacecraft to take humans into orbit. The mission marks a significant milestone for SpaceX and NASA, aiming to reduce reliance on Russian Soyuz rockets and establish a new economic model for space travel.

site_title: Pandemic-era celebrities struggle to strike appropriate tone
summary: Celebrities, including Oprah, Julia Roberts, and George W Bush, are participating in a 24-hour livestream event called "Call to Unite" to encourage donations to Covid-19 relief efforts. However, their efforts have been met with criticism from social media users who find their online content, such as relaxing at home, to be tone-deaf and out of touch with the struggles of those affected by the pandemic. The event aims to raise spirits and funds, but its effectiveness remains to be seen.

site_title: Google travel data show lockdown fatigue in US; other countries, including Singapore, stay home
summary: Google travel data shows increased disobedience with lockdown orders in the US, as people returned to parks and jobs in April. However, in countries like Brazil, Japan, and Singapore, lockdown fatigue led to more people staying home as novel coronavirus cases surged. Data from January to February also showed rising compliance with lockdown orders. The findings suggest varying responses to lockdowns globally.

site_title: Gold set for weekly fall as Europe readies to ease lockdowns
summary: Gold is set for its largest weekly decline in seven weeks as European nations ease lockdowns, including the UK, which pledged to lift restrictions. The European Central Bank cut funding costs for banks but refrained from boosting its bond-buying program. US job losses deepened, with initial claims totaling 3.84 million, and personal spending data plunged. Despite the gloomy economic data, gold has risen this month as stimulus boosts its allure as a store of value.

site_title: Tokyo Olympics unlikely to happen in 2021, virus experts say
summary: Tokyo Olympics organizers are unlikely to hold the 2021 games due to the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic, with infectious disease experts warning that the virus may not be fully contained globally by then. The highly contagious virus will be spreading in different countries by next summer, making extensive testing and quarantines for guests and athletes impractical. Experts warn that the games would need to be significantly modified or potentially cancelled to ensure fairness for athletes and prevent a devastating playing field.

site_title: White House blocks Fauci from testifying to Congress on coronavirus response
summary: The White House has blocked Dr. Anthony Fauci, the US top health official, from testifying to Congress on the coronavirus response, calling it "counterproductive". Fauci was scheduled to testify at a House Appropriations subcommittee hearing on May 6. The White House claims it is unnecessary to have individuals involved in the response testify, while the House Speaker and Senate Democratic leader have urged investigations into the Trump administration's handling of the outbreak.

site_title: Oil firms, ends with weekly gain, as OPEC+ begins record cuts
summary: US oil prices rose 5% on Friday, with Brent crude reaching $26.44 per barrel, its first weekly gain in four weeks, as OPEC+ began record output cuts to tackle a supply glut. The deal, which includes 9.7 million barrels per day in cuts, aims to address the coronavirus crisis. Despite the cuts, analysts doubt the production reduction will be enough to boost demand, which is expected to recover slowly. Oil prices are expected to remain volatile, with US energy firms cutting oil rigs for a seventh week in a row.

site_title: US: Wall Street tumbles as renewed tariff threat adds to uncertainties
summary: US stocks plummeted on Friday, closing down over 2% as President Trump revived a threat of new tariffs against China, exacerbating economic uncertainty. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 622.03 points, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite lost 2.8% and 3.2%, respectively. Mixed earnings reports, including a disappointing Amazon.com report, and dismal economic data also contributed to the sell-off. The corporate reporting season has crossed the midpoint, with earnings seen having fallen 12.7% from a year ago.

site_title: Stampede to buy euros at end-of-month fix rattles FX trading
summary: Traders rushed to buy euros on the last day of the month, driving up the currency to a two-week high of $1.0972 versus the dollar. Nearly $3.7 billion worth of euro futures contracts traded in the 30 minutes before the London fix, the highest since March 6. This surge in volume followed the expiry of nearly 2.1 billion euros of options and the drop in volatility in the euro from a month earlier, which prompted investors to rebalance their portfolios.

site_title: Virus may be a welcome reality check for Dubai's property glut
summary: Dubai's property market may receive a temporary reprieve due to the COVID-19 pandemic, as developers halt new projects and buyers have less cash to pay for new homes. Chairman of Damac Properties, Hussain Sajwani, expects no new launches in 2020 or most of 2021, but predicts the market may start to recover by October 2021, coinciding with the opening of the World Expo. Developers are focusing on selling existing inventories and offering discounts to attract buyers.

site_title: Australia's home price surge ebbs as sales hit a sinkhole
summary: Australia's home prices rose 0.3% in April, the slowest pace since last June, due to a coronavirus lockdown's impact on buyers and sellers. This marks a significant decline from March's 0.7% growth. The slowdown is attributed to a spike in unemployment, which is eating into incomes. The data from CoreLogic suggests that the home price growth is expected to worsen, indicating a challenging market for the Australian real estate sector.

site_title: As we keep our distance, smart tech brings healthcare closer
summary: Telemedicine is playing a crucial role in delivering healthcare during the COVID-19 pandemic, enabling specialists to connect with patients remotely. With renewed interest in the practice, countries like the US and India are seeing a surge in the adoption of telemedicine. Technology is also helping in diabetes management, with cloud-managed systems and mobile apps allowing patients to monitor their glucose levels and receive remote consultations. As the world navigates the "different normal" of physical distancing, health tech is becoming increasingly important in delivering crucial care to those who need it.

site_title: Trump now says he hopes US coronavirus deaths less than 100,000
summary: US President Donald Trump has revised his estimate of coronavirus deaths, stating he hopes for less than 100,000 fatalities, a higher upper limit than previously discussed. This comes after the number of deaths passed 60,000, eclipsing the number of Americans killed in the Vietnam War. Trump initially mentioned 60,000-70,000 deaths, but now seems to be adjusting his estimate. The actual number of deaths has surpassed 63,260, according to a Reuters tally.

images.alt_text: President Donald Trump on Friday seemingly increased his estimate of possible deaths in the United States from the coronavirus, telling a White House event he hopes for less than 100,000 fatalities, a higher upper limit than the 60,000 to 70,000 deaths he discussed on Monday.

site_title: Reits (May 2-3, 2020)
summary: US mortgage rates have risen for the first time in five weeks, after a recent decline. This marks a reversal in the trend and may impact the housing market. Meanwhile, the UK saw a rebound in homebuyer demand to a six-month high. In Singapore, a Q3 wave of condo launches will test demand for projects above S$3,000 psf. Manhattan rents have hit another record, with more increases expected. WeWork has secured new tenants and filled more space at its office in Singapore after its bankruptcy. Goldman Sachs acquired hotel and retail assets in Seoul.

site_title: US issues emergency approval for remdesivir for Covid-19 patients
summary: US regulators have granted emergency approval for remdesivir, an experimental antiviral drug, to treat Covid-19 patients. The approval comes after a clinical trial showed the drug shortened the time to recovery in some patients, with hospitalised Covid-19 patients experiencing a 31% faster recovery time. The Food and Drug Administration has authorised the drug for use in both adults and children hospitalised with severe Covid-19, and Gilead Sciences has pledged to donate 1.5 million doses for free.

images.alt_text: The experimental drug remdesivir has been authorised by US regulators for emergency use against Covid-19, President Donald Trump announced Friday.

site_title: China to launch property investment trusts to spur infrastructure development
summary: China plans to launch a public market for real estate investment trusts (Reits) to spur infrastructure development and revive its economy, which has been impacted by the pandemic. The new Reits market will allow personal savings and private capital to be channeled into infrastructure projects, reducing debt risks and converting savings into investment capital. The pilot scheme will focus on infrastructure projects, such as warehouses and toll ways, and could expand to other areas in the future.

site_title: Cooler than ICE
summary: BMW has released a plug-in version of its X3 model, combining traditional combustion power with clean electricity. The move comes as Singapore is considered a suitable location for Electric Vehicles due to its urban driving conditions, but the country's high car prices may deter potential buyers. The X3 plug-in aims to cater to consumers who want a vehicle that can handle long trips, such as traveling to Penang, despite the high upfront cost.

site_title: Singapore, Japan agree to deepen bilateral cooperation to fight Covid-19 pandemic
summary: Singapore and Japan agree to deepen bilateral economic cooperation to combat the Covid-19 pandemic. Both countries will refrain from imposing export restrictions on essential supplies, including agricultural food products and medical supplies. They will work together to secure supply chains, facilitate the essential movement of people, and boost business confidence through joint efforts in the digital economy and the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP).

site_title: Market value of Singapore stocks swells in April as funds redeploy cash into blue chips
summary: Singapore's combined stock market value rose 5.1% in April as funds redeployed cash into blue-chip stocks, driven by signs of recovery. Top performers included Singtel, DBS Group, Wilmar, and Thai Beverage, which rebounded from 52-week lows in March. Analysts attribute the surge to dividend payouts and ample liquidity, with blue-chips expected to lead the market in a recovery.

site_title: What is sport without the spectators?
summary: The article discusses the importance of spectators in sports, highlighting a memorable moment from the 1984 Olympic Games where a dehydrated Swiss marathoner, Gabriela Andersen-Schiess, was cheered on by a packed stadium despite struggling with heat exhaustion. The author argues that restarting live games behind closed doors is not the right move, as spectators play a crucial role in the sport's atmosphere and emotional impact. This perspective emphasizes the value of live events and the human connection that spectators bring to the game.

site_title: Rebuilding trust in financial services industry
summary: Financial industry trust remains low over a decade after the global financial crisis, with global regulators imposing over $320 billion in penalties on banks. Conduct risk, linked to organizational culture, is difficult to eliminate due to unpredictable human behavior. High-profile scandals, such as the Lehman Brothers minibond crisis and Libor manipulation, have eroded consumer trust. To rebuild trust, firms must develop more effective ways to manage conduct risk and promote a good corporate culture, where employees are incentivized to act responsibly.

site_title: In praise of pessimism
summary: Defensive pessimism, a mindset characterized by leaning into anxiety and planning for worst-case scenarios, may be a constructive adaptation in times of uncertainty, such as the COVID-19 pandemic. This approach can help individuals prepare for different contingencies and avoid being caught off guard by unforeseen events. Research suggests that defensive pessimists are more likely to take precautions and plan ahead, making them more resilient to the challenges of the "new normal." While this approach may not eliminate anxiety, it can provide a sense of control and focus on controllable aspects of life.

site_title: More recovery facilities to be set up for migrant workers
summary: The Singapore government plans to set up new facilities in migrant worker dormitories for workers who have recovered from COVID-19 or display mild symptoms. New strategies to monitor their health and working arrangements will be developed, including the use of pulse oximeters and telemedicine. The recovery phase will be challenging, requiring re-housing and adjustments to new situations, and employers will need to make new arrangements. The government will also maintain safe distancing guidelines and enforce them at all workplaces.

site_title: Life of I, with a puma
summary: During the COVID-19 pandemic, people are rediscovering the value of human connection and escaping into virtual worlds like Second Life, where they can interact with others, engage in activities, and explore new environments. As social interaction dwindles, virtual contact is on the rise, with people using apps like WeChat, WhatsApp, and Zoom for communication. Meanwhile, wild animals are venturing into cities, taking advantage of the lack of human interaction, and people are embracing the opportunity to reconnect with the "Real World" and reevaluate their priorities.

site_title: How to stock your home bar
summary: To create a home bar, start with basic supplies like whiskey, vodka, gin, rum, and tequila, as well as mixers like tonics, soda water, and cola. Invest in a few essential tools like a jigger, mixing glass, bar spoon, and shaker. Bolster your bar with bitters, vermouth, and citrus. Consider adding specialty bottles for unique cocktails. Online recipes and classic cocktail books can provide inspiration, and don't be afraid to experiment and adjust recipes to suit your tastes.

site_title: URA seeks marketing consultancy for strategic review of Jurong Lake District to draw businesses
summary: The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) is seeking a marketing consultancy to review and rebrand Jurong Lake District, aiming to change perceptions of the area as a mainly industrial town. The review will focus on presenting an exciting vision and narrative to position the district as a compelling business location. The URA plans to scale up marketing and promotion from the third quarter, with existing tourism development plans to boost the area's appeal.

site_title: Stair climbs, masks and closed bars: Welcome to the post-lockdown hotel
summary: Hotels are expected to reopen with new safety protocols after the lockdown, including walk-up stairwells, face masks, and closed bars. Guests will check-in online and be directed to their rooms, where breakfast will be delivered and guests will dispose of the remnants hygienically. Elevators may be closed, and no meeting rooms or event space will be available. The price of a hotel room will play a crucial role in luring people back, and hotels must strike a balance between safety and welcome.

site_title: Malaysia eases some virus curbs, most businesses to reopen from May 4
summary: Malaysia will allow most businesses to reopen from May 4, partially easing COVID-19 restrictions, Prime Minister Muhyiddin Yassin announced. Businesses that involve close contacts, such as cinemas and nightclubs, will remain closed, along with schools and universities. The government will enforce strict health standard operating procedures, including mask-wearing and social distancing. Inter-state travel and borders remain closed, and restaurants will reopen with strict social distancing measures. The move aims to cushion the economic blow from the pandemic, with a stimulus package worth RM250 billion announced.

site_title: Covid-19 crisis makes 'going concern' calls more challenging
summary: Auditors are facing significant challenges in assessing a company's ability to continue trading as a going concern due to the ongoing Covid-19 pandemic. Uncertainties and restrictions are making it difficult to make judgments about inherently uncertain future outcomes. Auditors must develop alternative procedures to obtain sufficient evidence, and companies must make significant judgments and estimates to evaluate their ability to operate as a going concern. The pandemic's impact on markets, economies, and businesses is unprecedented, making it hard for auditors to provide assurance under relevant auditing standards and certainty amid uncertainties.

site_title: Financial planning via MoneyOwl: a compass for your retirement
summary: MoneyOwl, a joint venture between NTUC Enterprise and financial planning firm Providend, offers comprehensive financial planning services to individuals aged 18-54. The service starts with an online fact-find and generates a report, followed by a two-hour consultation. MoneyOwl's approach focuses on "lifestyle" financial planning, balancing current assets with future goals. The firm integrates CPF assets into the planning process and recommends a 4% withdrawal rule for portfolio investments. For a limited time, the one-time charge for a plan is waived, making the service accessible to those who want a personalized financial plan.

site_title: SGX RegCo queries HCSS on controls to safeguard the interests of company
summary: The Singapore Exchange Regulation (SGX RegCo) has queried HC Surgical Specialists (HCSS) on the adequacy and effectiveness of controls to safeguard the interests of the company and its shareholders. This comes after a complaint was lodged against HCSS's 70% owner, Dr. Julian Ong, in 2018, alleging collusion with another specialist in having sex with "vulnerable" female patients. HCSS was asked to clarify the terms of a put option that requires Dr. Ong to repurchase shares if his employment is terminated and to confirm that the board has put in place adequate controls to safeguard the company's interests.

site_title: More facilities to be set up for healthy, recovering migrant workers
summary: The Singapore government is setting up new facilities in affected migrant worker dormitories to house recovered Covid-19 patients and increase housing capacity for healthy workers. The third phase of the strategy focuses on the recovery of workers, with on-site facilities providing medical care and telemedicine services. The government is also introducing pulse oximeters to monitor workers' health and will deliver medicine to dormitories as needed. Minister for Manpower Josephine Teo warned that the recovery phase will be challenging, requiring new strategies to keep workers safe and adjust to new situations.

site_title: Millions had risen out of poverty. Coronavirus is pulling them back
summary: Global poverty rates are expected to increase for the first time since 1998, with at least half a billion people potentially slipping into destitution by the end of the year. The COVID-19 pandemic has led to widespread unemployment, particularly in the informal sector, and the World Bank estimates that sub-Saharan Africa will experience its first recession in 25 years. The gains made in fighting poverty, largely due to women entering the workforce, are now at risk of being reversed, and funding for anti-poverty programs may be cut.

site_title: Stay-home notice for construction sector extended till May 18
summary: The stay-home notice (SHN) period for construction sector workers in Singapore has been extended to May 18, from May 4, due to a rise in infected cases living outside purpose-built dormitories. The Ministry of Manpower, Ministry of Health, and Building and Construction Authority issued the joint statement, citing higher transmission rates among workers.

site_title: Oxley gives updates on local, overseas projects amid pandemic
summary: Oxley Holdings reported S$2.2 billion in revenue from its Singapore and overseas projects as construction progresses, despite the COVID-19 pandemic. The company has sold 73% of its residential units in Singapore and 95% of its London apartments, with projects in Ireland and Phnom Penh also on track. Oxley expects to redeem its S$150 million bonds and is striving to complete its KLCC project on schedule. Shares closed at 23 Singapore cents, up half a cent.

site_title: Covid-19 Act staving off restructurings, specialists say
summary: Restructuring companies and law firms in Singapore are receiving more inquiries about financing options due to the COVID-19 pandemic. However, experts say it may take a few months for companies to schedule restructuring appointments. The government's recent measures have reduced the urgency of restructuring, with companies focusing on shoring up cash positions and raising funds instead. As a result, companies are now less likely to pursue restructuring, which could help stave off potential restructurings.

site_title: Latest Earnings
summary: Oil prices rose over 2% as investors weighed market outlook, tariffs, and sanctions. US stocks edged down from records amid tariff threats, while Europe's stocks declined due to bank and healthcare sector drag. NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer received 9.8 times oversubscription. Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall in H2 and operating loss similar to H1. London's Heathrow considered increasing fees for a £10 billion upgrade. Meanwhile, Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a 285 trillion rupiah graft case.

site_title: Ezra's application for judicial management to be heard on June 22
summary: Ezra Holdings has rescheduled its judicial management application from May 18 to June 22, according to a filing with the Singapore Exchange. The application, filed on February 4, aims to place the offshore and marine group under judicial management, resulting in a moratorium until it is granted or dismissed.

site_title: Temporary job redeployment may not avert layoffs later
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has caused a significant shock to Singapore's economy, with industries such as aviation severely impacted. To mitigate job losses, the government has introduced measures like the SGUnited Jobs Initiative, which aims to create 10,000 positions, including temporary roles. However, labor market watchers warn that these efforts may not be enough to avert a looming layoff tsunami, as job opportunities are expected to decline. Redeployment may not be cost-saving and can entail logistical challenges, and policymakers are still grappling with issues such as overtime pay and entitlements.

site_title: Saudi central bank net foreign assets drop by about US$20b in April
summary: Saudi Arabia's central bank reported a net foreign asset drop of about $20 billion in April, reaching $443.75 billion. This represents a $25 billion monthly decline and the largest drop in at least 20 years. The decline is attributed to $40 billion transferred to fund investments by the sovereign wealth fund PIF in March and April. Saudi Arabia is facing economic challenges due to historic oil price lows and the impact of the new coronavirus.

site_title: SGX RegCo queries HC Surgical Specialists
summary: The Singapore Exchange Regulation (SGX RegCo) has queried HC Surgical Specialists (HCSS) about its handling of allegations against Dr. Julian Ong, who owns 70% of the company's endoscopy clinic. The allegations include claims of Dr. Ong colluding with another specialist to have sex with vulnerable female patients. SGX RegCo is seeking information on the company's controls, processes, and procedures to safeguard its interests and those of its shareholders, as well as the terms of a put option that requires Dr. Ong to repurchase shares in the company if his employment is terminated.

site_title: Journalists targeted in attacks as US protests rage
summary: US protests have led to a surge in attacks on journalists, with over two dozen documented incidents of violence against reporters and media crews covering protests nationwide. Attacks on CNN's Omar Jimenez and Kaitlin Rust, and Reuters' Julio-Cesar Chavez, were among the incidents. Media experts say the attacks are a violation of the First Amendment and come amid anti-media rhetoric from US President Donald Trump. The incidents have sparked condemnation from media organizations and politicians, with some calling for greater action to protect journalists.

site_title: Hedge fund in Sweden trounces return target with rare AI model
summary: A Swedish hedge fund, Volt Capital Management, has exceeded its 10% return target by 24% for the year, thanks to its unique AI model. The fund, with $30 million under management, used machine learning to position for market fluctuations, including a positive return of 12% in March amidst the COVID-19 pandemic. Fund manager Patrik Safvenblad attributes the success to combining fundamental models with machine learning, which helped navigate economic weakness and volatility.

site_title: Twitter attaches disclaimer to Trump tweet for 'glorifying violence'
summary: Twitter has attached a disclaimer to President Donald Trump's tweet for "glorifying violence" after he stated that looters at protests in Minneapolis would be shot. The tweet, made during a time of racially charged civil unrest, was deemed to break Twitter's rules, but the platform has determined it may be in the public's interest to leave it accessible. This move escalates a feud between Trump and tech companies, following an executive order signed by Trump threatening Silicon Valley social media firms with new regulations over free speech.

site_title: Tensions at the mouth of the dragon
summary: Hong Kong's new security law has sparked concerns about its status as a financial and business hub. Experts warn that the law's impact will be long-term, with increased volatility and potential talent drain. While some see the law as a stabilizing measure, others believe it erodes trust and may lead to a decline in Hong Kong's status. The US has declared Hong Kong no longer autonomous, and investors are considering alternatives like Singapore. The city's unique position at the mouth of China's economy makes it a crucial hub, but its future is uncertain amidst rising tensions between China and the West.

site_title: Oxley on track with sales targets for its Singapore projects
summary: Oxley Holdings has achieved its sales targets for residential projects in Singapore, with 73% of its development portfolio sold as of April 30. The company expects S$1.4 billion of secured revenue from Singapore projects and S$819 million from overseas projects. Oxley is on track to redeem its S$150 million worth of bonds due on May 18, 2020, and its flagship project Royal Wharf in London has sold over 95% of its 3,380 residential apartments. Construction of The Peak project in Phnom Penh is progressing, with 85% of units sold.

site_title: Hurricanes may cause more pain for pandemic-hit insurers
summary: Hurricanes may cause significant losses for insurers and reinsurers, already struggling with the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic. The Atlantic hurricane season is forecast to be above average, with 13-19 named storms and 6-10 potential hurricanes. This could lead to a 50% increase in property rates, providing an income boost for insurers. Reinsurance rates in Florida could rise 25-45% due to increased flood damage and building costs. Insurers face $100 billion in investment losses, and the pandemic may exacerbate hurricane losses, particularly in vulnerable areas like the Bahamas.

site_title: Jetstar Asia extends suspension of scheduled services until May 31
summary: Jetstar Asia extends suspension of scheduled services until May 31, following Singapore's circuit breaker extension to June 1. The airline will offer refunds to passengers with existing bookings from May 19-31 in the form of travel credit vouchers. Temporary network services from Singapore to Manila, Bangkok, and Kuala Lumpur will operate until September, mainly for citizens and residents returning home or with written approval for travel.

site_title: HDB: May BTO exercise to be combined with August launch
summary: The Housing and Development Board (HDB) in Singapore has announced that the May Build-to-Order (BTO) exercise will be combined with the August launch, offering approximately 7,800 flats. Some BTO projects are expected to be delayed by up to six months due to the circuit breaker period. HDB has resumed some critical services, including flat booking and key collection, starting June 2, and will schedule appointments for other services from June 8. Buyers will be informed of revised probable completion dates through their My HDBPage account.

site_title: ComfortDelGro to halve taxi rents for June
summary: ComfortDelGro Taxi in Singapore will halve taxi rents for June as the country starts Phase One of its reopening plan. The rental waivers will range from S$45 to S$86, but this move is expected to push the taxi operator into the red. The company had previously warned of an S$80 million daily rental relief set aside until September 30, which would result in full-year losses. The move aims to boost driver income by securing more delivery jobs through its platform, which will continue until the end of September.

site_title: US firms in Hong Kong awake to 'sad day' as Trump vows to curb economic ties
summary: US President Donald Trump announced plans to revoke Hong Kong's preferential treatment as a separate customs and travel territory from China, citing Beijing's proposed national security legislation as a breach of Hong Kong's autonomy. This move is seen as a significant blow to Hong Kong's economy and global financial centre status. The American Chamber of Commerce in Hong Kong described it as a "sad day" for the city. Washington has also vowed to impose sanctions on individuals seen as responsible for suppressing Hong Kong's freedom.

site_title: Technology's role in Covid-19 battle
summary: IBM's Open P-Tech platform provides free digital learning training in AI and cybersecurity to students aged 14-20 in 80 countries, including Singapore, where it was launched in May. The platform aims to equip young people with skills relevant to the digital era. American Express staff volunteer through its Serve2Gether colleague network, providing skills to non-profit organizations. LinkedIn's Coaches program empowers job seekers to grow their careers through career conversations and LinkedIn platform training. These initiatives aim to support the community during the Covid-19 pandemic and promote digital transformation.

site_title: ECB expected to pump up eurozone support as pandemic persists
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) is expected to announce hundreds of billions of euros in new bond-buying to combat the pandemic crisis, with analysts predicting an additional 500 billion euros to the existing Pandemic Emergency Purchase Programme (PEPP). The decision comes amid EU governments' struggles to agree on a joint response and a German Constitutional Court ruling limiting the ECB's powers. The ECB's actions may also be influenced by the upcoming release of June's quarterly growth and inflation forecasts, which are expected to show a strong contraction in the eurozone economy in 2020.

images.alt_text: The European Central Bank could announce Thursday hundreds of billions of euros in new bond-buying to keep fighting the pandemic crisis, analysts predict, as EU governments prepare to wrangle for months over a joint response.

site_title: Private equity - even better in bad years
summary: Private equity has consistently outperformed traditional asset-class returns, particularly during economic downturns. Historical data shows that PE has generated strong returns in recessions, with some studies suggesting it can act as an economic stabilizer. PE firms are better prepared today to capitalize on opportunities in distressed sectors, such as travel and retail, and sectors benefiting from shifting consumer preferences. Experts recommend a 10-15% allocation to PE in high-net-worth portfolios for diversification and attractive risk-adjusted returns.

site_title: STI slips 4.24 points to close at 2,515.24 on mixed trading
summary: The Singapore market ended Thursday at 2,515.24, down 4.24 points or 0.17%, with Singtel and ComfortDelGro among the worst-performing index components. Singtel reported a 25.7% drop in earnings, while ComfortDelGro said it would halve its taxi rents for June. In contrast, CapitaLand Mall Trust, CapitaLand Commercial Trust, and Jardine Strategic Holdings posted gains of about 2.5%. Rubber suppliers, including Sri Trang Agro Industry and Halcyon Agri, also bounced, with gains of 18.8% and 15.2%, respectively.

site_title: Beyond the 3 Rs: How can Singapore move forward on sustainability?
summary: Singapore faces a challenge in moving forward on sustainability as the country seeks to balance individual actions with systemic change. Despite efforts by environmental groups and government initiatives, the nation still struggles with issues such as excessive packaging and waste generation. Experts argue that while individual actions are important, they are not enough to address the crisis, and systemic change is necessary to effect meaningful change. The government has shown willingness to engage with the public and NGOs, but progress is hindered by constraints such as market forces and economic considerations. A united and collaborative approach among sustainability groups and the government is seen as key to overcoming these challenges.

site_title: Fortitude Budget: S$33 billion package to support firms, save and create jobs
summary: Singapore's Deputy Prime Minister and Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat presented a S$33 billion Fortitude Budget to support firms, save jobs, and create opportunities for workers amid the Covid-19 crisis. The budget includes wage support for firms, foreign work levy waivers, rental waivers, and targeted support for sectors like aviation and tourism. The government also allocates over S$500 million to encourage digital transformation and provides additional support for households and social services. The total government support in the Covid-19 crisis has risen to S$92.9 billion, or almost a fifth of GDP.

site_title: Six steps to post-Covid planning
summary: Singapore's post-Covid future is uncertain, with the Monetary Authority predicting a 4-7% GDP shrinkage this year. To mitigate the situation, companies can take six steps: empower remote workforces, engage customers virtually, provide remote access to everything, accelerate agility and efficiency, protect against new cyber security risks, and reduce operational costs and enhance supply chain continuity. These measures can help companies adapt to the crisis and prepare for a future with digital technologies.

site_title: US states, cities cry out for federal aid amid pandemic
summary: The US states and cities are crying out for federal aid amid the COVID-19 pandemic, citing a draining of public finances and a slower recovery. Governors like Andrew Cuomo and Gavin Newsom warn that without help, states will have to slash spending, raise taxes, or cut services, leading to lasting consequences. Experts estimate that over three million public jobs could be lost, and the national GDP could be slashed by two percentage points. The National Governors Association is calling for $500 billion in aid, but the request has become a political issue ahead of the presidential election.

site_title: Warner Music launches its IPO
summary: Warner Music Group is set to launch an initial public offering (IPO) valuing the company at up to $13.3 billion, with 70 million shares to be floated at $23-$26 per share. The listing on Nasdaq marks a turnaround in the music business, driven by the rise of streaming services, which now account for nearly 80% of US retail sales revenue. The company's revenue has grown from $3 billion in 2015 to $4.5 billion in its last fiscal year, reflecting the shift in the industry.

site_title: Is it time to rethink Singapore Savings Bonds programme?
summary: Singapore's savings bonds, introduced five years ago, now offer record-low interest rates, with a 0.57% first-year rate and 1.05% average return over 10 years. This is lower than 12-month fixed deposits at some financial institutions and even the average return for long-term SSBs. With a risk-off environment and central banks slashing interest rates, the SSBs' unattractive rates may prompt a rethink of the program, which has seen declining interest and high redemption rates. The government initially committed to maintaining the program for five years, but now faces a strong case for reassessment.

site_title: Citi Singapore to return wage support funding to the government
summary: Citi Singapore will return its Jobs Support Scheme (JSS) funding, worth tens of millions, to the Singapore government. The funding, intended to support local employees during the COVID-19 pandemic, will be returned by the company's Singapore CEO, Amol Gupte. This move aims to signal that companies like Citi are committed to the well-being of the community, with over 80% of its 8,500 employees being Singapore citizens or permanent residents.

site_title: 344 new coronavirus cases in Singapore; 4 Singaporeans and PRs
summary: Singapore reported 344 new COVID-19 cases, bringing the total to 31,960. Among the new cases, 4 Singaporeans and permanent residents were confirmed. The majority of cases were migrant workers in dormitories. The rate of discharge from hospitals increased, with 14,867 patients (47%) fully recovered. There are currently 16,717 active cases, with 8 in intensive care.

site_title: 'Real Lords of the Flies' shipwreck to become Hollywood movie
summary: A Hollywood movie based on the true story of six Tongan teenagers who survived 15 months on a remote island after being shipwrecked in the 1960s has been announced. The film, titled "The Real Lord of the Flies," will be produced by New Regency and will prioritize cultural authenticity, with local crew and consultants involved. The survivors, Sione, Luke, Mano, Tevita, Fatai, and Kolo, will share the proceeds of the film, which is expected to be a low seven-figure deal, amidst competing bids from Netflix and MGM.

site_title: Britain's fat dividends face biggest slimdown in Europe
summary: British firms are expected to face the biggest decline in dividends in Europe, with payouts shrinking by more than $40 billion, a 35% drop, due to the pandemic. The British Treasury has barred recipients of state-backed loans from future payouts, and nearly 50% of UK Stoxx 600 members have delayed or cancelled dividends. Classic defensive sectors such as food, drink, and healthcare are considered safer picks, while sectors like leisure, transport, and energy are at risk.

site_title: President Halimah Yacob gives in-principle support to tap reserves for fourth Covid-19 support package
summary: Singapore President Halimah Yacob has given in-principle support for the government to tap past reserves for a fourth Covid-19 support package, valued at around S$21 billion. The measure aims to help businesses and individuals affected by the outbreak. The government will announce new measures on Tuesday, focusing on workers and companies that cannot resume activities immediately after the circuit breaker period ends on June 1. The support package will include measures for the social service sector, as Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat announced. The move is seen as necessary to ensure a safe transition to the new normal.

site_title: Aviation's darkest hour
summary: The global aviation industry is facing its "darkest hour" due to the COVID-19 pandemic, with airlines, airports, and aircraft makers under siege. Passenger traffic has plummeted by 99.5% globally, with Asia Pacific carriers bearing the brunt of the losses. IATA projects a 55% decline in passenger revenues and a $314 billion loss for the industry this year. To stay afloat, airlines are raising funds through rights issues and government support, with Singapore Airlines securing a critical lifeline from majority shareholder Temasek. The industry is expected to need $200 billion in government support to ride out the crisis, with many airlines facing bankruptcy or restructuring. The global airline association urges governments to implement financial packages and collaborate on a plan to restart operations as borders re-open.

site_title: Airlines caught unawares as India allows local flights to resume
summary: India has allowed domestic flights to resume on May 25, catching airlines off guard. Top executives at three Indian airlines learned of the decision through a tweet from the aviation minister, with most airlines having suspended ticket sales until June 1. The move contradicts India's rapid spread of coronavirus infections, which are the fastest in Asia. The decision is seen as a surprise, leaving many airlines puzzled and uncertain about the future of their operations.

site_title: Pushing the envelope
summary: Singapore Post's CEO Vincent Phang is pushing the envelope to adapt to the disruption caused by e-commerce, which has largely changed the way consumers shop. The postal service provider is exploring new technologies, such as smart stamps and letterboxes, to improve delivery efficiency and reduce lost mail. Phang believes that the existing infrastructure can be re-engineered to handle e-commerce products, and the company is investing heavily in the customer experience journey. SingPost has also been delivering medicine and is exploring partnerships with hospitals and polyclinics, with the goal of becoming a national delivery system. The company aims to capture 50-60% of the domestic e-commerce delivery market and is using its existing network to offer customers a seamless experience.

site_title: China's Great Wall Motor expects mild domestic auto sales growth in H2
summary: Great Wall Motor expects China's auto sales to return to pre-pandemic levels in the second half of 2020, with a focus on electric models and increasing market share. The company plans to invest heavily in electrification and intelligent vehicle technologies, with a goal of starting to sell hydrogen fuel-cell passenger cars in 2023. Great Wall aims to expand its presence in international markets, including India, Thailand, Australia, and South America, and will localize production of core car parts to manage supply chains.

site_title: 'Confinement' food takes on a new meaning
summary: During the COVID-19 pandemic, people have turned to high-end food and premium ingredients, boosting businesses of food suppliers and wet market vendors. This trend, known as "CB Belly," is driven by social media and islandwide delivery, allowing consumers to access luxury food items. Meanwhile, restaurateur Liling Ong plans to open new Italian eateries despite the pandemic's impact on the industry. The article also highlights virtual tours of design museums and ways to stay calm and focused during the pandemic, including meditation and arts and culture.

site_title: Britain's M&S to accelerate change as profit falls 21%
summary: Britain's Marks & Spencer (M&S) is accelerating its turnaround programme as it deals with the fallout from the coronavirus crisis, which saw a 21% fall in annual profit. The retailer will focus on online sales through its partnership with Ocado, improve its food supply chain, and re-engineer its clothing and home business. CEO Steve Rowe aims to deliver a renewed, more agile business in a changed consumer environment, with measures taken to deal with the crisis totaling over £1 billion. The retailer expects the impact of the crisis to last through the 2020-21 year.

site_title: Ho Bee Land sets up S$1.3m Covid-19 fund to help smaller charities, social enterprises
summary: Ho Bee Land sets up a S$1.3 million Covid-19 support fund to help smaller charities and social enterprises affected by the pandemic. The company has pledged S$1 million and an additional S$300,000 from its board and senior management. The funds will be channeled through the Ho Bee Foundation to support beneficiaries' funding gaps and enable them to continue working amid the crisis.

site_title: Government calls allegations of profiteering against Surbana Jurong 'false and malicious'
summary: The Singapore government has denied allegations of profiteering against Surbana Jurong (SJ) in the development of a community-care facility at the Singapore Expo Convention and Exhibition Centre. The government claims that SJ worked on a cost-recovery basis and charged below normal costs, with no management fees. The development was undertaken at short notice due to the COVID-19 pandemic, and the government accepted that legitimate questions can be raised about the spending. The government has responded firmly to scurrilous allegations of corruption, stating that it will provide explanations for the spending.

site_title: PropertyGuru grew sales 24% while gauging IPO window
summary: PropertyGuru, a South-east Asian online real estate leader, reported a 24% revenue growth in 2019 to S$88.4 million, surpassing its forecast of S$85.6 million. The company, which pulled its IPO plans in 2019, attributed the growth to surging wealth in the region. Operating free cash flow rose to S$14.2 million, and the company has introduced new virtual viewing features to serve customers during the COVID-19 pandemic. It is unclear when the firm might attempt to list again due to economic uncertainty.

site_title: Sustainable strategies outperform in Q1, BlackRock research finds
summary: BlackRock research finds that sustainable funds and companies outperformed in the first quarter, driven by strong risk-adjusted performance and resilient properties. Sustainable open-ended funds and ETFs attracted $40.5 billion in new assets, a 41% rise year-over-year. BlackRock's CEO Larry Fink aims to make sustainable investing the new standard, citing climate change as a long-term structural crisis. The firm's research also shows a correlation between sustainability and traditional factors such as quality and low volatility, with 51 out of 57 sustainable indices outperforming broad market counterparts.

site_title: Money FM podcast: Investor conferences - bypassing intermediaries
summary: Money FM podcast "Prime Time with Howie Lim" discussed investor conferences and bypassing traditional intermediaries. Raghav Kapoor, CEO of Smartkarma, shared insights on the current state of investor conferences, highlighting the need for investors to directly engage with companies. This could lead to more efficient and cost-effective investment strategies, allowing investors to gain access to companies without intermediaries. The conversation emphasized the potential benefits of direct investment, but also noted the challenges and risks involved.

site_title: Market temperature indicators suggest fixed income investors should look to Asia for opportunities
summary: Investors are shifting their focus to Asia for fixed-income opportunities due to divergent market sentiment and valuations. Despite the US economy's strong rebound, Asian bonds offer more scope for downside scenarios, with credit spreads significantly wider than those in the US. Issuance volumes in Asia have fallen, while the US corporate debt market has seen record issuance. Investors are taking a more defensive stance in US bonds, while being more aggressive in Asian corporate debt, driven by the region's relatively more contained coronavirus outbreak and lower valuations.

site_title: Bidders are lining up to buy Virgin Australia after collapse
summary: At least 20 bidders are vying to acquire Virgin Australia Holdings, the collapsed airline, with Brookfield Asset Management and Rahul Bhatia's InterGlobe Enterprises among those considering submissions. The airline's administrator, Deloitte, will review indicative bids by Friday, with shortlisted bidders preparing binding offers by June 12. Buyers are drawn to Virgin Australia due to Australia's large and growing domestic market, which could support a low-cost carrier model. However, any attempt to revive the airline as a low-cost carrier may face opposition from the competition watchdog and scrutiny from the Foreign Investment Review Board.

site_title: Tencent revenue rises on online gaming surge during lockdown
summary: Tencent's revenue surged 26% to 108.1 billion yuan during China's Covid-19 lockdown, driven by a 31% increase in online gaming sales. However, the company warns that these gains may fade as China returns to normality and advertising budgets shrink. Tencent's gaming division rode the pandemic spending wave, while its fintech division recovered from a decline in April. Despite the strong Q1 growth, analysts predict a challenging second quarter due to lingering industry and macro headwinds.

site_title: Petrobras looks to China's 'teapots' to keep oil exports flowing
summary: Brazil's state-run Petrobras sees no need for cuts in oil production, citing robust demand in China and rebounding domestic demand for fuel. The company's strong relationship with independent refineries in China's Shandong Province has allowed it to export a record amount of crude despite weak global demand. Petrobras reversed its production cuts in April, surprising many, and expects demand for all products except jet fuel to return to near-normal levels in the third or fourth quarter. The company also plans to reduce its real estate footprint to cut costs.

site_title: Training centre space at Paya Lebar Square up for sale at S$6.1m
summary: A training centre space in Paya Lebar Square, Singapore, has been listed for sale by private treaty at S$6.1 million, equivalent to S$2,276 per square foot. The 2,680 sq ft space, comprising two adjoining units, can be converted to a corporate office with meeting rooms and agile-working spaces. The asking price reflects the space's potential for redevelopment.

site_title: Coronavirus savages US retail sales again in April
summary: US retail sales plummeted 16.4% in April, the largest decline since 1992, as the novel coronavirus pandemic kept Americans at home. This marks the second consecutive month of record declines, with core retail sales falling 15.3% and consumer spending dropping 7.6% in the first quarter. The economic slump is expected to continue, with a possible 40% contraction in the second quarter, and Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell warning of an "extended period" of weak growth.

site_title: Have property cooling measures lost their punch?
summary: Singapore's property cooling measures, implemented to curb speculation and rein in home prices, have lost their potency over the years. The measures have been less effective in moderating the market, with prices rising again after each cooling measure is introduced. Experts attribute this to buyers adapting to the measures and expecting them to become a normal part of the property landscape. Additionally, income and wealth growth among buyers, a desire to hedge against inflation, and the appeal of real estate as a safe and stable asset have contributed to the measures' reduced effectiveness. Despite the ongoing Covid-19 crisis and expected recession, market watchers predict that cooling measures will remain a permanent feature of the Singaporean property market.

site_title: Rocky road ahead for 'sharing economy' platforms amid pandemic
summary: The "sharing economy" is facing significant challenges amid the pandemic, with companies like Uber and Airbnb experiencing declining growth and profitability. Despite predictions of $335 billion in revenue by 2025, the industry is bleeding cash and shedding workers. Consumer behavior is shifting towards greater personal space control, with ride-hailing services and micromobility platforms potentially gaining traction. However, rebuilding trust and overcoming concerns about safety and infection risks may take time. Some segments of the sharing economy, such as corporate jets and high-end black car rides, may emerge stronger, while others, like home-sharing, may face a slower rebound.

site_title: Hedge fund Tradeflow Capital made money amid Singapore commodity turmoil
summary: Tradeflow Capital Management, a Singapore-based hedge fund, has returned a half percentage point to investors in April, marking a steady gain despite commodity turmoil in the region. The fund has returned about 5.5% over the past 12 months, with steady, bond-like returns from financing trade for commodities. Tradeflow skirts the turmoil by not lending directly to buyers, sellers, or trading firms and instead acts as a middle-man in small trade-finance deals, taking ownership of the commodity.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close lower on profit-taking
summary: Tokyo stocks closed lower on profit-taking, with the Nikkei 225 index down 0.12% to 20,366.48, and the Topix index down 0.26% to 1,476.72. Investors are cautious about economic restarts following coronavirus shutdowns. The decline follows recent gains, with investors watching for developments in US-EU trade talks and tariff threats.

site_title: Scientists in China believe new drug can stop pandemic 'without vaccine'
summary: Scientists at Peking University in China have developed a new drug that could potentially stop the COVID-19 pandemic without a vaccine. The drug uses neutralizing antibodies isolated from recovered patients to prevent the virus from infecting cells, reducing viral load by a factor of 2,500 in animal tests. The researchers believe the drug could offer short-term immunity and shorten recovery time, with plans for clinical trials in Australia and other countries. If successful, the drug could be a faster and more efficient way to stop the pandemic, offering a potential "cure" for the disease.

site_title: ST Engineering expects FY2020 revenue to fall 5-15%
summary: ST Engineering expects its FY2020 revenue to fall 5-15% compared to FY2019 due to the COVID-19 pandemic's impact on customer demand, supply chains, and workforce. Despite this, the company has a strong balance sheet, diversified revenue streams, and a robust order book of S$16.3 billion. ST Engineering plans to focus on sustainable long-term growth, capitalizing on new demands in areas like command and control, cybersecurity, and sensors. The company aims to strengthen its core businesses and maintain a strong liquidity position.

site_title: An unexpected consequence of disruptions from Covid-19
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has disrupted the shipping industry, leading to a significant decrease in bunker prices. Heavy fuel oil (IFO 380) prices have dropped to around $200 per tonne, while marine gas oil (MGO) prices have narrowed the gap with blended alternatives, with MGO sometimes selling for less than its alternatives. The IMO's 0.50% sulfur limit regulation, which was a major challenge for the industry, has been overshadowed by the pandemic. Shipowners are reassessing their options, with some considering delaying scrubber installations and others questioning the economic case for blended alternatives.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed higher on Wednesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 17.20 points to 1,397.13. The market saw a higher volume of 9.544 billion lots worth RM5.071 billion. However, losers outnumbered gainers 558 to 395.

site_title: US: Stocks rally despite surge in unemployment, Dow up 1.9%
summary: US stocks rallied on Friday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average rising 1.9% to 24,331.32, despite a surge in unemployment to 14.7%. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index also increased, driven by anticipation of a gradual economic recovery and conciliatory statements from Chinese and US officials. Investors are optimistic that the economy will bottom out in the second quarter and improve in the fourth quarter, with many expecting less bad data in the third quarter.

site_title: Make workers' welfare intrinsic to ESG practices
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has brought workers' welfare to the forefront, particularly in migrant worker dormitories. Companies are being urged to prioritize workers' welfare as part of their environmental, social, and governance (ESG) practices. Over 280 investors with $8.2 trillion in assets under management have called for companies to protect their workforces and communities. Singapore corporates, especially those in construction and property development, are advised to ensure their stakeholders are treated fairly, and to hold accountable those who neglect workers' welfare.

site_title: Landlords will become kingmakers; and local brands could benefit
summary: Singaporean retailers may benefit from landlords' increased support as the country's retail sector navigates the post-COVID-19 era. Landlords are expected to play a crucial role in boosting local brands, with many adopting the gross turnover rental model to collaborate with efficient and profitable tenants. This shift could lead to a more equitable relationship between landlords and tenants, with landlords supporting promising local brands to create unique shopping experiences. As e-commerce continues to grow, having a physical presence in well-managed malls remains essential for retailers, and local brands are expected to benefit from this trend.

images.alt_text: Joan Ng

site_title: New daily high of 958 Covid-19 patients discharged in Singapore
summary: Singapore has reported a new daily high of 958 Covid-19 patients discharged, bringing the total number of recovered patients to 4,800. The country's total cases have reached 25,346, with 675 new cases identified, mostly among migrant workers. The daily average of new cases among Singaporeans, PRs, and long-term pass holders has fallen to six, and the number of unlinked cases has decreased to two.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore retail sales plummeted 13.3% in March, the largest decline since 1998. Ninja Van secured US$279m in Series D funding to focus on delivery solutions in South-east Asia. Singapore experienced its 4th straight record year for tourism arrivals and receipts in 2019. HC Surgical Specialists' surgeon Julian Ong is now required to provide written consent from patients before continuing to act as their physician. UOB extended S$4 billion in loans to mid-sized enterprise clients under the government-assisted loan scheme. The STI gained 0.34% to close at 2,572.36.

site_title: ARA, John Lim's family office make foray into fintech with majority stake in Minterest
summary: ARA Asset Management's family office, JL Family Office, has acquired a 52.08% stake in Singapore-based fintech company Minterest, marking ARA's entry into the fintech sector. The move is part of ARA's wider ambitions in the global real estate credit business, with Minterest providing a crowdfunding channel for real estate financing. The partnership is expected to enhance investors' portfolio diversification and deliver higher risk-adjusted returns, with Minterest launching its inaugural real estate secured mezzanine debt financing product in May.

site_title: Riskiest firms in India struggle to sell debt after fund closure
summary: India's riskiest firms are struggling to sell debt after a fund closure, exacerbating their financial woes amid the pandemic. Local-currency bond issuance fell to a nine-year low in April, with A-plus rated bonds issued at 1.9 billion rupees (S$35 million). The spread on A-rated three-year corporate bonds has surged to a four-month high of 295 basis points, making it difficult for these companies to access capital. The situation highlights the challenges faced by India's weaker companies during the pandemic.

site_title: 605 of the 632 new coronavirus cases in Singapore are foreign workers from dorms; 9 new clusters
summary: Singapore reported 632 new coronavirus cases, with 605 belonging to foreign workers staying in dorms, and 12 in the community. Nine new clusters were announced, and a 44-year-old Bangladeshi national died due to COVID-19 complications. The total number of cases in Singapore is 19,410, with no imported cases. The global outbreak has infected over 3.58 million people and resulted in over 250,000 deaths, with the US being the worst-affected country with over 1.18 million cases and nearly 69,000 deaths.

site_title: Bank group raises questions on debt relief for poorest countries
summary: An international banking association, the Institute for International Finance, has raised concerns about the ability of the poorest countries to join a plan to suspend debt payments. The plan, agreed by the G-20, aims to provide $20 billion in liquidity to 76 vulnerable economies. However, the IIF president, Tim Adams, highlighted challenges, including potential downgrade of debt ratings and impairment of borrowing capacity, due to contractual obligations and fiduciary duties of private creditors. A lengthy, contract-by-contract approach may be required to achieve voluntary participation.

site_title: Money FM podcast: Endowus expands CPF Investment Scheme offerings
summary: Endowus, a Singapore-based investment platform, has expanded its CPF Investment Scheme offerings by partnering with one of the world's largest passive fund managers. This new option allows CPF members to invest in a fund managed by this global fund manager, providing a new diversification opportunity. The partnership aims to cater to the growing demand for diversified investment options in Singapore.

site_title: Raffles Family Office eyes Asia expansion
summary: Raffles Family Office (RFO), a multi-family office and independent asset manager, plans to expand into Asia, with offices in Shanghai, Asean, and Dubai or Australia. Founded in Hong Kong in 2016, RFO has assets under management (AUM) of around US$1.8 billion and aims to double its AUM to US$5 billion by 2021. The firm's CEO, Kwan Chi Man, expects market volatility to create opportunities for growth, particularly for clients with high-net-worth assets.

site_title: Virus pandemic's long-term pain is just becoming clear to markets
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has led to a massive expansion in global debt, with over $8 trillion in fiscal measures worldwide, according to a Bloomberg compilation. This shift in the financial landscape will have long-term implications for corporate earnings, interest rates, and investment decisions, with some analysts warning of "secular stagnation" or stagflation. Governments may need to increase taxes to fund social contracts and state-owned enterprises, while central banks face the challenge of managing debt levels and interest rates.

site_title: E-sports Australia integrity boss eyes corruption threat in online games
summary: Australia's newly appointed sports integrity boss, David Sharpe, is addressing the threat of betting-related corruption in e-sports. Police have charged five men for match-fixing in online gaming in Melbourne, and Sharpe plans to work with the e-sports industry to combat this issue. He notes the potential threat of organised crime and global intelligence will be used to address these risks, following a surge in global interest in e-sports during the coronavirus pandemic.

site_title: Bangkok's street food hub of Chinatown comes alive as lockdown eases
summary: Thailand has relaxed some lockdown rules in Bangkok's Chinatown, allowing food stalls and restaurants outside shopping malls to reopen and shops to sell alcohol for drinking at home. The move comes as the country's daily tally of new cases has fallen to single digits for the past week. Under the relaxed rules, customers are allowed to eat in again while observing social distancing, and outdoor markets and small shops can reopen. However, a nighttime curfew will remain in place until the end of the month, limiting the return of Bangkok's nightlife.

site_title: President's 'So what?' as 5,000 die sparks fury in Brazil
summary: Brazilian President Jair Bolsonaro sparked outrage after saying "so what" in response to the country's 5,000th coronavirus death, with many governors, politicians, and healthcare professionals criticizing his lack of empathy. The country is facing a severe outbreak, with over 91,000 confirmed cases and a death toll that threatens to surpass predictions. Bolsonaro's remarks have drawn comparisons to US President Donald Trump, and his leadership style has been criticized for being insensitive and unempathetic.

site_title: South Africa's Imperial Logistics to sell European shipping business
summary: Imperial Logistics, a South African ground freight firm, plans to sell its European shipping business to Häfen und Güterverkehr Köln AG for 225 million euros. The move is part of a broader restructuring plan to focus on growing its African footprint and reduce debt. The shipping business, which employs 910 staff and operates in Europe and South America, will continue to serve South America on a stand-alone basis. The sale proceeds will be used to optimize Imperial's financial position and reduce debt.

site_title: Thai central bank worried about strong baht, ready to use necessary measures
summary: Thailand's central bank is concerned about the rapid rise of the baht, which may be out of line with the country's fragile economic conditions. The bank is prepared to take necessary measures to prevent the baht's strength from exacerbating economic fragility. This comes as the coronavirus outbreak continues to impact the economy.

site_title: What's Up This Week
summary:
Here's a 100-word summary of the article:

Several businesses are offering special deals during the Circuit Breaker period. Mandarin Orchard is offering discounts on its Chatterbox chicken rice and Shisen Hanten's Michelin-starred dishes when ordering for delivery or takeaway. 28 HongKong Street's 28HKS House Party allows groups to enjoy a cocktail and snacks at home, while Queen re-recorded a lockdown version of "We Are the Champions" to support frontline workers. HBO Asia's new Taiwanese original series "Workers" premieres on May 10, and The Fullerton Hotel Singapore's Jade Restaurant offers takeaways and home delivery of Cantonese favorites. Firebake is also offering Mother's Day pies for delivery.

site_title: Worst seen over for HK home prices: report
summary: Hong Kong's residential real estate market is expected to see a rebound, with home prices rising up to 10% by the end of the year, according to Citigroup. The worst is likely over for the market, driven by a decrease in coronavirus cases and a shortage of suitable land. Property prices in the secondary market have declined just 1.3% since the start of the year, despite the Covid-19 outbreak and pro-democracy protests. Developers such as Sun Hung Kai Properties and New World Development are seen as attractive, with landlords Hang Lung Properties and Wharf Real Estate Investment also expected to perform well.

site_title: Lights out for struggling startups
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has exposed the harsh realities of working for a startup, with many employees bearing the bulk of the strain. According to a global survey, 74% of startups saw their revenues decline since the virus outbreak, with up to 16% experiencing a sharp drop of over 80%. Startups are forced to cut payroll, slash marketing budgets, and negotiate extended payment terms to ride out the storm. Many employees, including those who were hired to fill growth roles, are being let go or put on unpaid leave. The pandemic is also highlighting the cons of working in the startup industry, including burnout and a lack of work-life balance.

site_title: Covid-19: 876 new coronavirus cases in Singapore, 3 are Singaporeans and PRs
summary: Singapore reported 876 new Covid-19 cases, bringing the total count to 23,336. The majority of new cases are work permit holders in foreign worker dormitories, with 3 of them being Singaporeans and PRs. The country has seen a spike in cases, with the number of local cases declining and the number of unlinked cases also decreasing. Singapore now has the highest number of confirmed cases in South-east Asia, with 20 reported deaths.

site_title: OCBC expects credit costs from Covid-19 impact to be higher than during GFC
summary: OCBC Bank expects higher credit costs due to the Covid-19 pandemic, with cumulative costs predicted to be between 100-130 basis points over the next two years, surpassing the 110 basis points experienced during the 2008-2009 global financial crisis. The bank's net profit fell 43% to S$698 million in Q1, driven by non-operating losses and provisions for oil-and-gas exposure. OCBC's CEO, Samuel Tsien, expects a strong recovery unlikely until 2021 and plans to extend moratorium relief and government-assisted loans to over 165,000 individuals and businesses.

images.alt_text: OCBC's chief financial officer Darren Tan says that there will be no change to the bank's dividend policy.

site_title: Italian rice puts pasta in the shade during pandemic
summary: Italian rice production has seen a significant rise in consumption during the coronavirus pandemic, outstripping pasta demand in some cases. China has signed a deal to import Italian rice, particularly varieties used for risotto dishes, due to its perceived higher quality. Italian rice production totals 1.5 million tonnes annually, with the country boasting over 200 varieties. The pandemic has led to increased consumption of rice and risotto, with sales soaring 47% in the first six weeks of the pandemic.

images.alt_text: EUROPE'S top rice producer Italy has seen consumption of the staple rise throughout the coronavirus pandemic, putting even pasta in the shade.

site_title: Emerging Stronger Taskforce names 15 business leaders as members
summary: A government-led task force, Emerging Stronger Taskforce (EST), has appointed 15 business leaders to guide Singapore's economic growth beyond the pandemic. The task force, co-chaired by Desmond Lee and Tan Chong Meng, will assess the impact of the Covid-19 outbreak on the Singapore economy and provide recommendations on how to refresh economic strategies. The task force will focus on identifying systemic shifts and opportunities for growth, with preliminary recommendations to be shared by early next year.

images.alt_text: A government-led task force set up to guide Singapore's economic growth beyond the pandemic, appointed 15 business leaders as members during its inaugural video conference meeting on Wednesday, where it also defined its areas of focus.

site_title: Making the cut
summary: Singapore's bespoke tailors face challenges due to the city-state's hot climate, which favors casual wear over formal attire. Despite rising demand for custom-made clothing, orders have dropped by more than half for some tailors due to the COVID-19 pandemic. New generations of tailors are emerging, but their shops often lack visibility and struggle to compete with fast fashion. Despite this, many tailors remain committed to their craft, citing personal satisfaction and the potential for growth. Experts predict that custom-tailored clothing will continue to be in demand, driven by the need for tailored clothing to fit individual body shapes.

images.alt_text: MAKING THE CUT: Singapore's next-generation tailors, whose niche business had grown in a recently revived trade, now face fresh threats.
"We're a small operation and the service we offer is very personal. It's strictly by appointment," says Dylan Chong of Dylan & Son.
"We see custom-made tailoring making a comeback," says Tulsi Kamath of Perfect Attire. "People are again going to tailors."
"Here (in Singapore) we have a dress-down work culture. Our men don't wear a suit to work. It's the weather, which is our main problem," says Kevin Seah of Kevin Seah Bespoke.
"There'll always be a need for tailored clothing because there are many different body shapes which can't fit into standard size clothing," says Fong Loo Fern of CYC.
"Tailoring is not a lucrative business, but it still provides enough to put food on the table and a bit of fun," says Matthew Lai of KayJen Dylan.
Thomas Wong at The Prestigious with his trainees and staff. "I want to train a new generation of tailors and breathe life into the industry," the master tailor says.

site_title: Reopenings mark a new phase: Global 'trial-and-error' played out in lives
summary: The world is entering a period of high-stakes experimentation as cities and countries reopen amid the coronavirus pandemic, serving as guinea pigs for how to safely and effectively reopen. Governments are pushing ahead with policies built on a growing but imperfect understanding of the virus, with little consensus on balancing public health against social and economic needs. Each policy is a trial of what works, what's worthwhile, and what people will accept, with many questions remaining unanswered for the duration of the crisis, including the value of a life saved.

images.alt_text: Commuters arrive in Milan after lockdown restrictions were eased. The first wave of reopenings in Asia and Europe, are providing a preview of what could become a continual process of experimentation and recalibration.

site_title: SIAEC posts 5.9% rise in Q4 profit; trims final dividend
summary: SIA Engineering Company (SIAEC) reported a 5.9% year-on-year increase in Q4 net profit to S$52.2 million, driven by government support and strengthened operating performance. Revenue fell 10.4% to S$229.3 million, while expenditure decreased 9.1% due to reduced material, staff, and departmental costs. The company trimmed its final dividend to five cents per share from eight cents, citing the need to conserve cash amid the Covid-19 pandemic. Full-year net profit rose 20.4% to S$193.8 million.

site_title: India wilts under heatwave
summary: India is experiencing a severe heatwave, with temperatures reaching 50 degrees Celsius in some areas, including Churu in Rajasthan, and 47.6 degrees Celsius in New Delhi, the hottest May day in nearly two decades. The heatwave is projected to continue for several days, exacerbating existing water shortages and coronavirus concerns. The country is already struggling with a significant number of coronavirus cases and deaths, with over 150,000 cases and 4,500 fatalities reported. The heatwave is the latest challenge for India, which is also dealing with cyclones, floods, and locust infestations.

images.alt_text: India is wilting under a heatwave, with the temperature in places reaching 50 degrees Celsius and the capital enduring its hottest May day in nearly two decades.
